HEADLINE: Cutting Federal Deficit to Zero Is a Good Idea

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your opposition to a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution is well founded (editorial, Nov. 14), but your declaration that "there is no compelling reason" to shrink the deficit to zero -- that is, to balance the budget -- misses an important point and appears to rest on a dubious premise. 
 The case for spending no more than the sum of incoming revenues (except in a recession) is clear: by ending annual deficits, the Government would stop adding to its outstanding debt and to the interest it must pay each year. With the debt stabilized, or even reduced gradually, a larger share of future revenues would be available for more useful spending.
You worry that eliminating the deficit will lead to the cutting of "expensive items first," the "public investments on which the future health of the economy depends," while nickel-and-dime appropriations to please scattered special interests -- "pork," in the vernacular -- will survive. The line-item veto just signed into law is supposed to enable the President to winnow out the pork. Its effectiveness will depend on the President.
As for your assumption that Congress would eliminate those public investments that contribute most to economic vitality, I know of no basis for it. The debate of 1995-96 shows that both parties believe that what most needs paring is spending for entitlements, especially benefits that go to those above the poverty line, whether for health care or old-age income. Of course, there are differences of degree and detail, but this is where the biggest savings are needed and will occur, if the President and the Congressional leadership decide to forge a compromise.
Medicare and Social Security are not "investments" that are determinative of the country's economic health.
 
EDWARD COWAN
Washington, Nov. 14, 1996
The writer is an economic policy analyst.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: U.S. Publications Focusing on Africa Fade

BYLINE: By GREGORY JORDAN 

 BODY:
Crises in Africa, like the current troubles in Zaire and Rwanda, are one of the few guaranteed ways the continent draws media attention, as representatives of relief agencies, governments and sometimes international military forces descend and try to cope with the situation.
For in-depth coverage, people interested in African developments have mostly been dependent on smaller, African-focused publications that routinely analyzed more positive issues like the growing trade between the United States and the Southern African Development Community, the rise of Uganda's economy or the rehabilitation of Mali's democracy. 
 Today, however, the three definitive American sources for African news and analysis in print -- Africa Report, Africa News Service and Africa Notes -- are defunct, or about to be. While Africa News Service has been reincarnated on the Internet's World Wide Web and detailed coverage of Africa continues in publications like Foreign Affairs, the specialty press in this area has all but disappeared.
In contrast, other former cold war hot spots like Southeast Asia and Eastern Europe are spawning numerous American magazines and newsletters focused on their churning economies and shifting politics.
African-focused publications have always existed on the financial fringe. When it closed in 1995, Africa Report, the most financially solvent of the three that focused on Africa, had an annual budget of $240,000. Circulation, once as high as 15,000, had dropped to 5,700 by 1995. The $30 subscriptions did not bring in enough to make the venture worthwhile for the African-American Institute, which put out the magazine.
Africa Notes, a publication of the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies, has a circulation of about 1,000 -- including corporate executives, diplomats and scholars. The December issue will be its final publication.
Africa specialists like Helen Kitchen, who was the first editor of Africa Report in 1960 and founded Africa Notes in 1982, are baffled that the growing cultural and economic links between the United States and African countries are not supporting an African-focused cottage industry within the American news media.
"I have always believed in Africa as a cup that is half full and not half empty, and I have always believed that there is a wide American audience that wants detailed information on African events," Ms. Kitchen said. "There is massive potential in Africa, economic and otherwise. And there has been growing reportage in Britain and France in recent months. But American coverage just keeps dwindling."
The simple explanation for their demise is that these publications -- which, along with their sponsors, have failed to develop strict financial management skills -- simply lack a readership substantial enough to sustain them.
Still, Africa Notes and its kin serve a relatively small but highly influential cadre of policy makers, investors and corporations, nongovernment organizations and African immigrants -- all of whom are alarmed by the gap left by the publications' demise.
The last editor of Africa Report, Margaret Novicki, emphasized that the magazine was never out to make a profit. "We had a financial backer," she said, referring to the African-American Institute. "When that backer ran into financial problems, so did we."
Ms. Novicki also said: "There is definitely an audience out there of both influential people and your average reader who just wants to learn more about Africa. The problem is that advertisers don't see specialized magazines as a good market for their advertising dollars."
Steve McDonald, the executive vice president of the African-American Institute in New York, recognized the breadth of the powerful and committed readers that Africa Report served.
But Mr. McDonald pointed to the success of British and French magazines that are focused solely on African economics, trade and investment.
"They're specifically targeted and they are doing quite well," he said. "We had economic reporting from time to time, but we were all basically focused on general analysis. That's where we fell afoul in being able to draw a larger readership."
The inability of African-focused publications to sustain themselves without outside help suggests to many that the notion of a broad American readership is illusory.
But Michael Clough, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, which publishes Foreign Affairs, argued that it is an absence of cooperation, not of readers, that is killing the publications.
"The problem with these magazines is the problem with African-oriented institutions in general -- the different groups are unable to come together and say, 'We need one magazine and let's rally behind it instead of everyone trying to do their own thing,' " Mr. Clough said. "Africa Report in its early years served that role because at that point the Africanist community wasn't as fragmented as it is today."
Dave Miller was a reader of all three publications in his role as associate director at the Corporate Council on Africa, a group that advises 105 American companies engaged in trade and investment with African countries. He believes there is an audience eager for African news and analysis.
"The United States has a combined two-way trade with African countries that is greater than our trade with all of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union combined," Mr. Miller said. "Sure, the trade is resource heavy. But we have no magazines, trade or otherwise, that track this stuff for investors. That's just absurd. Someone will need to fill the void."
And Mike Kiernan, communications director for Interaction, an umbrella group of 150 American nongovernmental organizations, said that such regionally focused news providers were "very essential" to his community.
"The long-term solutions to crises like Zaire are being written and reported in these smaller publications," Mr. Kiernan said. "Without them, that dialogue disappears."
Trying to surmount disunity and indifference, Reed Kramer and Tami Hultman, a husband-wife team in Durham, N.C., who founded Africa News Service 33 years ago and closed the print version in 1993, have resurrected their publication on line (http://www.africanews.org).
As a regionally specific news provider, Africa News Service subcontracts to native African news organizations and reporters. The results of their efforts, Mr. Kramer said, are far more positive than anything Africa News Service experienced during its 30 years of print circulation: underwriters like Essence Magazine and Centura Money Managers advertise on the site, and hits to the home page, although at best a very rough indicator of readership, exceed 100,000 a week.
"From what we can tell from our statistics and research, one-fifth to one-fourth of our users are from the business world, another 25 percent are from overseas," Mr. Kramer said.
"This is more than just a web site," he added. "It's an electronic network. Africa News Service was not set up as a publisher but as a provider. We weren't as specialized as some people wanted us to be, but on line they can focus as they wish."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Refugees streamed out of a camp in Zaire last week, heading home to Rwanda. The trek attracted worldwide coverage, but the number of publications in the United States focusing on Africa is still dwindling. (Associated Press); While British and French magazines focusing on African trade and economics have succeeded, such American offerings as Africa Report and Africa Notes are disappearing; Africa News is available only on line.

HEADLINE: Essay;
With an All-New Cast

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
O.K., so I won by eight points, and all those polls showing an 18-point spread right up through the final weekend were wrong. It's a lucky thing the Republicans never knew they were in single-digit range, and the media were misled by those polls into thinking it was no real horse race.
Now let's make a Cabinet. Has to be congenial, to be easy to confirm, good on television, loyal to me when the crunch comes. 
 Colin Powell would be right down the alley for Secretary of State, which I offered him once before, and he's now a Republican to boot. But Al Gore worries that making Powell the foreign policy superstar would build up a rival for the 2000 campaign. Same with Sam Nunn; can't set him up for a primary run.
George Mitchell? He was last week's sure thing, and I owe him for falling on his sword in the health-care fiasco. But Mitchell is the one authentic liberal who has a chance of getting Senate confirmation if I nominate him to the Supreme Court. Maybe save that card.
Richard Holbrooke, the Bosnia headknocker? Tony Lake would go through the White House basement roof, and even if I moved Tony from national security adviser to C.I.A., the two bureaucratic enemies would be leaking at each other.
My favorite, of course, is Strobe Talbott, and it would be nice to move the Deputy to the top job. Probably could have done that if Jesse Helms had not been re-elected, but Strobe knows he would never get past Senate Foreign Relations now. That's why he's writing articles for Time magazine already. I'll enjoy his book a lot more than Dick Morris's, which could be trouble.
I suppose I could go with Madeleine Albright, though she has that hawkish streak. Really need to pay off the single women. (Married women split evenly, and I got over two out of three of the unmarrieds.) Madeleine would be good if Janet Reno gets my heave-ho hint and heads back to Florida so Hillary can move Jamie Gorelick up to Attorney General. We can trust Jamie to stop asking the courts for special prosecutors -- why did I ever sign that law in the first place? I'll veto any extension when it lapses, but that may be too late. Save Al a lot of trouble, though.
I could put Jamie across the river at C.I.A. First woman Director of Central Intelligence would take a little of the heat off our spooks. Poor John Deutch thought he'd ease the tension with the blacks on that drug-dealing nonsense by holding a town meeting, but they just didn't feel his pain.
I promised Secretary of Defense to Deutch if he'd fix up the C.I.A. for me, and now that bill has come due. But the trouble with John is that he's the smartest guy in the room and is driven to make sure everybody knows it. Bill Perry thinks I would need a Tom Pickering or some other diplomatic type to be Deutch's Deputy, to smooth ruffled feathers at the Joint Chiefs and to reassure the Secretary of State.
Appoint Bill Cohen at the Pentagon as my Republican? If I do, he'd be the only published poet and novelist in that job. But Cohen went up against Nixon during Watergate; I need loyalists. (Reminds me -- got to find a Cabinet slot for Harold Ickes, Labor or Interior, before he kills me with the libs. He knows too much to let be sore.) And no wonder Mickey Kantor bailed out of Commerce -- that'll be the hot seat for investigation into what Bruce Lindsey did for John Huang.
Maybe Tommy Thompson, G.O.P. Governor of Wisconsin, to run welfare. Loved the way he stabbed Dole in the back. Or Jack Kemp, who's big on empowerment -- Al doesn't worry about him. But they tell me Jack rolls his eyes a lot at Cabinet meetings and argues with Treasury.
Can't replace Bob Rubin at Treasury. He's got to keep Alan Greenspan at the Fed to keep me out of a recession for at least another couple of years, past the '98 elections. Then Bob can run for Governor of New York while Charlie Schumer runs against Al D'Amato, and I'll bring Laura Tyson back from California to run Treasury. I all but caved on the Republicans' balanced budget amendment -- what would it cost me? -- until Rubin jerked me back. He's the only one I'll let make me look foolish in public.
What I'd really like in my new Cabinet is a fresh face with universal appeal. Maybe a single Asian-American Republican moderate woman.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Credit Offerings During the Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two- and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.
According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.99 percent and the rate on the six-month issue, 5.04 percent. In when-issued trading the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.66 percent, and the five-year note, 5.95 percent.

HEADLINE: Japan Aims to Regain Semiconductor Leadership

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Japan's Government and semiconductor manufacturers are starting a series of consortiums and cooperative research programs on a scale not seen since the project two decades ago that catapulted this nation into the front ranks of the world's computer chip producers.
The companies and the Government will spend between $500 million and $1 billion over the next five years to develop advanced technology and to improve the competitiveness of the Japanese industry, which has been hurt as South Korean companies have encroached on their markets and the American industry has revived. 
 The new programs "are a conscious attempt to wrest technological leadership in manufacturing away from foreigners," said Kenneth Flamm, a Brookings Institution economist and author of a recent book about international semiconductor competition. He estimates spending on the new programs will reach about $190 million a year.
Some experts say the effort could signal a renaissance in Government-industry collaboration in Japan.
While Japan has long been known for that approach to industrial development, the practice had faded somewhat in the high technology industry, as Japan's electronics companies became big enough to do research by themselves and had caught up to Western competitors.
But now Japan once again sees itself playing catch-up in areas like software and telecommunications at a time when corporate research budgets are crimped by an economic slump. So the Government has stepped in, increasing its spending on research and development.
"There is a more widespread feeling among Japanese industry that the Government has to do something," said John P. Stern, senior vice president of the Asian Technology Information Program, a nonprofit technology monitoring organization based in Tokyo that published a report by Dr. Flamm on the new Japanese chip programs.
Another factor clearing the way for a revival of such projects is that trade tensions have diminished as the share of Japan's semiconductor market held by American and other foreign manufacturers has tripled in the last decade to about 30 percent. Last summer, a semiconductor trade agreement between the United States and Japan expired and was replaced by a far weaker accord.
A few years ago, when trade tensions were higher, "We were not so confident of acceptance by our U.S. counterparts," said Hajime Sasaki, the executive vice president in charge of semiconductors for the NEC Corporation.
American companies are not complaining now about Japan's "industrial targeting" as they did in the past. However, there is still some concern about a renewed competitive threat from Japan.
William J. Spencer, the president of Sematech, an American semiconductor industry consortium, said the Japanese companies rejected a call to participate in a project involving American, European, Korean and Taiwanese companies and opted to start their own, in an apparent effort to gain a competitive edge. "Every major semiconductor company in the world except the Japanese is in our program," he said.
Japanese executives contend that the United States has little ground for complaint since it undertook a joint industry-Government effort in the form of Sematech, the consortium based in Austin, Tex. that started in 1987 and had a budget that was bigger than the Japanese programs combined. Until last month, when its Federal financing ended, Sematech spent about $200 million a year, half from the Defense Department and half from its member companies.
Indeed, Japanese officials said they were prompted to start their programs in part by the success of Sematech in revitalizing American chip manufacturing, just as Sematech had been partly a response to the VLSI Project, an earlier Japanese program in the 1970's. VLSI stands for very large-scale integration, a reference to putting thousands of microelectronic circuit elements on a chip.
Japanese officials point out that collaborations are increasingly common in the semiconductor industry, because the cost of advancing the technology has become too high for any single company to shoulder by itself. They also note that some of the Japanese projects have foreign participants, while Sematech was restricted to American companies.
"Industrial policy may come back, but it's not the same as the targeting policy 20 years ago," said Toru Nakayama, deputy director of the industrial electronics division at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, or MITI.
The VLSI Project, in which the ministry backed cooperative research by Japan's major electronics companies, was arguably the most successful of Japan's industrial development projects. By the middle 1980's, Japanese companies had virtually taken over the world market for dynamic random-access memory chips, the main type of computer memory chip, forcing all but a couple of American companies to drop out.
But now South Korean companies are challenging Japan's leadership in D-RAM's. Meanwhile, the Japanese companies have not been able to make much of an inroad into advanced chips, like microprocessors, that are the province of American companies. And, owing in part to Sematech, the American manufacturers of chip-making machinery have improved in competitiveness.
The Japanese collaborations started in 1994 when Japan's 10 largest semiconductor manufacturers formed the Semiconductor Industry Research Institute Japan, a research center that planned the programs that are starting now. One new effort is the Association of Super-Advanced Electronics Technologies, or ASET. This consists of 10 separate research programs aimed at developing technology to make future generations of computer chips, as well as disk drives and liquid crystal screens.
The five-year project, which began in March, is being financed by MITI, with total spending perhaps reaching $300 million over five years. It received 10 billion yen, or nearly $100 million, in last year's budget but only 1.3 billion yen, or $13 million, this year. Three American companies -- Texas Instruments, I.B.M. and Merck -- are participating in some of the research projects.
Another new consortium is Semiconductor Leading Edge Technologies Inc., or Selete, which is budgeted at $350 million over five years and is financed completely by the 10 member companies.
It aims at evaluating equipment for manufacturing semiconductor chips using silicon wafers 300 millimeters, or 12 inches, in diameter. Selete is now nearing completion of a $50 million clean room, a manufacturing site, at a Hitachi laboratory in Yokohama.
Right now chips are generally made on 8-inch wafers. Using 12-inch wafers would allow more chips to be made on each wafer, lowering manufacturing costs per chip. The shift to the new technology, expected by the year 2000, will represent a big chance for companies to gain or lose market share.
Sematech set up a similar cooperative program, in which 12 companies from the United States, Korea, Europe and Taiwan are participating. But the budget for this effort is only $26 million over 18 months.
Another new Japanese project, the Super Silicon Crystal Research Institute, aims to develop 400-millimeter, or 16-inch, wafers, which will not come into use for 10 years or more. The project is budgeted at 13.4 billion yen, or about $130 million, over five years, with half being paid by the Government and half by its member companies, which are seven Japanese makes of silicon wafers.
The Japanese industry has also begun a small program to finance semiconductor research at universities, similar to one started many years ago by the Semiconductor Industry Association in the United States.
The semiconductor research institute is also considering starting a program to develop software for chip design, an area in which Japanese industry is dependent on small American companies.
Japan's Government-industry collaborations are not always effective. The Fifth Generation Computer program, which aimed to develop machines with artificial intelligence, is widely viewed as a colossal failure.
A recent book about the Ministry of International Trade and Industry's programs by Scott Callon, chief strategist for BT Asia Securities in Tokyo, describes how the ministry often had to twist the arms of the companies to get them to participate.
Companies rarely donate their best researchers to such consortiums and do not cooperate as well as it appears, Mr. Callon writes in "Divided Sun: MITI and the Breakdown of Japanese High-Tech Industrial Policy, 1975-1993" (Stanford University Press, 1995).
Japanese executives acknowledge that such problems do occur. But they say that the current programs were begun by industry itself.
"This time they are very cooperative," said Hiroyoshi Komiya, a former chief semiconductor engineer at Mitsubishi Electric Company who now is the executive vice president of Selete. "The industrial situation is completely different from in the past. We need so much money to develop new technology."

HEADLINE: As the Shoreham Well Runs Dry, a School District Struggles With the Bottom Line

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: WADING RIVER, L.I., Nov. 12

 BODY:
It seemed too good to be true. For two decades, the small but growing school district here reaped a tax bonanza from a large property, enabling educators to finance their dream programs.
At times, that single property paid 90 percent of the Shoreham-Wading River School District's annual budgets. And what budgets they were. 
 Kindergartners got individual violin lessons. Budding biologists sailed the Hudson River. Each child had a personal adviser. A dish antenna delivered educational television via satellite. Spanish classes traveled to Madrid. Tennis courts were lighted for night players. Star teachers were recruited from other states. Class size shrank to as few as 15 pupils. Students produced shows in their own television studio. The library boasted 60,000 books, Colonial-era newspapers and 25 computer terminals. A demonstration farm had goats, pigs and a garden.
The results have been extraordinary. The schools have had virtually no dropouts, crime, vandalism or graffiti, and 93 percent of the graduates go to college. Despite an enrollment of only 2,166, the district racks up countless trophies and awards in competitions ranging from art to math to English to sports. It has National Merit Scholarship semifinalists every year and had a first-place Westinghouse science scholar.
"We've had hundreds of visitors come to see the programs," said a former school board president, Albert G. Prodell. Parents were thrilled, and families moved here for the schools. Homeowners profited from low taxes, and houses fetched premium prices compared with those in neighboring districts.
But there was a big catch.
The property that made it all possible was the Long Island Lighting Company's nuclear power plant at Shoreham, a troubled project that has been a political and economic quagmire for Long Island.
Now a State Supreme Court decision has transformed the school district's golden goose into an albatross. On Nov. 7, Justice Thomas Stark ruled that Lilco had been overassessed for taxes on the power plant, which was abandoned because of environmental opposition before it ever went into operation.
That ruling threatens to bankrupt the schools. Lilco contends it is owed $1.15 billion in refunds and interest from local governments. That includes a staggering $472 million from the school district, or an average of $85,000 for each of its households.
"Paying back $400 million is impossible," said the school board's president, Patricia A. Fearon. Desperate to avoid the bill, the district is appealing the ruling.
The Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, has been talking to Gov. George E. Pataki to find a way to ease the refunds, which Lilco is demanding from Brookhaven town and the county as well. The officials hope to solve the problem as part of a broader state plan to take over Lilco because of its high electric rates -- partly caused by Shoreham's construction debt and high property taxes. But the chances of such a complex deal are uncertain.
"People are starting to ask about it, and I tell them I don't know what's going to happen," said Kenneth P. Kaufman, a real estate broker. "Shoreham-Wading River schools have always been top-notch, but the proverbial free ride is over." Residents face a double whammy of rising taxes and dampened home values, he said.
The power plant started creating problems for the district in 1992, when the state's Long Island Power Authority took over the plant and began reducing its payments to the schools.
The school budget, which peaked at $38.8 million that year, is now down to $30.1 million, even though enrollment and costs have grown. Power plant payments still account for $17.6 million, but that subsidy is shrinking by about $3 million a year. Spending per pupil has dropped to $13,900 from $19,000. Taxes, though still a bargain, have risen.
The number of teachers has fallen to 190 from 230, and 100 other jobs have been cut. Average class size has grown to 24. Teachers who once advised 8 or 9 students are now assigned 12 or 13.
"A lot of the individualized program has been lost," said Cornelius J. Mahoney, the president of the teachers union. "The district has changed dramatically, and the staff is doing their best to maintain quality education."
Astronomy, horticulture and home economics courses have been dropped, and business, science and photography classes have been trimmed. The farm was given up.
On Tuesday, high school students dismantling stage sets for their "Inherit the Wind" production were saving not only the lumber but also the screws. Some lamented that in the good old days, they received minimum wage for work they now do for nothing.
But there is little sympathy from other Long Islanders, who bear some of the nation's highest local taxes. They have envied the Shoreham-Wading River district's good fortune and reviled it for extravagance.
"I know there is resentment," Mr. Prodell said.
Lou Lewis, a lawyer for the district, said, "People seem to think we have swimming pools, carpeted hallways and golf courses, and that's all untrue."
The district is mostly middle class, mostly white, and the homes range from a trailer park to expensive homes on the bluff overlooking Long Island Sound. District officials say that a number of teachers from other districts moved here so their children could take advantage of the school programs.
Unapologetic, school officials say they were trapped by circumstances. "This was a situation not of our making," said Mrs. Fearon, who added that the district did not build the power plant or set the assessment; Lilco and Brookhaven did. "What were we supposed to do, say we don't want the money?"
Providing conventional education would have saved money, resulting in even lower residential taxes and higher home prices. But Mr. Prodell said he was proud that the board opted for first-class schools, "giving our kids a chance to succeed."
When a 1992 court ruling on the power plant signaled tax refund problems, should the district have started building reserves? School officials say that state law sharply limits the annual amount of such contingency funds.
In addition to challenging the latest ruling, school officials are fighting in court to overturn a special law, passed in the 1980's, that made the district liable for tax refunds. In Suffolk's other districts, the towns pay for refunds.
"I just felt it would be extremely unfair, after all the largess Shoreham-Wading River received, that a payback would come out of the people of 21 other school districts in Brookhaven," said George J. Hochbrueckner, who sponsored the law as an Assemblyman. "We thought this would come home to roost, which it did. I don't fault the district for what they did. They did what they thought was right at the time, and they probably didn't have a choice."
The school district won one ruling against the law but lost on appeal and is seeking a decision from a higher court.
Whatever the outcome of all the legal and political maneuvering, school officials say that student successes justify the district's investments.
Just last year, Daniel Durand was on the "Today" show with his winning entry in a national Duracel science contest. Five of the fall sports teams were league champions, and Masami Stampf was chosen by the National Orchestra, a student ensemble.
"Last season, there were two network television programs, one with Karen Sillas -- class of '81 -- playing the lead, and another series starring D. B. Sweeney -- class of '79," said their old high school drama teacher, Jeffrey L. Bennett. "Not bad for a small school."
Although many public schools have extracurricular theater programs, Shoreham-Wading River is among the few to offer courses in drama. Mr. Bennett said he knows of only two others in the state.
"Many consider it a frill and a luxury, but it has a noble tradition here," he said. But whether that tradition will continue is unclear. Mr. Bennett is retiring this year. He said he did not know if he would be replaced.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1467 words

HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LOOMS FOR WELFARE BILL OFFERED BY PATAKI

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Now that Gov. George E. Pataki has released his long-awaited plan to reconstruct the state's $4 billion welfare system, the debate has shifted to the Legislature, where many Democrats are already vowing to block major portions of his initiative.
The 300-page bill the Governor unveiled last week called for cutting benefits to families by 45 percent over four years and ending them entirely after five, and replacing cash grants to able-bodied childless adults with vouchers for food, clothing and shelter. If enacted, the plan would represent the most thorough revision of state welfare policies in six decades and significantly change the lives of 1.4 million recipients. 
 But interviews with a broad sampling of Assembly Democrats in recent days show that many of them strongly question, if not outright reject, several important provisions in the Pataki plan, particularly those that would cut benefits for families.
Since the Democrats control the Assembly by a comfortable 95-54 margin, they have virtual veto power over most of the Governor's welfare agenda -- a muscle they flexed in 1995 and again earlier this year in rejecting similar welfare proposals.
Still, the Democrats are far from united in their opposition to the Governor's plan, and some conservatives are likely to cross party lines to endorse parts of it. Many of those conservative Democrats agree with the Governor that the new Federal welfare law requires the state to revamp its policies to push more people off the welfare rolls.
As a result, the Democrats are bracing for a heated battle first among themselves and then with the Governor over welfare revisions when they take the issue up, probably in January. Emboldened by their party's strong showing in this month's elections, liberals and some moderates say they plan to mount a strenuous campaign against Mr. Pataki's plan so as to wrest control of the debate from the Republicans.
"I think it's important that the Assembly's approach be clearly articulated and that the Governor's rhetoric not go unchallenged," said Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, a Manhattan Democrat. "It's important that opponents be out early saying that this not the way to get welfare recipients off welfare. It is simply reckless and punitive cutting."
Democrats are not the only ones raising concerns about the Governor's ideas. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has echoed Democrats' worries about the benefit cut for families, though he praised many other parts of Mr. Pataki's plan.
In New Jersey, the debate over Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's welfare plan is expected to be much less contentious, partly because Democrats helped write her plan and partly because both houses of the Legislature are controlled by Governor Whitman's fellow Republicans. Connecticut is not expected to have a major battle over welfare because the Legislature enacted a comprehensive plan last year.
In a signal of just how hard fought next year's welfare debate in New York is likely to be, some liberals, who represent one of the largest voting blocs in the Assembly, plan to oppose setting a five-year limit on cash benefits to families. The new Federal welfare law prohibits states from using Federal funds to pay benefits to families that have been on welfare longer than 60 months, meaning that should the state decide to extend that limit, it might have to pick up all of the tab for people in the program longer than that. The Federal law does not restrict how states use their own money.
Many Democrats say they would support a plan that would extend cash benefits beyond five years if it could be shown that there were not enough entry-level jobs for welfare recipients, based on a formula using unemployment and job-creation rates. Such a plan would almost certainly cost the state extra money.
"The Governor's plan is predicated on the notion that if you don't work, you shouldn't get welfare benefits, even if you are a single parent with small children," said Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a Manhattan Democrat. "Are we in a position to guarantee that everybody can get a job? The answer is no."
The Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat who will play a pivotal role in the welfare negotiations, has already endorsed the idea of extending time limits for people who cannot find jobs. Mr. Silver has been traveling in China and was unavailable for comment on Mr. Pataki's new plan. But his aides said he was uncomfortable with several parts of the Governor's bill, particularly benefit cuts for families.
Conservative Democrats, however, said they would object to any plan that required using large amounts of state money to extend the five-year limit. "That's not realistic," said Assemblyman Eric N. Vitaliano of Staten Island. "The state doesn't have the money to do that."
Welfare advocates also think they have found a loophole in the Federal law that would allow the state to circumvent the five-year limit. Contending that the Federal time limit applies only to parents, not their children, the advocates argue that the state could use its own funds to pay parents' benefits beyond five years and Federal money to assist children.
Asked about the legality of this proposal, Michael Kharfen, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services, said, "I don't know, to be honest."
But independent welfare experts said they doubted the maneuver would work, saying the clear intention of the Federal law is to establish a five-year limit on entire families. And any such proposal would face stiff opposition from the Republican-controlled Senate and Mr. Pataki, who believes time limits are the best way to end welfare dependency.
When he released his bill last week, Mr. Pataki said his plan would provide a humane and effective way to prod entrenched welfare recipients to find jobs. The plan would cut benefits to families by 10 percent after 18 months, with the benefits shrinking gradually to 45 percent after 4 years and ending completely after 5. But Mr. Pataki would also allow parents to keep their welfare benefits even if they earn as much as $1,080 a month from work; now, benefits are reduced for those who earn more than $667 a month.
While Mayor Giuliani has generally endorsed the thrust of the Governor's proposals, yesterday he reiterated his concerns about the long-term effect of the plan.
"I have concerns about the third, fourth and fifth years," he said. "The cuts are very, very steep."
The Governor's bill would abolish the state's Home Relief program, which provides cash grants to about 230,000 mainly able-bodied childless adults, and replace it with a system that provides vouchers for food, shelter and clothing.
Mr. Pataki's plan would also impose a host of restrictions and rules on recipients. Parents would lose a portion of their benefits if their children, up to age 19, were absent without excuse from school three times in an academic quarter. Teen-age recipients would be required to attend high school and live with their parents. All recipients would have to undergo drug testing.
Felons who violated parole or probation would lose cash benefits. And the plan would end the state's policy of increasing cash benefits to families who have additional children while on welfare.
The cuts come after the state has already tried to curtail welfare spending; yesterday, the Governor said the state had reduced welfare rolls by 25,000 by taking fingerprint images from recipients to reduce fraud.
In a survey of nearly a dozen Democratic Assembly members from different parts of the state, almost all said they would oppose benefit cuts. Most said they disliked punishing families with truant children, saying the policy would allow unruly teenagers to hurt their siblings. And most said they would oppose a cap on family benefits.
But opinions were more divided on other aspects of the Governor's plan. Several Democrats said that the proposal to test welfare recipients for drugs should be strongly considered, though they stopped short of endorsing it. And several said they liked the idea of using vouchers instead of cash to assist certain welfare recipients, provided there was enough money available to meet those needs.
In a year when Democrats picked up a seat in the Assembly, most Democrats said they felt on stronger ground than ever in opposing major elements of the Governor's plan. Still, Democrats from the suburbs and upstate said they believed that voters wanted changes made to welfare, though nothing as sweeping as Mr. Pataki has proposed.
"I'm not sure I won't end up supporting some of what he's putting forward," said Assemblyman Steven Englebright, a Suffolk County Democrat. "Thematically, these ideas lean in the right direction. The devil is in the details."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1970 words

HEADLINE: Quality of Life Is Up for Many Blacks, Data Say

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS

 BODY:
Four years ago, officials here in Marion County decided to make an all-out effort to curb the stubbornly high level of births among unmarried women, a problem that affected a cross-section of the county, but was particularly acute for blacks.
The health department, public and private social service agencies, the schools, even the local prosecutor's office, all joined in to help. Last year the effort seemed to pay off: 358 fewer babies were born to unmarried black women than in 1992, a drop of more than 12 percent, within a 4 percent overall decrease in Marion County. 
The county's success in confronting what was a seemingly intractable problem among its black population is a small victory but not an isolated one. Without much fanfare, a remarkable and little understood change is occurring among the nation's 33.5 million African-Americans. After a decade of rising drug use, growing violence, disintegrating families and declining measures of health among some segments of the black population, things are starting to turn around in many ways.
While there is much debate on whether the gains are temporary, and although wide gulfs in opportunity, incomes and education still exist between blacks and whites, signs of improvement abound:
*The black teen-age birth rate fell by 9 percent in 1995 and has dropped by 17 percent since 1991. Last year, the percentage of black babies born out of wedlock fell to 69.5 percent, from 70.4 percent, the first such drop since 1969.
*For the first time since the Census Bureau began keeping track in 1959, the poverty rate fell below 30 percent of all blacks in 1995. Median income for black households rose by 3.6 percent, far faster than the 2.2 percent increase for white households. (Census data show that many of the strongest gains in earnings are at the bottom, rather than at the top, of the black income scale.)
*Blacks are the only group whose inflation-adjusted median income exceeds what it was in 1989. That year, households headed by black married couples earned 79 percent as much as their white counterparts. By 1995, the gap was 87 percent.
*The rate at which black people were victims of murder dropped an estimated 17 percent last year, and the average life expectancy for black men rose to 65.4 years, the highest since 1984, when crack cocaine and accessibility of weapons like assault rifles began to engulf many black communities.
*The proportion of young black adults, age 25 to 29, who have completed high school has reached that of young white adults.
*Verbal scores on national standardized tests have risen faster for black students than for white students, but African-Americans still score much lower than whites.
"I think that this is a short period of really very substantial and significant gains," said Milton Morris, vice president of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a Washington group that tracks trends among African-Americans. "In the heat of the political debates and atmosphere of the last year or so, very few people have been paying serious attention. And yet when you do, you see that by virtually every measure of well-being, African-Americans have been on a significant uptrend during the 90's."
There remain large gaps between African-Americans and whites in educational attainment, infant mortality, income and poverty rates. And sociologists, economists, demographers and civil rights advocates caution that the improvements should not mask problems with crime, welfare dependency, discrimination and unemployment that still confront the black population in this country.
"I don't know that I can agree with how robust those indicators are in terms of significant gains," said Evelyn Moore, the executive director of the National Black Child Development Institute, a nonprofit advocacy organization in Washington. "I think there are still very serious challenges facing our children."
Some scholars also worry that the recent gains may be reversed if the economy falters or, in the short term, by the new welfare law.
"I think there's reason to be concerned about the impact of the welfare bill on a number of these trends, on the poverty rate, on the employment rate," said William Julius Wilson, a professor of social policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. "When the welfare mothers reach their time limit, they will flood a pool that is already filled with a lot of jobless workers."
Still, in public hospital waiting rooms, in medical clinics and in the offices of social welfare programs around the country, workers point to glimmers of improvement even with poverty and hopelessness.
Jarvis Emerson, the director of the school-based program for the Watts Health Foundation, a nonprofit group in the South-Central section of Los Angeles, said he was beginning to notice gains in the struggle to reduce the soaring rates of out-of-wedlock births in the neighborhood.
"I do think it is a slight decrease or leveling off of births to teen-agers," he said. "With all the programs out there all putting out the same message, there is more of a heightened awareness among the young people of becoming pregnant."
Diane Sawyer, who works in the G.E.D. program at Jefferson State Junior College in Birmingham, said more black students were taking the test each year. Lisa Crumley, a supervisor with the Department of Human Resources in Bessemer, a suburb of Birmingham, said fewer black people had applied to her office to receive welfare benefits in recent months. "I don't know if that means the quality of life has improved or what," Ms. Crumley said.
In Camden, N.J., there was a 21.2 percent drop in the number of births to mothers on welfare there from 1992 to 1994, according to Gary Young, a researcher at Cooper Hospital-University Medical Center in Camden, and Ted Goertzel, a sociology professor at Rutgers University.
Scholars who study America's black population give much of the credit for the improvements to the country's overall economic prosperity, though they acknowledge that better economic times cannot explain the whole story. A number of economists and sociologists note that in 1995 the black unemployment rate tumbled under 10 percent for the first time in 20 years, though it has since inched up above that level.
But while a brighter labor market helps account for black gains in income and the drop in poverty rates for African-Americans, many experts cannot fully explain improvements in the out-of-wedlock birth rate or the teen-age pregnancy rate.
Some researchers in New Jersey credit the drop in the out-of-wedlock birth rate among the state's welfare families -- about 46 percent of whom are black -- to its 1992 law denying increased cash benefits to women who have more children. Other states, like Delaware and Indiana, which did not institute policies like New Jersey's until recently, have also reported such decreases.
"Something is going on," said Kristin Moore, the executive director of Child Trends, a Washington-based research group. "Whether it's cultural factors, or a thousand programs finally seeing some success, we don't know."
A growing sense of material well-being is even changing the makeup of the military. The Pentagon recently found that the number of blacks joining the armed forces has fallen by about half since 1990, a steeper decline than for any other group. Defense Department and civilian analysts are unsure of the reason, but one theory is a growing confidence among blacks in their ability to succeed in the labor market.
Some economists argue that the closing of the gap between blacks and whites is partly explained by surveys that often count most Americans of Hispanic heritage as whites. Recent increases in the number of Hispanic immigrants, many of them low income, thus hold down overall white performance.
Some economists also say the nearly 800,000 black adults in Federal and state prisons and local jails are not counted when looking at things like unemployment or high school completion rates. So the measures of black improvements seem higher than they actually are.
"Those people are gone from all these employment and earnings statistics," said Richard Freeman, a professor of economics at Harvard. "Those are huge numbers."
But there is disagreement over how much these two phenomena affect the overall picture, and some sociologists say whatever distortions that occur only show up when comparing achievement among blacks to that of whites, not when looking at black improvements by themselves.
"Some figures would be different if they were counted, but I don't think the overall trends would be affected," Professor Wilson said of the numbers of black men in prison.
Across the country, from Jersey City to Cleveland to Los Angeles, the signs of improvement are also beginning to be felt among the people.
"In my area, I see things getting better all the time," said Felicia Wearing, 25, who lives with her daughter in the Bergen Lafayette section of Jersey City. "It used to be like hell, groups always on the corner, cussing and fighting, ripping and raiding, shooting each other. It's calmed down a whole hell of a lot."
Chuck Wheeler, 39, a former drummer who bought an aging laundry in a black section of Cleveland, also senses a change. "People are not doing the same things they were doing before," Mr. Wheeler said. "People are waking up. They're realizing what they need to do is get their families and themselves together."
But not everyone is convinced that things are improving. "To tell you the truth, I really think things are going back," said Harold Truxon, a black community activist from Ellendale, Del. "I really see more problems than I ever have."
In his own way, Richard Edwards of Indianapolis is symbolic of the changes. A little more than a year ago he was selling and using drugs. He never spent any time in prison, but he had been arrested on narcotics charges and had been given probation. A high school dropout, he also spent very little time with the son he had fathered out of wedlock.
Today, at 26, he is living with his girlfriend and spending time with his son. Mr. Edwards said he had no intention of having more children until he was married and financially able to provide for them. He is studying for a G.E.D. and is working as a maintenance mechanic at a hospital.
"I've been here 10 and a half months," he said, smiling and clutching a practice test for his G.E.D. "I've never held a job that long."
In October 1992, health officials in Marion County, Ind., surveyed all women who gave birth there. Among the findings of the survey was that more than 90 percent of the unwed mothers said they had not intended to get pregnant. So officials saw an opportunity to make a dent in the illegitimacy rate with better education and family planning.
Now, all major hospitals in the county offer family-planning programs, as do clinics and classes run by the county health department and private agencies like Girls Inc. and Planned Parenthood.
Recently, a local middle school and a high school have begun giving boys and girls life-like computerized dolls that are programmed to cry at random. So they can learn that parenthood brings responsibilities that do not end, the students must cart around the dolls even on weekends or arrange for a baby-sitter.
But even as officials take note of progress, people like Virginia A. Caine, the director of the Marion County Health Department, worry about complacency.
"People's perception," Ms. Caine said, "is that we've solved the problems and we don't have to put as many resources into it. Let's focus our attention on something else. People have no idea the amount of effort it requires to get people to receive services and to change their lives."

HEADLINE: Profit Squeeze for Publishers Makes Tenure More Elusive

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
Michael Parkhurst knew that his doctoral dissertation on the German sociologist and philosopher Theodor Adorno would not compete for sales with Oprah and Dennis Rodman.
Still, he was stunned that when the Cornell University Press said it was not interested in publishing his book, it cited its lack of marketability. 
 "I was not particularly surprised or hurt that they did not think my work would be a best seller," said Mr. Parkhurst, who is teaching at two universities in Oregon while trying to finish his dissertation. "But I was astonished that they explicitly cited sales as a criterion for considering manuscripts' worth."
Like Mr. Parkhurst, hundreds of young scholars around the country are facing this latest obstacle in a glutted academic job market.
To get tenure in the humanities and social sciences, it is all but mandatory at some universities, especially the most prestigious ones, to get an academic book published, usually by one of the 100 university presses that are members of the Association of American University Presses. But, as financially strained libraries are slashing budgets for books, university presses are cutting back on publishing specialized monographs, like doctoral dissertations.
A result is a collision between the financial logic of the book market and the ground rules of academia. Some say the conflict is a serious threat to the future of new scholarship at America's universities.
"University presses are increasingly having to make their decisions by reference to the market," said Sanford Thatcher, director of the Pennsylvania State Press, "so that presses will publish fewer books that have expected low sales. The whole problem, though, is that university presses were set up to publish precisely these kinds of books, and the tenure process depends on our decisions. Right now the whole system is breaking down."
Even a glance at academic publications makes it clear that the system has not entirely broken down. University presses publish about 8,000 books a year, some 15 percent of the 50,000 books published in the United States. And recent titles like "Essays on the Ethnography of the Aleuts" from the University of Alaska Press or "The Etablissements de Saint Louis: Thirteenth Century Law Texts from Tours, Orleans and Paris" by the University of Pennsylvania Press make it clear that you do not need best-seller potential to get published by university presses.
But financial pressures are making economically marginal books increasingly hard to justify. University library budgets have been under pressure for years. At the same time, scholarly journals have been drastically increasing in price. Since journals in various disciplines, particularly the sciences, are often considered essential purchases, budgets are being eaten up by the cost of journals at the expense of books.
"In 1975 a library might spend 70 percent of its annual budget on books and 30 percent on journals," said Walter Lippincott, director of the Princeton University Press. "Now those percentages are reversed."
When Mr. Lippincott worked at Cambridge University Press a few years back, he said, the assumption was that the institutional market for scholarly books was about 800 books. Others put the figure at 1,000. Now, he said, the expected market is 300 books, and it is difficult to justify publishing books with such a small sales potential. The Association of Research Libraries, which mostly represents university libraries, said its 119 members bought 23 percent fewer books in 1995 than in 1986.
Presses are finding ways to adjust. Many are focusing on books of regional interest or seeking books with general or academic appeal that stretches across different disciplines, thus broadening the market. And hot fields, like gay and lesbian studies, are prospering at academic presses, particularly those that have focused on such books, like the University of Chicago Press.
Also, some of the more aggressive university presses are hoping that as general-interest publishers focus more on blockbuster books, university presses will inherit many of the smaller, mainstream titles.
"Many big publishers don't want to publish books that don't have a chance of sales of 100,000 or more," said Stanley Fish, executive director of the Duke University Press. "The authors are becoming more willing to turn to university presses."
But none of that is likely to help scholars in specialized fields publishing works of academic importance but narrow appeal. Scholars say that may not matter at all to the general public, but it matters enormously to scholars dependent on getting their work disseminated and seeing the works of others in their field.
In a recent column in the weekly Chronicle of Higher Education, James Shapiro, a professor of English and comparative literature at Columbia University, warned that a result would be that trendy subjects would be explored while important but less sexy ones would not.
He cited two scholars, one studying Milton, the other cultural studies. Inevitably, the second would be more likely to be published and granted tenure, he said.
"The odds are that fewer Miltonists will get tenure; before long, there won't be enough around to train the next generation," he wrote. "It can hardly be a good thing" when the knowledge that is valued "is determined by market forces rather than by intellectual exchange."
There is much talk of solutions. One possibility is the rise of electronic publishing to the point that manuscripts could just be distributed and reviewed over the Internet rather than published in book form. But while electronic publishing is growing, few think the Internet is likely to replace books. Many academics say it is more likely that tenure procedures will have to change.
"There has not been anybody in my department to get tenure without a book in the last 25 years," said Gerald Snare, chairman of the English department at Tulane University. "Considering the number of extraordinarily bright young people who are having trouble even getting a reading, I would think in the next couple of years departments are going to have to rethink the tenure requirements."
Professor Shapiro of Columbia suggested that the tenure process be revised so that unpublished manuscripts could be judged on their intellectual merit rather than only being judged as finished books.
For now, though, young scholars like Mr. Parkhurst are having to play by the old rules. He is revising his manuscript on the political implications of the work of Adorno, a member of the Frankfurt School of scholars, of whom Herbert Marcuse is the best known.
"It's not like the mating habits of the Eastern woodfly, but it's still pretty esoteric," he said. "It doesn't have a high profile even in academia. But people who do esoteric nonmarket-oriented research don't do it to make money or be famous. They do it because they really want to do it. So I think people like me will continue to do what we do. It's just going to be harder and harder for us to find venues to share our work."

HEADLINE: Hard-Liners Are Regarded as Likely To Succeed Croatia's Ailing President

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The passing of President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, who lies seriously ill with cancer in a Washington hospital, would probably strengthen hard-line nationalists who are openly hostile to the American-brokered Muslim-Croat federation in Bosnia and who care little for democracy, say Western diplomats here.
The United States has often been frustrated with Mr. Tudjman's imperial style, his iron control of news reporting, political debate and the economy, and his refusal to allow the return of more than 200,000 ethnic Serbs driven from Croatia during the war. But at the same time, the 74-year-old former Communist general has battled back extreme factions in his governing party, the Croatian Democratic Union. 
 While he has not been an enthusiastic supporter of the federation in Bosnia, set up by the Americans in 1994 to end fighting between the ethnic Croats and the Muslims, he has insured its survival. And since the establishment of his Croatian nationalist state five years ago, he has astutely done just enough to keep his American and European allies behind him -- such as permitting a handful of small opposition newspapers to publish and backing the Dayton peace agreement for Bosnia.
But the President's party includes a powerful group of staunch nationalists who disapprove of the President's flexibility. Many of them live in Croatia in exile from the area in Bosnia held by ethnic Croats. That faction, which has amassed great wealth in the last few years by seizing control of state businesses following Croatia's independence in 1991, is dismissive of parliamentary democracy. Many members have close links with emigre groups in various countries like Canada and Australia whose members left Croatia after World War II because of the involvement they, or their ancestors, had in the Nazi-allied fascist state.
The loss of the President could not come at a worse time. His party is increasingly divided, facing mounting corruption scandals and struggling to halt a steady decline in its popularity. Only Mr. Tudjman, widely viewed as the father of the Croatian state, has been able to keep himself largely above the fray, although members of his family have profited handsomely from lucrative business deals.
"Without Tudjman, the ruling party could have a hard time holding on to power in free and fair elections," a European diplomat said. "But we worry about the lack of commitment by many of the people around the President to democratic procedures."
Even under Mr. Tudjman's patronage, the Muslim-Croat federation in Bosnia barely functions. The ethnic Croats in Bosnia, who carry Croatian passports and vote in Croatian elections, have refused to dismantle their self-styled government of "Herzeg-Bosnia" and to form common institutions with the Muslims. Diplomats here say that without the President's restraining hand, the hard-liners could well call for the annexation of Croat-held Bosnia, which is contiguous with the Croatian border. That would seriously destabilize Bosnia and openly repudiate the Dayton agreement.
The faction clustered around the Croatian Defense Minister, Gojko Susak, who comes from the Croat-held part of Bosnia known as Herzegovina, has steadily pushed the party to the right. Mr. Susak, widely regarded as the second-most-powerful figure in Croatia, has also been ill, however. He was operated on in the United States this year for lung cancer, and reports of his continued illness persist despite official statements that he is in good health.
But even if he were out of the picture, that faction still dominates the party, controlling the police, internal security and the military. Mr. Susak works closely with several hard-line members of Parliament, including Ivan Milas, Vice Vukojevic -- who also originates from Herzegovina -- and Vladimir Seks.
The moderate Foreign Minister, Mate Granic, who has often helped curb the excesses of the hard-line wing, will probably be the big loser if the President is unable to stay in office, although the Foreign Minister has the respect of Croatia's most important allies, including the United States.
"Granic is the last, best hope for Croatia," said a Western diplomat. "But it is doubtful that he will be able to prevail over the hard-liners, who do not want to see the vast economic and political gains they made during the war diminished."
The country's fractious opposition coalition is unlikely to galvanize enough support to challenge the hard-liners in the governing party, in the scheduled presidential and parliamentary elections next year. The coalition is locked out of the Government-controlled news media, and its members are often harassed and lack financial backing. The coalition is also plagued by bitter divisions.
The opposition coalition began a monthlong boycott of Parliament meetings last Wednesday because of the governing party's refusal to honor the spirit of the municipal elections last year in Zagreb, the capital. Opposition candidates won control of the City Council, which is supposed to appoint the Mayor. The Council has nominated a series of candidates for Mayor, but the President has vetoed each one, citing a murky national security clause in the Constitution.
The Speaker of Parliament is designated by the Constitution to take over Mr. Tudjman's responsibilities if the Supreme Court decides that the President is unable to carry out his duties. Croatia has no Vice President. The Constitution calls for new elections 60 days after the President leaves office.
"Tudjman got away with this refusal to honor the results of democratic elections because of his personal stature," a Western diplomat said. "But no one else in the ruling party has that kind of authority. If the same tactics continue under a less popular politician, it could trigger a political upheaval."

Tudjman Said to Improve
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (Reuters) -- President Tudjman, under treatment in a Washington hospital, was feeling well and was working, a diplomat from Croatia's Embassy said today.
"He feels well," the diplomat said in a brief telephone interview. "He's performing his duties."
American officials said late last week that Mr. Tudjman was seriously ill and was being treated in Walter Reed Hospital for stomach cancer.
Croatian officials, apparently anxious to discourage speculation about the President's health, have avoided any mention of cancer and described his illness as a "digestion problem."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
How a Landmark of American Merchandising Deflated Its Own Balloon

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

THE RAIN ON MACY'S PARADE
How Greed, Ambition and Folly Ruined America's Greatest Store
By Jeffrey A. Trachtenberg
Illustrated. 274 pages. Times Business/Random House. $27.50.
Depressingly familiar is the story that Jeffrey A. Trachtenberg tells in his new book, "The Rain on Macy's Parade: How Greed, Ambition and Folly Ruined America's Greatest Store." Not only are the character flaws referred to in his subtitle commonplace, but his story of decline and fall is also all too symbolic of the corporate takeover era through which the American economy recently passed. 
 As Mr. Trachtenberg tells it, the descent of R. H. Macy & Company into bankruptcy in January 1992 is very nearly archetypal. Six years earlier, the chairman, Edward S. Finkelstein, recognizing the value of Macy's assets and wanting to protect his company from a hostile takeover by outside raiders, had engineered an ambitious leveraged buyout, placing himself at the head of a team of inside investors who hoped to be made rich by the maneuver. But in doing so, Mr. Trachtenberg says, Mr. Finkelstein projected too rosy a picture of the economic future and took on too heavy a burden of debt.
Poor management and bad luck increased Macy's vulnerability, Mr. Trachtenberg argues. When the economy turned sour, particularly through a series of Christmas seasons, Macy's was finally forced to seek bankruptcy protection. Because Mr. Finkelstein and his team could not come up with a viable reorganization plan, he was forced to resign, his management team lost its entire investment, and Macy's was eventually taken over by Federated Department Stores.
Mr. Trachtenberg, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, tells this story somewhat unevenly. He is spirited on Macy's rise to prominence, noting how the store was the first to sell Polaroid cameras and the games Monopoly and Scrabble, and how the Herald Square Macy's once auctioned live sheep and cows on the fifth floor.
He catches close up some of the more significant moments in his story, like the post-buyout victory party Mr. Finkelstein arranged for himself at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he pronounced for the gathering his own version of Henry V's St. Crispin's Day speech: "We few, we happy few, we band of brothers." Or the shareholders' meeting on June 19, 1996, at which, despite the articulate objections of certain dissidents, Mr. Finkelstein's buyout proposal was overwhelmingly approved.
And Mr. Trachtenberg is adept at weaving into his narrative the parallel stories of other department-store empires, particularly Federated, which, by dealing more wisely with many of the same challenges that Macy's faced, was ultimately able to outmaneuver its rival.
Unfortunately, in certain other respects, Mr. Trachtenberg's narrative is weaker. True, we are all economists now, as commentators on the recent election have pointed out in explaining voters' resistance to Bob Dole's tax-cut proposal. But we are not all so sophisticated that we can follow, without a little coaching, Mr. Trachtenberg's sometimes rapid-fire references to "senior subordinated debentures," "nonrecourse senior real estate debt," "clean-down requirements," "debtor-in-possession financing" and "the cash flow ratio coverage covenant relative to debt."
More bothersome, the author fails to show precisely how Mr. Finkelstein's supposed personal failings worked to undermine Macy's struggle to survive. Various associates are quoted as accusing the chairman of nepotism, of an intolerance of contradiction, of surrounding himself with yes men, of rewarding himself too lavishly and of losing touch with the rank and file.
But no real connection is made between these shortcomings and Mr. Finkelstein's failure, for instance, to coordinate the operations of Macy's with its sister store Bamberger's, or his inability to understand that the success of the upscale stores in his organization, like Bullocks in Los Angeles, and the I. Magnin specialty store chain, depended on limiting inventory, so that wealthy shoppers would have the sense that they were getting something exclusive.
To judge from Mr. Trachtenberg's account, Mr. Finkelstein's fatal failing was that he counted too strongly on good economic times to repay Macy's huge debt, which is hardly an unusual flaw in a highly speculative business. So to end up calling Mr. Finkelstein "a King Lear-like figure -- angry, abandoned, bewildered" seems cliched and melodramatic, particularly when the reader hasn't gotten to know him well enough even to compare him to as elementary a character as the giant in "Jack and the Beanstalk." It is insulting, really, to both Mr. Finkelstein and Lear.
The discontinuity between character and action in Mr. Trachtenberg's narrative is summed up by his curious citation of a comment by Robert Miller, a lawyer who represented Macy's bondholders in dealings with Mr. Finkelstein after he resigned.
"Do you know the movie 'The Producers'?" said Mr. Miller. "At the end, when they are singing 'Springtime for Hitler,' Zero Mostel says, 'I hired the wrong director, the wrong actor, the wrong story. Where did I go right?' It was like that for Ed. Ed did everything right. So today he believes that the mistakes and faults weren't his. It was the weather, it was the recession, but never me."
These remarks are incoherent, and so is Mr. Trachtenberg's point in quoting them. To anyone who recalls "The Producers," the point of Zero Mostel's funny comment "Where did I go right?" is that he has a hit on his hands despite having done everything in his power to produce a failure. This is exactly the opposite of what Mr. Finkelstein tried to do by taking Macy's private. Presumably he tried to do everything right, and went wrong. Unless, of course, a hidden side of this story exists that Mr. Trachtenberg, in this ultimately superficial account, has neglected to reveal.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 20, 1996, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A book review on Monday about "The Rain on Macy's Parade: How Greed, Ambition and Folly Ruined America's Greatest Store," by Jeffrey A. Trachtenberg, misstated the date of the meeting at which R. H. Macy & Company shareholders approved a buyout proposal by the company chairman, Edward S. Finkelstein. It was June 19, 1986, not 1996.

HEADLINE: An Odd Rift Develops Between an Author and Borders, a Chain Promoting His Book

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Ever since he filmed the docu-comedy "Roger and Me" at the nadir of the 1980's recession, Michael Moore has gained fame and money playing the guileless Everyman who skewers corporate America. Little did he suspect that an Everyman corporation might someday skewer back.
But to hear him tell it, that is precisely what Borders Group Inc., the bookseller whose megastores are among the sales elephants of the literary jungle, is doing. 
 In a column appearing today in The Nation magazine, Mr. Moore contends that Borders executives have banned him from promoting his popular book "Downsize This!" in any of their 152 stores. He says Borders security guards have intimidated him and that long-planned readings and autograph sessions have been canceled.
Why? Mr. Moore's explanation is that last month, while in a Borders in Philadelphia to promote his book, he said it is a good idea for bookstore employees to join unions. It happens that two unions have begun trying to organize the 8,000 workers of the chain; last month the Lincoln Park, Ill., store voted to join the United Food and Commercial Workers.
"I just don't think they're thinking very clearly now because they're so afraid," Mr. Moore said. "I was really looking forward to going out on a book tour. I'm not going out on a union organizing tour."
For their part, Borders officials suggest that Mr. Moore suffers from a persecution complex. They say the union movement extends to barely four of the company's sites, and has already failed in Philadelphia. "Downsize This!" got generous billing in a promotional magazine that Borders gives to customers, and Borders officials say it defies logic for a bookstore to muzzle an author who is padding their bottom line.
And they profess to be mystified as to why Mr. Moore would start a public attack on a company contributing so heavily to his success. "We welcome him and are pleased to have him sign copies," said Jody Kohn, a spokeswoman for Borders, based in Ann Arbor, Mich. "We are doing what we can do to help sell his book. He's gone to several places and done exactly what you're telling me, which is to kind of bad-mouth us."
In short, Ms. Kohn said, Mr. Moore's account of Borders's behavior is flat-out incorrect. Mr. Moore says her version "flies in the face of everything I know to be true."
It is an odd rift. Mr. Moore, who is from Michigan, fondly remembers shopping at the original Ann Arbor Borders when the company was a single store owned by "two hippies" who let customers browse as long as they wanted.
The chain and Mr. Moore got off to a rousing start this year, when Mr. Moore regaled an Ann Arbor audience with a speech speckled with praise for Borders. He spoke about the union drive when asked. "I answered that I think everyone should like to join a union and that I support them," he said. "But I also said that I had to say I think Borders is probably the best bookstore in America."
Things went downhill from there. The two sides disagree little over facts, but are light years apart on questions of motivation.
No one disputes, for example, that the situation was dicey when Mr. Moore arrived to speak and sign books in Philadelphia. The International Workers of the World was trying to unionize the store; there were accusations, denied by Borders, that a worker was dismissed for supporting the union's efforts.
Mr. Moore, a committed union supporter, refused to cross a picket line outside the door. But with the apparent blessing of officials of Borders, Mr. Moore invited the pickets inside and let the dismissed worker speak.
But The Philadelphia Inquirer quoted an unidentified union official saying Mr. Moore urged his audience to buy their books elsewhere, an account Borders officials agree with.
"He said, 'Hey, there's a Rizzoli's down the street; you can shop there,' " Ms. Kohn said, referring to a competing store.
Mr. Moore denies it: "I don't want people to boycott Borders. Maybe someone said 'I don't want to buy your book at Borders' and I said, 'Maybe you can buy it somewhere else.' "
His next appearance at a Borders shop in the World Trade Center in New York also did not go smoothly.
Mr. Moore's version is that two officials of Borders canceled his speech an hour before the event, telling him they did not want to repeat Philadelphia's commotion. He said, "They told me I could sign the books but I was not to open my mouth," adding that when he took the dais he was flanked by two security guards he viewed as enforcers.
Ms. Kohn said the speech was scrapped because the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey police told the store to winnow the "enormous" crowds at lunchtime author sessions. The executives were there on other business, and many stores have guards, she said.
Two weeks later, after a signing party in a Des Moines high school gym (Borders provided the books), Mr. Moore said worried store employees hailed him in a parking lot, saying Borders ordered them to stay away. The Food and Commercial Workers are organizing at the Des Moines outlet; an election is scheduled for Dec. 10.
Ms. Kohn says that account is fiction and that Borders workers were given time off to attend the signing.
For Mr. Moore, the last straw was the cancellation of a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., book signing early this month. "They said they'd received a directive from corporate headquarters that Michael Moore would not be allowed to speak at any Borders nationwide," he said.
"That's not true," Ms. Kohn said. Rather, she said, Mr. Moore's appearance was never confirmed; the store decided on its own to bypass the event.
Ms. Kohn says she is "perplexed" by Mr. Moore's animosity. He says he is willing to take Borders at its word and resume appearances.
 In the meantime, he says, he is donating the royalties from 1,000 copies of his book to the union drive.

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Nov. 18 about a rift between the Borders bookstore chain and an author, Michael Moore, misidentified the labor group trying to unionize a store in Philadelphia. It is the Industrial Workers of the World, not the International Workers of the World.
