HEADLINE: New Bird Found in Brazil Forest Owes Survival to Cocoa

BYLINE: By LES LINE

 BODY:
OVER the last decade, some 20 new bird species have been found in the remote tropical forests of South America. None of them, however, have astonished scientists quite like an acrobatic treetop species with bubble gum-pink bill and legs that has been found nesting along one of Brazil's busiest highways, and owes its survival to the human craving for chocolate.
The warbler-size bird, called the pink-legged graveteiro ("twig gatherer" in Portuguese), lives in towering forest trees that shade cocoa plantations in the coastal state of Bahia. But cocoa production, once a major part of the Brazilian economy, has suffered a catastrophic blow from an accidentally introduced fungus disease. "The shade trees are being cut and sold as landowners turn to raising cattle or growing bananas," said Bret Whitney, a research associate at Louisiana State University and one of the ornithologists who discovered and documented the species. 
 "This remarkable new bird and its secrets could disappear in the coming decade," Mr. Whitney warned.
The discovery of the pink-legged graveteiro (Acrobatornis fonsecai), whose genus is also new to science, was announced in the current issue of The Wilson Bulletin, an ornithological journal, by Mr. Whitney and his Brazilian colleagues. The bird's Portuguese name is "acrobata," referring to its habit of foraging for winged termites and other small insects while swinging upside-down from the foliage of 140-foot-tall trees, or creeping along the underside of canopy branches heavily laden with bromeliads, lianas, orchids and mosses. The startlingly colored legs of the otherwise black and gray adults are unusually stout for a bird its size, Mr. Whitney said.
The pink-legged graveteiro belongs to the ovenbird family, a group of New World tropical birds with more than 230 species and found in virtually every kind of habitat, from cloud forests to deserts. The family gets its name from domed nest structures of hardened clay or mud that are built by several species and look like miniatures of the baking ovens common in rural Latin America. Several ovenbird species, including the graveteiro, construct huge arboreal nests of tightly interlaced sticks that the birds enter through long tunnels leading to one or more rooms.
Mr. Whitney said that after the Bahia species was found by two Brazilian friends in November 1994, he counted a number of its nests "along highway BR-101, which runs through the middle of its range and is as crowded with traffic as a freeway in the United States." He said the bird had been overlooked "because it stays way up in the canopy and its nest was confused with that of another species." Mr. Whitney said a total of 131 nests of the graveteiro were found at 53 different sites. But there was no estimate of the bird's total population.
For years, Louisiana State researchers have scoured the South American rain forests for previously unknown birdlife with considerable success. But the pink-legged graveteiro was found in a densely populated agricultural region, and Dr. Van Remsen of the university's Museum of Natural Science called it "the most exciting new species of bird discovered in decades." Dr. Gary Graves of the Smithsonian Institution said, "That it apparently occurs only or principally over cocoa plantations makes it all the more unexpected."
The excitement was tempered, however, by the knowledge that the bird's unusual habitat is rapidly disappearing. The cocoa planations of Bahia preserve a remnant of Brazil's once vast Atlantic forest, a coastal lowland ecosystem that was rich in endemic species but has largely been obliterated by logging, agriculture and living space for the majority of the country's human population. One of the world's rarest mammals, the golden-headed lion tamarin, is also found in the canopy over cocoa trees.
Cocoa was introduced into southern Bahia from the Amazon in 1746, and in the 1970's it was Brazil's second most important export after coffee, with more than 1.25 million acres planted in the crop. But the international price for cocoa crashed in the late 1980's, about the time a destructive fungus called witch's broom began to spread through the plantations. "Control of the fungus was expensive and ultimately not effective and cocoa production plummeted," Mr. Whitney said. "Plantation owners, often with reluctance, have little choice but to cut their valuable old trees and sell the timber for immediate cash."
Mr. Whitney said there was no officially protected forest and almost no intact native forest in the range of the pink-legged graveteiro. Cocoa, he explained, is cultivated by removal of the forest understory and thinning of the canopy to about 10 trees per acre. "This system has preserved, to a considerable extent, the humid microclimate upon which many forms of life depend," he said. "The canopies are almost continuous over large tracts and hold magnificent adult trees of a wide variety of species."
The ornithologist said that because of the failing cocoa industry, conservationists had an opportunity to buy two large blocks of land "to preserve a representative sample of the biodiversity in this part of the Atlantic forest," adding, "The cocoa could be removed and seedlings of native tree species planted to replace mature trees that are nearing the end of their life spans."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Yen but Falls Vs. Mark on Aide's Remarks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday but ended mostly lower, weakening after a top Bundesbank official surprised the market by saying he did not think the dollar could gain against the mark.
The remarks by Ernst Welteke, president of the regional central bank based in Frankfurt, contradicted a chorus of recent statements by other officials of the German central bank, including its president, Hans Tietmeyer, expressing support for a higher dollar. 
 "That was a shocker when it came out," said Elliott Dix, assistant vice president for foreign exchange at the Signet Banking Corporation in Richmond. "The Germans were the only ones giving a solid front, then Welteke comes out and blindsides us like that."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5015 marks from 1.5103 marks on Friday. The dollar rose to 111.48 yen from its seven-week low of 110.88 on Friday.
The British pound continued to trade at four-year highs against the dollar, up to $1.6662 from $1.6635.
Asked at a conference in Frankfurt whether the Bundesbank is now content with the dollar's level against the mark, Mr. Welteke said, "German exporters would like to see it go higher, but I don't see any reason why it should."
Although Mr. Welteke later backtracked and said the Bundesbank would like to see a stable and slightly higher dollar, his initial remarks still suggested a divergence of opinion in the German central bank over the dollar's value against the mark. The dollar fell sharply against the mark and other European currencies and never recovered.
"This was perceived to be a surprise," said Jim Powers, vice president of foreign exchange sales at Westdeutsche Landes Bank in New York. "All the others are supportive of a strong dollar."
Mr. Tietmeyer and other Bundesbank aides came out forcefully in support of a stronger dollar last week after it fell below 1.5000 marks. A weaker dollar hurts German exporters, who are helping lead Germany out of a prolonged period of economic weakness.

HEADLINE: Serbia Opposition Claims Municipal Vote Victory

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Serbia's opposition parties claimed victory today in municipal elections and called on President Slobodan Milosevic's governing Socialists to concede defeat, warning them not to tamper with the vote.
The four-party opposition coalition, called Zajedno, won control over 32 municipalities, including the capital, Belgrade, and several former Communist bastions, according to unofficial results from the vote, held on Sunday. 
 Mr. Milosevic's party suffered the biggest blow in Belgrade, where the Zajedno coalition won 12 of 16 municipalities, or 70 seats in the 110-seat city council, the opposition said.
The results would give non-Communists their first chance to form Belgrade's local government in more than 50 years.
The Socialists seemed surprised and unprepared for the returns, refusing immediate comment. They claimed to have won in some smaller municipalities, but the tone of their statements today was uncharacteristically humble.
The municipal councils have little real power, but the returns meant a symbolic loss to the President and could tarnish his image. They could also put a dent in the power of the leftist bloc made up of Mr. Milosevic's Socialists and the neo-Communist party headed by Mr. Milosevic's wife, Mirjana Markovic.
In a statement, the opposition warned the leftists against trying to annul vote results. "We will defend our election victory at any price, and we warn Slobodan Milosevic and his wife not to play with the people's will," they said.
About 10,000 opposition supporters crowded downtown Belgrade, where they threw firecrackers and blew car horns through early morning to celebrate.
"I call upon the European Union and the United States to bring Milosevic to his senses and make him admit that democracy has won," a Zajedno leader, Vuk Draskovic, told the cheering crowd.
In addition to Belgrade, the opposition also claimed victory in the industrial cities of Kragujevac and Nis. All three cities were once Milosevic strongholds, but workers are angry over Serbia's dismal economy, still largely in state hands.
Half the work force is unemployed, and those with jobs are often idle and have to wait months for wages.
Zoran Djindjic, the opposition candidate for mayor of Belgrade, said there had been many irregularities during the balloting, including fistfights in Nis and another town, Smederevska Palanka, and that opposition monitors were barred from several polling stations. The Government authorities had no comment.
Two weeks ago, Mr. Milosevic and his wife easily triumphed in elections for the Parliament that represents Serbia and its only partner in Yugoslavia, tiny Montenegro.
That victory could secure Mr. Milosevic's election by the legislature as Yugoslav President next year, when his second term as President of Serbia expires. He is constitutionally barred from a third term.

HEADLINE: A Generic Fighter Plane

 BODY:
Tight budgets, advanced technologies and the end of the cold war are at last bringing some sanity to the way the Pentagon buys new weapons systems. Lockheed Martin and Boeing have been selected as the surviving bidders in a competition to build a reasonably priced fighter plane that can be modified for use by each of the military services. The plan puts an old and honorable idea into practice. The logical notion of a generic fighter plane has been around for decades, but was always trumped by service rivalries and members of Congress eager to keep the aircraft plants running back home.
Military reformers have long known that use of a common aircraft by the Air Force, Navy and Marines could save billions. But reaching that goal will still require uncharacteristically rigorous management by the Pentagon and measured military spending by Congress. 
 Changes in the world order and the nation's budget priorities at home make this a timely step. Over the next two decades, the United States will need new combat aircraft to maintain its military power as China and other countries develop new planes of their own. But the urgency and scale of production need not match cold-war expectations. The cost of acquiring new planes must be held down to allow Federal spending on domestic programs.
The Pentagon seems determined to contain costs this time by setting a price of $35 million per plane and sticking with one design that can be adjusted for the varying combat demands of the Air Force, Navy and Marines.
Last weekend the Pentagon trimmed the field of potential manufacturers to Boeing and Lockheed Martin, dropping McDonnell Douglas from the competition. Even if Pentagon orders for the new plane are kept to a reasonable and financially sound level -- far below the 3,000 aircraft now estimated -- American and foreign contracts are likely to total several hundred billion dollars over the next 25 years.
Despite the expense, this approach is a striking departure from the old system of designing gold-plated weapons systems in Washington and insisting on costly Pentagon technical specifications in manufacturing. This time the Defense Department wants cost-conscious companies to produce a utilitarian design and come up with an economical manufacturing plan.
To survive in the much-tightened defense market, recently merged companies like Lockheed Martin have driven down production costs by negotiating labor concessions and turning over parts production to outside companies. Computer simulation has streamlined the design phase.
The new combat aircraft, known for now as the Joint Strike Fighter, must satisfy the Air Force's need for a nimble fighter that will replace its fleet of some 1,400 F-16's. The Navy is looking for a durable, stealthy attack plane that can be launched from aircraft carriers, and the Marines would like a warplane like the Harrier jet that can operate on short runways and land vertically.
Getting all those attributes from a single aircraft design will not be easy. Lockheed Martin and McDonnell Douglas produced plausible proposals based on relatively conventional aircraft technology, while Boeing offered a futuristic plane that resembles a flying wing. By eliminating McDonnell Douglas, the Pentagon seems to be betting on Lockheed Martin, while waiting to see if Boeing can produce a technological breakthrough.
None of this will work if Pentagon turf battles resume, abetted by Congressional trade-offs designed to shovel money into as many districts as possible. The Pentagon plan could also be undone if Lockheed Martin or Boeing find orders falling so far below expectations that they cannot take advantage of mass-production savings to keep the price down. But for now the Pentagon seems to be trying to change its wasteful ways. With aircraft production not expected to begin until 2008, there will be time to reconsider the plan if the costs start to escalate.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Is VW's New Plant Lean, Or Just Mean?

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

DATELINE: RESENDE, Brazil

 BODY:
At first glance, the work force at Volkswagen's truck and bus factory here seems like any other, clad in unremarkable gray uniforms. But look at the pockets, and you will see the key to what Volkswagen executives call the factory of the future. The names stitched there are Rockwell, Cummins, Remon and MWM. What are conspicuously scarce are Volkswagen workers.
In this new factory some 100 miles northwest of Rio de Janeiro, Volkswagen employs a mere 200 of the 1,000 workers, those responsible only for overall quality control, marketing, and research and design. The assembly work -- from counting spark plugs to bolting down engines -- is left to suppliers. 
 This is the "dream factory" that Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua has long promised would revolutionize auto manufacturing Mr. Lopez, Volkswagen's charismatic, controversial head of purchasing, quit General Motors in 1993 because that auto maker, he said, would never build it. General Motors, for its part, accused Mr. Lopez of stealing its plans for "Plant X," and building it here.
Whatever its origins, the plant, inaugurated this month, transforms Volkswagen from a manufacturer into a contractor, overseeing the work of other companies. Some eight major subcontractors have their own shops along the assembly line, where their workers assemble components, including parts from 400 suppliers, before dropping them onto chassis.
Volkswagen is betting that the system will reduce the number of defective parts, improve efficiency and cut costs. If it does, it could become a manufacturing model for the developing world, where almost all growth in the auto industry is expected to take place, According to Mr. Lopez, it could apply to other types of manufacturing as well.
But industry analysts ask whether Volkswagen's factory for the future is lean, or merely mean: whether it achieves true gains in productivity, or furthers a trend toward squeezing subcontractors and employees. Volkswagen's subcontractors shoulder more direct costs and risks, and the assembly-line workers are paid roughly a third as much as auto workers in Sao Paulo.
While Volkswagen calls this new way of putting together trucks and buses a "modular consortium," it can look like a Russian doll of auto making. The subcontractors include Brazilian companies like Delga Automotiva Industria e Comercio Ltda.; local subsidiaries of transnational corporations, like Rockwell International and Cummins Engine of America and Motorenwerk of Mannheim Eisenmann of Germany, as well as consortiums like Remon created for the venture.
This blurring of distinctions between suppliers and auto maker, as between electrical components and mechanical ones, is also a sign of change in auto manufacturing, said Sean McAlinden, manager of economic studies at the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan. "Who's the customer and who's the supplier?" he said. "In the future, those boundaries may not make sense."
While truck makers and Japanese auto makers have long relied heavily on pre-assembled components, "We haven't heard of a completely supplier-run plant before," Mr. McAlinden said.
With South America's largest economy and population, and with more than 90 percent of its goods transported by truck, Brazil is an important testing ground for Volkswagen.
"How things work in a country like Brazil matter very much indeed," Mr. McAlinden said. "It doesn't even matter if the product isn't meant for outside Brazil. The most important prototype plants today are prototype plants for the third world."
For the moment, the factory is producing only one truck a day, because of delays in installing some equipment, such as an electronic overhead monorail. The cab factory and the paint shop are not finished, and so for now, every truck produced here is white. Suppliers are using the time to train workers, who were hired without experience.
Instead of a traditional assembly line, on which a single piece of metal grows part by part into a truck or bus as it moves from worker to worker, Resende runs subassembly lines parallel to the main line. The process begins with a chassis delivered to a loading dock; as the chassis moves along the main line, each supplier simultaneously assembles its components.
At the first stop for a chassis, workers from Iochpe-Maxion mount the gas tank, transmission lines and steering box.
At it moves down the line, Rockwell-Braseixos workers mount the axles and brakes. At the next stop, workers from Remon put on wheels and adjust tire pressure.
MWM/Cummins prepares and installs the engine and transmission. The cabs -- supplied by the Ford Motor Company now, but eventually to be produced by Delga -- are outfitted by VDO do Brasil, a unit of Adolf Schindling A.G. of Germany. Painting will be done by Eisenmann.
When the plant reaches capacity next year, its two shifts are expected to produce 100 trucks a day, using only 800 assembly workers, compared with 2,500 in traditionally designed plants in Brazil. And Volkswagen is betting that with suppliers on hand to inspect each component before it becomes part of a vehicle, quality will be high. Volkswagen pays suppliers only when trucks are completed and pass inspection. If a component is not up to quality, the supplier is not paid.
That, some analysts said, could solve a major drawback of developing countries: quality control.
In Japan, for example, Toyota does not need such a system, said James P. Womack, an efficiency expert and co-author of "Lean Thinking: Banish Waste and Create Wealth in Your Corporation," because only 5 parts in a million are defective; in much of the developing world, defective parts can run 15,000 to 20,000 per million.
The plant also saves on wages, which the suppliers have all set at $374 a month, which Volkswagen says is in line with factory work in the Resende area. And, any down time on the assembly line -- say, because parts are missing -- is charged to the workers, who must make it up without overtime.
The plant's manager, Luiz Antonio Pinteado de Luca, said salaries usually accounted for about half the cost of producing trucks in Brazil. Nevertheless, he said he expected the biggest savings to come from logistics, even though one part of the strategy, just-in-time delivery, could be vulnerable to hitches like poor roads or strikes at supplier bases in Sao Paulo.
But industry analysts wonder how much of Volkswagen's lowered production costs depend upon simply paying workers and suppliers less.
"It's not clear how much is a fundamental efficiency game, and how much of it is a way to get people to work for less money," Mr. Womack said. Mr. Lopez's calls for a third industrial revolution, familiar to industry insiders, never mentioned lowering salaries, he said.
"Merely cutting wages does not constitute a revolution," Mr. Womack said. "It constitutes a counter-revolution, in some ways."
Volkswagen calls its suppliers in Resende "partners," and it required them to put up $50 million of the factory's $300 million cost. Despite their capital investment, they are not, like true partners, sharing profits.
Given the reputation Mr. Lopez has developed for muscling suppliers to lower prices, those at Resende said they designed their contracts with Volkswagen very carefully, building into prices, for example, allowances for Volkswagen's withholding payment until trucks are completed.
"Basically, we recognize that Mr. Lopez is a tough negotiator and tough with suppliers," said Sergio Carvalho, director of sales and service at Rockwell do Brasil. "But we foresee the chance to grow our market share with Volkswagen."
Ricardo Chuahy, director of operations at Cummins do Brasil, concurred. "The concept is very aggressive," he said. "If it works, other manufacturers will copy Volkswagen."
Similarly, Volkswagen maintains that the lower wages at Resende merely reflect the labor market. But while the plant's work force is expected to unionize eventually, local union leaders admit they are perplexed by its web of employers.
Much of the plant's success will depend on Volkswagen's ability to break into the domestic truck market dominated by Mercedes-Benz, a unit of Germany's Daimler-Benz, said Jose Roberto Ferro, an economics professor at the Getulio Vargas Foundation and local coordinator of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's International Motor Vehicle Program.
Volkswagen is counting on the Resende plant to be an important source of exports to Europe and South America, but it does not have a corresponding international distribution network, he said.
"It's a nice solution, and the primary reason it sounds so neat is because labor is so cheap, and it gives Volkswagen a massive two-by-four to wield against its unions in Sao Paulo," Mr. Womack said.
If so, the message was not lost: last week, workers at General Motors and Volkswagen plants in Sao Paulo accepted management's first offer on a new contract.

 Like Tom Sawyer and his fence-painting project, Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua designed Volkswagen's new truck plant in Resende, Brazil, around work done for Volkswagen's benefit by others. Major suppliers are assigned space in the plant and their own workers add components to trucks rolling down the assembly line. Volkswagen's employees, a minority in the plant, supervise the work and inspect finished trucks; only when they pass are the suppliers paid.

HEADLINE: 1.12 Loss Halts Dow's 10-Session Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average fell just shy of its ninth straight record yesterday as an afternoon rebound faltered in lackluster trading.
The Dow fell 1.12 points, to 6,346.91, also ending a string of 10 straight winning sessions that had produced a gain of about 325 points, or 5.4 percent. 
 Broader measures also finished lower as investors, expecting few market surprises from this week's light schedule of economic events, secured some profits on a stunning post-election rally.
"How long can you celebrate the election? You need some positive events to drive the market," said Robert Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Van Kampen American Capital in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., noting that no big earnings or economic news is expected in the next few days. "The market's going to be in a pretty tight range this week."
The market's early afternoon turnaround could be traced to another good day for I.B.M., which surged for the second straight session on positive comments by securities analysts. I.B.M. spent the morning lower amid some profit taking after Friday's 8 1/8-point advance, but then jumped higher after an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company raised his 12-month target price for the company's stock to 170 a share, from 145.
I.B.M. rose as high as 150, then settled to close at 146 3/4, up 1 3/4 on the day, giving the stock a two-day gain of 7.4 percent.
I.B.M.'s fortunes were not good enough to keep the rally going yesterday afternoon, and stocks fizzled in the absence of any broader news.
"The volume is contracting; you need to show superior firepower to keep it going," Gregory Nie, a technical analyst at Everen Securities in Chicago, said.
Declining issues outnumbered advancers by a narrow margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 388.5 million shares, down sharply from Friday's 529.1 million shares.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.60 point, to 737.02, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.12, to 389.90. The S.& P. 500 had closed at record highs in seven of the last 10 sessions, while the Big Board composite had set new marks in 8 of the last 10 trading days.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 7.23, to 1,254.57, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index fell 1.23, to 584.18.
The Dow's other big gainer was Boeing, which rose 1 1/2, to 93 1/4, after Saturday's announcement that the Pentagon had narrowed the competition for a joint strike fighter contract to Boeing and Lockheed Martin, cutting out McDonnell Douglas. McDonnell shares slid 4 1/4, to 52 1/2, in active trading, with several brokerage firms downgrading the stock. Lockheed rose 1 7/8, to 95 5/8.
The Dow's biggest loser was Texaco, which fell 2 3/4, to 98 3/8, as investors reacted to a settlement late on Friday in a racial discrimination suit against the company.
The Big Board's most active issue was Deutsche Telekom, which rose to 21 1/2 from an offering price of nearly $19 as the German state phone monopoly raised about $13.3 billion in an initial public offering.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Separate Trade Pact by Canada and Chile

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: TORONTO, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Bypassing a deadlock in Washington over whether to expand the North American Free Trade Agreement to include Chile, Canada today signed its own accord to open trade with Chile.
Although Chile, one of South America's fastest-growing economies, is not a major Canadian trading partner, commerce between the two countries has been growing in recent years and now exceeds $500 million (United States) a year. Canadian mining companies already have made big investments there, and businesses in both countries have formed more than 50 joint ventures. 
 Today's agreement removes tarriffs on three-quarters of all imports and exports between the two countries, with the remaining duties scheduled to be eliminated over the next five years.
But Canada's most important goal in pursuing a trade agreement was to pave the way for the eventual entry of Chile into the North American Free Trade Agreement, where it could help offset some of the dominance of the United States.
"We will keep pushing the U.S.," Prime Minister Jean Chretien told reporters after he signed the agreement in Ottawa with President Eduardo Frei of Chile. Mr. Chretien said he firmly supported "extending Nafta very rapidly" to include Chile.
A United States trade official, who spoke on condition that he not be further identified, said the Canadian agremeent appeared to be "a good interim step" that would help speed the process of Chile's admission to the North American trade bloc once negotiations with the United States resumed, perhaps early next year.
After the North American trade pact went into effect in January 1994, the three original members -- the United States, Canada and Mexico -- looked forward to expanding it to bring in other Western Hemisphere nations. In December that year, the leaders of the three nations announced their intention to begin the process of extending membership to Chile.
But that initiative got off track within weeks, after Mexico was forced to devalue the peso, setting off a financial and economic crisis that required a multibillion-dollar rescue effort led by the United States.
Mexico's problems soured many members of the United States Congress against free trade. The fast-track negotiating authority the Clinton Administration wanted before opening discussions with Chile became entangled in political disputes in Washington.
Fast-track authority allows for a trade agreement to be voted on without being subject to unlimited amendments. Without it, the Administration might have risked reopening the existing trade agreement with Canada and Mexico.
Chile has been eager to join the exclusive trading club. But the nation's leaders did not want to proceed unless the American legislative measure had the fast-track provision.
That was when Canada stepped forward to pursue its own negotiations. Trade with Chile has more than doubled since 1988, with Canada sending grain, minerals, machinery and paper products to Chile, and buying fruit, nuts, wine and fish.
Negotiations between the two nations snagged several times and nearly broke off over Chile's strict capital requirements. In the end, Canada accepted the Chilean demands.
All foreign investors in Chile are required to deposit almost a third of the capital they bring into the country with the Chilean central bank. The money remains on deposit for a year. Chile thus hopes to avoid developing an overreliance on speculative capital, or leveraged deals, of the type that damaged Mexico's economy before devaluation.
The United States trade official said that unless Chile changed its stance, the capital requirement would probably stand in the way of Chile's entry into the North American Free Trade Agreement.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Post Slight Drop

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended slightly lower yesterday, as a lack of economic data and the prospect of auctions later this week discouraged active buying.
"This could be a difficult week: The market's looking for reasons to move, and I don't really think it's going to get any," said George Adell, a trader at Starboard Capital Markets Inc., a Philadelphia-based firm. "There's going to be no direct news to drive the market." 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 2/32 yesterday, to 100 12/32, leaving its yield unchanged at 6.46 percent. The price of the two-year note also fell, driving its yield up to 5.67 percent, from 5.65 percent on Friday.
The Treasury, meanwhile, sold $14.1 billion in three-month bills and $14.1 billion in six-month bills at its regular weekly auction yesterday. The three-month bill was sold at an average discount rate of 5.03 percent, up slightly from 5.02 percent last week, while the six-month bill was sold at an average rate of 5.07 percent, the same as last week.
Weighing on bond prices yesterday was expectation that Wall Street firms would push yields higher to drum up demand for the $30.75 billion of notes the Treasury is selling this week.
"You have two auctions this week, so the market has backed up a little bit," said Terry Rose, who helps manage $2 billion of bonds at Advisers Capital Management Inc. The Treasury sells $18.25 billion of two-year notes today, and it will offer $12.5 billion of five-year notes tomorrow.
The market will also have more data to digest this week. Today, the Commerce Department reports on October housing starts. The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia releases a monthly survey of manufacturers in the mid-Atlantic region on Thursday.
In the corporate bond market, Tri Polyta, an Indonesian maker of resins and plastics, sold $185 million of seven-year Yankee notes, or debt sold by foreign entities in the United States. The notes were priced to yield 11.5 percent, 5.5 percentage points more than the comparable Treasury note.
Other companies are lining up to borrow while Treasury yields are low. Slim spreads, or differences in yield between corporates and Treasuries, have also made borrowing inexpensive.
"Rates are very favorable, spreads are very favorable," said Steve Bohlin, who manages $1.7 billion at the Thornburgh Management Company in Santa Fe, N.M. "The rumor is that there's a fair amount of supply ready to roll before year end."
Last week, companies including the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company and the Export-Import Bank of South Korea sold more than $4 billion of new bonds.
At least a dozen corporations are scheduled to sell at least $3 billion in bonds this week, with junk-rated corporations making up the bulk of the borrowers.
Some of the bigger expected sales include junk bond offerings by Allied Waste North America Inc., the Lamar Advertising Company and WCI Steel Inc.
Bonds are considered below investment grade, or junk, if they carry ratings below Baa3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Municipal bonds were little changed as investors looked for more attractive returns on the $3.8 billion in new bonds to be sold later in the week. About $225 million in new bonds were priced today.
Two San Francisco revenue bond sales lead this week's offerings.

HEADLINE: Losses May Signal End of Gambling's Lucky Run

BYLINE: By ADAM NOSSITER

DATELINE: CONWAY, Ark., Nov. 14

 BODY:
The congregation's opinion of gambling fitted as snugly with the Rev. David Hatfield's view as his low-slung brick church did with the neat houses across the road. The members of the Woodland Heights Baptist Church did not need much persuading that casinos were bad.
Gambling interests had flooded Arkansas television screens with one of the industry's biggest advertising campaigns. More than in two previous gambling votes in the state, this threat seemed urgent to Mr. Hatfield and to his congregation: nearly one-fifth of whom signed up to vote for the first time. The story was repeated across Arkansas and on Nov. 5., with help from many new voters, a casino proposal was crushed. 
 "I think people felt more of a threat this time," Mr. Hatfield said. "They saw an all-out barrage by gambling forces."
What happened in Arkansas on Election Day mirrored the larger picture across the country. In six other states, wagering proposals were rejected by voters. Only Michigan voted to allow casinos in hard-pressed Detroit. Elsewhere, voters appeared to combine new suspicions of the industry's economic optimism with old moral qualms while vigorous grass-roots campaigns like the one here worked hard to muster the anti-gambling vote.
This rejection appears to be part of a slight shift in the fortunes of the highly profitable gambling industry, still not universally accepted despite vigorous efforts to improve its image. Critics and boosters alike agree that the great period of gambling expansion appears to be over.
The National Coalition Against Legalized Gambling, a lobbying and advocacy group based in Washington, reports victories for anti-gambling efforts in over two dozen states in the last two years, in legislatures and in referendums. Industry proponents deride some of these as no more than isolated defeats for them.
But even advocates of gambling suggest that it may have reached a point of saturation, now that every state but Hawaii and Utah permits some sort of wagering. Frank Fahrenkopf, the president of American Gaming Association, said a better economy has lessened the demand for casinos and the like.
Critics of gambling cite a different reason for the apparent roll-back. They say long-standing public suspicion of the industry has deepened in the last few years, and politicians are becoming aware of this.
A 1995 survey by Gtech, the world's largest supplier of lottery equipment, found that sentiment for legalized gambling had declined by 10 percent since 1994 and concluded that support for the industry may be waning. Moreover, the anti-gambling coalition found that gambling initiatives had been defeated in the last two years in the legislatures of such states as Alabama, Hawaii, Maryland, Pennsylvania and Texas.
"All the polls show that the longer you have it, the more you have of it, the less popular it becomes," said Robert Goodman, a professor at Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., and the author of "The Luck Business" (Free Press, 1995).
Gambling's major defeat this year, in Ohio, was spearheaded by Gov. George V. Voinovich, who led a campaign against a proposal for eight riverboat casinos. Mr. Voinovich spoke out strongly and often against gambling's social costs, enlisting the aid of churches, businessmen and educators. The gambling initiative was defeated by 36 percentage points.
In Washington State, a successful drive to defeat slot machines on Indian lands was led in part by State Senator Dwight Pelz, Democrat of Seattle.
"I think most people have a distasteful image of slot machines as one-armed bandits for dazed idiots," Mr. Pelz said. "Folks are starting to realize it is not the magic bullet of economic development."
In Louisiana, voters cut back on gambling in the state, throwing video poker out of 33 of the state's 64 parishes in the wake of a legislative bribery scandal. But a heavy advertising campaign by the gambling industry helped secure a yes vote for the state's river casinos and the land casino in New Orleans. In Colorado, Iowa and Nebraska, voters rejected limited expansions of gambling while approving them in Arizona and West Virginia.
In a surprise result, voters in Michigan approved casinos for Detroit by three percentage points. Opponents had been so certain of defeating the casino proposal that they hardly bothered to mount a campaign, said Bill Ballenger, editor of Inside Michigan Politics. Mayor Dennis Archer had backed the proposal, as did the city's voters, irritated by a successful new casino across the Detroit River in Ontario.
In Arkansas, casino gambling has twice before been rejected by voters, in 1964 and 1984. But this year, with casinos in neighboring Mississippi and Louisiana drawing patrons from Arkansas, the state's voters faced growing pressure to approve a constitutional amendment that included a referendum for three casinos in Hot Springs, a lottery and bingo.
Gambling's backers here, principally Charles Cella, who owns the Hot Springs horse track and who would have gained one casino, outspent the opponents almost 6 to 1. Most of the opposition money, came not from citizens' groups but from Mississippi casinos, fearful of competition. In all, the proponents spent nearly $4 for every person in Arkansas, or about $10 million.
Still, the gambling proposals never led in polls, though in mid-October supporters drew almost even with opponents, worrying the Christian grass-roots campaign that had been organizing for over a year.
"I had some doubts about keeping our lead," said Larry Page, director of the Christian Civic Action Committee in Little Rock. "They were running their ads unopposed. It was saturation advertising."
But Mr. Page, whose group represents conservative evangelical churches, had anti-gambling coordinators in virtually every Arkansas county. Pastors copied the anti-gambling literature sent by Mr. Page, distributed it to congregants and used the pulpit to speak about the evils of gambling. His group also led a statewide drive for new voters, and a "substantial increase" was registered by the Secretary of State's Office, officials said.
On Sundays, the message in churches up and down the state rang out for months before Election Day, seeking to counter the industry's extensive advertising campaign.
"For me it was critical," said Stewart Bell, pastor of First Baptist Church in Searcy. "If there was ever a time I needed to take a stand, it was now."
The proposals were rejected 61 percent to 39 percent.
Mr. Hatfield of the Woodland Heights church summed up voters' sentiment this way: "I do wish the gambling forces would get the message: take your efforts somewhere else. We don't want it here."

HEADLINE: Typical Relief Check This Year Was Worth Half That of 1970

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Cash welfare benefits in the typical state have lost half their purchasing power in the last quarter-century, a Congressional committee reported today.
The report, by the House Ways and Means Committee, shows that the states as a whole have not increased the benefits nearly enough to keep up with inflation. 
 The data appear in the committee's 1996 Green Book, a compendium of facts and figures on welfare, Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid and other Federal programs.
They reflect payments during the period 1970-96, when, under the old Federal welfare law, states had wide discretion in setting the level of welfare benefits. Under the new law, enacted this summer, the states will have even greater authority, running their own welfare and work programs and setting benefits at any level they want.
The report shows that in January of this year, the maximum cash assistance payment for a family of three within the 48 contiguous states ranged from $120 a month in Mississippi to $703 in Suffolk County, N.Y.
In the median state, the maximum welfare payment for a three-person family was $389, up from $184 in 1970. But the purchasing power of this cash assistance, as reflected by adjustment for inflation, had declined by 51 percent since 1970, the Green Book says.
The decline was 43 percent in Connecticut, 59 percent in Illinois, 47 percent in Massachusetts and Michigan, 65 percent in New Jersey, 48 percent in New York City, 60 percent in Pennsylvania and 68 percent in Texas.
The report also makes these points:
*Legal immigrants who become citizens are less likely than native-born Americans to receive welfare, food stamps and Medicaid.
*Elderly people typically get back much more in Medicare benefits than they contribute in payroll taxes and premiums during their lifetimes. A man who retired in 1995, after working 30 years at the average wage, contributed $30,691 to Medicare but will typically get back benefits worth $80,442 after adjustment for inflation.
*Seventeen percent of the Federal budget is spent on "income-tested benefits" that provide medical assistance, welfare, food, housing and educational assistance to people of low or moderate income.
*Although Congress established the child-support enforcement program to help offset the costs of welfare, the Federal Government has lost money on it every year since 1979. Most states make a profit on it, though, spending less than they receive in payments from parents and from the Federal Government.
The study confirms that many people may lose assistance as a result of the new welfare law, which sets a five-year lifetime limit on payments to any family: although roughly half the families on welfare leave the rolls within one year, most of them return, the report says.
"In fact," it says, "of the 4.4 million families now on welfare, about 65 percent, or 2.9 million, will eventually be on welfare for eight years or more. Research also shows that despite the short welfare spells of some families, the average length of stay on welfare, counting repeat spells, for families enrolled at any given moment is 13 years."
The report also documents the growth of Medicare spending. After adjustment for inflation, Medicare spending per beneficiary grew by an average of 4.8 percent a year from 1990 to 1995. This included growth of just 2.5 percent a year, adjusted for inflation, in spending on hospitals and doctors. But it also included inflation-adjusted growth of 19.9 percent a year in spending on skilled nursing homes, and 28 percent a year on home health care and hospices.

HEADLINE: Shift in Zoning On Megastores Is Challenged

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY

 BODY:
Nearly two years ago, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed sweeping zoning changes that would allow huge warehouse-style stores to move into New York City's manufacturing areas, he called the changes a key component of his plans to revive the city's economy by adding jobs, raising new tax revenue and keeping consumers from spending money in the suburbs.
But yesterday, the proposal came before the City Council for its biggest test as Council members voiced community concerns that the zoning changes would prevent neighborhoods from having a say on where the stores should go and asserted that such "big box" stores would destroy the singular character of New York's many vibrant commercial strips. 
 In fact, the opposition has grown so strong in recent months that many Council members believe the Mayor's plan will have to be severely curtailed before it is finally approved. At the very least, in the first of two days of public hearings, they made clear that the proposal was headed for a tough fight when the Council votes on it in mid-December.
For hours yesterday, the debate revolved around whether the Council would lose some of its hard-won authority over land-use policy in the city and whether allowing the age of megastores to come into New York would ruin the city's tradition of neighborhood shopping. But also at issue was the question of whether the city should encourage megastores to locate in the five boroughs with a measure that allows no public input on where the stores will be situated, so long as they are in a manufacturing zone.
"There are several layers to this issue, starting with the future of manufacturing in this city, going to the viability of small businesses and to the role of consumers and residents," said Stephen DiBrienza, a Brooklyn Councilman who is one of the most outspoken critics of the Mayor's proposal.
"Then it boils down to a question of power," he continued. "And I'm not embarrassed to say that because that is the Council's role and that's what people in the community expect from us, to make sure that we, and consequently they, are not excluded from the process."
Mr. DiBrienza and many of his colleagues were expressing the concerns of neighborhood groups, particularly those that have fought to keep large stores like Pathmark or Home Depot out of their communities. They fear that the zoning changes would end their ability to challenge or stop a megastore from being built in their communities.
But Mr. Giuliani, in keeping with his general philosophy that business is overregulated in New York City, has said he believes that the public review process that requires community board and City Council approval is often tedious and has discouraged new development in the city.
After two and a half hours of intense questioning yesterday by Council members, Joseph B. Rose, the City Planning Commission chairman and the Giuliani administration's representative, said, "I understand now that we have a big job ahead of us."
The Planning Commission, which the Mayor largely controls, has approved the measure in an unusually close vote. Twenty-one community boards and the five borough boards had all recommended "no" votes.
Mr. Rose acknowledged that there was much opposition to the proposal, but he insisted that residents' concerns about being shut out were unfounded and said the changes provided a more uniform policy that actually protected neighborhoods across the city.
"This is an extremely narrowly drawn, well-planned and carefully considered proposal, and it has been misrepresented," he said. "Our retail economy is dying on the vine, but there are professional store stoppers who have made a cottage industry of stopping retail development in New York City, and the city simply can't afford it anymore."
Current zoning regulations, which were adopted in 1974 in an unsuccessful attempt to keep industries and lure new ones into manufacturing areas, prohibit large stores like 24-hour supermarkets and discount retailers from opening in industrial zones. But sprawling hardware stores like Home Depot and toy stores like Toys "R" Us are permitted, because they did not exist when the law was written and therefore were not explicitly prohibited.
The Mayor's proposal would repeal the restrictions and allow as many as 57 new superstores of any kind to open throughout the city on wide streets in areas zoned for light or medium manufacturing. The stores could be as large as 200,000 square feet, a little more than the size of four football fields, and they would be "as of right," which means that no public hearing process would be required and neighborhood views on where the stores go would not be solicited.
Throughout the daylong hearing, City Council members heard from small business owners who fear the superstores would destroy them and from borough presidents who voiced concerns about the loss of community input.
But some community leaders contended that minority areas desperately needed larger supermarkets that provided lower prices and better variety. And for a short time, about 100 construction workers filled the balcony of the Council chamber while 100 of their colleagues waited on the steps of City Hall, but they all left before their union representatives testified about how the construction industry would benefit from the development of new superstores.
Walter L. McCaffrey, chairman of the Council's Subcommittee on Zoning and Franchises, which organized the hearing, pointed to Chicago as a big city that has found a way to accommodate large stores without harming smaller retail or manufacturing businesses.
Donna M. Ducharme, a consultant and a deputy commissioner of Chicago's Planning and Development Department until last month, said Chicago had created "planned manufacturing districts" where viable industrial businesses are protected from other development, but buffer zones have been created around those areas where superstores are allowed.
"We agree with the assumption that there is an excess of manufacturing," Mr. McCaffrey said. "But the as-of-right approach prevents the community not just from being heard but from being felt, and the administration to date has not addressed that problem."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "OVERVIEW: Plan for Superstores"
A proposal to change zoning rules, which was approved by the New York City Planning Commission in October, came before City Council yesterday for the first of two day of public hearings. The proposal would allow as many as 57 new superstores to locate the city's manufacturing zones without going through the current arduous approval process.
 
EXISTING RULES
 
Current zoning restricts supermarkets, clothing and department stores larger than 10,000 square feet from opening in industrial areas. The stores that are exempt from the existing restriction include harware stores like Home Depot, toy stores like Toys R Us, and drugstores like Walgreen's.
 
Stores larger that 10,000 square feet can apply for zoning variances through community boards, the Planning Commission and the City Council. But that process can take up to three years.
 
PROPOSED RULES
 
The change would allow any kind of superstore as large as 200,000 square feet to open on wide streets in areas zoned for light or medium manufacturing, without a lengthy review process that includes community and City Council approval.
 
The changes would allow as many as 57 new superstores: 21 in Queens, 17 in Brooklyn, 8 in the Bronx, 6 in Staten Island and 5 in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Industrials Slip 1.12 As Profit Taking Halts Rally
The Dow industrials fell 1.12 to 6,346.91, ending a string of 10 winning sessions and falling just shy of a ninth straight record.
Broader measures also slipped, as investors secured profits made in the the stunning post-election rally that lifted the Dow 325 points, or 5.4 percent. The S.& P. 500-stock index fell 0.60 to 737.02, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 7.23 to 1,254.57. [Page D10.]
 
Treasury prices eroded slightly, as a lack of economic data and auctions scheduled this week discouraged active buying. [D21.]
 
Deutsche Telekom Comes to Market
Buoyed by a six-month ad campaign, shares in Deutsche Telekom's initial stock offering surged in Frankfurt to 33.90 marks, up nearly 19 percent from the opening price in the first day of trading. The offering raised 20 billion German marks, or $13.3 billion. In New York, the company's American depository receipts were the day's most active issue and opened at $22, up from the offering price of $18.89. But they eased during the day, closing at $21.50. [D5.]
 
Hewlett-Packard Earnings Off 4.4%
Hewlett-Packard reported a 4.4 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings to $648 million after the market closed. The company also announced a new Government-approved encryption technology for secure data transmission over the Internet. [D4.]
 
Lockheed Martin to Close 8 Plants
Lockheed Martin plans to close eight plants in California, Connecticut, New York and Pennsylvania to cut operating costs following its $9.1 billion Loral acquisition. [D2.]
 
For Gambling, a Possible Peak
With seven of eight states voting down gambling proposals, critics and boosters alike agree that the gambling industry's great period of expansion appears to be over. [A22.]
 
Kellogg to Buy Lender's Bagels
Kellogg said it would buy Lender's Bagels from Kraft Foods for $455 million, expanding its presence in breakfast foods. [D4.]
 
$1.5 Billion Pipeline Is Planned
Chevron announced that it and other big Western oil companies had agreed with the Governments of Russia, Kazakstan and Oman to build a $1.5 billion pipeline to send oil from Kazakstan to the West. [D8.]
 
U.S. Decision a Setback to RCN
RCN Corporation, a fledgling media company that is challenging Time Warner and Nynex in the cable and telephone businesses, faces a murky future; the Government rejected a bid by MFS Communications, a sister company, to transmit video over telephone wires. [D4.]
 
Europeans Avoiding Child Labor
In Europe, the use of child labor, particularly in the making of Oriental rugs, has galvanized public attention -- Ikea was pilloried in Sweden. After consulting with child-labor experts, Veillon, one of Switzerland's largest mail order houses, has adopted a code of conduct to insure that it offers rugs made only by adults. [D9.]
 
Big Bankruptcy in Japan
One of Japan's flashiest real estate companies, Sueno Kosan, was forced into bankruptcy, with more than $6 billion in bad debts. [D8.]
 
Canada-Chile Trade Pact
Bypassing a deadlock in Washington over whether to expand the North American Free Trade Agreement to include Chile, Canada signed its own Chilean trade agreement. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
THE American wine drinker's love affair with chardonnay continues to be as passionate as ever. Red wines have gained in popularity in recent years, with merlot and zinfandel now sharing the spotlight with cabernet sauvignon. Among white varieties, however, chardonnay has no serious competition.
California, the country's principal source of wine grapes, had 73,000 acres of chardonnay vines last year, according to Wines and Vines, a trade publication, compared with 11,000 acres of sauvignon blanc, the second most popular white variety. There were 44,000 acres of zinfandel vines in the state, 38,000 acres of cabernet sauvignon and 25,000 acres of merlot. 
 Chardonnay has become equally important on the world scene. So important, in fact, that many European wine makers are abandoning or modifying their traditional commitment to place names, like Macon and the Languedoc, and emphasizing that the wine in the bottle is made from the chardonnay grape.
With white wine so popular, one might expect to find an overwhelming supply of really fine white wines in the marketplace. There are plenty of them, but an appalling number of poor ones, too. Featuring the grape varietal name so prominently leads many consumers to believe that one wine, in this case chardonnay, is much the same as any other. Not so.
A cheap chardonnay from the south of France has almost nothing in common with a great white Burgundy, which also happens to be made from chardonnay. For that matter, it has little in common with an inexpensive chardonnay from California. Or one from Australia. Or from South Africa or Italy.
Indeed, the undue emphasis on the name chardonnay has led to plantings of the grape in relatively unsuitable places like the Pfalz region of Germany and in various parts of Italy. Chardonnays from Eastern Europe, which show up on these shores from time to time, are mostly worthless.
Adding to the confusion is the number of wineries in the United States pumping out chardonnay: some 700 in California, and a hundred or so each in Oregon and Washington. Include New York, New Mexico, Virginia and a dozen other states, and it adds up to quite a bit of chardonnay.
What's more, chardonnay seems to defy the basic laws of economics. Even though there is so much of it available, prices have risen rapidly in the last two or three years. That might be acceptable if quality improved at the same pace. It hasn't. In many instances, it's difficult, if not impossible, to tell a $30 California chardonnay from a $12 one. Often, wines selling for less than $10 are much better buys than wines selling for two or three times as much.
There has been -- and continues to be -- a serious shortage of good grapes, both red and white, in California. Phylloxera and other diseases have ravaged some of the best vineyards in the last six or seven years, and new plantings are not yet productive. At the same time, there has been a surge of interest in fine wines.
I must confess to what for want of a better phrase I'll call a longstanding disappointment with many West Coast chardonnays. I find them too heavy, too fruity and far too oaky. The oak flavor is supposed to be a subtle component in a good wine, the result of its having aged in an oak barrel. In many California wines, oak is the dominant flavor. This is particularly true with many inexpensive chardonnays that have not been allowed to age and have almost certainly been forced through oak chips or subjected to some other artificial process.
To dissociate themselves from the spirits industry, American wine makers vigorously promote their product as a beverage to drink with food. In fact, many chardonnays are difficult to match with food, particularly the lighter foods that traditionally are paired with white wine. Oaky chardonnay overwhelms most of these dishes.
It is not surprising that chardonnay is a popular sipping wine; often it's better as an aperitif than as a table wine. Nor is it surprising that, in comparisons, California chardonnays are frequently preferred to a Burgundy or Macon wine from France in the same price range. The French wine seems sharper and thinner, but will probably do better with fish or chicken than an American chardonnay.
Given these cavils, here are six chardonnays in the $10 to $12 range that will grace any holiday table:
EDNA VALLEY CHARDONNAY 1994 From California's south central coast, this wine has long been an example of moderation; the oak has never masked the attractive flavors of the chardonnay grape.
ESTANCIA CHARDONNAY This is a separate venture by the people who run Franciscan Vineyards in the Napa Valley. Estancia chardonnay comes from extensive vineyards in Monterey County.
LOUIS JADOT MACON VILLAGES 1995 Macon is a vast area between Burgundy and Beaujolais that is devoted almost entirely to white wine, all of it made from chardonnay grapes. Jadot is a Burgundy shipper with impeccable credentials when it comes to making attractive white wine.
GEORGES DUBOEUF BEAUJOLAIS BLANC 1995 White Beaujolais comes from the northernmost vineyards of Beaujolais, next door to the Macon region. Only an expert could tell the difference between the two.
GALLO SONOMA CHARDONNAY 1994 Gallo, based in Modesto, Calif., out in the hot San Joaquin Valley, owns hundreds of acres of the best vineyard land in Sonoma County. Its Sonoma wines, including this chardonnay, are extremely well made.
KENDALL-JACKSON VINTNERS RESERVE CHARDONNAY One of America's favorites. A touch of added sweetness seems to be the not-so-secret ingredient that has made this the catnip of California chardonnays.
 
TASTINGS
Vichon Winery Zyrah 1993, Napa Valley. About $12.
 
From the folks who brought you Chevrier, later Chevrignon, comes this latest flight of fancy, a combination of the names zinfandel and syrah, but actually a sort of varietal catchall. Those two grapes are there, but so are bits of grenache, mourvedre, cinsault, merlot and cabernet sauvignon. The name is pronounced ZEER-ah. Soon after Vichon Winery went into business in 1980, it made a big hit with Chevrier, a blend of sauvignon blanc and semillon. But not big enough. In 1985, when Vichon was nearing insolvency, the Robert Mondavi Winery, next door, took it over. First, Chevrier became Chevrignon; then some excellent cabernets appeared, and now there is Zyrah. The fad for Rhone-style wines seems to have abated in California, but this full-bodied one is definitely worth trying. After all, there can be 13 different grapes in Chateauneuf-du-Pape. This one's got only seven.

HEADLINE: F.C.C. Isn't Missing Data on Digital TV

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Nov. 16 editorial "Go Slow on Digital TV" did a good job of summarizing the issues before the Federal Communications Commission as it considers finalizing its tentative decision to adopt a new standard for digital television broadcasts. However, the statement that the F.C.C. "does not have the facts at hand to resolve the issues of innovation, cost and market access" is inaccurate, and your conclusion that the commission should go slow and appoint "an independent panel of experts to resolve key technical issues" is misguided. 
 The issues you highlight are not new. They were thoroughly investigated and debated during an eight-year process in which world-leading technology was developed and tested under the direction of the F.C.C. Advisory Committee on Advanced Television Service, which was appointed by the commission to arrive at a recommended standard. With the assistance of the Advanced Television Systems Committee, of which I am chairman, the advisory committee achieved a broad consensus and recommended a standard to the commission without objection in November 1995.
During the last year the commission itself has developed an extensive record that demonstrates that the proposed standard far exceeds its requirements and is the most interoperable, computer-friendly television system on the planet.
Yet, almost a year after the advisory committee delivered this breakthrough around a stunning technological achievement, the F.C.C. has still not acted. The sad paradox is that while unfounded concerns over computer interoperability have been permitted to delay adoption of a standard, a far less computer-interoperable standard -- begun in Europe three years after the technology was invented here in the United States -- is sweeping the world, and has even been adopted for two American direct-broadcast satellite services, stealing the economic benefits that should be accruing to American workers and the American economy.
Three of the four F.C.C. members understand this and are working to bring the matter to a final vote at the December meeting. The commission has all the relevant facts at hand, and it's high time that it follow through on its oft-repeated commitment to adopt a standard. Further delays would be unconscionable.
 
ROBERT K. GRAVES
Washington, Nov. 17, 1996

HEADLINE: Some Routine Lab Tests May Be Unnecessary

BYLINE: By DENISE GRADY 

 BODY:
THE little plastic specimen cup and the blood vials with the brightly colored caps have long been essential elements of that time-honored ritual, the medical checkup. But judging from recent research, the cups and vials, and the tests they represent, may be about as useful as the unclosable gowns that complete the examining-room experience.
A team of doctors from the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., has reported that four common sets of laboratory tests -- urinalysis, complete blood count, thyroid studies and the chemistry panel that measures various blood components -- were of little value in routine checkups of apparently healthy people. 
 "The chance of those tests actually finding something is very small," said Dr. Marc Silverstein, who directed the study, which was published recently in The American Journal of Medicine. Dr. Silverstein, who recently left the Mayo Clinic to become director of the Center for Health Care Research at the Medical University of South Carolina in Charleston, emphasized that his findings applied only to people having routine physicals, not those with illnesses that would lead doctors to order specific diagnostic tests.
An estimated $30 million worth of these routine tests are done each year, said Dr. Michael Bissell, a clinical pathologist who is chairman of the research advisory committee of the Clinical Laboratory Management Association.
Dr. Silverstein and his colleagues studied 531 patients, with an average age of 63, who visited the Mayo Clinic for checkups. The researchers looked at the "therapeutic yield" of the 1,508 laboratory tests ordered for those patients, that is, the percentage of the tests that revealed something that led to a change in treatment for the patients. Generally, the yield was low: 2.8 percent for the chemistry panel, and less than 1 percent each for thyroid, urinalysis and complete blood count.
Given those findings, Dr. Silverstein said, and today's pressures to economize, patients and their doctors might want at least to consider skipping some of the tests. He himself orders fewer tests than he did in the past. "I take more time to inform patients about what's recommended," he said.
Dr. Silverstein's findings came as no great surprise in medical circles. Before his study was published, similar recommendations about reducing tests during checkups had already been made by professional groups, including the American College of Physicians and the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, a unit formed by the Public Health Service.
Even so, Dr. Silverstein said, he did not expect his paper, or the professional groups' guidelines, to bring about quick changes in medical practice. "Patients expect lab tests," he said. And even when the tests do not show anything, patients may regard that as reassurance rather than money wasted.
Many doctors are in the habit of ordering tests partly to be thorough and partly to protect themselves from malpractice suits. "Physicians are very concerned about liability," Dr. Silverstein said. Although skipping the tests that he studied is unlikely to provoke a lawsuit, doctors may fear that if they are sued for something else, failure to test might be used as extra ammunition. "The general concern," Dr. Silverstein said, "is that since tests like these appear noninvasive and low cost, the courts will find they should or could have been done. But I think that since the expert panels have made their recommendations, physicians may need to worry less. They might have some defense."
Still, even at a progressive institution like the Mayo Clinic, where the department of medicine asked Dr. Silverstein to study laboratory tests, his findings have not changed the way things are done, and are not expected to in the future, a spokesman for the clinic said.
"It's the practice style at Mayo to order a lot of tests," Dr. Silverstein said. It is a point of pride there that the clinic has a longstanding and worldwide reputation as the place patients go when doctors at other hospitals cannot figure out what is wrong with them. "Patients expect tests and come here for this sort of thing," Dr. Silverstein said.
The tests themselves are harmless to patients, he said. "But the harm is that we're spending money that should be spent for other reasons," he said, citing more effective screening tests like those for breast, cervical and colon cancer, as well as the one laboratory test that his study did find useful: the lipid profile that can detect high blood cholesterol.
Dr. Silverstein's study did not include the commonly used test for prostate-specific antigen, or P.S.A., another common test that the task force has recommended against using routinely because of a high incidence of falsely positive results for prostate cancer.
The four tests that his study questioned cost about $165, not a great expense. "But in the aggregate they're substantial," Dr. Silverstein said.
Dr. Harold Sox, chairman of the department of medicine at Dartmouth Medical School, and chairman of the Preventive Services Task Force that also recommended against some screening tests, said, "The medical literature is full of examples in which doctors haven't changed their test-ordering behavior very much despite the findings of an important study or the release of guidelines from a reputable expert panel."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Mostly Stronger Except Against Surging Pound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Widespread weakness in the German mark left the dollar mostly stronger in foreign exchange trading yesterday, but the dollar fell against the surging British pound.
Although there was no news to spur additional appetite for the pound, traders said its momentum over the last several days pushed it past important technical levels that incited more buying. 
 "For sterling, the news only gets better there every day," said Rob Sabia, a vice president of foreign exchange at ING Capital Markets Inc. in New York. "Right now, it's attracting the most interest."
Britain is the only major industrialized country where interest rates are clearly going up, which makes assets denominated in pounds worth more.
Traders also increasingly view the pound as an alternative to the uncertainties created by Europe's planned single currency in 1999. Britain is not expected to participate in that plan initially.
"People are looking at sterling as the better buy, compared to marks, the Swiss franc and the dollar," said Charles Cheesman, an assistant vice president at the New York branch of Bank Austria.
In late trading in New York, the dollar rose to 1.5053 marks from 1.5015 marks on Monday. The dollar fell to 111.40 yen from 111.48 yen. The pound rose to $1.6739 from $1.6662, the highest since October 1992.
The mark weakened partly as a result of the pound's strength, as well as the diminished effect of conflicting comments Monday from Ernst Welteke, a senior Bundesbank official. Mr. Welteke first said he saw no reason why the dollar should gain against the mark but later retracted that comment. Other senior officials of Germany's central bank have been saying they want to see a stronger dollar, which will aid German exporters by making mark-priced goods more competitive abroad.
Traders said the mark also weakened after President Jacques Chirac of France, during a visit to Japan, expressed confidence in Europe's single-currency plan and France's ability to meet its strict criteria.
Such news has tended to hurt the mark, which will be replaced as the dominant currency in Europe by the single currency, known as the Euro, once the plan takes effect.

HEADLINE: Debt and More Debt

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I hope Russell Baker will allow me an addendum to his ruminations on our economically stratified society (column, Nov. 16). On the other side of the rainbow from the "rich, very rich and very, very rich," sand the in debt, the very in debt and the very-very-how-did-I-get-here in debt. 
 As someone who will accumulate approximately $400,000 worth of debt in my pursuit of higher education, I'd hate to be lumped with any poor slob who happens to have "maxed out" her credit cards to the tune of a paltry $5,000.
Instead, I have proudly joined the growing number of 20-somethings who will emerge, blinking, into the light with the equivalent of a house in Scarsdale tied to our bent backs. Happy holiday spending.
 
LIZ PRICE
Somerville, Mass., Nov. 18, 1996

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
A Sony expansion adds to San Diego's reputation as a center of technological manufacturing.

BYLINE: By Kevin Brass 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
SONY ELECTRONICS INC. is adding a warehouse and distribution center the size of six football fields to its already substantial manufacturing complex in San Diego.
The 394,000-square-foot building will be part of the 95-acre Sony Technology Center in the community of Rancho Bernardo, in the northern inland section of San Diego, about 20 miles north of downtown. 
 In 25 years the San Diego operation has grown into Sony's largest industrial center in the United States, with more than one million square feet of industrial space and 2,500 employees. It is the home of Sony's United States operations for manufacturing televisions, computer display systems, wireless phones and optical storage products, including CD-ROM's.
In addition to the new warehouse and distribution center, construction began earlier this year on a 210,000-square-foot, three-story structure in Rancho Bernardo to house an engineering operation. Sony is also expanding plants in the Tijuana, Mexico, area, south of San Diego, that manufacture televisions and computer monitors.
"The San Diego area has the large labor pool for both manufacturing and engineering talent that we need," said Richard Clancy, vice president of corporate communications for Sony Electronics.
The proximity to Tijuana and the shipping port of Long Beach, Calif., were also factors in Sony's decision to expand in San Diego, Mr. Clancy said.
Other Asian consumer electronics giants -- Sanyo, Casio, Uniden, Matsushita and Samsung -- have large manufacturing and research centers in both San Diego and Tijuana. More than 11 million television sets are produced in the San Diego-Tijuana area each year.
The county also has the fourth- largest concentration of biotechnology companies in the country, according to a 1995 study by the accounting firm of Ernst & Young.
San Diego is "probably 20 years behind Silicon Valley but we're moving fast," said Barbara Bry, director of programs for Connect, a privately financed support agency formed by the University of California at San Diego and the local high-technology industries. The high-technology region known as Silicon Valley is south of San Francisco.
In addition to the Rancho Bernardo area, large high-technology industrial developments have grown in Otay Mesa; Sorrento Mesa, along the coast north of downtown San Diego, and in the city of Carlsbad, north of San Diego.
One attraction of the San Diego region is a legacy of the miscalculations of the last decade: the region was overbuilt, and prices for industrial space plummeted in the first part of the 1990's, according to real estate experts. "Many of the properties have been a bargain compared with other metropolitan areas," said Gary London, a real estate consultant.
As recently as 1994, the vacancy rate in industrial space was more than 10 percent, Mr. London said. Now it is closer to 6 percent. Consequently, land and lease prices are rising again.
High-technology industrial space is the "healthiest sector in the San Diego economy," Mr. London said.
In recent years the City of San Diego has had a program to help streamline the permit and fee process for large companies. Water and sewer hookup fees have been cut by 50 percent, according to Steven Weathers, vice president of the San Diego Regional Economic Development Corporation, a private nonprofit organization.
"That is having a huge impact," said Tim Hoag, vice president of John Burnham & Company-Oncor International, a real estate company.
One of the fastest-growing San Diego companies is Qualcomm Inc., which has developed a digital wireless phone technology. Qualcomm occupies more than two million square feet of space in San Diego.
In 1994, Sony joined with Qualcomm to form Qualcomm Personal Electronics, which designs and manufactures digital cellular phones. The phones using Qualcomm's technology are built in Sony's expanding San Diego complex.
Sony moved into San Diego in 1972, when it built the first television assembly plant established by a Japanese company in the United States.
For the new warehouse and distribution center, Sony is leasing the property from Mitsui Real Estate Sales and Tenant First Real Estate Services of San Diego. They are building the structure to Sony's specifications.
Mitsui and Tenant First used a similar arrangement earlier this year to build a 110,000-square-foot office and warehouse for the Matsushita Television Company in the Otay Mesa area, near the Mexican border. The building will house the North American and South American headquarters for Matsushita, which were previously in Chicago.
With large vacant industrial sites scarce, more companies are doing these "build to suit" industrial projects in San Diego, Mr. Hoag said.
