HEADLINE: Opting for an Early Warning When E. Coli Is Suspected

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

 BODY:
IT was the day before Halloween and officials at the Seattle-King County Health Department had to make a decision quickly. Should they go public with their finding that there was a strong link between a recent outbreak of illnesses due to E. coli bacteria found in Odwalla apple juice, or wait for further proof? More than 700 illnesses and four deaths were reported three years earlier in the Northwest during an E. coli outbreak traced to hamburgers sold at a fast-food chain.
The evidence in this latest incident, though fairly strong, was not conclusive: 6 of the 10 people who had become ill said they drank an Odwalla product. Carl Osaki, the director of environmental health with the Seattle-King County agency, decided to make the announcement. 
 "We could have been wrong," Mr. Osaki said in a telephone interview last week. "We could have ruined a business, but the probability of our being wrong was about 10 percent."
There was another consideraton, Mr. Osaki added. "It was the day before Halloween," he said, "a time when a lot of apple juice and apple cider are consumed."
Odwalla Inc., a juice processor in Half Moon Bay, Calif., was notified of the impending announcement. The company voluntarily recalled all of its products made with unpasteurized apple juice as well as a few non-apple products that were processed on the same assembly lines as those that contained apple juice.
Dr. David A. Kessler, the Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, and other F.D.A. officials held a marathon telephone conference call with health officials from Seattle-King County, the State of Washington and the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, which lasted until 3:30 A.M. As many as 40 people were on the line at various times, discussing further action by the Food and Drug Administration, including nationwide notification of the recall.
The conferees unanimously agreed that Washington State had made the right decision despite the lack of one important piece of evidence, one that is traditionally required before any recall is instituted: the results of microbial testing that would have confirmed that the E. coli O157:H7 bacteria causing the outbreak had come from Odwalla's apple juice.
"One of the major decision points is whether you act on the basis of epidemiology only or do you wait for the microbial testing," Dr. Kessler said. Because Seattle-King County has an effective reporting system for E. coli in place, all of the health officials thought it was prudent to notify the public.
Washington State and Minnesota have the most sophisticated response systems to outbreaks associated with E. coli, according to the Food and Drug Administration. Seattle has a major children's hospital that carefully follows potential public health problems. In addition, scientists now have the ability to match the genetic fingerprints of the bacteria found in patients who contract an illness so they can identify the source. And Seattle-King County has adopted a set of non-leading questions to help elicit information about the possible sources of an illness. In the Odwalla case, for example, patients were not asked directly if they drank the company's apple juice: they provided the information unsolicited.
"Seattle gets an enormous amount of credit for having strong surveillance of E. coli in place," Dr. Kessler said.
The particular strain of E. coli in question can cause hemolytic uremic syndrome, the leading cause of kidney failure in children, which can lead to death in the most extreme cases. Symptoms include bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramping and vomiting. Elderly people and children under 12 (especially those under 5) are particularly vulnerable.
The bacteria are usually found in the manure of animals like cows. Apples may become contaminated when they fall from trees or when someone with the bacteria comes in contact with the food. The pathogens can be eliminated by washing uncut apples thoroughly and boiling or pasteurizing apple juice.
No one has yet determined how the bacteria got into the apple juice, but subsequent inspections of the Odwalla plant by the Food and Drug Administration have not found any E. coli at the plant. But the agency did uncover some inadequacies in the plant's sanitation systems, though no conclusions were made about a relationship to the E. coli outbreak.
Odwalla products are sold in seven Western states and in British Columbia. A total of 64 cases have been reported since the first was confirmed on Oct. 10. There has been one death in Colorado.
"And now we are seeing secondary cases," Mr. Osaki said, describing people who have been infected by those who became sick from the apple juice.
"It could have been a much larger problem," he added. When the microbial testing was completed last weekend, E. coli was found in one of the recalled bottles of juice.
Today, scientists are trying to decide if pasteurizing apple juice products would eliminiate E. coli contamination and should therefore be required. At a news conference on Monday, Odwalla announced that it had stopped production of all fresh apple juice products until it had set up a better safety monitoring system. It recommended that other producers do the same.
"This is the kind of issue we have to confront increasingly because we are eating more and more uncooked produce and because of an increasing global economy," Dr. Kessler said. "There is also a difference of opinion about whether E. coli 0157:H7 is an emerging bacterium or whether the reporting system is better."
There have been at least three outbreaks since the 1993 Jack-in-the-Box episode, the most recent a serious incident in Japan this year.
"At the very least we need to have an early warning system in place," Dr. Kessler said.
 
Before You Sip Or Slice or Bite
PRECAUTIONS can be taken to lessen the chances of becoming ill from products contaminated with E. coli 0157:H7. Here are some of them:
* Always wash hands before handling food.
* Do not eat whole apples if the skin has been punctured. Scrub apples before eating them.
* Look for pasteurized apple juice (apple juice in refrigerated cases may be unpasteurized). If you are unsure, write to the manufacturer for information.
* Unpasteurized apple juice purchased in a store or at a roadside stand should be boiled for 30 seconds before drinking.
* Hamburgers should be cooked to an internal temperature of 155 degrees.
There is also much less chance of being infected by solid pieces of beef like steak, because the interior is sterile and the exterior is always cooked long enough to kill bacteria.

HEADLINE: The Fattening Of America

BYLINE: By DONNA ST. GEORGE 

 BODY:
THE next time you hear about a friend's low-fat diet, the next time you see a kitchen stocked with low-fat cookbooks and fat-free snacks, consider this: Three of the fastest-growing foods in America are hamburgers, french fries and chicken nuggets.
Several years after low-fat eating became a full-fledged national obsession, there are signs that many Americans may have had their fill of fatlessness. 
 For the fourth year in a row, America is not eating more better-for-you foods, even as new low-fat items show up daily on supermarket shelves, according to a survey published this week by the NPD Group in Rosemont, Ill., a marketing research company that has tracked eating habits for 16 years.
At the same time, America is big on restaurant junk food, feasting on almost eight million more orders of french fries, nearly six million more hamburgers and five million more servings of chicken nuggets in a two-week period this year than last, the survey found.
"You can tell me all you want about how you're concerned about health and you're eating healthy foods, but then who's eating all of these hamburgers?" said Harry Balzer, a vice president of the NPD Group.
In their 11th annual report, "Eating Patterns in America," Mr. Balzer and his researchers did their best to find out what Americans actually eat, rather than what they say they eat.
They did this by relying on meal-by-meal dairies, kept by 2,000 households and mailed in daily, to avoid regretful revisions. It turns out that, when it comes to talking about how they eat, Americans are prone to fib or forget. Diaries are not foolproof either, the researchers admit, but they come closer to depicting real life. "You wouldn't trust what they tell you, not when it comes to food," Mr. Balzer said. "They begin to make value judgments about what society would prefer, not how they behave."
Part of the reason eaters are secretive is they "want their fries, and they want to cut their fat, too," said Dr. Warren Belasco, a professor of American studies and a food historian at University of Maryland's Baltimore County campus. "I just see Americans with very contradictory tendencies," he added. "We feel guilty. We worry about it. But we still go on eating what we eat."
Instead of giving up chocolate-chip cookies for nutritious fruit and grains, for example, many people opt for popular low-fat brands like Snackwell -- and imagine that they are health-conscious.
And often one or two low-fat cookies are not enough. "What they don't tell you is that they eat the whole box instead of three or four cookies," Mr. Balzer said.
The new survey found that 86 percent of Americans consume at least one low-fat or no-fat food every two weeks. Over all, 31 percent of the American diet is better-for-you foods. But for four years, that percentage has not budged. "It's hit a plateau," Mr. Balzer said. "There still is a health trend, but it's not going to be low fat anymore."
In supermarket aisles there are also signs of a low-fat lag, based on a sampling of sales figures from Information Resources, a Chicago company that tracks supermarket sales. For example, sales of Snackwell cookies and crackers soared from 1992 to 1995, then dropped 20 percent from 1995 to 1996. Over all, sales are flat for low-fat frozen dinners and Healthy Choice frozen desserts, according to Information Resources.
Snackwell officials said that, with a greatly expanding product line, the company's annual sales have jumped $200 million in spite of the plunge in cookie and cracker sales.
At the same time takeout restaurants are doing a booming business, surpassing table-service restaurants for the first time. In a decade, takeout food has jumped from a 35 percent share of the nation's restaurant business to more than 50 percent.
More and more, people are wolfing down fast food in their cars, in a kind of pit-stop dining, food as fuel. That may help to explain the top five fastest-growing restaurant foods and beverages: soft drinks, tap water, french fries, hamburgers and chicken nuggets.
"You want a dangerous health trend?" Mr. Balzer said. "The one that will kill you is driving down the road eating and talking on your phone, trying to avoid hitting the construction workers."
That people are confessing to such french-fried habits may suggest less embarrassment, more of a collective shrug, about unhealthy eating. "It may be a backlash against nutritional correctness, like the backlash against political correctness," said Dr. Belasco, the food historian.
The survey comes in a year when McDonald's gave up on its low-fat hamburger, the McLean Deluxe; when obesity rates are rising and when a newly popular book, "Eat Fat" by Richard Klein (Pantheon, $24), talks up the virtues of fat.
But other trends may give more comfort to nutritionists. While takeout food is on the rise, for instance, American families eat dinner together five nights a week, the NPD survey found.
To Bonnie Liebman, the director of nutrition at the Center for Science in the Public Interest, where healthful eating is a daily crusade, most of the survey results are a bit disappointing. Referring to hamburgers, fries and chicken nuggets, she said, "If you had to make a list of the worst foods to eat, they are way up there."
But Ms. Liebman contends that the low-fat movement has had a lasting effect. "Some people have cut down on fat," she said. "It's a big country."
Other experts question whether fat is really on the way out of the American mind. Dr. Marion Nestle, the chairwoman of the department of nutrition and food studies at New York University, said that the most health-conscious Americans tend to be highly educated, well-to-do city dwellers. "Everybody I know is still concerned about fat," she said.
Mr. Balzer argued that age, not economic status, was the greatest determining factor in healthy eating: older people watch their diets more than younger people.
He also maintained that old habits were hard to break and that better-for-you food allowed many Americans to avoid the painful task of giving up old favorites. These are the days, after all, of lower-fat Twinkies, pork sausage and chocolate cake. Never mind all the empty calories. "Manufacturers have given us the perfect way to keep eating what we like and feel healthy," he said.
Mr. Balzer understands the penchant for self-deception. A pushover for oatmeal-raisin cookies himself, he tells people: "I'm big into grains." As he explained it: "There's flour in there. Flour's a grain."

HEADLINE: The Pope's Visit to Cuba

 BODY:
Like Mikhail Gorbachev's visit to the Vatican in 1989, Fidel Castro's meeting with Pope John Paul II yesterday was infused with political as well as religious meaning. The Polish Pope, who helped accelerate the collapse of European Communism, agreed to visit Cuba, a largely Roman Catholic island that is one of the last redoubts of Marxist rule. The Catholic-educated Mr. Castro, in power nearly 37 years, had never before met with a pope.
The Pontiff and the Cuban dictator are experienced and determined fighters for opposing causes. Yet each now sees possible gains from a papal visit, despite obvious risks for both men. If all goes well, the biggest winners could be the Cuban people. 
 The Pope would like to extend his career-long crusade for human rights and democracy to yet another Communist land. He is insisting on the same ground rules in Cuba he has negotiated for all of his travels, including the freedom to go anywhere and meet with whomever he chooses. Institutionally, he would like to open up more space for an officially constrained Roman Catholic Church and its unofficially persecuted believers.
When Fidel Castro seized power, he shut down hundreds of Catholic schools and expelled hundreds of priests. Today Catholicism can be freely practiced in Cuba, but its public role is largely confined to church premises. The Pope will probably seek greater church access to the news media and an end to unofficial discrimination against practicing Catholics in public and professional life.
In Communist Cuba as in Communist Poland, the church represents the only major social institution not controlled by the Government. Looking to the future, the Pope will try to give the church a wider role in whatever political transition takes place after Mr. Castro leaves the scene.
For Mr. Castro, a papal visit can give broader legitimacy to his regime. He may especially hope to take advantage of the Vatican's opposition to all forms of economic sanctions to maximize Washington's isolation over the reckless Helms-Burton law, which provides for the punishment not only of Americans but of foreigners who do business with Cuba.
The Pope's plans to preach the gospel of freedom on Cuban soil ought to point the way to a wiser American policy, one that recognizes the reality of Mr. Castro's present power but seeks to influence the future by directly engaging the Cuban people, rather than trying to coerce an unwilling world into shunning them.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Show An Advance

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices advanced yesterday for the first time in three sessions after a surprise slump in home building buoyed expectations for a slowing economy and restrained inflation.
"Housing was the one thing in the economy that wasn't slowing," said David Hoffman, who manages $300 million of bonds at Brandywine Asset Management in Wilmington, Del. Bond investors "have one more piece of evidence that there's very little in the way of inflation pressure," he said. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 14/32, to 100 25/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.43 percent, from 6.46 percent on Monday. The price of the two-year note also rose, driving its yield down to 5.65 percent from 5.67 percent.
Bond prices started to rally after the Commerce Department reported that housing starts fell 5.1 percent in October, the slowest rate in a year. The market had been expecting an increase for the month, following a decrease of 6.1 percent in September. In addition, building permits fell 2.7 percent in October.
The data pointed to continued moderate growth for the economy and a steady interest policy from the Federal Reserve as a result.
Such expectations were confirmed by private reports yesterday that showed a slump in retail sales as the crucial holiday shopping season approaches. LJR Redbook Research said sales fell 2 percent in the week ended Saturday. Sales fell three-tenths of 1 percent in the week, according to the Mitsubishi Bank-Schroder Wertheim index.
The rally in bonds, however, did little to spur demand at the Treasury's sale of $18.255 billion of two-year notes. In a sign of less than stellar demand, the bid-to-cover was 2.11, less than the 2.39 average at the previous 10 sales. The bid-to-cover ratio is the number of bids compared with the total amount of securities sold. The new two-year notes also sold at a yield of 5.662 percent, more than the 5.657 percent that traders expected before the sale.
Investors are already "somewhat tapped out" after buying enough securities to drive yields to the lowest since early March, said Mark Sauvigne, a trader at Chase Securities. "When you asked a lot of people it seemed like not a lot had interest."
What's more, some traders may need to sell securities to make way for the $12.5 billion of five-year notes the Treasury is selling today, he said.
Some bond managers are betting the rally will fizzle. "We're not in a recession, and I think we're going to have to start to see a recession to justify some of these yields," said John Burgess, who helps manage $70 billion of bonds at Bankers Trust Global Investment Management in New York.
In the corporate bond market yesterday, the First Security Corporation, the Arizona Public Service Company and CIT Group Holdings Inc. sold a total of $350 million of debt amid continued strong demand for bonds which pay more than Treasuries.
First Security, a bank holding company based in Salt Lake City, sold $150 million of 10-year notes yielding 6.9 percent, or 75 basis points more than the comparable Treasury. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In other trading, Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, raised $500 million in a sale of three-year global bonds which were sold to investors around the world.
Following are the results of the Treasury's auction of two-year notes yesterday:

HEADLINE: U.S. Readies $100 Million Erie Canal Plan

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
The Federal Government is on the verge of announcing a $100 million revitalization of the waterfronts along the Erie Canal and its connecting waterways, a plan aimed at increasing tourism in a region that has been hurt by a sharp loss of jobs.
The plan has several features that are similar to one announced 16 months ago by the New York State Thruway Authority, which operates the 524-mile system of canals. 
 But that plan stalled in a dispute between Gov. George E. Pataki and the authority's chairman at that time, Peter Tufo, who refused to surrender his job despite being a Democrat in a Republican administration.
Now the idea of rebuilding the waterfront along the canal system has been revived by Andrew M. Cuomo, an assistant secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the son of former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
The new plan was to have been announced today at a news conference where Mr. Cuomo was to appear in Syracuse and Albany with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. But the announcement was postponed because some financing and other issues had not been resolved.
The effort to mount a new canal plan has been the subject of intense and often contradictory political speculation. Mr. Cuomo has been mentioned in political circles as a possible candidate for Mr. D'Amato's seat. He has also been mentioned as a candidate for Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, a job that would require confirmation by the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs, which Mr. D'Amato heads.
Thus there was a tangle of theories, many of them conflicting, about what Mr. Cuomo's motives might be in pushing ahead with the canal revitalization plan.
Mr. Cuomo declined to discuss details of the new plan yesterday. But he said that loans and grants totaling "in the range of $100 million" would be made available to scores of cities and towns bordering the canal to create shops, canal landings, parks, housing and improved streetscapes.
The aim would be to transform the historic but commercially moribund canal into a magnet for American and foreign travelers and for economic development benefiting the canal's municipalities. Cities and towns like Buffalo, Rochester and Fulton have been losing manufacturing jobs for years, and a revitalized canal would provide a way to animate their economies, he said.
"Where is their economic future?" he said in a rhetorical manner reminiscent of his father. "Bingo. What you come up with is the barge canal as an asset unique to New York. What can you do with the barge canal? You use it to generate economic development projects as well as regional approaches that would use the entire breadth of the canal, creating jobs, revenues, a tax base."
Mr. D'Amato, who is familiar with the canal from his days as a student at Syracuse University, predicted that each Government dollar would invite $4 of private investment, giving the canal project the potential to yield more than $400 million in investment. He called the HUD plan a "fait accompli."
A 10-page draft outlining the HUD plan, called "The Canal Corridor Initiative," that has been distributed to local officials said that as much as $120 million would be made available. Of that amount, $60 million would be in grants to small cities and towns and the rest in loans to large cities like Syracuse. The localities could compete for the money by filing development proposals.
The mule-drawn barges of the Erie Canal opened the Midwest to commerce from the Northeast and the Atlantic 170 years ago. The canal survived competition from the railroads, but the building of superhighways and the St. Lawrence Seaway rendered it obsolete.
In July 1995, Mr. Tufo, as head of the Thruway Authority, disclosed plans to spend $146 million over 15 years to spruce up the waterfronts of seven cities and towns on the canal. The money would have come from government and private financing as well as Thruway tolls.
The chief aim of his plan was to capitalize on the canal as a recreational asset for boating, biking and hiking, as well as for tourism.
But his announcement annoyed Governor Pataki and his aides. They were already seething that Mr. Tufo did not promptly surrender his post as Thruway chairman. They saw his Erie plan as an additional sortie to garner publicity in his long-range ambitions to take over the Governor's job. They also thought it was imprudent to be discussing spending state money on what Mr. Tufo called a "recreationway" at a time when the state was facing huge deficits.
When Mr. Tufo departed in January, a reconstituted authority soft-pedaled the Erie Canal plan, and in July a new five-year canal plan was announced that Mr. Tufo criticized for restricting Thruway funds to a bare-bones minimum.
The effort to revive the canal survived because the bordering towns and cities want some comprehensive plan that would draw travelers and boaters to take pleasure trips on the canal, which winds through the pleasant scenery of western New York, the Finger Lakes, the Mohawk Valley and up to the Adirondacks. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who has long had a fascination with the history of the canal, and Mr. D'Amato were brought in, and a new plan was worked out to use HUD money.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Obstruction Charge For Ex-Texaco Official
The former Texaco executive who recorded senior company officers belittling minority groups and planning the destruction of documents that were demanded in a discrimination lawsuit was charged with obstruction of justice. Those tapes set off a furor over the company's relations with minorities, and led to Texaco's record settlement of the bias suit last week.
Richard A. Lundwall, who until August was a senior finance executive at Texaco, had given the tapes to plaintiffs' lawyers in the suit. Mr. Lundwall was the first Texaco executive to be charged in the case. [Page A1.]
 
Housing Starts Drop 5.1%
Housing starts fell by 5.1 percent in October, the second consecutive month of diminished activity. The drop, which surprised analysts, raised questions about whether economic growth might be faltering. [D2.]
 
I.B.M. Up Again, Fueling Market
The Dow industrials surged 50.69 to 6,397.60, the ninth new high in 10 sessions, as money managers scurried to add I.B.M. shares to their portfolios. I.B.M. jumped 7 3/8, to 154 1/8, and other leading technology stocks also rose steeply. Broader measures gained, as well, with the Nasdaq composite rising 8.05, to 1,262.62. [D6.]
 
Treasury prices advanced, pushing the yield on the long bond down to 6.43 percent. [D16.]
 
G.M.'s New Models in Demand
General Motors has some popular new models this fall, but under its manufacturing schedule the new cars and mini-vans are arriving in dealerships in a trickle, not a flood, to the consternation of analysts and dealers. [D3.]
 
Investment Adviser in Guilty Plea
Teresa V. Fernandez, an investment adviser working from her home in Tenafly, N.J., pleaded guilty to fraud; prosecutors said she had stolen more than $65 million from clients. The S.E.C. also filed a complaint. [D3.]
 
Utility Turns to Power Marketer
Seeking big cost cuts, Oglethorpe Power, a big Georgia utility, is turning to an outside power-marketing company, LG & E Energy, to supply half its electricity needs. [D2.]
 
Intel and E.P.A. in Novel Plan
The Environmental Protection Agency granted a huge Intel chip-making plant in Arizona extraordinary operating flexibility; in exchange Intel pledged to do better than the law requires in controlling pollution. [A18.]
 
Three Retailers Exceed Forecasts
Dayton Hudson's third-quarter earnings more than doubled, and two other retail groups, Limited Inc. and Ann Taylor, also turned in better-than-expected earnings, on strong demand for new women's fashions. [D16.]
 
Plan for Crash Notification
Seven major airlines in the United States and the State Department signed an agreement to provide speedier notification for the families of those killed or injured in international air disasters. [A1.]
 
Robert Citron Is Sentenced
Robert Citron, the former treasurer of Orange County, Calif., was sentenced to one year in jail and fined $100,000 for his role in the county's bankruptcy. In addition, he must do 1,000 hours of community service and faces five years of probation once he leaves jail. [D2.]
 
Sumitomo Loses $1.9 Billion
Sumitomo announced a $1.9 billion loss for the first six months of its fiscal year, its first loss in its 77-year history, as $2.6 billion in losses from unauthorized copper trading more than offset gains elsewhere. [D4.]

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Belle Signs the Richest Deal: 5 Years, $55 Million

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH 

 BODY:
The Chicago White Sox made Albert Belle the highest-paid player in baseball yesterday, signing the free-agent slugger to a five-year contract worth a guaranteed $55 million that made the City of Big Shoulders look more than ever like the City of Big Bucks.
The confluence of Belle's impressive numbers and the revenues enjoyed by a large-market club allowed Belle to shoot past the likes of Ken Griffey Jr., Barry Bonds and his new teammate, Frank Thomas, becoming the first baseball player to surpass $10 million a year. 
 That staggering amount could grow because the contract not only has an option for a sixth year with a guaranteed $5 million buyout, but also has a promise that Belle will be among the top three salaried players for the life of the deal. But, as Thomas, a two-time most valuable player, said: "Albert has set himself apart from the rest of the players the past couple of years. He should be the highest-paid player in the game."
The White Sox owner, Jerry Reinsdorf, now has the highest-paid players in two team sports. Reinsdorf, also the owner of the National Basketball Association's Chicago Bulls, is paying Michael Jordan $30.14 million this season.
Reinsdorf flexed economic muscles that few baseball teams can, despite his call for fiscal restraint on salaries and his successful challenge of a proposed agreement with the players' union that would have placed a luxury tax on the teams with the highest payrolls.
"We're not being fiscally irresponsible because we can afford it," said Reinsdorf, whose actions drew immediate criticism yesterday from John Hart, the general manager of the Cleveland Indians. "But it does bother me that there are only a few teams that can afford to do this. That means the game is not healthy. I want the people in Pittsburgh, Kansas City and Milwaukee and all the other small towns to have a chance to compete. I want competitive balance."
Reinsdorf cited a need to win back fans, having seen home attendance fall from 2.9 million in 1991 to 1.6 million last year, when the White Sox were in contention with the Indians.
Belle, who has hit 98 home runs and driven in 274 runs over the last two years for the Indians, said he wasn't looking only at the money.
"It wasn't about the most money," the 30-year-old Belle said at a news conference at Comiskey Park yesterday. "I'm sure I could have shopped around and got more money. But you have to look at the personnel and the organization. I was very excited about being a part of the lineup. I hope I make the organization better."
Arn Tellem, the agent for the outfielder who has been at the center of several controversial incidents, looked to intangibles, not the least of which was the accommodating embrace Chicago is noted for giving the famous and sometimes infamous.
"The money is a factor, but if he left Cleveland, of the teams that expressed interest, this is where he wanted to be; this was the best place for him to make a fresh start," said Tellem, who negotiated a deal in which Belle will earn $1.5 million more than Griffey next season and nearly $3 million more than what Bonds and Thomas will make in 1997.
First, Chicago could offer what other suitors -- including Cleveland and the Florida Marlins -- could not: Thomas, who is Belle's good friend and a player of equal offensive wallop. Tellem said Belle "often thought that they could do what Jordan and Pippen have done for the Bulls for Chicago and have that same impact."
Then there was the comfort of staying in the American League, but also the comfort of the city itself.
"Chicago is a city with big shoulders and it has embraced a lot of star athletes, specifically Dennis Rodman," Tellem said of the Bulls' forward known for his tattoos, hair colors and cross-dressing.
"Dennis came from the Bulls' most hated enemy -- the Pistons -- and the city has had a love affair with Rodman," Tellem said. "For Albert, that was something that definitely went through his mind, hoping that if he did well and performed that the fans would embrace him here."
Belle, like Rodman, has had his image troubles, including run-ins with fans and the news media, and he has been heavily fined and suspended. After he hit a photographer with a baseball last season, he was ordered by the American League to undergo counseling.
Reinsdorf, who made the Rodman lovefest in Chicago possible, has enjoyed a close relationship over the years with Tellem.
"And I think when Jerry met Albert, the two of them felt very comfortable with each other," Tellem said. "And Jerry stressed to Albert that he's had a lot of experience dealing with stars, not just in baseball, but in basketball, and that he would go to the end of the world to help protect him."
As Reinsdorf said, "The people of Chicago have shown in the case of the fellow with the pink hair that if you are playing for us, and you are playing your heart out, we're going to embrace you."
Thus the coming-out of baseball's most reclusive superstar, who sounded like a man ready for a new beginning as he met the news media just three days after Cleveland took its last offer from the table and just four days after the bidding for free agents began.
Thomas, Chicago's All-Star first baseman, was also at the news conference. He expressed excitement over the possibilities as he, Belle and Robin Ventura brace to become arguably the game's most powerful 3-4-5 hitters in the lineup.
The Indians got back in the pennant-winning business for the first time since the 1950's thanks in good part to Belle, whom they drafted in 1987. Belle became the Indians' career home run hitter (242), and last season he led the league with 148 runs batted in, the second-highest total in Indians history and the most by an American Leaguer since Ted Williams and Vern Stephens had 159 in 1949.
Belle batted .311 last season and his power numbers brought him a third-place spot in the voting for m.v.p., his second straight near miss. Yet on Saturday, the Indians withdrew a five-year contract offer of about $40 million, essentially severing the relationship with the player who helped them win a pennant in 1995 and the A.L. Central last season.
"I don't consider that I'm abandoning Cleveland," said Belle, a career .295 hitter with 751 r.b.i. in eight seasons. "I'm very happy that the fans of Cleveland stuck by me during some tough times. But things didn't work out."

HEADLINE: Zoning Battle Is Early Issue For Campaign

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Stepping up the political battle over superstores, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is running radio commercials to promote his plan to allow the stores in some areas. And yesterday, he harshly attacked Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President and a probable mayoral candidate, who is running ads against the plan.
The Mayor accused Ms. Messinger of cheating on campaign finance rules by spending taxpayer money on her ads, which he suggested were intended to promote her mayoral effort. Mr. Giuliani's commercials will be paid for with about $70,000 raised by a private group organized by the Mayor, which calls itself the Committee for Consumer Choice. 
 Ms. Messinger demanded yesterday that the Mayor disclose where the committee was getting its money and suggested that he "needs a Valium." Fran Reiter, the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, would not provide names of contributors yesterday, but said most of the money would probably come from retailers and developers.
Neither Mr. Giuliani nor Ms. Messinger has formally announced plans to run for mayor next year, but their intentions have become increasingly clear in recent weeks. In Ms. Messinger's commercial, which she is paying for with money from the Borough President's budget, she attacks Mr. Giuliani as much as his proposal.
The Mayor's commercial, which started running on Monday night, represents the first time Mr. Giuliani has used paid advertisements to try to sell one of his initiatives to the public. The ads indicate how seriously Mr. Giuliani has taken the possibility that the City Council could sharply scale back or even defeat his plan.
Yesterday, the City Council held its second day of hearings on the Mayor's plan, which Council members have said is headed for a fierce battle when the Council votes on it next month. The zoning changes would allow as many as 57 new superstores on wide streets throughout the city in areas zoned for light or medium manufacturing.
Council members said yesterday that the paid ad campaigns sponsored by the Mayor and Ms. Messinger would have no impact on their decision-making process.
"I don't think either of these ads have anything to do with megastores because they have everything to do with the 1997 mayoral campaign," said Walter L. McCaffrey, the chairman of the Council's Subcommittee on Franchising and Zoning.
The Mayor's commercial praises the plan as a way to bring "larger, modern supermarkets and discount stores" into "poor and minority neighborhoods." It criticizes "politicians and special interests" who are trying to keep the stores out of the city.
"This is an important public policy issue," Ms. Messinger said yesterday, "and I welcome the Mayor to the airwaves. He wants the public to hear his side, like I want the public to hear my side. Fine."
Her commercial tries to exploit growing concern that the Mayor's zoning proposal would cut citizens out of the process because superstores would be allowed in certain industrial areas "as of right," or without community review on where the stores would go. "Apparently, Rudy Giuliani doesn't care what you think," Ms. Messinger says in the commercial.
The Mayor condemned Ms. Messinger's commercial yesterday as a tactic typical of "old-fashioned politicians" and said she was improperly using public money to pay for a political ad.
"Before she's even started running, she's cheating," the Mayor asserted, adding, "She shouldn't be allowed to get away with it."
The Mayor said Ms. Messinger's radio ads were the latest in a history of abusing the city's campaign finance law, accusing her specifically of cheating in her 1989 and 1993 campaigns for borough president. But when asked to substantiate the allegations, the Mayor's aides were unable to document any particular improprieties.
Administration officials, though, cited a complaint filed by the Giuliani campaign in 1993 -- one of many filed by various candidates against each other -- that Ms. Messinger had improperly contributed to the campaign of Mayor David N. Dinkins.
The complaint was withdrawn by the Giuliani campaign after the election, and no determination was ever made by the Campaign Finance Board that Ms. Messinger had acted improperly.
The agency found her to be in "substantial compliance" with the campaign finance law in 1993, the same determination made about the Giuliani campaign.
Also yesterday, Councilman Andrew S. Eristoff, a Republican representing the East Side, filed a complaint about Ms. Messinger's radio ads with the city's Conflicts of Interest Board. The complaint accuses Ms. Messinger of using $7,400 in public money for personal political purposes by denigrating the Mayor and furthering her own candidacy for mayor.
Ms. Messinger defended her financing of the ads, saying that using money from her Borough President's budget was appropriate because planning issues are part of her responsibilities.
Giuliani administration officials have also said Ms. Messinger's commercial, and contentions by other opponents of the proposal, have been dishonest and irresponsible.
"After a while," Mr. Giuliani said yesterday, "we get tired of all the kind of lying that's going on about this, so we're putting on an ad that lays out the absolute truth about this proposal."
The Mayor's commercial suggests that his plan would increase competition in the city and would specifically bring more shopping choices to the city's poor.
"It's us who put up with the stale produce, sour milk and clothing we can't afford, while wealthy areas have better prices and all kinds of shopping choices," the announcer says on the ad. "Don't let the special interests stop us from getting lower prices and better quality."

HEADLINE: Careers Are Among the Casualties Of C.I.A.'s Latest Security Breach

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The careers of the bright new graduates of the Central Intelligence Agency's school for spies are blighted: the F.B.I. fears that the class lists and curriculum are sitting in a Russian safe.
The identities of American businessmen in Moscow who volunteer intelligence secrets to the C.I.A. have probably been exposed. The agency's operations in Moscow, Tokyo, Manila and Malaysia have been compromised. And the reputation of the nation's clandestine service has taken another crushing blow. 
 That, for starters, is the damage believed to have been done by Harold J. Nicholson, the C.I.A. officer arrested on Saturday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and charged with selling secrets to Moscow, intelligence and law-enforcement officials said today.
Though it will take months to complete a definitive damage assessment, "we have a pretty good idea of what he had access to and what he could have had access to," a senior law-enforcement official said. The officials assigned to figure out exactly which secrets Mr. Nicholson sold to Moscow must assume the worst. And the worst is very, very bad.
Officials suspect that Mr. Nicholson sold his Russian contacts the names of every student who prepared for undercover assignments overseas at the C.I.A.'s training school in 1994, 1995 and the first half of 1996.
The school, Camp Peary, is a secret 9,275-acre base near Williamsburg, Va., known informally as "The Farm." It provides a yearlong graduate seminar in espionage.
Mr. Nicholson taught a 16-week course in tricks of the trade like stealing mail, using disguises, evading pursuers and handling agents. He is suspected of telling the Russians everything about Camp Peary's core curriculum.
Mr. Nicholson read the biographies and the future assignments for every officer trained at Camp Peary during his two-year tenure there, the F.B.I. says in an affidavit that was unsealed on Monday. The C.I.A. has to assume that since Mr. Nicholson knew every student, the Russians do, too, intelligence and law-enforcement officials said.
That knowledge damages the immediate prospects of many of the agency's newest spies. Normally, they would be working undercover as State Department diplomats overseas. Now they cannot -- particularly not in Russia -- without fearing that Mr. Nicholson, their trusted instructor, has blown their covers.
"It will be difficult, if not impossible, for the C.I.A. to place some of these newly trained officers into certain sensitive assignments for the rest of their careers," the affidavit says.
They will be in danger of exposure in any country where the Russian foreign intelligence service has a presence. For years to come, many will be forced to work at desk jobs, either at headquarters or in obscure and out-of-the-way foreign capitals, processing information instead of gathering it. That will not improve morale at the clandestine service.
"There's a very real cost involved in this case, and that may be the highest cost of all," said Robert M. Gates, Director of Central Intelligence from November 1991 to January 1993. "It will be very difficult to have them targeted against Russia. It clearly puts some limitations on assignments. Time will have to pass before they are assigned overseas. There will be a much greater cost in creating cover for them. Their careers will be delayed" -- if not destroyed.
Some of the betrayed young officers may be retrained to assume "non-official cover" -- that is, to pose as businessmen or in some other guise overseas. It costs millions of dollars for the agency to train and support such a deep-cover officer, and the assignment is far more dangerous, since it lacks the diplomatic immunity provided by posing as a State Department official.
The affidavit also said Mr. Nicholson, in addition to blowing the cover of one of his own star pupils who was headed for an undercover assignment in Moscow, sold the Russians the name of the agency's new Moscow station chief and information about the new chief's staff of clandestine officers.
Equally galling to the C.I.A. is that Mr. Nicholson is charged with selling secret files on American citizens who live or work in Russia. These Americans, mostly businessmen, have volunteered information to the C.I.A. on the structure of Russian banking, the state of the Russian economy and the workings of Russian military and industrial companies, among other subjects.
Those who have cooperated with the C.I.A. may pay dearly for trusting that their roles would stay secret.
"They are clearly at risk," a former senior intelligence official said. "They have to worry whether they are going to be subject to increased surveillance by the Russians."
Mr. Gates agreed, adding that American businessmen in Moscow may now be reluctant to open a relationship with the C.I.A. "Others willing to help may now decline to do so for fear their business will be damaged," he said.
Mr. Nicholson is also suspected of revealing details of intelligence operations in Japan, Malaysia, the Philippines and Romania, all countries he served in as a spy from 1982 to 1994. A former intelligence official said, "He very well may have disclosed specific collection operations that C.I.A. might have had targeted against the Russians or against local governments that the Russians might be interested in."
And diplomatic relations between Washington and Moscow have been damaged. The United States lodged official protests over the case, one delivered face to face by Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, who summoned the Russian Ambassador, Yuli M. Vorontsov, to the State Department on Monday. The United States is contemplating expelling a Russian spy working under diplomatic cover in Washington, Government officials said, just as it did when similar spy cases arose during the cold war.
[At a news conference in Australia on Wednesday, President Clinton said that he was concerned about the breach but that the arrest was "the direct result of the tightening of the system." He said the United States had discussed the matter with the Russians. "We will do what we think we have to do in intelligence," he said, but he declined to elaborate.]
The C.I.A. has taken pains to point out that the charges against Mr. Nicholson were dwarfed by the case against Aldrich H. Ames, the career C.I.A. officer who pleaded guilty to espionage in April 1994. Most important, no one died. Mr. Ames's treachery led to the execution of every important Soviet and East European military and intelligence officer secretly working for the C.I.A. -- at least 10 of them -- and the destruction of most of the espionage operations aimed at Moscow at the height of the cold war.
But Mr. Gates, the former Director, said the two cases had had a similar effect on the C.I.A. -- and a perversely healthy one.
"They've cleared away a lot of mythology within the agency," Mr. Gates said today. "There was a view that people in the agency didn't turn and work for the other side. C.I.A. people didn't steal. They didn't cheat.
"What we've found is that C.I.A. is like any other big institution. It's made up of human beings, some of whom are weak. They do embezzle. They do work for the other side. They do cheat and steal. The biggest effect of these cases has been to eliminate a good deal of the cultural mythology inside the agency and a certain measure of arrogance that went along with it -- that the agency was different and better than anybody else."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Arab Burden

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: CAIRO

 BODY:
I asked President Hosni Mubarak the other day what qualities he would like to see in the next U.S. Secretary of State. The Egyptian leader remarked that Warren Christopher was the ideal Secretary for the past four years. His low-key, lawyerly style was well suited for a period in which Israelis and Palestinians were driving the peace process by themselves and the U.S. role was to ease them over the bumps. But with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu having replaced Shimon Peres, and with the Israeli-Palestinian negotiations soon to reach the knotty final-status issues, the U.S. may again need a Secretary of State with more of the Jim Baker, in-your-face style of diplomacy, Mr. Mubarak gently suggested. "With no Rabin, no Peres, the President will have to select a Secretary of State who works differently," he said.
Mr. Mubarak is half right. The next Secretary will certainly need to have a Bakeresque taste for knuckle-breaking, strategic leaking and other diplomatic contact sports. It was one thing for the U.S. to promote the peace process when there was an Israeli leadership -- Mr. Peres and Yitzhak Rabin -- who were ready to drive the agenda, take all the heat and make the tough choices. It is another thing for the U.S. to promote the peace process with an Israeli Government preoccupied with looking for ways to move forward without political costs and without making the really tough choices vis-a-vis the Palestinians. But the U.S. isn't the only party that will need a new style. So too will Egypt and the Arabs. 
 Here's why: The only way the peace process is going to proceed is if Mr. Netanyahu can be persuaded to break off the far-right religious-nationalist wing of his coalition and build a constituency for peace based on Labor doves, who are 50 percent of Israel's population, and Likud security hawks -- those who voted for Mr. Netanyahu because they want a deal with the Palestinians but just a better one than they thought Labor would negotiate -- who are 25 percent of the population. Together, they are 75 percent of Israel.
But Egypt has to help. Sure, it's easy now for Arab leaders to generate support at home by pummeling Mr. Netanyahu. Because of the high-handed way he tends to deal with Arabs, he really agitates them, right down to the man on the street. He's now a popular target. Egypt's very able Foreign Minister, Amr Moussa, is the most popular diplomat in the Arab world today, precisely because of the way he has been bashing Mr. Netanyahu -- without ever saying a good word for the rest of Israel, or encouraging the peace coalition that still exists there. This has got to stop. It's cheap. It's counterproductive and it's throwing out the bathwater with the Bibi.
The only way U.S. diplomats can effectively pressure Mr. Netanyahu is if they have the visible support of the moderate Arabs, who make clear that they are ready to help nurture the Israeli constituency for peace -- that 75 percent -- that still exists beneath the surface of the Israeli elections. But if that Israeli peace constituency detects that the mood in the Arab world is reverting to anti-Israel, and not just anti-those in Israel against the peace process, if it detects that Mr. Netanyahu will get bashed if he does the right thing or the wrong thing, that peace coalition will never get galvanized and drive the process forward.
At least a few Egyptian intellectuals, who have long been hostile to the peace process, recognize this. Al Ahram's editor, Ibrahim Nafie, wrote the other day: "Is it possible for us to continue to deal with Israeli society as a monolithic entity, one which has a unified stand toward peace, given the schisms that exist in the Israeli body politic?" If the answer is no, he said, then the question for the Arab world is "how should we act to further the cause of peace within Israeli society and marginalize those opposed to its implementation?"
In other words, the loss of Messrs. Peres and Rabin not only makes it incumbent on the U.S. to take more responsibility for the peace process, it makes it incumbent on the Arabs, and particularly Egypt, to take more responsibility as well -- to persuade the Israeli man in the street that despite the current impasse there is still an Arab peace partner out there, ready to deliver real security and economic benefits to an Israel still willing to take risks for peace.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Global Pact on Computers May Be Nearing

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials expect two major meetings in the next month to set the stage for a global agreement abolishing tariffs on computer and software products.
Such an Information Technology Agreement, or I.T.A., would liberalize some $500 billion worth of computer and software exports annually -- roughly equivalent to world trade in agriculture -- among the United States, Canada, Europe, Japan and many other Asian and Latin American countries. 
 "We are working quite diligently on this," said Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States trade representative. "And while I'm cautious by nature, I think most countries realize the benefits of an I.T.A."
The first of the meetings is scheduled to begin later this week in the Philippines, when the 18-member Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum gathers to take up the issue. APEC is committed to achieving complete free trade in the region. Then, on Dec. 9 in Singapore, the APEC countries will press the more than 100 members of the World Trade Organization at their first meeting of trade representatives to also adopt this free trade agreement.
The impact of such an agreement could spread beyond the relatively narrow scope of information technology. To complete the Uruguay Round of trade talks in 1993 that created the World Trade Organization, negotiators left unresolved a liberalization of world trade in service industries: maritime shipping, financial services and telecommunications.
Since then, attempts to resolve the issues have failed, and accord on information technology will be seen by some as breaking a three-year logjam on multilateral trade agreements. At the same time, a failure could be seen as a stunning blow to global trade talks.
"An I.T.A. is the minimum needed to show trade liberalization is still alive," Gary Hufbauer of the Institute for International Economics in Washington said.
One problem in jump-starting the information technology talks is that there are several competing visions as to what course the W.T.O. should take next. Several trade strategists want a commitment to merge the world's proliferating number of small, regional free trade areas into one worldwide free trade region. Others -- including Europe's chief trade negotiator, Sir Leon Brittan, and Renato Rugiero, head of the World Trade Organization -- have suggested that the W.T.O. session should begin a new round of trade freeing negotiations.
But the United States and many other governments seem unenthusiastic. "This is not the time for grand new initiatives, which would only encourage countries to hold back concessions they are being asked to make now for the final package deal that could be years away," said Jeffrey Lang, deputy trade representative. More likely, Ms. Barshefsky and Mr. Lang said, is that the trade representatives will begin exploratory talks on a number of smaller issues at Singapore rather than take up any grand schemes.
These smaller issues include such things as whether restrictions on foreign investment hamper trade and the commercial impact of differing labor market standards, environmental and antitrust regulations and government procurement policies.
"A Mercedes-Benz without gas" is how Sylvia Ostry, a former Canadian trade negotiator who now teaches at Toronto University, described this distinctly subdued World Trade Organization agenda. She said that with the cold war over, Western democracies no longer felt the need to consolidate their political links by encouraging freer trade.
"There seems to be little commitment to implementing the built-in agenda of the Uruguay Round or completing the service sector negotiations, let alone setting new targets for further liberalization," Mrs. Ostry said.
But those hopeful about the coming meetings in the Philippines and Singapore also see advantages in a series of small steps. "Free trade in information technology could make it easier for the Asians to accept freer trade in telecommunications," Mr. Lang said.
In fact, trade negotiators are already working to create some momentum toward renewing the talks on telecommunications. Earlier this month, the United States and the European Union submitted new, more liberal telecommunications proposals to the World Trade Organization, with Europe proposing to quicken the pace of its liberalization and the Clinton Administration agreeing for the first time to let foreign companies land underwater cables on United States shores.
If an agreement on information technology does emerge from the coming meetings, it will be for three main reasons.
First, the four so-called Quadrilateral Powers -- the United States, Canada, the European Union and Japan -- have already agreed to one in principle at their April 1996 summit meeting in Kobe, Japan, provided they get enough support from Asian countries.
Freeing trade in information products is attractive to many APEC countries. But China is always reluctant to open its market to outside goods and might try to link acceptance of an agreement on information technology to its own admission into the W.T.O. -- something the United States is not yet willing to accept. Indonesia may also have reservations, since it is not a big electronics exporter.
Second, an accord is also favored by the European electronics industry, which wants to reduce the cost of imported semiconductors. But while Asian exporters want to include consumer electronics like television monitors and videocassette recorders, European producers fear the increased competition and want the agreement to dismantle administrative barriers to trade as well as to abolish tariffs.
And third, an agreement on information technology would allow the European Union to join a recently renegotiated semiconductor agreement between the United States and Japan. That agreement has opened up the Japanese market to United States producers and enabled them to grab close to a 30 percent share. The United States has refused to let the union join in the agreement until it agrees to complete free trade in information technology products.

HEADLINE: October Starts Of Housing Fell by 5.1%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
For months, analysts puzzled over the housing construction market's seeming disregard of last winter's sharp rise in interest rates that pushed mortgage costs higher and cut down on buyers. No more. Figures issued today showed that builders in October broke ground on the fewest new houses in a year, as activity tumbled for the second consecutive month.
The drop of 5.1 percent in housing starts came as much of a surprise to analysts as the earlier strength had been. With most analysts having predicted a rebound from a 6.1 percent decrease in September, the October figures raised questions about whether economic growth might be faltering. Mortgage rates have fallen again, however, and some analysts see housing construction recovering. 
 Nevertheless, the October figures were eye-catching. Joseph Liro, chief economist at CIBC Wood Gundy, a securities firm in New York, said he and his associates were "taken aback by the extent" of housing's two-month skid. He predicted that this important sector would be a drag on growth over the balance of the year.
October's drop in housing starts, moreover, was accompanied by a decline of 2.7 percent in permits issued for construction, an indicator widely -- but not universally -- regarded as a business forecaster. This was the third consecutive month of lower permits, and the pace was the lowest since July 1995.
Whether the economy continues to grow at a slackened pace or possibly tips into recession, today's results were further vindication of the Federal Reserve's decision against tightening monetary policy this autumn in the belief that the economy was cooling enough on its own.
"This makes the Fed look prescient in having not raised rates," said Paul Taylor, senior economist at America's Community Bankers, a trade group whose members are major mortgage lenders.
But while housing-market psychology has "shifted so dramatically," according to David F. Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, he and others contend that construction is likely to stabilize now that interest rates have reversed course. Conventional mortgages are now available at about 7 5/8 percent and adjustables at 5 1/2 percent, he said.
Moreover, the supply of unsold homes is relatively lean, apparently reflecting caution in the industry that sooner or later the early-year jump in rates would have an impact.
"Builders have reasonable control over their inventories this time," Mr. Taylor said.
At the same time, the association's housing-market index fell to 51 in November from 55 in October, the group reported on Monday, well down from May's peak of 63. All three survey components declined -- current sales of single-family homes, their projected sales over the next six months and traffic of prospective buyers.
October's 5.1 percent drop in housing starts, which followed September's 6.1 percent slump, included all areas of the country except the West and multiple-dwelling buildings as well as single-family homes, the report showed.
In the Northeast, where activity has long been slowest, the decline was 9.3 percent while the Midwest and South were down 9.2 percent and 8.3 percent, respectively. The West posted a 6.5 percent gain but this recovered less than half the ground lost in September.
Over all, starts ran at a seasonally adjusted pace of 1,336,000, or 10.9 percent below the August peak.
Single-family homes eased 4.6 percent last month while dwellings in buildings with at least five units, a more volatile sector, dropped 12.5 percent.
As for permits, the report found a 2.7 percent October decline, with all regions other than the Northeast, which registered no change, down by roughly similar amounts.
The annual rate was 1,361,000, with permits for the more economically important single-family component down 3 percent last month.
Elliott Platt, a senior economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said he was tempted to predict that housing starts would rebound in November on a presumption of renewed strength in the South and Midwest. But he counseled resisting this notion because of exceptionally bad weather that may be causing a big drop in the Midwest.
The October pace nonetheless stood 6.2 percent above that of 12 months earlier, reflecting the surprisingly buoyant first half of the year.
Today's report also included a lagged tally for mobile homes, shipments of which ran at an annual rate of 373,000 in September, 1 percent higher than in August.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Housing Construction" tracks new private housing started and permits authorized, at seasonally adjusted annual rates, from May 1995 through October 1996. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
The Inspass system for hassle-free entry into the United States is being expanded.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
AFTER three years of apparent fraud-free use at Kennedy International Airport in New York, Newark International Airport and Lester B. Pearson International Airport in Toronto, the Inspass system will soon be in place at eight more airports. Its purpose is to provide frequent travelers hassle-free entry into the United States.
Those eligible for the program are citizens of the United States, Canada, Bermuda and the 25 other nations that participate in the visa-waiver pilot program, provided they travel to the United States on business at least three times a year. Also eligible are "low risk" visitors like diplomats, airline crews and representatives of international organizations. 
 To enroll in Inspass, which is run by the the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service, travelers must visit an I.N.S. office and be approved by an agency inspector. After receiving an Inspass card, the traveler arriving at a participating airport can bypass immigration lines by inserting the card into what resembles an automated bank teller machine. But unlike users of the bank machine, Inspass card holders must also insert their hand in a "reader" that compares it with the image captured at the time of their enrollment.
The airports scheduled to have Inspass in place by mid-1997 are Miami, Los Angeles, Vancouver, Honolulu, Houston, San Francisco, Chicago and Montreal. The system at the Canadian airports is to provide pre-clearance for entry into the United States.
 
Guarding Your Laptop
With laptop computers a prime target of thieves at airports and hotels, Port Inc., a Norwalk, Conn., company that manufactures accessories for portable computers, has come up with a motion sensor alarm system. The 6.2-ounce system, Defcon 1, employs a cut-resistant steel cable that passes through the handle of the carrying case or into a laptop's security lock slot. Because the motion sensor operates on time-delay, the alarm gives three warning chirps if the computer is moved, shaken or tilted. If not disarmed, an ear-spliting alarm will alert the owner -- and presumably everyone else within earshot. The price of the alarm is $49.95.
 
Call for Help
Mastercard International is offering card holders who travel abroad an easy way to report lost or stolen cards, find the nearest A.T.M. machines or get emergency card replacement or cash advances: a toll-free telephone call in any language from anywhere in the world (or through a collect call where toll-free service is not available). The numbers can be obtained by asking local directory assistance in each country for the toll-free Mastercard Global Service number, or through hotel concierges and Thomas Cook travel and currency-exchange locations in major cities.
 
Route Planning
Three weeks ago the Promus Hotel Corporation began offering travelers free customized auto route planning via three World Wide Web sites on the Internet. By Monday those Web sites had mapped out about 100,000 trips for browsers.
The Web sites, available to anyone with access to the Internet, are for each of three Promus brands -- Hampton Inn and Hampton Inn and Suites, whose site is www.hampton-inn.com (Hampton Inn and Hampton Inn & Suites); Embassy Suites, whose Web site is www.embassy-suites.com, and Homewood Suites, at www.homewood-suites.com.
 
Promoting the Slopes
The ski industry contributes $3.2 billion a year to Colorado's economy, but skiing has been pretty much a no-growth industry nationwide for about a decade.
To "fill the pipeline," as one concerned ski executive put it, the Colorado state government and Colorado Ski Country USA, a marketing organization, have teamed up to give every fifth grader in the state a season pass entitling them to ski and snowboard for free at 23 resorts statewide.

HEADLINE: Utility Seeks Partner to Aid Power Needs

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
A big Georgia utility said yesterday that it was turning to an outside power-marketing company to supply half its electricity needs in an effort to cut its costs by tens of millions of dollars over more than a decade.
The deal between the Georgia utility, the Oglethorpe Power Corporation, and the power marketer, the LG & E Energy Corporation, is indicative of how utilities are likely to seek partners with more expertise to help them take advantage of an increasing competitive market for electricity. 
 The arrangement also demonstrates the growing ability of power marketers, who trade in electricity as a commodity, to take on long-term contracts to deliver power over a decade and longer.
Under their agreement, an LG & E subsidiary, LG & E Power Marketing, will provide Oglethorpe with half its electricity for 15 years. The contract estimates the current value of that electricity at $4.5 billion to $5 billion.
LG & E will take over the management of Oglethorpe's plants, which can produce about 3,200 megawatts of power, or enough to serve a medium-sized city.
It will buy electricity from outside sources if that proves cheaper than producing it. It will also sell power from the plants if it proves to be more lucrative.
"We decided we would use the advantage they have developed to see if we can save money," said Clarence Mitchell, the vice president of generation for Oglethorpe.
The companies said they believed that it was the largest long-term power marketing agreement so far.
Oglethorpe is also negotiating with two other big power marketers, Enron Power Marketing Inc. and Duke/ Louis Dreyfus, to manage the rest of its electricity needs, which total about 5,000 megawatts.
Although Oglethorpe provides wholesale electricity to 39 electric cooperatives serving 2.6 million households in Georgia, it does not have the experience that LG & E has in buying electricity. LG & E Energy, the parent company of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company in Kentucky, has been one of the most aggressive utilities to market power outside its home base.
Oglethorpe was set up by the cooperatives in 1974 to provide power after rising fuel prices, high inflation and tight supplies pushed up electricity prices.
Mr. Mitchell said that although Oglethorpe itself had experience in power marketing, it could not match the sophistication and the big volumes handled by the large marketers like LG & E that buy and sell power daily from many sources.
He said that under the contract Oglethorpe had locked in a certain price that LG & E had to meet. If LG & E was able to buy electricity at lower prices, then it could keep the difference.
The agreement, which will take effect Jan. 1, still must be approved by the Rural Utilities Service, a Federal agency that oversees the nation's electric cooperatives.
The trading of electricity has been growing rapidly and is expected to surge when states begin to open up their utilities to outside competition. An order from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission last spring has also made the delivery of power over the nation's grid more equitable, since utilities must now treat outsiders using their grids on an equal footing as themselves.
What is unusual about Oglethorpe, which is the nation's largest power supply cooperative, is that it made its decision on its own to have outsiders manage its power.
"This is the precursor of many deals that will happen," Mike McInnis, the president of LG & E Power Marketing, said.
"Managements will focus on those risks where they have the greatest strengths," he said. "Oglethorpe wants to manage the risk on the customer side in distribution and allow us to manage the risk on the generation side."
Shares of LG & E Energy gained 50 cents yesterday, closing at $24.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Cooperatives were set up, beginning in the 1930's, to bring power to rural farm areas where private utilities were reluctant to build power plants and transmission systems.

HEADLINE: A Mayor Slides Off His Pedestal

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19

 BODY:
There are those who will now assert that they knew all along that Willie L. Brown Jr. would slip, that it was only a matter of time and hubris before he would stop being "the wildly popular Mayor of San Francisco" and become just the Mayor.
It had been the prevailing local view that beneath his Cheshire cat smiles and his $3,000 Brioni suits, Mr. Brown possessed a non-stick political skin. He had gotten away with describing his Board of Supervisors as "mistresses that you have to service." He had compared California's Attorney General to the Nazis and got barely a rebuttal. Several ballot measures he supported in the Nov. 5 elections were roundly defeated, and nobody said a word. 
 But then Mr. Brown made the mistake of turning his switchblade tongue on something truly sacred, a quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers.
Last week, after a tough loss in overtime to the hated Dallas Cowboys, Mr. Brown called the 49ers' beleaguered back-up quarterback, Elvis Grbac, "an embarrassment to humankind" and vowed that Grbac would never play in any new stadium that the Brown administration helped build for the team. He later claimed not to have known about Grbac's post-game confession that he may have been distracted by the precarious health of his 9-month-old son, who had undergone spinal surgery for a birth defect. But the Mayor's explanation seemed to mean nothing in the fury that ensued.
As Mr. Brown flew off in a private jet for a five-day trip to Paris, angry callers besieged the telephones of local newspapers, radio stations and City Hall. Fax machines ran out of paper. Sports bars were in an uproar. In one radio station's overnight telephone poll, 84 percent of the 1,548 people who called in said they believed Mr. Brown's effectiveness as chief executive had been undermined.
At the 49ers' game on Sunday, the most-photographed banner read, "Keep Elvis Trade Willie." And after the local heroes prevailed over the Baltimore Ravens, 38-20, with Grbac (pronounced gerbach) completing an exclamatory 26 of 31 passes, The San Francisco Examiner announced the victory with the headline: "Elvis wins, humankind rejoices."
Mr. Brown, who reveled in his reputation as the Deion Sanders of city government -- brashness and talent in equal measure -- has responded in an uncharacteristic way: he apologized. After some intercontinental penance through the press, which he also blamed for failing to inform him about the condition of Grbac's child, he called to the 49ers' practice field on Friday and delivered his regrets to the quarterback directly.
"It was a dumb thing to have uttered," Mr. Brown said again today, at his first news conference since flying back from France (He was now pronouncing it "Fronce."). "I'm sorry it was said. I'm sorry it was done. Mr. Grbac accepted my apology."
But if the Mayor sounded about as close as he could to sheepish, some analysts of the city's politics suggested that he might well have overestimated the taste of San Franciscans for what many of them see as an imperious style of governing.
"He's talking like he's the dictator of San Francisco, like we should be bowing down to the king!" Bob Santilli, 34, an operations manager at a stock brokerage, objected last week over a drink at Harrington's Bar and Grill in the city's Financial District. "He's got the Board of Supervisors in his pocket, so he think's he's the god of San Francisco."
Mr. Brown insisted today that whatever arrogance might have been seen in his remarks, his style would not change. And in a recent interview, he predicted that complaints about his perceived authoritarianism would probably be a staple of local politics during his tenure.
"You're going to hear that," he said. "Because this city has never been run properly. Nobody's been willing to make a decision. Incumbent enjoyers of the current, chaotic process will be critics, and that includes the press."
The writer of a new biography of Mr. Brown, James Richardson, noted that in his three decades in the California State Assembly, mildly outrageous, off-the-cuff statements by Mr. Brown came and went without ever getting the kind of attention they have drawn since he became Mayor. It was taken for granted in Sacramento, Mr. Richardson said, "that there was a difference between Willietalk and Williedo."
It is, of course, a measure of Mr. Brown's success in San Francisco that his outburst about Grbac has occasioned what is by most accounts the most serious "crisis" of his first year in City Hall.
The larger challenges of governing the city, with its growing service economy and its decaying, underfinanced infrastructure, have been steadily apparent. Federal officials were brought in to take over the city's decrepit housing authority in March.
A ballot proposition intended to give the mayor greater control over the hiring and firing of 500 mid-level municipal employees was roundly defeated despite a $700,000 campaign on its behalf.
Mayoral aides have battled for months for changes in the city's inefficient, underfinanced public transportation system. Health and social-services officials have pledged to oppose Federal and state cuts in aid to welfare recipients and immigrants, but they have not yet explained clearly how they will foot the bill themselves.
Still, it is also widely felt that whatever his real accomplishments, Mr. Brown's energy and ebullience have helped to crystallize a significant lifting of the city's mood.
"He's taking no end of grief for this, but it's not going to have any fundamental effect on his political future," said Dan Schnur, a former aide to California's Governor, Pete Wilson, and a political analyst for KGO Radio in San Francisco.
"For a combination of reasons -- a rejuvenated economy and Willie Brown among them -- this city is feeling better about itself than it has in a long time."
It was also clear that many San Franciscans were enjoying the crisis. Even the Mayor's old friend, the San Francisco Chronicle columnist Herb Caen, was repeating the latest Willie joke to make the rounds.
"Why does Mayor Brown buy Italian shoes?" Mr. Caen asked in his column.
"Because they taste better."
