HEADLINE: Judge Rejects Move to Block CSX-Conrail Merger Deal

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Norfolk Southern Corporation failed to thwart a giant railroad merger between its rival, the CSX Corporation, and Conrail yesterday, when a Federal judge in Philadelphia refused to grant a preliminary injunction blocking the $8.5 billion deal.
The battle for Conrail and for supremacy of the rail freight industry east of the Mississippi is far from over, however. 
 Norfolk Southern, which has offered $10 billion for Conrail, immediately appealed the decision by Federal District Judge Donald VanArtsdalen in Philadelphia. More important, CSX must still persuade Conrail shareholders next month to allow the railroad to acquire more than 20 percent of Conrail through its friendly, though less lucrative, offer.
"The next battleground is going to be the proxy fight leading up to the shareholder meeting in December," said Barry Benzing, a lawyer at Wolf, Block, Schorr & Solis-Cohen, whose firm is representing four arbitragers hoping that Conrail goes to the highest bidder. "It looks as if CSX will have a headstart now, but Norfolk clearly has the superior economic offer."
With yesterday's ruling in hand, CSX is now expected to counter Norfolk Southern's advertising blitz with its own campaign promoting its offer. The CSX offer would give shareholders $110 cash a share for 40 percent of Conrail shares and, if the deal is approved, a stock swap worth $84.22 a share for the remaining 60 percent of the shares. Norfolk Southern is offering $110 a share for all Conrail stock.
People close to the negotiations say that CSX will sweeten the offer for the remaining 60 percent of Conrail in early December to get the votes it needs.
Barring a successful appeal by Norfolk Southern, CSX is expected to complete its tender at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow for 19.9 percent of Conrail, giving shareholders about $2 billion in cash for a merger that may not take place until 1998, if at all.
Norfolk Southern had sought to block the friendly combination, contending in Federal court that Conrail's directors had abrogated their fiduciary responsibilities by agreeing to "unprecedented" merger terms that barred them from considering another richer offer for 270 days and prevented them from lifting the company's poison pill rights plan for any bidder other than CSX.
Moreover, Norfolk said that CSX's coercive, two-tiered, cash-and-stock offer was an attempt to stampede shareholders into accepting CSX's lower offer.
Testifying on Monday, John C. Coffee Jr., professor of corporate law at Columbia University, said he had not seen a "disparity this great" between the front and back ends of a takeover bid in over a decade.
"The Conrail directors are not in a position to live up to their own fiduciary duties, even if they wanted to," Professor Coffee, who testified for Norfolk Southern, said. "I don't think you can sell or trade your duty."
But Bradley Jones, a Conrail director, testified today that the company reviewed all its options before seeking out CSX in a strategic merger of equals.
Judge VanArtsdalen sided with Conrail in rejecting all of Norfolk Southern's arguments.
"It is hard for me to conceive of any shareholder being misled by Conrail or CSX," the judge said.
The judge's ruling came after the stock market closed. Earlier on the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Conrail rose 37.5 cents, to $96.375, while CSX shares rose 87.5 cents, to $45.375. Norfolk Southern shares edged up 12.5 cents, to $89.
After CSX acquires 19.9 percent of Conrail, it must convince the majority of Conrail's shareholders at a special meeting in mid-December to allow CSX to acquire the rest of the stock without having to offer $110 cash for all shares. The bulk of Conrail's outstanding shares are now in the hands of pension fund managers and arbitragers who have favored Norfolk Southern's richer offer and vowed to stop the merger with CSX.
No matter which company wins the war for control of Conrail it is unlikely that a merger will take place for at least two years.
In testimony before the House Transportation Committee yesterday, David Konschnik, director of the Surface Transportation Board, said the board was proposing a 10-month review process, with the final vote on the deal coming sometime late in 1997. The hearings before the board, which regulates railroads, are expected to provoke extensive and sometimes angry testimony from shippers and state and local officials because the merger could result in a single railroad dominating traffic in anywhere from 38 to 64 cities in the East, including Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Baltimore.
"With more and more mergers, shippers have become captive to one railroad, and typically, shippers captive to one railroad have not enjoyed the improvements in service and price as shippers who have more options," said Jim Hall, who oversees the transport of plastic and detergent products for the Condea Vista Company in Houston. "I'm a free-market guy, but monopolies aren't good."
In Maryland, where the Port of Baltimore is served by Conrail and CSX, Gov. Parris Glendening pulled together a task force last month of shippers, port officials and government agencies to assess the potential effects on the state's economy.
Both Norfolk and CSX have long coveted Conrail and its monopoly over freight rail traffic in the Northeast, particularly at the Port of New York, perhaps the richest consumer market in the nation. But it was John W. Snow, the chairman of CSX, who positioned himself as Conrail's white knight. He advised the railroad on a reorganization plan in the 1980's and then in 1987 Mr. Snow aided Conrail in fending off Norfolk Southern's takeover bid for Conrail shortly before the Government sold the company to the public.
A year ago, Mr. Snow and David R. Goode, chairman of Norfolk Southern, did spend several months exploring a joint bid for Conrail and a subsequent division of the assets but nothing came of it. Conrail ultimately opted to pursue a combination with CSX this fall. The company's love affair with CSX may be motivated by a sense that Conrail franchise and its aggressive managers would be embraced at the larger and somewhat creakier CSX, according to transportation analysts. Norfolk, by contrast, is regarded as the best run railroad in the industry and may not need another set of managers when and if it swallows Conrail.
"With CSX, Conrail believes that their management team has a chance to run the combined railroad in the future," Kevin Keefe, editor of Trains magazine, said. "Their future probably isn't as good with Norfolk Southern. Norfolk is the class of the industry when it comes to making money and running a railroad."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mark Strengthens vs. Dollar; Yen Weakens in Late Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against most currencies yesterday, hurt by an unexpectedly large increase in the United States trade deficit and new evidence of vitality in Germany's economy that helped strengthen the mark.
But the dollar recouped against the yen, which weakened broadly in late trading in New York on a report by the Kyodo News Service that the Japanese Ministry of Finance was closing the Hanwa Bank, a regional bank, because of insolvency. 
 "That bank has a huge amount of bad loans and is a reflection of Japanese banking weakness," said Kazuhiko Sekiguchi, vice president of foreign exchange at the Toyo Trust and Banking Company in New York. After the Kyodo report, he said, "Everybody sold the yen against the dollar and the mark."
Hanwa would be the first Japanese bank to shut down as a result of a glut of unpaid debt from the speculative 1980's and was seen as another reason why Japan's record-low interest rates are not likely to rise anytime soon. Higher rates would help the yen but aggravate the Japanese banking crisis.
"It brings forward the problem that these banks are still saddled with very poor loans," said Stephen Flanagan, senior foreign exchange trader at Credit Agricole in New York. "It's fess-up time in Japan. The fact of the matter is there are good fundamental reasons for the yen to be weak, and that mainly is the overhang of this debt."
In late trading in New York, the dollar settled at 111.55 yen, up from 111.40 yen on Tuesday. The dollar traded at 1.4968 marks, down from 1.5053 Tuesday and below the psychologically important 1.5000 level for the first time since Nov. 11. The pound was quoted at $1.6770, up from $1.6739, extending the British currency's string of four-year highs against the dollar.
The main catalyst for the dollar's weakness was the Commerce Department report that the trade deficit rose to $11.3 billion in September, the worst showing after a record $11.6 billion shortfall in July.
Forecasters had expected a slight decrease, reflecting their view that the slowing United States economy had diminished demand for imports. A rising deficit weakens the dollar by increasing the supply of dollars held abroad, which ultimately dilutes demand for the currency.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Be thrifty and invest well, and then wait for the huge tax bill.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
GOOD news for the affluent and thrifty: the 1996 law raising the minimum wage also suspends the 15 percent tax on "excess distributions" from retirement savings. Trouble is, the suspension of the tax lasts just three years. And what very few Americans understand, a new study argues, is that Washington has long been chipping away at retirement tax breaks, creating huge potential tax liabilities for millions of baby boomers and their heirs.
While the plight of those who have ridden the great bull market of the 1990's may not evoke much sympathy, a study by John Shoven of Stanford and David Wise of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, just published by the Center for Economic Policy Research at Stanford, suggests that it does illustrate the law of unintended consequences. "I don't think Congress meant to punish those who saved long and successfully with 90 percent taxes," Mr. Shoven allowed. 
 According to the conventional wisdom, "qualified" retirement savings -- defined benefit corporate pension plans, 401(k)'s, individual retirement accounts, Keogh's -- are the last great tax shelter for the middle class. Taxes on the money set aside from current income, along with taxes on the earnings of the money set aside, are deferred until the nest egg is spent in retirement.
But there are catches. To deter the rich from exploiting retirement accounts, Congress put an extra 15 percent tax on annual distributions exceeding $150,000. This is the tax that was suspended from 1997 through 1999; thereafter "excess distributions" will be indexed to inflation before they are taxed.
A companion "excessive accumulation" tax (which was not suspended or indexed), adds a 15 percentage point surcharge to Federal estate taxes on retirement assets in excess of the amount actuarially needed to finance a $155,000 annual pension. For the estate of a 65-year-old, an accumulation greater than $1.2 million is considered excessive; for an 80-year-old, the figure is about $800,000.
Because the excess distribution tax is not deductible from state or local income taxes, those liable to pay it end up in a 56 percent Federal bracket. In a high-tax state like California they pay 61 cents of the last dollar spent. With a substantial estate (one in excess of $3 million), the combination of Federal estate taxes and the excess accumulation tax put the heirs in a 62 percent bracket.
But wait: personal income taxes must also be paid on tax-sheltered retirement accumulations within estates. And that puts the $3 million estate in the 92 percent bracket, or even more if state taxes are exceptionally stiff. For the heirs of a $10 million estate in New York who are themselves in the top tax bracket, Mr. Shoven and Mr. Wise calculate that government gets 99.73 cents out of the last dollar.
What does all this have to do with just plain folks who eat early-bird dinners and make good use of their A.A.R.P. discounts? More than you might expect, the economists explain, provided that investments in stocks do as well in the future as they have in the past.
Take the case of a professional who begins a career today at age 25 with a $50,000 salary, averages just a 2 percent annual real raise for the next four decades, saves 10 percent of her income in qualified retirement plans and enjoys an 8 percent real rate of return. She will accumulate $1.8 million by age 65 and $2.7 million by age 70 -- more than enough to set off the excess accumulation tax, should she die before spending the principal.
Or consider a baby boomer who started work in 1971 at $15,000, enjoyed salary increases of 2.5 percent annually after inflation through 1995, and then settled down to 1 percent raises until retirement. If he saved 10 percent of his income and earned 8 percent on the assets annually through 1995, he would have accumulated $675,000 by age 50. Another 15 years of persistent 10 percent savings that compounded at an 8 percent return would get him up to $2.4 million.
One very practical implication, Mr. Shoven argues, is that tax shelters can easily become tax traps for middle-income Americans who are thrifty and invest well. But the broader issue here is whether it ever makes sense to tax assets at rates exceeding 90 percent.
After all, high savings rates are good for the economy as a whole, both because they reduce the proportion of retirees who need public subsidies and because capital accumulation raises the productivity of those still working. It is one thing to deny lucrative tax breaks to the tiny fraction of the population that is drowning in wealth. It is quite another to undermine the savings incentives of the upper middle class.

HEADLINE: North Korea's Heir Seems in Charge, but a Grim Winter Looms

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 15

 BODY:
As wintry cold spreads across the Korean Peninsula, North Korea is desperately short of oil and food and lacks a president. But it at least appears to have someone in charge.
Kim Jong Il, 54, has still not taken over the titles of head of state and head of the ruling party since his father, Kim Il Sung, died more than two years ago. But even though the posts remain vacant, diplomats and other analysts increasingly say the son appears to be running the country and consolidating his authority. 
 Moreover, some say that for all North Korea's problems and despite speculation that it is near collapse, it could stagger on indefinitely.
"Our view is that Kim Jong Il is in firm control over his country," said Lieut. Gen. Park Yong Ok, the South Korean Assistant Defense Minister. "We think North Korea is capable of maintaining its system for the time being. We don't expect North Korea to collapse right now."
Still, there is little doubt that North Korea's 24 million people face a desperate winter. Severe flooding in 1995 was compounded by torrential rainstorms this summer. The latest flooding left 147,000 people homeless and killed 32,000 head of livestock, the International Red Cross says.
Even North Korean soldiers, who have been protected from the worst of the food shortages, are not getting enough to eat. Chang Chol Bong, a North Korean sergeant who defected this year, stood 5 feet 4 inches tall and weighed just 92 pounds.
"They simply don't grow enough to feed their people," said James T. Laney, the American Ambassador to South Korea. "We think that probably by February, they should have real shortages of grain."
"We don't have many reports of real starvation," he said. "We have a lot of reports of malnutrition."
North Korea is responding to its difficulties in a variety of ways. It now tolerates private markets in many areas, allows foreign aid workers access even to poor areas and has been surprisingly frank about its food shortages.
There are also growing accounts that North Korea is turning to counterfeiting and drug trafficking to raise money. Some intelligence experts say they believe that North Korea is turning out fake $100 "supernotes" in a factory in its capital, Pyongyang, and a recent defector from North Korea asserted this month that the North was operating opium farms in more than 10 places across the country.
The defector, a former pharmaceutical official, said the opium was sold abroad for hard currency.
The economic difficulties might also explain why North Korea is reluctant to exchange liaison offices with the United States, a step toward normalizing relations. The United States is willing to open an office in Pyongyang on a reciprocal basis, but North Korea has balked, and some officials say they believe that the problem is a lack of money to open a mission in Washington.
Many experts expect Kim Jong Il to assume the top Government and party posts next summer, around the third anniversary of his father's death. Mr. Kim, who always used to be called the "Dear Leader," is now referred to by the North Korean news organizations as the "Great Leader," although the expression in Korean is different from the term for "Great Leader" that was always used to describe his father.
In a measure of the kind of adulation that Kim Jong Il receives, the North Korean Government declared this year that in addition to his other accomplishments, he is "a great maker of witty remarks." The announcement said those jokes "have equipped the people with the most scientific and revolutionary world outlook."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Political Gambling

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: CAREFREE, Ariz.

 BODY:
The gamblers won a ballot initiative in Arizona, where voters called on the Governor to sign a casino deal with Indian tribes -- though he gutsily says he won't. And in Detroit, citizens fearful of losing business to a casino in Ontario voted to build a defensive one of their very own. That's two scores for the crapshooters.
But elsewhere across the country, the moral blight of organized, big-league casino and riverboat gambling -- and the public disgrace of state-sponsored gambling -- took a licking from people who have grown tired of being taken for suckers. 
 Despite more than $4 million spent by casino operators, gambling industry PAC's and unionized croupiers, the voters in 23 elections and referendums decisively defeated proposals to make the get-rich-quick philosophy -- with transfixed players tugging ever-hopefully at the one-armed bandits -- their local way of life.
Why? One reason is that experience has shown the promise of state-sponsored lotteries -- that the proceeds would be used for more or better education -- is a fraud. Money is fungible; when the state or city raises money "painlessly," from public or private gambling, some of that money is ostentatiously set aside for schools -- but legislators soon treat that as a replacement for funds previously voted for education.
Another reason for the gambling defeats is bipartisan shame. Liberals are ashamed of raising money regressively, preying on those who can least afford to lose. Conservatives are ashamed of allowing government actively to encourage an ancient vice and exploit a human weakness. Up to now, the nation's anti-gambling majority has been afflicted with "pluralistic ignorance" -- not realizing it is a majority.
That's ending because rampant casino-ism in Las Vegas and Atlantic City is competing with the tax-avoiding palaces of glitz operated by real and phony Indian tribes, and their market appears to be reaching the saturation point. Even the largest supplier of lottery equipment noted a 10 percent drop in sales and admitted to Adam Nossiter of The New York Times that "public support of legalized gaming may be waning."
The public is not as apathetic as cracked up to be at the spectacle of government promotion of moral degeneration. We're not talking here about a friendly evening of dollar-ante poker or a charity bingo game or office pool; we're dealing with a $40-billion-a-year predatory industry that deserves no official boost. Gambling's new ability to turn a home computer into a slot machine should get no government encouragement.
Thanks to Tom Grey and his National Coalition Against Legalized Gambling, and to Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska and Representative Frank Wolf of Virginia, a national commission was set up this summer to study gambling's impact. The casino lobby, unable to weaken it, is now out to rig the nine-member commission with gambling enthusiasts.
Trent Lott resisted, picking a family-values type and an objective radiologist, but Newt Gingrich let down morality's side. Eager to help a Nevada freshman under union financial assault get re-elected, the Speaker named the C.E.O. of the MGM Grand casino company in Las Vegas, along with an unbiased academic.
Democrats may do worse. President Clinton is on the verge of appointing a Nevada gambling bureaucrat and a pro-casino Native American; his third pick may give the illusion of balance. Tom Grey suspects that Senator Tom Daschle leans toward a South Dakota gambling commissioner and the House's Dick Gephardt is pledged to a union official representing casino employees, but both say they have not decided.
That would stack the commission in gambling's favor, guaranteeing a Pablum report and undermining the whole point of the exercise.
It's hard to believe the President is ready to go along with this. Such tilting of the table is in direct conflict with his family-values pitch; equally important, he no longer needs the soft money from casino interests for future campaigns. It would cost him nothing to do what is right.
Clinton's commission choices will determine whether we get the truth about gambling's impact on economies and its victim-customers -- or get the sort of sleight-of-hand at which some gamblers are so adept.
No dead-of-night appointments. We'll all be watching.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Moscow Journal;
The Cloakrooms of Russia, the Dens of Dragons

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Winter has slowly begun to muscle its way back to its natural place at the center of Russian life. Furs are starting to emerge from storage. So are hats and boots. It is the season when mud gives way to snow and people tape their windows shut against the cold.
It is also the season of the awesomely powerful, routinely unpleasant women who rule the cloakrooms of the nation. There are very few figures of serious authority left in Russia -- people nobody would dare to challenge. The guardians of cloakrooms -- there is one in nearly every public building in the country -- are definitely among them. 
 At dry cleaners in America, who hasn't lost a ticket and still come away with the goods? But in Russia, rules -- however rare, bizarre and contradictory they may be -- are still rules.
"I lost my coat check once at the Bolshoi," said Galina Abalkina, 37, an economist who works for the Moscow City prosecutor. "I didn't even bother to ask for it. I just went home in the cold, shivering. My mother finally had to get the coat for me."
This is a country where etiquette is not particularly prized. But even here there are limits, and wearing coats indoors exceeds them.
You cannot enter a building unless you turn your coat in at the door. Drafts in offices here are as common as the snows (and the object of another national obsession) but do not try to keep your coat on in any business, hotel, restaurant or other large building. It won't happen.
To many of the pension-age women who work in cloakrooms, the fact that people would actually leave their coats on indoors is the clearest sign that the nation has seriously lost its way.
"I see this type of person from other countries on TV shows," said Yuliya Aleksandrovna, who did not give her last name because, at 65, she does not want anyone she once worked with to know that she checks coats at the Institute of Russian Language for a living.
"They walk into a room and a man starts smoking and sitting on a couch in his coat," she said. "They don't even take off their boots. And the women -- they put their feet right up on a chair without taking off their shoes. It's terrible. For me, it's an atomic bomb."
Most of those employed at cloakrooms make less than $100 a month. There is a union, a Coat Check Society, and its members make more, sometimes twice as much. The women receive modest tips as well. And befitting its nature as one of the last true Soviet institutions, the guild also supplies those members with complete medical benefits, trips to spas and other benefits. What it cannot supply its members, however, is their salaries.
"Half our clients have failed to pay their salaries this year," said Vladimir N. Zlobin, head of the society.
Outside his office in central Moscow there is a list of items a coat-check person is not required to accept. No flammable objects, poison, waste, sharp instruments or explosives. Nothing overtly agricultural or obviously spoiled. Anything else goes.
"We do a serve a very important social function, and the list of our customers is a list of noble and great Russian institutions," Mr. Zlobin said. "The Tretyakov Gallery, the Lenin Library. They want the services but they can't afford to pay us."
For that reason, most institutions are going it alone these days. But none except movie houses dare dispense with the custom altogether. That is probably because the coat-check system -- however inflexible it became in the Soviet experience -- has a noble heritage.
"Garderobe," as the cloakroom is known here, is a French word that appeared in Russian dictionaries for the first time only in 1780. The system began as a way to honor the elegance of fashion in a country where the elements always make elegance a struggle.
"In prerevolutionary times, people dressed for the theater in the most magnificent manner," said Irina Saveleva, professor of arts at the Russian Science Institute of Textile and Light Industry. She teaches the history of clothing and folk clothes.
"People came in furs and diamonds and the most sumptuous clothing," she said. "There couldn't even be talk of entering with outer clothes on. It didn't match the luxurious interior of the theater, or the action that was going on stage. It was a celebration."
"We undress everywhere," Professor Saveleva continued. "Even at restaurants. We don't take our clothes off only in those places that are 'to go' " -- a place like McDonald's, for example.
At the Rossiya Hotel, which was closed by an epidemic of rats two years ago but is now back in business, the coat-check team is among the most aggressive around.
"Don't give me one," Aleksandra I. Boyevna, 61, said when asked what she does with coats that lack loops sewn into the back. "I don't accept them."
That is routine. Anyone offering a coat without a loop can expect to become engulfed in a torrent of abuse. Anybody trying to wear a coat inside can, too.
"This country is falling apart," she said, practically spitting and warily examining a foreigner's coat for any sign of hooklessness. "But in one profession we can have standards. You don't wear a coat inside. That is policy that survived the czars and it survived the Communists. It's rude. It's wrong. And we won't allow it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: In Russia, no one wears a coat inside. Enforcing that rule are the cloakroom attendants, among the few figures of serious authority left in the country. At the Pushkin Museum in Moscow, an attendant surveyed her world. (James Hill for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Romania's Communist Legacy: 'Abortion Culture'

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Dorina Ciuplan, a 40-year-old mother of three teen-agers, recalled with a mixture of terror and emotion the nine self-induced abortions she endured during Communist rule under Nicolae Ceausescu.
"I sometimes think I'm lucky to be alive," said Mrs. Ciuplan, her eyes watering as she described forcing miscarriages at home and then going to a hospital, where doctors and nurses tormented her with abusive words and rough treatment as they finished terminating the pregnancies rather than let her die. 
 For more than two decades, contraception and abortions were strictly forbidden by Mr. Ceausescu in an attempt to build his country into a colossus through population growth. His government was overthrown in 1989, and one of its legacies was orphanages filled with unwanted and neglected children.
Another legacy of those horrific years, for Romania's women, is abortion. Some 10,000 women are believed to have died from complications of illegal abortions, and many more were permanently maimed.
Abortions were legalized as soon as Mr. Ceausescu was toppled, and contraception is theoretically available through the state health system.
But overwhelmingly, Romania remains what Western doctors call an "abortion culture," with an abortion rate that remains the highest in Europe. It also has by far the highest rate of pregnancy-related mortality, the strongest indication that Romania continues to lag far behind the rest of Europe and Russia in providing reproductive health services for women.
According to the United Nations Population Fund, Romania had 3.2 abortions for every live birth in 1990. By last year, the rate was 2.2 abortions per live birth. In 1995, the equivalent rate was 2.0 in Russia, 0.67 in the Czech Republic and Hungary and 0.2 in Germany.
The reasons why Romanian women turn to abortion center on the reluctance of the Government to promote family-planning despite healthy doses of Western aid to help the country establish such services, Western and Romanian doctors say. Iulian Mincu, who was Minister of Health until recently and who had been a personal physician to Mr. Ceausescu, publicly stated his opposition to family planning. After a public outcry over poor conditions in the health system, Dr. Mincu was dismissed this summer by Mr. Ceausescu's successor, Ion Iliescu, in an attempt to clean up the Government's image before parliamentary and presidential elections that Mr. Iliescu lost anyway.
The President-elect, Emil Constantinescu, made it clear during his campaign that he would make improved health services a priority, and family planning advocates said they were optimistic that the new Government would be more supportive of their efforts.
Without guidance from the Government, many Romanian doctors have been more enthusiastic about the more lucrative work of performing abortions than about recommending birth control, said Daniela Draghica, one of the administrators of 12 pilot family-planning clinics in Romania opened in 1995 and financed by the United States Agency for International Development.
The state pays for abortions, but as with almost all public health services women say they feel obliged to give the doctor a sizable extra payment, thus making abortions more financially rewarding.
A 28-year-old woman who would give only a first name, Adina, was at the gynecological clinic at Giulesti Hospital in Bucharest. She said she had had six abortions. An abortion costs 3,000 lei, a little less than $1, at public hospitals, where the vast majority of Romanians get their health care. But she said she had paid an additional $7 as a "gift" to the doctor.
On top of this, many doctors, repeating myths from the Ceausescu years, tell women exaggerated stories that oral contraceptives are deleterious to their health, Mrs. Draghica said.
"Women had these myths about contraception," Mrs. Draghica said. "The doctors had told them that pills were bad because they made women fat and gave them heart disease. It's a battle to get their confidence."
Some women are beginning to look for other alternatives. Maria Staicu, 41, who lives in the city of Sibiu and has two children, said the pain and debasement she endured in 1991 when she had a legal abortion left her determined not to go through it again.
"They did 20 women in a few minutes: 'Ready, go; ready, go,' " she said, describing the atmosphere in the state hospital. In the last five years of the Ceausescu regime, she had managed to buy Hungarian-made oral contraceptives on the black market, she said. After her abortion in 1991, she was fitted with an I.U.D.. "I would prefer anything else than an abortion," she said.
Romania remains the only country in Eastern Europe not to manufacture any kind of contraceptive. Thus supplies, including condoms, must be imported and are too expensive for many women, who say they have trouble even getting food on the table in the chaotic Romanian economy. Birth control pills imported from Hungary, the Netherlands or Germany cost as much for a month's supply -- or in many cases up to two or three times as much -- as an abortion, even though Western aid helps subsidize some of the cost.
The Western aid stems from publicity in 1990 about the plight of the unwanted Romanian children. Foreign assistance was sent to help care for the children, and for a longer-term solution, funds were offered to create family- planning services, including a $14 million World Bank loan and a $5 million grant from the United States Agency for International Development.
In the last year, a little progress has been made, but not enough given the resources that have been made available, those who work in the program say.
According to a report by Adriana Baban, a psychologist who counsels at one of the Romanian family-planning clinics funded by the A.I.D., and Dr. Henry P. David, director of the Transnational Family Research Institute, a nonprofit group in Washington, Romania had at least 445 deaths attributable to illegal abortion in 1989. By 1992, the number had been reduced to 120 and last year to 59.
But despite these reductions of deaths from self-induced abortions, the pregnancy-related mortality rate remains startlingly high. The World Health Organization reported that in 1990, for every 100,000 live births in Romania, 84 women died in childbirth. By contrast, the rate in Poland was 19. Last year, the number in Romania was 48. In the United States last year, the rate was 8, according to the Population Reference Bureau.

HEADLINE: All Aid Is Political

BYLINE: By Chester A. Crocker; Chester A. Crocker, a professor of diplomacy at Georgetown University, was Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs in the Reagan Administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Nothing better illustrates the lessons and risks of humanitarian intervention than the fast-changing situation in Central Africa. It reminds us that intervention (just like nonintervention) is an inherently political action with inescapable political consequences.
The United States should have learned this in Bosnia, Somalia and northern Iraq. Labeling an intervention humanitarian may temporarily allay the qualms of public opinion, but it does not dilute the political effects on a region. By the same token, if we decide not to step into a crisis, our determination not to get involved does not free us of political and ethical responsibility for our inaction. 
 Look at Africa. Our post-Somalia paralysis prevented us in 1994 from calling for Western intervention in Rwanda to halt the killing of a half million Tutsi by the Hutu majority. This butchery could have been prevented by the prompt deployment of an international force with a mandate to isolate and disarm the extremist Hutu militia and to detain their leaders for a war crimes tribunal.
When the tide turned and a Tutsi rebel movement (now Rwanda's Government) drove nearly a million Hutu refugees into Zaire, we rushed in to set up refugee camps. But our belated humanitarian spasm did nothing to help the refugees free themselves from the grip of the Hutu militia leaders; nor did we act to turn these warlords over to a war crimes tribunal. The refugee camps soon disrupted Zaire, inflaming Hutu-Tutsi tensions within the country, aggravating relations between Zaire and Rwanda and providing a base for the Hutu militia to raid Rwanda.
Thus, two years later, the Clinton Administration was facing allied and public pressure to "do something" about the impending disaster in Zaire. Despite the obviously political nature of the problem, the United States and Canada were determined to confine any action to a "humanitarian" response, even asking for the agreement of local players before we intervened. Pentagon planners, fearing any proximity to ethnic strife, made it clear that the mission was not to police, disarm, detain or arrest anyone.
To the Administration's vast relief, the refugee crisis largely resolved itself last weekend. No American ground troops will be sent to Zaire, although military airlifts and logistical support will be needed. How did it all change so quickly? Because the Rwandan Government and Zairean rebels took matters into their own hands, fearing that the United States might make the problem worse by sustaining and nourishing the camps.
Zairean rebels (mostly local Tutsi acting in coordination with the Rwandan Government) liberated perhaps 600,000 Hutu refugees near Goma from their militia warlords; the same thing is likely to happen at camps farther south. Hutu civilians rushed to return to Rwanda, while Hutu remnants of the former Rwandan Army and the militia and their followers are moving deeper into Zaire.
So what are the real lessons here? Most important, if America is not prepared to use its muscle to address underlying political problems, it should think twice about creating and sustaining humanitarian safe havens and corridors. When humanitarian action becomes unavoidable, it is equally vital that we link it to a broader political strategy.
In Central Africa, that strategy should have been to clamp down on the Hutu extremists who organized the hatred through radio campaigns and unleashed the carnage in the first place. It is not too late to provide help in this regard; we should share our intelligence reports with some area governments and provide legal expertise and financial aid to further the efforts of the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda.
Also, greater care should be taken in describing problems in Central Africa and elsewhere as "ethnic conflicts." If it were that simple, would hundreds of thousands of Hutu be streaming back to their villages in Tutsi-controlled Rwanda?
Civil wars are too volatile and costly to handle reactively. Before violence erupts again, we should more actively push Central African nations toward political solutions. In moving on from the Mobutu era and solving its many problems -- revitalizing the economy, instituting democracy, restoring collapsing institutions -- Zaire needs help from the United States and its allies. And it needs help now, before the next "humanitarian" crisis forces our hand.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Note Auction Success Sends Bonds Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose in late trading yesterday, following a note auction that was better than expected and by a rebound in the dollar.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 11/32 , to 1014/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.41 percent, from 6.43 percent on Tuesday. 
 Bond prices rose after the Treasury successfully sold $12.5 billion in new five-year notes, following the sale of $18.25 billion in two-year notes on Tuesday. The five-year notes sold at a discount of 5.95 percent, down from 6.325 percent at the last auction in October and the lowest rate since Feb. 28.
"The auction did go well," said William Gross, managing director at the Pacific Investment Management Company in Newport Beach, Calif. He added that bids from Wall Street firms could have handled three times the securities that were sold, indicating strong market interest.
After the auction news was out, the dollar began retracing early losses against the yen on a report by Kyodo News Service that Japan's Ministry of Finance was closing Hanwa Bank, a regional bank, because of insolvency.
The report sent Japanese and American investors fleeing to the relative safety of the dollar and dollar-denominated securities, said Paul Kasriel, chief domestic economist at Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
"It just reinforces the view that the Japanese economy still has a lot of problems and that interest rates are not going to be rising there any time soon, which helps the dollar," Mr. Kasriel said.
Bond prices started the day lower after the Commerce Department said the nation's trade deficit climbed to $11.3 billion in September, the worst showing since an all-time high of $11.6 billion in July, as oil imports rose. Analysts had expected a slight narrowing, believing a downturn in the economy would dampen demand in the United States for foreign products.
The long bond was down a quarter-point at midday, but rallied when the auction results were made public around 2 P.M. and then again as the dollar advanced.
Further scrutiny of the trade deficit data calmed some fears in the bond market as well, as analysts noted slower growth in the gross national product than had previously been suspected, Mr. Kasriel of Northern Trust said.
"The trade numbers really weren't as bad in fundamental terms as they looked," he said.
"We did buy more oil, and we paid a higher price for it. But we didn't ship as many aircraft, and now we know that Boeing's orders are very strong both domestically and foreign," so aircraft exports going forward are going to be strong.
Prices of short-term Treasury securities ended unchanged, while intermediate maturities rose between one-eighth point and one-quarter point, reported Dow Jones Telerate Inc., a financial information service.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 1.40 point, to 1,262.66.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 117 3/4, up from 11719/32 on Tuesday. The average yield to maturity was 5.72 percent, down from 5.73 percent.
Following are the results of the Treasury's auction of five-year notes yesterday:

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
With the Mud Flying, Race for Mayor Begins

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
And suddenly, in a furor of radio ads and accusations, the 1997 mayoral campaign has begun on a distinctly rancorous note, very possibly foreshadowing the tone for the year to come.
With a swiftness and bitterness that have surprised many local politicians, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his most prominent opponent for re-election, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, have already prepared thinly disguised attack advertisements on the radio and are charging each other with improprieties. The ads are ostensibly about the Mayor's proposal to allow superstores in parts of New York City, but their propulsion systems are clearly political. 
 Ms. Messinger's ad touts her as a "mom who raised three kids" and says the Mayor "may not care what you want for your neighborhood." The Mayor's ad blasts the "politicians and special interests" who are deliberately keeping prices high by prohibiting superstores.
He accused Ms. Messinger of abusing the campaign finance law by spending public money on her ads, and -- though he was unable to substantiate the contention -- said she had "cheated" in her financing of two previous races. Ms. Messinger, saying the Mayor needed to take a Valium and some "truth serum," criticized him for not revealing who is paying for his ads.
Similar skirmishes have also occurred in recent weeks between Mr. Giuliani and various potential opponents over such matters as the sale of public hospitals, the size of the education budget, and the battle with Time Warner Cable, making it clear that virtually any contentious issue is fuel for the political crucible.
Four years ago, when Mr. Giuliani was preparing his second run against David N. Dinkins, the acrimony was nowhere near this level. There was some early jousting over Mr. Dinkins's response to the Crown Heights disturbances, but there was no explicit name-calling, and the ads were months away. Rarely, in fact, do mayoral campaigns accelerate quite as rapidly as this one has in the fortnight since the Presidential election.
The Mayor's supporters blame Ms. Messinger, who they say started it all by running such a harsh radio ad and using money from her own public budget to pay for it. Having maintained a strong stand against the unfettered development of superstores for more than a year, Ms. Messinger does seem to have left herself vulnerable to such criticism by not using any of the $1.3 million in campaign money she has raised to pay for the $7,400 ad.
"Her commercials use taxpayer money under the guise of spelling out her view," said Raymond B. Harding, the Liberal Party leader and one of the Mayor's close political advisers. "She's the one who attacks Giuliani by name and refers to herself as a mom who raised three kids. Why should the taxpayers have to pay for her attacks on the person of the Mayor?" Another of Mr. Giuliani's allies, Councilman Andrew S. Eristoff, has filed a formal complaint about the ads with the city Conflicts of Interest Board.
To some degree, the direction of the campaign so far reflects the nature of running against a strong incumbent best known for reducing crime and working to restore a perception of order to the city, still the most important issues for many voters. Opponents are forced to seize upon the remaining issues -- education, hospitals, superstores, among others -- and hammer hard at those areas where the Mayor may be vulnerable.
But Mr. Giuliani's political style has also clearly contributed to the current decibel level. For weeks he has been attacking his most likely opponents as "old-fashioned politicians" or "machine politicians" who have personally caused the problems he has had to fix. Having made it apparent over the last three years that he considers a personal attack a legitimate response to those who oppose him, he has built up an atmosphere at City Hall in which every policy debate -- whether over the budget, union contracts, education, or crime -- quickly escalates into a confrontation.
"I believe what is happening now comes as a result of the perception, which is factual, that Giuliani will readily engage in gutter politics," said former Mayor Edward I. Koch, a former supporter of Mr. Giuliani and now a confirmed opponent. "These other candidates, therefore, have decided that to protect themselves, they have got to begin early and sling as much mud as he does. It's bad for the city, because it brings everyone down to the lowest common swamp denominator."
Ms. Messinger said she thought the Mayor had set a negative tone earlier this month when he denigrated each of his potential opponents by name. But the decision to run the advertisements, she said, was made because the superstore zoning issue is before the City Council, and was unrelated to Mr. Giuliani's remarks. She used public money for the ads because she considers fighting the zoning proposal part of her job, she said.
In response to questions first raised by Ms. Messinger, the Giuliani administration yesterday released the names of four people who are helping to raise money for the Mayor's ad campaign on superstores: Kathryn Wylde, president of the New York City Investment Fund, a nonprofit group that promotes economic development; Edward J. Molloy, president of the Building Trades Council; Joseph Fedele, co-owner of the Fairway supermarket in Harlem, and Joe Wiscovitch, owner of an advertising agency that specializes in marketing products to the Hispanic community.
Mr. Wiscovitch, the designated spokesman for the group, which is calling itself the Committee for Consumer Choice, said the names of contributors were not yet available because fund raising was still going on. He said the group hoped to raise at least $100,000 for its ad campaign, which will begin criticizing "special interests" next week.
And there are still 348 days until the election.

HEADLINE: Treasury Report Will Oppose Federal Taxes on Internet Sales

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
The Treasury Department, struggling to devise a tax policy that keeps up with the rapid growth of electronic commerce, will publish a draft report today that outlines the Administration's opposition to new Federal taxes on the Internet but underscores its determination that the global computer network not become a haven for tax evaders.
"We absolutely reject the idea that the Internet is some sort of golden goose whose feathers should be taxed," Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers said. "The key message of the report is, no Internet taxes." 
 The report, which will be posted for public comment on the Treasury Department's World Wide Web site (www.ustreas.gov), will make no formal policy recommendations. Treasury officials said the report would advocate an "overarching goal of neutrality," at least on the Federal level, when it comes to the Internet.
"Neutrality means we shouldn't treat a transaction any differently because it occurs over the Internet, as compared to one that does not occur over the Internet," one senior Treasury official, who insisted that he not be identified, said. "We can take existing tax principles and evolve them."
Although the 50-page report is intended to disclose the Clinton Administration's general thinking on key issues affecting global electronic commerce and taxation, it will not specifically address the issues of state and local taxation on electronic transactions and on-line services.
A number of states, including New York, are considering the possibility of new sales and use taxes on the Internet and on-line information services, which have attracted tens of millions of consumers and hundreds of thousands of businesses in recent years.
The report outlines the challenges faced by tax officials in a world where buyers and sellers can be anonymous, where transactions take place in cyberspace and where both money and products exist as flurries of electronic bits.
"The issue is really whether they can effectively maintain an income tax, as electronic commerce grows and people start using digital cash, especially if it can be used anonymously," said Andrew Whinston, a professor of computer science and economics at the University of Texas in Austin.
"There is also the issue of illegal transactions," Dr. Whinston said. "For example, drug transactions that are now conducted with a suitcase of $100 bills can potentially escape detection on the Internet. This in turn gets into the issue of key escrow encryption policy, and whether the Government has the right to decrypt certain messages to see whether they are concealing violations of the law."
According to industry analysts, the value of computer-based electronic commerce in the United States is expected to expand to more than $70 billion a year by the end of the decade, from slightly more than $500 million this year.
Besides the Federal Government, many of the country's more than 30,000 state and local taxing authorities have taken an interest in that flow of money. Computer and on-line industry executives, as well as many Internet users, have been alarmed by the recent proposals and suggestions, mainly on the state level, to impose new taxes, beyond standard sales taxes, on Internet use and transactions.
But the Internet poses legal and technical issues for tax officials. For example, where does a transaction take place: at the user's personal computer; at the Internet service provider's computer, which may be in another state, or at the seller's computer, which may be in a different country?
And, how can tax officials monitor transactions when technologies like digital cash make it possible to buy and sell anonymously?
The report is likely to calm some Internet companies fearful of new or redundant taxes, at least on the Federal level, but other analysts said it missed a chance to simplify the tax code, especially as the Internet becomes a major force in international commerce.
"Why evolve a mess?" said Bill Bluestein, director of new media research at Forrester Research Inc. in Cambridge, Mass. "Why not take the opportunity to simplify it?"
Mr. Bluestein said attempts to add new taxes on the Internet "take away the ability to use the Internet as a more efficient delivery channel, which would ultimately benefit consumers by lowering costs."
Ellen K. Fishbein, assistant general counsel for America Online Inc., said the Interactive Services Association, a trade group whose members include most of the country's largest on-line service providers, was preparing its own position paper on Internet taxation, expected to be released within a month.
"Our goals are uniformity for definitions and rates between the states," Ms. Fishbein said, "but we view it as a stepping stone on how to deal with taxation globally. Whatever concepts we come up with need to be applied everywhere."
The Government report was prepared by Treasury Department experts with support from the White House, the office of the Vice President and the National Economic Council.
"We view this as the beginning of the process of getting comments," the senior Treasury Department official said. "We can see that the developments on the Internet are dramatic, and they are accelerating. This is our attempt to stay ahead of the curve."

HEADLINE: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT WORSENS, AND GAP WITH CHINA GROWS

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
As President Clinton prepares to press top Chinese officials to open their market more fully to American goods, the Government reported today that the trade deficit with China rose in September to another record. It was part of one of the widest overall monthly trade gaps posted by the United States in years.
The Commerce Department said the nation's overall trade deficit for September unexpectedly surged to $11.3 billion, $1 billion higher than a month earlier and the second-highest gap, after July's $11.6 billion, since the Government adopted its current measurement system in 1992. Economists had predicted a decline of $1 billion or more. 
 For the second consecutive month and the third time this year, the deficit with China was the largest with any nation, further evidence of how China is supplanting Japan as the primary source of trade tension for the United States.
Mr. Clinton is scheduled to meet President Jiang Zemin of China in the Philippines on Sunday at a gathering of Asian leaders, and Mr. Clinton is expected to insist that China break a long pattern of intransigence and lower its trade barriers if it wants to join the global trade body, the World Trade Organization. Secretary of State Warren Christopher met today with China's leaders in part to prepare the ground for Mr. Clinton's meeting. [Page A10.]
With the two nations also at odds over issues including human rights and nuclear arms, Mr. Clinton spoke in upbeat terms today about the opportunity to "sustain an engagement" with China and improve relations across a broad front.
"The United States and China will continue to have our differences, especially in the area of human rights, and we will continue to discuss them candidly," Mr. Clinton said in Australia, where he was visiting before attending the meeting of Asian leaders.
"But by working together where possible and dealing with our differences openly and respectfully when necessary, we can deepen our dialogue and add to Asia's stability."
The trade deficit with China was $4.73 billion in September, up just fractionally from its August level but nearly $1 billion higher than the September deficit with Japan, which was down marginally from a month earlier.
While the cumulative deficit with Japan for the first nine months of the years remained larger than the deficit with China, the trade gap with Japan was down 27 percent for the period while it grew 14 percent with China.
Today's figures led critics of the Administration's trade policies to complain that Mr. Clinton's team has been long on rhetoric but short on results when it comes to prying open foreign markets and reducing the deficit. The overall trade deficit has grown in each year of his Presidency and is on track to exceed last year's total of $105 billion.
"The fact is there has been a leadership void in U.S. trade policy during the last year," said Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, a Republican who is chairman of the subcommittee on trade.
The rise in the overall deficit was driven in part by surging oil prices, which pushed up the value of imports, and by a strong dollar and weak economic growth among a number of major trading partners, which held down demand for American goods and services abroad.
Despite the sharp slowdown in the American economy in recent months, higher oil prices kept imports steady at $80.1 billion in September. More recently, oil prices have fallen somewhat, raising the prospect of a decline in that element of the trade deficit.
Exports, which had been one of the primary sources of strength in the American economy, declined by $1 billion in September to $68.8 billion. The total was depressed somewhat by a decline in exports of aircraft and parts, which fluctuate sharply because commercial airliners are individually so expensive and are usually ordered in bunches.
On the other side of the ledger, exports of automobiles and parts reached a record high of $5.9 billion.
The unexpected rise in the trade gap for September led some analysts to project that economic growth estimates for both the third and fourth quarters would have to be scaled back. The Government's original estimate of third-quarter growth, 2.2 percent, already down sharply from the 4.7 percent growth rate in the spring, may now be revised downward to around 1.5 percent.
"This was truly a pathetic performance that raises some questions about the extent of growth going forward," said Joel L. Naroff, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Philadelphia.
"Yes, the entire increase in the goods deficit can be traced to higher petroleum imports, and as the price declines, the nominal trade deficit will decline as well," Mr. Naroff said. "But the situation with China has become critical."
Senator Grassley called the coming meetings between the American and Chinese leaders "yet another opportunity to establish the terms of the relationship the U.S. will have with China."
"While the latest trade deficit numbers show that it's important to have China in the W.T.O.," he said, "the Administration must insist that China enter under terms that are fair to the American people."
Although the growth in exports has slowed this year, Mickey Kantor, the Secretary of Commerce, said the overall level of exports would again set a record, reflecting the improved competitiveness of American industry and market-opening agreements with Japan and other nations.
Mr. Kantor said the September trade figures would "really have no effect" on negotiations with China. Those talks have proved almost unremittingly frustrating to the United States over the last few years despite China's professed commitment to agreements like one seeking to control Chinese piracy of videos, software and other intellectual property.
"We have continued concerns over market access in China within the industrial and agricultural sectors," said Mr. Kantor, who was the Administration's chief trade negotiator before he was named Commerce Secretary earlier this year. "We've been heartened to some degree by China's willingness to implement the second intellectual property agreement, but we've not made appreciable progress with regard to their accession to the W.T.O."
China's Finance Minister, Liu Zhongli, said in Washington on Tuesday that the trade gap between the nations was an "old issue" that was exacerbated by differing systems of measuring trade flows.
Mr. Liu also said the United States could help its trade position by relaxing export controls on many types of technologies that would find ready buyers in China.
The deficit with China has risen for six consecutive months, even as the two nations have wrangled with little apparent progress over how fast China should be subject to the free trade obligations that would come with membership in the World Trade Organization and its right to protect state-owned enterprises and certain sectors of the economy from international competition.
The increase in the last several months has been caused partly by seasonal imports of Chinese-made toys and Christmas ornaments, analysts said.
But it also reflects sweeping changes in the structure of Asian economies generally, with Japanese and South Korean companies, among others, seeking low-wage manufacturing sites in China.
"It looks fairly clear that a fair bit of production that used to take place in other Asian nations has now moved to China," Robert E. Rubin, the Treasury Secretary, said after meeting with Mr. Liu on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Retailers Left Out of Computer-Stock Boom

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The holiday season is when the consumer is king of the personal computer industry. So the recent fall in the stock prices of computer retailers like CompUSA, Circuit City Stores and Best Buy has some investors and analysts scratching their heads.
How is it, they wonder, that the retailers can be doing so badly when stocks of the companies making the products they are trying to sell -- like I.B.M. and Compaq Computer -- are doing so well? 
 "What that tells you is that the computers are selling somewhere else, or we are all going to be in for a rude awakening after the first of the year," said Louis Mazzucchelli, an analyst with Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company in New York.
October saw the worst comparisons in sales from stores open at least a year in the history of the PC industry, David Childe, an analyst with Salomon Brothers, said. On Tuesday, Wal-Mart Stores, the world's largest retailer, said it would stop selling computers at 629 stores, or 25 percent of the chain, because of their poor sales.
CompUSA shares plunged 9 percent on Tuesday after Montgomery Securities lowered its rating on the stock to a "hold" from a "buy." The stock rebounded yesterday, closing at $46.625, up $1.875. Still, Circuit City shares were down 62.5 cents, closing at $33.625, and Best Buy was unchanged at $13, only slightly more than its 52-week low.
Even as the retailers' stocks have slid, manufacturers are reaching all-time highs based in large part on predictions of booming sales of personal computers. I.B.M. has risen $15.75 a share, or about 12 percent in the last week. It closed yesterday at $152.625, down $1.50. Compaq shares slipped 12.5 cents yesterday to $80.375 after setting an all-time high on Tuesday. Shares in the Intel and Microsoft Corporations, which sell the main components of most PC's, have also been soaring.
"You've got money managers chasing performance," said Fred Hickey, the editor of the High Tech Strategist, a monthly newsletter based in Nashua, N.H. "That is how you get the difference between perception and reality."
To Mr. Hickey and other technology bears, retail sales are a leading indicator of overall personal computer demand. Last year, computer stocks also boomed on the eve of the Christmas season because investors were convinced that Windows 95, the new PC operating system from Microsoft, would produce record sales. When such sales did not materialize, retailers were left with large inventories that cast a pall over the industry for much of this year.
Now, just as the industry has gotten over that hurdle, Compaq, Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and other established manufacturers of home PC's are facing stiff new competition from Japanese computer makers that are determined to get a slice of the United States market.
Mr. Hickey said that Toshiba recently cut the price of its home computer featuring a 166-megahertz Pentium microprocessor to $1,699 after Compaq cut the price of its comparable offering to $1,799. Both machines were introduced in September at prices around $2,500. Mr. Hickey estimated that the total cost of producing such a machine was about $1,700, leaving little or no profit for the manufacturer.
But other analysts said that bears like Mr. Hickey were not accounting for some important changes in the computer industry.
Tom Courtney, the analyst at Montgomery Securities who helped send CompUSA's stock tumbling, still says that industry forecasts of 18 percent growth in PC sales over all this year are on target.
That is because measuring growth in stores open at least a year does not take into account the large number of new stores that electronics retailers have opened in the last year.
"While computer sales may be down at stores that were operating last year, overall retail computer sales were up," he said.
The greater threat to computer retailers is not declining demand, Mr. Courtney added, but a change in buying patterns. His recent study of the top seven retailers showed that a growing number of consumers are buying machines through mail-order companies rather than at retailers.
"The retail channel is slowing and the direct channel is growing," Mr. Courtney said.
That would appear to benefit direct computer vendors like the Dell Computer Corporation and Gateway 2000 Inc. But analysts said that Compaq, Hewlett-Packard and I.B.M. would gain because corporate sales will be stronger than usual this year, compensating for the weaker consumer sales.
Computer Intelligence Inc., a market research company in San Diego, estimated that corporate sales would soar in the fourth quarter compared with virtually no growth last year. The biggest driver behind such sales, the company said, is the adoption of Window NT, Microsoft's operating system for corporate networks.
"We saw a strong upgrade cycle starting in the third quarter this year that we believe will extend to next year's second quarter," said Matthew Sargent, a Computer Intelligence analyst.
But Brian Kritzler, a technology analyst at Van Kasper & Company in San Francisco, said that the sales of Windows NT anticipated by Microsoft could not generate enough computer sales to justify the current rally in computer hardware stocks.
Then again, few analysts are able to justify the rally. Daniel Mandresh, the analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company who sparked I.B.M.'s rise on Friday by raising his 12-month price target to $195 a share from $150, is at a loss to explain the market reaction.
"I caught the crest of the wave," he said yesterday. "So help me, to my knowledge nothing has changed other than the fact that more people are willing to say glowing things about the same company that existed last Thursday."

HEADLINE: Christopher, in Beijing, Sees Better Relations With China

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Seeking a fresh start in tattered relations with an emerging superpower, Secretary of State Warren Christopher met today with China's leaders and said he was hopeful of a better, more stable relationship in the future.
After meetings with Foreign Minister Qian Qichen, Prime Minister Li Peng and President Jiang Zemin, Mr. Christopher made no claims to more than slight progress on specific areas like trade, human rights and American arms sales to Taiwan. In those and other areas, both countries acknowledged huge differences that cannot be talked away. 
 But after a first term of the Clinton Administration in which relations with China were buffeted by disputes over Taiwan, protection of copyrights, suspected Chinese sales of nuclear equipment to Pakistan and trade and human rights issues, the atmosphere had improved, American officials said.
"The Chinese have made a strategic decision to build a constructive relationship with the United States, and they'll make some reasonable efforts to insure that it happens," a senior American official said. "Without claiming any major breakthrough, we've made systematic progress since last spring, enough to at least stabilize the relationship."
The Americans, for their part, have made known their desire not to let continuing concerns over China's treatment of political dissidents and religious opponents jeopardize cooperation in other spheres.
Mr. Christopher's visit was meant, in part, to prepare the ground for President Clinton's meeting this weekend with China's President at an economic conference in the Philippines. The two leaders are expected to agree to exchange visits, a gesture China has long sought.
In Australia today, en route to the conference, President Clinton pledged to work for a stronger United States relationship with China.
"The United States has no interest in containing China," Mr. Clinton said. "That is a negative strategy. What the United States wants is to sustain an engagement with China" to try to "increase the chances that there will be more liberty and more prosperity."
At the same time, Mr. Clinton said in a speech to the Australian Parliament, "the United States and China will continue to have our differences, especially in the area of human rights, and we will continue to discuss them candidly."
Today's visit to Beijing was only Mr. Christopher's second in the last four years. In March 1994, he had a disastrous visit to Beijing, talking tough on human rights and linking trade relations to an improvement in them, only to have Mr. Clinton reverse that policy. In 1995, relations chilled after Washington granted a visa to Taiwan's leader for a private visit to the United States.
In recent months the Clinton Administration has adopted a new strategy toward China, in which positive ties will be promoted where possible and no single issue, such as human rights or trade disputes, should dominate the relationship.
The Chinese praised Mr. Christopher for "important improvement" in bilateral ties, and a Chinese spokesman said both sides "indicated a willingness to keep up the momentum for improvement."
Differences between the two countries were serious and would persist, American officials said, but the Chinese were more willing today to discuss them, while concentrating on issues of shared concern like North Korea, the spread of nuclear technology and the global ban on nuclear tests that both countries support.
Given China's improved record on nuclear nonproliferation, since a pledge in May not to ship nuclear-related materials to unmonitored plants, Mr. Christopher said there was room for further, limited cooperation on peaceful nuclear energy.
The Chinese, in turn, agreed today to adopt regulations to prevent questionable exports.
But both sides also highlighted areas of concern. Mr. Qian, in a news conference before meeting Mr. Christopher, said that Taiwan was China's prime concern and how it was handled would help define future bilateral relations. He urged the United States to slow and eventually to halt arms sales to Taiwan, as agreed in a 1982 joint communique negotiated by President Reagan.
"We can only be reassured when this promise is turned into a reality," Mr. Qian said. "China is most concerned about massive sales of U.S. weapons to Taiwan," which is receiving 150 F-16 jet fighters and Patriot antimissile systems.
American officials said they reassure China at every opportunity about Washington's commitment to the 1982 communique and Taiwan's status as a part of China to be eventually reunited with the mainland. But the Americans said they have no intention of stopping arms sales to Taiwan in the meantime.
At the same time, American officials admit privately that their decision last year to bow to Congressional pressure and grant the Taiwanese President, Lee Teng-hui, a visa to enter America for a college reunion was a mistake. The visit led to shows of military force by China and, in response, the United States Navy.
Mr. Christopher and his aides said that he spent as much time discussing Chinese human rights issues as he did on any other topic with Chinese leaders and repeated the American view that the relationship could not reach "its full flowering" so long as China continues to mistreat its own citizens.
Mr. Li, the Prime Minister, was willing to debate human rights but only in general terms, American officials said, and refused to discuss individual cases, which the Chinese regard as matters of domestic law.
For China, one important test of relations is whether the United States will support its entry into the World Trade Organization under terms that will allow a more gradual end to Chinese protectionism than the organization has demanded. The Americans say they are willing to negotiate some concessions, provided there is progress in reducing some trade barriers and in other areas like intellectual piracy.
Chinese wariness about Mr. Christopher and his visit was evident in the heavy security presence in Beijing and the lack of an official banquet for him, although American officials say he was offered one.

HEADLINE: As Debate Over Megastores Rages, One Opens in Queens

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
As the dispute over the future of superstores in New York City continued to boil at City Hall, one of the biggest of the so-called warehouse stores, Costco, opened its doors in Queens yesterday, selling food and household goods in bulk at low prices. And judging by the crowds, New Yorkers appeared eager to welcome the store, a staple of suburban shopping.
Price Costco, a leader in the $45-billion-a-year membership warehouse club industry, owns and operates more than 270 superstores in the United States and abroad under the names Price Club and Costco, and it plans to open another outlet today in Brooklyn. Business owners and individuals must pay an annual fee of $30 or $35, respectively, for the right to use the stores. 
 The Giuliani administration has maintained that the lack of such retailers in the five boroughs has forced many city shoppers to the suburbs, and it has proposed zoning changes to make it easy for the megastores to locate in manufacturing areas.
Yesterday, with most of the 500 parking spaces at the Queens Costco full before noon, it was clear that many shoppers appreciated having such a store closer to home.
David Wolff, 44, a writer who lives on Roosevelt Island, described the supermarket he uses there as "horrible, beyond awful." Having been to Price Clubs in Hackensack, N.J., and Old Westbury, L.I., he had waited for years, he said, for a membership warehouse store to enter the New York City market.
"You can go a little crazy the first time," Mr. Wolff said, leaning over a jumbo shopping cart containing a 2-pound bag of Starbucks coffee beans ($10.99), a 5-pound package of boneless chicken breasts ($13.10) and a 33-ounce bottle of Pert shampoo ($5.70).
The new store, at 32-50 Vernon Boulevard near Broadway in Astoria, consists of two beige warehouse-style buildings covering 130,000 square feet. It sprawls over five acres previously occupied by a steel manufacturer.
The property is in a residential zone. But because the last occupant was there before the passage of the 1961 zoning laws still in effect, Costco was able to put its store at the site without a special review.
George Delis, the district manager for Community Board 1, said Costco encountered little opposition, although there were some concerns about traffic.
"In my opinion, it has taken an area that could use an uplift," Mr. Delis said. "The local community people love it because the Price Club is very popular, and now they have to go to Nassau County."
Many of the shoppers on hand yesterday were already members of Price Club, with some saying they regularly visited the outlet in Old Westbury. One membership is good for all Price Clubs and Costcos.
The store carries a staggering variety of merchandise: 2.5-gallon jugs of Mazola corn oil, best-selling books, 15-roll packages of Bounty paper towels, evergreen wreaths, television sets, 200-ounce containers of Tide detergent, dog food, luggage, diamond engagement rings, cinnamon buns and just about anything else imaginable.
"It gives an opportunity for people at a certain income level to get more value," said Faith Hope Consolo, senior managing director at Garrick-Aug Associates, a nationwide retail leasing company based in Manhattan.
"In today's economy, where we see this happening in apparel and toys, it's important that it be available across the market, and that includes food. Otherwise, those people go out of state to shop."
Last December, a Costco store opened on Richmond Avenue in Staten Island, the first in New York City. The Brooklyn store scheduled to open today is at Third Avenue and 39th Street in Sunset Park. And a fourth store is to open on Eighth Avenue and 34th Street in Manhattan in 1998, said Robert Kyle, a regional marketing manager for Price Costco.
But Price Costco, which is based in Issaquah, Wash., and formed in 1993 with the merger of Price Club and Costco Wholesale, takes its membership concept seriously. Eligible members include those employed in such fields as government, utilities, media, banking, health care and education.
Professional and licensed individuals, including real estate agents, lawyers and architects, are also eligible.
David Poneman, a retailing analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, an investment research firm in Manhattan, said the intent of the restrictions was not to exclude "employed responsible adults" but to keep out minors. "They don't want it browsed by shoplifting teen-agers," he said.
