HEADLINE: Chicago, Joined by an Array of Dignitaries, Bids Farewell to Cardinal Bernardin

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 20

 BODY:
It was a very long goodbye, and it had to be. For three days, all Chicago, Catholic and non-Catholic alike, seemed to be bidding farewell to Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, whispering one last prayer and blinking away a final tear for a soft-spoken religious leader whose life and death touched so many here.
Starting Monday, more than 100,000 people wound day and night past the Cardinal's open coffin in Holy Name Cathedral, a procession interrupted by a series of memorial services there conducted not only by Roman Catholic clerics but also by leaders of other denominations and even other religions. 
 And it was not just Chicago that grieved for its Archbishop, who died of cancer last Thursday at the age of 68. Today, in final ceremonies that rivaled any major state funeral, a cathedral full of civic and religious dignitaries, including Vice President Al Gore and personal representatives of Pope John Paul II, commended to God a churchman whose personality and leadership transcended class, race and even creed.
Then the church bore Cardinal Bernardin's coffin to Mount Carmel Cemetery in the nearby community of Hillside, a journey that, like the Cardinal, spanned the city in all its parts.
One hundred cars strong, the funeral procession passed down Michigan Avenue's Magnificent Mile through the newly gentrified near West Side close by the convention center where the Democrats met in August. It continued through poverty-shattered neighborhoods, where the people lining the streets were as likely to be Baptist as Catholic and where black and Hispanic children from Catholic schools sang and tossed flowers at the passing hearse. It went on through old affluent suburbs and newer working-class ones to the cemetery, where Cardinal Bernardin was laid to rest alongside other bishops in a special mausoleum. As the coffin was carried into the mausoleum, 15,000 people watched in cold and snow flurries.
Earlier, from the pulpit of Holy Name Cathedral, Msgr. Kenneth Velo, the fellow worker of many years whom Cardinal Bernardin had asked to give the funeral sermon, addressed the 1,300 assembled mourners -- relatives and friends of the Archbishop, and many dignitaries. They included not only the Vice President and his wife, Tipper, but also Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services; Henry G. Cisneros, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development; Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff; Jim Edgar, the Governor of Illinois, and Richard M. Daley, the Mayor of Chicago.
But Monsignor Velo said he was speaking as well to people listening on their car radios or watching television in hospitals and nursing homes.
"You are all dignitaries," Monsignor Velo said, "for God has touched you through the life of Cardinal Bernardin."
"He brought people together," the monsignor added. "He was a unifier."
Although the ceremonies today had a magnificence and a solemnity suited to Cardinal Bernardin's high rank in the church, the funeral liturgy was ultimately the same one, the Mass of Christian Burial, as for the humblest believer.
And it carried the same message, repeated over and over: "that God has created each person for eternal life and that Jesus in death and Resurrection has broken the chains of sin and death," as Roger Cardinal Mahony of Los Angeles, whom Cardinal Bernardin had asked to be the chief celebrant of the Mass, said at its outset.
Still, there were aspects of these three days of services that reflected much that was particular about Cardinal Bernardin's role in the church here.
The Cardinal had stitched extraordinarily close ties among different religious groups in Chicago, and especially between Catholics and Jews. That was an achievement reflected in the ecumenical prayer service over his body in the cathedral on Tuesday, and in the Jewish-led memorial there later.
"He was a jewel from God's treasure chest," Rabbi Byron Sherwin, vice president of the Spertus Institute of Jewish Studies, said at the latter event, which, although not strictly a religious service, was presided over by three rabbis and four Jewish community leaders, all of whom traveled to Israel with Cardinal Bernardin last year.
Later, on Tuesday night, the steady stream of people paying their respects to the Cardinal was halted yet again, as the cathedral was filled with the archdiocese's priests.
The priests sang, prayed and listened to a two-page letter to them that will be included in "The Gift of Life," a final book by Cardinal Bernardin to be published early next year.
"The things people remember most are small acts of concern and thoughtfulness," the Cardinal wrote. "Years later, that is what they tell you about their priests and other clergy." By "simple goodness," he said, the clergy can be a symbol of the transcendant that people of all faiths, or of none, have a yearning to touch.
That certainly seemed to be true in the Cardinal's own case, especially after he was found to be suffering from cancer and underwent treatment in 1995 -- and then took up helping other cancer patients as a special ministry.
"He seldom said no," Monsignor Velo said in the sermon today. "He would write thank-you letters for thank-you letters."
Again and again, Chicagoans this week have talked of an encouraging note or word they got from the Cardinal, or simply of the example he set in meeting his own suffering.
At 2 A.M. on Tuesday morning, Cindy Jaso, an unemployed data clerk, stood in the line outside the cathedral to pay her respects. "My mom is on dialysis, and my dad was in a car accident," she said. Cardinal Bernardin "was so courageous at the end -- he didn't take time for his own illness. I wish I was handling it as well."
Another in the line, which stretched for two blocks in 35-degree weather, was Paul Janoviak, a 37-year-old police officer in the suburban town of Oak Lawn. "He's a sincere example of decency, which I don't see in my business too often," Officer Janoviak said.
In his funeral sermon, Monsignor Velo did not skip painful episodes: bitter protests that ensued after Cardinal Bernardin had decided that archdiocesan finances required closing some parishes, and accusations of sexual abuse made against the Cardinal in 1994, later retracted by the accuser. But Monsignor Velo noted that such episodes had repeatedly ended in the Cardinal's forgiveness and in reconciliation.
On Tuesday night, beginning a litany at the priests' service, a reader prayed, "For his powerful presence of healing and forgiveness so gently offered to the lost, the alienated and those fragmented by division or blinded by anger, we praise and thank you, O God."
And in the darkened cathedral, lighted only by the candles in the priests' hands and the tall Easter candle burning by the Cardinal's coffin, the response came back: "Blessed be God forever."

HEADLINE: Americans Straddle the Average Mark in Math and Science

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
In the most comprehensive study of science and mathematics achievement by students around the world, students in the United States ranked slightly below average in mathematics and slightly above average in science, according to an international comparison of 41 countries released yesterday.
Singapore, South Korea, Japan, Hong Kong and the Czech Republic were among the top-ranking nations of those surveyed. Colombia and South Africa were among the lowest. The United States results did not differ significantly from some other Western nations like Canada, England and Germany. 
 The survey reflected neither the most extreme proclamations of persistent educational decline that have become part of the political landscape, nor the hopes of some educators that a decade of education "reform" would have produced more striking gains by students in the United States.
But the results are further proof that the United States has virtually no chance of meeting the national goal set out in 1990 to make its students first in the world in mathematics and science by the year 2000. And it reflects the degree to which any education progress in this country is being matched or exceeded by many other countries around the world.
"You can put the results together and say our results compared to the rest of the world are average, but in the United States of America in this education era, average is far too low," said Education Secretary Richard W. Riley. "What's encouraging is that this is the best data we've ever had on what works best and what it takes to improve math and science performance."
The findings were significant both for what they showed about the relative ranking of Americans and the kinds of practices and attitudes that have produced more impressive student achievement elsewhere.
And despite an education debate in this country that is focused on politically volatile issues like school choice, many education and scientific experts said the results indicated that where American education really needed to focus attention was on the basics: what is taught, how teachers are trained, what is demanded of students.
The countries that performed best tended to be ones like Singapore, where all students are tracked individually and expected to perform, or Japan, where videotapes of teachers done as part of the study showed that Japanese teachers were uniformly better trained and prepared than their peers in the United States. And almost all the best-performing countries had national standards that were clearly being carried out, unlike the situation in the United States.
"What stands out is that we have failed to really emphasize the importance of learning how to teach in this country: it's not the fault of the teachers, its the fault of the system," said Bruce Alberts, president of the National Academy of Sciences. "We're spending the same hours teaching these things as the Japanese, but they're outperforming us by a tremendous margin. We're working as hard, but we haven't stressed curriculum, we haven't stressed teaching, we haven't stressed learning the way some other countries have."
Indeed, a report a month ago -- part of the same international study -- said that both mathematics and science teaching in the United States lacked focus and coherence compared with other countries. Schools teach too many things in a fragmented way, producing inferior results, the report concluded.
The study, the Third International Mathematics and Science Study is part of a survey of 500,000 students, tested in more than 30 different languages, from 15,000 schools in 45 countries. The survey released yesterday examines the mathematics and science performance of seventh and eighth graders in the 41 countries whose results were methodologically comparable. Later reports will look at elementary and high school performance.
Critics of the two previous studies by the International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement have objected to the comparative nature of such tests. In many cases, they said, poorer students have dropped out of school or are not included in the sample.
But because this study deals almost exclusively with 13-year-olds, "in almost all the countries except the developing countries, just about all the students are still in school at that age," said Dr. Albert E. Beaton, of Boston College, director of the study.
The scores of United States students showed some improvement from earlier studies, which ranked the United States as below average in both subject areas. But because those studies were smaller and less rigorous than the new one, officials said, it was hard to make direct comparisons with them.
On the new test, eighth-grade students showed an average of 500 in mathematics, which was below the international average of 513. Singapore had the top score of 643. The United States ranked 28 out of 41 countries. In science, American eighth-grade students scored 534 compared with an international average of 516. Again Singapore had the top score, 607. The United States ranked 17 out of 41.
Over all, the scores were viewed as not surprising, but a modest disappointment after almost a decade of calls for education reform and signs that Scholastic Assessment Test scores were showing some improvement.
"My sense is that the scores are somewhat disappointing, not catastrophic, but disappointing," said William H. Schmidt, a professor of applied statistics at Michigan State University who was the national research coordinator for the study in the United States.
Some of the findings were striking in the degree to which study habits and patterns of life around the world have become more alike over time.
In places as diverse as the United States, Singapore, the Czech Republic, Hong Kong and England, eighth-grade students reported spending about the same amount of time -- 2.6 to 2.7 hours a day -- watching television. Students in the United States, however, reported spending more time playing sports -- just over two hours a day -- than students in any other country.
But in other areas, cultural differences played a clear role in student achievement. The remarkable performance of Singapore was a source of considerable surprise. Larry Suter, deputy director of the division of research, evaluation and communication at the National Science Foundation, said it reflected, in part, cultural differences that would be difficult to duplicate here. Singapore, a small country with a rigidly centralized educational system, monitors the achievement of every student. If a student falls behind, his teacher and parents are notified and steps are taken to improve his performance.
On the other hand, Mr. Suter said many of the top-performing countries had succeeded in making education a widely understood national priority in the way the United States could do but has not. "Many of the countries that performed best, like Japan, are places where education is a top priority from the time a kid enters school," Mr. Suter said.
Other differences are more narrowly focused on educational practices. All the best-performing nations have clear national or federal education standards and expectations. Nothing comparable exists in the United States and the standards that have been drawn up by professional groups have in some cases been adopted in other countries more than they have been here.
One of the most striking findings in the report has to do with teaching practices.
Mathematics teachers were videotaped in Germany, Japan and the United States, and their lessons transcribed so that they could be reviewed without a cultural bias toward one country or another. Of the American teachers, 87 percent were given low marks for lesson content, 13 percent received medium grades and none were given high grades. Of the Japanese teachers, 13 percent got low grades, 57 percent medium grades and 30 percent high grades.
"In Japan teachers don't teach until they've had extensive mentoring and really professional education on how to teach," Mr. Alberts said. "We tend to throw teachers out on their own as soon as they get out of college. I don't think we have to spend a lot more money on education. But we have to be much more focused and coherent about what we're doing."
In teacher training, curriculum, standards and others areas, the report is an indication that while the United States may be improving its education, others, particularly in the Far East are improving faster.
"Southeast Asian and eastern European countries are the powerhouses in these subjects," the Council of Chief State School Officers said in a statement today. "They have a very high national motivational level to improve achievement in mathematics and science as a part of their overall national economic strategies."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Trade Deficit Rises As China Talks Near
As President Clinton prepared to press top Chinese officials to open their markets more fully to American goods, the Government provided further evidence that China was supplanting Japan as the primary source of trade tension for the United States.
The deficit with China rose in September to another record. It was part of one of the widest overall monthly trade gaps recorded by the United States in years, $11.3 billion, and was up $1 billion from that of a month earlier. Economists had predicted a decline of $1 billion or more. [Page A1.]
 
Dow Hits Another Record
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped to its 10th record this month, in a rally driven by gains in the shares of General Motors, Caterpillar and Boeing. The Dow rose 32.42 points, to 6,430.02, but broader indexes had smaller gains, with the Nasdaq rising 2.32 points, to 1,264.94. [D12.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities rose, pushing the yield on the 30-year bond down to 6.41 percent, after the Treasury successfully auctioned $12.5 billion in new five-year notes. [D22.]
 
Employees Sue Smith Barney
At Smith Barney, which quietly paid $1.35 million to settle claims by a managing partner that she was humiliated and discriminated against because she was black and a woman, 25 more current or former employees have joined discrimination suits in New York and California. Smith Barney denies it tolerated sexual harassment or discrimination. [D4.]
 
Intervention Sought on Texaco Suit
In a Federal court motion, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission asked to be allowed to intervene in a discrimination suit settled by Texaco last week, raising the possibility that the record settlement might have to be renegotiated. [D4.]
 
Another Quarter Of Profits at Kmart
Kmart reported its second consecutive profitable quarter, after two years of disappointing results, but the company's stock fell after a big gain the day before. Sales remained sluggish, but the chief executive, Floyd Hall, trimmed operating costs enough to produce earnings of $9 million. The average estimate of 20 analysts polled by First Call was for a break-even quarter. [D2.]
 
A Tax Tightrope on the Net
The Treasury Department, struggling to devise a tax policy that keeps up with the rapid growth of electronic commerce, will publish a draft report that outlines the Administration's opposition to new Federal taxes on the Internet but underscores its determination that the global computer network not become a haven for tax evaders. [D7.]
 
Biotechnology Company to Be Sold
Chiroscience Group, a chemical and drug company based in Britain, has agreed to acquire Darwin Molecular, a biotechnology company whose prominent backers include the Microsoft founders William H. Gates and Paul Allen, for about $120 million. [D9.]
 
It's Not Air Force One
Bob Dole's run for the White House may have failed, but that does not mean he is no longer involved in a campaign. Mr. Dole is appearing in a humorous advertisement for Air France, believed to be the first instance in which a Presidential candidate of a major political party has agreed to allow his image to be used for commercial purposes. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D10.]
 
Norfolk Southern Request Denied
A Federal appeals panel kept alive Norfolk Southern's attempt to thwart the merger of CSX and Conrail, but it declined to block the first step of the deal. The panel denied Norfolk Southern's request for an emergency injunction to block CSX's tender offer for 19.9 percent of Conrail's shares. [D24.]
 
Channel Tunnel Remains Closed
The rail tunnel under the English Channel, shut down since a fire ripped through a freight train en route to Britain on Monday night, may remain closed until the end of this week. Late last night, the safety commission was reported as saying that freight trains could resume using the tunnel. [A5.]

HEADLINE: Now, Ads Bound For Coffee Tables

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MASON

 BODY:
"ZONA HOME." "The Table: Diane von Furstenburg." "A Tiffany Christmas." "The Ikea Book of Home Design."
In the flagrant age of the advertorial, could the book-as-brochure -- call it the advertome -- be far behind? 
 On the cusp of Christmas 1996, the phenomenon of cross-marketing is all-pervasive: magazines spinning off CD-ROM's and television shows; basketball players trading on their athletic sweat by hawking haut perfumes; fashion designers conjuring up scented candles.
But few promotional devices today lend the heft of respectability like a coffeetable book.
And so, among the more than 800 coffeetable books about design at Barnes & Noble's Lincoln Center store, self-congratulatory volumes abound. "If you want to do a book on design, your only option is to link up with a celebrity or a well-known store to interest a publisher," said Helen Pratt, a New York book agent. "It's not about information; it's about whose information it is."
Today's linkups are so explicitly promotional that some store owners are complaining that even the coffeetable book has been dumbed down. "Zona Home" (Harper Style, $50) is a paean by Louis Sagar to his home-furnishings empire, which brought Southwestern style to SoHo and beyond. "Shabby Chic" (Harper Style, $30) promotes the rumpled, deshabille style (swiped from English grandmothers) as its own. The author, Rachel Ashwell, founded the four Shabby Chic stores in America that sell the look -- and the book.
"Retailers have come to learn that publishing a book expands their market," said Delsie Brainer, a book reviewer at Publishers Weekly. "And writing a book can make a business seem more legitimate. It's all about promoting an image."
Liz Hennessey, the buyer for life-style and interior-design books at Borders, the national chain based in Ann Arbor, Mich., has an explanation for this trend. "We're obsessed with brand names in America," she said. "When you walk into a supermarket you buy the brand you know."
Some books are subtle in their manipulation: London's reigning minimalist architect, John Pawson, recently came out with "Minimum" (Phaidon/Chronicle, $95), whose subtitle could be "Acropolis, Stonehenge and me." In it, Mr. Pawson maximizes his own handsome projects, which he immodestly sprinkles amid images of awesome contributions to architectural history.
In this regard, "Minimal" is not unlike the deceptively commercial "Extraordinary Furniture" (Harry N. Abrams, $60) by David Linley. The book, bolstered by a tour that began in New York last week and was doted on by a bevy of Trumps and Forbeses, offers a glossy romp with Princess Margaret's son (hailed irreverently in Britain as the most famous carpenter since Jesus) through the history of furniture. Among 192 pages of Viscount Linley's favorite things -- Louis XV's bureau at Versailles; Empress Josephine's bed at Malmaison -- are 16 pages of furnishings made and designed by his own firm. The grandeur by association is hard to miss.
"Yes, of course, to include work we've done in the book is quite crassly promotional," said Ruth Kennedy, a spokeswoman for Viscount Linley. "But we feel we can justify it because the work is quite extraordinary, and it is all done by hand." She added, "Not a lot of people want to print a book about furniture."
Derek Ostergard, of the Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, agrees with the premise. "The sad thing," he said, "is there are so many wonderful scholars laboring away in silence who are always being told by publishers that their books are too esoteric." The new breed of book-brochures, he lamented, "are not unethical; they're just bad taste. I'm tired of buying them only to get them home and find they have no depth."
Cynthia Conigliaro, a co-owner of Archivia, the elegant Madison Avenue decorative-arts bookstore, said that to increase sales, big chain stores are forcing publishers to produce design books that she calls "boring, safe and unintelligent."
In response to the charge, Ms. Hennessey at Borders said: "We don't put pressure; we make suggestions. We tell them to publish the books we think will sell."
Not long ago, Ms. Hennessey pointed out to Lauren Shakeley, editorial director at Clarkson Potter -- the publisher of that life-style marketer nonpareil, Martha Stewart -- that no book on African-American design was available and that there was also a huge potential market for books about pillows, lamp shades and small apartments. To Ms. Hennessey's great satisfaction, those books appeared this season.
"The MTV generation doesn't want a house that looks like an English stately home," Ms. Hennessey said. "Maybe the books are lighter and superficial, but that's what a lot of people want." She added that how-to books have evolved into books that are part catalogue, part how-to, which have a wider appeal.
"I understand the economics involved," Ms. Conigliaro said, "but I'm really not interested in selling shallow, self-promotional books that rely upon the fame of the author."
So how does she explain her window display, dominated by Viscount Linley's book? "That's rather tender ground for me," she replied. "He's a very good customer."
The Linley book kept busy a staff that many magazines would envy: a contributing editor, a text editor, an executive editor and a project editor, to say nothing of an executive art editor, two designers and two picture researchers. (When asked to comment on reports that Viscount Linley had neglected to write the book that bears his name, Ms. Kennedy, the Linley spokeswoman, appeared to choose her words cautiously. "He worked very hard," she said. "With a text editor.")
With so many ghostwriters at large, and publishers eager to capitalize on the built-in appeal of brand names, it is easier than ever for well-known individuals and their commercial enterprises to bask in the glory of tomes that bear their names -- without the inconvenience of having to sit down and write them. Having given us "The Bed" and "The Bath," Diane von Furstenberg now offers a privileged peek at "The Table" (Random House, $40), including that of Dolly Parton (who shares her recipe for meat loaf) and Jane Wenner, a publisher of Rolling Stone (who serves up pork tenderloin).
Some close to the book say Ms. von Furstenberg's contribution occupied little of her time. "Yes, of course, I wrote it," Olivier Gelbsmann said of the introduction to the book, one of three he has planned and executed for Ms. von Furstenberg.
I THINK so many of the well-known designers who put their names on books nowadays think of them very much in the same category as having some curtains made," said Stephen Calloway, a former curator at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London and an authority on the decorative arts. "They no more expect to sit down at a typewriter to produce gleaming prose than they would dream of laboring over a hot sewing machine. Why bother if you can pay someone else to do it?"
But Mr. Calloway points out that ghosted design books are hardly new. He lists such titles as "The House in Good Taste" by Elsie de Wolfe (written, he said, by Ruby Ross-Wood) and "The Glass of Fashion" by Cecil Beaton (written by Waldemar Hansen, according to the Beaton biography by Hugo Vickers).
The dream of all retailers desirous of a book to vaunt their fame is to echo the success of Angus Wilkie, former owner of a SoHo antiques store and author of "Biedermeier" (Abbeville, $75). His authoritative book has ridden the Biedermeier wave of resurgence to a fourth printing, though he ultimately turned his back on his good fortune and sold his store. "I became restless," said Mr. Wilkie, now a Christie's consultant and a columnist for Elle Decor. "But doing a book certainly brought a lot of people into the shop."
Ms. Hennessey, in her predictive mode, said she expected more stores to venture into publishing their wares in book form. She expressed astonishment that Pottery Barn, with stores in 22 states, has yet to capitalize on the trend. "They have a strong brand name and a captive audience," she said. "I can't understand why they haven't done a book. Seems like a no-brainer to me."

An article in The Home Section on Nov. 21 about coffeetable books that are explicitly promotional misstated the name and the position of an observer of the retail book market who commented on the value to retailers of publishing a book about their business. She is Dulcy Brainard, not Delsie Brainer, and she is an editor at Publishers Weekly, not a book reviewer.

LENGTH: 241 words

HEADLINE: Southern Italy Doesn't Merit Bad Reputation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Unfortunately, your Nov. 15 front-page article "North-South Divide in Italy: A Problem for Europe, Too" bashes the Italian south.
The regions of the Mezzogiorno display a complex array of growth and poverty, political probity and policy successes as well as corruption. In Basilicata, Calabria's neighbor and the site of Carlo Levi's autobiographical essay "Christ Stopped at Eboli" and the research that first depicted the culture of poverty in Italy's southern reaches, the years since World War II have witnessed huge increases in levels of education, declines in the density of housing, well-planned highways and railroads, as well as other indicators of social transformation. Indeed, Fiat has just opened a plant in Melfi, formerly a pocket of poverty. 
 Southern Italians are no less willing to work to improve their economic conditions and no more corrupt than northerners. The political scandals that have transformed the Italian polity began in Milan, not Calabria. Why should southerners be prohibited from using funds that provide relief from floods or earthquakes to improve their region?
The tendency for northerners to treat the Mezzogiorno as a colony should not define reporting on Italy. As Italians struggle with calls for secession, it is important to refuse a bias that denigrates southerners.
 
ALAN S. ZUCKERMAN
Providence, R.I., Nov. 18, 1996
 
Prof. of Political Science, Brown U.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Gains for the Pound Continue In Britain's Healthy Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The British pound reached another four-year high against the dollar yesterday, driven by fresh evidence of economic health in Britain that is expected to lead to higher interest rates.
The dollar was mixed in other dealings. It retreated slightly against the yen on the diminished impact of a bank failure in Japan, which helped depress the yen on Wednesday. But the dollar rose against the French franc on widespread weakness in that currency, and ended marginally higher against the mark. 
 The pound, which has gained more than 3 percent against the dollar in November alone and has reached levels last seen in October 1992, continued its climb yesterday.
"It's been just a one-way street for weeks now," said Tom Hoge, vice president of corporate foreign exchange trading at the Bank of New York. "You've got an economy over there that's much better than anything else in Europe."
In late trading in New York, the pound traded at $1.6873, up from $1.6770 on Wednesday. The dollar fell to 111.29 Japanese yen from 111.55 yen, but rose to 1.4980 marks from 1.4968 marks.
Expectations that British interest rates will rise further have been an underlying element in the pound's rally since the Government increased its base lending rate last month. Rising rates make the pound more attractive.
Britain's economic indicators have all been pointing to falling unemployment and rising inflationary pressure, further increasing expectations of a rate increase before the end of the year. The latest indication came yesterday when the Government said consumer spending rose 1.1 percent in the third quarter, more than expected.
"Every bit of news that comes out reinforces the fact that you're going to see higher rates," said Joe Fetters, vice president of foreign exchange at the Corestates Bank in Philadelphia. "Everything coming out supports the fact that the economy over there is going very well."
In other dealings, the dollar strengthened against the French franc on broad weakness in the franc, particularly against the mark, after rumors of a looming reshuffle in the French Government.
The dollar also gained against the franc from the aftermath of reported comments earlier this week by a former French President, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, who urged a broad devaluation of the franc to make French exports more competitive abroad in advance of the plan for a single European currency in 1999.
The franc sold off despite statements from Prime Minister Alain Juppe of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany saying the franc's relationship with the mark reflected economic fundamentals.

HEADLINE: Homely Soup, Dressed Up and Ready to Go

BYLINE: By ERIC ASIMOV 

 BODY:
IN the soup business, passion rules.
Why else would sensible people wait patiently in line for over an hour even in Arctic temperatures to pay $10 for 16 ounces of soup to be eaten at cluttered desks, on the curb or on a park bench? 
 What else would drive a man to work up to 20 hours a day and on weekends, relentlessly inventing new soups and improving old ones, complaining bitterly all the way?
What else would spur on new entrepreneurs who are trying to turn soup kitchens into big businesses, with visions of soup restaurants not only throughout Manhattan but also all over the country and even the world?
All this passion for humble, homely soup?
In an unlikely makeover, soup has thrown off its terry cloth robe and has dressed up to take a public bow. Five Manhattan restaurants, up from one just two years ago, are specializing in soup, serving thousands of people at lunch each day. Two are about to open other outlets around Manhattan. Not to be left behind, delicatessens, coffee bars and health food stores, most of which had quietly dished out soup in the past, are calling attention to their wares, putting up signs and displaying soup kettles.
The appeal of soup crosses every ethnic and economic line. Soup ranges from the bottom rung of the social ladder, when doled out as the watery broth of prison movies, to the top, when sipped as delicate consomme flavored perhaps with wild mushrooms or foie gras and costing as much as $22 a portion at Daniel, the acclaimed restaurant on the Upper East Side.
"My love of soup is very big," said Daniel Boulud, the chef and owner of Daniel, where he offers at least five soups each day. "I grew up on soup every day."
From soup's current ascendant position, all roads lead back to Soup Kitchen International, the little storefront on West 55th Street that has been drawing huge lines of loyal customers for over 10 years. This is the domain of Al Yeganeh, who painfully bears the stigma of Soup Nazi, as he was caricatured in a "Seinfeld" episode last fall that parodied the precision of his way of selling soup.
Since then, Mr. Yeganeh's business has boomed more than ever, though he feels he has paid a significant price for his fame, both in the public's perception of him and in distraction from his work. "It's made my life miserable," he said.
Not so for Chris Ramani and his partners, who opened Soup Nutsy on East 46th Street last June, openly knocking off Mr. Yeganeh's operation.
"We planned it as soon as we saw the 'Seinfeld' episode," he said. Business has gone through the roof, Mr. Ramani said, and Soup Nutsy has new outlets in the works. Are they considering a Silicon-Valley-style public offering?
"Oh, sure we are," he said. "We basically want to be the Starbucks of soup."
Whatever its hopes, Soup Nutsy is not without rivals. Daily Soup opened in February on East 41st Street, but not, a co-owner, Peter Siegel, insists, because of the "Seinfeld" episode.
"I hear that every day, and I spend a lot of time saying we weren't influenced in any way," Mr. Siegel said. "I am a passionate soup freak, and have been all my life. I was always doing the bread-dip thing with soups, and I just woke up one day and said, 'Hey, let's do it.' "
Daily Soup is doing so well that a second outlet is to open soon on 17th Street between Broadway and Fifth Avenue, Mr. Siegel said, pausing to chat just before catching a plane to the Netherlands to discuss the development of Daily Soup Europe. "We are aggressively expanding," he said.
While Mr. Ramani and Mr. Siegel are more businessmen than soup makers, Jonathan Schnipper, the chef and a co-owner of Hale and Hearty Soups, takes a back burner to nobody in his passion for soups. "It's absolutely a labor of love," he said.
When it opened in June 1990 on Lexington Avenue, Hale and Hearty was a health-oriented food shop and soup was a minor part. "For a long time, the first thing people used to ask was what kind of soup we had today," Mr. Schnipper said. "It always seemed to be what people were really interested in."
So in May 1995, Hale and Hearty Soups was born. "That was before the 'Seinfeld' episode," Mr. Schnipper points out, though he concedes the episode did not hurt his business. "It just brought a ton of soup interest in Manhattan," he said. "People ask us, 'Oh, are you the Soup Nazi?' "
Hale and Hearty serves 400 to 500 customers a day, not including a large delivery business. It is just about to open a soup kiosk in the concourse of the World Trade Center and two other outlets in Manhattan.
While the influence of the "Seinfeld" episode is debatable, nobody disputes Mr. Yeganeh's influence. With minor variations, the soup restaurant formula is his: soup served to waiting customers in paper containers, accompanied by bread, fruit, plastic spoon, napkins and perhaps a moist towelette.
When he looks at the soup landscape, what does he see? "A bunch of idiots trying to cash in everywhere," said Mr. Yeganeh, who is not so much bilious as he is proud of his soups and of his single-minded dedication to soup making. "I only compete with my own self."
He said he sleeps little and works endlessly, trying to improve his recipes, and while he scorned his competitors, he was humble about his own products, particularly when comparing them with the platonic ideal of soup he carries in his head.
"I learn from my customers," he said, citing a 90-year-old woman who calls to criticize his matzoh ball soup. "Only call me if there's a problem," he added. "If you love my soup, I'll hang up on you, but if there's a problem I beg you to call me."
Why do people love his soup? Mr. Yeganeh spoke of its healthfulness, said it helps people lose weight, and groped for the mantra from the movie "Field of Dreams."
"If you make it, they will come," he said. "Nobody around was making it, only grandma in the home. I make it, and they come."
Here is a sampling of Manhattan restaurants that specialize in soup.

Soup Kitchen International
259A West 55th Street, (212) 757-7730; noon to 6 P.M. Mondays through Fridays; $6 to $17 for 12 to 32 ounces.
The reputation and the crowds were in place before the famous "Seinfeld" episode, but the public exposure complicated matters for Mr. Yeganeh, who says the curiosity-seekers have made it more difficult for him to serve his loyal customers. The nub of the problem is this: Mr. Yeganeh has boiled down his system for selling soup at his takeout operation to a few, simple rules, and he cannot understand why they are not easy to follow. In addition to the menu listing the 6 to 10 soups available each day, Mr. Yeganeh has posted this sign: "For most efficient and fastest service, the line must be kept moving. Please have money ready, pick up the soup of your choice, and move to the extreme left."
Mr. Yeganeh, who stands behind a line of kettles doling out portions, says simply moving left is not good enough, people must move to the extreme left for their own protection -- to block anyone who would try to steal their soup. "It's happened many times."
Implicit is the threat of what will happen if the rules are not obeyed. "No soup for you!" was the arbitrary punishment in the "Seinfeld" episode. I have never heard Mr. Yeganeh say that to anybody. I've never heard him say a cross word, or offer more than an annoyed glare at having his concentration disturbed. But the regulars are eager to trade war stories while standing in line, which can stretch around Eighth Avenue and up to 56th Street. The wait easily reaches an hour, and the anxiety is palpable.
"One time he just refused to give a woman soup, for nothing," one fellow offers. "How could he do that?"
"Why do we wait here?" another asks. "What does he put in the soup?"
The answer to that question, of course, is known only to Mr. Yeganeh. This much is clear: Mr. Yeganeh's soups continue to set the standard that the others hope to reach.
The reason is the depth and complexity of flavor and the high quality of the ingredients. Corn-and-seafood chowder provokes a swoon on first sip. The rich fish stock, amplified by the corn, has a toasty, almost smoky flavor and is full of chunks of fish, shrimp, scallops, even lobster claw. Veal goulash is a peppery, soupy stew generously flavored with caraway and chunks of veal, potato and celery. Cuban black bean, a vegetarian soup, is more subtle, tasting of cumin, parsley and pepper. The longer it sits, the better it seems to get as the flavors emerge and blend.
Each serving of soup comes with a hefty portion of excellent bread, fruit (grapes, bananas or apples) and belying his dour reputation, a delicious chocolate mint.
 
Soup Nutsy
148 East 46th Street, (212) 972-8800; 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Mondays through Fridays; $5 to $17 for 12 to 32 ounces.
Soup Nutsy began as a parody. Just like Soup Kitchen, it's a little takeout spot with a line stretching out the front. You are asked to make your decision in advance and have your money ready. Step up to the counter, and a stern counterman ladles out one of the 12 to 15 soups in crock pots. A sign reads: "Soup Nutsy: No Soup for You!" Its insignia is a scowling caricature of Mr. Yeganeh, and the operation seems just a step away from show business.
"If they want us to be mean, we can be mean," Mr. Ramani said. "We're not really mean."
To Mr. Ramani, the leading soup makers all put out equivalent products and the Soup Nutsy name is what sets his operation apart.
Not true. While the smirk is there, the soup-making skill is at least a notch below. Chicken with lemon is chock full of chicken and noodles cut into spoon-size pieces, but the broth is weak, overpowered by lemon. Fish chowder is better. The thick broth is full of cubes of fish, celery and flecks of tomato. But the flavors are dull and lacking intensity. Vegetarian mulligatawny, made with lentils, has a peppery, lemony tang, as if the flavors are fighting to come out, but only Manhattan clam chowder offers real satisfaction. The tomato-and-clam broth is complex with long-lasting flavor, full of clams and vegetables.
Soups come with nondescript rolls or bread wrapped in a wax-paper bag and fruit.
 
Daily Soup
21 East 41st Street, (212) 953-7687; 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Mondays through Fridays; $5 to $15 for 12 to 32 ounces.
Daily Soup offers the antithesis of the Soup Kitchen International experience: soup as fun rather than soup as anxiety. Not only can you actually wait inside (though the line at lunch often stretches out the door), you can even sit down to eat on one of the dozen wooden stools in front of a gleaming aluminum counter under black-and-white photos of people enjoying soup. The staff is attractive and happy, full of smiles and laughter, spurred on by the jump blues playing in the background. The whole room is modern and appealing, illuminated by light bulbs shaded by conical strainers.
A dozen or so soups are available daily, labeled nonfat, low-fat, vegetarian, spicy or dairy free. Many of the soups are creative, like Malaysian cabbage with peanut. Even the standards are unusual, like thick, smooth split pea soup with bits of spicy Italian sausage that leave the mouth glowing. Black bean soup is rich and bright, tasting of sherry, herbs, carrots and onions. The beautiful salmon-colored Indian shrimp soup is delicately flavored with coconut and sherry. Moroccan chicken, though, doesn't measure up. It's full of chicken and couscous but tastes mostly of cumin.
Following the formula, the soup comes with bread (thick wedges of crusty sourdough) and fruit (like apples, bananas and mandarins).
On the wall: T-shirts and baseball caps reading, "Thank God for Soup."
 
Urban Hero
245 West 38th Street, (212) 719-0665; 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Mondays through Fridays; $3 to $5.50 for 12 to 16 ounces.
Not much attention is paid to appearances at Urban Hero, a small soup and sandwich shop that is easy to miss in the tumult of the garment district. Most of the business is takeout, though a half-dozen tables, covered in red-and-white plastic, are in the dingy rear between some beverage cases and an unused steam table.
Urban Hero's specialty is creative low-fat sausages, but more and more, it has been turning to soups and offers five a day. Gregory Dal Piaz, the chef and owner, estimates that soup accounts for 30 percent of his daily sales, two to three times the rate of a year ago.
Mr. Dal Piaz's white bean soup with shrimp and crayfish is fabulous, rich yet delicate with a seafood flavor that is subtle rather than overpowering. Chicken minestrone is served daily, full of chicken chunks, tomato, carrot, red beans and corkscrews of pasta.
Chicken soup with ancho chilies and squash is a novel turn, the chilies adding a delicious little kick to the sumptuous broth, while tomato fiorentina is bright in color and in flavor, tasting almost like gazpacho with its freshness, flavored with basil, pepper and garlic.
Urban Hero offers fresh rolls with its soups, but none of the other Soup Kitchen trappings.
On the other hand, the sausages are terrific.
 
Hale and Hearty Soups
849 Lexington Avenue, near 64th Street, (212) 517-7600; 8:30 A.M. to 7 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays, until 6 P.M. Fridays; 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Saturdays. Closed Sundays. $2.25 to $5.95 for 8 to 16 ounces.
Hale and Hearty, narrow and bright, is generally quiet except at lunch, when it feels like Bloomingdale's at Christmas. People lining up to select soup in the rear are wedged between a wooden counter with stools and a second line of people waiting to claim their soups and pay. But cheeriness rules, and the crowd is as decorous as the polished wood table with a marble inset holding the soup pots.
Maybe it's because the 9 or 10 soups offered each day are so elegant, like the fresh, seasonal, roasted butternut squash, a light, smooth puree spiked with apple and flavored with cinnamon, nutmeg and salt, and the rich split pea, with bits of ham.
Soups are served with unbleached paper napkins. Hale and Hearty breaks from the Soup Kitchen mold by offering several tables and chairs and a few salads and sandwiches. Bread is not included, but the rolls and olive twists, available for a modest price, are excellent, as are the fresh juices and yogurt drinks.
 
Veselka
144 Second Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 228-9682; open 24 hours daily; $1.95 a cup, $2.75 a bowl.
Veselka, my favorite of the Eastern European cafes that dot the East Village, is a full-service restaurant that has always offered at least eight soups a day. It has just reopened after a renovation, but you'd never know it just by looking. Yes, the dining room is enlarged, and a mural in progress is crawling along the rear wall, but it looks as rumpled as ever.
The waitresses, despite their reputation for surliness, still work quickly and efficiently; the specials are still announced on handwritten signs, and best of all, the recipes are intact. That means the most delicious borscht around.
This is Ukrainian borscht, with "true healing powers," the menu claims.
Don't debate it; just eat. The garnet beet broth is rich with just a touch of sweetness, full of tender bites of beef and lima beans. It's the kind of soup that makes me pick up the bowl to drain every drop.
"We reopened about four weeks ago and we've been selling more soups than ever," said Thomas Birchard, the owner.
Mr. Birchard said the borscht was his best-selling soup. With good reason: the others are pallid by comparison.
"This whole soup thing kind of passed me by until a friend was saying soup is a really big thing and you should trumpet your soups," he said. "I never really thought about it before."

HEADLINE: Diplomacy vs. Semantics on China Visit

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher came to booming Shanghai today to sound a hopeful theme of "cooperation" between the United States and China in the next century, based on common interests of trade and security.
The audience at Fudan University, however, was expecting a speech with a different title: "Building a Partnership for the 21st Century." Those words, based on an earlier draft of the speech, were painted on a big blue sign above the podium to advertise Mr. Christopher's speech, and people had seen it. 
 But Mr. Christopher's address was revised by senior staff members who removed the word "partnership" and replaced it with "cooperation." Some officials objected to what one called the "hackneyed" use of "partnership."
Another official said: "We use words carefully. If we felt we could use 'partnership,' we would have used it. But would it pass the laugh test?" The last question referred to the credibility of talking about a partnership between the United States and a China that is still cited for human rights abuses.
In China, too, words are used very carefully. Ni Shixiong, a professor and deputy director of the Center for American Studies, which was Mr. Christopher's official host, said on Wednesday: "Christopher is using the word 'partnership' in the title of his talk. This is the first time we've heard this word. It's much better than 'cooperation.' It means we have a real chance to improve relations now, and I'm very optimistic."
Overnight, word of the title change was passed to Shanghai, and a new blue sign, reading "U.S. and China: Cooperation in the 21st Century," was hung over the podium two hours before Mr. Christopher's arrival.
When asked about the change, senior American officials were embarrassed and concerned that what they called a normal process of policy-making -- revision and editing -- would be seen as a policy change, which they said it was not.
Some of their caution over the use of the word "partnership" seemed puzzling, however, given that President Clinton, in a news conference in Canberra, Australia on Wednesday, had used the word quite happily in regard to China.
In a news conference, Mr. Clinton said the United States and China could work together, as they did on the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty and on restraining North Korea's nuclear ambitions, while cooperating on global issues like terrorism, nuclear expansion and the environment. "But I see this in the context of building a partnership with China, not isolating it," Mr. Clinton said.
Asked about the difference between "cooperation" and "partnership," the American Ambassador to China, James Sasser, said: "I don't think we're in a position yet to say we're partners. But there's increasing understanding and cooperation between the two coutries."
President Reagan came to this same place in 1984 and spoke to students then in basic terms of shared humanity and aspirations. "But we know a lot more about one another than we did then," a senior American official said. "There's been a lot more history between us."
Mr. Christopher spoke in fairly specific terms, saying that at times in the past, "distance and differences have blinded us to our common hopes and interests, creating distorted images of each other that drive us apart."
There is now an "opportunity to build a new era of cooperation for a new century," Mr. Christopher said. "We must seize it."
Mr. Christopher went on to say that cooperation must not mean silence on important areas of divergence, and cited disagreements on human rights issues as an example.
"History shows that nations with accountable Governments and open societies make for better neighbors," Mr. Christopher said. "While we recognize that each nation must find its own path, consistent with its own history, we believe that these ideals reflect the values not just of the United States, but of countries and cultures all over the world."
In response to a student's question about the human rights issue, Mr. Christopher responded: "I have been working on human rights problems much of my life. There's no magic wand on this issue. But it is important to remember the dignity of the individual, and the need to treat the individual with dignity, concern and compassion."
Some of the students here were flattered by Mr. Christopher's coming, but not convinced by his speech. Li Meng, 20, a computer scientist, said, "I think both sides should learn how to refrain from imposing their values on the other."
Lin Hao, 21, who is studying international business, said: "Chinese people don't like being pressured. We have our problems. We know that better than anyone. We have to improve our human rights domestically. But we don't need the United States to tell us that. Why is the U.S. always raising a big stick at us? Is this constructive?
"Of course we have problems with human rights," Ms. Lin said. "But look how much better things have gotten. It's much better than during the Cultural Revolution."
Sheng Qiang, 21, a social science major, added, "Christopher's trip shows the U.S. cares about China."
Professor Ni said: "Students now are more aware of the basic differences between the United States and China. We always emphasize collective over individual rights. We always stress economic rights before civil rights. I don't think students have gone from pro-U.S. to anti-U.S. But there is a change. They see things more clearly."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Dares Bratton to Run Against Him Next Year

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday enthusiastically dared former Police Commissioner William J. Bratton to run against him in the mayoral race next year, suggesting that Mr. Bratton would quickly be exposed as a one-note candidate.
A day after Mr. Bratton accused Mr. Giuliani of race baiting and pointed to his own managerial credentials for the post, Mr. Giuliani said he would look forward to raising a variety of issues unrelated to crime -- including education, economic development and welfare -- if Mr. Bratton entered the race. 
 "I'd like to see Bill Bratton run," he said, smiling broadly at a news conference yesterday. "I would like to see him running as a candidate, and getting exposed to all the same issues, the broad range of issues that you have to face when you're mayor of New York City."
Most Democrats and close advisers to the Mayor do not believe that Mr. Bratton, now a security consultant, intends to run. Democratic officials say he has sounded out power brokers about his prospects as a candidate and has been rebuffed, because of his strong Boston-accented background and his limited experience without a badge.
But as the Mayor's laughing encouragement of his candidacy underscores, there is one possible benefit to the Mayor from Mr. Bratton's presence. Mr. Bratton is the one man who is even more tied to the crime issue than is Mr. Giuliani.
Although Mr. Giuliani receives high marks in public opinion polls for having reduced the crime rate, his approval rating falls sharply on other important issues. Democratic opponents are lining up to try to exploit those vulnerabilities.
By next year, the Mayor will apparently need to substantially broaden his appeal beyond the reduction in crime, and standing in contrast to Mr. Bratton, he hopes to be seen as a Renaissance man.
"One of the things that it would do for me politically is, the whole big broad agenda that we have, we could start talking about all of that," Mr. Giuliani said. "There are many many other issues just as important as crime. There are many things involved in being the mayor of New York City. When you know someone's strengths and weaknesses better for having worked with him, you sort of look forward to running against him."
Mr. Bratton changed his affiliation from independent to Democrat this year, and the Mayor suggested that if Mr. Bratton is allowed to run in the Democratic primary, he should be allowed in the primary, as well.
Though Mr. Giuliani, who is all but certain to be on the Republican and Liberal lines, said his suggestion was not frivolous, he did not indicate that he would make a serious effort to add the Democratic nomination.
Mr. Bratton, who did not respond to requests for comment yesterday, has not declared his intentions. But his tone in an interview on the New York 1 cable channel on Wednesday was more combatively political than he had struck before. He accused Mr. Giuliani of race baiting in linking his probable opponents to former Mayor David N. Dinkins and said Mr. Dinkins deserved much of the credit for the reduction in crime by using the Safe Streets, Safe City program.
Mr. Giuliani denied the allegation of race baiting, saying Mr. Bratton "should be ashamed of himself" for repeating the allegation. Mr. Giuliani said it was perfectly legitimate to criticize former mayors and their performance without doing so for reasons of race.
"To inject that into this race is a very big mistake," Mr. Giuliani said. "And probably if he were a little more skilled and a little more seasoned at this, he wouldn't have done it."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Slip, Despite Weak Data

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended slightly lower yesterday after meandering for most of the session.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 5/32 , to 1011/32 , leaving its yield unchanged at 6.41 percent. 
 The yield is at its lowest level since March amid expectations that the economy is growing at a pace too slow to revive inflation.
"The bond market is fully priced for a slowdown in the economy," said Denny Niedringhaus, who oversees $300 million of bonds at the Southwest Bank in St. Louis. "We've gone about as far as we can go if we're expecting just a slowdown" rather than a recession.
Reports confirming the economy's slow pace failed to stir much buying activity yesterday.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said its inflation index fell to 14.6 in November from 21.9 last month, meaning that fewer manufacturers in the Philadelphia region reported paying higher prices. Still, its index of regional manufacturing rose to 6.4 in November from 5.3 in October. Analysts at MMS International had expected the index would fall to 5 this month.
The Government said the number of Americans applying for first-time jobless benefits rose 17,000, to 344,000 last week, more than the increase of 5,000 that economists expected.
The rise suggests that "the economy is continuing to soften," said Donald E. Maude, chief U.S. fixed-income strategist at Scotia Capital Markets (U.S.A.) Inc.
The benign environment for slower growth and inflation has bolstered Treasury prices in recent weeks. While prices rose after the Philadelphia Fed and initial-jobless claims reports were issued, the market failed to hold on to those gains, and prices seesawed through the rest of the session.
In the corporate bond market, Daimler-Benz A.G., the Simon Debartolo Group and other companies raised almost $1.9 billion yesterday.
Simon Debartolo, a shopping mall developer based in Indianapolis, led three borrowers that together raised $875 million in the corporate bond market.
Aramark Services, based in Philadelphia, sold $125 million of 10-year notes, and Commercial Credit, a finance unit of Travelers Inc., sold $200 million of five-year notes.
In another large deal, Daimler, the German conglomerate, sold about $795.2 million of bonds backed by truck loans.
The bonds, 5.85 percent-coupon securities, were priced at 99.989256 to yield 5.93 percent. The securities were rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's and sold through Daimler-Benz Vehicle Trust 1996-A. Monthly payments begin Dec. 20. Delivery is scheduled for Nov. 26, with accrued interest from Nov. 20.
In the municipal market, bonds were little changed as money managers sought to raise cash or swap out of existing bonds to buy some of this week's $3.7 billion in new tax-exempt securities.
The new-issue market has captured the attention of many investors in recent weeks as they look for bonds that will benefit most if interest rates continue to decline.
Investors who buy both taxable and tax-exempt securities are also finding muni bonds enticing when compared with other fixed-income investments.
"Munis are attractive right now," said Michael Schroeder, a manager for First International Asset Management in Naples, Fla.
New bond sales slowed to about $400 million yesterday, with most of the offerings by smaller issuers. Debt sales are expected to be slow until after the Thanksgiving Day holiday next Thursday.

HEADLINE: Claims by Jobless Jump Unexpectedly

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
The number of American workers filing first-time claims for jobless benefits unexpectedly shot up by 17,000 last week to the highest level since last July.
New applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 344,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, the Labor Department said today. 
 It was the largest number of new claims since 367,000 were filed during the week that ended on July 13 and the steepest advance since a 23,000 jump in the week that ended on Oct. 26 that was largely attributed to strikes at General Motors plants.
Many analysts had expected a much smaller increase last week, noting the shortened filing period due to the Veterans Day holiday and the continued return of employees after the end of the G.M. strikes.
Claims for the week that ended on Nov. 9 were revised lower to 327,000 from the 328,000 initial estimate.
The four-week moving average of new weekly jobless claims also rose, up 6,250, to 336,250, and matching the level reached in the period that ended on Oct. 12. Many analysts prefer to track the less volatile four-week average because it smooths out the spikes in the weekly reports.

HEADLINE: Japan Learns to Love Safety;
For Both Car Makers and Consumers, a New Sales Factor

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 21

 BODY:
"I want to be loved by you, just you," Marilyn Monroe croons seductively, as a mini-van smashes into a wall. Another accident caused by a driver daydreaming?
No, this is a Japanese television commercial for the Toyota Motor Corporation, advertising its new love affair with safety: the mini-van test crash, Toyota says, shows that its car bodies protect passengers. 
 Safety is finally starting to sell in Japan, the home of the tin-can subcompact. Blame a legal system and culture that don't encourage liability lawsuits or consumer activism. Blame Japan's narrow, congested roads, where drivers can't go fast enough to kill each other at American-style rates. For whatever reason, until now, safety took a back seat to fuel economy and style among both Japanese auto makers and consumers.
Indeed, Japanese cars sold at home haven't been as crashworthy as the cars sent to the United States, where safety regulations are stricter.
Now, though, alarmed by a surge in traffic fatalities, Japan's Government is toughening its standards. This year it released crash-test data for the first time -- but for just eight vehicles, and 18 years after the United States began doing so through the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
And as their home market has opened to American and European imports that use safety as a selling point, Japanese companies are adding safety features, strengthening their car bodies and stepping up research on electronic systems to prevent accidents.
The new attention to safety could make the Japanese more competitive not only at home, but worldwide, as they catch up in one of the few aspects of car design in which they are not already leaders.
They have already improved the crashworthiness of the vehicles they sell in the United States to meet the standards and competition there. But they have never had a reputation of leadership in safety, as do, say, Volvo and Mercedes-Benz. That is now a goal.
One belated addition is air bags, which are finally becoming standard equipment here, five years after the trend began in the United States.
But Toyota, Japan's largest auto maker, is also introducing throughout its product line -- including the American-made Camry -- a new body with stronger pillars and wall, floor and roof reinforcements. Toyota says its cars will be as safe as any in the world.
The Nissan Motor Company, the No. 2 auto maker, is advertising a similar "zone body concept," after beating Toyota to the punch in 1994 by making driver-side air bags standard equipment throughout its lineup, as well as passenger-side bags in its medium and large cars.
Now Nissan boasts that it was third in the world, following Volvo and Mercedes-Benz, to install a side-panel air bag in a model: the luxury Cima that it sells in Japan.
Imports have stressed safety to make inroads here. Last year Opel, the German subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation that is growing fast in Japan, advertised that all of its cars came equipped with dual air bags, anti-lock braking systems and seat belt tensioners.
Starting in 1992, the Ford Motor Company installed anti-lock brakes and dual air bags on all imports into Japan, even on models -- like the sport-utility Explorer -- that did not include those as standard features in the United States.
But now that Japanese companies have caught on, a spokesman for Ford Japan, Hiroo Tanabe, said, "Safety does not provide a competitive edge at the moment."
Some critics say Japanese companies are still not making serious efforts to make safer cars.
"The Japanese base their safety on the tests the U.S. gives," said Akio Takaoka, a former engineer for the Honda Motor Company who quit after disagreements with his boss about crash testing. Now a safety consultant, he earns a living largely as an expert witness in lawsuits in which Americans sue Honda over defects.
"It's not based on a philosophy," he said of the auto makers' new emphasis on safety. "It's for advertising purposes."
Japanese cars long had a reputation in the United States for crumpling like accordions in a crash, even as they won reputations for superior fuel economy, reliability and -- at least until the recent rise of the yen -- affordability.
Part of the reason was that Japanese cars tended to be small and light. Even compared with other small cars, though, Japanese models tended to do poorly in crash tests and in real accidents.
In 1982, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, which compiles data from insurance claims for American insurers, reported that the death rate in Japanese subcompacts was 34 percent higher than in American subcompacts.
By the mid-1980's, Consumer Reports was finding that Hondas and Toyotas had improved in crashworthiness, but that models from Nissan, Mitsubishi, Isuzu and Subaru were still occupying the lower rungs of its safety rankings.
Under competitive pressure, though,the Japanese gradually closed the gap. In 1994, reviewing the results of more than a decade of Federal crash tests, Consumer Reports noted that "the biggest improvements have been in small Japanese cars, particularly Hondas, Nissans and Mazdas."
Robert Knoll, the director of automobile testing for Consumer Reports, said that in terms of safety, Japanese cars now "don't appear to be any different from any other cars."
That, however, is not the case in Japan, where there has been less pressure from government to improve auto safety.
Infant car seats, for example, are not required in Japan, as they are in the United States. There has been little analysis of traffic accidents, so that data on the effectiveness of devices such as air bags almost invariably come from the United States.
And while American drivers are now being warned that air bags can kill children and small adults, and Federal officials are considering giving drivers the option of disconnecting the bags, there has been little discussion of the issue here, and no directives from the Ministry of Transportation. (Air bags here, however, use less inflating power than those in the United States.)
Other pressures on the industry are also absent. Product-liability lawsuits are rare because Japan is not a litigious society, and there are few lawyers. Since Japanese courts do not use juries, large damage awards are even rarer.
In a society where most citizens do not want to stand out as protesters, Japan also has a weak consumer movement. The Japan Automobile Consumers Union appears to be a one-person operation, though that person, Fumio Matsuda, said he calls on a network of 25 volunteer technical experts, such as retired auto company employees.
Safety consciousness among consumers also appears to be low. When Consumer Reports warned earlier this year that Isuzu's Trooper sport-utility could roll over in quick turns at low speeds, almost no attention was paid in Japan, even though the same vehicle is sold here.
And while shoppers say they are paying more attention to safety, it is still often not their top concern.
"I think the style is more important," said 29-year-old Shigeko Utsumi, whose boyfriend was buying a Jeep at a Yokohama dealer. "If I couldn't have a wooden steering wheel with an air bag, I'd take the wooden steering wheel."
Akihiko Hagiwara, a 27-year-old office worker shopping at a Toyota dealership in Yokohama, said he welcomed the fact that air bags and anti-lock brakes are becoming standard, because people would then use them. But, he said: "If it's there, I will take it. If it's optional, I wouldn't."
Mr. Matsuda of the automobile consumers union said that Japanese cars sold domestically tended to lack safety features such as stronger pillars to prevent a roof collapse in a rollover, reinforcing bars in the doors, and collapsible steering columns.
Mr. Matsuda, a former Nissan engineer, said that skimping on safety -- at a saving of $300 to $500 each vehicle -- was one way the auto makers generated profits in their protected home market to finance their export drive.
Mr. Takaoka, the former Honda engineer, said that there were also differences in Hondas made for different markets in pillar strength, seat belts and other features, though they have been narrowing in recent years.
Executives at Honda took issue, saying that the basic construction of its cars sold in both the Japanese and American markets, such as the Civic and the Accord, have always been the same.
The president of Honda, Nobuhiko Kawamoto, said it was natural, however, to tailor cars to the requirements of different markets.
In Japan, he said, people in cars make up a smaller percentage of those who die in traffic accidents than in the United States, and pedestrians a larger percentage.
"If we make the car bodies stronger today, it would probably mean more damage to pedestrians and people riding bicycles," Mr. Kawamoto said.
Traffic fatalities have been on the decline in the United States until a recent rise. But Japan saw a surge to more than 10,000 traffic deaths in 1988, the most since the 1970's, when the construction of pedestrian overpasses sharply cut the toll. While the increase appears in large part attributable to more Japanese driving, traffic deaths have remained at more than that politically sensitive level ever since.
Alarm over the rising fatality count has spurred some action. In 1992, the Government and auto industry established an institute to analyze accident data. Since 1994, new cars have had to meet certain safety standards in a frontal crash test, something the United States required since 1989. A side-impact testing regulation, already being instituted in the United States, will take effect here in 1998.
The Ministry of Transportation has also organized the automobile companies to develop "advanced safety vehicles," prototypes expected to be completed by about the year 2000 that are to feature special safety systems.
These systems, now in prototype form, include cameras and radars to detect other cars or pedestrians in a car's path and apply brakes automatically if necessary. There are also drowsiness detectors which would monitor a driver's eyes or pulse, or the car's steering pattern. If a driver were nodding off, an alarm would sound, or the seat would vibrate. Nissan's design would even include a mechanism to spray a fragrance to keep the driver awake.
Japan has even seen the debut this year of a magazine devoted to automobile safety -- bankrolled by the Takata Corporation, a leading maker of seat belts and other safety equipment. Said Shinzo Yamamoto, the magazine's editor, "For the first time, we're allowed to ask questions about safety."

GRAPHIC: Photos: A pair of Toyota Coronas, a car built in Japan for Japanese consumers, undergoing a crash test at 31 mph. After years if inattention to safety considerations, the Japanese Government now requires crash tests for cars sold in Japan. (Toyota Motor Corporation)
 
Graph/Chart: "A New Concern"
In the last few years, Japanese auto makers have responded to competition from imports and consumer concern about traffic fatalities in Japan by adopting many of the same safety features and practices that are standard on cars sold in the United States.

Both are becoming increasingly common features.

Years after similar tests became standard in the United States, cars in Japan now must meet minimum safety standards in head-on collisions. Side-impact standards are being added in 1998.
 
HANDLING
Steering systems have been improved to increase traction.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
'Only a Matter of Time'

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Aleksandr I. Lebed is the Russian general who became a politician and has no doubt that he will be Russia's next president. He says 25 years as a paratrooper taught him to talk concretely. In New York this week he used one word to describe Russia's efforts to prevent its nuclear warheads and materials from being stolen for terrorists or by rogue missile crews: "unsatisfactory."
But when it came to talking about what would then happen, he could not find concrete words in him. Nobody had ever lived in such a world, he said -- horrors unseen, dangers never conceived. When he said this to a few Russian and American journalists at the Regency Hotel I felt this man who looks like square rock and talks like rolling thunder was even more shaken than we were, because he knows more. 
 At Harvard, Prof. Graham Allison also knows what he is talking about. Normally milder than a Russian general, on nuclear terrorism he is writing and talking even more plainly -- not "if" it happens, but when. He writes in a letter that it is only a matter of time before a terrorist detonates a bomb in America.
Professor Allison heads a team from Harvard's Center for Science and International Affairs that produced a book-length report called "Avoiding Nuclear Anarchy." I cannot think of a more important book.
These are some of the major points:
1. "Loose" nuclear weapons and material are the number one threat to America's vital interests.
2. Russia and America have taken some steps to tighten security, but they are inadequate. The personnel and the one-tenth of 1 percent allocated to the job in the U.S. defense budget are not "remotely proportionate" to the problem.
(In late October, Vladimir Nechai, director of Russia's Chelyabinsk-70 nuclear complex, shot himself. He died ashamed at the failure of the Government even to pay scientists the $50 a month they earned. The lesson was inescapable: In a society where bitterness and humiliation can kill a top nuclear director, there can be no security.
3. Nuclear theft has arrived. Six known thefts in Russia have been intercepted abroad.
4. Once they have the material, terrorists have the bomb. It takes only enough enriched uranium or plutonium to fill a soft-drink can. (Since the U.S. cannot prevent tons of narcotics from getting in, the best place to hide it would be a bale of marijuana.)
5. If the bombers in Oklahoma and New York had 30 pounds of nuclear material they could have wiped out downtown Oklahoma City and Manhattan from the Battery to Gramercy Park. No bother with vans.
6. As the most open society, the U.S. is the most vulnerable. But because Russia is in chaos it may be the first target. (General Lebed spoke his own fears: the danger of mutinous takeover by Russian missile crews who have to put to sea or go up in planes knowing that they left behind families without decent food, shelter -- or dignity.)
7. Nuclear weapons and bomb material are scattered in 200 sites across Russia -- including storage depots and laboratories. Neither the Russian or Kazakh Governments had been aware of 1,000 pounds of nuclear material in Kazakhstan. When they came across it Kazakhstan sold it to the U.S.; now it is in Tennessee. But the Iranians -- they were aware and trying to get hold of it.
8. The combination of a demented economy, miserable nuclear workers and security to match, law by Mafia and terrorists with real money make more leakage inevitable.
Still the authors believe dangers can be lessened by increasing cooperation between Russia and the U.S. and the involvement of other countries. But they also say that although a better "political environment" is necessary the four critical players -- Russia, its nuclear ministry, Congress and the Clinton Administration -- have created a "pattern of behavior" that permits only "slow and grudging" progress, at best.
So as a non-scholar non-general I believe one way to avert nuclear terrorism is U.S. retaliation against non-nuclear terrorism, heavy enough to make terrorist nations forgo the pleasure of nuclear murder of Americans.
M.I.T. Press, Cambridge, Mass. 02142. The time to read it is now, not after "if" becomes a second ago.
