HEADLINE: Canadian Tribe, Shedding Ashes of an 'Evil Place,' Gets a Chance at Rebirth

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: DAVIS INLET, Newfoundland

 BODY:
All that stands on the windswept bluff where Gregory Rich's house used to be is a tall wooden cross, put there by the Innu Indians to recall the fire nearly five years ago that killed six of their children, and seared the image of this remote community on the conscience of Canada.
There were other tragedies, like the night in 1993 when six Innu teen-agers were found sniffing gasoline in a frozen shack, so intoxicated and so despairing that they threatened to kill themselves. 
 But it is the fire, which killed Mr. Rich's five children and a nephew while he and his wife were out drinking, that marks the low point of this community and the beginning of its healing.
After the fire, Davis Inlet became such a notorious symbol of all that is wrong with Canada's policies toward its more than 800,000 indigenous people that many high schools include the case in social studies classes. Now the national Government says a project to relocate and rebuild the Innu community is a symbol of how those policies have changed from misguided paternalism to an approach stressing self-government and economic development.
The Indians of Davis Inlet signed an agreement with the federal and provincial governments this month to try to help put behind them the drunkenness and desperation, the foul water, the raw sewage, the poverty and debilitating dependence endured on this rocky island off the northern coast of Labrador, to which the Government forced them to move 29 years ago.
After years in which the Innu demanded that to heal themselves they had to leave the island, and after an outpouring of support for the Innu across Canada, the Government has finally acknowledged its mistake and agreed to relocate them.
This time, all 500 Innu will be moved to a spot they selected, a traditional campsite on the mainland called Little Sango Pond, only five miles west but a world apart from Davis Inlet. The relocation will cost the Government $62 million. Although it could be achieved much faster, it will take as long as six years to build the airstrip, streets, sewage system, school and houses that are needed, because the Innu are to be involved in everything from planning to construction.
"In a way the signing represents a victory for this community," said Mr. Rich, now 27 and an Innu leader. He and his wife, Agathe, still face charges of abandonment related to the fire, but he said he had not taken a drink in almost a year or sniffed gasoline for a long time. He is a symbol of the Innu attempt at healing.
"There are things that happen that we can't do anything about," he said, "but the future is something we can control. That's what I picture at Sango Pond."
Ronald A. Irwin, Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development, said just before signing the agreement during a ceremony at Davis Inlet that the relocation "reflects a new spirit of partnership and working together."
He added: "It reflects the determination of all parties involved to lay the foundation for self-reliant and self-sustaining communities."
The Indians call this island of sand and evergreen Utshimassit, "Place of the Boss." They say they were forced by the provincial government and missionary Roman Catholic priests to give up the last remnants of their nomadic culture and move here in 1967.
Official records are sketchy, but there is evidence that the government and the church felt they were acting in the best interests of the Indians. The chief at the time, Joe Rich, a relative of Gregory Rich, was said to have supported the move to a less isolated place with a better waterfront, room for an airstrip and wooden houses.
However they came to be here, it was soon clear that moving to the island was a disaster. The Innu, who total about 2,000 in Canada, are not related to the Inuit, or Eskimos. Rather, their lineage has been traced to Indian groups in the more southerly parts of Canada. Their lives, like those of their ancestors for 10,000 years, had been attuned to the running of the caribou across the frozen barrens of northern Labrador.
"Davis is an evil place, eating away at the young people," said James Pasteen, 84, who followed the caribou and lived the ancient way of life until he came to Davis.
What Mr. Pasteen and other Innu soon discovered was that Davis had little water, despite the authorities' promises of plenty. Most families had to go long distances to haul what they used. The houses built for them were sturdier than tents but still rattled with the frigid winds that blew from offshore.
When the houses shifted and opened big cracks to the wind, the Innu, not knowing anything about such dwellings, had no idea how to fix them. Without drainage, families used plastic pails as toilets, and often just emptied them out onto the roads.
And worst of all, the Innu say, the forming and thawing of ice made Daniel Rattle, the strait between the island and the mainland, impassable for up to four months a year, cutting them off from their traditional hunting grounds.
By the time of the fire in February 1992, Sebastian Piwas remembers, nearly all the adults in Davis were receiving public assistance and getting drunk on cheap liquor or a powerful concoction known simply as home brew: sugar, molasses and yeast stirred into boiling water and left in five-gallon plastic buckets overnight to ferment.
"I was at a friend's house drinking home brew when we smelled smoke and someone came in and said, 'There's a house on fire,' " he said. It was about 11 o'clock on a night veiled with deadening cold.
"We had no firetrucks or pumps," Mr. Piwas said. There wasn't even enough water nearby to fill a bucket. "People said there was kids in there. But there was nothing to do but watch the building burn."
The next morning they found the charred bones of Wendy, Jeremiah, 9-month-old Daniel, Simon and the twins, Mary Jane and Madeline.
The deaths gave tragic notice that something had to change, and that the Innu themselves would have to make sure it happened. Adults began to sign up for alcohol counseling or leave for rehabilitation programs in the west of Canada. A sober chief and Band Council, an Indian form of governing body, were elected. Indian law enforcement officers, called peacekeepers, were trained.
And the Innu decided they had to move from the Place of the Boss to their own place.
Leslie A. Anderson, director of major projects for the national Department of Indian Affairs, said the tragedies at Davis Inlet focused official attention. No government wanted to be affiliated with that kind of horror, she added.
In 1994, the Government agreed in principle that the 1967 relocation to Davis Inlet had been a failure and that the Innu should be moved. But doing so before the Innu had learned to solve their own problems would have left the door open for another failure, Ms. Anderson said.
That is a departure from traditional policy in Canada. "A situation of dependency has been created by the federal Government," said Adrian Tanner, an anthropologist at the University of Newfoundland in St. John's. "They have maintained a dependency regime."
Under a new national strategy still in formation, Indians are encouraged to take control of their own lives. Thus, before any approval was given for the relocation, the Innu had to come up with a plan that was technically feasible, reasonably priced and supported by a majority of the community. They also had to come to grips with their problems of high unemployment, alcoholism and gasoline sniffing.
Innu elders say the rate of alcohol abuse in adults, once about 95 percent, has been cut in half. A training program has helped many young men become carpenters; they have rebuilt nearly every house here, picking up skills they will use in building at Sango Pond.
But Chief Katie Rich, a cousin of Mr. Rich and granddaughter of Chief Joe Rich, said the Innu were the first to admit that simply moving will not resolve everything.
"It took us 25 years to get where we are now," she said, "and it's probably going to take another 25 years to get where we want to go."
Some Innu even worry that moving may not change anything at all. "I think there could be even more drinking," said Toby Noah, a burly 24-year-old who anticipates getting a construction job at Sango Pond. "They say we'll have running water, but if there is, people can make home brew real easy."
Despite all the tragedy at Davis Inlet, the Innu say they want to see parts of their old home preserved.
One is the cemetery, just off the seal-colored sand of the cove at the far end of the community. There, pencils, a doll's head and a faded blue cap have been placed on the graves of the six children.
Another is the place where the cross stands, where Gregory Rich sometimes goes by himself, to pray.
"It's very hard to go up there," he said, "but sometimes I go and pray. I pray that such things not happen to any other family. And I pray that we Innu can have a healthier community."

HEADLINE: One Airline's Shift to a One-Maker Fleet

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
American Airlines and the Boeing Company left out few superlatives in announcing a widely expected agreement yesterday, in which American will buy 103 jets and perhaps hundreds more over the next 20 years as the carrier moves toward an all-Boeing fleet.
And some of the labels American and Boeing applied to their deal -- unprecedented, unparalleled, innovative -- were warranted, offering plenty of reasons for their shareholders to cheer. Partly in anticipation of yesterday's announcement, shares of the airline's parent company, the AMR Corporation, have risen sharply this month, though they eased 50 cents yesterday, closing at $90.50. Boeing's shares gained $1.125, closing at $97.50. 
 Although some of the broader implications of American's announcement were not exactly heartening to either hardened skeptics about the airline industry or to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, whose prospects have been very much the talk of the airline and aerospace industries in recent weeks, for American, the deal should be beneficial.
Most large United States carriers have cited the need in recent years for a simpler fleet with fewer aircraft types. That would reduce the costs of maintaining spare-parts inventories and of training pilots and mechanics.
But American, not a company known for taking half steps, has pushed the trend further than its competitors in agreeing to rely on Boeing in a deal worth more than $6 billion at list prices for the 103 firm aircraft orders. Even USAir, which said recently that it planned to buy as many as 400 new Airbus Industrie planes, did not rule out the possibility of buying other kinds of aircraft.
American and Boeing also used the term "purchase right," to describe an unusual aspect of their deal. Historically, an airline's option for new aircraft required the carrier to tell the manufacturer two to three years in advance that it, in fact, wanted to buy the aircraft. With American's purchase rights for 527 new aircraft, it can give Boeing as little notice as 15 months to deliver narrow-bodied aircraft, and 18 months for the wide bodies.
That means less guesswork for American in trying to keep its capacity in line with demand, something that has not been easy for the industry -- its propensity to overexpand in good times has been the main reason that carriers have lost billions of dollars since the industry was deregulated in 1978.
"The agreement," Robert L. Crandall, American's chairman, said yesterday, "will enable us to acquire the aircraft we need while avoiding the need to make larger firm commitments, thus preserving the strength of our balance sheet."
The deal was contingent upon approval of a new labor agreement with the union representing American's pilots. The union leaders voted on Wednesday to pass the agreement on to their members, but the aircraft order will not go through if the members vote it down. The contract vote is expected next month.
In recent years, the industry appears to have learned from its mistakes. By restraining capacity in the face of good demand, it has gained more control over pricing and profits.
Still, industry experts are asking whether the industry's troubled history will repeat itself, for United, Continental and USAir have all placed orders for new aircraft in recent months.
Yet some aspects of the industry are different this time. The airlines are all saying that the new aircraft will be used largely to replace older aircraft that will become obsolete in a few years because of tougher noise regulations. American said yesterday that it planned to expand only about 2 percent a year, in line with industry growth.
Candace Browning, an industry analyst at Merrill Lynch who wrote a research report in August entitled "Capacity Creep -- Have Managements Really Reformed?", said she was "not yet overly concerned" by the new aircraft orders. After all, she said, the older planes that will be retired would be costly to refurbish and operate and are therefore not likely to find their way back into service through smaller carriers looking for cheap, older planes to expand their fleets.
Still, "this is something that I am paying a lot of attention to," she said.
Kevin C. Murphy, an airline analyst at Morgan Stanley, also said it would be wise to keep an eye on too-rapid growth in capacity. "Today's order may be good for American Airlines, but is it good for the U.S. industry?" he said, "That is the important issue."
What is certain is that yesterday's big order represented more disheartening news to McDonnell Douglas, the third-largest manufacturer behind Boeing and Airbus, and a longtime supplier to American.
The company has been in a slump of late, acknowledging in recent weeks that it would become a niche player in commercial planes. Last weekend, it lost out on a chance to compete for a huge contract to build an all-purpose fighter aircraft. And Delta Air Lines, another big customer for McDonnell Douglas, has said recently that it is talking only to Boeing and Airbus about buying airplanes to replace many of its L-1011's.
The American and USAir aircraft orders underscore that some airlines are serious about simplifying their fleets and are teaming with suppliers with a broader array of planes than McDonnell Douglas offers.
Industry experts, in fact, said that of the major domestic airlines, only Delta and Northwest Airlines were candidates to place big orders with McDonnell Douglas anytime soon.
"One of those almost has to go to Douglas if they are going to continue to be a viable producer of commercial airplanes," Edmund S. Greenslet, an industry analyst who runs ESG Aviation Services, said. "The list is getting very short for Douglas."
Others, however, contend that concerns about McDonnell Douglas's future are overblown. Paul H. Nisbet, an aerospace analyst with JSA Research, said that the recent big orders were quickly filling the capacity of Boeing and Airbus, meaning they may have little incentive to bargain with other customers, including foreign airlines.
"There is a very good chance you will see some spillover to McDonnell Douglas in the not too distant future," he said. "And they will be sitting there, arms open, waiting for the next order, and they will survive quite well through this cycle."

HEADLINE: Europeans Link To Chicago Merc

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Two big European futures exchanges are linking up with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, carving up business in advance of the planned single European currency.
The London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange has signed a deal with the Chicago Merc to link trading in some interest-rate futures and options. 
 And the French futures and options exchange Matif signed an accord with the Chicago Merc to start Matif's French bond futures, applying to all contracts of a year or more.
With the single currency, to be known as the Euro, planned for introduction in 1999, financial markets have been jostling for position.
A futures contract is an agreement to buy or sell a commodity or financial instrument at a set price on a specific date. An options contract grants the right but not the obligation to buy or sell a stock, bond, currency or other instrument at a set price by a certain time. The contracts are used by investors and corporations to make money and limit risk on their other investments.

HEADLINE: FORGIVEN ENEMY: A special report.;
From Suspect in Murders To a New Life in America

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

 BODY:
In the last days of spring in 1985, Pedro Antonio Andrade was a leftist guerrilla commander so committed to overthrowing the United States-backed Government of El Salvador, officials say, that he helped plan the most violent attack on Americans of El Salvador's civil war: the shooting of four off-duty marines and nine other people as they dined at sidewalk restaurants in the Zona Rosa section of San Salvador.
Five years later, Mr. Andrade and his family were living quietly in the United States, their visas approved by American diplomats and their new life financed with thousands of dollars from the Central Intelligence Agency for his services as an informer against the cause he once championed. 
 The facts of Mr. Andrade's admission were confirmed by United States officials this month after nearly a year's investigation by officials of the State, Justice and Defense Departments and the C.I.A. That long inquiry broke into public view after the family of one of the marines killed in the attack pressed a United States Senator to join its battle to have Mr. Andrade, who has been arrested on charges of overstaying his visa, held to account.
"Andrade, an illegal alien and murderer of American marines, must not be allowed to exploit our bureaucracy," Senator Richard C. Shelby, an Alabama Republican, wrote in a letter to President Clinton that was made public yesterday.
Mr. Andrade has consistently denied any direct involvement in the killings and has said he initially agreed to act as an informer only under duress. He also took two liedetector tests, which were described by several American officials as inconclusive. Some of those officials -- including one who came to know Mr. Andrade well -- said they believed that the evidence of Mr. Andrade's role in the Zona Rosa case was far from certain.
Yet, as told by Mr. Andrade, other former rebels and more than a dozen American officials familiar with his case, the story of how one of the reputed masterminds of the Zona Rosa massacre became a highly paid informer for the Salvadoran armed forces reveals the contradictory impulses that guided the United States involvement in the Salvadoran civil war. It is perhaps the most remarkable in a series of recent cases that have illuminated questionable ways in which intelligence agents and other American officials pursued their missions in Latin America in the waning years of the cold war.
Several officials said that among at least some of the C.I.A. agents who sought to broker Mr. Andrade's services as an informer for Salvadoran intelligence, there was a familiar sense of expediency, a belief that in the cause of keeping Marxist rebels from seizing power in El Salvador, distasteful means were often justified.
"Their doctrine is that they'll play ball with the Devil if he can be useful to us now," said one diplomat involved in discussions of Mr. Andrade's fate at the United States Embassy in San Salvador. "And they thought he could be useful."
In a report that is still classified, the inspectors general of the three departments and the C.I.A. criticized the deal to allow Mr. Andrade into the United States, describing it as the product of "significant intra- and interagency problems."
But in justifying the deal, some diplomats, mindful of the risk Mr. Andrade took in providing extensive information on his former comrades, argued that the agreement made with him had to be respected, regardless of his possible complicity.
"We did this out of the best of motives, and we did it with the knowledge that these were Americans who were killed," said Richard J. Chidester, a 45-year-old lawyer and retired diplomat who was the embassy official in charge of the case. "If we had gotten evidence that he was implicated in the murder of the marines, then he would have been prosecuted for that. We didn't, and guys said, 'We think this guy has some real value and can help us hurt the guerrillas.' "
More than six years later, however, the deal that was cut with Mr. Andrade is very much under review.
Two months after being arrested on charges of failing to properly renew his visa, Mr. Andrade sits in a small cell in the Passaic County Jail in Paterson, N.J. The former rebel, who had been living in West New York, N.J., has asked the Immigration and Naturalization Service, a branch of the Justice Department, for political asylum on the ground that he might be killed by his former comrades if he returned to El Salvador.
Almost from the moment Mr. Andrade fell into the hands of the security forces in 1989, in the waning years of the Salvadoran war, it became clear that he was not an ordinary mid-level commander among the guerrillas fighting to overthrow the government then headed by President Jose Napoleon Duarte.
Less than two days after his arrest on May 28, 1989, Mr. Andrade proved his worth as an informer when he accompanied Salvadoran military intelligence officers to the small construction-supply shop he owned in San Salvador, the nation's capital, and uncovered hundreds of assault rifles and other weapons -- the biggest arms cache seized from the rebels in the 12-year conflict.
Shortly after that, according to officials familiar with his case, Mr. Andrade said he could offer his former enemies other important help as well. His essential condition for providing extensive information on the rebels' operations during the preparations for the last major offensive of the war was that he and his family be protected from the insurgents and be helped to resettle in the United States.
 
The Rebel Attack In the 'Pink Zone'
 As he has consistently, Mr. Andrade told American diplomats after his arrest that he was merely a logistics officer for the smallest faction of the rebel umbrella organization, the Faribundo Marti National Liberation Front, known by its Spanish initials as the FMLN, and as such arranged for medical aid, uniforms and other logistical help for the rebels.
In an interview at the Passaic jail last Friday, Mr. Andrade, referring to Americans by using Salvadoran slang, said, "What was proposed was that there was going to be an action against the whities without mentioning a specific target." Recounting his clandestine meetings with another rebel commander, whose nom de guerre was Rogelio Martinez, Mr. Andrade added, "He told me that I should remain at the margins of it because my presence in San Salvador was of strategic importance for the FMLN."
At the time of the killings, in 1985, United States policy in El Salvador was turning an important corner. The Salvadoran military and security forces were beginning to distance themselves from atrocities committed by the armed forces and right-wing death squads in the early 1980's. Advocates of the United States policy grew more comfortable and aggressive in their support for the Government.
The rebels remained strong in the countryside, but they were forced into a prolonged, hit-and-run war of small ambushes and economic sabotage. The specter of the United States' long and deep military involvement in Southeast Asia began to lift from the bitter debates in Washington.
Hoping to remind Americans of that specter, the urban commando group attacked the marines, who were frequent off-duty visitors to the row of small restaurants that anchored the Zona Rosa, or pink zone. The rebel group named the operation Yankee Agressor in El Salvador, Another Vietnam Awaits You.
On the night of June 19, 1985, a group of the guerrillas jumped from a pickup truck in front of the restaurants and opened fire with semiautomatic weapons, killing the four marines, two visiting American businessmen and seven Salvadorans. Three days later, a little-known FMLN guerrilla cell calling itself the Mardoqueo Cruz urban commandos took responsibility for the killings.
It took a full week for the FMLN leadership to endorse the attack, a delay that rebel leaders later attributed to the fact that the commandos had not consulted with them before carrying it out.
 
Investigating The Incident
Within a few months, the Salvadoran authorities had arrested one of the men later convicted of participating directly in the attack and two of his accomplices. Two or three other major suspects were presumed dead.
But according to declassified C.I.A. and State Department cables, a task force made up of C.I.A. and Salvadoran intelligence and military officials had also assembled extensive information on the Mardoqueo Cruz commando, its members and their backgrounds.
One State Department cable lists Mario Gonzalez, the nom de guerre that Mr. Andrade used, as the first among three men who planned the operation and identifies him as "chief of the Mardoqueo Cruz Urban Commandos, later discovered to be Pedro Antonio Andrade Martinez." He is also listed on another United States Embassy cable that named the suspects in 1987 in response to a Congressional inquiry. A C.I.A. report, dated Jan. 21, 1986, that recounted the testimony of an informer in the case told of "Mario" working closely with the rebel who led the commandos and dropping off the weapons that it used.
An extensive report in 1993 of a United Nations-sponsored commission that investigated the worst abuses of the Salvadoran war also implicated Mr. Andrade.
The investigators, who interviewed Mr. Andrade and other rebels and inspected classified documents about the attack, concluded that "Pedro Antonio Andrade was also involved in planning the attack."
After the 1985 attack, at a memorial service for the six Americans killed, President Ronald Reagan promised to use "all available U.S. resources" to insure that sooner or later, those responsible would pay.
"I pledge to you today that they will not evade justice on earth any more than they can escape the judgement of God," Mr. Reagan said, his voice choking with emotion. "We and the Salvadoran leaders will move any mountain and ford any river to find the jackals and bring them and their colleagues in terror to justice."
As a result of pressure by American diplomats, the Zona Rosa case was one of a handful to be exempted from two amnesties that covered human rights violations on both sides of the civil war.
 
Making a Deal With a Rebel
How closely American officials reviewed the evidence against Mr. Andrade after his capture in 1989 remains unclear. But half a dozen officials who served in the embassy at the time said there was no question as to his identity.
According to those officials and others who have seen the report of the inspectors general, a senior official of the embassy's C.I.A. station approached the United States Ambassador, William Walker, and told him that Mr. Andrade had been captured and might provide important cooperation to the Salvadorans. The only problem, the agent said, was the rebel commander's possible role in the Zona Rosa case.
Hoping to arrange for Mr. Andrade to serve as an informer for the Salvadoran military but concerned that he might yet be prosecuted in the case, C.I.A. officials suggested that Mr. Chidester be recruited to help assess the rebel's possible culpability.
Mr. Chidester, who had worked with the Nicaraguan rebels while stationed in Honduras earlier in the 1980's and who described himself as a strong believer in the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America, had retired briefly from the Foreign Service and returned in March 1989 to become Mr. Walker's legal attache.
Along with an F.B.I. agent based at the United States Embassy in Mexico City, Mr. Chidester was briefed on Mr. Andrade and on the Zona Rosa case by Salvadoran military intelligence officers, and questioned him in a cell at the Salvadoran National Police headquarters on June 6, 7 and 8, 1989.
After Mr. Andrade's denials of direct involvement in the Zona Rosa case, mid-level officials of the State and Justice Departments and the C.I.A. met in Washington to discuss the case, and Mr. Chidester, who happened to be in town, joined them. As was the case throughout the debate over how to deal with Mr. Andrade, the Justice Department's representatives strongly opposed his being allowed into the United States in return for his information, officials said. Diplomats at the embassy suggested that he be given a polygraph examination.
Mr. Andrade ultimately underwent two such tests, both of them administered by Salvadoran military investigators and reviewed by F.B.I. agents. Three former embassy officials said the first was viewed as inconclusive, while the second appeared to suggest that Mr. Andrade was telling the truth. But two other officials familiar with the subsequent inquiry into Mr. Andrade's parole into the United States argued that both examinations were of dubious quality.
In October 1989, officials familiar with the inspectors' general report said, the C.I.A. station in San Salvador began providing the Salvadoran security forces with what ultimately became $20,000 for the resettlement of Mr. Andrade and his family in the United States, and $22,400 that was reimbursed to the Salvadoran security forces and other agencies for the cost of keeping him in a special safe house for the next nine months. After continued objections from Justice Department officials, the C.I.A. began to distance themselves from Mr. Andrade, intelligence officials said.
Responding to a request from the station chief in San Salvador, officials at the agency's headquarters said they would not take responsibility for Mr. Andrade's parole into the United States on the ground of national security, officials said. And in January 1990, the office of the C.I.A.'s general counsel lined up more directly with the Justice Department.
"Our office of the general counsel got back to the station and said, 'Whatever was your view of this before, knock it off,' " one intelligence official said, describing warnings from the agency's warnings from its headquarters in Langley, Va.. "It's not going anywhere. Desist."
Two embassy diplomats said the station chief subsequently went to Ambassador Walker and asked if Mr. Andrade could not be paroled in using the Immigration and Naturalization Service's authority over cases "strictly in the public interest."
Mr. Andrade's parole was approved by the immigration agency in June 1990. He lived briefly with relatives in Southern California and then moved to West New York, N.J., in 1991, working mostly as a truck driver until his recent arrest on immigration charges.
 
Deciding the Fate Of an Informer
While Mr. Shelby and other officials said the Justice Department has ruled out trying to prosecute Mr. Andrade in connection with the Zona Rosa case, advocates for the families of the slain marines are adamant that he not be allowed to remain in the United States.
"The dark stain of Andrade's deeds and our Government's de facto ratification of them must not be allowed to spread amidst interminable hearings, wrangling and legal maneuvering," Senator Shelby, who requested the Federal investigation on behalf of the family of one of the marines, wrote in the letter to President Clinton.
But diplomats involved in the case continue to defend their actions.
"There was a moral commitment to this guy when he was brought into the United States," Mr. Walker said. "I'm not saying he would be sent back to his death in El Salvador, but his life would certainly be in danger."
Advised of the Senator's letter urging the President to deny him parole, Mr. Andrade telephoned a reporter yesterday from jail. He denied having received any other money than about $10,000 he said was taken from his San Salvador home when he was first captured, and noted that his children and wife, who has long been a legal resident of the United States, had lived on welfare since 1993 because his earnings as a truck driver were not enough to support the family.
"This situation now is the consequence of a campaign of misinformation that the FMLN and some other people have waged against me," he said. "But I came to the United States because of an offer by this Government, and at its initiative."
In his letter to Mr. Clinton, Senator Shelby described the Zona Rosa episode as "a wound that remains open and untreated"; in El Salvador, it has long since begun to heal.
Two of the three other former rebels who were convicted of participating in the killings have already served their prison sentences and have been released, along with a fourth man who was held for five years before being acquitted in 1993. Two more rebels who were thought to have led the attack are believed to have been killed in fighting outside San Salvador later in 1985.
Yesterday afternoon Francisco Jovel, the leader of the FMLN faction in which Mr. Andrade served, interrupted a conversation about the Andrade case, explaining that he had another debate to attend to. He is now a member of the Salvadoran National Assembly.

HEADLINE: For Blacks, Economic Gain Is Limited to a Few

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Quality of Life Is Up for Many Blacks, Data Say" (front page, Nov. 18) implies that there has been significant improvement over all for African-Americans -- an inaccurate assumption. However, it does reflect that the gap between the haves and have-nots among blacks is widening, as is happening among whites.
The income statistics emphasized are limited to married couples, which gives an exaggerated impression of progress. Yes, the Census Bureau reports median income of black married couples at 87 percent of that of white married couples, up from 79 percent in 1989. But the percentage of married couples among black families declined from 50.2 percent to 46.1 percent, while the absolute number of black married couples fell. 
 More indicative of progress, if any, among blacks are long-term trends in family income. Since 1972, the first year for which comparable statistics are available, the real median income of black families, adjusted by the Consumer Price Index, increased only 3.7 percent. Black median income fell to 57.7 percent of non-Hispanic white median income, down about one percentage point. The reported dip in black poverty below the 30 percent level is welcome, if it starts a trend. But it is 3.4 times the percentage of non-Hispanic whites in poverty, a ratio that has not improved.
Black unemployment remains high and has been rising alarmingly, according to the Labor Department. It increased from 9.9 percent in October 1995 to 10.8 percent in October 1996, while the rates for whites and Hispanic-Americans fell.
Over the year, the proportion of white adult males with jobs went up to 74.5 percent, while among black men the number dropped to 65.5 percent. The white-black gap has widened to nine percentage points. There is still a long way to go.
 
VICTOR PERLO
Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., Nov. 19, 1996
 
The writer is an economic consultant.

HEADLINE: Time for a Broader Asian Agenda

 BODY:
During the cold war, Washington saw its role in Asia as clearly defined -- containing the spread of Soviet-backed Communism. The region today defies easy classification. While East Asia is the world's fastest-growing region economically, it is also an arena where four of the world's most powerful countries -- Japan, China, Russia and the United States -- are awkwardly working out new relationships with each other. The Clinton Administration has yet to devise a policy that adequately balances American economic and security interests in this vital region.
President Clinton's current trip underscores the need for such a policy. The trip's ostensible centerpiece, an Asia-Pacific economic conference in Manila this weekend, is largely an empty event. Two years ago, Pacific leaders agreed to create a regional free-trade zone by 2020. But there is no real consensus for taking concrete steps toward this laudable goal. The more vital business is likely to come in side discussions among some of the 16 leaders assembled in Manila. Mr. Clinton, for example, is discussing economic and security issues individually with Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan and Presidents Fidel Ramos of the Philippines, Kim Young Sam of South Korea and Jiang Zemin of China. 
 China's economic clout and rising military power are reshaping relations among Asian nations. Japan, an economic but not a military power, is anxiously studying Chinese intentions. But Tokyo also understands that any attempt to rebuild Japanese military power would stir angry memories throughout Asia of past Japanese aggression.
South Korea, guarding the last military frontier of the cold war, worries about a second Korean War and a militarily resurgent Japan. Suspecting that Washington is too complacent about both dangers, it is edging closer to Beijing as a strategic insurance policy. Meanwhile Russia, though militarily weak, cannot be discounted. Traditionally a rival of both Japan and China, it now seems interested in warmer relations with both.
The United States can serve its own interests and the region's by helping to maintain a security balance in the area. As long as China, Russia and Japan do not feel threatened, they can be encouraged to assert themselves economically rather than militarily, sustaining the surge toward prosperity that has characterized the region in the last decade.
The United States must recognize that Russia has a legitimate role to play in the region. Washington can work with both Moscow and Tokyo to encourage the return to Japan of islands Moscow seized at the end of World War II.
American relations with Japan, after several years of trade confrontations, have settled down as Japan struggles to climb out of a recession. This has given the Clinton Administration a chance to re-emphasize security cooperation. Tokyo can continue to rely on Washington for protection from external threats while expanding its own participation in United Nations and other international peacekeeping operations.
China presents the hardest challenge. Washington and Beijing are talking again after last spring's chill over Taiwan. But the Administration has not found effective ways to moderate Chinese behavior or hold Beijing to the agreements it has worked out with the United States and other countries. Mr. Clinton's ability to establish a more productive dialogue with China will be an essential measure of his success in Asia during his next term.
Over the last four years, the Clinton Administration has positioned America to compete effectively in Asia's booming markets. But the growth of those markets now depends on assuring stability in the region. That will require more than a strategy to sell American cars in Japan and to protect American intellectual property in China.

HEADLINE: Victory of 5 Redistricted Blacks Recasts Gerrymandering Dispute

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 22

 BODY:
The re-election of five black members of Congress, in districts recently redrawn to eliminate black voting majorities, has sharpened the debate on a crucial legal and political question: Is it still necessary to gerrymander legislative districts along racial lines to insure minority representation?
Those who have successfully petitioned the Supreme Court to reject districts drawn along racial lines see the results of the five races in Florida, Georgia and Texas as a vindication of their efforts. The success of black candidates in majority-white districts, they say, demonstrates that legislators do not need to consolidate blacks into oddly shaped districts in order to insure that a black is elected. 
 "The idea that minorities have to have a super-majority of black voters to win in their district, that's history now," said A. Lee Parks Jr., the lawyer representing the plaintiffs who successfully challenged two black-majority districts in Georgia.
But civil rights leaders argue that the key to the victories on Election Day was less the design of the districts than the incumbency of the black candidates. Early analysis of the results suggested that whites and blacks continued to vote largely in racially polarized blocs. And most of the winners said that they succeeded only because their previous representation of black-majority districts gave them the name recognition, fund-raising capacity and legislative records they needed to attract the necessary share of the white vote in their new districts.
"The real test of whether majority-minority districts are still necessary will come from the minority candidates who vie for this seat after me," said Representative Cynthia A. McKinney, a feisty and flamboyant black Democrat who won 58 percent of the vote in Georgia's newly designed Fourth District.
"It may very well be the case that attitudes in the South have changed for the better," Ms. McKinney said. "But one thing is for certain: representing the old 11th District allowed me to run and win in the new 4th District without having to change my views, my gold tennis shoes, my braids, or having to auction off my principles to the highest bidder."
It is clear that the direst predictions by civil rights leaders have not come to pass, at least so far.
After the Supreme Court struck down racially gerrymandered districts in Texas and North Carolina last June, the Rev. Jesse Jackson said the decision would lead to "a kind of ethnic cleansing." Laughlin McDonald, the director of the Southern regional office of the American Civil Liberties Union, predicted a "bleaching of Congress," and Elaine Jones, the director-counsel of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc., warned that "the noose is tightening."
But the only black incumbent to lose this year was Representative Gary A. Franks, a Connecticut Republican whose district was not affected by Supreme Court rulings. And while one black incumbent, Representative Cleo Fields, Democrat of Louisiana, chose not to run this year because the courts ordered his district redrawn, another black candidate, Julia M. Carson, won in an Indiana district that has long had a substantial white majority.
Five years ago, under pressure from the Bush Administration's Justice Department to comply with the Voting Rights Act, state legislatures around the country created several awkwardly designed Congressional districts that linked black population centers. The redistricting plans had both the intended effect of maximizing the election of black candidates and the more surreptitious effect of draining reliably Democratic black voters from districts that then became vulnerable to Republican takeover.
In subsequent years, plaintiffs challenged the districts in several states and the Supreme Court issued a series of 5-to-4 rulings striking them down. If race was a predominant factor in the construction of the districts, the Court ruled, they were unconstitutional racial gerrymanders. Legislatures were instructed to redraw the districts, and where they failed, the Federal courts stepped in to do the job.
In this year's general elections for the House of Representatives, 53 black candidates -- 38 Democrats and 15 Republicans -- ran and 37 won, 36 Democrats and 1 Republican, according to an analysis by David A. Bositis, a senior political analyst with the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies. In 10 instances, black candidates ran against each other.
Twenty-three candidates won in districts where at least 50 percent of the voting age population is black, 7 won in districts where 40 percent to 49 percent of the population is black, and 7 won in districts where less than 40 percent of the population is black, Mr. Bositis said.
In the newly drawn districts this year, the most striking results came in Georgia.
Ms. McKinney cruised to a third term against a moderate white Republican in a district that is predominantly Democratic but where blacks represented only 33 percent of the voting-age population, according to the 1990 census. Political strategists estimate that the black voting-age population in the district, which consists of suburbs east and northeast of Atlanta, has grown to nearly 40 percent black in the last six years. But that is still far below the 60 percent of the voting-age population that was black in Ms. McKinney's old district.
A study completed this week by Allan J. Lichman, a professor of history at American University, found that Ms. McKinney won more than 90 percent of the black vote and an estimated 31 percent of the white vote. Turnout among black voters was about 60 percent while turnout among whites was 65 percent, Mr. Lichman said.
In the Second District in southwest Georgia, Representative Sanford D. Bishop Jr., with a moderate voting record, won 54 percent of the vote in a district where the voting-age population is 35 percent black. His previous district had been 52 percent black. Mr. Lichman found that Mr. Bishop won more than 90 percent of the black vote and an estimated 36 percent of the white vote. Turnout was higher among whites than blacks, 55 percent to 40 percent.
In Florida's Third District, which includes Jacksonville, Representative Corrine Brown won 61 percent of the vote in a district where the voting-age population is 42 percent black. Her previous district had been 50 percent black.
The two remaining districts, in Texas, are somewhat less revealing because black and Hispanic voters combine there to create heavy majorities of minority voters.
Representative Eddie Bernice Johnson, a Democrat, won 55 percent of the vote in the 30th District, in Dallas, where 42 percent of the voting-age population is black and 16 percent is Hispanic. In the 18th District, in Houston, Representative Sheila Jackson Lee, a Democrat, won 77 percent of the vote in a district where the voting age-population is 44 percent black and 21 percent Hispanic.
In all five races, the black incumbents raised more money than their opponents. Ms. McKinney, for instance, had raised more than twice as much as her Republican rival, John Mitnick, as of mid-October.
And Ms. McKinney's pollster, Ron L. Lester, said that her four years in Congress provided her with a voting record on issues like education, the minimum wage, Medicare and the environment that appealed to constituents in her new district, particularly to women.
"By virtue of being the incumbent, she was able to connect with voters on these issues," Mr. Lester said. "I don't think another black candidate could win this seat."
Across the country, well over 90 percent of the incumbent House members who ran for re-election won. Civil rights leaders said that black incumbents benefited along with white incumbents.
"There was a question in my mind whether incumbency would trump race, and it appears that it has," said Theodore M. Shaw, the associate director-counsel of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc.
But Abigail Thernstrom, an author and academic who has crusaded against racial gerrymandering, said the incumbency advantage was overstated.
"They weren't incumbents in these districts," Ms. Thernstrom said. "These are new districts."
If black contenders run effective campaigns, she said, whites will vote for them.
"I think there is enormous willingness to vote for black candidates in this country," she said, pointing out that many black mayors had been elected in white-majority cities. "People don't want to think of themselves as racists."
People on both sides of the debate believe that this year's results will influence decisions on redistricting by legislatures and by the Supreme Court.
On Dec. 9, the Court will hear an appeal of a lower court's drawing of the district lines used this year in Georgia. The new districts have been challenged by the Justice Department and A.C.L.U. on several constitutional grounds.
Lawyers who have fought racial gerrymandering said they hoped the Election Day results would help reassure Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the most tenuous vote of the five-member coalition that has rejected black-majority districts.
North Carolina's Legislature must redraw the state's Congressional map next year and is likely to eliminate the black majority in the 12th District, which is represented by Melvin L. Watt, a black Democrat. Rather than focus on the results in Georgia, Mr. Watt said, lawmakers should consider the racially polarized voting in his state's Senate race this year. Polls of voters leaving voting booths showed that Harvey Gantt, a black Democrat, won 89 percent of the black vote but only 36 percent of the white vote in his unsuccessful race against Senator Jesse Helms.
Mr. Lichman, the historian, predicted that this year's results, if they are repeated in 1998 and 2000, would affect the next round of redistricting in "a dramatic way."
"It'll be much less likely that you'll get districts that are 65 percent black," he said. "But I hope they affect them in a sensible way, that we don't make blithe across-the-board assumptions. In some states it may well be possible to create districts that provide opportunities for minorities to elect candidates of their choice where the minority population is about 40 percent. In other districts, it may require black majorities, even substantial black majorities."

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices End Lower in Dull Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended slightly lower in dull trading yesterday as players squared portfolios ahead of the weekend and braced for new economic data next week.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 12/32 , to 100 22/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.44 percent from 6.41 percent. A week ago, the yield was 6.46 percent. 
 While trading was light, there was some interest in the 10-year note, which ended slightly lower, pushing its yield up to 6.13 percent from 6.12 percent.
"Activity today has been exceptionally light," said John Canavan, a money market analyst with Stone & McCarthy Research Associates. "If players are doing anything, it's a little bit of position-squaring ahead of the weekend."
Bond prices rose early in the session after the Labor Department reported that the United States import price index, excluding fuels, declined three-tenths of 1 percent in October. It was the fifth consecutive month that the import price index declined.
The data "reminded us that low import prices have been one of the factors explaining all the good inflation reports," said Robert Dederick, chief economist at Northern Trust.
"All yearlong, import prices, ex-oil, have barely moved," he said, "and that also reflects the sluggish worldwide economy."
Yesterday's report follows recent data on consumer prices, showing that inflation in the United States remains tame. The latest figures showed that the consumer price index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in the month of November.
In another report yesterday, the Treasury said that the total United States budget deficit widened to $40.26 billion in October from $22.58 billion in the previous year, a gap that exceeded analysts' predictions.
 Still, the market was also somewhat disappointed yesterday as the Federal Reserve refrained from carrying out an expected coupon pass operation. Traders said the operation was expected after a flood of fresh supply that entered the market earlier in the week.
The Fed, however, decided to add temporary reserves to the banking system through $2 billion customer repurchase agreements.
"We were expecting the Fed to come in with a coupon pass to prop prices up, which didn't happen," said a trader at an investment bank.
The market also paid little attention to remarks by a Federal Reserve Board governor, Susan Philips.
Ms. Philips said she saw consumer spending rising in the fourth quarter, adding that her best guess was that the economy was to stay moderate but in a sustainable growth path.
Analysts said trading yesterday was in the hands of professional players. Hedge and mutual funds as well as retailers were mostly out of the market. Volume was extremely thin. By late afternoon, total volume as measured by GovPX, a bond pricing service, was $46.35 billion, around 20 percent below average for a Friday in the fall.

HEADLINE: Subic Bay, Minus U.S., Becomes Surprise Success

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: SUBIC BAY FREEPORT, the Philippines

 BODY:
When President Clinton and 17 other world leaders gather here on Nov. 25 for an economic conference, they will stay in new luxury villas built on the site of ammunition bunkers at what was once one of America's main overseas military bases.
They will discuss international trade at a converted officers' club with a balcony that looks out over a vast tax-free port and industrial complex that has quickly become a model for the conversion of a military base to civilian uses. 
 "It is a coming-out party of the Philippines, not only for Manila and Subic but for the entire country," President Fidel V. Ramos said as he toured the former base before the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting opened on Wednesday.
The rapid conversion of Subic Bay Naval Station and nearby Clark Air Base over the last four years since the Americans were booted out has emerged as a symbol for the country's economic success under President Ramos, a sign that Filipinos, somewhat to their own surprise, can make it without the Americans.
While much of the region is suffering through an economic slowdown, the Philippine economy is picking up steam, growing by more than 7 percent a year. Inflation has dropped to 4.4 percent, exports are growing, and the budget is in surplus for a third consecutive year.
Richard Gordon, chairman of the Subic Bay Metropolitan Authority, which administers the port, said officials from around Europe and Asia had visited to study his model of base conversion, including the leaders of Panama, Vietnam and Lithuania and representatives from Guam and Okinawa, in Japan.
In an interview, Mr. Gordon seemed as astonished as anyone at his success; he is the grandson of an American serviceman and had been one of the foremost lobbyists for retention of the bases, arguing that few preparations had been made for their conversion.
Despite lobbying by him and by former President Corazon C. Aquino, the Philippine Senate, fired by a wave of nationalism, voted in 1991 not to extend the lease of the bases. It ended an American military presence in the Philippines that began with the withdrawal of the Spanish in 1898.
When the American flag was lowered at Subic on Nov. 24, 1992, predictions of economic ruin were almost universal. The American Secretary of Defense, Dick Cheney, predicted that closing the bases would be "a real tragedy for the Philippines."
Together, the bases were the nation's second-largest employer, after the Government itself, directly employing more than 68,000 Filipinos and contributing about $28 million a day to the local economy.
When they pulled out of Subic, the Americans left behind $8 billion in infrastructure, but took with them almost everything portable, including dozens of bowling lanes, the communications system and, most important, the floating dry docks that could have boosted Subic's hopes to be a ship repair center for the region.
"A lot of people were apprehensive," said Ferdinand Roaquin, a local resident who now works in Mr. Gordon's office. "We grew up with the Americans. My mother was a little bit tear-jerk when they left."
Predictions of disaster seemed at first to be confirmed when looters stripped the Clark base of everything from light fixtures to toilet bowls when the Americans abandoned it in 1991 after it was buried in volcanic ash by the eruption of Mount Pinatubo.
But at Subic, Mr. Gordon enlisted 8,000 unpaid volunteers to guard the empty base and maintain its buildings, power plant and storage tanks until new tenants could be attracted.
With the region's economy growing then, it proved surprisingly easy to attract manufacturing and investment. Now, four years later, employment here has actually risen, Mr. Gordon said, with 55,000 people working in the Subic port alone, mostly in foreign-operated factories.
Some of those are former workers on the American base. Some other craftsmen on the base found similar work in Guam or elsewhere overseas. But many -- like the prostitutes in the now-darkened red-light district of the neighboring town of Olongapo -- dispersed throughout the Philippines in search of other work.
Today more than 200 companies have invested $1.6 billion in Subic, and 150 companies have put $257 million into Clark, according to official figures.
Here at Subic, Japanese and Taiwanese industrial parks manufacture a variety of products, from computer motherboards to armored personnel carriers. Their total exports have risen every year, to $263 million in the first 10 months of this year, Mr. Gordon said.
In its biggest coup, Subic has become the regional hub for Federal Express, which has taken over former military warehouses and now makes an average of 67 landings a night on a newly reinforced runway, ferrying everything from Timex watches to fresh tuna around Asia.
The base is also developing a tourist industry that is attracting planeloads of visitors on charters from Hong Kong and Taiwan to take advantage of its beach front and woodlands as well as the tennis courts, stables, skeet range and yacht club left behind by the Navy.
Nowhere does the Philippines look as shipshape as on this former naval base, where the lawns are as trim, the grounds as clean and and the traffic as orderly as they were under military command.
A secret of Mr. Gordon's success seems to be the almost military discipline he has imposed here. Security guards salute when he approaches and stand at attention to recite, at his command, a 12-point pledge of professionalism.
"It is the Lee Kuan Yew model," Randy David, a leading sociologist, said, comparing Mr. Gordon's methods to those of the autocratic leader of Singapore. "In fact, we call him jokingly Dick Kuan Yew, and he loves it. You won't see that kind of leadership elsewhere in the country -- thank God, if you ask me."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	 U.S. Warns of Terrorism
MANILA, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The United States today warned of "possible threats" at an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum where President Clinton and other leaders are arriving this weekend.
"The U.S. Embassy in Manila has received information about possible threats to American diplomats in the Philippines during this conference," the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said in Manila. He refused to elaborate, and a Philippine official denied it.
Since Wednesday, the authorities have found two bombs in Manila, killed two rebels outside the capital and fought to hold back protesters.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 31; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1117 words

HEADLINE: Fearing a Rate Rise, Shippers Await 2d Front In Rail Merger

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Susann D. Felton was in the midst of negotiating railroad contracts last month to handle six million tons of coal a year for the Potomac Electric Power Company when the CSX Corporation disclosed an agreement to buy Conrail.
Ms. Felton, vice president for materials at Potomac Electric, said she felt a sense of dread that only grew after CSX's rival, the Norfolk Southern Corporation, began its own hostile offer for Conrail, setting off a bidding war that continues to this day. No matter who wins the battle, Potomac Electric, which receives supplies for its four coal-fired power plants from all three of the rail carriers involved in the battle, is likely to end up entirely dependent on a single railroad for three of the generators. That will not leave Ms. Felton with a lot of negotiating room. 
 "Was I thrilled?" she said. "No."
She added that any shipper could count on paying at least a 60 percent premium on captive routes above what it costs where competition exists. And then there is the worry that service may deteriorate as the merged railroad struggles to cut costs.
Now on the sidelines, rail users all along the East Coast are waiting for the opening of a second front in the battle for Conrail: The winning bidder must take the proposed merger before the Federal Surface Transportation Board for public review and regulatory approval. Shippers, port operators and state officials hope to be more successful in keeping their options open than they were in their unsuccessful opposition to the giant mergers in the West, where the Union Pacific combined with the Southern Pacific and Burlington Northern swallowed the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe to together control 90 percent of all rail traffic.
Indeed, they have a better chance of extracting at least some concessions this time, in part because the merger is taking place in the East, where the political spotlight is brighter, and because it revolves around Conrail, the Government-subsidized amalgamation of several bankrupt railroads. The Consolidated Rail Corporation has a near monopoly on rail freight in the Northeast, especially in the Port of New York, the richest market in the nation.
Still, opponents of a merger are fighting an uphill battle. The number of major railroads has already dropped to 10 from the 40 that existed in 1980 when the industry was deregulated. Most analysts believe that when the dust finally settles there will only be two or three transcontinental railroads.
"We have a greater interest in this merger than we had in Union Pacific," said Representative Bud Shuster, a Pennsylvania Republican who is chairman of the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure. "Conrail is a creature of Congress and the American taxpayers put over $7 billion into it, so we have a responsibility going forward. And as consolidation occurs in the rail industry, we have a greater public policy interest in preserving competition than we did with the U.P."
Mr. Shuster is also out to protect his constituents. He expressed concern about the impact of a merger on railroad workers in his rural Pennsylvania district, where Conrail has a locomotive and car repair shop.
CSX recently acquired 19.9 percent of Conrail stock as the first step in its friendly $8.5 billion takeover of Conrail. The company, however, needs shareholder approval in December to take the next step in the process and Norfolk Southern is dangling an attractive lure in front of shareholders: $10 billion cash. Whoever wins, the three-member transportation board would then have the power to require the transfer of track rights or asset sales as a condition of approving the deal.
So far, the consolidation of the industry appears to have done more good than harm. The industry has increased its share of overall freight traffic and, adjusted for inflation, managed to cut rates in half since 1980.
Shippers concede that freight rates have gone down over all. But with the dwindling number of railroads, there are many more routes today that are served by a single railroad. And some shippers, especially those moving bulk commodities, often cannot turn to a trucker or a barge company if rail rates soar. Privately, shippers and port operators angrily talk of a railroad extracting contracts on competitive routes by threatening to raise prices on captive lines.
Moreover, said Ed Emmett, president of the National Industrial Transportation League, an alliance of 1,000 large freight users, the decline in rates appears to be over. Shippers are "afraid that after the mega-mergers it'll go from a steady climb to a skyrocketing climb," Mr. Emmett said. "They view the situation today as possibly just as dire as it was at the turn of the century."
A merger of Conrail and CSX would leave a single railroad in control at 64 cities in the East where competition now exists. A Norfolk takeover would affect 38 of these cities.
But this merger is about more than the couple of dozen cities that weigh in the balance; it is about market dominance in the East. The Association of American Railroads says a CSX-Conrail combination would control 65 percent of the rail traffic originating in the East, leaving Norfolk with less than a third. If Norfolk wins, it would control about 50 percent of the market and CSX about 45 percent.
The ultimate prize, though, is the market that serves New York City and northern New Jersey. David R. Goode, chairman of Norfolk Southern, has proposed to end Conrail's stranglehold on the Port of New York, a suggestion vehemently opposed by Conrail and CSX.
"This is the last chance for competitive rail service in the Northeast," Mr. Goode argued. "Now that Conrail is on the block, it is bad public policy to preserve a monopoly in New York and it is unrealistic of CSX and Conrail to think they can."
But Conrail's chairman, David M. LeVan, while conceding that regulators are likely to insist that the merged railroad take steps to "preserve" competition in cities currently served by two railroads, said he saw no duty to "enhance" competition in New York and other Northeastern cities. Besides, he said, Conrail has to compete with truckers. "Our numbers show that trucks carry 80 to 88 percent of the imports and exports coming through the Port of New York," he said. "So there's plenty of competition."
In the end, said Anthony Hatch, an analyst with NatWest Securities, the battle for Conrail may well open up competition in some cities that have long been rail monopolies. "We'll see a more equitable split of the market in the Northeast," he said. "Anything else would create an uproar among shippers, the rest of the rail industry, unions and politicians."

HEADLINE: Our Cures for the Drug Problem Make It Worse

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A. M Rosenthal has attacked me repeatedly as a drug legalizer (columns, Nov. 15, Nov. 8 and Oct. 22). I am not for legalization but for a saner drug policy.
Some form of addiction or substance abuse is endemic to all societies. The way they deal with it has considerable bearing on how healthy they are. A drug-free America is unattainable. We should aim at minimizing the ills connected with drugs. 
 Our policy of treating drug abuse as a crime exacerbates the problem. The adverse effects of our policy are more severe than the adverse effects of addiction. Our policies have increased drug-related disease, death and crime, and incarcerated hundreds of thousands of Americans.
Focusing resources on interdiction ignores basic economics. As long as profits are so high, there is no way to cut off supply. The profits provide ample resources for generating additional demand by drug pushing.
There are no final solutions to our drug problems, but we do know at least some of the steps we should be taking now: making methadone and sterile syringes readily available to addicts; removing criminal prohibitions on the ability of doctors and patients to treat pain with whatever medications work; saving jail and prison cells for violent criminals and predatory drug dealers (not nonviolent addicts willing to undergo treatment), and exploring new means of reducing the harm done by drug use and our prohibitionist policies.
Above all, we need a free and open debate on all alternatives to current drug policies.
 
GEORGE SOROS
New York, Nov. 21, 1996

HEADLINE: Some Changes In Stock Rules To Be Delayed

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Securities and Exchange Commission agreed yesterday to delay by a few months some parts of its new order-handling rules that are aimed at revamping the Nasdaq stock market. But it did not change any major parts of the rules.
The rules, which are to be phased in starting Jan. 10, are intended to make it easier for investors to get better prices on trades. Although the rules are aimed primarily at Nasdaq, they apply to all markets. 
 The rules call for quotes in so-called electronic markets, like Instinet, to be posted on Nasdaq if those quotes are better than the ones available on Nasdaq; the S.E.C. did not change that provision.
But while the original order called for trading in the 1,000 most active Nasdaq stocks to be subject to the new rules on Jan. 10, the revision cuts that figure to 50 stocks, with 100 to be added Jan. 31 and the other 850 on Feb. 21. The phasing-in of the other Nasdaq stocks will not be affected.
Major stock markets have minimum quote increments, usually of one-eighth of a dollar, or 12.5 cents, for most stocks. But some electronic exchanges do not have such limits. So it is possible that Instinet, say, might have a bid on a stock of $25.0625, or one-sixteenth of a dollar more than the $25 bid on Nasdaq.
Current quote machines cannot display such small increments, so there would be no way to know that there was a better bid. The S.E.C. therefore required that the machines add an asterisk to the price, showing it as $25*, as an indication that a better price was available. The industry said programming for that would take many months, and the S.E.C. agreed yesterday to delay that provision until July 31.
A committee of the Intermarket Trading System, whose members include the major stock exchanges, had asked that the asterisk be deleted. The chairman of the panel, Allan H. Bretzer, said last night that he had not seen the S.E.C. decision, but added that "if the asterisk is staying in, we're going to have a problem."
The other delay that was granted concerned the display of limit orders. Under the rules, if an investor enters a limit order -- an order to buy or sell at a specified price -- and that price is better than what is in the market, the market maker who receives the order must either fill it or post that order for all to see within 30 seconds.
For example, if the best bid for a stock is $20, and an investor puts in an order to buy at $20.125, that would become the best bid if it were not filled immediately. The S.E.C. had said that such limit orders would have to be displayed starting on Jan. 10, but yesterday it delayed that until April 10.
"By setting a tight date, we pushed people to work very hard" on programming for the changes, said Richard Lindsey, the S.E.C.'s director of market regulation. "They have been, but they need a little more time."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 3, 1996, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Nov. 23 about new rules aimed at the Nasdaq stock market referred incorrectly to a rule that a limit order -- an order to buy or sell shares at a specified price -- must be disclosed immediately when its price is better than the market price. The Securities and Exchange Commission did not delay the rule. But it did say that until April 10 it would not enforce a part of the rule requiring disclosure of the limit order within 30 seconds.
A front-page article on Sunday about Wall Street strategies for minimizing capital gains tax liability misspelled the surname of a financial adviser who was quoted on the strategy of selling a business to an employee stock ownership plan. He is Francois de Visscher, not de Vissher.

GRAPHIC: Photos/Charts: "An Escape For Business Owners"
Owners of private business can avoid the capital gains tax by selling the company to their employees, as long as they put the proceeds in certain investments, like ESOP notes, that Wall Street is eager to provide. "Economically, it a fabulous transaction," said Francois de Vissher, a financial adviser and investment banker.

But now that play is also giving the owners, including Philip Inglis, left, and Don Cummings, a way to cash out without paying capital gains taxes. (Laura Pedrick for the New York Times)

An investment partnership including former Treasury Secretary William E. Simon sold the Avis car-rental agency and other companies to their employees, allowing the partners to avoid capital gains taxes. (pg. 44)
 
"An Escape For Big Stockholders"
Investors with large blocks of stock in a company can use one of several exotic strategies to lock in profits on that stock and raise cash for other kinds of investments without actually selling the shares, which would create a tax bill.

Mr. Broad used some of his stock in SunAmerica as unofficial collateral for a new form of security issued by Merrill Lynch, which then passed much of the proceeds from that issue back to Mr. Broad. (Mojdan B. Azimi for The New York Times)
 
A. LORNE WEIL
Autotote
Mr. Weil "swapped" shares in his company, Autotote, to Bankers Trust in return for the income he could have earned on a less risky investment.
 
RONALD LAUDER
Estee Lauder
Instead of selling shares in the family business directly to the public, Mr. Lauder and his mother borrowed an identical number of shares and sold them, avoiding as much as $95 million in Federal capital gains taxes alone.
 
"An Escape For Property Owners"
Real estate owners can sway properties without incurring the capital gains tax required when a sale is made. This allows them to diversify their holdings and raise cash for other purposes.
