(Julio Ibarra for The New York Times) (pg. 45)
 
Graphs: "No Longer Just A Bill for the Rich"
For many middle-income taxpayers, the only source of capital gains is profits on mutual funds. Lately, those taxpayers' gains have shot up, while gains reported by the typically wealthier taxpayers who profited from all kinds of assets stagnated. (Source: I.R.S.) (pg. 1)
 
"Where Gains Come From...And Who Get Them" show sources of capital gains reported by individuals and their income categories, 1993. (Sources: Congressional Budget Office; Internal Revenue Service)
 
"One Wall Street Way To Reinvest Tax-Free" shows total amount of ESOP notes outstanding, 1987-1995. (Source: Securities Data Company) (pg. 44)
 
"Squeezing Cash From Equities" shows new issuance of DECS (debt exchangeable into common stock) securites, 1993-96. (Source: Salomon Brothers)
 
"An Umbrella to Shelter Property Profits" shows the total market value of upreits (umbrella partnership real estate investment trust), 1992-96. (Source: National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts) (pg. 45)
Here's how the Western Southern deal worked: Salomon Brothers sold notes to the public and made most of the proceeds available to its client, Western Southern, through a private transaction "whose terms mirror the terms of the DECS sold to the public," said Anand S. Iyer, director of global convertible product analysis at Salomon. Each note sold for roughly the same price as one share of Cincinnati Bell. The notes pay a fixed rate of interest and give the noteholder a share of any future increase in the stock price. If the stock price falls, the noteholder bears all of the loss, which will be reflected in a lower resale price of the note.
When the notes mature, Western Southern can repay its obligation to Salomon with cash or with its Cincinnati Bell stock, either of which Salomon can use to cover what it owes to noteholders. If it pays in cash, no taxes will be owed, because legal ownership of the shares will have remained with Western Southern. In the meantime, it had the use of most of the cash raised from the note sale, free of capital gains taxes.
Because they offer a cheap way to borrow that does not worry credit-rating agencies, most exchangeable-note deals in the last three years have been done on behalf of corporate taxpayers, including Times Mirror and American Express.
But Eli Broad's deal last June marked the first public use of this remarkable product by an individual taxpayer. The deal, tailored like the Western Southern deal, locked in Mr. Broad's profit on a block of SunAmerica stock worth roughly $194 million, just as if he had sold the shares. Although he had shed any risk of loss, Mr. Broad kept the right to any further gains after the stock price had risen 35 percent, and he did not hand over legal title to his shares. Thus, he owed no capital gains taxes.
Mr. Broad's innovative deal has tax lawyers talking. "Actually, I'm looking at a bunch of those products now," said Steven M. Surdell, a partner in the Chicago firm of Jenner & Block. "I have a client who is an Eli Broad kind of guy, and an investment bank has given him a brochure about doing this."
 
The Debate
 
Competing Proposals For a Better System
Wall Street's willingness to cater to wealthy, tax-averse clients is as old as the capital gains tax itself, but the infrastructure that supports the creation of these high-technology strategies is much newer.
The equity swap borrows heavily from the mathematics developed by global bankers in the creation of "interest rate swaps" barely a decade ago. As active markets have developed for these and other esoteric instruments, commonly called derivatives, Wall Street has been able to use those markets to measure and hedge the risks of doing these transactions for wealthy clients. All this is the daily routine of squadrons of so-called rocket scientists -- the mathematicians and software engineers Wall Street has recruited from academia in recent years to find new ways to harness the potential of new software and new markets.
Taken together, these changes allow Wall Street to separate the various attributes that once were knotted into a single security. A security that fluctuates in price but pays a steady dividend can be cut into a fluctuating-price slice and a steady-dividend slice; a bond that pays principal and interest can be cleaved into a principal-paying chunk and an interest-paying chunk. And a stock that has both economic value and voting rights can be teased apart, so that the voting rights stay with the legal owner while the economic benefits flow to others.
"In a world where the distinctions between financial instruments are blurred, or where different instruments are combined in new ways, the practitioners of financial engineering will always be a step -- or, more likely, a mile -- ahead of the regulators," said Mr. Gale, the Brookings economist. "Because of all these instruments that are becoming available, the effective capital gains tax rate is fairly low among the very high-income groups."
Some critics say that Wall Street's ingenuity proves the case for scrapping the tax or at least modifying it. Under the current system, "if you're rich enough, you can hire the entrepreneurial accountant or the entrepreneurial guy at Salomon Brothers who thinks these things up," said Theodore Forstmann, chairman of Forstmann Little & Company and a member of the National Commission on Economic Growth and Tax Reform, commissioned by Republican Congressional leaders to recommend ways to overhaul the tax system. "What I would like is a system that put these guys out of business." At a minimum, he said, the Government should tax only inflation-adjusted profits.
The political debate about the capital gains tax has been devoted mostly to arguments over whether capital gains should be taxed at all, and, if so, how much. Privately, some who believe that capital gains taxes stifle the economy by reducing incentives for entrepreneurs suggest that the country may benefit from techniques that allow such people to escape taxation.
Until the Clinton proposals were introduced early this year, little attention had been paid to whether the existing tax could be levied more fairly.
The Administration's proposals do aim to make it harder for wealthy taxpayers to avoid capital gains taxes, although some less affluent investors would be affected as well. "I think it is clear there are things that are permissible now that should not be," said Lawrence H. Summers, Deputy Treasury Secretary. "What are functionally capital gains realizations should be taxed."
Specifically, the Administration has proposed eliminating the rule that allows investors to identify which specific shares of stock are being sold in each transaction, one of the rules that helps middle-income investors save on capital gains taxes. Using this rule, an investor who paid escalating prices for a company's stock over time can specify that only the most expensive shares were sold, which reduces the capital gain subject to taxation. The new rule would require investors who sold their entire stake in a company to use their average cost; if they sold only part of their stake, they would be deemed to have sold the first shares they had bought.
The Administration has also proposed defining as a taxable sale any transaction that "substantially eliminates risk of loss and opportunity for gain" on the underlying security. This rule would eliminate the short against the box and at least some equity swaps, but its impact is uncertain because it does not specify how much risk and opportunity must be retained by an investor to avoid making a sale.
The Treasury estimates that these two proposals would raise $4.5 billion in new revenues over the next five years; Congressional estimates are half that amount.
But many tax experts say the Clinton proposals give Wall Street a lot of wiggle room. Transactions like the one used by Mr. Broad are expected to survive, and the tax breaks for ESOP sales, upreits and the traditional real estate swaps are not even on the policy makers' radar. "And, undoubtedly, Wall Street will soon come up with something new," said Mr. Willens, the Lehman Brothers executive.
Treasury officials acknowledge that the current proposals would be challenging to enforce and might not curb Wall Street's latest techniques. The proposals are a good start, Mr. Summers said, but "the lines are difficult to draw between hedging and transferring ownership." He added, "That's why the area has such complexity."
Mr. Willens of Lehman Brothers agreed that tougher, clearer definitions of a sale were probably the only way the Government could deal with the challenge of Wall Street's ingenuity. "Old-fashioned notions of sale are totally inappropriate for the world we live in today," he said. "You've got to look behind the niceties of language to the substance of what's happening. Have you surrendered the benefits and burdens of ownership? If the answer is yes, you have probably sold it and you should probably pay taxes."
In any case, the Administration's ideas face a tough fight in Congress, where the controlling Republicans say they are still firmly committed to lowering the capital gains rate for top-bracket taxpayers to 19.8 percent from 28 percent.
Administration advisers agree that the loophole-closing steps will probably be adopted only as part of a bipartisan compromise that also lowers the current tax rate and perhaps expands the tax break for selling homes.
 
The Beat Goes On
 
The Latest Techniques Draw a Big Crowd
Last Tuesday morning, more than 200 people jammed a banquet room at the Yale Club on Vanderbilt Avenue in Manhattan to hear specialists from Bankers Trust discuss the latest techniques for raising cash and diversifying assets without incurring capital gains taxes.
One increasingly popular approach with investors who own a lot of a single stock, said Steve Gordon of Bankers Trust, is borrowing against a hedged position -- sometimes called a zero-cost collar with debt attached. A big investor in the XYZ Corporation, for example, sets up a hedge that consists of two options contracts on XYZ stock. One protects him from a drop in the stock's price; the other lets him keep a bit of any price increase. Then Bankers Trust will lend him up to 90 percent of the value of those XYZ shares.
The bankers also reviewed equity swaps, shorts against the box and various other strategies. Although Congress might tinker with some of them next year, one speaker said, wealthy taxpayers still have "a wonderful window of opportunity" to use those techniques now.
Moreover, the bank offered other ideas -- "customized advanced techniques" -- that could be tailored to the needs of different clients. "If you want to stay state of the art," Mr. Gordon said, "you have to continually develop new products."
These strategies differ, the banker told the crowd, but each allows wealthy taxpayers to achieve that coveted objective: the deferral of capital gains taxes, optimally for as long as it takes to avoid those taxes entirely.
"You can have your cake," he said with a smile, "and eat it, too."
 
Christopher Drew participated in the preparation of this article, a continuation of a series that included articles on deferred compensation, which appeared on Oct. 13 and 14.

HEADLINE: RECORDING VIEW;
Orchestra Finds Means of Survival In Hard Times

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH 

 BODY:
UNDER OTHER circumstances, it might be tempting to castigate the Czech Philharmonic for unadventurous programming in its Avery Fisher Hall concert this afternoon. Along with Brahms's Violin Concerto, which has already had two high-profile performances in New York this season, comes predictable Bohemian fare: Dvorak's "New World" Symphony and "The Moldau" from Smetana's "My Country."
As it is, however, one is relieved to see the orchestra, long one of the world's finest, alive and presumably well. Indeed, to judge by reports from Prague, the Czech Philharmonic has been engaged in something of a death struggle since its last New York appearance, in 1990, bent on surviving if only to celebrate its 100th anniversary this year. 
 The orchestra gave its first concert as a symphonic adjunct of the National Theater in 1896, led by Antonin Dvorak on his return from America. Having safely negotiated difficult shoals over nine decades, it was brutally buffeted by the rising expectations and falling subsidies stemming from the Velvet Revolution of 1989, Czechoslovakia's return to a free-market economy and the foundation of the Czech Republic in 1993.
Confusion vied with dissension as the newly independent orchestra shunned its estimable music director Jiri Belohlavek, in 1991, in favor of a German, Gerd Albrecht, and found itself leaderless for almost two years. Many players thought that the switch would position the orchestra better internationally for tours and recordings.
Well, here the Philharmonic is, led by yet another principal conductor, Vladimir Valek, who was hired after Mr. Albrecht's departure last season, and facing an international classical-record industry in meltdown. But the former Czechoslovak state label, Supraphon, itself independent since 1992, has remained faithful for its part, celebrating the orchestra's centenary with a release of 100 CD's, encompassing many of its greatest recordings.
It is a fascinating list, heavy, of course, in the usual Bohemian and Czechoslovak suspects, but with outposts of Germanic, French, Russian and Hungarian repertory. The conductors include most of the orchestra's music directors of long standing -- Vaclav Talich, who led it almost continuously from 1919 to 1941; Karel Ancerl, who was principal conductor from 1950 to 1969, and Vaclav Neumann, who followed until 1990 -- as well as shorter-term eminences like Rafael Kubelik, Karel Sejna and Mr. Belohlavek.
Perhaps the most remarkable strain in the list is a sprinkling of no fewer than seven versions of "My Country" ("Ma Vlast"), Smetana's great nationalist epic, led by Sejna (1950), Talich (1954), Ancerl (1963), Neumann (1975), Vaclav Smetacek (1980), Belohlavek (1990) and Kubelik (1990). As a record of a continuing love affair between orchestra and work, the series is exhilarating and treasurable. As a veritable case study in the hard times that have befallen record companies (or, rather, that the companies have brought upon themselves), it is mildly depressing.
These were mostly years in which major conductors could blithely renew the warhorses, confident that buyers were ready to replace earlier versions, inevitably dimming on badly worn vinyl. But the digital compact disk, the ultimate mixed blessing, has changed all that, making permanently available the successive generations of performances, often in excellent sound. Ever more impressive reissues tumble over reissues.
Any buyer stocked with two or three of those Supraphon versions might reasonably overlook whatever new account of "My Country" may appear. For that matter, even other splendid reissues, like Kubelik's classic 1952 Chicago Symphony recording of the work, newly available on a Mercury Living Presence CD, can barely make their way through the throng.
The indispensable classic among the Supraphon versions is the Talich (11 1896-2). The old master's conception is wonderfully warm and wise. To cite just one of its many glories, the muted strings in the moonlight section of "The Moldau" give the river of the title a lovely reflective surface. (Just listen for moonbeams shimmering on water; you can't miss it in this version.) Although the recording is monaural, the performance springs to vivid life on CD.
The few years that separate it from the Sejna (11 1913-2) are crucial in terms of sound. This is another attractive performance, but the recording, taken from 78's, lacks depth; in relation to prominent strings, the winds sound recessed and pinched. Similarly, the Ancerl (11 1925-2), a slightly stiffer performance to begin with, suffers further from hard, glassy sound.
For the rest, sound is not a particular issue. The Neumann performance (11 1958-2), however, is stately, verging on stodgy.
The Kubelik recording (11 1910-2), his fifth of the work, was made live at the Prague Spring Festival in 1990, on the conductor's triumphant return after 41 years in self-imposed exile. It is easily recommendable to those who find Kubelik's marked tempo contrasts within movements and his insistent emphases less disruptive than I do. For me, the modern alternative to Talich would be Smetacek (11 1981-2), for a crisp, powerful statement, or Belohlavek (11 1986-2), for a more expansive account with good clarity in both performance and recording.
As for the orchestra at the center of all this activity, what emerges time after time is individuality. If you listened only to recordings by the great American orchestras, which prize smoothness, blend and seamless interchange, you might never know that the sinuous flute line at the start of "The Moldau" is produced by two overlapping instruments. The Czech players make no attempt to conceal the fact. Their rule seems to require instead that each player put as much character into the sound as possible; if it makes the overall fabric more diverse, so much the better.
The strings, though lean and incisive, provide plushness and warmth as appropriate when they are well recorded. Especially in the Smetacek, the brasses swagger in patented East European style. With due allowance for changing technology, the woodwinds in the Belohlavek recording retain some of the same penetrating warble of the Sejna.
Here's hoping that the qualities that stood up so well through the four decades of these recordings have survived the trauma of the last five years.

HEADLINE: Cutting Lumber In Private Forests

BYLINE: By SAM LIBBY 

 BODY:
THE state's long-dormant lumber industry is back, changing the nature of privately owned forests and raising questions about the effect on the native forest as a whole.
Private landowners are profiting from tax-abated properties by allowing lumber companies to harvest on land that often has gone untouched for decades. The harvest is primarily the oak that is the state tree and an important source of food for the forest's wildlife. 
 As a result, some scientists say, there will be dramatic changes in the ecology of Connecticut forests. Most foresters argue that controlled lumbering poses no threat to the environment, but others are wary indeed of the changes taking place.
Connecticut's lumbering industry grew by more than 25 percent between 1990 and 1993, according to a recent industry survey, pushed on by rising wood prices. Red oak, the mainstay of the state's timber industry, now fetches about $250 per thousand board feet, and can reach $425 for high quality veneer, according to industry publications. A single well-proportioned oak tree could be worth hundreds of dollars to a landowner.
"For the first time, Connecticut forest landowners are in the position to make a little return on their land, and put that back into forest management activities," said George Stephens, a forestry scientist at the State Agricultural Experiment Station in New Haven.
"Some people think that clear cutting is just a terrible thing," Mr. Stephens continued. "But if your goal is to get the maximum number of oak on a property, you are essentially forced into it."
When Europeans first arrived in Connecticut, the forest had many more beech, maple and hemlock trees than today, said Jeff Ward, an assistant forestry scientist at the Agricultural Experiment Station. By the 1840's, most of the land had been clear cut for agriculture. As the West was opened to settlement, crop and pasture land was abandoned and second-growth forests quickly appeared, but dairy farmers set fires in them to keep land open for grazing.
Oak trees were best suited to take root under these conditions. Their thick, tough bark, offered protection from fires and their acorns quickly germinated, taking hold on scorched, cleared land, said Mr. Ward.
Oaks, now 45 percent of the state's forests by some estimates, have become an important component of the ecology. Acorns, for example, are an important food source for deer, squirrels, white-footed mice and many other wild animals, he said. But since 1907, forest fires have been suppressed in Connecticut, and as a result oak trees began to decline. Lumbering is now accelerating that decline, Mr. Ward said.
Lumbering increased from less than 55 million board feet per year during the 1980's to about 70 million board feet in 1993, according to a marketing survey of loggers and sawmill operators conducted every three years by the Department of Environmental Protection's forestry division.
The state's resurgent lumber industry depends on the sale of trees by thousands of small landowners. About 60 percent of Connecticut is forested, and 90 percent of that land is in private hands.
Since the state's real estate market crashed in the late 1980's thousands of acres of woodlands have been placed under municipal tax abatement, meant to ease pressure on landowners to develop their properties. Public Act 490, which allows for a dramatically lower assessment and tax, places only minor restrictions on commercial logging.
Now logging companies are looking up the names of those whose land is listed under Public Act 490 and offering to buy their timber.
The tragedy, according to Robert Perschel, regional director for the Northeast of the Wilderness Society, is that the forest never reaches its full potential, either economically or recreationally. Much of the selective cutting is "high-grading" -- clearing all the big trees and leaving the small ones standing.
"It has impacts that we're not even aware of," Mr. Perschel said. "We haven't done the studies to understand the connection between harvesting trees and the effects on all forms of wildlife and wildlife habitat. We have to be cautious, we have to be careful, we have to be conservative with what we do."
In order to encourage the growth of diverse plant and animal habitats, the current trend in forestry is not to automatically shun clear cutting. In fact, the only way to get good oak regeneration is clear cutting, or at least very heavy cutting, Mr. Stephens said, to provide the best conditions for the germination of acorns.
Having a management plan for a forest is similar to having a plan for a garden, said Mr. Ward. It's possible to cut heavily and still maintain a healthy productive forest., he said.
A possible problem is that only one in six timber operations is overseen by a forester, said Stephen Broderick, a forester with the University of Connecticut Cooperative Extension Service.
"A lot of timber buyers take the attitude that, 'If I don't log this lot, the next guy will,' " Mr. Broderick said. And sometimes owners will liquidate forest land for quick cash, without regard to the consequences. "It remains a problem," Mr. Broderick said, "and I think education of the landowners themselves is a big part of the answer."
The state is also working on stricter regulations. This year the Department of Environmental Protection started mandatory certification for all foresters and loggers under the 1991 Connecticut Forest Practices Act. The hope is to prevent unskilled operators from removing too many trees from a property and causing erosion, said a state forester, Donald Smith.
The regulations require foresters and loggers to file annual reports with the state, providing, it is hoped, the first really accurate gauge of the amount of wood harvested.
Future regulations will almost certainly include mandating forest professionals use "best management practices," state-endorsed guidelines that prevent erosion from logging roads during cutting operations, said David Smith, a professor emeritus at the Yale School of Forestry and advisor to the state forester.
Because humans have controlled nature in this region for centuries, the virgin wilderness is gone, said Karl Wagener, director of the state's Council on Environmental Quality.
But scientists are just beginning to understand the ecology of the state's oak-dominated forests.
For example, bumper crops of acorns appear every three to four years, allowing a boom in the populations of white-footed mice and white-tailed deer, two very important hosts of the ticks and pathogens that cause tick-borne illnesses like Lyme disease, according to an article in the May issue of Bioscience. Because of a recent bumper crop some scientists are anticipating a substantial rise in tick-borne diseases this year.
But white-footed mice, because they eat gypsy moth cocoons, have been an important factor in suppressing gypsy moth infestations and massive defoliation of forests.
Because the large white-tailed mouse population is expected to begin crashing as soon as next year as the local acorn supply shrinks, some scientists are predicting a gypsy moth infestation and defoliation of local forests starting around 1999.

HEADLINE: Changing Patterns of Commuting

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
IN the spring, employees of the Philip Morris Capital Corporation will be transferred to Stamford from the Westchester County offices of Philip Morris International. That's to make room for Kraft Food International, another Philip Morris subsidiary, which is leaving White Plains for the Rye Brook location, explained K. Richmond Temple, a spokesman for Philip Morris Capital.
With the Kraft move, "Space became a premium in Rye Brook, which necessitated our looking at which groups could be easily moved, intact, out of that office," Mr. Temple said. "Philip Morris Capital Corporation was one that could, so we looked at appropriate space in the area and settled on Stamford." 
 So how will Philip Morris Capital's 150 employees handle the move? If they are like a growing number of New York residents, they will commute to Connecticut.
For years Fairfield County has been a bedroom community for New York, but there is an increasing flow of traffic in the opposite direction, officials say. From 1989 to 1995, reverse commuter traffic on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad grew 89 percent. "Those numbers were a little surprising," said Janine Johnson, a spokeswoman for the Fairfield County Information Exchange. "Everyone had the sense that people go from Fairfield County to New York, not the reverse."
Transportation officials see the trend as one way to help pay for some of the improvements underway in the county, such as a $100 million center- island platform at the Stamford train station that is designed to double its capacity. If there are fewer empty seats on return trips in the morning and evening, that means more money coming in.
"It's like the airline industry -- we have available seating, and we would love to fill it," said Charles Zabielski, a spokesman for Metro-North. "When you have traffic on the return trips, the revenue falls right to the bottom line." Even more surprising to many is the 121 percent increase in traffic between stops on the commuter rail line: people getting on in Norwalk and off in Bridgeport, for example, a commute that has tripled in ridership over the six-year period.
"The type of intermediate, or intrastate, ridership that Connecticut is experiencing is highly unusual," Mr. Zabielski said. "Typically, metropolitan riders start at one remote location, and don't get off until they've arrived in their major-city destination."
State officials say there are more than $1.3 billion in transportation projects underway in southwestern Connecticut to cope with increased traffic. "None of the work is specifically geared toward reverse commuting, but that doesn't mean that reverse commuting isn't helped by all of the projects," said Harry Harris, deputy commissioner of the State Department of Transportation. "You can't build a highway for commuters going one direction in the morning without building a highway of equal size for them to come home on at night, which creates an infrastructure for people commuting in the opposite direction as well".
"Clearly, reverse commuters are one of the two markets we are most interested in serving, the other being intrastate commuting," Mr. Harris said. That's the case in Danbury, which recently dedicated a new $4 million train station. While there is not a lot of reverse commuting into the city yet, officials hope that making it easier to get there in the morning, and home at night, will encourage economic growth.
"It's there to accommodate existing traffic that's heading south of Danbury," said John Schweitzer, city engineer and director of public works in Danbury. "But we also want to encourage people to use it to come here."
Ms. Johnson said reverse commuting is an outgrowth of the economic boom that Fairfield County is enjoying. Between 1995 and 1996, the number of Fortune 1000 companies in the region increased from 29 to 33, and Entrepreneur Magazine ranked it one of the top 30 areas for small business, she noted.
The strongest measure of commuter traffic is the sale of monthly passes. In 1989 Metro-North sold an average of 228 passes a month for commuters traveling from New York to Connecticut. That increased steadily through the study period, to 431 a month last year. Passes in the other direction still make up the bulk of the sales, but showed a smaller increase, 14 percent over the six years, from 16,726 to 19,114.
Intrastate passes in Connecticut were up 121 percent, from 825 a month in 1989 to 1,823 in 1995. Sales were up 100 percent or more on more than a dozen routes, with Stamford one of the most popular destinations: sales of Stratford-to-Stamford passes tripled, to 214 per month, and Milford-to-Stamford passes nearly doubled, from 132 to 258 per month.
Ms. Johnson said the Information Exchange chose to study the six-year period of 1989 to 1995 because mass transit typically suffers during a recession, which Connecticut endured during that period. The increases, therefore, were even more surprising. "There's been a great deal of interest in these numbers, but they raise as many questions as they answer," Ms. Johnson said. For instance, why are people choosing to commute, rather than move closer to their jobs?
She said many people are either following jobs, like Swiss Bank employees who had their office moved from Manhattan to Stamford. Others are looking for new jobs, like the thousands of IBM employees laid off in White Plains, N.Y., over the last few years, many of them now working at high-technology companies in Fairfield County, just 20 minutes away. For many, the commute does not make it worth moving.
"It's a personal decision," Ms. Johnson said. "People who have established themselves in a community are usually not eager to pick up their families and move."
The majority of Metro-North riders in both directions are in the 35 to 54 age range, which means they probably have children as well as a home, and it would be difficult to move.
"Certainly, people will go where they have to go to keep their jobs," Ms. Johnson said. "But maybe they want to hold onto their homes for a while to see how their new career is going to go, whether the company is going to stay in business, whether they like the area, and so forth."
It is not just rail lines seeing an increase in reverse commuting. Michael A. Sanders, administrator of transit and ride sharing for the Connecticut Department of Transportation, said that when his office started a Stamford-White Plains bus route recently, his office was surprised to see so many of the Stamford-bound buses filling up in the morning and White Plains-bound buses at night.
"We actually have close to even ridership in both directions," Mr. Sanders said. Of about 200 trips a day since the service started in June, about 110 are commuters originating in Stamford, and the rest are commuting to Stamford.
Also encouraging, he said, is the number of people taking the train or another bus into Stamford and connecting with the White Plains bus. In the last survey in August, 31 percent of the riders on the new line walked to the bus stop, 36 percent took a bus, 20 percent arrived on Metro-North, and 8 percent drove or were dropped off at the station. (The remaining 5 percent did not answer the survey.)
Based on projections, he said, the department expects the Stamford-White Plains bus route to be breaking even by 1998, at which point the state could turn it over to a private operator.
Mr. Harris said the reverse commuting numbers demonstrate how improvements in the infrastructure can lead to improvements in the economy -- if you make it easy for people to get to a city, more businesses will tap into its labor pool. Connecticut's investment in railroad improvements has been more than $1 billion in the last 10 years, and the state is averaging $100 million a year now in public transportation projects. In all, about 45 percent of the D.O.T. budget is geared to public transportation, he said.
Ms. Johnson said the question for transportation planners is, how do we get people out of their cars?
"We need to assure them they can get home in an emergency, that their schedule can coincide with day care, that shuttles will take them from the station to work," Ms. Johnson said. "There are some important links that have to happen to see these increases continue."

GRAPHIC: Photos: In Stamford, reverse commuters leave an eastbound train while instrastate commuters board, and, top, Stamford-bound commuters getting on a shuttle bus to their office. (Photographs by Helen Neafsey for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: State Faces Loss of a Seat In Congress

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT is expected to lose one of its six Congressional seats when representation is reapportioned after the next census in 2000, and that prospect promises some bruising political battles to come.
Possession of the six seats had been shared equally by the Republicans and the Democrats for a dozen years, but in the election on Nov. 5, voters shifted their preference toward the Democrats, who now enjoy a 4 to 2 advantage. 
 But it is the Democrats' newly-won control of both houses in the General Assembly that may prove more advantageous in the future, several political leaders said, because there, and in the Governor's office, is where the battles over which party is more seriously wounded by the loss of a district will take place.
The battle will likely be fought over bread and butter issues like the economy, jobs and education in the next two elections, when the Governor and the legislators who have the power to approve new Congressional district lines will be elected.
Under the State Constitution, the General Assembly, to be elected in 2000, is charged with redrawing the state's Congressional and legislative districts. If the legislature cannot agree on a redistricting plan, the job goes to a nine-member commission.
In interviews following this month's election, officials from each major party blamed the other side for the potential loss of the Congressional seat, and argued why it is the other side who should lose if the state's delegation is reduced to five.
"I would underline the 'if', " added Edward L. Marcus, the Democratic Party's state chairman.
Indeed, nothing will happen until the next census in 2000 determines if the state's demographic forecasts are correct. Several other states in the northeast share Connecticut's prospects in those forecasts, augering a further drain of political power from the region. States in the South and the West will grow the most, according to the Census Bureau.
Massachusetts is expected to lose one of its 10 Congressional seats. New York and Pennsylvania are expected to each lose two, slipping to 29 and 19 respectively.
Connecticut's population has declined by more than 12,000 since 1990, according to Census Bureau estimates, and it is projected to rise only by about 9,000 from 1995 to 2000. That would be a net loss of 3,000 people for the decade in a total population about 3.1 million. The state's population would have fallen more except for large numbers of immigrants, mostly from Central and South America and Asia, who replaced thousands of residents who migrated to the Sun Belt in search of jobs.
Reapportionment of Congressional seats, required every 10 years by the Constitution, normally is hotly fought over by the major parties, because seats in Congress can be gained or lost for decades depending how the district lines are drawn. In 1990, all the parties had to do was maintain the status quo, each sharing three seats. The current 4 to 2 imbalance would be enough to spark a tougher battle by itself. Losing a district will make reapportionment all the more bitterly contested.
In addition to losing a vote in Congress, the loss of a House seat would have other ramifications. For example, the clout of the largest cities in each of the new districts would be diluted because each district would take in more suburban towns, which generally have gained population while most of the cities have lost it.
The state chairmen of the two major parties agreed that the state's poor economy was the cause of its decline in population. "People voted with their feet," said State Representative Chris DePino, the Republican leader.
But they disagreed over whose fault that was. Mr. DePino blamed the Democrats, contending that they were responsible for high taxes that hurt the economy and drove people and businesses away. Mr. Marcus, on the other hand, blamed Gov. John G. Rowland for not bringing more new businesses into the state.
"Right now, the underlying issue in the state of Connecticut is jobs," Mr. Marcus said. "Connecticut is seeing blue collar unemployment and white collar unemployment in this last recession."
He said that Connecticut is the last of the 50 states to recover from the economic slowdown of the early 1990's, and the highest in bankruptcy and foreclosure per capita. At the same time, it is the first or second in income per capita because of concentrated wealth in a few towns, notably in southwestern Fairfield County.
Another point of disagreement between the two party chairmen was how to make five districts out of six. One district must go.
Should it be the first, second, third or fifth, currently held by Democrats Barbara B. Kennelly, Sam Gejdenson, Rosa L. DeLauro and James H. Maloney, or should it be the fourth or sixth, held by Republicans Christopher Shays and Nancy L. Johnson?
Mr. DePino felt the Democrats should lose a seat, since they now hold four. It would be unfair to take one of the two Republican-held districts while the Democrats could lose one and still have more, he said.
Mr. Marcus, however, thought it made perfect sense for the Democrats to have four out of five seats. He noted that Mrs. Johnson, whose district had been considered solidly Republican and in no danger of losing, squeaked by on Nov. 5 narrowly winning by just over 1,500 votes.
By Mr. DePino's reckoning, the First District, large and centered around Hartford and its suburbs, is an unlikely target for dismemberment. The Second District, composed of 54 towns and covering nearly a third of the state, and the Sixth, with 44 towns in the northwestern quadrant of the state, are both too large. The Third and the Fourth are too densely populated.
That left the Fifth District as the most likely to be broken up and dissolved according to Mr. DePino's calculations. It is also the only district that shares borders with all the other five. The Fifth happens to be held by a Democrat, Mr. Maloney, who wrested it away from the Republican incumbent, Gary A. Franks, this month.
Mr. DePino said the Fifth might be divided up between the Third, Fourth and Sixth, "but that's purely speculation on my part," he added.
"It's very likely that Connecticut will go from six seats to five," Mr. Maloney acknowledged. But when told of Mr. DePino's speculation, he laughed and said, "Well, we'll see."
Mr. Maloney said that if the Democrats controlled the State Legislature after the election on Nov. 7, 2000, he did not believe they would do away with a Congressional district held by a Democrat.
Mr. Marcus supposed that the Third and Fourth Districts could be combined, causing the loss of a Republican district.
Mr. Shays, a Stamford resident, suggested that if his Fourth District is extended northward into the Fifth, Mr. Maloney, a resident of Danbury, and he might find themselves in the same district. "There's no member who is free of the possibility of having to run against an incumbent in another district," Mr. Shays said.
Actually, Connecticut gives the job of drawing new district lines do a bipartisan committee. It is routinely supervised by the courts as well. Nevertheless, the party that controls the state legislature can approve a plan of its liking and the party that elects the Governor can veto a plan it doesn't like.
Mr. Maloney, a former State Senator, said he expects that reapportionment and the impending loss of a seat will combine to enliven the gubernatorial race in 1998 and the General Assembly contests in 2000, which is also a Presidential election year.
It was not clear how redistricting would affect candidates' stands on issues though it could, for example, if an incumbent anticipated running in a district distinctly more urban or more rural than the old district.
Another way, Mr. Shays said, would be if membership in one of the political parties is so concentrated that that party's primary becomes the election. That could push a candidate farther to the right or left, he said.
Mr. Shays noted that this year's Presidential campaign highlighted differences over the Federal budget and welfare reform among Connecticut's Congressional delegation. The same will probably happen as the time nears to draw new district lines and eliminate a position.
Nevertheless, both parties tended to run toward the political center this year, Mr. Shays said. He said he did not foresee much change from that in the future.
Nor did Mr. Maloney, who noted that the trend among voters to register unaffiliated to a party is a moderating influence. "There are fewer solid Republican or Democratic districts," he said. "They are all competitive."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
The Dish On Dishes: Growth

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
IT took nearly eight years for the nation's retailers to sell the first one million color television sets, four years to sell the first million VCRs, and three years to sell the first million compact disk players. By contrast, according to statistics compiled by the Satellite Broadcasting & Communications Association, a trade association in Alexandria, Va., it took only one year, from mid-1994 to mid-1995, for retailers to sell the first million 18-inch digital satellite dishes, making the product one of the fastest-selling consumer electronic items in history.
And though satellite television systems have been of little use to residents in vertical environments like New York City -- the dishes need both a secure exterior perch and a direct line of sight to their satellite -- new marketing strategies along with a recent ruling by the Federal Communications Commission promise to greatly expand both the satellite industry's horizons and the choices available to New Yorkers seeking an alternative to cable television. 
 "I've been jumping between five different news networks all afternoon and I love it," said Arthur I. Weinstein, vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, describing a benefit of his new 200-channel digital satellite television system.
For Mr. Weinstein, who lives on Fire Island year round, installing a satellite system was hardly a luxury -- there is no cable television service on the island. In the last year or so, however, many other Americans -- even those who already have access to cable -- have been installing the small, relatively inobtrusive, increasingly inexpensive 18-inch dishes outside their homes and apartments. According to the Satellite Broadcasting & Communications Association, the number of satellite television subscribers nationwide is expected to grow to more than 15.5 million by the year 2001.
That growth, industry experts say, will be bolstered in part by a recent F.C.C. ruling that stunned many industry watchers. The ruling, issued in August, bars local governments and homeowner associations from unreasonably prohibiting property owners from installing the dishes outside their homes and apartments. "This ruling could have serious implications," said Debra Bass, a spokeswoman for the Community Associations Institute, an industry organization in Alexandria. Ms. Bass explained that in its ruling the F.C.C. gives condominium owners the right to install dishes on any property to which the owner has exclusive rights -- areas like private patios or balconies. It left open the question of whether co-op shareholders have the same right.
The commission is expected to rule on that issue, as well as whether individual condominium owners and co-op shareholders have the right to install satellite dishes in common areas, early next year.
"Our feeling is that homeowner associations should have the right to reasonably enforce rules regarding the means, methods and placement of these devices," Ms. Bass said. "You can imagine what will happen if everybody in a building starts installing their own satellite dish on the roof."
The issue of dishes on roofs is significant because of an inherent limitation in existing satellite technology -- typically, the dish must have unobstructed exposure to a specific point in the sky. "There are only so many places you can park a satellite in space," said Richard R. Muller, vice president of multi-unit sales for Direct TV, a Los Angeles-based company that has signed up more than 1.5 million subscribers in the last two years. Mr. Muller explained that Direct TV, in partnership with U.S. Satellite Broadcasting, a St. Paul company, beams more than 200 channels of programming to subscribers from a satellite orbiting 22,300 feet over Texas.
Private homeowners, he said, can generally find a location somewhere around the house that has the required exposure.
But since only those with a clear line of sight to the satellite can receive its signal, Mr. Muller said, and since landlords, co-op corporations and condominium associations understandably want to avoid having scores of individual dishes hanging from the side of their buildings, Direct TV is encouraging owners of high-rise buildings to install one master dish on the roof and run wires into individual apartments.
With that in mind, he said, the company has been signing contracts with system operators who will install and maintain rooftop dishes and wiring in multi-unit buildings. Last month, for example, Direct TV and U.S. Satellite Broadcasting teamed up with RCN, a New York City company that owns Liberty Cable -- which now provides video services to more than 50,000 apartments in the metropolitan area -- to mount an all-out effort to sell the company's programming to landlords and co-op and condominium boards.
Peter Price, president of Liberty Cable, explained that for properties where a master rooftop dish is used, individual unit owners and residents only have to buy the decoder box needed to unscramble the signal received by the satellite dish. Typically, Mr. Price said, it should cost individual customers no more than $400 to purchase the decoder from just about any large electronics retailer. (A decoder box with a dish costs from $399 to $899. Direct TV also offers a $200 rebate to customers who contract for a year of programming when they buy the equipment.)
Mary Kay Wedel, director of commercial business for U.S. Satellite Broadcasting -- (800) 204-8772 -- said that by combining options offered by her company and Direct TV, customers can choose among more than 200 channels.
"Our packages range from $7.95 to $34.95 a month," Ms. Wedel said, adding that Direct TV -- (800) 383-4388 -- offers programming that ranges from $5.95 to $44.95 a month. Customers typically buy a combination of both sets of programming, she said.
Other companies that offer satellite broadcasting include Primestar -- (800) 774-6378 -- Echo Star -- (800) 333-3474 -- and Alpha Star -- (888) 257-4278.
There are some drawbacks to satellite programming, however. Barry Rosenblum, president of Time Warner Cable of New York City, the company that now provides cable television service to Manhattan, Queens and parts of Brooklyn, pointed out that if a customer wants to use more than one television set, it is necessary to purchase a more sophisticated -- and more expensive -- digital decoder. Moreover, he said, the different satellite systems use different dishes and decoder boxes that are not interchangeable.
The most significant shortcoming of satellite television, however, is that unlike cable, it does not offer customers programming from the major television networks and local stations. As a result, satellite customers who want such programming have to either keep their basic cable service or, as a more archaic but economical alternative, dust off those old rabbit-ear antennas.

HEADLINE: A New Mixed-Income Village for Downtown Atlanta

BYLINE: By KEN EDELSTEIN 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
SPURRED partly by last summer's Olympics spectacle and partly by a national push to revamp public housing, this city is razing two dilapidated, low-income projects that have long been a public embarrassment and replacing them with new housing.
The Atlanta Housing Authority, in a partnership with private developers, is using tax incentives, Federal grants and the more flexible guidelines that now govern public housing to build a mixed-income neighborhood in place of two of its projects, Techwood Homes and Clark Howell Homes, which are being demolished. The site is next to some of Atlanta's most valuable commercial property. 
 "Nothing that we're doing right now would have been possible a couple of years ago," said Egbert L.J. Perry, the new development's managing partner. Neither the funds nor the motivation existed to deal forcefully with the problem, he said.
Mr. Perry, principal at the Integral Group, a real-estate investment company based in Atlanta, is overseeing construction of the 900-unit residential portion of the new development, which is being called the Village at Techwood. A total of 540 of the apartments will be set aside for low-income residents.
Some tenants have already moved into the first of five residential phases at the Village, which resembles a suburban condominium complex, with three-story wood and brick buildings around landscaped parking lots.
Mr. Perry said that each phase was likely to be architecturally distinctive. The first one is scheduled for completion this winter, with the last phase slated for the year 2000.
Plans call for interweaving the apartments with such amenities as a health club, a shopping center, an elementary school and a community center. As an added fillip, each apartment will get a special high-speed connection to the Internet. "This is really setting a standard for housing revitalization," said Renee Lewis Glover, executive director of the housing authority.
Techwood Homes and Clark Howell Homes were once considered models of a new wave in low-income housing. In 1936, President Franklin D. Roosevelt dedicated the first units of what would quickly sprawl out into 54 acres of red-brick, garden-style apartment buildings.
In recent years, however, civic leaders have bemoaned the crime, drug dealing and vandalism that crept across the projects. At one point the authority declared 500 of the units unsuitable for habitation.
Business leaders fretted that Techwood and Clark Howell were eyesores nestled between downtown office towers, the Georgia Institute of Technology and the fortress-like headquarters of the Coca-Cola Company. The spotlight shone more harshly on the two projects in the 90's when Olympic organizers built their athletes' village on Techwood's northern boundary and constructed a new Centennial Olympic Park two blocks to the south.
Now, most of the 1,100 units have been razed and nearly all residents have been moved out. Some former tenants have been shifted to private housing and enrolled in a voucher program to supplement their rent.
Business leaders are viewing the new development as an anchor in a still unsteady downtown revival that has followed on the heels of this summer's Games. Centennial Olympic Park, small apartment complexes, a new 1.6-million-square-foot Federal office building, plans for a basketball arena and efforts to establish a new entertainment district have raised hopes that downtown's sterile west side will become a showcase on the doorstep of the city's 2.5 million-square-foot convention facility, the Georgia World Congress Center.
"Any time you clear out a blighted area you're certainly going to improve the areas around it," said Gerald L. Bartels, president of the Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce. But the new housing complex also makes the whole area easier to redevelop, Mr. Bartels said, because it creates a better link between downtown and Georgia Tech. AND since it is a mixed-income development, it may help demonstrate that the downtown area is an acceptable place for middle-income people to live, he said.
The Housing Authority was able to begin razing the two existing projects and start building the Village at Techwood because it received a $42 million grant under the Federal Hope 6 program. The guidelines for this program gave the housing agency more opportunity to join forces with private developers, to reserve some space for middle-income tenants and to require low-income tenants to undergo training aimed at making them more self-sufficient.
"To some extent, the private developer shied away from dealing with HUD in the past because of the types of facilities we were trying to build," said Kevin E. Marchman, assistant secretary for housing in the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. HUD followed up the grant for Techwood and Clark Howell with $46 million for similar efforts at three other Atlanta projects.
The few expressions of criticism of the new development have focused mainly on the rapid pace of change. Edward L. Keating, an associate professor of city planning at Georgia Tech, notes that the authority has a record of mismanaging grant money.
"They're playing an extremely high-risk game," said Mr. Keating, who has worked as a consultant to Techwood tenants and HUD. "You're taking an agency that hasn't performed well in the past, that's got new leadership, and you're asking it to do extraordinary things. It could crash and burn."
Advocates for the poor and some residents worry that the dramatic changes will actually diminish the city's low-income housing stock.
Advocates for the homeless say vouchers don't always work as planned, and argue that bricks and mortar are a surer thing than a federally financed voucher system.
But the redevelopment has been welcomed by many others, including public-housing tenants who are looking forward to living in the new project.
"In the year 2000, I don't want to be still sitting here expecting something," said Frankie Taylor, a mother of three who has already enrolled in the self-sufficiency classes required to become residents of the village. "The suburbs are moving back to the city, I guess, and I think it's a good thing."
Mr. Perry said the opportunity to use a Federal grant as leverage with few strings attached to the physical design kicked the once-unattractive prospect of a public-housing makeover into the "comfort zone" for private developers.
He had overseen private residential projects in other parts of downtown when he served as president of H.J. Russell & Company, an established Atlanta construction and development company. Soon after he formed his own company in 1993, however, Mr. Perry had doubts that he could compete with larger firms to become the development partner for the Village at Techwood.
He therefore formed a joint venture with McCormick Baron Associates of St. Louis, which has managed and developed mixed-income projects in other regions. The joint venture is the developing and managing partner in a partnership for the residential portion of the project.
The other partners are the city's Housing Authority and an affiliate of Sun America Insurance Company, which has purchased equity shares in the project. Sun America will receive tax credits for its investment.
Additional financing is coming through low-interest loans from the Housing Authority and through conventional loans.
To Ms. Glover, the executive director of the Housing Authority, the biggest beneficiary is the authority and its clients. She noted that her agency was guaranteed new low-income housing, managed by a private company. Its loan must be repaid over the 55 years during which the authority will lease the land for a nominal fee to the partnership.
"It is an economically sustainable strategy for us," Ms. Glover said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Slowly, Hoboken's Riverfront Plans Near Reality

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE selection last month of a developer for a key building in Hoboken's attempt to revitalize its waterfront comes at a time when plans for developments on the New Jersey side of the Hudson River are receiving new impetus, but with construction to begin only when a major tenant is secured.
Three more projects are proposed in neighboring Jersey City. And all four have all or most of the needed approvals in place. 
 In Hoboken, hopes for a rebirth of the prized riverfront seemed like little more than a dream for over a decade. But that began to change last year when the tug-of-war between the city and community groups over how to develop the long-dormant southern portion of the riverfront ended in a compromise.
The 50 acres, extending from First to Fifth Streets, will be reshaped by the city in partnership with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey into an urban neighborhood of up to 2.3 million square feet of offices, housing, shops and a hotel with open and recreational space at its heart. There will also be a public waterfront walkway that will reconnect the city to the river.
The plan, drawn with public input, moved closer to reality when SJP Properties of Parsippany, known for its suburban offices, was chosen to build a 14-story, 1.1 million-square-foot office building.
Designed by HLW International in Manhattan, the $200 million brick building with masonry highlights and 50,000 square feet of shops is to rise on First Street, a block north of the landmark Hoboken Terminal, the city's mass transit hub, which is now being renovated. The architecture follows the redevelopment plan's design guidelines, among other things complementing the city's low-rise scale.
"This is the first time companies have the opportunity to take advantage of this prime office location," said Steven J. Pozycki, SJP's president.
As the first project it sets the stage to revive the rest of the riverfront, which in turn "will enhance and extend Hoboken's image as a first-class city," said Robert Drasheff, director of the city's office of waterfront development. It is hoped that the project will also give Hoboken, which missed out on the mid-80's boom, some of the tax relief, open space and jobs it badly needs.
When realized the entire waterfront project -- to be developed with public and private financing -- could generate 7,000 permanent jobs. Up to 4,000 of them could be in SJP's building, said Mr. Drasheff.
Under the redevelopment plan agreed to last year, the city sold the land to the Port Authority for $20 million. It then leased the land for $1 a year and, in turn, is subleasing parcels to developers. The first lease, for 98 years, was taken by SJP, which outbid 13 other developers. It will build, own and manage the structure.
For granting SJP the right to build on the waterfront the city will collect an annual payment in lieu of taxes. The payment, which will be based on a formula tied to the local tax rate, will begin at $2 a square foot and rise over the life of the lease. The city will also get 35 cents a foot to maintain the public amenities it will create using some of the $94 million the Port Authority is investing in Hoboken for infrastructure improvements.
(Under 1984 bistate legislation the authority was empowered to invest in waterfront projects in Hoboken and Hunters Point, Queens.)
SJP also will make land-lease payments to the authority, which Mr. Pozycki said would be about $3 a square foot, as well as 1 percent of the gross project revenues after expenses. The 50-acre waterfront development area will revert to the city once the bistate agency recoups its investment.
The SJP building reflects rekindled developer interest in constructing offices on the Hudson County portion of the riverfront.
IN Jersey City, where a swath of waterfront towers was put up in the 80's, three developers are planning office buildings at the river's edge. One with 750,000 square feet is to be built by the Lefrak Organization at the 400-acre Newport Center mixed-used project; another, of 1.1 million square feet, is being advanced by Columbia Development, a consortium of three New Jersey companies, on four acres at the 52-acre Hudson Exchange property. And at Colgate Palmolive's 20-acre Colgate Center tract a plot is being readied for a 435,000-square-foot structure.
The projects will open up both opportunity and competition, brokers and builders say. Since users are likely to come from Manhattan that city's resolve to keep jobs is also a factor, they add.
Still, most brokers believe Manhattan tenants will continue to come. Part of the reason is the absence of a corporate occupancy tax and the comforting presence of mass transit links, like PATH lines and ferries to Manhattan.
Stoking the push to build is the waterfront's lack of Class A space, the vacancy rate for which is 6 percent, reports Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage.
"Jersey City alone has absorbed 500,000 to 1.5 million square feet of space a year for five years" said Andrew Merin, a senior director at the firm's East Rutherford office. "That will be a problem to duplicate after this year."
No one doubts the waterfront's potential. The question is whether there is enough demand at this time for all four buildings.
"All this competition will do is drive down effective rents, making it difficult for the economics of any deal to make sense," said Robert P. Antonicello, president of the ACI Group, a real estate services firm in Jersey City.
But Peter Gilpatric, project executive for the Colgate site, thinks otherwise. "Everyone will try to build a better mousetrap," he said, "but tenants will still have to pay the freight because no one will build a new building at a loss."
Linda P. Morgan, director of the New Jersey office of the Regional Plan Association, added that developing in the state's urban centers and next to transit links is sound.
Jersey City, which started reviving its riverfront 10 years ago, now has a list of corporate residents that some brokers say will be the key in attracting more. So Hoboken is the new kid on the commercial-property block, and Mr. Drasheff, its waterfront director, said that the time was ripe to initiate the redevelopment plan with offices.
Asked why Hoboken had put offices ahead of housing in its waterfront priorities, he said that it was important to first build a tax base and create jobs. He noted that the plan drawn up by the Hoboken Waterfront Corporation and adopted by the city last year called for 380 residences. The corporation, created to devise an acceptable plan, includes city and civic leaders and professional planners.
Beyond SJP's office project the waterfront plan calls for 400,000 more square feet of offices, 75,000 additional square feet of stores and a 300-room hotel. Most important is the 525,000 square feet (17 acres), mostly on two piers, which will be devoted to recreational and open space, parks, an esplanade and a riverfront walkway, said Ron Hine, president of the Coalition for a Better Waterfront.
"For the first time in 100 years Hoboken's riverfront will be open to the public and that's precisely what we have been fighting for," he said, referring to the two earlier waterfront proposals his group helped defeat in referendums. Voters objected to, among other things, the project's scale, which once had 3.2 million square feet of space, and the role of the Port Authority, which then was the master developer.
Yet doubts linger over whether the plan, and in turn SJP's project, will get off the ground. Among those expressing such doubts is Donald P. Eisen, senior managing director of the New York region, based in the office of Cushman & Wakefield in East Rutherford.
While conceding that Hoboken had excellent mass-transit links, he pointed to the city's checkered redevelopment history.
"I will believe a building in Hoboken when I see the steel," he said.
But Joel Freiser, chairman of Hoboken's waterfront corporation, said that the city has built a consensus, adding that "everyone is pulling in the same direction."
Mr. Drasheff added that the site had been cleared and the city would soon begin work on the public amenities and on utilities and sewers.
Mr. Pozycki, SJP's president, said the development agreement also has guarantees and incentives for each party to the accord to speed development. For instance, he said, payments to the city and the Port Authority do not begin until construction on the building begins. He said he expected to start next year.
In terms of the competition, he echoed officials from the city and the bistate agency in voicing confidence that Hoboken's residential character and amenities, like restaurants and shops, would serve it well, as would the planned building's proximity to major mass transit links and clear views of Manhattan.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1392 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Plan to Enliven Downtown Stamford Draws Dissent

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: STAMFORD

 BODY:
FOR almost half of the 30-year urban renewal period that has transformed Stamford from small town to big city, a four-acre downtown parcel called Blocks 8 and 9 has remained a pocket of small stores, restaurants, parking lots and empty lotsamid the office towers.
While a new proposal for the parcel's development has the approval of the city and substantial public support, a dispute with the F.D. Rich Company, Stamford's urban renewal developer, and concerns over parking and density have delayed the signing of contracts. 
 The proposal, for a development to be called Park Square West, was presented jointly to the city in July by the Corcoran-Jennison Company of Dorchester, Mass., and Berkeley Investments of Boston. It was one of three proposals for the parcel submitted to Stamford's Urban Renewal Commission, including one by the Starrett Corporation of New York and one by Galbreath-Rich of Columbus, Ohio, and Stamford.
"I love it," said Mayor Dannel Molloy, referring to the Corcoran-Jennison proposal. "It's a good-looking, well-thought-out proposal. It brings added value to all the properties downtown and it strikes the right balance."
Indeed, plans for the complex, estimated to cost $80 million, comply with the city's desire for a lively neighborhood of apartments, shops, entertainment and parking, providing relief from what many local residents feel is a downtown overweighted with fortress-like office buildings.
The plan calls for 400 rental apartments with one to three bedrooms in two buildings of 7 and 14 stories. Twenty percent of the total units would be offered at below-market rates. To qualify for those units, a family of four would be required to have an income of no more than $43,000, which is 80 percent of the median income here. Rent would be 30 percent of that figure.
Seventy-five thousand square feet of restaurants and specialty retailers would occupy the ground floors of the apartment buildings and fill two retail pavilions. Parking would be accommodated in 780 spaces distributed in surface areas, a parking garage and under the apartment buildings.
Among the retail uses being considered are a bookstore and brew pub that would appeal to students at the University of Connecticut branch now under construction in the former Bloomingdales across Broad Street from the site and a 35,000 square-foot, 24-hour "greengrocer" offering groceries and take-home meals. Pocket parks, roof gardens and landscaped pedestrian accessways to downtown theaters and stores are other elements in the proposal.
ALTOGETHER it is a package that municipal officials and many members of the business community and the public have said they find exciting and viable. But concerns have been expressed by the Chamber of Commerce about the height of a 14-story apartment building looming over Columbus Park, a venerable piece of downtown surrounded by several restaurants. And some residents have expressed reservations about density of development.
While Edward C. Steinberg, executive director of Stamford's Urban Renewal Commission, strongly endorses the plan, he acknowledged that "Corcoran-Jennison did not conform to the specifications in our request for proposals."
"They exceeded the 40,000 square feet allotted for retail by 35,000 square feet," he said, "and the limit of 10,000 square feet for a single store by 25,000 square feet."
The larger amount of retail space and a shortage of parking has been criticized by 33 Broad Street Associates, whose partners are the Robert Kahn and F.D. and Robert Rich families of Stamford. The F.D. Rich Company was designated by the city as sole developer of the downtown urban renewal district in 1960, and as such it has approval power over the proposals for Blocks 8 and 9.
At present Sears Roebuck & Company is negotiating to lease 33 Broad Street's 1.6-acre lot across Broad Street from the UConn branch and build a 150,000 square foot store. The 33 Broad Street lot is part of the Blocks 8 and 9 parcel, and is adjacent to the lots that would be used for the proposed Corcoran-Jennison development.
"We are very interested in placing a store back in Stamford," said Tim Conway, a spokesman for Sears, which closed its 44-year-old branch off High Ridge Road here in 1995, "but a lack of parking is a concern that we're hoping can be worked out."
Sears and 33 Broad Street Associates want the city to build a 400-car garage, in addition to the parking envisioned under the Corcoran-Jennison proposal, for the use of Sears and the general public at a cost of $6 million to $8 million. Mr. Steinberg of the Urban Renewal Commission believes that the city should not underwrite the garage because the city does not benefit from retail sales taxes, all of which go to the state. "Rich-Kahn are using their approval authority over Blocks 8 and 9 as a bargaining chip to get Sears in," he said.
Sandy Goldstein, executive director of the Downtown Special Services District, disagrees. "It's very appropriate for the public to play a role in insuring that parking gets built for the entire downtown by participating in the financing," she said. "This dispute is not good for the city."
The disagreement has held up the signing of contracts between the Urban Renewal Commission and Corcoran-Jennison until a parking study by Barton Aschman Associates, of Chicago, can be considered. The study, due this month, was financed by the city, the commission, 33 Broad Street Associates, Sears and Corcoran-Jennison.
CORCORAN-JENNISON is willing to help finance the garage, said its president, Marty Jones. "We are very happy that the city is so enthusiastic about Park Square West," she said, "and we are ready to get moving. But it's disturbing that these external factors are slowing us down."
Tom Rich, Robert Rich's son and a principal in 33 Broad Street Associates, believes that the Urban Renewal Commission is overstepping its authority. "The commission has nothing to do with Sears and our request to the city for the garage," he said. "The Mayor, the Board of Representatives, the Downtown Special Services District and the Chamber of Commerce are the ones who have to support it."
According to Robert Rich, "there are 36 years of history behind all of this." In the early 80's, he noted, the F.D. Rich Company agreed to the city's request to relinquish its right to build a 1,000-car parking garage on the Broad Street site in exchange for 350 surface spaces.
Several years later the company agreed to an additional request allowing the conversion of the lot to housing and limited retail.
"The U.R.C. made a deal with Lincoln Properties [a national development and management company based in Herndon, Va.] to develop Blocks 8 and 9 but it collapsed when the bottom fell out of the market," said Robert Rich. "Now, after they selected Corcoran-Jennison's proposal they came to us and said that they want to build much more retail than we allow. This time we said no. The project is underparked and will affect our options for retail if Sears backs out." The matter has been referred to an arbitration panel that is expected to reach a decision by the end of this year.
Meanwhile, 33 Broad Street Associates filed a breach of contract suit last week in Stamford Superior Court against the city, the Urban Renewal Commission and its director.
Jay Sandak, lawyer for 33 Broad Street, said that a commission survey had encumbered the proposed Sears site with an easement for parking, thereby preventing the Sears development from taking place and violating the commission's contract to turn over the property free and clear.
A temporary injunction is also being sought to prevent the commission from withdrawing 33 Broad Street's development rights if it takes more more than 120 days to file plans for the venture as required. A request for plans was made on Oct. 3. A hearing on the temporary injunction is scheduled for Dec. 9. No court date has been set for the lawsuit.
Carmen Domonkos, chairman of the 40-member Board of Representatives, which will have the ultimate vote on the Park Square West proposal, said that "the Riches were given our whole downtown and they made a good living from it. Yes, they made concessions, but we have a plan that can work. The economy is up now and I'd hate to see this held up until it goes down again."
