SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 4; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1327 words

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Way Before the Turnpike

BYLINE: By DEBRA GALANT 

DATELINE: SOUTH ORANGE

 BODY:
PICTURE, if you will, a land with dense forests and pristine waters, abundant in wildlife, populated by people innocent in the ways of commerce. Then imagine the place discovered by foreigners from lands with sophisticated economies, who see big profits behind every tree.
The South American rain forest, perhaps? Plunderers from multinational corporations? 
 No. We're talking about New Jersey in the 17th century, Indians known as the Lenape and explorers from Holland, the richest country in Europe, lusting for furs.
Or go back, if you will, another 12,000 years. No lush woodlands, but tundra mixed with spruce and pine. It's cold, real cold. Mammoths, elephants, mastodons and giant beavers roam the land, walruses swim off the coast. A small but hardy people make their living by hunting.
New Jersey, 10,000 B.C.
It may be hard to imagine a New Jersey before diners and turnpikes. But think about all those Indian names -- Secaucus, Watchung, Ho-Ho-Kus, Weehawken -- and a foggy picture of prehistoric New Jersey might begin to form. Then, if you're lucky, spend some time with Herbert Kraft, professor of anthropology at Seton Hall University and one of the world's foremost experts on the Lenape Indians. Or visit his small museum of Indian artifacts in the lobby of Fahy Hall, in the middle of Seton Hall.
With a little imagination, you can hear drums in the distance.
Of course, as in all archeology (Dr. Kraft's branch of anthropology), you do need some imagination -- and a lot of guesswork. "Nobody knows better than an archeologist what he doesn't know, or may never know," said Dr. Kraft, who is 69. "We can never get the songs, the dances, the interpersonal communications -- the ephemeral things, in other words."
We do know an impressive amount about Indians who lived hundreds or even thousands of years ago, though, and for much of that we can thank Dr. Kraft, who recently won the Marden R. Nystrom Historian of the Year Award from the League of Historical Societies of New Jersey. Dr. Kraft has unearthed treasures from a dozen archeological digs in the state, including tools (10,000 B.C.) from the Paleo-Indian period, decorative burial objects (645 B.C.) from the Early Woodland Period and a painstakingly reconstructed 20-gallon clay pot (A.D. 1350) from the Late Woodland Period.
Some of the artifacts are so compelling they seem like telegrams from the past. One such find, also from the Late Woodland Period, is a tobacco pipe carved with a delicate face (A.D. 1500) -- so human-looking you get the creepy feeling that you're being watched. The pipe comes from Minisink site in Sussex County, which Dr. Kraft and 30 students excavated in 1975 and 1976.
Dr. Kraft considers himself a prehistorian; that is, he is concerned with what took place before recorded history. In the case of North America, history officially starts with the appearance of the white man. "I've always objected to the fact that we start history with the Colonial period," he said.
Nevertheless, much of what we know about Indians does come from the letters, diaries and trading accounts of European traders and settlers. "So we see the Indian through the eyes of the European," Dr. Kraft said. Although Dr. Kraft is a prehistorian, he is at his most interesting when discussing the enduring -- and fundamentally wrong -- myths about the American Indian, which stem from these Colonial sources.
If you went to grade school before the era of political correctness, you were probably taught, for example, how foolish the Indians were for selling Manhattan Island to Peter Minuit for just $24 in trinkets. Dr. Kraft says the traditional spin on that story fails to take into account the difference between the way the Indians and the Dutch viewed the concept of land. "In Europe, every square inch of land belonged to somebody," he said. "According to the Indian, land was put here by God for all people. They couldn't imagine that you could sell land any more than you can sell air or water." The Indians accepted the trinkets not as payment, but as a sign of good faith.
Europeans introduced not only the idea of real estate to America, but also the related concept of the fence. In fact, the Indians' failure to grasp the notion of private property led to the Peach War of 1650, near Kingston, N.Y., which started when an Indian woman spied some peaches in a Dutch garden, crossed a fence to pick them and was killed.
Although the Lenape Indians, or "common people," had their own vigorous culture -- including a matriarchal family system, agriculture, medicine and religion -- the Europeans saw them as heathens. "They spoke of naked savages," said Dr. Kraft. "They thought them ignorant." The fact that the Indians went around half naked was baffling to these people who dressed "from head to toe," he pointed out.
THE Indians, for their part, were mystified by these strange new people. "The Indians thought the Europeans very ignorant because they couldn't survive in the wilderness," said Dr. Kraft. "These people would starve to death in a land that had always provided the Indians with an abundance of nourishment."
And if the Dutch thought the Indians were guileless for selling Manhattan, the Indians thought the Dutch were equally misguided in their trades. "The Indians thought the Europeans were stupid for selling something so valuable as a metal knife or glass beads or a brass kettle for something so worthless as a beaver skin," said Dr. Kraft.
Our knowledge of the Indians who lived here thousands of years earlier comes mainly from archeological digs. Among the most important excavations that Dr. Kraft has led was a major project between 1964 and 1976 to unearth Indian artifacts in the 37-mile-long area that extends from the Delaware Water Gap to Port Jervis, N.Y. The project was underwritten by the National Park Service because plans were then being made to build the Tocks Island Dam, which in fact was never built.
"Archeology sometimes only succeeds where you have crisis situations," Dr. Kraft said. "As long as the dam was a threat we were able to get funding."
Among the most significant finds from that project were house patterns consisting of "post molds" -- organic stains left by the posts that once formed the frames of the Indians' houses -- which tell us that Indians of the late Woodland Period (about A.D. 900 A.D. to A.D. 1650) lived in round-ended long houses made of saplings and bark. Reproductions of these long houses are on display at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N.J., and in fact were designed and built by Dr. Kraft's son John, 44, who accompanied Dr. Kraft on most of the excavations from the time he was 11 years old, and who now serves as manager of operations at Waterloo Village.
Although relationships between archeologists and Indians have been strained in recent years, Dr. Kraft says he has taken care to maintain good relations with the modern Lenape, who call themselves the Delaware Tribe of Indians. He regularly consults with tribe officials, like assistant chief Michael Pace, on matters of protocol involving Indian burial sites and other excavation issues. "He's very sensitive to those things," said Mr. Pace, who lives in Oklahoma, along with 60 percent of the 10,236 surviving Delaware Indians. Good relations are a necessity for a modern archeologist, because of the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act, a Federal law that allows Indians to reclaim objects they consider sacred from museums and other collections. Dr. Kraft has not been asked to return any part of his collection.
Dr. Kraft and the Indians also learn from each other -- Dr. Kraft from the customs and ceremonies that have survived three centuries of the white man in America, and the Delaware from his research. "We're just in awe of the work that he does," said Mr. Pace. After all, without his work, the Indians themselves would know much less about their own past.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dr. Herbert Kraft, an expert on prehistoric New Jersey, with a display of Indian spearheads in his small museum at Seton Hall. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)
 
"There Was No Football on TV Either"
The first Thanksgiving, which took place in 1621 in Massachusetts, is a vital piece of American folkore. Dr. Herbert Kraft, professor of anthropology at Seton Hall University, comments that though this 20th-century painting (in an earlier style) is inaccurate in some details, it is essentially true to the event. Dr. Kraft, an expert in prehistoric New Jersey, says that the local Indians would have had somilar traditions to those in Massachusetts.
 
TURKEY was an American bird introduced by the Indians to the pilgrims, venison was also served at the first Thanksgiving.
 
CORN, SQUASH, PUMPKINS were grown by the Indians and unknown to Europeans.
 
THE INDIANS would probably not have sat at a table but on the ground. It is unlikely they would have worn fringed shirts and pants. They would probably dress in lose robes, as the Indian on the left. And they would likely not have eaten while the Pilgrims said grace. (Culver Pictures)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: The Luxury-Decontrol Wars

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
JUST beyond the season of glad tidings, virtually with the drop of the New Year's ball, unwelcome letters from landlords will start popping up in mailboxes at fashionable, rent-regulated buildings, heralding what one landlord lawyer has dubbed "the hunting season."
So begins the annual four-month period during which those tenants must prove that their income did not surpass $250,000 in each of the previous two years and that, therefore, their apartments should not be subject to "luxury decontrol" and their rents doubled, tripled or more. 
 Evoking sympathy for people who earn a quarter million dollars a year while occupying apartments that rent for at least $2,000 in upscale neighborhoods is, at best, a Sisyphean task -- with tenant advocates facing the uphill struggle and landlord representatives more than willing to nudge the boulder back.
And yet, since their passage three years ago, the so-called "luxury decontrol" statutes of New York State and City have affected more than just the affluent. They have also resulted in the dislocation, on technical grounds, of people whose incomes are well below the threshold for deregulation of their apartments. And, in the process, they have raised certain constitutional questions and become a wedge issue in the fractious struggle over whether, or how, the rent-regulation law covering more than a million apartments in the state will be retained beyond its expiration date next June 15.
There is no denying a degree of dread -- almost regardless of the tenant's level of wealth -- when, after months of form filling and appeal filing, he or she rips open that letter from the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal and finds in bold type: Order of Deregulation.
"We've been here 36 years, and I expected to live here for the rest of my life," said one tenant of a luxury building on Manhattan's Upper West Side who, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he is appealing his Order of Deregulation. "It makes you very uneasy, it's unnerving," said the man, who now pays $2,400 a month and asserts that a neighbor's deregulated rent jumped to $12,000 -- a possibility confirmed by several market observers.
About 3,000 apartments have been deregulated so far under policies that apply to vacant or occupied apartments renting for $2,000 a month or more, with the number expected to increase.
"It's terribly upsetting," said Peter Sudarsky, 67, a tenant in the Langham at 135 Central Park West, who contends that he received an Order of Deregulation after he became confused by two of the multi-page, look-alike forms he received during the process, and mailed one to the wrong address. Mr. Sudarksy said his household income is well below $100,000.
"When you're over 65, your eyes don't focus so clearly, and the plain fact is I'm incompetent to deal with this form, that form," Mr. Sudarsky said. "I wonder how many little old ladies, people who can't read this thing, people on Social Security, are hit with this."
Under luxury decontrol -- an umbrella term for the two methods by which a landlord can start charging free-market rates -- the regulated rent for the apartment must have already reached $2,000 a month. Under one method, officially called high-rent vacancy decontrol, the apartment must become vacant before a new tenant can be charged whatever the market will bear. Under the other, called high-income decontrol, the gross taxable income for the household must have reached $250,000 in each of the two previous years.
Landlords view luxury decontrol as a just means of liberating at least a segment of the regulated market so that economic benefits will, eventually, flow for all. "You have wealthy people not paying the market rent," said Arnold Goldstein, president of Samson Management and chairman of the Rent Stabilization Association, the city's largest landlord organization. "As a result, the owner's rent rolls are depressed, and, thereby, that deprives the city of an opportunity to raise the assessment and obtain more tax dollars, which they would use to improve city services, so everybody would benefit.
"I just feel it's an injustice," Mr. Goldstein said.
Jeffrey Turkel, a lawyer who represents landlords in luxury decontrol cases, said: "Older folks who are retired but can still afford $2,000 a month obviously are people of means. These people are frequently living in apartments with two or three bedrooms, the children have moved away, and there are families desperate for those apartments that can't get into them. Luxury deregulation makes those apartments available to the families that really need them.
"It's unfortunate that people might have to move, but anybody with $2,000 a month to spend on rent will certainly find a place to live."
BUT it's not always so simple, as one East Side resident -- a businessman who has faced financial difficulties in recent years -- asserts. "There's the disruption factor when you have a family, a tremendous amount of anxiety attached to this," said the man, who spoke only if he would not be identified.
"I've had a substantial drop-off in income, but our income never closed in on the range of deregulation, much as I wish it had," said the man, whose apartment was decontrolled on a technicality.
"The way the rental market is these days, any apartment I looked at that would suitably house my family would already be deregulated," he said. "As I understand it, if it's $2,000 or more now and it's vacant it's already deregulated."
Tenant advocates view luxury decontrol as the first brick yanked from the rent-regulation dike.
"It's bad policy," said Michael McKee, the rent law campaign manager for the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition. "It only helps rich landlords who own high-rent buildings where they are already making enormous profits."
"This is a tough sell to the public," Mr. McKee said, "because they say, 'Why should somebody who has an income of $250,000 a year benefit from rent regulation?' It makes us seem to be defending rich people who don't deserve protection.
"But even if you aren't concerned about people at that income level, once having established a means test for rent regulation, which is what this is, the real estate industry and its allies in the Legislature will always try to lower the threshhold."
And, in fact -- with rent regulation up for renewal in June and a Republican, George E. Pataki, in the Governor's Mansion -- landlords have vowed to do just that. The president of the Rent Stabilization Association, Joseph Strasburg, said recently that, "at a minimum," his group would push for:
* Reduction of the existing income level for luxury decontrol from $250,000 "closer toward $100,000 a year" and of the current $2,000-a-month rent threshold to "something like $1,500."
* Vacancy decontrol of all apartments so that "whenever a vacancy occurs the owner will be free to ask whatever the market will bear."
* Gradual phase-out of all rent regulation.
Mr. McKee, however, calls means-testing "a slippery slope" for a mechanism that is supposed to create "an even playing field" in a city facing a chronic housing shortage. Rent regulation, by law, is mandated when there is a 5 percent vacancy rate and, as of 1993 -- the latest survey available -- the city's vacancy rate was 3.44 percent.
In actual numbers, luxury decontrol has, so far, affected only a small segment of the market. Since the program began, according to Jonathan Grossman, chief of the luxury decontrol bureau at the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, a total of 2,631 apartments have been deregulated, almost all of them in Manhattan.
Mr. Grossman said that 1,298 apartments have been deregulated under the high-income decontrol program, all but two in Manhattan. Of those in Manhattan, 547, or 42 percent, were in the 10021 ZIP code area, on the East Side between 61st and 80th Streets.
Statistics for the high-rent vacancy decontrol program are based on rent-stabilization registration forms that landlords are required to file every year. Numbers for 1996 have not yet been tabulated, Mr. Grossman said, but 526 apartments were deregulated in 1994 and another 807 in 1995, for a total of 1,333. Of those, 1,286 were in Manhattan, 46 in Brooklyn and one in the Bronx.
But the impact ripples well beyond the hard data. "Take the number of people who realize that their time is coming," said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a large Manhattan rental and sales brokerage. "They know that it's going to happen within a couple of years and, so, they exercise the choice to move before it does."
"Mostly, they are buying," Ms. Packes said, pointing out that "the rental market doesn't have less expensive options for them" -- especially in a climate where a one-bedroom apartment can easily go for $1,500 or more.
Barbara Corcoran, chairman of the Corcoran Group, agreed: "They don't wait until they receive notice that their apartment is being deregulated. They are savvy people. And, fortunately, they have the financial wherewithal to purchase."
For those who remain in, and those who move into, a deregulated apartment, the rent increase can be sizable. "It's common to see rents double or triple," Ms. Corcoran said, citing a loft in TriBeCa where the rent climbed from $2,000 to $5,000. Ms. Packes said a deregulated apartment on Park Avenue jumped from $2,500 to $7,500.
And Ms. Corcoran said she knew of "some exceptional examples where rents increased tenfold."
"There was a 10-room Park Avenue apartment where an elderly woman was paying $2,000 a month," she said. "Her net worth was more than $50 million. Her family didn't want to relocate her, so her rent was increased to $20,000."
And then there are those whose apartments have been deregulated for procedural reasons, even though their incomes may be nowhere near the $250,000 threshold.
"For me," said Samuel Himmelstein, a tenant lawyer, "the big issue is the issuance of default Orders of Deregulation, which can occur on a variety of technicalities." The tenant may not mail in one of the forms in time, or, for a variety of reasons, fails to respond at all, Mr. Himmelstein said. Sometimes, no decision is rendered in a case that began in one calendar year before the landlord starts the process again the following year. "The tenant's response is often confusion: 'Why should I answer this again?' Or, they get the docket numbers mixed up," Mr. Himmelstein said.
"It points to a fundamental flaw in the statute," he said, "which is that if a tenant doesn't answer or makes some kind of procedural error, the state doesn't check their income. It just presumes the income is over $250,000," then issues a default Order of Deregulation.
"And when tenants attempt to convince D.H.C.R. to vacate these default orders," Mr. Himmelstein said, "in many instances attaching copies of their tax returns, the D.H.C.R. is refusing to open up these cases." D.H.C.R. officials insist they are merely adhering to the letter of the law.
According to the law, every year between Jan. 1 and May 1 -- the period that Mr. Turkel refers to as "the hunting season" -- the landlord for an apartment where the rent is over $2,000 can send an Income Certification Form to the tenant. The form asks the tenant to list all occupants of the apartment and to certify whether or not the household income has surpassed $250,000 for two years. The tenant must return the form to the landlord within 30 days.
IF the landlord disputes the information in the Income Certification Form, or if the tenant does not respond in time or at all, the landlord can file an Owner's Petition for Deregulation with the D.H.C.R. by June 30. The D.H.C.R. then mails a copy of the owner's petition and a response form to the tenant. A failure to respond within 60 days can result in a default Order of Deregulation. "They won't even check with the tax authorities, they just deregulate," Mr. Himmelstein said.
Stanley P. Danzig, a former Civil Court judge in Manhattan who still practices law, claims he returned the Income Certification Form in time, indicating that his income was "embarrassingly lower" than $250,000, but that he never received the Owner's Petition for Deregulation. "The next thing I know I have a notice saying I'm destabilized," he said. Judge Danzig pays $2,160 for a two-bedroom apartment in the Belnord, a 1908 Renaissance Revival building at 209 West 86th Street.
Because Judge Danzig did not respond to the owner's petition, which he says he never received, the D.H.C.R. will not reconsider its order deregulating his apartment, his lawyer, Robert Katz, said. "D.H.C.R. does not ask the state Department of Taxation to verify the income," Mr. Katz said, "they only ask if the person answered the landlord's petition. This is insufficient protection where you are trying to deprive someone of his rights to his apartment."
Mr. Katz said he plans to file a brief supporting a suit brought by Mr. Sudarsky -- the man who claims he was confused by look-alike forms and mailed one to the wrong address -- questioning the constitutionality of the D.H.C.R.'s strict enforcement of the procedures.
Mr. Sudarsky's lawyer, Seth Miller, asserts that D.H.C.R.'s reliance on the reliability of mail delivery places tenants at risk. "The Owner's Petition for Deregulation comes in the middle of the summer, when a lot of people are away," Mr. Miller said. "It looks a lot like the Income Certification Form that was sent by the landlord earlier; the two can easily be confused."
Mr. Sudarsky's suit against both the D.H.C.R. and his landlord, Jeffrey Manocherian, contends that, "on its face and as applied," the law is unconstitutional.
"The statute provides that a tenant's apartment may be deregulated, under the guise of 'luxury deregulation,' merely because the tenant did not answer or did not answer completely, within 60 days, a notice sent by regular mail in the middle of the summer," the suit says. "The statute makes no provision for a tenant to vacate such default, no matter how excusable."
Mr. Manocherian did not respond to a request for comment on the case. But Paul Roldan, the D.H.C.R.'s deputy commissioner for rent administration -- speaking about the agency's policies rather than a specific case -- said the decontrol law "requires the agency to deregulate apartments whose tenants have defaulted in submitting income verification information to the agency.
"Now, that's regardless of those tenants' actual incomes."
The law, Mr. Roldan said, "requires that the tenant's answer be submitted within 60 days of the date the agency sent the landlord's petition -- 61 days is a default, and it's that strict."
Asked if some of the defaults could be avoided if the agency changed the appearance of the forms and used return-receipt mail, Mr. Roldan said: "We're always trying to make the forms more clear. We will look into any suggestion regarding our forms." As to the use of return-receipt mail, rather than just first-class and certified mail, Mr. Roldan said, "That would be something we might want to study."
Landlords, too, have difficulties with the process.
Some tenants intentionally use different versions of their name on their leases and tax forms, said Mr. Goldstein of the Rent Stabilization Association. "The problem is that we make the petition out as the name appears on the lease," he said. "So let's assume it's John Smith on the lease. The tenant may be filing the tax return as J.B. Smith, so we don't get a match. Believe it or not, our application gets rejected."
Mr. Turkel said: "Some tenants file from their summer house. If the tenant provides misleading information, the tax department may not be able to find their return." Also, he said, self-employed people can manipulate their income. "Every other year, they can just pay themselves their bonus on Jan. 1 instead of Dec. 31, so that they never make $250,000 in two consecutive years."
In the landlord-tenant realm, each side of the coin usually bears starkly differing images.
There is the advertising executive who declares that the apartment she uses five days a week at 800 Fifth Avenue is her primary residence, while her husband lives and works in Michigan and comes back East to spend weekends at the home they own in Connecticut -- though it is occupied by their children and grandchildren.
"I filled out the Income Certification Form and, for the last 10 years, the apartment in Manhattan has been in my name," said the executive, who declined to be identified. "And anyway," she said of her court appeal to overturn the order deregulating the apartment, "my net income is under $250,000, so that's not an issue."
But Robert Goldstein, the lawyer for the landlord, sees it differently: "Here is someone who is married and apparently lives with her husband as husband and wife when their schedules allow it. They have an apartment in New York City that is rent-stabilized and, thereby, they are getting a benefit from the State of New York in that their apartment is worth a lot more than they are paying.
"Her husband argues that since he is not a primary resident of the apartment, his income should not be counted. But he gets a benefit by having a New York City apartment. He uses it whenever he wants, and he doesn't pay taxes to the State of New York.
"I mean this is the great example of how people in New York think that they have a birthright to rent-regulated apartments."
And then there are cases that stretch the bounds of credulity.
Stephen and Deborah Weiss, along with their two small children, live in a 35-story, white-brick building at 245 East 63d Street. They pay $2,800 for a two-bedroom apartment.
Mr. Weiss, an environmental lawyer, said his income is "comfortably below" the $250,000 threshold -- as he so indicated on the Income Certification Form that arrived in early 1994, requesting information about his earnings in 1992 and 1993.
SOON after, however, a form arrived asking about the income of his son -- then all of 1 year old. "I wrote to the D.H.C.R. and attached a copy of my son's birth certificate," Mr. Weiss said. And, based on that evidence, the D.H.C.R. denied the landlord's petition to deregulate the apartment.
But then, "about three weeks later," Mr. Weiss said, "we received a request for additional information from the D.H.C.R." The Weisses concluded that the new request "had crossed in the mails with the department's prior order" denying the landlord's petition for deregulation -- and made the consequential error of not responding. "Unbeknownst to us, the landlord had commenced a collateral proceeding, related to income in 1993 and 1994, and they overlapped," Mr. Weiss said.
On Jan. 6 of this year, the dreaded letter arrived: Because they failed to respond to that second request for information, the Weiss's apartment had been deregulated.
They plan to move soon.
"The landlord acted within his rights," said Mr. Weiss. "The regulations were put on the books for his benefit, and he was availing himself of that benefit. But the manner in which the proceedings were executed gives me little confidence that the general populace is being fairly treated.
"I'm a lawyer who deals day in and day out with intricate and sometimes arcane documents," Mr. Weiss said. "What happens to old people?"

SECTION: Section 3; Page 9; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 883 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Heads or Tails, a Star Investor Will Fill His Pockets

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY MIDDLETON 

 BODY:
THERE are some people you just don't want to encounter on the opposite side of the table when you are making a deal. They are savvy business people who always seem to know when a market has bottomed out and when it has peaked. If they are buying, you sure hate to be selling.
For many investors, Michael F. Price has been that kind of guy. A renowned value investor who runs the Mutual Series funds, Mr. Price has a knack for finding investments that are undervalued. Likewise, some investors say, when he decides to sell it may be a sign that an investment is fully valued. 
 So coin collectors, take note. After a couple of decades of collecting, Mr. Price is selling his entire cache of ancient Greek and Roman coins. The collection, in gold and silver, has been assigned a presale value of $1.5 million to $2 million.
The estimate could prove low. "When you have a good collection and sell it together, it always generates more money," said Eric McFadden, director of Seaby Coins in London.
Even so, it will be chump change to Mr. Price, who late last month sold his Mutual Series of five mutual funds to Franklin Resources for more than $600 million and a contingency that could add $200 million to the total over a few years. He bought the fund business, known as Heine Securities of Short Hills, N.J., for about $4 million in 1988. Some observers considered his decision yet another sign that the boom in mutual funds had reached its zenith.
Though Mr. Price, 45, has been buying paintings for a new home, he denied that the coin sale signaled a switch in his personal life to serious art collecting. "I pretty much accomplished what I wanted to," he said of the coin business.
"I want to find some other thing to do now -- just like with my business -- and I have no idea what," added Mr. Price, who was recently divorced.
The prices of rare coins have traditionally moved in the same direction as those of other hard assets, like real estate, fine art and precious metals. But they have moved more independently in recent years. Along with bullion, the market for gold and silver coins peaked around 1980 and fell as inflation subsided. Since then, volatility has diminished.
"The market's been relatively stable over the last dozen years," Mr. McFadden said.
But in that narrow range, prices have been climbing of late. "After 1991, prices went down 10 percent to 15 percent," said Harvey Stack, whose Stack's Rare Coins of West 57th Street in Manhattan will sell the Price collection at auction on Dec. 3. "They're now back up, and we're hoping they're better" than they were that year, when Nelson Bunker Hunt sold a much bigger and more valuable collection.
The American Numismatic Association, of Colorado Springs, puts coin collectors' transactions at about $1 billion a year. Ancient coins, those minted before A.D. 1000, account for perhaps $100 million to $200 million of that activity, Mr. McFadden said.
Discoveries this decade have greatly increased the supply of old coins, causing prices to fall, especially for the more common Greek coins, some of which can be had for $10. The ancients buried their wealth instead of banking it, and troves of 1,000 to 5,000 coins have turned up in Europe with the advent of powerful metal detectors.
Edward Milas, owner of the Rare Coin Company of America in Willowbrook, Ill., said he sold his personal collection five years ago. "The very rare coins, the very high-quality coins, still bring good prices," he said. "But for the most part the ancient market has suffered because of the magnitude of coins that have come onto the market."
THE Price collection includes 257 coins, many of exceptional beauty and rarity, minted between the sixth century B.C. and the seventh century A.D. "The quality of the sale is magnificent," said Ira Goldberg, a senior executive of Superior Stamp and Coin in Beverly Hills, Calif.
Coins representing the first 12 Roman Caesars are the backbone of the collection. A real prize is a gold aureus issued by Octavian, which could bring $80,000 to $100,000. "This coin is very difficult to obtain in silver, and he's got one in gold," said Richard Giedroyc, international editor of Coin World, a hobbyists' magazine published in Sidney, Ohio.
The Price sale kicks off a week of activity for coin collectors. There will be several auctions, followed by the New York International Numismatic Convention, Dec. 6 to 8 at the World Trade Center.
The market, however, is not being invaded by speculators. "What we're seeing is a lot of collector interest -- not investors and dealers," Mr. Goldberg said. "And that in itself tells you you're not at the top of the market."
Mr. Milas, of the Rare Coin Company, concurred. "I feel this is not a prime time to be a seller," he said, "but really a better time to be a buyer."
But in a book by Peter Tanous called "Investment Gurus," to be published early next year by the New York Institute of Finance, Mr. Price describes how you never want to be buying what the smart people -- George Soros, the Pritzkers and the Tisches, to name a few -- are selling. Lovely as these old coins may be to hold, ardent believers in Mr. Price's strategy may well conclude that now is probably not a good time to buy ancient coins for investment purposes.

GRAPHIC: Photos: One highlight of Michael F. Price's collection of ancient coins is a silver tetradrachm, shown at right and below, minted in Greece in 405 B.C. It has a full-face portrait of Apollo on one side and a kinetic chariot race on the other. The presale value assigned by the auction house is $35,000 to $45,000.; Mr. Price will sell his entire coin collection at auction on Dec. 3 through Stack's Rare Coins. Lawrence Stack, a friend of Mr. Price since childhood, speculated that the investor paid $1.5 million for the coins over the years and estimated that they would bring as much as $2 million.; One prize in the collection is a gold aureus issued by Octavian, with his portrait on one side and an engraving of a crocodile on the other. Minted in January of 27 B.C., it celebrates his defeat of Anthony and Cleopatra. The aureus could bring $80,000 to $100,000. Stack's said Mr. Price paid $70,000 to $80,000 for it a few years ago. (Jonathan Levine)

HEADLINE: IN BRIEFS;
Montclair's Artists Make Their Presence Known

BYLINE: By DEBRA GALANT 

 BODY:
It's official: Montclair is teeming with artists. In what it touts as the first official artist census of a town, the Montclair Arts and Cultural Alliance has tallied the number of artists living in the town, which New York magazine has called "the Upper West Side of the suburbs."
Some 250 self-proclaimed artists responded to the survey, which was circulated this summer, but Paul A. Scipione, a marketing professor at Montclair State University, says that means there are about 1,000 bona fide artists living in the town, which has a population of 38,000. Nearly half of them are visual artists, and a quarter are musicians. But the survey also identified photographers, nonfiction writers, magicians, lyricists, stagehands, choreographers -- practitioners of 40 different arts disciplines. 
 Organizers hope to use the data to obtain financing for an arts center downtown. David Rosenak, a co-chairman of the alliance, argues that artists are engines for economic growth and points to SoHo, Lincoln Center and Theater Row in Manhattan as examples. He added that the survey proved Montclair to be an alternative to New York City for the seriously creative. Artists deserve to "have a home and a family," he said. "We do art here, too." DEBRA GALANT

HEADLINE: Use of Road Salt Endures Despite Concerns

BYLINE: By JIM MOTAVALLI 

 BODY:
DESPITE global warming, snow still falls through the winter on much of the nation, ice still forms on highways and road department spreader trucks still pour salt on the problem.
According to the Salt Institute, a trade association in Alexandria, Va., the Snow Belt consumes 10 million tons of rock salt in an average season, and as much as 18 million tons in a severe winter like that of 1994-95. (The winter of 1995-96, especially snowy on the East Coast, used up 14.4 million tons.) 
 The use of salt is anathema to many environmentalists, who contend that runoff into rivers and streams kills fish and aquatic plants, and that roadside plantings are also affected. "Salting the roads affects every facet of the surrounding environment," said Zev Ross, conservation coordinator for the River Alliance of Wisconsin.
The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection says much of the damage is caused by runoff from improperly stored salt stockpiles. "There is a potential for water supply contamination," said Andrew Briscoe 3d of the Salt Institute, which recommends storage under a roof on an impermeable asphalt or concrete pad, with all runoff channeled into a catch basin. Health officials say highly saline drinking water, with salt concentrations above 250 parts per million, poses a danger to the 15 percent of Americans who are both sensitive to salt and have high blood pressure.
 Until recently, most complaints about salted roads centered on the corrosion they caused to cars and trucks. But modern vehicles offer far better undercarriage protection from road salt than their predecessors had, and the salt controversy has largely become an environmental concern. Still, despite the complaints, salt remains king in the New York City metropolitan area, its use dictated largely by its effectiveness in melting ice and by simple economics. (It costs $30 a ton, compared with $675 a ton for calcium magnesium acetate, a less-corrosive substitute that is used on some bridges in Michigan.)
Sand is even cheaper, at only $5 a ton, but it doesn't melt ice and, maintenance officials say, requires costly and time-consuming cleanup operations come spring.
Joe Doherty, program manager for snow and ice control at the New York State Department of Transportation, says that in an average winter the state spreads 600,000 tons of rock salt, mixed with liquid calcium chloride so that it forms a solution and stays in place, on some 42,000 miles of icy roads.
"We're aware of the environmental problems, and we have cut back," Mr. Doherty said. "We use just enough to do the job."
New Jersey uses the same chemical mix, according to John Dourgarian of the state Department of Transportation. "We use the salt only when it's absolutely necessary, when our pavement-temperature monitoring tells us of the potential for icy conditions," he said. New Jersey stores 141,000 tons of rock salt statewide, and 632,000 gallons of liquid calcium chloride.
Connecticut mixes two parts of salt with seven parts of sand and uses 300 pounds of the mixture for each mile of two-lane road. "We've had some complaints about auto corrosion and environmental damage," said Michael Turrano, transportation maintenance director for the Department of Transportation. "Now we're experimenting with liquid magnesium chloride, which does less damage and saves a lot of cleanup time because it's a liquid." The experimental liquid sells for 85 cents a gallon.
Mr. Ross of the River Alliance says some states are experimenting with environmentally benign alternatives that also have the advantage of being agricultural byproducts. "In Wisconsin," he said, "they're trying to use the waste from cheese production."

HEADLINE: A Dream Engine Becomes Reality

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
TWO Japanese auto makers have succeeded in developing a new type of gasoline engine that can deliver substantial improvements in fuel economy without sacrificing power.
Proponents say that the new engine, known as a direct-injection engine, could represent the next fundamental change in engine technology, as significant as the shift in the last two decades from carburetors to fuel-injection systems. 
 "This engine should be the base concept for all engines in the future," said Akira Kijima, general manager of engine design at the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation. He said the new engine combined the fuel efficiency of a diesel power plant with the power and relative cleanliness of a gasoline engine.
In the direct-injection gasoline engine, fuel is sprayed directly into the cylinder -- where combustion occurs -- rather than being first mixed with air. That allows more precise control of the fuel and air mixture, reducing fuel consumption by 25 to 35 percent, engineers say, while offering slightly greater power and acceleration than conventional engines.
Automotive engineers have been pursuing direct-injection engines for several decades. In the 1960's, a young Mitsubishi engineer, Hirokazu Nakamura, now the company's chairman, visited Detroit to see such an engine under development at the Ford Motor Company. But only now have electronic engine controls advanced enough to allow such engines to become workable.
Some big problems must still be overcome, if the engines are to become as important as their proponents hope. The engines cannot yet meet California's emission requirements, so they will not be offered in the United States in the foreseeable future.
The engines cost more, too, and consumers -- particularly in the United States, where gas prices are low by world standards -- have not been willing to pay extra for fuel economy.
"Obviously, affordability is a big issue," said Gary Smyth, a manager in the advanced powertrain group of the General Motors Corporation in Michigan. He said direct injection was just one of many approaches to reducing fuel consumption.
Mitsubishi is offering its engine, a 1.8-liter in-line four-cylinder, in its new Galant sedan and Legnum station wagon, which went on sale in Japan in late August. Orders have been strong, with 91 percent of Galant buyers and 39 percent of the Legnum buyers opting for the direct-injection engine even though it adds about $300 to the cars' prices.
At the end of next year Mitsubishi plans to introduce the engine to Europe in the Carisma, a car it builds in the Netherlands in a joint venture with Volvo.
Toyota is expected to announce next month that its two-liter, four-cylinder direct-injection engine will be an option in Japan on its Corona sedan.
Even in Japan, where gasoline costs about $3.50 a gallon, consumers have not flocked to a previous generation of engines, known as lean-burn engines, that offer somewhat improved mileage but do not represent a radical technical shift from existing engines. Lean-burn engines have put off consumers because they have less power, which the auto companies say is not the case with direct injection.
Virtually all auto companies are thought to be working on direct-injection gasoline engines, although the Japanese seem to be in the lead. An official of the Honda Motor Company, which prides itself on its engines, said Honda had not decided whether to mass-produce direct-injection power plants.
Tadahiko Takiguchi, a senior managing director of the Mazda Motor Corporation, said the company would first use direct injection in diesel engines. Direct-injection diesel engines have become popular in Europe, and Volkswagen is offering one in the United States in the Passat, a midsize car. But diesel engines are noisier and produce more soot than gasoline engines.
Gasoline engines work by igniting a mixture of gasoline and air, generally at a weight ratio of 15 parts of air to 1 part of fuel. This is done by mixing the air and fuel before they enter the combustion cylinder.
If the proportion of air can be increased, making what is called a leaner mixture, the fuel efficiency climbs. That is because when the fuel ignites, there is more air in the cylinder to expand and to push the piston down.
Lean-burn engines, while mixing air and fuel outside the cylinder, could work with 20 to 24 parts of air to 1 part of fuel. Direct-injection engines use a ratio of 40 or 50 to 1, raising fuel efficiency 20 percent over lean-burn engines.
The key is what is called a stratified charge. Rather than a homogeneous mix of air and fuel, the fuel concentration is kept highest right near the spark plug, allowing combustion to take place. Elsewhere in the cylinder is a lot of air without much fuel.
To accomplish this, the air entering the cylinder is made to swirl so that the fuel, injected separately under high pressure, is swept up in the air flow and carried toward the spark plug without dispersing. The top of the piston, rather than being flat as in a conventional engine, has a sunken area that traps the fuel and brings it to the spark plug.
While this might sound easy, controlling the combustion under different driving conditions requires ultra-precise timing of the fuel and air flow. Direct-injection engines were made possible by modern electronic engine controls and by the ability to simulate fuel and air flow on computers.
The fuel savings are greatest when the engine is idling. In highway driving, or when high power is needed, the stratified approach cannot provide enough power and a homogeneous air-fuel mixture is used.
A big problem is emissions, particularly of nitrogen oxides, or NOx. The three-way catalyst normally used to reduce these emissions does not work for lean air-fuel mixtures, which has kept lean-burn engines from catching on in the United States.
Toyota and Mitsubishi say that in their direct-injection designs, the nitrogen oxide emissions can be reduced by 90 percent through other means, like recirculating exhaust gas through the engine. But even so, the emissions are unlikely to meet American regulations, particularly in California.
Companies like Toyota are trying to develop a catalyst that could operate with lean mixtures, clearing the way for wider use of direct injection. "The lean NOx catalyst will be a major breakthrough," Mr. Smyth of General Motors said.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: "New Technology for Gasoline Engines"
The direct-injection gasoline engine sprays fuel directly into the combustion chamber in each cylinder, where the gasoline mixes with air. The engine provides exceptional fuel economy because the mixture, on average, contains a high ratio of air to fuel. To make the combustion of this "lean" mixture efficient, an indentation in the top of the piston pushes the richest mix into contact with the spark plug.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;
Rerouted Copters Jar Ears to East

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
For the residents of the Upper East Side, already indignant about horn-honking traffic tie-ups at the Queensboro Bridge, the agreement by helicopter operators that went into effect Oct. 1 promised at least one source of peace and quiet: the skies.
But what they got, much like the divisive plan to ease Queensboro Bridge congestion, is an agreement that appears to pit one neighborhood against another. Residents east of First Avenue complain that much of the air traffic that once buzzed west of Second Avenue has been rerouted over their neighborhood. 
 Unlike previous complaints about helicopter noise, which involved seemingly random flyovers on the Upper East and Upper West Sides, the new complaints result from new helicopter routes that took nearly seven months to negotiate. Under the agreement, National Helicopter and Liberty Helicopter, whose tourist flights make up much of the copter traffic over Manhattan, promised to fly higher than before, mainly over water and away from residential areas.
"But they've taken all the copters over there and put them over here," said Patricia Namm Saffran, an artist who lives on the top floor of a six-story apartment building at 65th Street and First Avenue, near the East River. "Have you ever watched a Vietnam War movie? It's like that."
Joy Held, a grant writer who works and lives near 65th Street and York Avenue, counted 36 helicopters flying overhead between 10:30 and 11:30 A.M. on Sunday, Oct. 27. She gathered 93 signatures from neighbors in less than an hour to protest.
Last year, there were nearly 141,000 takeoffs and landings at Manhattan's four principal heliports, according to a study by the city's Economic Development Corporation.
Under the voluntary agreement with La Guardia air traffic control that went into effect last month, National and Liberty agreed to fly at least 100 feet higher than the 1,400 feet now required and fly north over the East River, instead of over Second Avenue, then west across Central Park at 86th Street, instead of anywhere in the park.
Maureen Connelly, a spokeswoman for National Helicopter Corporation of America in Farmingdale, L.I., said that its pilots conformed to the agreement but that corporate and broadcast-media helicopter operators may account for the increased noise. ANTHONY RAMIREZ

LENGTH: 2707 words

HEADLINE: An Economy of Happily Ever After?

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS the White House and Congress prepare to attack the big issues that could shape the economic landscape for years to come, Washington is bathed in something of a rosy glow.
Balancing the budget? Bipartisan cooperation should yield a happier outcome this time around. 
 Saving Medicare from bankruptcy? For all the political Sturm und Drang during the Presidential campaign, the two parties are not really that far apart.
Putting millions of unskilled welfare recipients to work? The nation can create plenty of jobs for everyone.
Most telling of all -- and the presumption on which much of this sunny outlook rests -- is a certain economic cockiness that is rooted in the idea that we do not need to worry about a serious business downturn any time soon. It is a byproduct of nearly six years of steady, if modest, growth; low inflation; strong job creation, and resurgent international competitiveness. Not to mention the stock market, where a post-election continuation of a remarkable two-year run is seen by both parties as a validation of their own policies.
"If we can keep interest rates down with the deficit-reduction package and a balanced budget, keep investing in education and technology and keep expanding trade, I'm not sure we'll be as victimized by the business cycle as we have been in the past," President Clinton said shortly after the election. "We may be able to have much more stable and much longer-term growth than we ever had before."
And that reassuring hue is reflected around the country, where many business leaders and Wall Street investors seem convinced that President Clinton and the Republicans who control Congress will hold each other in check while hammering out solutions to potentially destabilizing problems, allowing the economy to keep rolling along without a recession.
But just how realistic is all this optimism? What if the conventional wisdom both inside and outside the Beltway is wrong?
"I am deeply suspicious of the seemingly smug attitude that we have tamed the once-ominous business cycle, that inflation is dead, and that it is onward and upward for the economy, the markets and for Washington's ability to fix anything and everything that ails America," said Stephen S. Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley.
Indeed, we have heard this sanguineness before, often just before the next downturn. Citing the example of the late 1960's -- when policy makers and economists convinced themselves they could fine-tune the economy through any potential peril, only to lead the nation into a deep mess in the 1970's -- Mr. Roach said it was folly to believe that steady growth and low inflation, or policies predicated on them, could be maintained indefinitely.
"A balanced budget amendment can work if the economy stays on a steady-state path of stable growth and low inflation," he said. "As soon as the economy deviates from that path and the Fed takes a shot at controlling the economy and we have a recession, which is obviously going to happen in the next few years, the path gets altered permanently."
To be sure, there are solid reasons for optimism. In Washington, both parties profess to have learned painful lessons about fiscal recklessness, and the Federal Reserve's monetary policy since the last recession has been seen as exemplary. Out in the real economy, there are signs that long-term structural changes have seriously dampened inflation.
Still, it seems a fair question to ask: Is Washington really prepared to cope if a nasty or even moderately unpleasant shock comes along? If it is not, what will it mean for consumers who are amassing staggering amounts of debt, former welfare recipients who are holding down their first jobs, investors who keep plowing money into the stock market and companies that are counting on nothing but steady expansion ahead?
"The probability of a recession is at a historical low point," said Jerry J. Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers. But if the positive scene he envisions gives way to an economic downturn or a return of political gridlock in Washington, he said, the outlook will be very different: a rise in economic populism and possible trade protectionism, and a downturn in corporate profits and stock prices, all contributing to an environment of slower growth.
INDEED, for those with a degree of skepticism, rosy assumptions are a challenge to history. The current expansion, at five years and eight months, is already the third-longest of the century, after the nearly nine-year boom in the 1960's and a slightly shorter one in the 80's. Should it last until 2002, the target date agreed on by both parties for eliminating the deficit, it would be the longest on record.
But if a recession were to occur, either as a result of a mistake in monetary policy or because of an external shock like a sharp rise in oil prices, it could wreak havoc on the effort to balance the budget.
In the economic assumptions that underpin their budget plans, neither the Administration nor the Republican leadership explicitly makes any provision for a downturn. Both sides, though, say their budget numbers reflect the long-term growth potential of the economy, and thereby take into account, to some degree, the possibility of cyclical ups and downs.
On the assumption that a balanced budget plan is implemented, the Administration, in its most recent projections, sees growth running at 2.3 percent for most of the next decade; the Republican estimate is 2.2 percent. Both sides are updating their figures in preparation for next year's negotiations. Because of the upbeat economic outlook, Republicans are most likely to revise downward the estimates of the deficit in coming years.
But consider some bad-news possibilities examined by the Congressional Budget Office. If growth were to prove just one-tenth of a percentage point lower than projected each year, it would leave the deficit $16 billion bigger than it would otherwise be by 2002. If the inflation rate were one percentage point higher than projected each year, it would add $22 billion to the deficit by 2002. If interest rates were one point higher than projected each year, it would mean the deficit would be $53 billion higher in 2002.
And in a study earlier this year of forecasting accuracy, the budget office found that its own five-year economic projections starting in the late 1970's proved overly optimistic -- but not as much so as those made by successive administrations.
EVEN before such long-term concerns can arise, however, there are more immediate political realities at play.
"Don't forget, this isn't easy," said Charles A. Gabriel Jr., a political analyst in Washington for Prudential Securities. "Right now the optimism is very generic, and people are willing to engage in a suspension of disbelief. But there's still residual bad will from the campaign, and there are radically different ideas about how you balance the budget."
Start with the looming fight over the proposed balanced budget amendment, which Republicans strongly favor and plan to make an early test of their legislative strength in the next Congress. The Administration is opposing the measure, despite Mr. Clinton's suggestion this month that he is resigned to its passage.
To Republicans, enshrining fiscal rectitude in the Constitution would remove from the political process all the excuses for why the nation's books cannot or should not always balance. To many Democrats, including Mr. Clinton, that is exactly the problem with the amendment. They maintain that despite the bond market's insistence on public parsimony, the Government should retain the ability to use fiscal stimulus, albeit judiciously, to arrest and reverse a recession, as it has for more than six decades. (The amendment, as most recently drafted, would require a three-fifths vote in both the House and the Senate to run a deficit.)
Indeed, the fight over the amendment has highlighted this question: To what degree should fiscal stimulus be seen as the inevitable and proper response of the Federal Government to a downturn?
If a recession, and a resulting shortfall in tax revenue, came during a concerted push to balance the budget, the Government would be left with a conundrum. Cutting spending further -- or raising taxes -- to keep deficit reduction on track could make the downturn steeper or longer as a result of fiscal contraction. On the other hand, providing some fuel for a recovery through a fiscal stimulus would risk the wrath of the bond market, which could send interest rates higher.
Proponents of sticking to deficit reduction, even in a downturn, argue that fiscal policy was becoming modestly tighter during the 1990-91 recession, and does not appear to have exacerbated the situation. Moreover, they say, the experience of 1993, when the Clinton Administration raised taxes as part of its deficit-reduction plan without noticeably crimping the economy, suggests that the benefits in lower interest rates outweigh whatever drag that fiscal policy puts on the economy.
"The old Keynesian formula, if it was ever true, has proven no longer to be valid," said Martha Phillips, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a fiscal watchdog group.
But there is an even bigger question in how other policy initiatives, like welfare reform and rescuing Medicare, fit into the balanced budget effort.
The welfare legislation put together by Congressional Republicans and signed by President Clinton last summer will require several million people, most of whom have little or no work experience and few skills, to find jobs in the next several years. Mr. Clinton has proposed employer subsidies and tax credits to encourage companies to hire welfare recipients. But the nation's ability to absorb a big addition to its labor pool will depend, in large part, on how robust the economy remains.
IF the economy softens, the Federal Government will come under additional pressure from the states to provide more money to help create jobs. But at a time when Congress will be looking to cut spending, it is doubtful that Washington will be willing to provide much more cash. As it is, Republicans are counting on the new welfare system to save $54 billion from now through 2002 by cutting specific programs like food stamps and by providing block grants to states, which will have wide discretion in how to allocate the funds.
Moreover, Congress is likely to find it politically difficult to increase spending to help welfare mothers find jobs if an economic downturn raises the unemployment rate, which is currently 5.2 percent.
"If a tight labor market is the best employment program we have and it doesn't work very well, then what are we going to do under more normal times, when labor markets are not so tight?" asked Richard Kogan, an analyst at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research group in Washington that studies programs for low-income people.
Mr. Kogan said that the experience in states with very low unemployment, like Michigan and Wisconsin today or Massachusetts in the 1980's, suggested that even strong demand for labor generated few private-sector jobs for welfare recipients. Yet spending money to create public-sector jobs holds its own perils, especially in a downturn.
"If the United States were to put a fairly hefty amount of money into public-service employment, this raises the question of what you do for people who lose their jobs in a downturn but are not welfare moms," Mr. Kogan said.
A recession, he added, would not only mean hardship for many people who previously would have benefited from social welfare programs. It would also mean that the role of welfare programs in stabilizing the economy would now be limited. .
Welfare spending has always risen more or less automatically as the economy has turned down. But under the block grant system, with its assumption that states bear a responsibility to stretch their funding as far as possible without running to Washington for more, it is questionable whether welfare spending would rise enough to act as a meaningful fiscal stimulus.
The uncertainty about whether Congress will provide more money for welfare is just one of many questions about what a balanced budget agreement will look like. At the top of the list is whether such an agreement would prove credible as the years went by, especially if economic conditions changed.
"While I am fairly confident that a major deficit-reduction package will be enacted next year, I am equally sure that the measure will not be sufficient to achieve balance by 2002 anyway," said Robert D. Reischauer, a former head of the Congressional Budget Office who is now with the Brookings Institution.
"We will dress this proposal up in estimates that suggest it will achieve balance," Mr. Reischauer said. "But then economic weakness, or a failure to achieve the spending cuts that are called for, or unexpected increases in entitlement spending, or some permutation or combination of those factors will insure that we don't reach balance by 2002. If we want to reach balance, we will either have to enact further spending cuts or further tax increases."
MR. CLINTON'S current budget proposal has been roundly criticized by Republicans for containing overly optimistic economic assumptions and for back-loading the really painful reductions onto the last two years of the plan -- after Mr. Clinton has left office.
The President's plan, Republicans say, is full of gimmicks that allow him to minimize or postpone cuts in nonmilitary discretionary spending -- the one-sixth of the Federal budget on which nearly all the reductions proposed by both parties will have to fall.
(Most of the rest of the budget is either fixed or much harder to cut in one way or another: interest on the national debt, which must be paid to avoid a Government default; Social Security and Medicare, which have huge and powerful political constituencies to defend them against assault, and the Pentagon, which has already absorbed deep cuts.)
The Administration, for example, forecasts that corporate profits will be much stronger in coming years than does the Republican plan -- 8.6 percent of gross domestic product in 2002 versus 7.4 percent -- which helps the White House to project higher tax revenues. The Administration also counts on phasing out some of its proposed tax cuts after 2000 -- a step that some analysts said amounts to a stealth tax increase.
The Republican plan has its own problems -- including a question of political viability. While Republican leaders say they have a more credible plan, they rely on even deeper spending cuts than the Administration and continue to promise tax relief.
Neither party at this point has a great deal of enthusiasm for plunging back into the political maelstrom surrounding Medicare. But they have little choice. First up is the necessity for a short-term fix to avert insolvency in the hospital-insurance portion of the program, which is projected to go into the red in 2001, and to address the continuing drain on the general budget from rapid increases in payments for physician care.
Mr. Clinton has proposed dealing with the short-term problem largely by cutting payments to health care providers. The Republicans, wounded by Mr. Clinton's portrayal of them during the campaign as willing to hurt the elderly to fix the program, are unlikely to make any bold proposals of their own.
THE two parties will probably ask an independent commission to propose a solution to the long-term problem: how to reorganize the program to plan for the surge in demand -- and costs to society and the Government -- that will accompany the aging of the baby-boom generation. And eventually, Washington will have to begin looking seriously at how to revamp Social Security to cope with the same demographic phenomenon.
All of which suggests a sobering conclusion: that despite the current rosy economic outlook, the divide between President Clinton and the Republicans over how much pain the electorate will tolerate to solve the nation's problems could well mean that these issues and their progeny will dog America beyond 2002.

HEADLINE: The Racism We Condemn

BYLINE: By Glenn C. Loury; Glenn C. Loury, a professor of economics at Boston University, is the author of "One by One From the Inside Out: Essays and Reviews on Race and Responsibility in America."

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
We emerged from a dream-like political campaign, in which almost nothing of substance was said about racial issues, only to find that from St. Petersburg, Fla., to Pittsburgh the problems of alienation, resentment, contempt and enmity are still with us. And now, out of Texaco's corporate headquarters, out of its executive suite in White Plains, N.Y., comes evidence of unacceptable racist attitudes, and even the possible obstruction of justice.
Reactions across the political spectrum to the Texaco discrimination scandal illustrate the cynicism so rife in American race relations. Civil rights leaders called for a national boycott and demanded that Texaco resolve its discrimination case, expand its diversity training programs and increase its dealings with minority-owned businesses. 
 Peter I. Bijur, Texaco's chairman and chief executive, has moved with breathtaking speed to appease these demands. Texaco agreed on Nov. 15 to pay more than $140 million to settle the lawsuit brought by its minority employees, and the company also pledged to turn its affirmative action programs over to a committee largely appointed by outsiders. This is all well and good, but much of what Mr. Bijur has so eagerly agreed to will do little to lessen racial tensions, inside his company or anywhere else.
Consider "diversity training." Texaco has pledged some $35 million for employee workshops on race relations. Yet Texaco had already held such workshops. (Indeed, during the executive meeting recorded on tape, Robert Ulrich, the company's treasurer, called African-American employees "black jelly beans" -- a reference to something said at a diversity seminar!)
I doubt that anyone astute enough to rise to the top of a major corporation really believes that diversity workshops are the way to get blacks and whites to work together with mutual respect. But few will now dare give candid expression to that view. Hiring a diversity consultant is a primary way for the company to show its concern for minority sensibilities.
Or, consider the corporate focus on so-called economic development -- that is, buying more products from minority-controlled businesses and spending more on advertising in black media outlets. Jesse Jackson, who organized the nationwide boycott of Texaco, has for years made this economic brokering a centerpiece of his strategy. But this "development" rarely trickles down to rank-and-file black folk, and it does very little for those minority workers within the white-owned companies. But it is a relatively inexpensive way for companies to assure civil rights leaders that their demands have been met.
So much for the liberal solutions. But there is cynicism enough here to cover both sides of the political spectrum. For years, conservatives have been saying that we should be a color-blind society, that taking race into account in the workplace inhibits achieving this goal and that racial discrimination should be punished, case by case, wherever it exists. That sounds quite reasonable until one begins to think about the following question: How are we supposed to know whether discrimination exists?
At Texaco, fewer than 1 percent of those earning more than $106,000 a year are black, and not one of the 49 highest-paid executives is black. From these numbers alone, it seems reasonable to conclude that blacks have a hard time attaining positions of real power. Indeed, Mr. Bijur effectively acknowledged that the numerical racial imbalances constitute a problem, ipso facto.
Yet conservatives who advocate a color-blind America think that one cannot prove discrimination with statistics. The color-blind argument insists that looking at employment numbers is wrong, that one should focus instead on the treatment of individuals.
But outsiders or lower-level employees are seldom privy to the complex deliberations and the raft of subjective judgments that go into the selection of the top people in any large, complex organization. Texaco, for instance, had used secret lists to designate which employees had the potential to be senior managers. In proving acts of discrimination, would conservatives always insist that African-Americans produce "hard" evidence like secret tape recordings of senior managers making racist or racially inappropriate remarks?
Of course, corporations also have an interest in collecting their own evidence -- to establish that they do not discriminate. So companies across the country will most likely be paying greater attention to work-force diversity, especially in the upper ranks. And the careers of more and more managers will now probably be determined in part by the number of minority employees they recommend for promotion.
Making the advancement of minority employees a measure of a manager's performance is particularly offensive to the color-blind idealists, since it practically guarantees that some promising blacks will receive preference over equally promising whites.
Another name for this practice is "affirmative action." Experience in the Army, and in a number of large businesses, has shown that some program of this sort -- which does not lower standards but concentrates on finding and promoting qualified blacks -- is probably the single most effective way to eliminate informal barriers to black advancement. Though it may not be politically correct on the right to say so, the Texaco case provides ample support for this point of view.
It is strange that this is a message that conservative theorists must learn from their more pragmatic political allies in business. Yet, I find it stranger still that the deep problems in the inner cities, issues that lie at the core of much racial tension in the country, go untouched despite the frenetic activity by whites and blacks in the Texaco case. It would appear that, when civil rights leaders manage to get rich and powerful Americans to pay attention to racial justice, the most profound and enduring injustices are not part of the conversation.
That $35 million which Mr. Bijur has promised the diversity consultants would do wonders for some inner-city school systems. But asking a penitent business organization to take some responsibility for uplifting the black poor does not appear to be part of the "development package." And, I admit, my proposal is a radical idea.
It's too bad that it takes insensitive and insulting remarks to make powerful businessmen acknowledge their sins and make their amends. And it's too bad that, even then, one does not presume to ask them to surrender too much of their wealth or power.
