HEADLINE: Health Cares;
Harry and Louise Were Right, Sort Of

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

 BODY:
REMEMBER the frightening things that were going to happen if the Clinton health care plan passed? Like losing the right to choose a doctor or a health plan? How about the slow death of old-fashioned medical insurance and the like-it-or-not march into health maintenance organizations? Not to mention restricted benefits and even rationing.
Harry and Louise, the fortysomething couple created by the Health Insurance Association of America, vented their anxieties about these possibilities -- and, by extension, millions of other Americans' fears, too -- in a series of television commercials in 1993-94, fretting around the kitchen table as health care legislation was furiously debated, and ultimately killed, on Capitol Hill. Now, with the benefit of three years' hindsight, it can be said: Harry and Louise were at least half right. There were indeed big changes in their future. 
 Imagine the surprise around that kitchen table today: The proportion of American workers in managed care plans has grown to 74 percent, up from 55 percent in 1992, when Bill Clinton was beginning his first campaign for health care reform, according to a recent survey of employers by KPMG Peat Marwick.
As for choice, the study found that employers of all sizes have reduced the number of alternative health plans available to their workers over the last year; among mid-size employers, 52 percent now offer their workers only one plan.
"People believed that if the Clinton plan died the managed care revolution would die with it, that you'd be able to keep your choice of doctors," said Bob Blendon, an expert on public opinion and health at Harvard. "People were calling the Clinton plan socialized medicine because they were going to force you into an H.M.O., and yet we've had this huge growth of managed care since the plan died."
The supposedly halcyon days of fee-for-service medicine, covered by traditional indemnity insurance, have clearly passed for most Americans: Just 26 percent of the people who get their insurance through work are enrolled in the traditional plans, down from 71 percent in 1988. And hospital stays are now so strictly limited by some insurers that Congress recently stepped in and required that new mothers and their babies get a minimum stay of 48 hours.
Still, Louise did not have to deal after all with the new "billion-dollar bureaucracy" that she so often worried about, because the Government was left out of this revolution.
And a lot of analysts argue that, in retrospect, this turned out to be a good thing -- and not just because of the abiding American mistrust of bigger government. Insurance companies and employers had the expertise and the stomach, these analysts say, to do things that elected officials could not do -- like closing underused hospitals, restricting the freedom to choose a physician and taking other measures to squeeze down the costs of health care.
Uwe Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton, argues that President Clinton ought to be thankful the dirty work was done by somebody else.
"Maybe it's not a bad thing to have it come out that way -- because otherwise government would have gotten a terribly bad name for things that are not really government per se, but things that needed to be done," Mr. Reinhardt said. "Someone had to say to doctors and patients, you cannot have all these resources all the time." He concluded that "the managed care industry has become the flak-catcher for all the things that Clinton would have been the flak-catcher for."
Moreover, there is little dispute that in the realm of cost control, which was always the primary concern of many of the policy elites anyway, the private sector has been quite successful. And it restrained health care spending without the unwieldy, confusing new Government entities that Harry and Louise -- and, judging from the polls, millions of other Americans -- had found so unappealing.
No big new alliances, the much-maligned purchasing cooperatives that Mr. Clinton and the chief architect of his doomed plan, Hillary Rodham Clinton, envisioned as the middlemen between consumers and the insurance companies. No complicated cost controls or global budgets.
 
 
 
Private Choices
 "While it's certainly true that there's been a powerful movement in the direction of managed care, these are private choices rather than government choices," said Bill Gradison, president of the Health Insurance Association of America, which led the industry's fight on Capitol Hill.
"Moreover, in an employment situation, if you're really unhappy with the choice your employer made, you often have a union to go to bat for you, or an employee benefit department. You may not always prevail, but it's easier than going to some distant government agency."
But would Harry and Louise be happy with the way things turned out? Do they even realize how much has changed? A survey published last summer for the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, a health research organization, suggested that most Americans do not perceive the great slowdown in health care costs, not to mention the profound changes in the marketplace.
Still, there are signs that at least Louise, who was usually the one reading up on health care in the commercials while Harry stood by supportively, would have recognized that there was a price to be paid for letting employers and insurance companies work their will.
Paul Starr, another health care expert at Princeton who worked on the Clinton plan, said, "What we're getting is managed care but without the consumer protection and patients' rights that people have a right to expect."
He noted that the alliances, unlike employers, would have been required to offer consumers a variety of health plans, and would have provided many more safeguards for consumers' rights.
Drew Altman, president of the Kaiser Family Foundation, a health-care research group, said, "There are a lot of people out there who feel, or should feel, that they fought off the Government monster only to find themselves faced with changes in the marketplace that they care about a lot more."
Defenders of managed care systems, like Karen Ignagni, president of the main industry group, the American Association of Health Plans, argue that consumer satisfaction within these networks is actually quite high.
"Consumers now have access to a product that is more affordable, that has very low out-of-pocket costs, that has more comprehensive benefits and that stresses prevention," Ms. Ignagni said. Where people have a choice, as is the case with Medicare recipients, they are increasingly choosing managed care plans, she said.
But there is clearly some backlash brewing among the Harrys and Louises of America. Accordingly, Congress has shown a new willingness to regulate the industry in the wake of a flurry of complaints, ranging from shortened hospital stays to restrictions on what doctors in some managed-care networks can tell their patients about treatment options. The law requiring 48-hour maternity stays is only the beginning, many analysts say.
"The big, somewhat underreported health care story of 1996 is that the Congress, in a bipartisan manner, has moved into regulating health insurance, which they have not done before -- and there wasn't a dime's worth of difference between the Democrats and the Republicans on this," said Mr. Gradison.
President Clinton, for his part, has announced that he will appoint a panel of experts to recommend ways of protecting consumers in this fierce new health care marketplace. This kind of bipartisan consensus reflects the broad popularity of these regulatory moves, analysts say.
In other words, Government may not look so frightening to Louise these days, as she sits at her kitchen table fuming over her latest dispute with her new health care plan. Perhaps she has a few regrets. She may even be muttering, once again, her mantra from three years ago:
"There's got to be a better way."

HEADLINE: Meridel Le Sueur, 96, Reporter And Children's Book Writer

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Meridel Le Sueur, who reported on the plight of the poor during the Depression and celebrated the free spirits of early Americans in her fiction for children, died on Nov. 14 in Hudson Memorial Hospital in Hudson, Wis. She was 96 and had lived in the hospital's residential unit in nearby St. Paul, Minn., for the last few years.
Miss Le Sueur, a native of Murray, Iowa, grew up among the radical farmer and labor groups that informed her youth, like the Populists, the Farmers Alliance and the Wobblies, the Industrial Workers of the World. Her first story was published in a literary magazine in 1927, and she kept writing into her 90's. 
 Her mother and stepfather, Marion Wharton and Alfred Le Sueur, were ardent socialists who imbued her with an idealism that never left her. Just beyond their Middle Western kitchen the world was filled with eloquent radicals: Big Bill Haywood, Eugene V. Debs, Lincoln Steffens and Emma Goldman.
Largely self-taught, Miss Le Sueur teamed with kindred souls in literary communal relationships and, sent East by her mother, moved in with Goldman while attending the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. She came to know John Reed and met Theodore Dreiser and Edna St. Vincent Millay at Mabel Dodge's literary salon.
She won acclaim in 1927 for her story "Persephone" and again in 1934 for "The Horse," a strange, powerful novella. With her distinctly personal style of journalism, she rendered detailed observation with a sense of political urgency. She reported on bread lines and unemployment offices and on deserted mining towns and desolate farms.
Blacklisted during the McCarthy period, she continued to write, turning out experimental prose works, novels and poems and storing them in her basement in Minnesota.
Her highly praised children's books, in which she interwove history and regional lore in poetic prose, included "Little Brother of the Wilderness: The Story of Johnny Appleseed," "Nancy Hanks of Wilderness Road: A Story of Abraham Lincoln's Mother," "Sparrow Hawk" and "Chanticleer of Wilderness Road: A Story of Davy Crockett."
Miss Le Sueur's own wilderness relented as collections of her prose began to appear in the 1970's. Her recovery culminated in "Ripening: Selected Work, 1927-1980" (Feminist Press, 1982), a clear reflection of how she had listened from childhood to the stories of immigrants and Indian women.
An early milestone in her career was "North Star Country" (1945), the story of how Minnesota and Wisconsin were settled. It was reprinted by the University of Nebraska Press in 1984. Her recent work included "The Dread Road" (1991), a novel about a mining strike in Colorado.
She is survived by two daughters, Rachel Tilsen of Hudson and Deborah Le Sueur of Graton, Calif.; 8 grandchildren; 27 great-grandchildren, and 2 great-great-grandchildren.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Obituary (Obit); Biography

HEADLINE: Baltimore Journal;
Popular TV Show Helps Enliven a Neighborhood

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Nov. 23

 BODY:
As Sharon Bondroff walked home one day in the spring, she was horrified to see a man lying on the sidewalk and another man standing over him, pointing a gun. A police officer stood at the corner, apparently oblivious to the scene behind him. Ms. Bondroff raced over.
"Aren't you going to do anything?" she screamed. 
 "You think I'd just be standing here if that was real?" the officer replied.
Ms. Bondroff laughed at the retelling of the incident. In a flash, she said, she realized what was going on. Ms. Bondroff lives in the Fells Point section of Baltimore, a historic waterfront area of cobblestone streets and old brick buildings just east of downtown.
In recent years, as Baltimore's urban renaissance has spread outward from the Inner Harbor area, Fells Point has attracted not only new residents, bars, shops and restaurants but also the production company for "Homicide, Life on the Street," the critically acclaimed police drama on NBC-TV on Friday nights.
What Ms. Bondroff saw that afternoon was the taping of a murder scene, and like many Baltimoreans -- momentary palpitations aside -- she could not have been more delighted.
For five television seasons, "Homicide" has staged all sorts of crime and mayhem around Baltimore, in the process making the city as much a star of the show as its actors. But unlike many other movies and television shows that are shot on location, "Homicide" does not pack up and leave when the eight-month shooting season ends.
Most members of the "Homicide" crew, about 120 people, have made Baltimore their home, working out of the show's Fells Point production office on Thames Street, a converted recreation center, and pumping as much as $27.5 million a year into the local economy, according to the Maryland Film Office, a state agency. The principal cast members rent homes or town houses for the season, and one, Andre Braugher, a Chicago native, who plays Detective Frank Pembleton, lives here year round with his wife and young son.
"It's a nice town," Mr. Braugher said the other day, as he left the production office. "The people are nice. They are more amazed at our presence here than people in Los Angeles or New York, but they are uniformly pleasant."
As a major city between New York and Washington but without their cultural and political clout, Baltimore has always been proud of its assets -- the Orioles of professional baseball, world-class medical centers, ethnic neighborhoods and, in recent years, a thriving film community.
Inspired in large measure by Barry Levinson, a Baltimore native who set his films "Diner," "Avalon" and "Tin Men" in Baltimore, other film makers have come here and used the city's ample supply of electricians, carpenters and art designers. Mr. Levinson created "Homicide" with Baltimore in mind, and lately, other directors, like Jodie Foster, Clint Eastwood and Terry Gilliam, have shot parts of movies in the city, using many of the same production people.
"This is a wonderful opportunity to show off the city that I live in," said Vince Peranio, the "Homicide" production designer, who grew up in south Baltimore and who broke into show business as an art director for another well-known film maker from the city, John Waters.
It is Mr. Peranio and Kathi Ash, the "Homicide" location manager, who are primarily responsible for wedding the city to the show. They drive around town each week, searching for buildings and neighborhoods that might fit future scripts. Often, local residents call the "Homicide" office to offer their homes and businesses for shooting.
But just as the city has taken to "Homicide," so have the featured actors to the city, as residents and as volunteers for charity projects and public school programs. Richard Belzer, who plays Detective John Munch, has been particularly active, helping raise money for Johns Hopkins Hospital, the Boarder Babies Project and the local public radio station, WJHU.
Not all Baltimoreans are enamored of the presence of famous actors and their colleagues. Celie Ives, who owns Celie's Waterfront Bed and Breakfast, a small inn across the street from the "Homicide" headquarters, has complained about blocked streets and the city's willingness to accommodate the production company's needs for parking. Her guests are often forced to use a parking lot several blocks away.
"I haven't lost business," Ms. Ives said. "But for the elderly, it's difficult to walk up and down the street to a parking lot."
Other local business owners say Ms. Ives represents a minority view. They contend that despite the occasional disruptions caused by parking restrictions, "Homicide" has taken a cherished place in city lore, alongside the Orioles and steamed crabs.
"In general, they have been very good for the city," said Steve Bunker, the owner of China Sea Marine Trading Company and president of the Fells Point Community Organization. "The only complaint I ever hear is parking, and that's a minor inconvenience. But they have provided jobs in a community that desperately needs jobs, and they have been good neighbors.
"Besides," he added, "there was never much parking down here, anyway."

HEADLINE: Walter E. Hoffman, 89, Dies; Judge in Agnew Proceeding

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Judge Walter E. Hoffman, who took his turn at historic proceedings that disgraced Vice President Spiro T. Agnew and branded a fellow judge as a felon, died on Thursday at Sentara Leigh Memorial Hospital in Norfolk, Va. He was 89.
At his death, he was a senior judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia, sitting in Norfolk. President Dwight D. Eisenhower appointed him to the court in 1954. 
 In 1973, Mr. Agnew went to his political demise in a kickback scandal. He stood accused of a lucrative ward-heeling scheme that dated from his public service in Maryland, where he rose to Governor, and continued with payoffs he reaped while Vice President.
Mr. Agnew engaged in convoluted bargaining with Federal prosecutors to avoid prison and pleaded no contest to a tax evasion charge. Judge Hoffman, presiding over the proceedings, accepted the plea, and Mr. Agnew resigned as part of the bargain. The judge, who would have preferred a prison sentence, made clear that he regarded the nolo contendere as equal to a guilty plea.
Mr. Agnew died on Sept. 17 at 77.
In the case that put one of his peers into the dock, Judge Hoffman was assigned to Reno in 1984 to handle the final corruption trial of District Court Judge Harry E. Claiborne of Las Vegas, Nev.
The drawn-out proceedings proved highly contentious, with Judge Claiborne fighting to the last. But he was found guilty of tax evasion, the first sitting Federal judge to become a convicted felon. Judge Hoffman sentenced him to two years in prison and a $10,000 fine, and Judge Claiborne was removed from office.
Walter Edward Hoffman was born in Jersey City and graduated in economics from the University of Pennsylvania in 1928. He received a law degree from Washington and Lee University in 1931 and went into private practice in Norfolk.
He rose to leadership in the Virginia Republican Party and headed the state Republican convention in 1952, straddling a split between Eisenhower and Taft Republicans. He sided with General Eisenhower and supplied support at the National Convention that propelled the General to the White House.
Upon his appointment to the bench, Judge Hoffman was faced with defiance of court-ordered school integration. As he issued rulings to implement the Supreme Court mandate ending racial segregation, some schools shut down rather than comply, and a cross was burned on his front lawn.
He was shunned by friends but persisted in his duty, finally issuing an ultimatum to officials to open the schools to black students or go to jail. In later years, he described his dealing with the Agnew case as easy compared with the personal trial he underwent during school integration.
In recognition of his service, the Norfolk courthouse bears his name.
Judge Hoffman is survived by his wife, Helen Caulfield Hoffman; a daughter, Carole Lee Hancock of Norfolk; a son, Walter E. Jr., of Virginia Beach, Va.; two stepdaughters, Ann B. Shumadine of Norfolk, and Elizabeth B. Libey of McLean, Va.; a stepson, William P. Ballard Jr. of Norfolk; a sister, Mary H. Vellines, also of Norfolk; five grandchildren; seven step-grandchildren, and two great-granddaughters.

HEADLINE: Taking Sides in the Superstore Fight

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Even as the political battle over the future of superstores in New York City grew heated and occasionally rancorous last week, executives at Price Costco, a major name in warehouse stores, congratulated themselves for opening two new stores in Brooklyn and Queens, where sales easily matched expectations.
More than 12,000 people streamed through the doors of the company's new outlet in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, on its opening day. And in 12 hours, nearly two tons of ground beef and 12,000 breakfast pastries were sold. 
 But consumer demand for discount retailers and superstores has never been in dispute. Instead, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal to allow megastores in certain manufacturing areas faces intense opposition because of concerns that the plan is too sweeping and would remove citizens and the City Council from the approval process.
Mr. Giuliani has maintained that his plan would further the city's economic revival by filling underused industrial areas while drawing retail businesses to the city. City officials have estimated that as many as 57 megastores would open in the next 10 years, recapturing $1.5 billion a year in retail sales that now flows to the suburbs, and creating more than 13,000 jobs.
But Council members made it clear that the proposal would have to be significantly scaled back to win approval when the Council votes on it next month. At the same time, the issue became fodder for next year's mayoral election, with the Mayor running radio commercials supporting the changes and Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President and a likely mayoral contender, running commercials against them.
Lost in the political bickering are many basic arguments concerning the arrival of superstores in New York City. Interviews with urban planning experts and New Yorkers who believe the zoning changes would have profound effects on the city's economy and quality of life revealed a broad range of opinions. There were assessments that city officials had for too long neglected the evolution of the city's manufacturing and retail economies, and that poor and minority neighborhoods had suffered for it. And there were fears that the age of megastores would drive industrial businesses out of the city, and that homeowners and their rights were being forgotten in favor of moneyed developers. VIVIAN S. TOY

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Michael Beyard -- Senior director for research at the Urban Land Institute
 
"Neighborhood strips may have to make some changes, but the major competition for big box stores is other big box stores and regional malls, not neighborhood stores."
While megastores have been a staple in suburban communities for years, the industry has just recently turned to cities like New York as its last frontier, said Michael Beyard, an expert on commercial development at the Urban Land Institute, a Washington-based research organization.
But while many community groups fear that megastores will hurt New York's neighborhood shopping strips, like they have hurt Main Street shopping districts in small towns across the country, Mr. Beyard said the concerns were unfounded.
"Small towns in other parts of the country have been devastated by the arrival of big box stores, but New York is an entirely different situation because you have more than seven million people and an enormous market," he said. "Adding five million square feet of retail is a blip, and you're adding it to neighborhoods that are being underserved right now." The Mayor expects more than 10 million square feet of big box retail space to open in the next 10 years.
Mr. Beyard said he believed that existing businesses would be able to compete with the megastores.
"I don't see it as the death knell for smaller stores," Mr. Beyard said. "Neighborhood strips may have to make some changes, but the major competition for big box stores is other big box stores and regional malls, not neighborhood stores. People in New York will always want to be able to walk to their neighborhood stores for certain things. You might walk to the corner hardware store for a box of nails because you don't feel like driving to Home Depot for it, or maybe it's a quart of milk at the corner store because that's all you need."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Mark Kupferberg -- Co-owner of Kepco Inc.
 
"The concerns we have about the issue are not a threat to leave but an expression of how much we want to stay. But if the Mayor's policy change goes through, it will put a lot of pressure on us to leave."
Kepco Inc., which employs about 250 people, has produced electronic equipment in Flushing, Queens, for more than 50 years, and its owners said they would like nothing more than to stay there for another 50 years, or more. But when Home Depot opened a 24-hour store next door a year and a half ago, Kepco's landlord called almost immediately to start renegotiating the company's lease, which expires in 1998.
"The concerns we have about the issue are not a threat to leave but an expression of how much we want to stay," said Mark Kupferberg, one of Kepco's co-owners. "But if the Mayor's policy change goes through, it will put a lot of pressure on us to leave."
He said that retail businesses would drive up rents in manufacturing areas, and he warned that the most desirable sites for megastores would naturally also be the best manufacturing sites, making it more difficult for industrial businesses to stay in the city. "I don't think the city understands that this is an unintended consequence of what they're doing," he said.
"The planning people say our company's concerns are not valid because there are technicalities that would keep our site from being developed for retail," Mr. Kupferberg said. "But I find that hard to evaluate, and all we can deal with is the reality of trying to get a deal to stay where we are. And as of right now, the city is not geared to deal with businesses like ours, and there aren't a lot of people to help us with the hurdles that we face."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Brendan Sexton -- President of the Municipal Art Society
 
"The point is we need to get an urban orientation for superstores in terms of design, placement and community input."
City dwellers may share many of the same concerns and desires as their suburban counterparts, but cities offer very different challenges to the superstore industry, said Brendan Sexton, president of the Municipal Art Society.
"In a lot of ways I think we're more ready for superstores than they are for us," he said.
When Bradlees opened in Union Square in 1995, for example, it was stocked like a suburban store, with lawn mowers and other suburban accouterments.
"They have since changed their whole buying strategy," Mr. Sexton said. "But the point is we need to get an urban orientation for superstores in terms of design, placement and community input."
An influx of sprawling stores in manufacturing areas will neither change the face of retailing nor wreak havoc on industrial businesses, he said, but the city should retain some form of community review because of the character of its neighborhoods.
"There's real opportunity to improve the economy, and this could be very profitable for New York City," Mr. Sexton said. "But we are a city of neighborhoods, each of which is unique and should be handled in its own way."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Patricia Dolan -- Vice president of the United Civic Council of Queens.
 
"We are fearful that this is the opening salvo in a campaign which is going to ultimately take away all community review and input on siting decisions."
The Giuliani administration maintains that the existing rules have discouraged some businesses, like supermarkets and discount retailers, from going to the city, while not regulating others, like large Home Depots or Toys "R" Us stores. If creating a more sensible and uniform approach means taking away the ability of some communities to arbitrarily reject megastores, so be it, officials have said. They add that the proposal actually offers more protection for many areas.
To community leaders like Patricia Dolan, vice president of the United Civic Council of Queens, which represents about 70 neighborhood groups, that kind of attitude does not bode well for the ability of residents to control the quality of life in their neighborhoods.
"We are fearful that this is the opening salvo in a campaign which is going to ultimately take away all community review and input on siting decisions," she said.
City planning officials, she said, have given short shrift to the fact that many manufacturing zones abut residential areas or may even have homes mingling with businesses inside those zones.
"This entire proposal has been designed to meet the needs of developers and not the needs of people who live in the neighborhoods that make up the city," she said. "At issue here is the way people believe government should work, and either it's an open process where people's opinions count and they have a right to have a say over their own lives, or they don't."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Kathy Goldman Executive director of the Community Food Resource Center.
 
"To compete, stores will have to pick up a little and change what they're doing. They'll get modern refrigerators, put in a deli counter, and maybe the meat will look fresher and more produce will be available."
The Community Food Resource Center, an advocacy group for poor and minority neighborhoods, has often been at odds with the Giuliani administration over benefits for the poor. But on the megastore issue, the center has been one of Mayor Giuliani's strongest supporters.
Poor neighborhoods, where people spend a disproportionate amount of their income on food, desperately need more food stores, and large supermarkets would offer better prices and more variety, said Kathy Goldman, the executive director of the center.
"Low-income people now are leaving the city in droves, using car services, car pooling, taking buses and doing whatever they can to get to better selection and fresher produce in stores in Westchester, New Jersey and Long Island," she said.
"The impact on these neighborhoods is going to be very big, because a lot of these manufacturing zones aren't that far out of their neighborhoods or they're within a short bus ride."
She also said that competition from a 24-hour Pathmark or a Price Costco store would improve the quality of existing food stores.
"To compete, stores will have to pick up a little and change what they're doing," she said. "They'll get modern refrigerators, put in a deli counter, and maybe the meat will look fresher and more produce will be available.
"When you're the only game in town, you can get away with offering less and charging more. Changing that means that people who are constrained will finally be able to get more for their buck."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Mitchell L. Moss -- Director of New York University's Urban Research Center.
 
"Retail is a very dynamic sector because it's constantly restructuring, and New York City cannot afford to act like an island and only have some types of retailing and not others."
The current zoning for manufacturing areas was enacted in 1974 and the prohibitions on certain kinds of retail developments, primarily supermarkets and department stores, were intended to try to keep existing industries and to lure new ones.
But Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University, said that manufacturing businesses nevertheless continued their exodus and that what remained of the sector has evolved in recent years. But the city, he said, has yet to respond to those changes.
"New York's land use system has really been very inert and the city has been excessively concerned with maintaining space even if those activities aren't there any more," he said.
"The decline in manufacturing has been profound but there also has been a resurgence of small-scale manufacturing because of immigrant entrepreneurs and a growing demand for customized products, and it doesn't require the same enormous spaces that industrial businesses used to. The economy and manufacturing in New York City has changed and so should our land use policies."
He said that city regulations have inhibited economic development and that officials have also ignored the fact that the retail industry has evolved.
"Most of the great famous names like Best & Company, Gimbels and Wanamaker's are all out of business," he said. "Retail is a very dynamic sector because it's constantly restructuring, and New York City cannot afford to act like an island and only have some types of retailing and not others."

HEADLINE: High Schools Get Less Aid Than Elementary and Middle Ones

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
The superintendents who oversee New York City's elementary and middle schools have long complained that the city's sprawling high schools soaked up a disproportionate share of precious education dollars.
So it came as a surprise last week when Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, in the most exhaustive accounting in the system's history, concluded that the high schools actually get much less -- an average of about $398 less per student than the elementary schools and $760 less than the junior high schools. 
 "They would always say we got more money," said John J. Ferrandino, who retired recently as the supervising superintendent of city high schools. "I would always say we didn't. No one would believe me."
Until now.
While individual school spending in the city's 32 community school districts has been publicly scrutinized by previous chancellors, none has done so as extensively as Dr. Crew and none has included the city's high schools.
An examination of those 1996 figures, sifted out of the 41-volume report prepared by Dr. Crew's budget staff and the accounting firm Peat Marwick, shows several discrepancies in spending for high schools.
High schools with the biggest concentrations of poor students, for example, spend less city tax money in the classroom than those with more middle-class students, an analysis of the figures shows. But the schools with poor students more than make up for the difference with the sizable supplements they receive from Federal, state and private grants. It was not immediately clear from the data whether the city was adjusting its allotment to these schools because they get these grants.
The figures also confirm, in many cases, the suspicions of some of the city's larger high schools: that the batch of small, experimental academies that have proliferated in the last four years often receive more money per student.
But the findings that created the greatest buzz within the system last week were those that, for the first time, measured budget allocations in the high schools against other schools in the city. The breakdown shows that high schools receive an average of $6,831 per student, compared with $7,229 for elementary schools and $7,591 for the junior high schools.
In many systems across the country, the high schools spend the most money per pupil because high school students require more extensive guidance services to prepare for college and take more expensive and specialized courses, like advanced-placement chemistry, that have smaller class sizes.
New York City is, apparently, different. While the reasons are varied and not always clear, the most salient factors are the share of budget cuts the high schools absorbed in the last three years, the severe overcrowding of high school buildings and the need to provide meals to younger students.
Part of the difference can be explained by size. It costs less per student to administer and supply teachers to a large high school because those costs can be divided among more students. And when taken together, the city's high schools are filled to nearly 140 percent of capacity, a degree of overcrowding that dwarfs most elementary and middle schools.
Thus, the salary paidto the principal at Newtown High School in Elmhurst, Queens, is spread over 4,573 students, while that at Public School 209 in Whitestone must be absorbed by just 511 students.
Line items like food also increase the budgets of elementary and middle schools, where students eat in school more often. In Community School District 9 in the South Bronx, for example, the $356 spent per pupil on food was more than double the average spent on food in all Bronx high schools.
But per-pupil spending in the high schools was also affected by something far less fixed: the more than $1 billion in budget cuts imposed in the last three years. And while no school in the system was spared, Chancellor Crew and his predecessor, Ramon C. Cortines, tried to preserve the spending on children in the younger grades because they are at a critical stage in their development.
Some elementary schools gave up music and art classes, as well as assistant principals. But many high schools were hit harder. They lost elective courses like psychology, sociology and advanced-placement history; had to raise guidance-counselor caseloads to 1,000 students or more; were forced to eliminate junior varsity sports and bands, and, in dozens of cases, even pared the school day to below the five and a half hours required by the state, drawing a reprimand.
"The whole system has been underfunded," said John Soldini, an economics teacher at Tottenville High School in Staten Island and the vice president for academic high schools in the United Federation of Teachers. "But the high schools were placed in even greater peril."
The budget report released last week makes clear that there are wide variations in spending among the high schools -- particularly in schools with large pockets of students living below the poverty level.
A computer analysis by The New York Times of the Chancellor's data on 153 high schools -- 90 with high concentrations of poverty and 63 with low concentrations -- found that those with the highest number of poor students spent an average of $348 less, per pupil, in city tax money on direct classroom services.
But in the end, the spending in schools with the poorest students was $480 more per student because those schools get more of the private, state and Federal grants. Most of those dollars came from the Title 1 program, which last year added $323 million to budgets of schools with poor students so they could hire teachers, teachers' aides and after-school counselors.
In preparing the report, the Chancellor's aides said they were not able to specify how many of those supplemental dollars reached the classroom, in the form of teachers' salaries and textbooks, and how many provided instructional support outside the classroom. The omission is substantial, given that that money represents 13 percent of the system's $8.2 billion overall budget. The Chancellor said he hoped to account for the money in future reports.
And what of the system's bumper crop of experimental, alternative academies? How did they fare financially?
Designed around themes like the city's museums or its underground infrastructure, more than 100 such schools have attracted several thousand students in the last four years. The amount allotted per student at three Bronx academies -- Fannie Lou Hamer Freedom ($10,340), South Bronx Academy for Community Leadership ($9,212) and Wings Academy ($8,796) -- exceeded that at two larger, more traditional high schools, William H. Taft ($5,790) and Bronx Science ($6,463).
But again, school size plays a role. And far more analysis will be required to determine if the schools that spend more per student actually get their students to achieve more -- the ultimate measure of how well their dollars are spent.
"We've got to caution people not to make too much out of the financial numbers alone," said Robert Berne, the vice president for academic development at New York University and a longtime student of the Board of Education budget. "This report only increases, exponentially, the number of questions that can be asked."

HEADLINE: CONCERN IS VOICED OVER THE QUALITY OF ECONOMIC DATA

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Almost every business day, the Government produces economic statistics that affect financial decisions, from buying a new house and expanding a business to monetary policy and the Federal budget.
But a senior Administration official warns that the quality of those statistics has been eroding steadily, increasing doubts about how accurately they depict economic activity. That, he says, is hampering policy makers and threatening to undermine the confidence of investors. 
 Others warn that remedies could involve reducing the growth of Government benefits, including Social Security, and raising taxes.
The official, Everett M. Ehrlich, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, said in an interview on Friday: "Our statistical system is failing to keep track with a rapidly changing economy. The data we provide give us a good picture of where we are in the business cycle but risk misrepresenting such long-term phenomena as inflation, productivity growth and the economy's changing composition."
A panel appointed by the Senate is expected to report in early December that the Consumer Price Index overstates inflation by as much as two percentage points, which would cost the Government as much as $634 billion over the next 10 years, primarily because of inflation-linked payments for Social Security and other Federal benefit programs.
Government officials say their methods have become outdated in the face of the increasing globalization of business and the growing economic role of services, which are generally harder to measure.
There are more down-to-earth reasons, too. The price index, for instance, tends to overstate costs. It does not reflect the fact that people tend to substitute, say, chicken for steak when the price of beef rises, and that they are more frequently buying during sales and at discount stores rather than paying full price.
Mr. Ehrlich is proposing a three-year, $150 million program to combat the problems.
But while some proposals by officials and experts would stir passion only in an accountant, others, like changes in the price index that could reduce Social Security checks -- could raise considerable opposition.
Concerns about the quality of the systems used to produce the figures were also voiced recently by the Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee, which sets short-term interest rates and influences the rates on loans, from mortgages to corporate bonds.
In September, facing a difficult decision on interest rates, committee members complained about poor data, especially on productivity, a basic element of economic well-being, according to minutes of the meeting released recently..
The committee's minutes, which did not identify any participants but reflected publicly expressed views of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, called figures on productivity in services "implausible" and suggested that they had been considerably understated.
Among other things, raising the measure of productivity would increase figures for the gross national product and result in a calculation of real wages that would show an increase, rather than the stagnation that has been widely reported.
Widespread agreement among economists that inflation measurements were inaccurate led the Senate Finance Committee in 1995 to appoint the commission to study the Consumer Price Index, which is used to determine the annual cost-of-living increases for Social Security and other Federal programs and for indexing Federal tax brackets.
Headed by Michael J. Boskin of Stanford University, the commission, also plans to make recommendations on how to fix the price index. That may well set up a confrontation with the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department, which compiles it and has denied charges that it is widely off the mark.
Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, took exception to Mr. Ehrlich's appraisal of Government statistics, contending that those produced by her agency, at least, are getting better despite a budget that has not risen in real terms since the late 1970's.
But she acknowledged knotty conceptual problems and said it was now harder to keep the gauges up to date, partly because economic activity is more concentrated in sectors like services, in which activity is much harder to measure.
She also acknowledged that more people are complaining about statistical flaws, largely because of the increased "pocketbook implications" of relying on the figures to adjust everything from Social Security to union contracts.
"The stakes certainly have gotten higher," Ms. Abraham said.
Joel Popkin, an economic consultant, said the system had deteriorated because companies were less willing to respond to Government requests for data, partly because those businesses have fewer people to do such work. Also, budget cutbacks have made it ever harder for the Government to attract high-caliber economists and statisticians.
Mr. Ehrlich of the Commerce Department, who is in charge of one of the biggest Government agencies that gather economic statistics, said that unless the measurement flaws were corrected, financial markets could lose confidence in the Government's data.
"Good data allow markets to anticipate economic policy and, by doing so, make it more efficient," Mr. Ehrlich said.
He said more attention needed to be paid to measuring intangibles like insurance coverage, rental activity, wholesale trade and on-line transactions. The numbers also fail to capture fully such "phantom" production as a construction company building something for itself instead of for a paying customer.
One measure of how the system has failed to keep up, he said, is that the number of businesses that defy traditional categorization has grown considerably.
Government hardware also needs to be improved, Mr. Erlich said, to minimize the risk of a disastrous computer failure.
He estimated that any crisis from data erosion was "years, but not decades," away.

HEADLINE: In Manila, Asians Pore Over Washington's Inner Truths

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: MANILA, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Anyone wondering why Asian business leaders showed such intense interest in the inner workings of the American political system this fall -- and such eagerness to contribute to both Democrats and Republicans in record amounts -- could find the answer this week in the sprawling ballrooms of the Shangri-la Hotel here.
In the days leading up to President Clinton's arrival this evening with the leaders of 17 other Pacific Rim nations, the region's billionaires and bankers, its industrial planners and its real estate investors poured into this city to assess how a second Clinton Administration will affect billions of dollars worth of new investments from Indonesia to California. 
 There was, of course, the usual cliches about doing business in the global village. But it was quickly evident that many of the villagers are more nervous than ever about Washington's increasingly central role in setting -- or vetoing -- the rules of global trade. After years of insisting that America is a diminished world economic power, Asian executives have concluded that decisions made in Washington are more important to their prosperity than ever.
So while Mr. Clinton was scuba diving off the Great Barrier Reef, the acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, was besieged with questions about the conditions under which Washington would let China join the World Trade Organization -- an issue little discussed in the United States but one on which fortunes could be made or lost here.
When Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor spoke today about the emergence of a "Clinton Doctrine" -- "not mutually assured destruction and a policy of containment but mutually assured prosperity and a policy of engagement" -- clusters of Asian executives debated whether these were code words for more pressure to open markets.
Business executives around the world have always had a close interest in Washington, of course, not least because the United States remains the world's richest market. But as the controversy over foreign campaign contributions so vividly demonstrated, that interest is taking on a new form.
As American foreign policy increasingly intrudes on how other nations organize their economies -- insisting, for example, that Indonesia change the way it treats factory workers -- foreign executives say they feel increasingly compelled to make themselves heard from Capitol Hill to the White House.
"You see this phenomenon all over Southeast Asia these days, and it reminds me of the political awakening of the Japanese 30 years ago," Thomas Hubbard, the American Ambassador to the Philippines and one of the State Department's most experienced diplomats in the region, said this week as his embassy scrambled to prepare for Mr. Clinton's arrival. "There is this sudden awareness that every large company has to deal with the way Washington works, and not just the executive branch. That's largely a good thing."
But it also carries considerable risks, as Mr. Clinton and his aides have learned the hard way in the past two months.
In an interview before he left for Asia, Mr. Clinton acknowledged that the flip side of growing economic engagement in Asia is that his Administration has become the target of far more vigorous foreign efforts to influence policy, which he and his aides insist the White House has resisted. But those efforts are in full view this weekend in Manila.
With the United States enjoying a robust economy, and Japan mired in a recession and a banking crisis, business leaders who once eschewed American politics now say they have reluctantly concluded that they must begin lobbying in Washington.
The assumption here is that that is exactly what James Riady, Mr. Clinton's old friend from Arkansas and head of one of the largest financial conglomerates in Indonesia, the Lippo Group, had in mind when he helped ease a top aide into the Commerce Department.
Until this year Mr. Riady had been a regular at the annual Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting, which Mr. Clinton inaugurated in 1993 in Seattle. Previous meetings of the organization, established in 1989, featured trade ministers rather than heads of state.
Two years ago, at the meeting in Jakarta, Mr. Riady held a flashy party for visiting Arkansans, and Mr. Clinton stopped by. This year, perhaps deciding that a little discretion is in order while the Congressional investigators circle, Mr. Riady did not show up. But his competitors did, and they said they envy his accomplishments.
"We were impressed that James was so well connected in Washington," said a top executive of an Indonesian conglomerate that competes with Lippo. "What was the problem? He did things the Asian way: He used his connections, but he was subtle about it.
"And you know, now if you cannot show your clients that you have a deep connection in Washington, you might as well shut down your international business."
That new regard for Washington as a hub of economic decision-making is a very different note than the one commonly struck throughout Asia just three or four years ago.
At the time, the United States was frequently portrayed as a declining power, a large but shrinking slice of the global economy. (Statistically, it still is.) Japanese politicians talked about "lazy" American workers, and the image stuck. Executives confidently proclaimed that the move toward open markets was making governments less and less relevant.
But an unexpected combination of forces -- from the surge in American financial markets and the recovery of its industrial prowess, to the Clinton Administration's sometimes intemperate threats of trade sanctions, to Washington's dominant role in the new World Trade Organization -- have restored the United States to a central role that many Asian executives say they occasionally find reassuring, and often find infuriating.
Money talks louder than free-trade promises in Asia, and the United States has generated surprisingly large amounts of it. Everyone agrees that much of the $1 trillion to $1.5 trillion required over the next decade to finance huge infrastructure developments will have to come from the United States.
"That money is going to have to come from someplace, and clearly Japan is not going to be in a position to provide as much of it as people once thought," said Maurice Greenberg, the chairman of American International Group Inc., one of the largest American insurance firms in Asia.
Supplying some of that capital should give the United States considerable power throughout the region. In fact, the 400 business executives who gathered here to put together recommendations to the leaders of the group's 18 "member economies" -- the term "member nations" is banned to sidestep delicate issues like the inclusion of Taiwan -- heard warnings today that there could be a backlash against the West.
"There must be careful management of these relationships so there is no fear of technological dominance" by Western software and computer firms, said Manuel Pangilinan, chairman of the First Pacific Company in Hong Kong. His words echoed those of American executives who warned in the 1980's that the United States was in danger of becoming a "techno-colony" of Japan.
America's new prickliness in the trade realm also explains Asia's new fixation on who is making decisions in Washington. While publicly lauding its commitment to settling trade disputes through international forums like the World Trade Organization, the United States has often short-circuited that system, threatening China, Japan and other nations with sanctions unless they cracked down on software piracy or opened their auto markets. Many Asian countries call this bullying, or worse.
On Friday Rafidah Aziz, the Trade Minister of Malaysia and one of the most outspoken critics of the United States, looked directly at Ms. Barshefsky, the trade representative, when she cited "countries that try to impose their norms and standards" on the world.
In fact, only a few years ago Malaysia was pressing its Asian neighbors to join an alternative organization that pointedly excluded the United States, among others. That effort to build an Asians-only organization faded, but Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir bin Mohamad, was well received today when he argued against too much American-style trade liberalization.
Sounding like many Americans in the last days of the Presidential campaign, Mr. Mahathir said he was worried about those who use their "economic strength or political influence" to attempt to change a nation's policies. But he was clearly not talking about mysterious donors to the Democratic National Committee pressing their case in the White House. Instead, he seemed to be talking about all those mysterious Americans -- hundreds of them -- lurking in the Manila's luxury hotels.

HEADLINE: Clinton Opens Tense Talks With the President of China

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MANILA, Sunday, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Trying to calm a stormy relationship, President Clinton met with President Jiang Zemin of China today. It was their fourth set of talks in neutral settings during Mr. Clinton's Presidency.
The two men met in the Green Room of the Central Bank of Manila, stopping first to pose for pictures, shaking hands warmly and smiling. 
 Mr. Clinton rejected suggestions that he should not meet with Mr. Jiang because of human rights problems in China, saying, "We're doing the right thing to have this meeting."
At the meeting, as expected, "the two presidents have accepted each other's invitations for state visits," Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman said. The time and the sequence of the state visits are still to be determined, he added.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	 The President's Goals
 By STEVEN ERLANGER
 MANILA, Nov. 23 -- President Clinton arrived in a steamy Manila tonight with some tense business to transact with the leaders of a coming superpower, China, and a sometimes difficult ally, South Korea.
As he arrived, his Cabinet secretaries for foreign and trade policy were pressing toward an agreement to reduce tariffs radically on information technologies so important to the United States and the booming Pacific Rim, which is having its fourth economic forum here.
The sprawling 18-member Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, APEC, which includes such diverse members as Australia, China, the United States, Mexico, Hong Kong and even Taiwan, represents two-thirds of all American global trade and 50 percent of the world's gross domestic product.
The group's yearly meetings, since Mr. Clinton raised them to summit level in 1993, are a kind of economic and diplomatic convention. The bilateral meetings between leaders and ministers are considered more important than the effort to remove all obstacles to free trade among members by 2010 for industrialized countries, and by 2020 for others.
The most drama here is expected to come from Mr. Clinton's meeting with the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin. The meeting could mark the restoration of relatively stable relations after three years of conflict and confusion over Taiwan, human rights, trade, copyright, nuclear and missile proliferation and other disputes.
After the groundwork laid by Secretary of State Warren Christopher last week in Beijing, the two leaders were primed to announce a series of higher-level meetings, beginning with Vice President Al Gore's going to China in the first part of next year, then Mr. Jiang's going to the United States on a long-delayed state visit, then a visit by Mr. Clinton to China in 1998.
But their meeting must also deal with continuing conflicts over trade, human rights, Taiwan, Hong Kong and reports of continuing Chinese arms deals with Iran and Pakistan.
Mr. Clinton was also ready to repeat the United States' eagerness for Beijing to join the World Trade Organization, but only if China moves more sharply to open its markets.
The United States wants a relationship with China that embodies regular meetings, as it used to have with the Soviet Union, where even profound differences can be discussed and the relationship will not be frozen by any one issue, whether it be human rights or trade.
Mr. Clinton will also meet the Japanese Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, to try to reassure him that closer ties to China will not be at Japan's expense.
But he will have to work hard to reassure the South Korean President, Kim Young Sam, whom he also meets on Sunday, that the United States supports South Korea in its rage over North Korea's recent submarine incursion.
South Korea demands a North Korean apology before continuing with the American-brokered deal to replace North Korea's military-related nuclear plants, which were producing weapons-grade materiel, with less dangerous South Korean ones.
The Americans, who are desperate that the North Korean nuclear deal not founder, have said they expect a gesture of contrition from North Korea, but South Korea continues to demand more, while wanting further reassurance from Mr. Clinton about the permanence of the American commitment to defend South Korea.
"It's now one of our weirder relationships," an American official said, "but it's no less dangerous for that."
The American economic push this year is on freeing up trade in information technologies, and APEC foreign and trade ministers agreed over the last two days to try to reach a global deal to phase out nearly all tariffs on computers, software, memory chips and telecommunications equipment by 2000. Such trade represents $500 billion a year today, and should reach $800 billion by 2000.
There are disagreements among the countries here, including Malaysia and China, about how many protections to retain for certain forms of technology and for how long, with even the United States seeking special treatment on some items to try to protect smaller companies.
But Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor today pronounced himself delighted with a unanimous statement that urges all members of the World Trade Organization to conclude a deal by its first big meeting less than three weeks from now in Singapore.
The real American target for pressure is the European Union, which has considerably higher tariffs on key elements of information technologies.
Negotiations on the World Trade Organization pact are continuing in Geneva, and American officials wanted "clear political will" and "a deadline" coming out of APEC, said the acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky. She said a deadline would help push other parties, especially the European Union, to negotiate in earnest.
"Without a deadline, no one would ever wrap it up," a senior American official said.
The officials tried to play down APEC's refusal over two days of negotiation to endorse a zero tariff in 2000. Instead, the joint statement by group's ministers said only that they "endorsed the efforts at W.T.O. to conclude an information technology agreement" by the Singapore meeting "and urged all other members of the W.T.O. to work toward that end."
Ms. Barshefsky said she never tried to get an endorsement of the terms of the agreement, which she said is predicated on the general understanding of zero tariffs by 2000. Every country will have specific reservations over certain products and the timing of gradual tariff reductions, she said, which is what the Geneva negotiations are about.
Her main intention, she repeated, is to bring pressure on all countries to finish the negotiations by the Singapore meeting.
Mr. Clinton, who deals on Monday with the summit meeting itself at Subic Bay Freeport, the former American naval base, is unlikely to get much deeper into the issue. His main task is to reassure all of Asia that America remains a Pacific power pursuing its economic interests while providing a generally benign security guarantee for the region.
But his main success will come if he can reassure Asia that the United States has figured out a policy to deal with the realities of a huge, transitional China that is already dominating the security and economic planning of every Asian-Pacific nation.

HEADLINE: Beware a Global Economy's Many Consequences;
Strong Franc, No Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Global Forces Batter Politics" (Week in Review, Nov. 17) blames "globalization" for the incongruence of the restrictive fiscal and monetary policies that France has pursued while unemployment rates are rising. In so doing, you accept the excuses of French politicians who would like to avoid blame for dubious decisions related to the "strong franc" policy, decisions that have a lot to do with national pride and little with economic forces. 
 The lack of success of policies to fight unemployment in France is related more to lack of interest in tackling its causes than to any global force. When Alain Madelin, the French Finance Minister, was forced to resign last year after he insinuated that civil servants had too many privileges, the reason was not turmoil in the capital markets but the refusal of large sectors of French society to acknowledge that the enormous and hyper-regulating public sector comes at a price.
The inability to adjust one's life style to one's own resources is neither new nor a consequence of globalization. While French and European politicians justify their inability to lead their countries through difficult choices, their citizens must live with Eurosclerosis.
 
LUIS GARICANO
Chicago, Nov. 17, 1996
 
The writer is graduate student in economics at the University of Chicago.

HEADLINE: THE BIG CITY;
Virgin Territory

BYLINE: By John Tierney

 BODY:
MICHAEL AULT IS content. At 1 A.M., he is sitting in his new SoHo club, Chaos, a loft on Watts Street whose red velvet settees are currently occupied by an extraordinary concentration of beautiful young women with long legs and high cheekbones. "Models are the most wonderful turbocharged creatures," Ault says. "I worship them." Today, like all days, he has been on the phone with dozens of them.
 
 "We have a couple of thousand models' names in our data base," says Ault, a veteran of clubs-of-the-moment like Spy, Merc Bar and Surf Club. "If they need anything - a roommate, an apartment, a boyfriend, a lawyer, an agent, a place to sleep in the Hamptons, a plane ticket - you provide it. Then, when you call, they come by the hundreds. The difference between a local bar and the hottest club in New York is the models." He looks around the room. "Don't they put a smile on your face?"
 They do. But I try to stop gawking long enough to consider Ault's metaphor: turbocharged creatures, which by coincidence is precisely the topic I came to discuss. I've brought a copy of "The Dynamo and the Virgin," the famous chapter from the 1918 autobiography "The Education of Henry Adams." During my days as an American-studies major, I never quite understood the scholarly reverence for Adams's laments about American society - to me, it all sounded like the grumping of a Boston Brahmin appalled to discover that going to Harvard and being named Adams was no longer enough to guarantee a man the Presidency. But his dynamo-Virgin theory was at least original. It was occasioned by Adams's visit to the hall of dynamos at the Exposition of 1900 in Paris. Watching the 40-foot machines churn out electricity, he decided that they had supplanted the force that had driven all previous civilizations, that had built cathedrals and inspired artists: the power exerted by the Virgin and Venus and ancient fertility goddess.
 "The Woman had once been suspreme," Adams wrote. "She was goddess because of her force; she was the animated dynamo; she was reproduction - the greatest and most mysterious of all energies. ... At the Lovre and at Chartres ... was the highest energy ever known to man, the creator of four-fifths of his noblest art, exercising vastly more attraction over the human mind than all the steam-engines and dynamos ever dreamed of; and yet this energy was unknown to the American mind. An American Virgin would never command; an American Venus would never dare exist."
 This is not an easy theory to explain in a noisy club, particularly when a six-foot model in a halter top is dancing five feet away. But Ault is a quick study. "He's right about the pwoer of virgin deities," Ault says, reaching into his shirt to show me the ancient Greek coin he wears around his neck. "This is the face of Athena, powerful virgin - the protector of heroes like Hercules and Jason. She's the ideal protector for my business. Women are the core of this machine. When a beautiful woman - I'm talking about a '12' - walks in the room, everyone responds, women as well as men. Beautiful women come here because they want to look at other beautiful women."
 "Virginal" may not be the first word that one associates with today's models, but there actually is a certain purity to their cultists' devotion. Doormen and bouncers at clubs have the same mission as the guards at the Temple of Vesta: to ward off lustful males. The're trained to exclude unattached herterosexual men and eject anyone who bothers the models. These women are to be admired, not touched, like the celestial images of Claudia Schiffer and Linda Evangelista hovering above Times Square. "Models are visual bait," says Baird Jones, a gossip reporter at The Daily News who spent 20 yearsas a party promoter for Studio 54 and other clubs. "Once you get them into a club or a restaurant - the easiest way is to bribe a low-level booker at an agency, someone who's handling the B-list of young girls just starting out - the rest of the food chain follows. The odd thing is that most of the men don't even make an effort to talk to them. Even the serious playboys, the rich guys who live to chase models, often aren't that interested in sex. They mainly want their fellow wolves to see them walk in with a model. The term they use is 'shoulder candy.' "
 The objects of this veneration know that a model can go out at night carrying just enough money for the first cab ride: meals, drinks, cigarettes and spending money will be provided by her followers. The profusion of offerings seems suspect at first - you mean all I have to do is show up? - but the models soon realize how much of New York's economy depends on their standing around doing nothing. And thye come to appreciate proper forms of devotion.
 "I feel protected here," says Kara Sands, a model with the Elite agency who has joined Ault at the table tonight. "They make sure nobody hits on me. They take care of anything I need. Today Michael was on the phone with me for an hour as I was babbling about my breakup with my boyfriend. When someone does that, you're glad to show up and help the club's business."
 I try to explain Adams's theory about the decline of the Virgin's power in modern America. Sands shakes her head. "Women have always had power," she says, "and they always will."
 An American-studies major might still argue that Adams was correct in his day about the dynamo: that contemporary New York is obsessed with female. icons because it's a postindustrial culture ruled by images instead of machines. But I think Sands has it right. The Virgin's power has never waned. It may have been displayed more discreetly during the Victorian era, but there were plenty of establishments not unlike Chaos. To understand the force that drives humans to build dynamos - or cathedrals or computers - it's essential to observe where the builders spend their earnings at the end of the day. If Adams had known the right places to go after dark, he could have beheld visions far more powerful than anything in the hall of dynamos. They might have even put a smile on his face.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Lebedtime Story

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Russian general, standing ramrod stiff in a business suit, waved aside another plate of American food. "Bread, salt and onions," he requested.
After a round of interviews with and speeches at many of America's opinion leaders, Gen. Aleksandr Lebed -- peacemaker of Chechnya, surprise political challenger to Yeltsin, recently bounced out of the Yeltsin Kremlin after pushing for too much power -- was relaxing at a reception given in the Bethesda home of businessman Fred Bush. 
 When a diplomat gently brought up the subject of Russia's negotiations with Ukraine about the former Soviet Black Sea fleet, Lebed said he was part Ukrainian and told a little joke:
"Russian soldier was carrying a wounded Ukrainian on his back. Ukrainian says, 'I am suffering, I want to die, shoot me.' Russian takes out his gun but then says, 'I have no ammunition.' Ukrainian says, 'I'll sell you a cartridge for two rubles.' "
I ingratiated myself by laughing at this thigh-slapper, and then put a political question to him: Why had Lebed taken the thuggish and corrupt Aleksandr Korzhakov, recently forced out as Yeltsin's confidant and bodyguard, to be his close adviser?
Eyes narrowed, the pugilist's face hardened: "I am here," he said, holding his flattened hand up to chin level, "and Korzhakov is down here," dropping his hand well below his waist. I took that to mean that Lebed was affirming his alliance with yesterday's worst influence in the Kremlin, but that he was using Korzhakov and not vice versa.
Lebed's purpose in coming to America was to impress Russia's moneyed interests with his ability to reassure U.S. investors that a Lebed regime would not be bad for business. Up to now, he has seemed like a loose cannon, gruffness concealing ignorance of economics, prone to ultranationalist gaffes.
He is the first Russian politician forced to make a good impression here, as well as in Russia's outlying provinces, to win the financial support centered in Moscow. Lebed makes no bones about it: "One information flow goes through the Russian regions and then returns to Moscow," he tells U.S. executives, "and the second flow goes abroad and then again returns to Moscow, and there they meet."
How goes the flow from here? After 40 minutes seated in a corner with a few members of the journalist persuasion, Lebed left the impression that he is not the political blockhead he was cracked down to be. He is well briefed to give answers Americans want to hear.
Thus, he is "not going to have a hysterical fit because of NATO's expansion" (plays well here) but talks vaguely of a "new security system," as if Russia were threatened by the West (plays well at home). His next trip will be to China.
Sprinkling salt on his bread but passing up the onions, Lebed said he agrees with Grigory Yavlinsky on economic reform (though the two could not get along) and warns that Yeltsin chief of staff Anatoly Chubais, whom he despises, is no free marketer.
The general has tried to assure Jewish groups here that he was "misquoted" about there being only two religions in Russia, though his subsequent praise of Jews as "managing money well" assuaged nobody. But when Susan Eisenhower asked why he should be President of Russia one day, his reply -- drawing on experience in Moldova and Chechnya -- had both power and appeal: "I stop wars."
To test for candor, I asked about the deal he made early this summer to split the anti-Yeltsin vote. Did Yeltsin give him money and television time in the final week that enabled Lebed to come on suddenly and take 14 percent of the vote? Answer: "No. I raised that money from my own sources." Baloney.
Early assessment: Lebed is smarter than expected, absorbent of briefings and trainable in the avoidance of deep water. He exudes the command presence that strikes some as arrogance, others as leadership. If this work in progress gets to power, I suspect he would shuck the impressive advisers he brought here with him for the likes of the repugnant Korzhakov.
When I passed along a plate of cookies, the General raised a hand in firm denial: "Sweets are for the weak."
