SECTION: Section C; Page 11; Column 1; Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1152 words

HEADLINE: Malraux Joins the Greats in the Pantheon As the French Exult in the Pride of Image

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 24

 BODY:
It is no doubt a measure of the importance that France gives to culture that the 20th anniversary of the death of Andre Malraux was celebrated here this weekend as a great national occasion. After all, it was Malraux who, as De Gaulle's Culture Minister from 1959 to 1969, decreed that the arts should be part of the lives of ordinary Frenchmen and women and not simply of the Parisian elite.
But there is more. Jacques Chirac, the first Gaullist President in two decades, was also eager to tap the Malraux legend, to boost his own eroded popularity and revive Gaullist dreams of French grandeur. He therefore presided over a grandiose ceremony in which Malraux's remains were transferred to the Pantheon, France's final resting place for illustrious men (and, so far, one illustrious woman, the physicist Marie Curie). 
 "Andre Malraux, you incarnate more than anyone the Gaullism desired by the General, a Gaullism neither of left nor of right, but of France," Mr. Chirac said on Saturday on the Pantheon steps, addressing Malraux's coffin shortly before it joined those of Voltaire, Rousseau, Hugo and Zola. "Because you lived your dreams and made them live in us, Andre Malraux, enter the Pantheon of the Republic."
Yet, for all that, the best explanation for the interest awakened by the anniversary may well lie in France's current mood of pessimism about its economic and political future. The country needs a hero to lift its spirits, and who better than Malraux? Writer, philosopher, adventurer, lover, bon vivant, anti-fascist and anti-Nazi fighter, orator and politician, he personified that almost-mythical figure, the man of letters who is also a man of action.
True, with Churchill and Roosevelt now well enshrined as 20th-century icons for Britons and Americans, France is not alone in turning past heroes into symbols. Yet there is something peculiarly French about the veneration of Malraux: many of the French like to think that he mirrors their own romantic, passionate, anarchic and idealistic free spirit, that he represents the sort of swashbuckling image they would like to project.
The past few weeks, then, have been turned into a veritable feast of Malraux nostalgia, with newspaper and magazine articles galore as well as television documentaries, radio debates, new books, university seminars, posters in squares and subway stations and even a new 3-franc stamp that reproduces a famous photograph of Malraux by Gisele Freund (albeit with his ever-present cigarette airbrushed as a nod to the times).
Intellectuals have also waxed poetic. "This melancholy, restless and impatient young man, consumed by a dream of grandeur, taking in revolutions like a bird of prey in search of space to spread his wings, this is the Malraux preserved in legend," Jean-Marie Rouart, a writer and editor of Le Figaro's literary supplement, wrote. "No one else has embraced the century with such impetuosity, passion and intelligence."
The real Malraux is more difficult to pin down. As a writer, he cannot be compared with, say, Proust, Gide or Camus; as a philosopher he was overshadowed by his ideological foe Jean-Paul Sartre; in the French Resistance, there were many greater heroes, and as a Gaullist politician, the former leftist opposed the May 1968 student movement. Yet his varied life and many talents give both leftists and rightists something to admire in him.
Born in Paris on Nov. 3, 1901, he dropped out of school at 17 and was soon drawn into the lively Paris world of writers, artists and intellectuals. In 1923 his sense of adventure took him to Asia, but the trip proved disastrous. He, his new wife, Clara Goldschmidt, and a friend were arrested for looting a temple at Angkor Wat in Cambodia. A three-year prison term was later reduced to a one-year suspended sentence.
He nonetheless continued to travel regularly to Indochina and China, where he saw the beginning of the power struggle between the Kuomintang and Mao Zedong's Communists. He used what he saw of an insurrection in Shanghai as the basis for his third and perhaps most successful novel, "La Condition Humaine" ("Man's Fate"), which in 1933 won the Goncourt literary prize, France's highest literary honor.
By then he was a committed leftist, denouncing Germany's new Nazi regime as early as 1933 and, three years later, organizing an international air corps to help the Republican forces in the Spanish Civil War, an experience that led to the book "L'Espoir" ("Man's Hope"). When World War II broke out, he joined the army, but he was captured by invading German forces in May 1940 and was held until he managed to escape six months later. He then hid on the Cote d'Azur until 1944 when, somewhat late in the day, he joined the Resistance under the nom de guerre of Colonel Berger.
By the time Paris was liberated in August 1944, Malraux was in charge of a Resistance group in Alsace. More significantly, he was by then openly anti-Communist. And the following year, when he met De Gaulle for the first time, the General named him his spokesman. But soon afterward, De Gaulle stepped out of public life, and Malraux returned to his writing, showing growing interest in the visual arts.
De Gaulle's return to power in 1958 immediately brought Malraux back into the limelight. Named France's first Culture Minister, he made his mark by creating cultural centers throughout the country as well as by promoting contemporary art, cleaning Paris monuments, preserving the prehistoric art of Lascaux by closing the caves to the public, and organizing major retrospective art exhibitions visited by hundreds of thousands of people.
Yet perhaps the final proof that Malraux was more artist than politician is that he is best remembered for a masterpiece of oratory that he delivered on Dec. 19, 1964, when the remains of Jean Moulin, a Resistance hero murdered by the Gestapo, were being transferred to the Pantheon. Quotations from this speech have been reproduced on posters displayed throughout France in recent days.
After his death at the age of 75, Malraux's flaws -- as a person, writer and politician -- were soon forgotten. Jack Lang, President Mitterrand's Culture Minister, tried to emulate him, while French intellectuals of the left and right felt almost duty-bound by his example to take stances on political conflicts around the world. And now, it seems, Malraux's job is to remind the French that panache and flair are good antidotes for pessimism.
"I think everyone needs this commemoration, the Government, the media, the intellectuals," said Bernard-Henri Levy, a French philosopher whose support for Bosnian Muslims prompted critics to snipe that he was "playing" Malraux. "It's probably because the French feel their identity is threatened, that their identity is being shaken to its very foundations. So it's understandable that we hold onto our memories in times like this."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Andre Malraux in 1951, when he was campaigning for De Gaulle (in background). (Paris Match)

HEADLINE: Clinton's Chinese Counterpart: A Weak Old Panda?

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 24

 BODY:
President Clinton can certainly sympathize with Jiang Zemin.
The 70-year-old Chinese President and Communist Party boss has no mandate at home to chart any new course in foreign or domestic policy and his ability to lead China into the next century is an open question. His critics call him "the panda" and his staff complains that he never initiates policies, he just responds to pressure. 
 Mr. Clinton, who just emerged from a re-election campaign where the same questions were raised about his leadership and where some Republicans disparaged him as "Bubba," might have had a sense of "I've been there" this weekend in Manila as he saw the Chinese leadership stall on the substantive issues that divide the two nations.
With a new chapter opening in United States-China relations, Mr. Clinton's 85-minute discussion in Manila today with President Jiang affirmed, if nothing else, that China is in the midst of a paralyzing leadership transition in which Mr. Jiang's power remains weak and may not be consolidated until late next year, if then.
Though Mr. Clinton has sent every conceivable signal that a new consensus in Congress for assisting China's economic and technological development may be sustainable, China's rulers remain absorbed in domestic politics. With a Communist Party congress scheduled next fall, Mr. Jiang is, in essence, running to stay in office before an exclusive electorate that consists of a few hundred members of the Communist Party and military hierarchies.
No Chinese leader in his shoes could be expected to undertake any bold new initiatives with an American President.
During months of diplomacy leading up to the meeting today, Mr. Clinton sent emissaries to push and cajole. He suggested amending United States trade laws to cement China's trade privileges in the American market, and he shared intelligence on Iran's nuclear program to try to convince Beijing to stop doing business with Teheran.
China sent the message back that it is not ready to take down the market barriers necessary to enter the World Trade Organization, although Mr. Jiang signaled today that he might be willing to do something on that issue.
Beijing refused to make any pledge to stop selling nuclear and missile technology to Iran, and it was adamant that it would continue to imprison anyone who speaks against the Government at home, as it did with the former student leader Wang Dan, who got an 11-year sentence just three weeks ago.
It may be possible for China to make progress on these fronts in the future. But As Mr. Jiang knows all too well, to make progress on these fronts requires a carefully prepared consensus among powerful institutions, including the Chinese military, major state industries, regional leaders and party factions.
When these stars are not in alignment, Mr. Jiang is left the hapless job of temporizing.
While Mr. Clinton looks at 1997 as a clean slate on which he would like to write a more constructive text, Mr. Jiang looks at the next 12 months like a barefoot man facing a bed of coals.
Before the end of next year, Mr. Jiang must show his skill in managing Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1. This will include a perilous choice between confrontation or accommodation with the pro-democracy forces that have flourished among the six million residents of the British colony.
Then, as part of the preparations for the 15th congress of the Chinese Communist Party, Mr. Jiang must orchestrate major personnel changes in the seven-man Politburo, including the retirement of the hard-line Prime Minister Li Peng.
It is at the party congress that Mr. Jiang is hoping for an unequivocal mandate to succeed Deng Xiaoping.
Even if he gets the mandate, Mr. Jiang could still turn out to be the weakest leader to rule Communist China in the four and half decades since the Communists came to power.
And, strangely, a number of Chinese seem content with that.
"Someone once said to me that Jiang Zemin is a nothing," said a member of one of China's most prominent families and a Communist Party stalwart, adding that he replied by saying: "That is what we need -- a nothing, because he must work within the system. He must consult with the other leaders, like Qiao Shi, the chairman of the National People's Congress, and Prime Minister Li Peng, and he must consult with the military."
"We need a leader who has no ideas," the official continued, "because he will get his ideas and his advice from within the system."
In this way, he said, "China needs a leader like Bill Clinton. Clinton was a nothing in 1992, just like Jiang Zemin, but look at Clinton now. He knows how to work within the system; he consults with the leaders of Congress and the military and then he makes his decisions."
Mr. Jiang might not find the analysis flattering, but its seems clear that as time passes and Mr. Deng, 92, slips deeper into Parkinson's disease, the collective leadership of Communist Party elders and Mr. Jiang's contemporaries find him a comfortable leader because he tries to accommodate all factions.
That may not be a prescription for progress in United States-China relations, but it is a prescription for staying in office.
And though he has been almost desperate over the last two years to convince Mr. Clinton to fete him with a state visit, Mr. Jiang can now undoubtedly see the risks of traveling to Washington with an empty briefcase and facing an onslaught of protesters who would take the opportunity to remind him how unpopular Chinese policies are on religious persecution in Tibet and on the harsh treatment of political dissidents.
For Mr. Clinton, too, there are risks in giving too much "face" to a Chinese leader who might crack down on Hong Kong's pro-democracy party after Chinese troops move in, and who might greet Vice President Al Gore in Beijing next spring by throwing dissidents into jail.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Clinton Surveys Manila Bay: What, No Corncob Pipe?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: MANILA, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Bill Clinton came into office self-conscious about the military, his salutes less than crisp and his interest in foreign affairs sporadic at best. All that has long since changed, his aides insist, pointing to Mr. Clinton's new reputation in Asia as the President who sent carriers into the Taiwan Strait this year as a warning to China.
But in every sense Mr. Clinton may have reached a new comfort level as Commander in Chief on Saturday night when he and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, settled into Gen. Douglas MacArthur's palatial suite at the Manila Hotel overlooking Manila Bay and Corregidor, the site of MacArthur's last stand in defending the Philippines against Japan. 
 Mr. Clinton did not show up at his morning staff meeting with a corncob pipe clenched between his teeth, but he was clearly enjoying the international status accorded by the size of his re-election victory.
The Chinese, who froze relations with Washington a year ago and made clear that they were rooting for anyone but Mr. Clinton in the election, were suddenly talking summit meetings and trade deals. The South Koreans were backing down, ever so slightly, after an ugly breach with the Administration over how to deal with the Communist North.
Tonight at Malacanang Palace, where Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos used to hold court before the People Power revolution of 1986, Mr. Clinton was twisting arms to get stronger wording in support of a worldwide trade deal to end tariffs on information technology.
"The other leaders realize that they are going to be dealing with this President for some time," Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor said from more modest digs in the Manila, where every wall appears to be made of some shade of teak and hand-rolled cigars are still sold -- and smoked -- in the lobby.
But Mr. Clinton's moment to play the American Caesar in one of Asia's great landmarks came at a political price. Delighting conspiracy theorists of all stripes, his neighbor at the hotel is Suharto, the aging Indonesian dictator.
Mr. Clinton spent a lot of time before he left for Asia insisting that he has never let his ties to James Riady, his multimillionaire Indonesian friend, influence decisions about his relations with President Suharto's Government. Nonetheless, his aides say they could live without pictures of the two men chatting it up in the lobby, and their exits and entrances seem timed to insure that there was no risk of their running into each other.
That left both of them more time to run into the the Sultan of Brunei, one of the world's richest men and the hotel's other famous weekend denizen. At past Asian summit meetings he was known to hand out thousand-dollar tips to bellhops, which is perhaps why, on the greeting board in the lobby, the Sultan's name is listed first, Mr. Suharto's second and Mr. Clinton's third.

Mundane, Gritty Reality
Modern economic diplomacy, of course, lacks some of the drama of retreating under fire, declaring, "I shall return."
The broad political goal of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, the clunky name for the summit meeting here, is to rip down trade barriers and promote economic growth. That's the lofty, job-creating stuff that the national leaders here love to talk about.
But the gritty reality this year is that every country has to submit a ponderous document, called an Individual Action Plan, laying out specific steps that countries are taking between now and 2020 (2010 for developed countries like the United States and Japan) to lower tariffs and remove trade barriers. These documents have become bureaucratic tributes to the art of making the trivial seem earth-shaking.
Anybody looking to export fish, cement and sugar to Papua New Guinea, where the gross domestic product is a little over $1,000 a person, take heart: there is a plan afoot to open the market.

Ramos Is Out to Impress
Five years ago, Fidel V. Ramos, then the Philippine Defense Secretary, was walking the streets of this city in a flak jacket, putting down monthly coup attempts against the famous but hapless President Corazon C. Aquino.
This morning, now President himself, Mr. Ramos was comfortably ensconced in an office in the Coconut Palace, an Apple computer sitting on his polished wood traditional Philippine table, receiving a stream of heads of state celebrating the recovery of the country once known as the sick man of Asia.
Mr. Ramos knows that the key to the recovery is keeping investment flowing in, and he is clearly out to impress. In a city that only a few years ago could not produce enough electricity to keep traffic lights on during the day, he now litters his desk with every type of electronic organizer, each flashing his politically convenient initials -- F.V.R. He has replaced his military terseness with trade-speak.
But it has not been an entirely easy week for the cigar-chomping former general, as he conceded in a chat a few minutes after Mr. Clinton came calling. This is the first time that a large summit meeting has been held in a country that still has an active, if weakened, Communist insurgency.
If that were not enough to put the Secret Service on edge, two bombs were found at midweek -- one in the passenger terminal of Manila's airport and another at Subic Bay, the former American naval base where the 18 leaders will meet on Monday. The Government put out a story that the bombs were planted deliberately to test security, but Mr. Ramos allowed today that he was not convinced that it was true.
"We are still investigating," he said.
He has also been plagued by a series of protests, from unions who threatened to bring Manila to a standstill and from motorists who resented the "Friendship Lanes" on city streets that allowed delegates to the conference here to zip past traffic that has gone from ordinary gridlock to perpetual parking.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Chinese President Agree to Exchange State Visits

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: MANILA, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Despite deep and unresolved differences, President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China agreed today to exchange state visits over the next two years. They would be the first such extended meetings between their nations since the massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators at Tiananmen Square in 1989.
The White House hopes the reciprocal visits -- to be preceded by a trip to Beijing by Vice President Al Gore in the first half of next year -- will cement the first steps toward improving a relationship that has floundered badly in the last four years over human rights, trade, nuclear proliferation and Taiwan. 
 But after an 85-minute meeting at an economic summit meeting of 18 Asian-Pacific leaders here, it was clear Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang had made little substantive progress on those issues.
The one possible exception, Administration officials said, was Mr. Jiang's apparent willingness to move ahead on opening markets to pave the way for China to join the World Trade Organization and thus diminish a source of longstanding tension between Washington and Beijing. The organization, which includes more than 100 countries, aims to promote trade and remove barriers that inhibit it.
In a separate meeting with President Kim Young Sam of South Korea, Mr. Clinton apparently succeeded in persuading him to maintain his country's minimal links with North Korea, despite Seoul's outrage over the incursion of a North Korean submarine and its crew into South Korean territory in September.
After that incident, the South demanded an apology from the North, which threatened to break the few remaining lines of communication across the Demilitarized Zone. But today Mr. Kim and Mr. Clinton issued a statement simply calling on the North to take "acceptable steps" to resolve the matter.
American officials said the precise timing of the Chinese-American state visits remained to be set, depending in part on the smoothness of the transfer of Hong Kong to the Chinese next July. But the assumption has been that Mr. Jiang will travel to Washington sometime next year, perhaps after the next scheduled APEC talks, in Vancouver in November, and that Mr. Clinton may go to Beijing in 1998.
As he posed with Mr. Jiang in front of American and Chinese flags before their meeting at the Central Bank building here, Mr. Clinton said, "We're doing the right thing." Afterward, he said: "I think it went very well. It was a good meeting, and I think that the next steps were appropriate."
An American translator later told reporters that Mr. Jiang had said that the timing of today's meeting, just after Mr. Clinton's re-election, gave it special importance.
In a gesture of goodwill aimed at American public opinion, Mr. Jiang also told Mr. Clinton that the Chinese had recently discovered the remnants of what appeared to be a B-24 bomber from World War II containing human remains in Guangxi province in southwestern China. Chinese officials first informed Secretary of State Warren Christopher of the discovery while he was in China last week, and today Mr. Jiang gave the President a videotape and an album of photographs and invited him to send an American team to the site.
Officials said Mr. Clinton made it clear that the United States would not back down on its longtime support for a United Nations resolution condemning China's record on human rights, while Mr. Jiang repeated China's longstanding objections to American arms sales to Taiwan.
But neither of those disagreements was at all unexpected. In fact, the Director of Central Intelligence, John Deutch, visited China last month and told Mr. Clinton's senior aides that he did not believe Mr. Jiang was in a strong enough political sitituaion to make concessions in any substantive area over the next year.
American officials said today that it was the Chinese who proposed leaving the timetable for the visits open, in part to wait until after the Communist Party congress next fall. Mr Jiang hopes the congress will solidify his control of the country before the death of Deng Xiaoping, 92, China's ailing paramount leader.
Over all, officials said, the disagreements did not dominate a session that one senior Clinton aide called "animated, responsive, a real conversation." Aides said the tone of the meeting -- the fourth between the Presidents -- was serious but friendly, with Mr. Jiang at one point suggesting Mr. Clinton try Chinese medicine or acupuncture for the hoarseness that often bothers him and that has dogged him on this trip.
Human rights groups swiftly denounced the decision to hold high-level meetings, saying it had removed an important lever in American efforts to persuade China to improve its handling of dissidents, workers and women.
"In his eagerness to announce a U.S.-China summit and tout the strengthening of the U.S.-China relationship as the major foreign policy achievement of his second term, Clinton seems to be on the verge of selling out on human rights," said Mike Jendrzejczyk, the Washington director of Human Rights Watch Asia, who is here in Manila.
"It's true that U.S. officials continue to express formal concern about human rights at official meetings," he said. "But if there is no political or economic pressure behind the words, the Chinese Government will continue to do what it's doing now: arbitrarily arresting anyone who gets in its way."
But Administration officials made just the opposite argument. Except for Jimmy Carter, every American President since Richard M. Nixon has visited China, and officials said their goal was not to let differences over individual issues -- however significant -- derail the entire relationship.
They noted, for example, that Washington maintained high-level contacts with the Soviet Union during the cold war.
"Human rights is very important," said Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs. "So is peace on the Korean peninsula, nonproliferation, trade and many other issues, and we're going to press all these issues. And we believe that regular, high-level dialogue is the most effective way to make progress on all these issues, including human rights."
Mr. Lord said the Administration recognized that "serious problems remain," adding, "You're not seeing any euphoria or complacency or naivete."
The session was in marked contrast to Mr. Clinton's approach to China earlier in his term, when disagreements over human rights, Taiwan and trade threatened to unhinge relations with Beijing.
Still, the meeting was as notable for what it did not achieve as for what it did: the Administration had hoped it might win medical leaves for Chinese dissidents, for example, not recovery of half-century-old remains from a war in which the United States and pre-Communist China were allies.
One senior American official said the two Presidents had made "no concrete progress" on China's membership in the World Trade Organization, the international body that adjudicates trade disputes.
As a condition of membership, Washington wants China to be bound by most of the rules on lowering tarriff barriers and the like that apply to the developed world. But China is heavily dependent on state-run industries and has worried that stripping away trade protections could risk serious unrest.
But another senior American official said tonight that Mr. Jiang had showed that China had the political will to go forward on the issue, with an attitude that was "extremely impressive and greatly helpful."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1759 words

HEADLINE: E.P.A. ADVOCATING HIGHER STANDARDS TO CLEAN THE AIR

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency is recommending tighter national standards for emissions of the chemicals and particles that form smog and soot, some of the most pervasive and unhealthy forms of air pollution.
The new definition of how clean the air must be to protect the public's health is sure to be one of the biggest environmental fights of the coming year, raging from the Oval Office to Capitol Hill and drawing in Federal judges and governors. 
 Under the proposal, hundreds of communities that comply with the Clean Air Act under the current rules could fall out of compliance, roughly tripling the number of counties where state and local officials must take further steps to clean up the air. At least 100 million people live in these areas.
"This is one of the most important decisions I will make to protect public health in this country," said Carol M. Browner, the E.P.A. Administrator. "We believe very, very strongly that there are real and significant health problems from this kind of pollution and that our final decision must be standards that protect against those."
Business groups are lobbying hard against the proposal, whose details will be announced within a few days, predicting that it will cost them billions of dollars trying to meet standards that they contend will offer no important benefit.
Environmentalists and public health groups, for their part, say that tens of thousands of people could be protected from illness or even death if the rules are toughened and that the E.P.A.'s proposal is unlikely to go far enough in that direction.
The environmental agency predicts that the costs, while running into billions of dollars, will be much less than industry studies predict and that most areas will eventually meet the standards without taking extraordinary steps, providing important health benefits to the public.
But complying with the new rules would be especially hard for many large metropolitan areas, like the New York City region, because they are still struggling to meet the current air quality standards.
The E.P.A.'s proposal has been years in preparation. And it has been the subject of especially intense debate in the past few days at the White House, with some senior officials urging that a major part of the package be delayed a few weeks or months, as big-business lobbyists have repeatedly requested.
It would be the first big environmental proposal since the election. Pollution issues played a prominent role in the Clinton-Gore campaign.
"The magnitude of this is not lost on anybody," said Kathleen A. McGinty, the head of the White House Council on Environmental Quality. "The President sees both the compelling importance of the public health issue and also, frankly, the need for pushing to try to minimize the economic costs."
She added: "The current standards don't sufficiently protect the public health, particularly children. The economic toll of hospital visits, days of work lost -- those are big, and those are real costs."
In Congress, Republican leaders have already signaled that they will challenge the agency's rule, perhaps seeking to overturn it next year under the terms of a new law that gives Congress the power to review major Federal regulations. In a report accompanying the agency's spending bill for the current year, Congress already ordered the E.P.A. to give serious consideration to the idea of leaving the current standard unchanged.
The E.P.A.'s decision is expected to be announced after a final review by senior regulatory officials at the White House. It follows an extensive study by the environmental agency of scientific studies documenting the damage that is done when health problems are exacerbated by soot and smog, especially in children, the frail elderly, asthmatics and outdoor workers. But there are heated arguments about whether this research is convincing.
Business groups and environmental and public health groups will also fight over the costs and benefits that could result from the change. By law, questions of cost should carry little weight because the Clean Air Act requires that health, not economics, dictate air quality goals. But politically, the potential expense of compliance is a major factor.
Among the strategies that states might include in their Federally approved compliance plans could be mass transit projects, incentives for companies to limit emissions, new requirements for pollution controls on factory smokestacks and improved programs for vehicle inspections.
State governors, stirred into action by a far-reaching industry campaign, have repeatedly written the Administration to raise concerns about the proposed rule change, which would tell many state and local governments that their past progress in cleaning up the air is no longer enough to satisfy the demands of the Clean Air Act.
The details of the new rule must be announced by Nov. 29 under a court order obtained by the American Lung Association, which sued to force a review of the existing standards for particulate matter, the fine particles of pollution formed largely from burning coal, oil and gas. The agency decided to issue at the same time a new standard for ozone, another harmful gas that helps form smog. The Clean Air Act requires that national standards for the six major types of air pollution, which include ozone and particulates, be reviewed periodically.
Even though those two types of pollution are not chemically identical, they share many common characteristics: where they come from, how they accumulate and travel, and the fact that they damage people's lungs.
The E.P.A. wants to regulate them simultaneously, both because it would be more efficient and because it is easier to defend the rules on the basis of protecting health if they are combined.
It has been clear for months that the E.P.A. wants to tighten the rules. The biggest questions are precisely how tight the new proposal will be and what formula for measuring pollution will be adopted.
The agency is widely expected to seek a standard of around 80 parts per billion of ozone in the air, compared with 120 parts per billion under the current rule, and to lower the size of the particles that are regulated to 2.5 microns, compared with 10 microns currently. (A human hair is about 70 microns thick.) But those numbers alone do not tell the whole story; other factors include the duration of violations, how frequently they occur, how precisely they are measured and much more. Every decimal in these complex equations will be debated at length by technical experts on both sides, as they have been disputed for years. The proposal is a first step; the agency will take public comments before reaching a final decision next summer.
Among the business groups most actively fighting the proposal are those representing oil companies, electric utilities, auto makers and other manufacturers. Together they have mounted a large, well-financed campaign to defeat the proposal, saying that the current air quality standards are strong enough and that attaining the new ones would be far too expensive to be worthwhile.
"We are not against protecting the public's health -- my gosh, you have got to do that," said Robert A. Beck, vice president of environmental affairs at the Edison Electric Institute, a trade group for power companies. "But we already have a good law here, and we are implementing it. We don't want to waste money and at the end of the day not get where we want to go."
Environmental and public health groups, for their part, have sought for years to get tougher standards, and they are likely to criticize the E.P.A. for not going far enough when it announces its proposal. They are expected to be especially critical of the proposal for the regulation of small particulates. But the environmental groups generally favor the direction the agency is going.
"This will get the communities where there really are health risks back on the nonattainment list and will get them doing something about it," said Carl Pope, executive director of the Sierra Club.
He predicted that industry lobbyists would have a hard time getting Congress to overturn the rule. "They are picking a fight on something people really care about, which is their children's health, and they are going to get creamed," he said.
Major rules like this one are always reviewed at the White House by the regulatory branch of the Office of Management and Budget, and industry lobbyists have been pressing the Administration for weeks either to retain as one option a final decision not to alter the standards or to split the rule in two, issuing only the part that addresses sooty particles, while leaving for later the part that deals with the chemicals that form smog.
Industry lobbyists, intent on fighting each part of the rule on highly technical grounds, would much rather separate them.
To the proposal's advocates, splitting it in half would be an early concession to industry groups, which have been pursuing what one Government official called a "divide and conquer" approach.
But a White House official said the Office of Management and Budget was no longer seeking substantive changes in the standards, which could have caused a lengthy delay. "This is not the Quayle White House; we are not here to weaken the standard," said this official, referring to the days in the Bush Administration when Vice President Dan Quayle and Office of Management and Budget officials routinely overturned agency proposals on the environment.
In meetings and correspondence last month with Sally Katzen, the head of the O.M.B.'s office of regulatory affairs, automobile industry lobbyists had asked that the combined rule on ozone and small particulate matter be split in half.
The biggest debate is over interpreting hundreds of scientific studies on how human health is affected by ozone and small particulates. A science advisory committee spent months reviewing the evidence and the E.P.A. staff's analysis. In the end, it gave the agency's plans a qualified endorsement.
Business groups have seized on the advisory panel's critique as ammunition to defeat the proposal, and the panel's chairman, George Wolff, a top scientist working for General Motors, is frequently quoted by lobbyists opposing the proposal.
But the panel's conclusions, like a communique from the United Nations Security Council, are open to many interpretations, and they are not the final word on whether the agency is moving in the right direction. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

European Currency System To Readmit the Italian Lira
Finance ministers and central bank governors from European Union nations, meeting in a special session, agreed to readmit the Italian lira to the European exchange rate mechanism. Officials said the ministers agreed to let the lira return to the currency grid at 990 lira to the German mark.
The lira had been dropped from the system in 1992 during a currency crisis in Italy, and re-entry was seen as crucial for Italy's hopes of being in the first wave of nations to adopt a single European currency in 1999. [Page D2.]
 
U.S. and China Agree on Visits
President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China agreed to exchange state visits in the next two years, the first such meetings since the 1989 massacre at Tiananmen Square. White House officials also said that Mr. Jiang had signaled a willingness to move ahead on opening markets to pave the way for China to join the World Trade Organization. [A1.]
 
Settlement Reached in TLC Case
The singing trio TLC, their recording label and managers settled a yearlong battle over how the fruits of the group's success should be divided. The trio had filed for bankruptcy at least in part to void their contracts; the case was important to the industry, because the royalty restrictions that TLC could have shed are common in the business. [D2.]
 
Endless, Unattainable Love
Shiori Fujisaki is a 17-year-old high school junior, Shingo Hagiwara a 21-year-old college sophomore who idolizes her. One problem: Ms. Fujisaki, left, is only a character in a video game, the goal of which is to get her or a friend to date you and fall in love. "Love simulation" games have become a hot category in Japan's home video game industry, and Mr. Hagiwara, who is quite real, is one of a legion of young Japanese men who have lost their hearts to a virtual girl. [D5.]
 
Tighter Clean-Air Provisions Sought
The E.P.A. is recommending tighter national standards for emissions of the chemicals and particles that form smog and soot. Business groups are lobbying hard against the proposal to redefine how clean the air must be, saying it would cost billions of dollars to meet standards they contend offer no important benefit. [A1.]
 
Departing Editors Are Sued
When the publisher and 2 editors quit Orchard Books to start an imprint at another publisher, it seemed just one more industry realignment. But in Orchard's case, nothing has happened in the usual way since. [D7.]
 
Big Shift in Health Care Billing
After signing large numbers of New York doctors, the nation's health maintenance organizations are radically changing the way they pay physicians there and have begun to reduce reimbursements. [A1.]
 
Paper Guides to Internet Sites
At least 10 ink-and-paper publications are fighting to become, in effect, the TV Guide of the World Wide Web. And, as bigger and better-financed magazines jump in, the competition is turning into a demolition derby. [D10.]
 
Chat as a Marketing Opportunity
Advertisers for the most part have either ignored on-line "chat" or poked fun at the phenomenon. But a study suggests marketers ought to take those cybercommunities seriously. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]
 
Michael Jackson's Global Reach
Though Michael Jackson's two-year-old album "HIStory" has failed to meet expectations in the United States, it remains a hit in dozens of other nations, selling 11 million copies worldwide. Sony Music ships as many as 100,000 overseas each week. Entertainment. [D7.]

HEADLINE: ALTERED MEDICINE -- A special report;
Reduced H.M.O. Fees Cause Concern About Patient Care

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
After signing up large numbers of New York doctors and establishing a seemingly unshakable position here, health maintenance organizations are radically changing the way they pay physicians and have begun to reduce reimbursements.
Patients who see the same doctor in the same office are generally not aware that a change has occurred. But while the health maintenance organizations assert that new types of payments help control medical costs, the region's doctors, and medical experts, are warning that the quality of care will suffer and that in some cases, it already has. 
 Managed care plans that have continued to pay old-style fees for office visits have been cutting rates, sometimes on a monthly basis. Beyond that, however, is a growing trend among many of the large health maintenance organizations like Aetna, Sanus and Pru Care, which have stopped paying many of their doctors for each patient visit. Instead, they give most general doctors a small fixed sum -- generally $100 to $300 a year -- to cover office care for each enrolled patient. Rare just a few years ago, the new payment system now accounts for nearly half of all the dollars paid by health plans to general physicians in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania.
Although doctors admit that traditional insurance, which paid handsomely for each office visit, rewarded doctors for doing too much, many say that the new reimbursement method -- known as capitation -- has pushed them to skimp on care. Some now acknowledge hurrying office visits, treating too many complaints over the phone and avoiding patients with illnesses like diabetes or AIDS that require frequent doctor's visits.
"These plans put you in the funny position of doing better financially if you withhold care, and that seems unethical," said Dr. Laurence Miller, a pediatrician in North Bellmore, L.I., who like dozens of doctors dropped out of Aetna this fall when the H.M.O. offered him a contract that paid as little as $5.25 a month for some patients. "People are going to get treated very differently under these arrangements."
But insurance executives said that set fees make more sense in a system in which doctors are paid to manage the entire scope of a patient's health. Sometimes, advice over the phone or arranging a physical therapy session makes more sense than an expensive office visit, they said. They added that doctors will not go hungry, estimating that current capitation rates should translate into doctor incomes of more than $150,000 a year.
Indeed, some health economists suspect that when H.M.O. patients are shortchanged, the culprit is not just a new type of payment but also a doctor who is unwilling to adjust to a new type of health care.
"When you hear physicians bellyaching, it's often hard to know if the dollar figures are unfair or if the docs are going through the five stages of accepting the death of the good old days of medicine," said Dr. Alan Hillman, a professor of health policy at the University of Pennsylvania.
Such fixed-fee contracts have become standard in many parts of the country in the last decade, covering over 60 percent of health-maintenance payments to doctors in places like California. But the adjustment for doctors and patients in New York may be traumatic, in part because the change here has occurred rapidly and in part because of smaller medical practices that are poorly suited to the new payment plan.
One New York City internist in solo practice recalled treating a man with AIDS-related pneumonia who was insured under the new payment method, and resenting the daily trips to the hospital -- trips for which he felt he was not being adequately paid. He said that another patient, who had recently tested positive for the AIDS virus, had asked him to continue as his doctor. But instead, he declined, forcing his patient to change doctors.
"I don't have tons of experience with the disease," he said, "but if I got reasonable compensation I might say, 'O.K., I'm his doctor and this is what I should do.' But knowing that I'd be doing it for free, I won't."
No one knows how many doctors have dropped plans over the new contracts, health experts say, and it is even harder to measure the subtle ways in which care might be affected. "A lot of these plans are trying to squeeze out money from doctors, and what worries me is that our ability to measure quality is still primitive," said Marc Rodwin, a professor at Indiana University and the author of "Medicine, Money and Morals." "We need to have better protections for consumers."

The New Rates
A Fixed Monthly Fee For Office Visits
Most of New York's managed care plans still pay doctors for office visits, although the rate is often only about three-fourths of the customary charge. But many have now switched to monthly fees.
"A few years ago, this was unheard of in New York," said Steve Kern, a lawyer with Kern, Augustine, Conroy & Schoppman, a law firm that represents physicians. "Now, most all primary care providers are participating in capitated plans."
These fees depend on the age and sex of the patient as well as the size of their copayment. Although most health maintenance groups offer these fixed fee contracts only to general doctors, some are also beginning to cap fees for specialists.
At Sanus, now known as New York Life Care, general doctors are paid $31 to $42 a month for infants under the age of 1, a rate that drops quickly to $5.80 to $7.97 for children ages 5 to 18. After adolescence, the rates start to climb, averaging $7.50 for men 19 to 39 years old and about $9.00 for women. The rates for men and women over 65 are $21 to $31 a month.
U.S. Health Care rates are higher for infants and young children, but lower for adults as they age. While Sanus pays $29.68 a month for a man over 65 with a $5 copayment, U.S. Health Care pays $22.52.
Some plans supplement these monthly fees with payments to cover the cost of vaccines; others add bonuses for doctors who use referrals judiciously, or submit billing information promptly.
These payments are supposed to cover all of a patient's office health needs, from exams for an ear infection to the treatment of conditions like asthma and high blood pressure; in New York, they do not generally cover the cost of specialty referrals. They are the same whether a patient is well or suffers from a chronic disease like diabetes, the logic being that the expense of the rare patient who is ill will be counterbalanced by the dozens of healthy people.
But in the New York region, where office overhead is high and hospital clinics charge $200 for a routine physical, many doctors feel that the new rates do not even cover the expenses for the healthiest patients.
"It is very easy now to get caught in a rate that is so low that you can't provide the kind of care you should provide," said Dr. Charles Aswad, vice president of the Medical Society of the State of New York.
Some doctors, like Dr. Miller, have resigned from plans when the fee structure changed. But many others say that they have so many patients in certain managed care plans that they cannot afford to quit.
And patients feel the fallout. Linda Girardin of East Meadow, L.I., who belongs to Aetna's plan, said that her husband's internist never checked his blood pressure and cholesterol levels -- later found to be dangerously high. And when the plan switched its doctors to fixed monthly fees, the family pediatrician dropped out.
"I wouldn't resent this so much if the money they save on us was buying medical care for someone who is poor," she said. "But who's benefiting here? Not the patients. Not the doctors. Not the uninsured."

The Patients
The Seriously Ill Face Big Risks
In interviews, doctors said that the new rates affected how they do business, with economics challenging lessons learned in medical school.
"Most earaches are infectious, so there is a great temptation if a child says his ear hurts to just prescribe antibiotics without seeing him," Dr. Miller said. "But that is not good medicine."
One Manhattan internist, who spoke on condition of anonymity for fear of jeopardizing his contracts, said: "You try not to look at what kind of insurance patients have because it will bias you. If you know you're getting $6.10 a month, you're not going to extend yourself."
The general effect of the new rates is to reduce the cash that flows into doctors offices, often forcing doctors to share at least some of the insurer's risk. As a result, some doctors said that they now shied away from patients who were seriously ill or hid areas of expertise from the health plans and patients, for fear of attracting sicker individuals.
"I hate to talk about patients this way, but if I get a 50-year-old diabetic who I have to see every month, it's a major economic disaster," said one doctor, who practices both general medicine and endocrinology. He is paid about $175 annually for patients in that age group.
Dr. Arthur Leibowitz, the chief medical officer of Aetna U.S. Health Care, a managed care company recently formed by the merger of two large H.M.O.'s, said that "corrupt physicians could learn to take advantage of any system," but that his company carefully monitored the quality of care. He noted that U.S. Health Care doctors who scored high in availability and patient satisfaction could receive bonuses 29 percent above their base rate.
"Our aim is to provide doctors with fair pay for taking care of patients without giving them the old incentives to do extra things," Dr. Lebowitz said.
But Professor Rodwin said, the new fee schedules "create an incentive to underuse services, and it's very hard to measure that."
In an increasingly cutthroat market, managed care groups are constantly revising their contracts with doctors, searching for a fee structure that will save money and promote cost-effective care.
Camille Carbonaro, executive director of the Richmond County Medical Society, said that she had received many complaints about contracts whose terms had changed or the rates had dropped within a month of signing. Indeed, virtually all contracts now contain a clause allowing organizations to change the payment structure midstream without the physician's consent.

Doctor's Predicament
Business Clashes With a Mission
Doctors say they are overwhelmed by the shifting sands, as some plans have created elaborate hybrid systems that still pay doctors per visit but still limit the health plan's expenses.
Oxford Health Plan organizes doctors from a given geographical area into "pods," with fixed yearly budgets. The doctors bill Oxford for each office visit, but if the pod comes in over budget one year, their rates can, in theory, be reduced the next.
Earlier this year, Cigna announced that it would allot a fixed sum each month to cover large groups of specialists, such as ear, nose and throat surgeons in Queens. Each surgeon submits monthly bills to the insurer at an agreed upon discounted rate: $300 for a tonsillectomy, for example. But if the bills for the borough surpass the monthly allotment, each bill is discounted further so that Cigna maintains its budget. Some surgeons resigned in protest.
But Dr. Zoltan Brody, a physician from Staten Island, said that most doctors just sign on. "Many doctors don't even read contracts because what's the point?" he said. "They have no recourse and no bargaining power."
Earlier this year, a group of patients and doctors from Long Island sued Aetna, claiming that the company's recent shift to fixed monthly fees jeopardized patient care. Last week, Judge Denis R. Hurley of United States District Court ruled that Aetna had to provide the patients with its internal data regarding quality of care.
But some health care analysts said that the system had advantages. Dr. Peter Kongstvedt, a partner in the Washington office of Ernst & Young, said fixed payments improved cash flow by infusing funds regularly and eliminating bill collection.
"Physicians have to start thinking like actuaries to understand how this will work and that is very hard," he said. "Doctors think of these payments as a fee -- they think I'm just getting $10 for this person and they keep coming in. But maybe they have 4 like this but 96 who rarely show up, who they're paid for anyway."
Dr. Kongstvedt said that good H.M.O.'s use statistical data to arrive at a fair rate, but he acknowledged that others would cut rates as much as the market would bear.
Rob Parke, an actuary at Milliman & Robertson, a Seattle consulting firm , said that many of the monthly rates being offered to doctors in New York seemed "reasonable," if the rates paid by Medicare are used as a yardstick. But those rates are quite a bit lower than many private physicians in the area now charge.
Many medical experts say that the capitated systems that have succeeded in states like California might not translate well here.
While most doctors in New York still practice in small groups, fixed-fee payments work best in practices with tens of thousands of patients. If a solo practitioner happens to take on a child with a devastating chronic illness, it has much more impact on the finances of the business than if a practice with 50 doctors and 25,000 patients gets the child.
A Manhattan internist in a two-doctor practice, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said, "Lets say in New York City I get 6 AIDS patients -- who I'm paid $108 a year to take care of -- that could put us in the toilet."
Large practices are also better able to hire staff, like physicians' assistants, to dispense services like blood pressure checks at lower cost. They can take on lawyers to review their contracts and they are in a much stronger position to negotiate with insurers as well.
Health economists predicted that the region's doctors would be forced to band together to gain these advantages and that, over time, market forces will correct injustices caused by payment schemes that are too stingy to support good office care. But that offers little solace to Linda Girardin, whose 11-year-old son cried when he learned that he would have to switch pediatricians. "So for now we're going to pay out of our own pockets," she said. "And that won't be easy."

HEADLINE: Texas Meeting Seeks A Rebirth of Populism

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: HUNT, Tex., Nov. 24

 BODY:
In 1877, a group of poor and angry farmers gathered in the hill country of Texas, vowing to fight the banks, railroads and other "monied interests." It was the spark that set off the Populist movement, a network of cooperatives and political action that grew into one of the largest democratic insurgencies in the nation's history.
Invoking that same spirit and directing their ire at modern forces like health-insurance companies and entertainment conglomerates, some 250 unabashedly left-leaning activists from 32 states met here in the hill country this weekend for the founding convention of what they pledged would be a populist alliance for the 21st century, "a new national force to end the corporate rule of America." 
 Just how significant this new movement will become is anybody's guess, though 45 local "alliances" -- most urban-based and committed to projects like gardening cooperatives, protests against Nafta and "sweatshop watch" programs -- have quietly sprouted around the country in the last 15 months.
Whether any of the oratory here will prove as enduring as William Jennings Bryan's legendary "Cross of Gold" speech in 1896 is also uncertain, though not for any lack of passion on the speakers' part. "The divine right of kings has been replaced by the divine right of C.E.O.'s," thundered Ronnie Dugger, an author who helped organize the convention.
And even what form the group should take politically remains unclear. Some of those on hand called for formation of a new People's Party. Others, apparently agreeing with the remark by Jim Hightower, the former Texas Agriculture Commissioner, that "America doesn't need a third party, it needs a second one," said the new movement should work to push the Democratic Party back to the left, much as the original Populists did.
Nonetheless, with its boisterous debates and free-wheeling proceedings, the convention here in central Texas offered an engaging contrast to the made-for-television, scripted-to-the-second conventions of the two major parties over the summer.
The proceedings also touched on one of the more intriguing questions that has coursed through recent American politics: just what does it mean to be a Populist?
As a means of rallying the disaffected or the downtrodden, so-called "populist" themes have been embraced by a remarkable range of politicians in this decade alone, from Pat Buchanan and David Duke on the right to Jesse Jackson and Ralph Nader on the left, not to mention Ross Perot, somewhere in the middle.
To organizers of the convention here, though, "Populism" is squarely grounded in the kind of anti-corporate sentiment of the agrarian revolt of the late 1800's, when many farmers firmly believed that rate-gouging railroads and bankers charging high interest rates were all part of the "system," which kept them poverty-stricken no matter how hard they worked.
Lawrence Goodwyn, a history professor at Duke University and author of "The Populist Moment" (1978, Oxford University Press), the definitive history of the 19th-century agrarian revolt, said that strains of the same general sense of alienation or anger exist today, whether spawned by the influence of corporate money in politics, the high pay and protected benefits of the nation's top business executives or the prospect that a Wal-Mart will open in town.
But, Mr. Goodwyn cautioned, mass movements based on that kind of wrath have historically proved "indescribably difficult to put together," which is one reason that the Populist movement of the late 1800's was such an extraordinary event in American history.
"The American people know that this is a corporate-dominated society," said Mr. Goodwyn, a keynote speaker at the convention. "Their problem is, they don't know what to do about it."
Actually, there was no lack of ideas on what to do about it at the convention here, held at the remote Mo-Ranch Conference Center. One proposal called for limiting any political contributions to $100 or less and requiring that they be from "flesh-and-blood" human beings rather than political action committees. Nationalizing the oil industry and doubling the minimum wage were also suggested.
Despite the meeting's radical undertones compared with the typical dialogue of a political campaign today, there were, perhaps predictably, those who insisted the whole exercise was not radical enough.
"You're chasing your tail here," complained Don Kemner, a retired insurance agent from Missouri, who advocates a national initiative system under which Americans could basically bypass Congress and pass laws directly. "You're playing their game with this kind of talk."
The convention grew out of an August 1995 article by Mr. Dugger in The Texas Observer, a liberal journal of opinion and investigation, that ran under the headline "Real Populists Please Stand Up." Mr. Dugger, the founding publisher of The Texas Observer, was clearly the guiding spirit behind the weekend's proceedings.
"We are ruled by big business and the government as its paid hireling, and we know it," Mr. Dugger said to raucous applause at Thursday night's opening. "The big corporations and the hundred-millionaires and billionaires have taken daily control of our work, our pay, our housing, our health, our pension funds, our bank and savings deposits, our public lands, our airwaves, our elections, our very government. It's as if American democracy had been bombed."
There were shades of correctness, political and otherwise. Those at the convention were asked, in deference to the fragrance-sensitive, to refrain from wearing hair spray, perfume or cologne. And many in attendance fretted over the minuscule number of African-Americans, Hispanic people and other minorities at the event.
Still, for those who attended, the meeting certainly reflected democracy in action, at times fulfilling Mr. Hightower's observation that "getting progressives together is kind of like loading frogs in a wheelbarrow."
After a long and somewhat contentious series of discussions, those on hand narrowly selected "Alliance for Democracy" as their group's name, over "Alliance for a New Democracy" and "People's Alliance."
"Pure democracy has its drawbacks," Al V. Krebs of Everett, Wash., said with a laugh. "But all in all, we really do feel that we're the beginning of a significant economic and social-justice movement."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 26, 1996, Tuesday

Because of a transmission error, an article yesterday about a convention of delegates intent on forming a new populist movement referred incorrectly to an article headlined "Real Populists Please Stand Up," written by Ronnie Dugger, who helped organize the convention. The article appeared in The Nation, not in The Texas Observer.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Sharply in Reaction To Europe's Accord on Lira

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar surged against most leading currencies yesterday as the Italian lira moved closer to joining a proposed single European currency and an official in Japan hinted that interest rates there would remain at their historic lows.
The lira rallied against the German mark after a weekend meeting approved the lira's re-entry into Europe's exchange rate mechanism. The reaction sent the dollar sharply higher against the mark as well. 
 "The dollar strengthened on the back of the decline in the mark against the lira," said John McCarthy, foreign exchange manager at ING Barings.
A report showing western German consumer inflation fell in November also hurt the mark by dampening expectations for higher interest rates in Germany, dealers said.
In late trading in New York, the dollar rose to 1.5230 marks from 1.5065 marks Friday. In addition, the dollar rose to 112.63 yen from 111.46 yen and to 1,510.75 Italian lire from 1,496.00 lire.
 In Tokyo, the executive director of the Bank of Japan, Tadayo Honma, warned a banking symposium that more failures of Japanese financial institutions remained a possibility. His comments suggested that Japan's economy was still too weak to allow an increase in the official discount rate, which is now at half of 1 percent.
"The financial backdrop in the U.S. is pretty dollar supportive, while the focus in Japan is on the soft environment highlighted by the banking problem," said Lisa Finstrom, an analyst at Smith Barney.
In other trading, the dollar surged to 1.2877 Swiss francs from 1.2708 francs, reaching the highest level since mid-January 1995. The Swiss franc slipped on talk that Swiss pension funds were considering broadening their investments to include more foreign assets, traders said.
The British pound slipped to $1.6686 from $1.6798. The pound rose early in the session but lost ground later as investors took profits after a strong rally in recent sessions.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, denied reports that Britain would seek to link the pound informally to the proposed single European currency, insisting that the pound would remain independent.
With Britain set to announce its 1997-98 budget today, investors sold pounds to book profits.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Macho Man: A Strong, Silent Minimalist Cowboy

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:

CLINT EASTWOOD
A Biography
By Richard Schickel
Illustrated. 557 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50
For nearly three decades, he has been the screen embodiment of an all-American masculinity: the solitary gunslinger who rides into town to exact his own brand of vengeance; the squinty-eyed cop who defies bureaucratic politesse to get his man; the ravaged Secret Service man who battles age and memory to protect his honor. Lean, lanky and laconic, he has always specialized in loners with a slyly ironic smile: men cut off by temperament and circumstance from the world around them. 
 This is a minimalist cowboy who could make you feel lucky (or unlucky). This is someone who could make your day.
In his new biography of Clint Eastwood, the film critic Richard Schickel writes that the actor has "taken the American male deeper into the country of disaffection than he has ever ridden before on screen, reversing the great theme of our adventure movies, which has been male bonding, and insisting upon the opposite, the difficulty men have in making connections -- not just with other men, but with communities, with women, with conventional morality, with their own best selves." Mr. Eastwood's screen character, he goes on, "represents an isolation more radically withdrawn than anyone has ever offered in movies intended for, and embraced by, a popular audience."
As he has demonstrated in his excellent short essays, ("Schickel on Film," 1989), Mr. Schickel knows how to use his prodigious knowledge of cinematic history to create portraits of film artists that illuminate their individual talents while at the same time situating them within a social and esthetic context. In this volume, he does an authoritative job of tracing Mr. Eastwood's development as an actor and director, and he also gives the reader a highly nuanced appreciation of Mr. Eastwood's iconographic role as a symbol of American manhood and American individualism as it has evolved in the second half of the 20th century. In addition, he provides a persuasive repudiation of critics like Pauline Kael, who have consistently underestimated Mr. Eastwood's enduring talents.
Unfortunately, Mr. Schickel's unabashed enthusiasm for Mr. Eastwood -- he has known the actor for almost two decades and seems to regard him as a kind of friend -- also leads him to hagiographic excess. He devotes pages and pages to lesser films like "Every Which Way but Loose" (in which Mr. Eastwood starred with an orangutan) and "The Beguiled" (in which he played a wounded Union soldier who recuperates at a girls' school), frequently rationalizing their weaknesses and inflating their importance. Even an early guest appearance by Mr. Eastwood on "Mr. Ed" (the television series about a talking horse) is carefully assessed.
Mr. Schickel tends to be equally verbose when it comes to Mr. Eastwood's personal life, repeatedly telling us about his kindness toward animals ("his humane relationship with the lower phyla") and his loyalty to friends. On the matter of Mr. Eastwood's contentious breakup with his longtime girlfriend, Sondra Locke, Mr. Schickel portrays the actor as having been remarkably "indulgent" over the years, given Ms. Locke's continuing relationship with her husband, Gordon Anderson.
The Eastwood who emerges from this book is an agreeably reserved man who usually keeps "the nuclear capability of his anger" under wraps. That temper, Mr. Schickel suggests, has roots in Mr. Eastwood's Depression-era childhood, when economic hardship forced his family to relocate repeatedly and made him feel lonely and displaced.
Those experiences, Mr. Schickel writes, taught the actor two lessons: "Do everything in your power to lessen the impact of mischance, whether it be cosmic or mundane; do not trust institutions to do this job. Or, to put the point more positively, turn yourself into an institution and set your own rules of work and conduct, your own boundaries against intrusion. Then insist that this institution, this lengthened shadow of yourself, devote itself to the celebration of characters variously subversive, antisocial, rebellious. In a phrase, place the rage for one kind of order in the service of a rage against a different sort of order."
This outlook led Mr. Eastwood to form his own production company, and to try, as he gained increasing power and recognition, to achieve a kind of autonomy within the business to direct himself or "employ people he knew would defer to him." As for his suspicion of institutional authority, it would be reflected in Mr. Eastwood's choice of movie roles (from the outlaws in Sergio Leone's spaghetti westerns through Dirty Harry and Will Munny in "Unforgiven"), roles that would not only establish his distinctive screen persona, but that would also help revise the genre conventions of the western and the thriller.
Although Mr. Schickel gives the reader a palpable sense of Mr. Eastwood's career, from his early days on the television series "Rawhide" through his latest movie, "The Bridges of Madison County," his descriptions of Mr. Eastwood's achievement have a way of curdling into pretentious overstatement. Of the evolution of the actor's screen persona, he writes: "A rude beast had been perceived slouching toward the Bethlehem of the New Masculinity, waiting to be reborn in more cuddlesome form." And of the characters in "Unforgiven," he writes: "We have no trouble seeing Will M. as Josef K., seeing Little Bill Daggett as the keeper of a dark castle, or as the judge at an endless trial where no one knows exactly what he has done to deserve such hard punishment."
Such passages have one effect: they make the reader wish that Mr. Schickel had emulated Mr. Eastwood's own "appraising taciturnity," his "preternatural cool."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Bill Clinton's New America

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
With determined concentration, President Clinton has worked a historic change in American foreign policy. Foreign policy amounts to a nation's political, moral and military stance in the world, its role and values. For America, the change will affect all these, and for ill.
Mr. Clinton has made trade the foundation of his foreign policy, far surpassing other traditional American goals and values, like democracy and human rights, and often overriding security interests. 
 Central to this change is China, with whose President he has decided to exchange state visits, to further his suddenly proclaimed "partnership" between the world's largest democracy and its largest tyranny. The message he sent to all who hoped the U.S. would help them attain some relief from political oppression and religious persecution is: Don't.
Easily grasped everywhere. Today China and occupied Tibet, tomorrow Cuba, Burma, Indonesia, Africa, the Mideast -- who can know this inconstant heart?
Mr. Clinton worked long to achieve the turnaround. Diligently he broke his promises of help to China's victims and instead tied his Administration to the overarching trade value. Consistently, he and the people with the stomach to carry out his policy underrated Chinese violations of agreements against sales of missiles or nuclear-warfare material.
And in tireless duplicity, they told America the issue was to "isolate" China or not. False: Human rights supporters cheered when Nixon-Kissinger "opened" China. They wanted it opened not for the weird so-called realpolitik of building Chinese power, but precisely to bring China's people out of the isolation of despotism.
Once, conservatives could be expected to oppose strengthening Communist power. No longer; as the left abandoned anti-Communism, the right has abandoned human rights. On this -- nothing to choose, between Bob Dole and Bill Clinton.
Once liberals opposed dictatorships that conservatives found congenial. No longer; Democrats grub money from the Indonesian dictatorship and rationalize the Chinese.
Senator Sam Nunn says China did not make much progress in our definition of human rights, but made a lot in a "broader" definition -- economic betterment.
This is the classic rationalization by dictators and for dictators. Now it allocates different human values to Asians. It says that America was able to rise economically from its revolution while expanding freedoms, but Asians are not.
Also corruptive of democratic values is the libocon position that the business of the world is now business, so if the right to talk without risk of arrest and torture has any lingering interest, let American businesses in China handle it.
It was never the business of business to take over from the American people and government the responsibility for human rights or even workers' rights. That protected America from the corporate government so dear to totalitarians.
At home, the rights to collective bargaining, Social Security and defined working conditions were not granted by business but came through the appropriate mixture of public opinion, legislation and business needs. Abroad, that mix created embargoes against South Africa and Cuba, and refusal to obey rules of the Arab boycott of Israel.
In China, U.S. businesses grow in numbers but not in inclination to walk up to one of Mr. Clinton's Chinese partners for a stern chat about the Chinese gulag. The idea that U.S. business would do that now because its own Government was abdicating on human rights may ease the conscience but is self-deceiving.
Mr. Clinton did not even get a decent bid for his change of policy. Economically China promised him only huge American trade deficits. Now China blackmails U.S. companies with demands for technology that would put more Americans out of work. The Clintonians failed with limp attempts to persuade China not to keep selling missile and nuclear technology to terrorist nations.
So, we must understand. Those human rights promises he made in the 1992 campaign -- he never intended to keep them. So be it. The human rights cause had been sold out before Mr. Clinton came cozily along. It rose, and will again.

HEADLINE: House Resales Fell by 1.5% In October

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Sales of existing houses dropped by 1.5 percent in October, the fifth consecutive monthly drop, the National Association of Realtors said today, providing further evidence that the housing market is slowing.
The association said house resales declined to an annual rate of 3.97 million in October, and it revised its figure for September to 2.7 percent. The October figures were lower than expected; analysts had predicted a drop of three-tenths of 1 percent last month. 
 The figures reflect actual closings.
Even though mortgage rates are falling, the housing market for 1997 is not expected to sustain the big contribution it made to the economy this year, analysts said. "Housing has gone as far as it will go for now," Jim Glassman, senior economist at Chase Securities Inc. in New York, said.
Despite the decline in resales, John Tuccillo, the chief economist with the association, said the average of monthly resales would set a record of more than four million this year. "It's been a banner year for housing," he said. "Next year, while it will be a good year, probably will be off 5 percent."
Even if the housing market slows, many economists still think the economy will sustain its moderate growth and low inflation through next year. That is the view of the National Association of Business Economists, which released a forecast today by 44 corporate economists, saying that the economy will grow at a 2.3 percent average annual pace in 1997 and that the Consumer Price Index would rise 2.9 percent.
That is in line with expectations of the Federal Reserve, which decided last month to leave the overnight lending rate for banks unchanged at 5.25 percent.
Resales of houses fell 1 percent in the Midwest, to an annual rate of 1.02 million, the National Association of Realtors said, and 5.8 percent in the South, to an annual rate of 1.45 million. In the Northeast, resales rose 3.3 percent, to an annual rate of 620,000, and in the West they rose 3.5 percent, to an annual rate of 880,000.
The strong resales rate in the West is chiefly the result of activity in the San Francisco Bay area, where resales rose 15.4 percent last month from October 1995, a real estate information service said last week.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Heating and Crude Oil Down On Apparent Iraq-U.N. Deal

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Prices for crude and heating oil retreated on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after Iraq agreed to the terms of a United Nations plan that would allow Iraqi oil to return to the world market.
On other markets, copper prices rose. 
 Nizar Hamdoon, Iraq's representative at the United Nations, confirmed in a letter to U.N. officials that Iraq no longer objected to some terms of the deal, which had originally been reached on May 20.
The United States had insisted all issues relating to the deal must be addressed before approving a pricing mechanism, while Iraq had wanted to first approve pricing.
"People after all these delays are taking the approach, 'We'll believe it when the oil's being loaded,' but this is the closest it's been in a long time," said Tim Evans, an analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group.
The United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, said that a pricing mechanism still must be completed; other officials also said that hardware for physical shipments of oil must be repaired.
The United Nations plan would allow Iraq to export as much as $2 billion of oil during a six-month period to pay for food and medicine.
Iraq estimated that oil would be flowing by mid-December. Analysts estimated that it would be mid-January before oil reaches the market.
Crude oil for January delivery fell 26 cents, to $23.49 a barrel. Other energy futures were also lower. December unleaded gasoline rose 0.19 cent, to 67.99 cents a gallon, and December heating oil fell 0.56 cent, to 72.23 cents a pound.
Copper prices rose on expectations that the London Metal Exchange would again report a sharp decline in its warehouse supplies today.
The International Copper Study Group said yesterday that its analysis of the market suggested that supply and demand would be in balance this year, which was taken as positive since most expectations have been for a surplus.
On the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, December copper rose 1.35 cents, to $1.059 a pound.
