HEADLINE: U.N. Reports a Billion Adults Not Fully Employed

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 25

 BODY:
The number of adults worldwide who were either unemployed or underemployed rose to one billion in 1995, according to a United Nations report that also warned that such levels are not sustainable.
The International Labor Organization report, to be officially released Tuesday, rebuked industrialized countries for dropping the goal of full employment and suggested ways to decrease joblessness. 
 "Current levels of unemployment make no economic sense and are neither politically nor socially sustainable," the agency's head, Michel Hansenne, wrote.
The 1995 figure was an increase of about 180 million people over 1993 and 1994, when the United Nations warned that the estimated 820 million underemployed or unemployed represented a crisis not seen since the Great Depression. Although the situation has worsened, the agency did not refer to that assessment in this year's report.
Unemployment in the 15 European Union nations increased in 1995 to 11.3 percent of the work force, compared with 2 percent in the 1960's, the report said. France, Germany, Italy and Sweden showed the biggest increases in unemployment, and Spain had the highest jobless rate at 22.3 percent.
In central and eastern Europe, unemployment remained at double-digit levels in most countries, the report said. Nearly one-third of the jobless were below the age of 25.
Unemployment increased in many Latin American countries. Although there were few figures for Africa and Asia, underemployment exists on a large scale in the developing world, the report said. Overall, about 30 percent of the world's labor force was either unemployed or underemployed, it said.
The organization said sustained economic growth is the best way to get people back to work, citing the United States as a success.
From August through October, the United States jobless rate has been at about 5.1 percent, a seven-year low, according to Labor Department figures.

HEADLINE: Iraq and U.N. Make Deal on Oil Sales for Aid

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Iraq and the United Nations announced today that they had reached a final agreement on the long-delayed deal allowing Iraq to sell oil for food and other emergency goods for the country's suffering civilian population.
Diplomats said Iraqi oil could begin flowing again as early as next month, for the first time in six years. The plan has seemed close to implementation before, only to be stalled because of disputes or objections raised by the United States or Iraq. 
 "I think we made an important step forward today," said an American official who has worked closely with the negotiations.
The plan allowing Iraq to sell $2 billion worth of oil in a renewable six-month period can go into effect as soon as the Security Council committee overseeing the sanctions agrees to a formula for determining the price of the oil.
Citing strong demand and low reserves at refineries, oil analysts said the sales are likely to only slightly reduce the cost of a barrel of oil on world markets.
Oil experts will also have to verify that oil-metering equipment on the Iraq-Turkish border is functioning. Iraq had removed the meters but has promised to reinstall them. Most of the oil is expected to flow through a Turkish pipeline. A smaller amount will be exported through the Iraq port of Mina al-Bakr.
"The United States is very pleased at this action," Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations said today. "For the last two years we have been working on a way to make sure that the people of Iraq are able to have additional humanitarian assistance."
Iraq has been under sanctions since its invasion of Kuwait in 1990. Although the government is permitted to import food, medicines and other urgently needed commodities, it has not done so.
After international agencies began reporting the deteriorating health and living standards of Iraq civilians, especially children, the Security Council proposed the oil-for-food plan in the spring of 1995 as a limited exemption to sanctions. A year and a half of haggling followed.
Sanctions are intended to stay in effect until Iraq eliminates or accounts for all its weapons of mass destruction. Baghdad has consistently stalled or lied about its arsenal to United Nations weapons inspectors, and no early lifting of sanctions seems likely.
Ms. Albright denied today that the Clinton Administration had been holding up the implementation of the new oil-for-food plan until after the American presidential elections. European diplomats had voiced suspicion earlier this fall that the Americans would not want to be seen doing anything that might be construed as relaxing the sanctions while Mr. Clinton was pursuing re-election.
Ms. Albright said President Saddam Hussein was responsible for recurring delays in agreeing to the plan's details, following an agreement in principle last May.
In August, the Iraqis put the plan in jeopardy by sending troops into the Kurdish areas of northern Iraq to takes sides in a flareup of an old civil conflict between Kurdish factions under international protection. The oil-sale plan mandates that about $130 million to $150 million in oil-sale purchases go to the Kurdish areas, to be distributed by relief agencies working with the United Nations.
American diplomats now seem confident that the distribution can go ahead in the Kurdish areas without Baghdad's interference. Iraqi officials will distribute goods in the rest of the country, observed by international monitors appointed by the United Nations.
A third of the oil proceeds will be earmarked for a compensation fund for victims of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Claims have been accumulating at the fund's headquarters in Geneva, where there is no money to pay them.

U.S. to Evacuate More Kurds
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The United States will evacuate some 5,000 Kurds and others from northern Iraq because of fears that they may be in imminent danger from Iraqi security forces, the State Department said today.
In the next few days, the Kurds and others will be taken to Turkey and then flown to Guam, where they will be processed for asylum in the United States, said a State Department spokesman, Glyn Davies.
Those being evacuated worked for 24 organizations supported or financed by the United States, Mr. Davies said, and "they bear the mark of the U.S. on them."
The mission to evacuate them will be a joint operation with Turkey, and the impact on relief efforts in northern Iraq was not clear. The latest evacuees were left behind after an American-led rescue in September of 2,000 others from the region, including Kurds who had worked for United States Government agencies.

HEADLINE: Clinton in Manila: Successes Are Not Spectacular, but Still Useful

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: MANILA, Nov. 25

 BODY:
When Bill Clinton assembled Asia's leaders for their first summit meeting, three years ago in Seattle, he talked grandly about building a "Pacific community," stitching together countries with no natural alliances, few common ethnic ties, vastly different economies and centuries-old rivalries.
Curiously, on his 12-day tour of the Pacific, which concludes on Tuesday in Thailand, Mr. Clinton has yet to use that term. His own Asia hands concede that in this age of atomized foreign policies, even the common bond of booming trade and investments across borders creates something well short of a community. 
 Measured by the overarching vision that Mr. Clinton sketched out, the annual meetings he inaugurated have accomplished little but vague assurances of "free and open trade" over the next 25 years.
But by other measures -- less headline-grabbing, certainly, and far short of a grand architecture for America's relationship with the most vibrant economies of the world -- the meetings have become enormously useful for Mr. Clinton.
And in at least three significant ways, they have changed the dynamics of how America negotiates with Asia and the rest of the world.
Mr. Clinton pointed out the most important of those changes at a private lunch today with the 17 other leaders of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation group at the former American naval base at Subic Bay.
"If it wasn't for APEC, Jiang Zemin and I would have barely met," he said, pointing to the Chinese President. In fact, Sunday's 85-minute meeting with Mr. Jiang was the third one at a Pacific summit, and none of the encounters would have been likely if the annual gathering did not exist.
Dialogue, of course, is very different from progress, and certainly the meetings have done little to resolve differences between the two countries. But those sessions may have also kept their uneasy relationship from jumping the rails at critical points.
The same might be said of Mr. Clinton's tense meeting with President Kim Young Sam of South Korea over how to handle military provocations from the North, a subject that has caused a rift between Washington and Seoul in the last two months.
The second change wrought by the summit meetings has as much to do with Europe as with America. With remarkable speed, the Administration has used its new relationship with Asia's vibrant economies to persuade -- and sometimes bludgeon -- recalcitrant European officials into agreements that otherwise would have taken years to achieve.
Mr. Clinton said as much at dinner at Malacalang Palace last night, corralling his opposite numbers to endorse a worldwide agreement to wipe out tariffs on computers and information technologies, an agreement that will benefit America and Asia far more than Europe.
"This was the big surprise," one of Mr. Clinton's top economic aides said the other day. "The Europeans are terrified of being left behind in our relationship with Asia -- technologically, economically, diplomatically. And you can play on that fear to accomplish some good."
And finally, the summit meetings have eased, but hardly eliminated, Asia's recurring suspicions about America's intentions.
Those suspicions take many forms, from worries that the United States is no longer committed to keeping 100,000 troops in the region, to the often-voiced certainty that America is manipulating the global trading system to its own advantage, forcing countries to swallow free trade agreements before they have a chance to nurture protected infant industries, the way Japan and South Korea did.
"It's taken us years to convince people, at home and in Asia, that we really do see economic security and national security as a seamless whole," Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor said here. "The advantage to having the President meet every year with Asia's leaders -- more often with a few of them -- is that it gives you new ways to demonstrate that economic interdependence builds peace and stability."
The problem is that no one has yet figured out how to build a strategic vision of the world out of this merger.
Even Washington cannot quite figure out how to integrate the two. Ronald H. Brown, the Commerce Secretary who died in a plane crash in Croatia in April, used to call the kind of work that Mr. Clinton was engaged in this weekend "commercial diplomacy," building ties by doing deals. Under that umbrella the Administration has focused enormous attention on "big emerging markets" like Indonesia and India, which never commanded the attention they should have in Washington.
But before he died, Mr. Brown conceded that he had yet to prove that more and more commercial interaction with the West would bring China, for example, around on human rights or prevention of the spread of nuclear weapons.
The other problem with commercial diplomacy viewed at the ground level is that it can be excruciatingly boring. Arms control talks were jammed with unintelligible acronyms, but at least the subject matter involved life and death.
Mr. Clinton found himself compelled today to describe as "a big deal" an important but unexciting agreement-to-agree on lowering tariffs on computers, chips and a range of other products.
Under the Administration's first term, there is little question that such accords, while unexciting, have become the building blocks of deeper relationships.
Coming up with acceptable wording on the information technology accord, for example, forced Mr. Clinton to deal directly with Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, the most persistent critic of America's central role in the Asia and Pacific group. It was an interesting encounter, because Dr. Mahathir had boycotted the first summit meeting in Seattle. He has apparently decided since then that Malaysia cannot afford to sit it out, and he called today's summit meeting a success.
Similarly, the first sign this spring that the Administration's relationship with China was slowly emerging from the deep freeze came when the two countries ended a fight over the piracy of software and videos.
Such political gains have become the subtext of these purely economic summit meetings.
"You can look at these narrowly and say that we are just slogging through, talking about goals for the year 2020," said C. Fred Bergsten, who led the "eminent persons group" that set the early agendas for these meetings. "And by that measure there isn't much to celebrate. But think of how little these countries talked four years ago, and how much they are talking now."

HEADLINE: Republicans Outline Proposal To Press for Modest Change

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Nov. 25

 BODY:
In a sharp contrast to their post-election gathering two years ago, Republicans meeting here today outlined an "incrementalist" 1997 agenda of specifically directed tax cuts, modest changes in Medicaid and as much cooperation with President Clinton as possible.
The Republican governors and Congressional leaders also promised swift action in the House and Senate on a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget. They said that after this month's elections, they appeared to have the decisive votes for the measure that died by a single vote in the Senate last year. 
 As the governors promised to lobby hard to get the amendment through Congress and then ratified in state legislatures, they appealed to Republican Congressional leaders for help on a number of Federal issues with huge effects on state budgets, from Medicaid and job training programs to next year's reauthorization of the Federal highway program.
"We take very seriously working together with the Republican governors," Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia said.
Two years ago, the post-election meeting between Republican governors and Congressional leaders took on extra meaning because the Republicans had just won control of Congress and 30 governorships. Then, Mr. Gingrich led a parade of speakers who promised governors a Republican revolution that would balance the budget, cut taxes deeply and shift power over welfare, Medicaid and scores of other programs from Washington to the states.
Welfare changes were enacted late last year, but some of the other promises never materialized. And much of their success was overshadowed by the budget battle with Mr. Clinton that, in the eyes of many voters, made the Republicans seem harsh and overly combative.
So even as the Republicans celebrated their success in defending their control of the House and Senate, this year's meeting was conducted in a pragmatic atmosphere.
"I think we have learned some good lessons," said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader. "I'm not interested in making a statement. I'm interested in producing results."
The tone seemed to suit most of the governors, although several favor a more aggressive push for tax cuts than was outlined by the Congressional leaders.
"The election results proved people don't want their leaders to stray too far to the right or to the left," said Gov. Jim Edgar of Illinois. "The Congressional Republican leadership is a very pragmatic bunch."
Pushing the balanced budget amendment is a safe way for Republicans to begin the new year. It was clear, however, that the Republicans were prepared to be cautious on more controversial issues.
The Republican budget plan in 1995 called for $245 billion in tax cuts, including a $500 per child tax credit and reductions in taxes on capital gains. Mr. Clinton has embraced the child credit and called for other specific tax cuts to help pay for college and to exempt most home sales from capital-gains taxes.
In 1995, Republicans had a take-it-or-leave-it approach on taxes. But Mr. Gingrich said the party was happy to take "an incrementalist approach" for the next few years, passing the "largest signable tax cut" in 1997 and then revisiting the issue every year after that.
"It adds up to a whole lot by the year 2000," he said, predicting that Republicans would do even better in the 1998 midterm elections than they did this year.
Mr. Lott, likewise, said Republicans had no magic number for tax cuts in 1997. He supported the thrust of Mr. Clinton's plans but said Republicans would seek a broader reduction in capital-gains taxes to stimulate an economy that he said was showing signs of sluggishness.
On Medicaid, the Republicans said they would bow to political reality and seek incremental reforms if Mr. Clinton did not change his position.
In the last Congressional term, the Republicans were adamant that the program be converted into block grants to the states, an approach Mr. Clinton rejected, saying it would put the poor and the disabled elderly at risk. "In order for anything to be effective," Mr. Lott said, "he has to be part of the solution."

HEADLINE: Dow Surges 76.03 to Top 6,500 As Post-Election Rally Roars On

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average, continuing its post-election surge, leaped past 6,500 points for the first time yesterday, a move that came only six weeks after the index first topped 6,000.
The Dow gained 76.03 points, to 6,547.79, pushing the widely watched barometer up 8.6 percent so far this month. If the market hangs on to these gains for the rest of this week, it would be the best month for the Dow in almost five years. 
 The surge has come amid enthusiasm over the status quo election results, which Wall Street hopes offer more of the same, and amid a spate of fairly weak economic statistics, which have reassured investors that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates.
"The market perceives we are in a perfect environment, with a Goldilocks economy and Goldilocks politics," said David Shulman, the chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, with the economic and political porridge neither too hot nor too cold.
Many other indexes also moved to highs, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock rising 8.30 points, to 757.03, and the Nasdaq composite index up 6.01 points, to 1,280.37. Utility stocks were especially strong, with the Dow Jones utilities average rising 2.72 points, to 238.12, a three-year high.
Mr. Shulman said that based on his estimate for earnings by the stocks in the S.& P. 500 that index ended the day at 18.9 times 1996 profits. Pointing to data since 1950, he said that the index had occasionally traded at higher multiples of earnings when those profits had been depressed by a recession, but he said it had never traded higher in the middle or late stages of an economic recovery.
At the peak in 1968, he said, the multiple was 18.8. It was at 18.7 at the high in 1972, before the disastrous 1973-74 bear market, and peaked at 18 in 1987, before the crash that year. "I'm getting very worried," Mr. Shulman said.
But he appears to be in a minority. Money continues to pour into mutual funds and companies continue to announce plans to buy back their stock. And the greater fear of both investors and money managers seems to be that they will miss a further increase, not that they might be caught in a price decline.
The Dow is now up 28 percent for the year. That is not quite as good as the 33.5 percent gain in 1995, but it is otherwise the best since 1975, when the Dow was recovering from the 1973-74 bear market.
And the two-year gain for the Dow, assuming the index closes at current levels, would be 70.8 percent. That would be the best such stretch for the index since 1954-55, when it rose 73.9 percent. Should the Dow climb to 6,667 by the end of the year, it would be the best two-year showing since 1927-28. The current month is in line to be the best since December 1991, when the index rose 9.5 percent.
But those statistics overstate just how well the stock market has done this year. Particularly since July, when the market suffered its worst dip of the year, this has been a rally dominated by large stocks. The Nasdaq composite has moved to highs because it is now strongly influenced by large companies, like Intel and Microsoft.
But the Russell 2000 index, which measures the performance of 2,000 stocks that, by market capitalization, are smaller than the 1,000 largest, is up just 11.5 percent for 1996 and is still below the peak it reached in May. Yesterday it rose 2.37 points, to 352.29, not nearly as strong a showing as larger indexes. Among money managers, the July dip seemed to create a desire for the safety represented by large, well-established companies.
Intel, for example, fell 7/8 yesterday, to 121 1/2, but is still up 89 percent since its July low. During that stretch, its market capitalization has risen by $47 billion. By contrast, the common stock of General Motors, which rose 3/4 yesterday, to 58 1/4, and is up 27 percent since its July low, has a total market value of just $43 billion.
The strongest performers among the Dow industrials yesterday included Philip Morris, up 3 1/4, to 105 1/2; J. P. Morgan, up 2 5/8, to 93, and General Electric, up 2 3/4, to 103 3/4. Philip Morris and other tobacco stocks surged on the news that David Kessler had resigned as head of the Food and Drug Administration. Banks were among the market leaders, with other strong performers, aside from Morgan, including BankAmerica, up 5 3/8, to 103 1/8, and Banc One up 1 1/2, to 46 1/4.
One of the oldest market theories holds that a bull market is clearly in force only if both the Dow industrials, which make the goods, and the Dow transports, which move them, are setting highs. By that standard, the current bull market has not been confirmed, because the Dow transports remain below the peak of 2,296.20 reached on May 22. But it is getting close, rising 24.41 points, to 2,289.75 yesterday. The strongest stocks in that index included Federal Express, up 1 7/8, to 44 1/4; USAir, up 3/4, to 23; AMR, the parent of American Airlines, up 1 5/8, to 92 5/8, and Union Pacific, up 7/8, to 57 7/8.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Owners to Meet Today On Labor Agreement

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Reject or ratify. Once more into the breach the owners step, given a second chance today to act on a labor deal they resoundingly rejected three weeks ago. Although no one can say what the outcome will be when the owners meet in Chicago today, the talk in recent days was that enough owners were prepared to change their votes to reverse the result.
But for the agreement to be ratified, 11 of the 18 owners who voted against the agreement on Nov. 6 would have to reverse their positions and the 12 ayes would have to remain in that column. Those numbers indicate that the optimism with which some people are viewing the second vote could be wishful thinking.
Owners could change their votes from no to yes for two reasons: 
 They are furious that Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox gave Albert Belle a record $55 million contract after leading the opposition to the agreement with the argument that the pact needed greater restraint on player salaries.
They have spent the past three weeks staring reality in its ugly face and concluded that they don't want to continue operating under the existing economic system and at war with the players.
Even Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, was said by an owner familiar with his thinking to be tiring of the fight. At the last meeting, Selig refused to take a public position on the agreement despite pleas from others to do so. According to one person who attended the meeting, Peter O'Malley of the Dodgers said repeatedly: "Bud, you are our leader. You must have a position. Tell us what your position is."
The owner familiar with Selig's thinking said that Selig was considering altering his stance today. A Selig endorsement, many management people have said, would prompt an undetermined number of other owners to vote for the deal. Selig did not return a telephone call yesterday seeking comment on his position or plans.
One indication of Selig's position could be the location of Randy Levine, the owners' chief negotiator, when the owners discuss the agreement and vote. At the Nov. 6 meeting, Levine was asked to leave when the meeting reached the critical stage of final discussion and vote. If Selig asks him to stay in the room today, it could be a sign that Selig will push for the agreement.
Selig's position aside, it was clear that some owners were upset with Reinsdorf for the Belle contract and for what they called his hypocrisy.
"You can't advocate one position publicly and do another thing privately," one owner said. "I have no idea what people are going to do, but I hope it will shock some of my peers and they'll say, 'Let's get this deal done.' "
Another owner said: "A lot of people are infuriated. You can't say one thing and do another."
Like Reinsdorf, who also owns the Chicago Bulls, Stan Kasten of the Atlanta Braves has a basketball team, the Hawks, as well as a baseball team. He defended Reinsdorf, saying: "I don't see anything hypocritical about it at all. Jerry is consistent. Jerry, in the two sports I'm familiar with him, competes as hard as he can under the prevailing system. All he says is the system is severely flawed in baseball."
However the owners vote today, the vote clearly will be the last chance for interleague play next season. Clubs have clamored for the 1997 schedule so they can start selling tickets, and Selig is feeling pressure to release it. If the owners reject the deal again, the teams will play a traditional schedule next year.
If the owners ratify the agreement, Levine will have to discuss two issues with the union. One is the free-agent status of certain players, including Jimmy Key, whom the Yankees retained by offering salary arbitration. Under the new agreement, Key would have been a free agent.
The other issue is the size of the players' pool from the first round of the playoffs. Under the new agreement, the players would have received 60 percent from that round this year, but without the deal in place, shares were computed on the basis of 80 percent, which the players had previously received.
It's too late to change back to 60 percent because the checks are in the mail. They were put there yesterday.

HEADLINE: Biting Into Food Industry Profits;
Downsizing Prevails as Customers Resist Paying More

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J.

 BODY:
It may be every grocery shopper's fundamental right to complain, but in these days of low inflation and competing superstores on every strip, there is less than usual to complain about. Walk down the wide aisles of the Pathmark 2000 supermarket here, for example, and you will see shelves jammed with a record variety of new goods in a time of stable prices.
Good times for consumers, though, have meant hard times for the packaged-food companies putting all those soups, cereals and cookies on the shelves. Unable to raise prices, and with margins squeezed by competition among retailers, the industry is looking inward for ways to please Wall Street, and its employees are paying. Consider these examples: 
 Shoppers here pay $3.29 for a 20-ounce box of Kellogg's Raisin Bran, 26 percent less than a year ago. The price for Kellogg Company workers: 1,400 fewer employees by the end of 1996, analysts estimate, on top of 6,000 lost over the last 15 years.
A can of Campbell's chicken noodle soup has 33 percent more chicken than a year ago. But the Campbell Soup Company is eliminating 650 employees this year, more than 100 of them in its poultry-processing operations. The company is cutting costs by buying from outside contractors and yesterday it announced yet another internal reorganization of its food operations.
Shelves of Pathmark stores, owned by Supermarket General Holdings, are crowded with new low-fat offerings from Snackwell's, like Iced Fudge Toaster Pastries for $2.19. Yet Snackwell's, the sales phenomenon of 1995, is struggling as other companies weigh in with similar products. Its owner, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, is undergoing a $428 million reorganization.
All told, at least 100,000 jobs have been lost in the food industry, in a relatively invisible reorganization that is still reminiscent of more high-profile contractions in the banking and aerospace industries. This time, the impetus is nothing so dramatic as deregulation or the end of the cold war, but rather the food companies' inability to raise prices in the era of shareholder value, when profit growth is an imperative.
"These days, supermarket aisles are the most violent places in the world," said Bob Messenger, editor and publisher of Food Trends Newsletter in Palatine, Ill. The big food companies are trying to adapt to a marketplace "that is more fickle and competitive, dangerous and risky than ever before," he said.
"People may want lower prices," he said, "but some of them end up as victims of downsizing."
John M. McMillin, a securities analyst for Prudential Securities Research, said that at least 100,000 jobs had been lost. "My guess is that about 10 percent to 15 percent of the employees in the entire packaged-food industry have been terminated in the last 18 months," he said.
Most food companies had already reorganized, even while inflation allowed them to pursue a favorite strategy for raising profits: routine price increases.
But now, consumers are resisting "pricing," as sticker increases are called, shopping for bargains among less expensive private-label and store brands, buying in bulk from warehouse clubs, and benefiting from price wars among a profusion of grocery chains, discounters and convenience stores.
"The routine across-the-board, 4 percent price hike twice a year is a thing of the past," said Paul S. Walsh, chief executive of the Pillsbury Company in Minneapolis, a subsidiary of the London-based Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. "You may be able to eke out a 2 percent rise if your costs spike up, or go up 1 percent here or there. But that's it."
At the same time, retailers are charging more for shelf space for new products, and those higher slotting fees now come directly out of earnings, instead of price rises. But flat earnings are fiscally incorrect. And so the industry is resorting to new rounds of reorganization, cost-cutting and downsizing. The only other option is to expand abroad, where European giants like Unilever N.V. are adopting the American lean-and-mean strategy to defend their turf.
"Most of the larger companies are looking at fairly modest growth in a mature United States market," Terry Bivens, an analyst at Donald & Company, said. "So if you're going to have growth, you have to find it overseas or cut your costs."
The poster company for this new environment is the once-stodgy Campbell, whose chief executive, David W. Johnson, woke up a roomful of sleepy securities analysts in September by announcing that his new plan for the company was more reorganization -- expected to cost $160 million and 650 jobs.
Campbell had already undergone six years of reorganization under Mr. Johnson, which helped to lift its share price 240 percent while cutting 9,000 jobs. Investors happily responded to yesterday's announcement by lifting the stock 25 cents, to $83.125.
The world's largest soup maker is hardly alone in the roster of the incredible shrinking food companies. The H. J. Heinz Company, Unilever, Conagra Inc., Nabisco, the Quaker Oats Company and Kellogg have all recently announced cost-cutting or major reorganizations.
Consumer resistance to high prices has caused tumult in the $8 billion cereal category, where shoppers have turned to private-label products or abandoned cereal for "breakfast substitutes" such as bagels and muffins.
"Those high prices were so out of line, I boycotted cereal," Barbara McGee, a mother of two from Greensboro, N.C., said. "We realized we could do very well without it."
In April, Post, which is owned by Philip Morris Companies, announced a 20 percent reduction in the retail prices of its Post and Nabisco cereals; Kellogg and General Mills Inc. followed suit. At the same time, jobs were crunched, too.
The work-force cuts in the food industry are deep, going beyond blue-collar workers into departments like marketing. Many executives have left the industry for "careers in the world of telecom and service industries, where they can bring their skill sets to high-growth areas," said Miles McKie, a partner with Heidrick & Struggles Inc., a search firm that has found jobs for many food-company executives.
Among the white-collar workers who have stayed in the industry, the job search is more challenging than ever. "The problem isn't so much finding a job, but finding a good job," said Robert Black, who was the vice president in charge of the high-growth Old El Paso Mexican-food brand at Pet Inc. in St. Louis, when Pillsbury acquired it last year.
Mr. Black said he had worked with Pillsbury for a while, "but we all knew that they would want their own management to take over." Though he helped many of his subordinates get jobs with Pillsbury, "a lot of people at Pet were let go," he said, "and a lot of people didn't want to leave St. Louis."
It took the 53-year-old Mr. Black a year to find a new job that was appropriate for his experience. He is now general manager of Barilla America, the Norwalk, Conn., subsidiary of Barilla S.p.A., the Italian pasta maker that has entered the premium pasta battleground in the United States.
Consumers are still willing to pay more for high-margin premium products such as coffees, salsas and snack foods. But even the growing variety available to consumers has a downside for the food companies.
"It costs $20 million to $80 million to introduce a new product, but it's sort of like throwing mud at the wall," Mr. Messenger said. "Whatever sticks, sticks. And whatever falls, falls. But there's not as much sticking as falling."
All of these factors have fueled a wave of mergers and acquisitions as companies seek to shed mediocre performers and acquire new category leaders. Companies are swapping divisions "like kids with trading cards," Mr. McMillin said, transforming the food business.
At the same time that Campbell announced its $160 million reorganization, for example, it also said it was paying $210 million to acquire the German soup maker Erasco Group from Grand Metropolitan to speed its expansion in Europe.
McCormick & Company sold its Gilroy Foods unit to Conagra. CPC International bought Entenmann's to combine with its Thomas's bakery business. And Heinz bought the Quaker Oats Company's $725-million pet-food business, while announcing in September that it would sell other units in the United States and abroad to concentrate on its core businesses.
The reorganization wave in the American food industry has begun to reverberate beyond the United States. The new co-chairman of the British-Dutch Unilever P.L.C., Naill Fitzgerald, recently traveled to New York and Boston to tell analysts and investors that the company planned to sell underperforming units, reorganize management and tie executive compensation to earnings growth.
"We are talking about rationalizing companies' total portfolios," Nomi Ghez, an analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company, said. "In the past, companies would hang on to small businesses even if they were No. 2 or No. 3 in the market. Now they can no long afford to."
Campbell's reorganization announcement was a significant symbol of the new competitive landscape, Ms. Ghez said. "Everyone thought Campbell had done all the restructuring it could do -- and then they told us there is a lot still to be done," she said. Yesterday, Campbell did even more, stitching together its international bakery, grocery, frozen and specialty food operations into a new global business unit.
Yet as consumers benefit, each round of reorganization takes a new toll on the industry. "There are no nags anymore in this industry," Mr. Messenger said. "They are all thoroughbreds, and that's raising the level of competition to a killing level."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices In Mild Rally On New Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
A weak housing report and a strong dollar combined to raise the prices of Treasury securities yesterday, with the 30-year maturity leading the mild rally.
Investors bought after the National Association of Realtors reported a 1.5 percent drop in the number of October home resales, to an annual rate of 3.97 million. That was less than the 4.01 million annual rate expected by analysts surveyed by Bloomberg Business News, reinforcing investors' perception that the economy was indeed cooling, reducing the chances of a rise in inflation and higher interest rates. 
 The 30-year benchmark issue was up 7/32 , to a price of 1011/32 , for a yield of 6.42 percent, down from 6.44 percent on Friday. The yield has been hovering at eight-month-low levels.
Jack Ablin, director of fixed income and senior fund manager of the Private Bank at the Bank of Boston, said that although activity was thin in Treasury trading, the corporate side saw a substantial amount of activity. The day's largest deal was by Chase Capital Securities, a subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, which made the public offering of preferred capital notes through Morgan Stanley & Company.
"Out of the $600 million offering by Chase Capital Securities," Mr. Ablin said, "I only got half of what I wanted, and that has to show you how much investor interest there was."
The preferred capital notes carried a 7.67 percent coupon, with a 30-year maturity and a 10-year call provision. They were priced to yield 120 basis points, or 1.2 percentage points, more than the 6.75 percent Treasury issue due Aug. 15, 2026.
"Coming into today the bond market was on a down note," Mr. Ablin said, "but then the Treasury took a positive turn that was helped by a weak housing report. More notably, it was the October home resale data and a strengthening dollar in overnight trading that contributed to the positive tone of the market."
Other factors keeping bonds on a solid footing included continued bullish sentiment, along with a buy-on-the-dip mentality, which kept profit taking to a minimum. In addition to the strong dollar, bonds were aided by stock market gains as the Dow raced through the 6,500-point level and by investors covering short positions. In addition, the day's move was exaggerated by thin volume ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday.
Rates at the Treasury's regular auction of new three-month and six-month bills yesterday were unchanged from a week ago and in line with expectations.
Following are the results of the auction:

HEADLINE: At Island Plane Crash Site, Sorrow and a Souvenir Hunt

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: MITSAMOULI, Comoro Islands, Nov. 25

 BODY:
In the clear tropical waters rocking the shards of Ethiopian Airlines Flight 961, a variety of emotions rose and ebbed with the tides today.
For dozens of Comoran villagers and fishermen, what was left of one of the deadliest airline hijackings in history was a thrill. It was a chance for them to wade the reef where the wreckage had broken apart, scavenging bits of clothing, playing on the shattered tail, stripping cushions from the airliner's seats and then, using chunks of coral as hammers, pounding the steel seats themselves apart for scrap metal and souvenirs. 
 For a State Department team of eight Americans, it was a vigil, waiting somberly for a flattened tunnel of fuselage on the beach to be cut open and the bodies added to a tally that is expected to include 127 of the 175 passengers and crew aboard.
Among the bodies inside the beached section of fuselage were those of a colleague, Leslieanne Shedd, an official at the United States Embassy in Ethiopia, and another American who has not been publicly identified.
Near the team's feet was a small pile the scavengers were being kept far away from -- passports and other items that would help identify the bodies inside.
For the Comoran police and army, it was a day of chasing curious crowds away with nightsticks and arguing about who was going to cut open the fuselage and recover the last, largest group of bodies -- the Comorans, with their inadequate chainsaws and their self-reliant pride, or the French Navy, with its modern cutting torches and its desire to command the operation without local interference.
For the guests at the remote Galawa Beach Hotel, it was a curiosity that was growing into an irritation. Scuba diving and parasailing were canceled for the third day, though water-skiing started up in the afternoon, creating the jarring picture of vacationers joyously filling the air with spray a few hundred yards from a beached tomb for rows of cadavers hanging upside down in their seats.
"The ones who were here the day it crashed understand," said Susan Ellis, the hotel nurse who was one of the heroes of the lifesaving efforts. "But the ones who arrived afterwards -- for them it's just a nuisance."
And for the police 25 miles away in Moroni, the capital, it was a day for the startling discovery that the two men they have under arrest in the hijacking are probably innocent.
The co-pilot, who was badly beaten in the ordeal, finally saw the men today and said they were not among the three hijackers.
The arrested men say they are from Djibouti and Kenya, while the hijackers are thought to have been Ethiopian. The two are being held in protective custody while the investigation proceeds.
One body apparently remains in the cockpit 150 feet underwater -- presumably that of the lead hijacker. The other two are probably among the dead, officials said.
"So we may never know what they wanted," said Mary Ryan, assistant secretary for consular affairs and head of the State Department team. "I guess we know they did want to die, flying around in the ocean until they ran out of gas like that."
By late today, all the injured survivors except the co-pilot had left the Comoros on charter flights.
As the horror of an airline disaster turned into the grind of salvage operations, the scene of the crash seemed increasingly bizarre. The beach -- one of the small stretches of white sand on this island of lava flow -- was cordoned off for the work, so guests in bikinis gawked from the hotel side and a large crowd of locals gawked from the public end. When the guests strolled too close, Comoran soldiers politely shooed them away. When the locals edged in, the soldiers would lunge at them, waving nightsticks, until the crowd broke and fled up the sand.
Rescuers had criticized police crowd control on the day of the crash, when the beach and road were so packed with people that some victims could not be treated quickly.
Meanwhile, 200 Comorans wading in the shallow water atop a coral reef 500 yards offshore were definitely having fun, looting the plane's skeleton without any police pestering. Women with their heads wrapped in bright Indian scarves were sifting the white sand between the beds of sea urchins. After some shiny buttons that probably came from a crew jacket were found, they were hoping for gold, they said.
But they were settling for flotsam. Jimba Mgondidi proudly carried off the volume control from an armrest, its wires still dangling. "Souvenir," he said. Another man had an oxygen cylinder. A third balanced a piece of aileron on his head.
One who gave only his first name, Selemano, was hanging off the side of a massive jet engine, sawing away at its Rolls-Royce innards with a kitchen knife, yanking out expensive connectors and piping like a mad surgeon.
"I'm a mechanic," he said. "I use it for bush taxi."
The Comoros -- volcanic islands with little fertile soil where huts of palm fronds rise from foundations of lava brick -- are the poor relations of the Seychelles, Maldives, Mauritius and other Indian Ocean islands now frequented by South African and European tourists. In a country where the gross domestic product is about $527 a year per person, fishermen with outrigger pirogues were suddenly making $12 a trip taking tourists to gawk at the scene on the reef.
"Usually, I fish at night, with a hand line," said one of them, who would give only his "business name" -- Bababoshe, meaning "Beach Father. "I catch barracuda, wahoo, tuna, and sell in village."
He was making extra money today.

HEADLINE: Cisneros Tells St. Petersburg To Heal Scars

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Wrapping up a three-day visit to St. Petersburg, Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros said today that any lasting solution to the problems that led to two recent racial disturbances in that city would hinge on effectively addressing the "historic tension" between black residents and the police.
Mr. Cisneros visited St. Petersburg as leader of a Federal task force set up to help the city recover from the two riots. He said the group, which met with city leaders and residents, would recommend that the Clinton Administration pump about $20 million in Federal money into the city for minority business loans, job training, housing redevelopment and neighborhood crime-fighting programs. The recommendation would need President Clinton's approval. 
 Mr. Cisneros said the Federal effort, which came at the request of Mayor David J. Fischer, should in no way be characterized as papering over problems by doling out Federal dollars, or as a reward for disruptive behavior. "Rather," he said in a conference call with reporters, "it is an attempt to apply meaningful Federal resources to longstanding problems in the community."
Mr. Cisneros said that the Administration was committed to helping St. Petersburg and that his plans to leave office in January would not affect that aid. He said the Department of Housing and Urban Development would assign a coordinator to oversee of the Federal response.
But any meaningful change, he said, must start in St. Petersburg with relations between the police and black residents.
The Secretary said that during his visit, he talked to a cross-section of the city's black residents -- young professionals, elderly women, religious leaders -- who all complained of police mistreatment and offered emotional descriptions of "the indignities they endured."
Mr. Cisneros said he found the consensus among such a wide group of people to be unusual.
But just as "stunning," he said, was that in talks with white city leaders, many seemed to be unaware of the grievances.
"Clearly, this is a community where people need to learn to talk to each other," he said.
Racial unrest erupted last month in St. Petersburg, a city of about 245,000 residents, after a white police officer fatally shot a black teen-ager in a traffic stop, and again earlier this month when a grand jury ruled that the shooting was justified. The Department of Justice is investigating the shooting, and the United States Commission on Civil Rights has scheduled hearings in December to review race relations in the city, whose population is 19 percent black.
Although St. Petersburg officials say blacks have reached representative numbers on city boards and commissions and in the rank-and-file of the police department, economic inequities and complaints about police treatment have been persistent, simmering problems in the mostly black southern part of the city.
St. Petersburg hit one of its lowest points in 1992, when a black city manager dismissed the white police chief after the chief had canceled cultural diversity classes for officers and had been widely accused of insensitivity to minorities.
The current Chief, Darrel W. Stephens, has stepped up community policing efforts and tried to ease the racial discord inside and outside the department since he was hired in 1993. Although Mr. Cisneros said Chief Stephens, who is white, was making "good progress," the challenge was in evidence recently when the chief had to order an internal investigation shortly after the second riot because someone in his department sketched two racially offensive drawings of the teen-ager killed by the white officer.
St. Petersburg officials and civic leaders said they welcomed the Federal involvement with hope, particularly because the task force had called for the creation of a community advisory group to offer its views on whatever was done.

HEADLINE: A $7.7 Billion Union of Gas, Electricity

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The Duke Power Company, one of the nation's largest electric utilities, and the Panenergy Corporation, one of the biggest natural gas companies, said yesterday that they would merge in a $7.7 billion stock swap, creating a marketing juggernaut to sell power and other services nationwide.
Unlike most other combinations in the utility industry, which have been driven by the need to save money and extend companies' service areas, the merger between Duke and Panenergy is intended to create a huge network to market natural gas and electricity as states open their utility markets to competition. 
 Under the merger agreement, Panenergy stockholders would receive 1.0444 shares of Duke Power for each share of Panenergy.
The deal would combine fast-growing marketing subsidiaries from the two companies with the goal of providing customers with one-stop shopping for all their power needs and eventually managing energy use to save money.
Customers' ability to bypass their local utilities and buy directly from a marketer has grown rapidly in natural gas, but is only beginning with electricity.
Units such as Panenergy Trading and Market Services, which has teamed up with Mobil Oil to become one of the nation's largest natural gas marketers, are building a valuable base of customers like fast-food chains and retail stores.
As the electricity market is opened to competition -- California, Massachusetts and Rhode Island, for example, will allow customers to begin choosing their suppliers in the next few years -- major producers of low-cost power like Duke will benefit.
While Duke has built up its own marketing subsidiary, the Duke Energy Group, and maintains a partnership with Louis Dreyfus Electric Power, it does not have the long experience and customer base in the freewheeling and risky field of selling as Panenergy does.
Utilities like Duke that have operated as regulated monopolies have found it hard to make the transition to a free market.
"The model that has been developed in the gas industry in the last decade will be the model for the electric industry," Richard B. Priory, the president and chief operating officer of Duke, said in an interview. "The management team at Panenergy will be helpful to point the way in electricity deregulation."
Under the deal, first reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal, Mr. Priory will become chairman and chief executive of the Duke Energy Corporation, as the merged company will be known.
As marketers have geared up to sell natural gas in states like New Jersey and New York, which are among the dozen that have opened their gas utilities to competition, subsidiaries of gas utilities or producers and pipeline companies have often emerged as the big winners.
Paul M. Anderson, president and chief executive of Panenergy, which operates 37,000 miles of gas pipeline handling about 15 percent of the gas consumed in the country, said his company had found it highly advantageous to have a pipeline system and its own supplies and storage. "You have more certainty over prices and guaranteeing delivery," he said, adding that this was an important consideration to big commercial and industrial customers.
Mr. Anderson will become president and chief operating officer of Duke Energy, which will have its headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., where Duke now has it headquarters. Panenergy will continue to run its pipeline operations from Houston.
Another area where the two companies will expand is in building power plants overseas, a fast-growing field where some American utilities have become successful competitors.
William H. Grigg, Duke Power's chairman and chief executive, predicted that shareholders would see the operating income of the new company grow by $225 million by the year 2000. Mr. Grigg will retire when the merger is completed.
The new company's board would have 18 members -- 11 from Duke Power and 7 from Panenergy.
Duke serves about 1.8 million customers in North and South Carolina and operates 3 nuclear power plants, 8 coal-fired generating stations and 38 hydroelectric dams.
Mr. Priory said Duke would be in the market to pick up some of the many power plants that are being spun off by other utilities, notably in California, where the state, as part of deregulation, has asked utilities to sell about 50 percent of their generating capacity.
The reaction of the stock market to the deal was mixed. Duke Power shares fell $1.75 yesterday, closing at $46.125 on the New York Stock Exchange. Standard & Poor's put Duke on credit watch since the combined company could be weaker financially because of an increase in debt. S.& P. also said, however, that the merger would enhance the competitive position of both companies.
The shares of Panenergy rose $1.75, closing at $44, also on the New York Stock Exchange.

Big Philippine Gas Deal
MANILA, Nov. 25 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- The Philippine units of Occidental Petroleum and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group will spend $5 billion to tap the Philippines' largest natural gas reservoir and use the fuel to run power plants.
According to the agreement announced here today at the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, Occidental and Shell plan to spend $2 billion to develop the offshore Camago-Malampaya field and build a pipeline to Luzon, the main Philippine island. Shell and Occidental's agreement is with the state-owned National Power Corporation.
"The development of the vast natural gas resources in Camago-Malampaya will drastically change the country's overall energy outlook for the next 30 years," said Guido Delgado, president of the state utility.
An Occidental vice president, Carlos Contreras, said about $3 billion more would be pumped in to convert a mothballed nuclear power plant and to build a gas-fired installation. Another group will build a second power plant.
Shell and Occidental, equal partners in the joint venture, discovered the Camago-Malampaya field off Palawan island in 1989. It contains 2.7 trillion cubic feet of proven reserves and may hold 3.4 trillion cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Dalai Lama Movie Imperils Disney's Future in China

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, Nov. 25

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company is planning on a big future in China: The appetite for animated features like "The Lion King" seems limitless, sales of merchandise at Disney-owned "Mickey's Corner" stores are growing fast, and Disney's president, Michael Ovitz, has traveled here repeatedly this year to discuss the possibility of opening a Disney theme park in southern China.
And Disney, like most other foreign businesses operating in the huge and growing China market, has been willing to follow China's imperative that politics be kept out of the movies, books and toys it sells here. 
 But Disney has suddenly learned the hidden perils of entering a country that takes its politics so seriously, and the company now faces an agonizing dilemma. Its grand plans for expansion here have been thrown into doubt because of a movie being co-produced by a Disney subsidiary that is not being made in China and is not even intended for distribution in China.
The Chinese authorities warned Walt Disney executives recently that the studio's role in a major film about the life of the Dalai Lama that is now being shot in Morocco by the director Martin Scorsese would force China to reconsider Disney's extensive plans for investment in China's entertainment market.
Few issues have been touchier for the Chinese than their country's control of Tibet, a policy that has been condemned as repressive by human rights advocates. A Chinese official explained the Government's position that anything portraying the situation in Tibet from the point of view of the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan religious leader, is unacceptable.
"We are resolutely opposed to the making of this movie," said Kong Min, an official at the Film Bureau of the Ministry of Radio Film and Television. "It is intended to glorify the Dalai Lama, so it is an interference in China's internal affairs."
Disney executives now face an alarming choice: jeopardize the huge business potential in China or capitulate to pressure on a creative issue, one involving a renowned director and a cause supported by a number of movie stars, led by Richard Gere, as well as human rights advocates around the world.
Disney executives, whose Asia-Pacific operations are based in Hong Kong, declined to comment today. Some people familiar with the Western film business in China said they had a hard time imagining that Disney would jeopardize its vast potential for sales in China to take a stand on one film.
"You can't ask an American company to ignore its very treasured freedom of expression, unless it affects other business worth hundreds of millions of dollars," said William A. Brent, publisher of China Entertainment Network in Beijing and an adviser to American media companies in China.
But if the company were to bow to the pressure and withdraw from involvement in the film, which is nearly finished shooting, its reputation could be damaged.
The movie, titled "Kundun," is about the life of the Dalai Lama, the religious leader of Tibet whom the Chinese authorities regard as an enemy to their control over the Himalayan region. It is being co-produced by Disney's Touchstone Pictures and Refuge Productions.
Mr. Kong, the Chinese official, said the director of the Film Bureau, Liu Jianzhong, traveled to the United States in October and told a senior Disney executive that China would be unhappy if the film was made, making it clear that other business could be affected.
As to precisely what China might do to Disney, Mr. Kong said it was too early to discuss specific measures.
"We're not sure how to answer this question yet," he said. "We have to discuss it with the Foreign Ministry and other relevant departments."
Disney has enormous ambitions in China. Mr. Ovitz, the company's president, has traveled here repeatedly this year to discuss its growing array of business plans, including a Disney World-type theme park as well as the further sale of Disney merchandise and release of films. The stakes are high; "The Lion King" was one of the biggest-grossing movies in China last year.
The story of Tibet in the middle of this century seems like a natural for Hollywood, with a gripping political drama, striking Himalayan landscape and a charismatic central figure in the Dalai Lama, who resisted China's growing control in the 1950's and finally fled to India in 1959.
A second Tibet feature now being filmed, in South America, is Columbia Pictures' "Seven Years in Tibet," directed by Jean-Jacques Annaud and starring Brad Pitt in the lead role of Heinrich Harrer, an Austrian mountain climber who broke Tibet's veil of secrecy by venturing there in the 1940's and becoming the Dalai Lama's personal tutor.
Asked whether the Film Bureau had contacted Columbia about "Seven Years in Tibet," Mr. Kong said he had not heard of the film.
"Is this a feature or a documentary?" he asked. "Maybe we should talk to them, too."
China's position will be the same for all Hollywood studios, he added.
Mr. Brent, the media company adviser, notes that the warning to Disney comes as China is trying to exert strict control over its film, television, newspaper and publishing businesses. Economic growth in China has meant loosened government control over most businesses and more exposure to information from overseas, and the authorities seem nervous about losing control over the media.
Led by the Minister of Propaganda, Ding Guangen, a campaign to stress "politics at every level" this year has instructed editors, studio heads and publishers to toe the Communist Party line in all manner of topics.
At the same time, Chinese leaders fear that allowing Disney and other studios into China too fully would undermine their own state-run film industry, which is having an increasingly hard time staying solvent.
China's position is that Tibet is historically a part of China that has periodically enjoyed greater or lesser amounts of autonomy through the centuries. Many exiled Tibetans argue that the land was traditionally independent.
Chinese officials proudly point to the hospitals and schools they have built in Tibet, and denigrate the closed and brutally elite nature of Tibetan society before the Chinese Army arrived in 1951. But human rights groups say China has sought to destroy Tibetan culture, and the Chinese have been largely unable to melt the adulation for the Dalai Lama among many ordinary Tibetans, who revere him as a god and a king.
Orville Schell, an American writer who is writing a book about American perceptions of Tibet, said that if the feature films attracted popular attention, it would inevitably fuel popular concern over human rights abuses in China.
"There's a building groundswell of interest in Tibet which is going to break like surf on the beach," said Mr. Schell, author of several books about China. "I don't know how the Chinese are going to handle it."
Undoubtedly, Chinese officials will use whatever leverage they can muster, whether or not they actually have to carry out their threats.
Cui Tiankai, a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, said Hollywood studies should know that while they have the freedom to make whatever movies they want, anything perceived to be "anti-China" is likely to have consequences on the studios' efforts to do business here.
As Mr. Brent put it: "The Chinese have absolutely no ground to stand on, except that they have all the leverage. And they're very good at using it."

HEADLINE: Oxford Journal;
We Can't Do Business, the Dons Tell a Big Donor

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: OXFORD, England

 BODY:
What university would turn down a gift of $34 million for a new business school? Hardly any -- except, that is, Oxford, the oldest university in the English-speaking world.
The dons of Oxford, to which the bright and the well born have flocked since the 12th century, recently said no to the money of Wafic Said, a Saudi billionaire of Syrian origin. 
 The Daily Telegraph, a conservative newspaper, called the 259-to-214 vote against the offer, among dons who came to a meeting about the issue on Nov. 5, elitist bias against business. It is, it said, "an old British disease that lies behind much of our industrial decline into not-so-genteel poverty."
Opponents of the project to build a "world-class School of Business Management" at a cost of $64 million -- the university would raise the rest of the money -- said it was a triumph for "the historical values of the university." A campus newspaper, The Cherwell, reflecting a widespread approval of the vote among students, published a banner headline "Dons Whack Wafic."
The two camps are gearing up for a new battle over the issue. The university is resubmitting the proposal to a wider congregation of dons -- 3,200 academics -- who are to vote by mail early next year. Between now and then, the lobbying is certain to be furious.
In conversations all over the university's colleges, it was clear that the issue is not so much business studies -- which already exist at Oxford -- but enshrining business management in a majestic new school destined, as Oxford administrators assert, to become a major center for management research in Europe.
"Things move slowly around here," said Yoav Harel, 26, a Canadian graduate student who came here this year to study business. "Intellectual debate on whether business is a legitimate pursuit of knowledge has been settled a long time ago everywhere else."
Business schools in the United States graduate some 80,000 Master of Business Administration students a year. By contrast, Oxford will graduate its first class of 49 M.B.A. students this year.
Mr. Harel and his colleagues are stuck on the second floor of the Radcliffe Infirmary, Oxford's old hospital, which is the only space Oxford has for them. The new school, which would be named for Mr. Said, would be palatial by comparison.
The debate over Mr. Said's offer has focused on issues of business education, not on his construction business or his nationality. Irritated by the vote rejecting his donation, Mr. Said, who made much of his money-making deals between British businesses and the Saudis, said, "One of the driving forces behind America's economic strength has been a close relationship between industry and universities and especially prestigious business schools."
That, precisely, is a notion viewed with suspicion at the colleges of Oxford.
The Saudi businessman, who has been giving $160,000 a year to Oxford for several years, said his offer was good until February. He vowed to persist -- despite a chorus of criticism in the Arab world of his "misplaced generosity" -- because, he said, Britain "has been good to me and my family."
Indeed, the question of whether Oxford will have its School of Business Management is far from settled.
If it does, the administration will probably choose a site for the school other than the 400-yard-long field in the center of Oxford that Mr. Said proposed. Opponents noted that it is a sole remaining patch of grass there, framed by unattractive science buildings and two roads jammed with cars. They revived an unwritten commitment, made by the administration 30 years ago, not to build on it.
But the basic obstacle comes down to persuading a majority of academics in this rarefied intellectual atmosphere that there is nothing unwholesome about a business education. Everyone readily admits that it is an uphill fight.
Maurice Lubbock, Deputy Governor of the Bank of England, acknowledged half-jokingly that the whole point of an Oxford education has been precisely to teach people to "do without the kind of money" they would earn with an M.B.A. Prevailing views, he and others said, are that education should prepare people for public service, not profit.
Kenneth King, director of the Emerging Markets division of Kleinwort Benson, a huge investment firm in London, said: "Most British institutions are not going to worship an M.B.A. Unlike Wall Street, this is not, yet, a major qualification to enter into business."
Prof. Colin Mayer, acting director of the tiny School of Management Studies, for which the new headquarters would be destined, said, "The horror comes from people who see that business education is all about how to make a half a million in six months.
"What motivates us is the intellectual aspect of the subject, the sociology and psychology of business. We believe this school is well placed to build on Oxford, and that is why we want it in the heart of Oxford."
That is not good enough, argues Alexander Murray, a professor of medieval history, who wants the school and the aura of wealth that surrounds business far away from the pure heart of Oxford. He has emerged as the leading voice in the opposition.
"I want to serve the truth above all things, to demand no more than a reasonable salary, to seek cooperation with colleagues rather than competition," he wrote in a widely publicized essay this month in an Oxford publication.
But Prof. Anthony Hopwood, deputy director of the existing School of Management Studies, said that with the globalization of the world economy, such arguments amount to an abandonment of academic responsibility.
Since business has become the most powerful institution of the 20th century, Professor Hopwood said, "can it seriously be argued that we should be any less interested in its workings than we were in the church, the monarchy or government in previous generations?"

HEADLINE: At Asian Meeting, Support for Free Trade

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Tuesday, Nov. 26

 BODY:
President Clinton persuaded the leaders of 17 other Asian-Pacific nations on Monday to endorse efforts to "substantially eliminate" tariffs on computers and other information technologies by the year 2000 as the next step in breaking down barriers among America's biggest trading partners.
In their final declaration after a two-day meeting of Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation, known as APEC, at the former American naval base at Subic Bay in the Philippines, the leaders endorsed a process that American officials hope will lead to zero tariffs on most technology products by the turn of the century. 
 The meeting on Monday was the centerpiece of the President's 12-day trip from Hawaii to Australia to the Philippines and on to Thailand, and the President pronounced the agreement "a big deal."
The leaders' agreement was nonbinding, but it could give the countries a new impetus to reach a binding agreement to begin phasing out tariffs.
Further action could occur as early as the first meeting of the 123-nation World Trade Organization in Singapore about two weeks from now.
More than 80 percent of global trade in information technology occurs among the APEC member nations, which account for 50 percent of the goods and services produced in the world. Technology products are a $1.8 trillion economic sector worldwide, with global trade amounting to $500 billion a year, fueling perhaps 200,000 export-related jobs in the United States alone.
The agreement fell just short of the flat-out declaration of support for zero tariffs that Mr. Clinton had hoped for, instead allowing member nations enough flexibility to continue protection measures on a few products, which virtually all of them, including Washington, want to do. Individual exceptions would have to be negotiated case by case at the World Trade Organization.
But American officials said Mr. Clinton's polite arm-twisting at meetings with the leaders on Sunday had left the agreement stronger than what might have been expected from such a diverse group of nations, some of which have tariffs on computer technology roughly 20 times as high as those of the United States, which are minimal.
For example, the officials noted that the draft agreed to by APEC foreign ministers last week contained no specified target date.
"Thanks to the President and others, we now have a firm date," said Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs.
If the conference produced nothing like the "thrilla in Manilla" that Mr. Clinton gently joked it might be in an interview before he left Washington, it amounted an international equivalent of the sort of modest, small-bore domestic programs that Mr. Clinton successfully campaigned on in the election this year.
In a brief appearance at the United States Embassy in Manila on Monday night, Mr. Clinton said computer and information products are "at the core of America's competitiveness."
"These products are to the 21st century what highways and railroads were to the 19th century, or in my recent language, they are a big part of that bridge we have to build to the future," he said. "Imagine if we went to zero tariffs in the entire world what that would mean to America in more exports and higher-paying jobs."
As the meeting began on Monday morning, President Fidel V. Ramos of the Philippines, chewing on an unlit cigar, welcomed the leaders to Subic, a onetime Spanish outpost that was captured in a Philippine-American operation in the Spanish-American War in 1898 and later became an important American naval base. The base closed in 1992 and is now undergoing conversion to civilian use as a special economic zone.
In keeping with the tradition of these summit gatherings, all the leaders at the Manila meeting wore a typical local costume, in this case a barong tagalog, the traditional Filipino shirt of beige silk and pina fiber, hand-embroidered in the province of Laguna.
The garment is lovely, but not especially suited to Mr. Clinton's husky middle-American frame, and he seemed at times to be wearing a very elegant straitjacket.
Mr. Clinton, alone among the leaders, was tall enough to have room for embroidered bamboo trees on his shirt, which fit him much better than the batik shirt the leaders wore in Indonesia two years ago. At that session, the President's shirt had to be retailored at the last minute beause it was too small.
Asked if he liked the shirt issued in the Philippines, Mr. Clinton said, "I think it's good; it's cool and airy, very nice."

HEADLINE: 100,000 Serbs Take to Streets Against Milosevic

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Nov. 25

 BODY:
More than 100,000 jeering demonstrators hurled eggs at the state-run television headquarters, blocked city streets for more than eight hours and roared their approval when opposition leaders vowed to shut Belgrade down until the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, was removed from power.
The largest anti-Government demonstration here in five years was staged to denounce a decision to invalidate opposition election victories in 33 local council seats because of unspecified "irregularities." 
 Leaders of the opposition coalition, Zajedno, called on their followers tonight to carry out the kind of sustained daily street gatherings that began in Prague in 1989 and eventually brought down the Communist Government there.
If the protests, which are also taking place in other cities, continue, the oppositon could force President Milosevic to use force to clear city streets, Western diplomats said. That would sharply step up -- or abruptly end -- the growing confrontation with the Government.
But either way, if Mr. Milosevic resorts to violence, his effort to rehabilitate his image with the United States and Europe is likely to suffer serious damage.
He began that campaign by accepting the role of representing the Bosnian Serbs at the Dayton peace negotiations last year and lending his support to the accord that was reached. Because of his assistance, especially in the latter part of the war, the Clinton Administration has been reluctant to challenge him.
But his own people have shown no such reticence. "The mood in the streets is very angry, very hostile," said Zoran Ziukovic, a leader of the opposition. "We are going through what Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Poland went through six years ago.
"In those countries the fall of the Soviet Union saw the collapse of the Communist system. In Yugoslavia we hung on because Milosevic astutely switched from Communist to nationalist rhetoric. Now he is being unmasked, not only because of these elections, but because of empty stomachs. It only remains now to see what kind of a revolution this will become."
There were some signs that the protests were spreading, especially when students decided to take over university buildings. But the Government, which has barred the state-run press from covering the demonstrations, said the protests would not interfere with plans to press ahead with a final round of local voting, which the opposition plans to boycott, on Wednesday.
The protests are the largest since 1991, when Mr. Milosevic announced his decision to go to war against republics seceding from Yugoslavia.
Now, Mr. Milosevic dominates what remains of Yugoslavia -- Serbia and tiny Montenegro. Mr. Milosevic's reputation for autocratic rule, culminating in his flagrant dismissal of the opposition victory, has proved too much for many people.
The state-run press has the difficult job of trying to dismiss the protests as insignificant and yet present them as jeopardizing law and order. The press quoted Ivan Markovic, the editor of Radio Yugoslavia, who attacked the protesters for fomenting "disorder, aggression and terrorism."
Although tens of thousands of protesters trapped television reporters and editors inside their offices for hours this afternoon as eggs splattered against the windows, the event was never mentioned on the air.
Many in the opposition say the President, who has presided over a deteriorating economy and turned his country, for the duration of the war, into an international pariah, may have gone too far.
"The decision to steal the local elections was the final straw for many Serbs," said Zoran Djindjic, one of the opposition leaders, as he prepared to move onto a balcony overlooking tens of thousands of boisterous supporters. "The regime pushed too far. There were many who were prepared to let Milosevic keep power for himself but hoped that the opposition would take control in some of the cities.
"His decision to discard the fig leaf of elections that helped cloak his dictatorship may prove to be his biggest mistake. Now we know that removing him by democratic methods will be impossible."
The crowd, which included large numbers of students and retired people, was spirited and often boisterous to the point of making lewd suggestions directed at the President. Many waved Serbian flags, blew whistles and sang.
Mr. Djindjic told the crowd: "This is no longer an election rally or a protest rally. This is a democratic revolution that Serbia has been waiting 50 years for."
The crowd, in response, chanted: "Serbia has risen! Serbia has risen!"
"Milosevic cannot fool anyone now," said Miroslava Mandic, 36, a bank employee who stood in a crush of people near the television building. "He has cheated us once too often."
When the polling ended eight days ago, Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party conceded that it had lost control of the city councils in industrial cities and towns across Serbia, including Belgrade. But the Government-run electoral commissions appointed by the President swiftly annulled the results in almost all of the districts won by the opposition bloc.
Few expect the President to go down without a fight. When confronted with citywide protests in 1991, he called out tanks to secure Belgrade's streets. The deployment resulted in at least two deaths. Opposition leaders hinted darkly today that the crowds might have to be ready to confront violence.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 29, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about anti-Government protests in Serbia misstated President Slobodan Milosevic's public stance on the outbreak of war in Yugoslavia in 1991. Although Serbia was instrumental in the Yugoslav military response to the secession of Croatia and Slovenia, Mr. Milosevic never formally announced a decision to go to war to oppose the breakup.
