HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Swiss and French Francs Fall, Aiding a Rally in the Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar was mostly higher yesterday, strengthening after Switzerland's biggest bank reported a large loss and two influential French officials called for a weaker French franc.
The gains built on the dollar's strength from a day earlier, when it advanced broadly on a large selloff in the German mark because of renewed optimism that Europe's plan for a single currency will proceed as scheduled in 1999. Italy's weekend readmission to the European exchange rate stabilization system after a two-year absence was the catalyst for that optimism. 
 "We've seen a turnaround in the dollar," said Jim Powers, vice president of foreign exchange sales at Westdeutsche Landes Bank in New York. "It's caught a lot of people leaning the wrong way."
The dollar rose to 1.5244 marks, from 1.5230 marks on Monday. The dollar also advanced against the Swiss franc, French franc and Italian lira. The British pound, though, rose slightly to $1.6714 from $1.6686.
Against the Japanese yen, the dollar ended slightly lower at 112.47 yen, from 112.63 yen.
Traders traced part of the dollar's strength yesterday to a selloff in the Swiss franc, which declined to its weakest level against the dollar since early January 1995. The dollar was quoted at 1.2913 Swiss francs in New York, up from 1.2877 Monday.
The Swiss franc declined after the Union Bank of Switzerland, the nation's biggest bank, announced a revamping and a projected 1996 loss of 500 million francs.
The news was seen as further evidence of the poorly performing Swiss economy and the likelihood that interest rates in Switzerland will not rise anytime soon.
The dollar's advance against the French franc was spurred by calls for a weakening of the franc against the dollar by a Bank of France official as well as by the former French President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, who is now head of the National Assembly's foreign affairs committee. The dollar ended at 5.1706 French francs, up from 5.1550.
In a radio address, he said he would like to see the dollar around 5.50 francs. A few hours later, the central bank official, Paul Marchelli, suggested the franc was 10 percent overvalued against the dollar.

HEADLINE: Clinton Hails Thais in Visit At Conclusion Of Asia Trip

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 26

 BODY:
President Clinton ended his 12-day Asia-Pacific trip today with a 24-hour state visit to this kingdom of glittering temples, teeming waterways and bustling economic development, honoring the 50th anniversary of the reign of its American-born, saxophone-playing King, Bhumibol Adulyadej.
In a speech at a major university and a state dinner at the storybook Grand Palace on the Chao Phraya River, Mr. Clinton celebrated the longstanding Thai-American military alliance. 
 He also witnessed the signing of a treaty intended to end double taxation on American companies doing business here and basked in the ebullient reception accorded the first American President to visit Thailand since Richard M. Nixon in 1969.
"The United States and Thailand, for all the distance and differences between us, share a common vision -- the dream of an Asia-Pacific region where economic growth and democratic ideals are advancing steadily and reinforcing one another," Mr. Clinton told an afternoon audience at Chulalongkorn University, named for the 19th-century modernizing monarch best known to Americans as the little Crown Prince in "The King and I."
As he wrapped up a three-nation swing across the Pacific rim, Mr. Clinton also praised the Thai Government for its cooperation in fighting drug trafficking.
Mr. Clinton's drug czar, Gen. Barry McCaffrey, retired, preceded him here for talks with his Thai counterparts aimed at fostering increased interdiction efforts.
"In all your work in this area," the President said, "Thailand is sending a clear message to drug lords: We will fight you. We are determined to stop you. And America has a clear signal to Thailand: We will stand with you all the way."
Mr. Clinton also met with the recently defeated Prime Minister, Banharn Silpa-archa, and with his successor-to-be, Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, and received assurances of the Government's willingness to press forward with legislation favored by the United States, chiefly a law to prevent money laundering and another to protect patents, American officials said.
The First Lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, arrived in Thailand a day earlier than the President, offering a serious message of her own. She visited former child prostitutes dying of AIDS and praised the Thai Government for enacting a law providing jail terms for owners, agents and families who exploit children for prostitution.
"Expanding educational opportunity for children, curbing the spread of AIDS and ending the exploitation of young girls in the commercial sex industry will not only help individual Thai girls and their families, but Thai society as a whole," Mrs. Clinton said in a speech at Chiang Mai University in northern Thailand.
But the Clintons' visit was mostly an occasion to celebrate the anniverary of the ascension of King Bhumibol, who is the world's longest-reigning monarch. The city is flooded with golden decorations commemorating the popular King's rule, and his 69th birthday on Dec. 5.
The King, who was born in Cambridge, Mass., when his father was studying at Harvard Medical School, is an amateur scientist and environmentalist -- and a prize-winning composer whose skill on the saxophone is widely regarded.
"You know, he's been a very constructive influence in his country, and he loves jazz music," Mr. Clinton told reporters on the flight here from Manila on Monday night. Tonight the President brought the King a series of vintage black-and-white photographs by Herman Leonard of jazz musicians from the 1930's.
From the moment King Bhumibol and Queen Sirikit met the Clintons at Don Muang Airport in a pale yellow Rolls-Royce on Monday evening, the visit has been one grand spectacle after another in this sprawling city where dozens of new skyscrapers under construction share space with 300 Buddhist temples, crowded markets, crooked byways and steaming canals.
Tonight the central courtyard of the Grand Palace was aglow with thousands of tiny white lights in topiary trees as the couples filed into a French-style dinner of foie gras in aspic, roasted veal and vegetables from the royal garden.
This morning Mr. Clinton witnessed the signing of a tax treaty by William Itoh, the American Ambassador, and Amnuay Virawan, the outgoing Thai Foreign Minister.
The treaty, which was under negotiation for 15 years, specifies the circumstances under which various kinds of income derived by residents of one country may be taxed by the other. American companies in Thailand pressed hard for the measure, because they have been at a competitive disadvantage with other multinational companies that have already concluded such treaties. It now goes to the Senate for ratification.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Hughes Signs Up to Launch Satellites on Japan Rockets

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Japan's fledgling effort to develop a space business received a major boost today as the Hughes Electronics Corporation became the first company to sign up to launch commercial satellites on a Japanese rocket now under development.
Hughes said it would use a new version of Japan's H-II rocket for 10 launchings over a five-year period starting in 2000. There are also options for an additional 5 to 10 launchings, according to Hiroshi Imamura, executive vice president of the Rocket System Corporation, the Japanese company handling the launchings. 
 Mr. Imamura also said today that his Tokyo-based company was close to receiving an order for 10 launchings plus options from Space Systems/ Loral, a unit of Loral Space and Communications.
Rocket System -- which is financed by 73 Japanese corporations, including the Mitsubishi Corporation, NEC, Nissan and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries -- was formed to market the H-II rocket, which was developed by Japan's space agency.
But until now there have been doubts that anyone would use Japan's rockets because the cost of a launching has been about twice as much as that of competitors like Lockheed Martin and Arianespace.
The Hughes order, which a Hughes official said could be worth as much as $1 billion, and a Loral order, believed to be of a similar magnitude, could start erasing those doubts.
Exact financial terms of the Hughes contract, which was signed on Monday in Los Angeles, were not disclosed. But it appears that by ordering so many rockets so far in advance, Hughes was able to get a good deal from the Japanese company, which is anxious to establish its credibility.
The National Space Development Agency of Japan is aiming for costs of about $75 million a launching with the new version of the H-II, which will be called the H-IIA. But Mr. Imamura suggested that Hughes would pay less than that.
Donald L. Cromer, chairman of Hughes Space and Communications International, a division of Hughes that builds communications satellites, said in a statement that the terms of the deal were "very competitive."
Hughes, based in Los Angeles and a division of the General Motors Corporation, also called the contract a "continuation of our partnership with Japan." That suggested that one reason for its order was to maintain relations so that Japan would continue to buy its satellites. Hughes, along with Japanese partners, is also preparing to start a Japanese version of its DirecTV service, which transmits digital television from satellites to homes.
The new contract is the latest effort by Hughes, which is the world's largest manufacturer of commercial communications satellites, to drive down launching costs by arranging bulk deals to use still undeveloped rockets. It has signed similar contracts with McDonnell Douglas for its Delta III and with the Sea Launch venture led by the Boeing Company, which plans to use a Russian rocket to launch from an offshore platform.
Despite its general technical prowess, Japan has never been a power in space. It did not launch its first satellite until 1970, a year after the United States landed on the moon.
But it has been hoping to change that with the H-II, the first Japanese rocket able to hoist large communications satellites used for television and telephone service into geosynchronous orbit, about 22,000 miles above the earth.
The rocket, developed at a cost of about $2.4 billion, was also the first to be built using exclusively Japanese technology. Previous generations of rockets had relied on technology bought or licensed from the United States.
The H-II made its maiden flight in 1994 and has so far proven reliable in the four times it has been used to launch government satellites. But the cost for a launching of 19 billion yen, or about $170 million, is twice as high as the going rate.
To cut that cost in half, the new H-IIA, scheduled to be finished by 2000, will have a simplified design and will use less expensive imported parts, even if that means diverging somewhat from the goal of using only Japanese technology.
Japan's space agency has another problem. Because of opposition from fishermen near its launching site on Tanegashima island in southern Japan, launchings have been restricted to a 45-day period in winter and a 45-day period in summer. That has allowed only two H-II rockets at most to be launched each year, meaning that Hughes's order alone would fill all the available launching slots over a five-year period.
To expand capacity, a second launching pad is being built and the Government is negotiating with fishermen to lengthen the season.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: The Mouse Makes a Stand

 BODY:
By announcing yesterday that it would go ahead with a film about the Dalai Lama despite threats from China, the Walt Disney Company demonstrated that it would not accept censorship as the price of doing business in China or anywhere else. That is a welcome stand at a moment when the American Government and American companies seem increasingly prepared to set aside important democratic principles in hopes of expanding commerce with China. China must understand that it cannot impose its repressive practices on the free global marketplace.
Like many other companies, the Disney organization has hit a lucrative bonanza in China. From Mickey Mouse to "The Lion King," Disney merchandise and movies are increasingly popular, and the company is talking about opening a theme park in China. Unrelated to all that, the movie about the Dalai Lama, who fled China when Tibet was conquered in 1959, recently went into production in Morocco, directed by Martin Scorsese. 
 Chinese authorities warned that Disney's business opportunities in China would be curtailed by the Government if the company went ahead with the movie. The Chinese warnings were especially outrageous because Disney has no plans to distribute the movie in China itself.
Tailoring movies, music and other forms of entertainment before distributing them to different audiences in different countries is common. But for Disney to have dropped a movie simply to save its business operations in China would have set a disastrous example, effectively letting Beijing dictate its own version of history to audiences beyond its shores. That kind of behavior, at the very least, is unacceptable for a country trying to become a member of the World Trade Organization, which China seeks to do.
Chinese leaders delight in lecturing Westerners that it is culturally imperialist to impose human rights standards on Beijing. Free expression and political pluralism, of course, are not a preserve of the West and are honored in some Asian countries. But the Chinese argument is now contradicted by its own insistence that it can force its peculiar form of repression on the global economic system.
Censorship seems on the rise in the world today. In the United States, self-appointed moral guardians have hectored the movie and music industries in Hollywood about tailoring content to suit their view of mainstream America. It is gratifying in the case of Chinese interference that Michael Eisner, the Disney chairman, has come down on the side of artistic freedom, albeit without any ringing statements explaining the decision.
The Disney action ought to be carefully studied by the Clinton Administration, which has just participated in an economic summit conference of Asian leaders in Manila. President Clinton was right to demand that all the countries of Asia work harder to lower trade barriers in the coming decades. The Disney episode shows that free expression is essential to the success of free markets. It should embolden the Administration to press China on human rights and other sensitive issues, even if China's leaders object. China must adjust to the dynamic world of free markets. That world does not and cannot operate by Chinese rules.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence in Economy Holds Steady

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence in the economy held steady in November, although most Americans remain optimistic about current business conditions, a private research group reported yesterday.
The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index was 107.3 this month, the same as the revised October figure. The index jumped 5 points in August and 6.9 points in July, hitting a six-year high before weakening slightly in September and October. 
 The Board's Present Situation Index, a measure of sentiment on current business conditions, rose to a seven-year high of 131 in November, up 6.4 points from October.
"Consumers are more positive about current business conditions than at any time this decade," said Lynn Franco, associate director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center.
"The strong level of confidence coupled with low unemployment, modest inflationary pressures and continuing wage growth should translate into healthy holiday sales in coming weeks," she said in a statement. But consumers were less optimistic about the future than they had been in October.
Consumer confidence is watched closely for indications of consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economy.
The November figures were in line with economists' expectations.
The Consumer Confidence Index, calculated from a base of 100, is derived from responses to questions sent to 5,000 households nationwide, polling them on matters ranging from job availability to home-buying plans. The Conference Board's report comes as financial markets scour new data for signs of economic weakness and low inflation, two factors that could cause the Federal Reserve to hold off on raising interest rates at its Dec. 17 policy meeting. Today's report shows consumers are quite confident about the present economic picture, with only 13 percent of those surveyed saying current business conditions are bad.
But the outlook for the next six months was not as rosy, with only 14 percent of those surveyed expecting better business conditions ahead.
"This is telling us that the economy is moderating and it will not take off and cause the central bank to raise interest rates," said Anthony Chan, a senior economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio.
Interest rates fell in the inflation-sensitive bond market on the consumer confidence figures.

HEADLINE: Stock Rally Halts, With Dow Dropping 19.38

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks fell short yesterday in a late bid to extend November's surprisingly resilient rally, having recovered from a sudden wave of profit taking.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which seesawed from an early 42-point gain to a 50-point loss before steadying near midday, briefly pulled into positive territory amid some late bargain hunting, but then trailed lower to close at 6,528.41, down 19.38 points. 
 Although relatively minor, the retreat was the largest for the Dow since late October, underscoring the blue-chip barometer's almost uninterrupted ascent this month. The Dow jumped 76.03 points on Monday for its first close ever above 6,500, pushing November's advance to more than 8 percent.
Most broad stock measures ended slightly lower after rebounding from their lows, although the technology-laden Nasdaq market managed to pull higher in the last hour, padding Monday's record high.
Stocks jumped in the morning as bonds rallied on the latest economic news, sending interest rates toward their lowest level since early March.
In another sign that economic growth may be moderating enough to contain inflation without an interest rate rise by the Federal Reserve, the Conference Board research group said its Consumer Confidence Index held steady in November. The index had jumped in July and August, hitting a six-year high before weakening slightly in September and October.
Bond traders were also heartened by news that economists surveyed by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia are predicting a fairly steady ride in 1997, firming hopes for continued growth with stable inflation and interest rates.
As bond prices rose yesterday morning, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a barometer of corporate and consumer borrowing costs -- briefly fell near 6.36 percent from 6.42 percent on Monday.
With investors nervously awaiting what many analysts consider an inevitable pullback after such a sharp advance in stocks and bonds, the early spurt set off a round of profit taking. As bonds fell, the long bond's yield rose to 6.44 percent, pressuring stocks. But as usual, the drop was viewed as a buying opportunity for those with cash on the sidelines.
"Investors are very nervous, and that's reflected in the action of the market," said Peter Anderson, chief investment officer at the IDS Advisory Group in Minneapolis. "They're afraid not to be in it, but scared to be in it. One hour they're more afraid than greedy, the next hour they're more greedy than afraid."
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.07 points, to 755.96, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.88 point, to 397.98.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 0.83, to 1,281.20, its second straight record finish.
The Dow's biggest decliners included many of the high-fliers of recent weeks. Caterpillar fell 2, to 78 1/8, and General Electric fell 1 3/4, to 102, while Procter & Gamble fell 1 1/2, to 109 3/8.
Walt Disney was the Dow's strongest issue, rising 2 1/2, to 76, after the company reported a 27 percent gain in quarterly profits, which beat expectations.
Deere fell 2 3/8, to 44. The company reported earnings that fell short of some expectations. Linens 'n Things Inc. was one of the most active stocks on the Big Board, with almost six million shares changing hands in its Wall Street debut. The shares rose 1/8, from the initial public offering price of 15 1/2. The company, a retailer based in Clifton, N.J., had expected the shares to be sold for between $15 and $17 each.

HEADLINE: The Japanese Money Mill Sputters;
Nation of Global Investors Isn't Venturing Too Far Now

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Tetsuo Ishii stood near a poster of Christopher Columbus, beckoning him to plunk his money into a fund that invests in America.
But Mr. Ishii, a 46-year-old chemical engineer, decided not to send his money to the New World. And he has lots of company in Japan, particularly in the cash-laden board rooms of companies and pension funds. 
 "You never know how the currency will fluctuate," Mr. Ishii said warily. "Personally, I'm not ready to accept that risk."
So Mr. Ishii's savings will not be used to lift stock prices on Wall Street, and the savings of many of his countrymen will not go to back mortgages in California or buy bonds in Massachusetts. Interest rates may be higher in America, but Mr. Ishii and many of his compatriots feel more comfortable keeping their money at home.
Mr. Ishii is part of what many financial experts say is a broad and potentially worrisome trend: Japan's role as moneybags to the world may be diminishing. In the long run, that could mean higher interest rates in the developing world and in countries like the United States that have come to rely on Japanese capital.
Financial experts are focusing on Japanese investment behavior because Japan has finally accomplished something American trade negotiators have demanded for several years. It has shrunk one of the most closely watched measures of global competition, its current account surplus, the bounty generated when exports of goods and services by Japan exceed its imports.
What does all that have to do with the price of bonds in Boston?
Except for a few years in the late 1980's when it declined, Japan's current account surplus had seemed to be made of helium, and this nation plowed its money back into investments abroad. Japan's export wave put some American workers out of jobs, but the accompanying flood of financial investments by Japan also kept American interest rates down, probably helping other Americans hang onto their jobs.
But now, some financiers are asking a crucial question: If the Japanese no longer have an expanding pile of cash or a willingness to invest overseas, could there be a shortage of capital, perhaps even a global capital squeeze?
For many economists, the answer is yes.
"It is one of the most serious problems for the world economy," said Makoto Utsumi, a business professor at Keio University and a former Finance Ministry official who negotiated financial issues with the United States. The reliance of America and other industrial countries on capital from Japan, he said, is a fundamental weakness of the global economy.
In the past, Japan swallowed nearly 40 percent of bonds sold at United States Treasury auctions; it bought chunks of American companies; it provided financing for everything from planes to trains and overall growth. Over the years, Japanese institutional money -- about $1 trillion of it -- swished through financial markets around the world.
But that infamous surplus has declined from a high of $132 billion three years ago to an expected $70 billion to $80 billion this year, economists here say. And though ups as well as downs are likely in the level of surpluses, a few even raise the possibility of a deficit in coming years.
Deficits are not inherently bad, but in this case it would mean Japan was no longer able to generate enough trade earnings to finance its growth. If it has to borrow, not only will there be less Japanese capital flowing abroad, but Japan will also be competing, perhaps with the United States, for capital from other countries.
In September, the monthly surplus dropped to 727.4 billion yen, or $6.6 billion, down 36 percent from the period last year. Likewise, investment in overseas securities, one big component of total capital flows from Japan, tumbled 93 percent, to 192 billion yen, or $1.7 billion, in the first eight months of this year. And while levels of direct investment overseas rose 40 percent in that period from the period last year, they are about half the levels of five and six years ago.
At the same time, the appetite for funds is expanding around the world. Emerging market economies need money for development, planned economies want to finance their transition to market economies and growth in most industrial countries is fairly robust. Many stock markets are at record highs, needing new investment to sustain the momentum. Many countries have gaping budget deficits. And all this must be financed.
The demand for imported capital among big countries, beyond what Japan can provide, is likely to expand in 1996 by 44 percent, to $74 billion, and even more in 1997, according to projections by Merrill Lynch.
"You can't square the market to the circle without a lot of money, and a lot of money that we've been able to get in the past is from Japan," said Kenneth S. Courtis, chief economist in Tokyo for Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Capital Markets, referring to the need to keep up with the expanding demand for money around the world. "It's not as though they will pull it away from us. They don't have it to recycle."
To be sure, not everybody agrees that a possible shortage of savings, or capital, from Japan is a problem, so long as there are other deep pockets around. If Japan, for example, is no longer earning American dollars from trade and using them to buy Treasury Bills, Americans may hold on to the dollars themselves and use them to buy Treasuries on their own.
Still, experts worry, in part because Japanese were pretty efficient at recycling American dollars, and Japanese save much more than Americans. Last year, Japan's capital outflow exceeded the combined sum of the 14 next highest capital-exporting countries, Mr. Courtis said, and Japan's outflow was six times that of the second-largest capital exporter, Switzerland.
Japan exported about $100 billion in excess savings last year to countries like the United States, which bought more foreign products than it sold of its own. So while the United States ran a huge trade deficit, and borrowed from the Japanese to pay for it, Japan ran a current account surplus of $100 billion.
"It's not so much a risk of capital not being available, so much as capital not being available at a certain price," said Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist in Tokyo for Salomon Brothers Asia. "A cheap price."
No one thinks Japan's current account surplus is going to dry up overnight, and until it does, Japanese capital will still be flowing out. And with capital flowing into markets around the world, it is hard to see how a shortage will suddenly emerge to end that.
"They've had a very large decline in the surplus, but it's difficult to say that it's been an enormous detriment to overseas markets, when global markets are at all-time highs," Michael Hartnett, senior economist at Merrill Lynch in Tokyo, said. "At the end of the day, there's been enough liquidity overseas to fund upward the value of stocks in the States."
One reason is that while Japan is likely to play a smaller role in global capital markets, some European countries may take on a greater burden, Mr. Hartnett notes. Countries in Europe, like Switzerland, France, Belgium and the Netherlands, in general have growing current account surpluses and have been easing shortages by providing capital, at least to industrial nations like the United States, Britain and Canada.
Moreover, while Mr. Ishii and many other Japanese remain hesitant, some individual investors -- appalled by low interest rates at home -- are beginning to think about sending their savings abroad. The amount of outflow from individuals is rising and could swell to a total of $30 billion or more by the end of the year, as long as people like Chieko Emoto continue their financial experimentation.
Mrs. Emoto, 43, took her 21-year-old son, Akimine, to a Daiwa Securities outlet to show him how to buy foreign bonds. But she will not touch United States Treasuries or American stocks. Instead, she owns Australian securities.
"There has been less currency fluctuation for the Australian dollar," she said.
Indeed, wild currency swings and the uncertain direction of the yen are keeping many Japanese corporations and pension funds from moving into foreign securities. For instance, Matsushita Electric Industrial keeps huge sums on hand but does not invest in securities overseas -- mainly, it says, because it will not accept the foreign exchange risk.
Many life insurers and other Japanese institutional investors are still smarting from losses on dollar investments because of exchange rate movements. Since 1990, for example, the yen has zigzagged from 155 yen against the dollar to 80 in April. After that, it reversed direction and dropped to 114, partly with the fall of the current account surplus; it settled above 112 today.
As a result, the Japanese Government has been pouring some money overseas to compensate for the lack of investment by individuals and companies. But because the Government is a conservative investor, that money is going into United States Treasury bonds, not oil rigs in China or subways in Thailand.
No one knows whether Japan's current account surplus is going to continue to fall or by how much, but some say the trend may soon stop, now that the yen is much weaker. Already, the surplus may have hit bottom in April, based on monthly seasonally adjusted data, according to Mr. Feldman at Salomon Brothers, and since then, the surplus seems to be edging up.
Even if the surplus rises and is recycled overseas again, Japan's role in global capital markets may be exaggerated.
"The market is too big for anyone to influence or for there to be a major change of behavior," Mr. Feldman said. Referring to Japan's role in the market, he added, "It's overemphasized in many people's thinking."


GRAPHIC: Japan is finally beginning to buy more imported products, reducing its huge annual trade surpluses. But some economists are warning that Japan's shrinking surplus may have a downside: less money for Japan to invest abroad. The result could be a credit squeeze, leading to higher interest rates, worldwide. Though Japan's overall income is up, its exports are flat, even as Japan spends more on imports, leaving Japan less money to invest abroad, and raising the prospect of a global capital squeeze.

HEADLINE: Cairo Journal;
Egypt Adding Corn to Bread: An Explosive Mix?

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Nov. 26

 BODY:
In Egypt, the word for bread and the word for life are the same: aish. And that is where things begin to get tangled.
The small loaves have a place at every Egyptian meal, scooping beans and falafel at breakfast, sopping up stewed vegetables at lunch and sharing plates at night with bits of salty white cheese. 
 But to keep bread cheap and plentiful, Egypt pays a heavy price, importing wheat from abroad and subsidizing flour at home, and it has decided to draw the line. Beginning next month, its planners have decreed, bread will be 20 percent corn.
The change has gone all but unadvertised; the Government seems to be hoping that few will notice. But in a city whose food chain begins at state-owned mills, there is worry that something basic will change.
"They'll add a little corn flour now, and then it will be 50-50, and sooner or later we will be eating a loaf with no wheat at all," complained Ahmed Ismail, a baker who gets up before dawn each morning to shape the small rounds.
Unlike the French, the Egyptians take no particular pride in their bread, a rough blend from whole-grain flour. Barely distinguishable from bakery to bakery, it is sold in tall stacks or heaped onto trays that deliverymen balance on their heads as they weave on bicycles through the Cairo traffic.
Its main virtue is price -- about a penny a loaf, one-third its real cost, thanks to $750 million a year in Government subsidies. Bread is so cheap that Egyptians are among the world's leading consumers of wheat, gobbling up nearly 400 pounds per person per year, more than three times the average rate in the United States or Europe.
But with its fertile land limited to the Nile Valley, Egypt can grow only enough wheat for about half its 60 million people. Last year alone, it had to import more than 6 million tons of wheat, most of it from the United States, and with world prices soaring, the price tag leapt to more than $1 billion.
To ease those financial strains, the Government could have chosen to cut subsidies or to cut imports. Instead, its planners decided that the most palatable solution was to transform the bread itself.
"The aim is to reach self-sufficiency," said Alaa al-Khouli, First Under Secretary of the Ministry of Supply and an architect of the plan to replace one-fifth of the wheat flour in every Government-milled sack with flour made from Egyptian corn.
In fact, officials concede, the rapid growth of Egypt's population will make it impossible for the country to reduce wheat imports. But the Government hopes at least to cap the total at its current level while using corn, which is cheaper, to help bridge the gap between what bread costs to produce and the pittance the Government asks Egyptians to pay.
Because bread remains so inexpensive, Egyptians tend to waste it, so much so that the Government a few years ago published scolding advertisements that showed goats feasting on discarded loaves.
But Egyptian officials are well aware of the link between bread and domestic discontent. At least one-third of its population live in poverty, and rely on bread for half of their calories, experts say.
The last time the Government announced an increase in the price of bread was in 1977, and then street riots forced Anwar el-Sadat, who was President at the time, to back down. Since then the Egyptian authorities have operated more subtly, introducing a higher-priced loaf in 1987 and touting its qualities while gradually making the cheaper loaf impossible to find.
In the years since, most Egyptians swear, the loaves shoveled from the ovens of state-sponsored bakeries have grown noticeably smaller.
But as soon as a price increase in Jordan last summer prompted bread riots there, the Egyptian Government quickly declared that it planned to maintain its subsidies, which for more than a decade -- despite steady inflation -- have kept the price of the simplest bread fixed at just five piasters a loaf.
"Bread is essential," said Alaa Mohammed, a clerk and the father of three who, like millions of other Cairenes, stops on the way home from work every afternoon to wait his turn at a modest bakery where men and women keep strictly to separate lines.
In some ways, Egypt has lightened the heavy hand it once imposed on the economy. It has ended subsidies on goods like soap, rice and tea, and this year it has moved rapidly to lower trade barriers and to privatize state-owned companies as part of what President Hosni Mubarak has called its decision "to join the world economy."
But nearly one-third of Egypt's economy is still in the hands of public enterprises -- including the mills that produce 80 percent of the country's bread flour. And even as delegates to an economic conference here this month were talking eagerly of the day when Egypt might look something like Singapore, one top official confided that the plan to reinvent Egyptian bread may have its roots in something closer to the old Soviet Union.
To guard against backlash, the Government plans to introduce the new flour only in phases, without telling bakers whether what they are baking is still 100 percent wheat. An experiment last winter in which the blended flour was quietly introduced in scattered neighborhoods produced few if any complaints, officials now insist.
At the United States Wheat Association, whose clients would miss out on potential new business, officials grouse that the new bread will be more prone to grow stale.
At bakeries, owners like Mohammed Iwedia say their worry is that the pockets so characteristic of Arabic bread may no longer puff properly. But whether or not the new dough is different, Mr. Iwedia said, he plans to keep right on loading it into his coal-burning oven to produce the bread that Egyptians so depend on.
"What can I do?" he said with a shrug. "I would bake anything the Government gives me, even if they ask us to bake dust."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The small wheat loaves that have a place at every Egyptian meal are about to change: the Government, to reduce the heavy subsidy it pays, has decreed that beginning next month the bread should be 20 percent corn. (Josef Polleross for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Japan May Approve the Pill, but Women May Not

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 26

 BODY:
The spread of the birth control pill in the West more than three decades ago is widely regarded as a milestone in the liberation of women and a turning point in social history.
So when is the pill coming to Japan? One of these years, the Government says. 
 Japan is one of a tiny number of countries -- perhaps the only other is North Korea -- where the pill is still banned for contraceptive purposes by law. But these days, there are signs that the pill may be legalized in the next few years, perhaps even next spring, because of recent favorable technical data and declining bureaucratic resistance.
The next question is whether women will use it. For now, the answer many Japanese women offer is: Not me!
"I don't think I'll use it," said Sayuri Ogawa, 36, a gynecological nurse. "There are many other contraceptive measures. I don't mind if other people use it, but I myself don't dare."
Japanese women tend not to see the pill as an icon of feminism or of sexual liberation, but rather as an untrustworthy chemical concoction that affects the natural rhythm of their bodies. Moreover, many couples hardly discuss contraceptives, although this reticence is easing among young people, and people know little about contraceptives and are reluctant to ask doctors for such intimate advice.
In Japan the condom is the most widely used form of birth control -- the choice for contraception three-quarters of the time, according to surveys -- followed by withdrawal. When condoms fail -- for they are one of the least reliable forms of contraception -- many women turn to abortion, which is easily available here.
"Japanese women have reached a certain stage mentally, so that whether or not the pill is approved we are already making our own decisions as to whether to have a baby," said Chiemi Amano, 44, who runs an export-import company with her husband. "The approval of the pill would not be a new advancement for women."
Women obviously have a say in the making of babies, and indeed, even without the pill, many are not having them. According to World Bank figures, Japan now has 1.4 live births per woman, and this is one reason the Government has not been pushing the pill: it worries that effective contraception would lower the birthrate even more.
Another concern is AIDS and the fear that use of the pill rather than condoms would allow the disease to spread. But data indicate no higher incidence of AIDS among those who use the pill.
So an advisory council to the Ministry of Health and Welfare may recommend approval next spring, and American pharmaceutical companies like the idea of millions of Japanese women taking their product every morning.
But even if the ministry lifts the ban, there will be another battle to win over the Ms. Ogawas of Japan. While millions of women around the world take the pill for granted, in Japan the pill conjures up frightening memories, awkward feelings and a general sense of aversion.
Some remember Japan's thalidomide babies, who were born more than three decades ago with shortened arms after their mothers took sedatives to alleviate morning sickness. Some have heard about side effects that may occur with high-dosage pills, which were once used for medical purposes in Japan.
Others say not enough research has been done about the potentially serious side effects, like cardiovascular disease, weakened immunity, cervical cancer and thrombosis, a serious blood-clotting affliction.
"Since this is a male-dominated system, the side effects tend to be neglected," said Dr. Reiko Takeda, a gynecologist and hormone specialist who endorses condoms over pills. "We should not be like that. Women should study about the side effects more seriously.
"If someone has to have sex every day, like 30 times a month, in that case, a pill would be called for. As one of the choices, it is necessary. But we should avoid it as much as possible."
A medium-strength form of the pill is currently available in Japan for medical purposes, and some women are using it as a substitute for the low-dose contraceptive pill normally taken by American women.
When Mrs. Amano, who has two children, once had a gynecological problem, her doctor prescribed the pill. She took it, but vomited and felt so sick that she stopped taking it after three to four days.
"I have the image that it could be a dangerous thing because of the side effects, and I'm interested in using it," Mrs. Amano said. "But I may not have the courage to take it."
Some women worry that taking the pill would send a signal of promiscuity. And the Government had earlier resisted the pill because it thought it would promote the spread of promiscuous sex.
Indeed, for many women, the pill could upset the delicate dynamics in the relationship between Japanese men and women.
Even married women tend not to discuss contraceptives openly with their husbands, and traditional Japanese men often are used to taking the lead in the relationship, especially in sex.
Yumiko Kurita, a 43-year-old married woman who spent a year in the United States, said she was awed by the independence of American women, who made their own decisions about whether to take the pill.
"I thought they were basically different from us -- they were so independent in their lives, while we just followed our men," Mrs. Kurita said after a gynecological checkup in a clinic in Tokyo. "But even now, if I look back, I have to say, I couldn't do that."
Mrs. Kurita says she is a traditional Japanese wife, and when her husband stumbles in the door at 2 or 3 in the morning, she is up waiting to welcome him home.
Since her husband is a doctor, she is never wanting for medical advice. But when she has questions about contraceptives, she asks her gynecologist, not her husband. In fact, she says, contraception is not so essential for her anyway.
"Considering how busy my husband is, there's no danger -- I don't have to talk with him about contraceptives," she said. "He's so busy that we go for two, three months without a relationship, sometimes even six months."
Other women quietly worry that if they took they pill, they would scare away their boyfriends and offend their husbands.
"There is a feeling among men that it is intolerable that women take the lead, and if women did, it would hurt their pride -- it is the Samurai principle that men should take the lead," said Dr. Ikuko Ikeshita, who promotes the use of the pill. "The husband of one of my patients started not wanting to have sex with his wife when she started to take pills."
Doctors say some women do not even consider whether to use contraceptives, leaving the matter totally in the hands of their partner, who is not always so careful. To Dr. Ikeshita and others, that means that abortions end up becoming a dangerous form of birth control.
"Between married couples, wives often have difficulty asking their husbands to wear condoms," said Nobuko Sema, an advertising manager who formed a small informal group to support the pill. Ms. Sema, who is divorced, added half jokingly, "I told my husband very clearly my views, and that may have been the cause of our divorce."
Statistically, Japan's health care is among the world's best, with the lowest infant mortality rates and better health care coverage than is found in the United States. But only 56 percent of women of childbearing age use any form of contraception, including condoms, according to World Bank statistics, and education about sex and human reproduction is sparse or virtually nonexistent in schools.
"They teach the parts of conception, like the sperm and the egg in a flower, where the female part and the male part meet and conception occurs," said Yoshiaki Sato, a gynecologist who sometimes visits schools to give lectures on human reproduction. "But they skip the step before that, the sexual intercourse."
The Education Ministry ardently defends its reluctance to have more classroom instruction about sex. "Some people say the United States gives more sex education to kids," said Kazunari Asanuma, an official in charge of education about AIDS and sex. "But then, who has more teen-age pregnancy?"
Japanese women often do not see a gynecologist until they become pregnant or are in their mid- to late 20's, partly out of a fear and dislike of gynecologists. The result is that men and women often learn about contraceptives from magazines and their friends, and because there is little publicity about the pill, they know almost nothing about it.
The Mainichi Shimbun, a national daily, published a survey this summer indicating that nearly 67 percent of women who responded and had heard of the pill said they did not want to use it, up from 53 percent who gave the same reply two years ago.
Kazuyo Kariya, a 25-year-old gynecological nurse, has been explaining the merits of the pill to all her friends.
"I understand how wonderful the pill is and how safe it is, and I recommend it," said Miss Kariya, as she was about to finish up her work one evening. Her first choice for contraceptive?
"My first choice would be the condom, and then the pill," she said with hardly a moment's hesitation. "Even if the pill is a low-dose pill, it doesn't mean it is totally free of side effects. And a condom is successful at least 90 percent of the time."
Her second reason for not taking the pill may also echo a common attitude.
"I have no intention of taking the pill," Miss Kariya said. "I am single. I have no steady partner, so I have no opportunities for sex."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices End Day Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities turned mixed yesterday, gaining early on signs that consumer confidence is not rising and that the economy is not growing rapidly, only to fall as some traders began to take profits.
Analysts said market participants began unloading securities after the price on the benchmark Treasury bond had risen enough to push its yield down to 6.37 percent, the lowest since March 4 and a key resistance level for technical traders. 
 The 30-year bond finished the New York session down 7/32, to a price of 100 26/32 to yield 6.44 percent, up from 6.42 percent on Monday, but still down near its eight-month-low levels.
The Conference Board's November reading of consumer confidence was unchanged at 107.3 from October's reading. Market reaction to the data was minimal, with early buying caused by the report drying up quickly. However, prices of Treasury securities remained firm in thin trading as the market next reacted favorably to a report by the Philadelphia Federal Reserve that economists it had surveyed expected slower growth in the fourth quarter. Market watchers also noted that there was year-end portfolio squaring by some dealers, which gave the market some of that early support, as money managers bought securities with longer maturities.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that although the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index for November was unchanged, consumer confidence was still quite buoyant, and certainly created a conducive environment for a favorable Christmas shopping season. He expects to see more evidence of that in today's release of the University of Michigan's Consumer Sentiment Index.
Other economic statistics are to be released today, but Mr. Fine does not anticipate that any of them will change the market's psyche. Third- quarter G.D.P. is expected to be revised downward, mainly as a result of lower inventory levels. The Chicago Purchasing Managers Index is expected to show only modest gains in that region's industrial sector, and a decline in October durable goods orders is foreseen.
"But all the recent data are very much in line with what the great preponderance of economic statistics have been indicating for some time," Mr. Fine said, "a moderating economy, but one that is certainly not faltering." He added, "Neither is the economy growing quickly enough to warrant fear about an overheating that could produce inflationary pressures."
The yield curve, Mr. Fine said, is likely to remain in a neutral Fed position. "At the same time the long end seems bounded by the continued sustainable growth of the economy setting a floor on yields in one hand, while on the other hand, the lack of inflationary pressures puts a cap on how high yields can go," he continued.
Analysts noted also that the long end of the government securities market was being pressured by issuance of corporate debt, which competes for investor dollars.
Stephen W. Carter, an analyst at MCM Corporate Watch, said about $1.56 billion of fresh investment- grade corporate debt was priced yesterday, including $750 million of 30-year capital securities issued by JPM Capital Trust I, a financing vehicle of J. P. Morgan & Company.
The bank capital notes, as they are called, are a new debtlike trust preferred stock.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 5; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1225 words

HEADLINE: Time to Lower Rebel Flag, A Southern Governor Says

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: ANDERSON, S.C., Nov. 26

 BODY:
South Carolina is the last state in the South to fly the Confederate battle flag from its statehouse. Some look to that white-starred blue X on a field of red and hear the roar of cannons. Others hear only the clink of chains.
It has been a divisive symbol since it was raised in 1962, not only in remembrance of the Civil War but more so to show the state's resistance to the civil rights movement. 
 Now, in a decision that goes against the wishes of a majority in his own party, the Republican governor says it is time to bring it down.
In a remarkable live statewide television address Tuesday night, Gov. David Beasley, asked South Carolinians to "compromise on the Confederate flag, and teach our children that we can live together." He wants the flag to be removed from the capitol dome and placed at a Confederate memorial on the statehouse grounds.
Mr. Beasley's speech tonight was the first time in more than a decade that a South Carolina governor has asked for time on public television to address an issue to all corners of the state, from the mill towns around Anderson, Greenville and Spartanburg through the midland part of the state in and around Columbia down to the coast at Charleston.
The public television station broadcast not merely Mr. Beasley's address, but also rebuttals from opponents. Several commercial television stations around the state, seeing the issue's importance to people here, also carried the address live.
The first-term governor opposed bringing down the flag in his 1994 campaign, when three of four voters in the Republican primary said they wanted the flag to continue flying atop the statehouse.
But racial incidents have hammered the state week after week in the last year, as South Carolina became the dateline for embarrassing and -- to many people -- heartbreaking confrontations.
Governor Beasley said he changed his mind after the recent burnings of black churches and a drive-by shooting of blacks outside a rural nightclub by men linked to the Ku Klux Klan.
"The true meaning of the flag has nothing to do with racial hatred," Governor Beasley said, but hate groups -- now and in the past -- have adopted it as their symbol.
"Hate-filled cowards cover their heads and hide under the cloak of night," said the Governor, and because of them and their misuse of the Confederate symbol, "those of us who honor the flag are called racists."
"It is inexcusable when we are called a racist state," he said. "We are not."
A 1995 amendment to the state's budget act requires any change in the location of the flag to be approved by the Legislature. The Governor said he would ask the General Assembly to vote to remove the flag and place it in the less prominent place on the grounds in 1997, reviving a plan that died for lack of support in 1994. Political experts have said Governor Beasley may have the votes to accomplish the flag's relocation this time, if he can get a sliver of Republican support to go with the Democrats who like his plan.
Just 40 percent of South Carolinians want to keep the flag atop the statehouse, according to state polls. The rest either want it down or do not care.
Black ministers have pushed for years for its removal, as a majority of whites opposed them. But in the last few years, business leaders have stressed that the flag and the divisiveness it engenders are hurting the state's economic growth.
Still, emotion -- not money -- is at the core of this fight.
Carl B. Grant is a black lawyer in Columbia. He recently represented a 10-year-old black boy tied to a tree and terrorized by a white couple and two white children.
"We all know that at the Klan rallies, at incidents of hate crime, this flag is their symbol," Mr. Grant said. "The flag embraces and perpetuates the ideology of white supremacy."
That is what he sees when he looks at it, and what he has seen since he was a child carried along by his mother to civil rights demonstrations. If a flag is supposed to be a proud symbol of the people who live under it, he asks, then how can the Confederate flag possibly be such a symbol for black people.
"That symbol only embraces the heritage of a particular people," he said. "That flag tells me that, because of the color of my skin, I am considered a second-class citizen. If it represents history, put it in a museum."
Any decision to bring it from its place of honor is, he said, "a victory."
Mr. Beasley said he wanted to continue to honor the flag, but did not want his children debating the flag's place above the capital 10 years from now.
Some black leaders have said they will be satisfied with nothing short of its complete removal from the grounds.
After Mr. Beasley's speech, leading state Republicans lined up to refute the Governor's claims that the flag had to come down for the good of the state.
Two powerful state Republicans -- Attorney General Charlie Condon and Senator Glenn McConnell of Charleston -- said they wanted a referendum on the issue. Mr. Condon said it was the "editorial writers and politicians" who should "be ashamed of themselves" for bringing the issue up over and over again.
They have created the problem, he said.
"If that flag is a symbol of honor," Mr. Condon said, "then there should be no controversy. If it is a symbol of racism and hate, it shouldn't be flying at all."
As for the argument about the flag's driving away business, he said, "we should never compromise our principles for money."
But Mr. Beasley said the state had little choice. "The issue is about a people that need to look deep into their heart, deep into their soul, and figure out how are we going to be a better people," the Governor said. "To say we can't resolve this is giving up, is saying to our children we're not capable of compromise, we're not capable of working together."
Mr. Beasley's flowery address was filled with words of praise and pride about the State of South Carolina and its proud history, including the Civil War, making plain his reluctance to push for the flag's removal.
But, he said, "hate struck the match and hate pulled the trigger" in the church burnings and drive-by shootings. It is better for the flag for it to be placed where its historical significance is clear, such as at the Confederate memorial, than to allow it to continue to be misused by some as a symbol of modern-day racial divisiveness.
Mr. Condon and Mr. Beasley both have ancestors who fought in the Civil War. But while the Governor said those ghosts could still be honored by the placement of the flag in a more historical setting, the Attorney General said it cheapened the memory of the war's veterans to have the flag take from its place atop the symbolic crown of state government.
"The Confederate flag did not burn those churches," Mr. Condon said.
Some political observers have said the debate between the two men is a preview of the race for the Republican nomination for governor two years down the road. It is expected to be damaging to Governor Beasley politically, but not fatal.
One young woman, who asked not to be identified because she said any white person who supported the flag was branded a racist, said she would prefer that the flag remain, "but we can live with it, if it has to come down."
A flag, Mr. Beasley said tonight "should be a symbol of all the people."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fund Investments Surge; Dow Loses 19.38 Points
Mutual fund investors, who have greeted every stock market rally this year with a fresh infusion of cash, continue to register their belief that stock prices can go even higher.
With the Dow Jones industrial average up 8.3 percent this month, several big fund companies, including John Hancock, Smith Barney, Vanguard, Charles Schwab and Fidelity Investments, reported that cash flows into stock funds in November were well ahead of last month's flows. [Page A1.]
 
The Dow average took a breather from its record-breaking run, falling 19.38 points to 6,528.41, but the Nasdaq composite rose 0.83 to 1,281.20, its second straight closing high. [D6.]
 
Treasury securities prices were mixed as traders took profits on early gains that followed a report by the Conference Board that its consumer confidence index held steady in November. The yield on the 30-year bond edged up to 6.44 percent. [D16.]
 
Disney Earnings Climb 27%
The Walt Disney Company reported a 27 percent rise in fourth-quarter profit to $336 million, helped by record theme park attendance and its "Aladdin and the King of Thieves" video. With Capital Cities/ABC it had net income of $354 million. Its stock surged $2.50, to $76, following the report. [D3.]
 
Disney said it would release "Kundun," a new Martin Scorsese film about the life of the Dalai Lama, despite a warning by the Chinese Government not to do so. [C9.]
 
Lehman's President Resigns
T. Christopher Pettit, 51, resigned as president of Lehman Brothers, months after stepping down as chief operating officer, ceding power to younger senior executives. [D2.]
 
Primark Deal for Baseline Expected
Primark, continuing its rapid growth in the financial information business, is expected to announce it has acquired Baseline Financial Services for $40 million in cash from Bowne & Company and Baseline's founder. [D16.]
 
A Snag in Nynex Merger Plans
The staff of the New York State Public Service Commission opposed approval of the proposed merger of Nynex and Bell Atlantic unless Nynex agrees to compensate customers for the loss of a potential competitor -- by cutting rates, for example. [B1.]
 
Hughes in Japanese Space Deal
Hughes Electronics became the first company to sign up to launch commercial satellites on a Japanese rocket being developed. [D5.]
 
Swiss Bank to Make Big Cuts
Union Bank of Switzerland said it would cut 800 jobs and take a special charge of $2.3 billion that will result in a 1996 loss. [D5.]
 
Russia Drops Western Advisers
The Russian State Property Committee dropped its Western advisers, led by N. M. Rothschild & Sons, for the planned sale of shares in RAO Svyazinvest, which controls most of Russia's local phone companies. [D5.]
 
Owners Back Baseball Agreement
Baseball club owners ratified an accord that assures the first labor peace in major league baseball in four years and paves the way for interleague play, a luxury tax on payrolls, a revenue-sharing plan to transfer $40 million to poorer clubs and a search for a commissioner. [A1.]
 
A.A.R.P. Weighs Health Plans
The American Association of Retired Persons said it was in talks about endorsing managed-care plans for its 30 million members with U.S. Healthcare, Kaiser Permanente and seven other H.M.O.'s. [D6.]
 
F.D.A. Approves Alzheimer's Drug
The F.D.A. approved a Japanese drug, Aricept, to treat the memory-robbing effects of Alzheimer's disease. Pfizer will market the drug in the United States. [C8.]

HEADLINE: A Former Stronghold Turns Against President of Serbia

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: NIS, Serbia, Nov. 26

 BODY:
His old blue raincoat flapping in wild gusts of wind, the newspaper editor pushed his way through the demonstrators in the central square of this industrial city like a man with a mission.
"Look," said Velimir Rakocevic, spotting a young man selling his small, 12-page tabloid, the only independent newspaper in the city. "A week ago anyone seen carrying a stack of our papers was beaten. Now we can't print enough of them. This is the first time we have been able to distribute our paper in public. We are even making a profit." 
 Nis, a city of 200,000, once a stronghold of the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, and the old Communist party, has turned violently against the Belgrade Government since the decision last week to annul the opposition victory in local elections here and in other cities. The Supreme Court ruled today to uphold a court ruling nullifying the vote.
Eight days ago, tens of thousands of angry blue-uniformed workers began the daily street protests that have now swept the country. Students and professors have occupied all of the city's university buildings and the local ruling Socialist Party leader, whose huge frame used to dominate the evening news, has disappeared from public view and ordered the party headquarters closed.
"We have every ill that besets Serbia here, only compounded," said Zoran Ziukovic, the head of the Nis opposition coalition. "Our industry is dead, people can barely make a living and we struggle under one of the most distorted and primitive forms of socialism in Serbia."
The protesters do not come from any one political party or represent any particular ideology. They range from nationalists to social democrats, but they have a common goal: They're tired of the Government.
Mr. Milosevic, who represented the Bosnian Serbs at negotiations in Dayton, Ohio, last year and who supported the peace agreement that was drafted there, has been helpful to the United States, at least for the period near the war's end, and Washington has avoided challenging him.
The Serbian Government, rattled by the protests, has moved some 5,000 police officers from an elite unit in Kosovo to the city's back streets. Opposition leaders say their presence is meant to counter the open support many local policemen have expressed for the protesters.
Nis perhaps epitomizes everything that has gone wrong under Mr. Milosevic since he took power in 1987.
The sprawling Elektronska Industrija Nis, one of two huge state-run factories here, has collapsed under mismanagement. A decade ago wages averaged $800 a month, but have now fallen to $40 a month and generally arrive three months late. The few hundred boxy television sets and washing machines that roll off the assembly line can barely keep 200 of the 23,000 workers employed.
The streets of the city, 140 miles south of Belgrade, are also in dismal condition. Lights are burned out; garbage lies uncollected; potholes look ready to swallow the small, sputtering Yugo cars that chug along the roads, and a layer of grime and pollution hangs over the city.
Presiding over Nis is the widely unpopular Socialist Party leader, Mile Ilic. He and his followers have milked City Hall for gleaming new Mercedeses, choice apartments and glittering new office towers where tenants turn their checks over to Mr. Ilic's wife, according to local business leaders.
Mr. Ilic, who travels with a group of armed bodyguards who are also trained kick-boxers, is a close associate of Mr. Milosevic. He led the movement to nominate Mr. Milosevic for the Nobel Prize, and in a recent public appearance said he "thanked God" that the Serbian nation is blessed with a "visionary" like Mirjana Markovic, Mr. Milosevic's wife and partner in state and party business.
The local elections, however, proved to be the ruling party's undoing. Party workers brazenly carried sacks of marked ballots into city polling stations and stuffed them in the boxes as outraged voters watched.
Thugs with crew cuts entered polling stations and savagely beat opposition election monitors.
And when 17 polling stations had the tenacity to report opposition victories, the city government annulled the vote and, without releasing figures, declared the ruling party victorious. On Wednesday a third round of elections is to be held, but opposition members have promised to boycott them.
Opposition leaders said they hesitated to mention Mr. Ilic's name at the daily rallies, which draw about 30,000 people here, because of the violence it could unleash, something they fear will play into the Government's hands.
Vladimir Djordevic, a 52-year-old clerk, stood in a cold drizzle in the city center today as opposition leaders addressed some 20,000 people from the concrete frame of a building that was designed to be the city's first McDonald's, but was left unfinished when economic sanctions were imposed during the war.
He said he monitored the vote for the opposition until he was attacked and badly beaten by kick-boxers and the deputy chairman of the city assembly inside a polling station.
"I remember lying on the floor screaming 'Thieves, thieves, thieves!' as they kicked me," he said, "and every time I remember that moment I vow to stand in this square until we drive them from power."

HEADLINE: Adopting a Cat Gets Complicated

BYLINE: By CLARE COLLINS 

 BODY:
IF you're looking to adopt a cat at Christmas, the peak adoption time, be prepared to prove you are the perfect parent.
Take the case of Margot C. Bright, who decided to adopt a kitten from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals -- and assumed it would be easy. 
 A corporate banker, Ms. Bright could well afford the expense of pet ownership. And while she worked long hours, she said she told the A.S.P.C.A. that she planned to be home most evenings and weekends to give her kitten "quality time."
So imagine Ms. Bright's surprise when the shelter on East 92d Street refused to let her adopt a kitten. Why? She works too much.
"I was told that because I work more than four hours a day outside the home, I was ineligible for a kitten," Ms. Bright said, fuming. "It's ridiculous. It's like saying only retired people or people who don't work should have a kitten."
The shelter suggested that Ms. Bright adopt an older cat that could better handle being alone all day. She declined. "I really wanted a kitten that I could raise myself," she said. "With an older cat, you don't know what kind of baggage it has, what kind of temperament."
Ailurophiles might also learn from the efforts of the suburban family who attempted to adopt a cat from the Central Westchester Humane Society in Elmsford. Their daughter, 4, spent hours picking out her favorite while her parents responded to the shelter's written queries: would they let the animal out during the day? Yes, chaperoned by family members. At night? No. How did they feel about having the cat declawed? Ambivalent.
The family was deemed unsuitable; the shelter's policy was to reject families who do not promise to keep the cat indoors at all times or who plan to declaw it.
More and more animal shelters have enacted strict standards for cat adoptions. In addition to rules about keeping cats indoors and keeping kittens sufficiently entertained, most shelters will not give a cat to someone who plans to have it declawed. Prospective owners are likely to be asked to supply proof of employment and references (which are usually called on the spot). Adoptions are refused if the applicant is unemployed or, in the case of a kitten, has children 6 or younger.
Applicants should expect to fill out a lengthy questionnaire covering everything from their work schedule to the number and ages of their children living at home to who will care for it should they become unable to. A growing number of shelters are checking for a criminal record of cruelty to animals. Some also make unannounced follow-up checks on the home, looking for signs of mistreatment or neglect.
While such stringent requirements have long been in place for dog adoptions, the attitude toward cats was always somewhat laissez-faire. That has changed over the last five to seven years, said the Human Society of the United States, in Washington. The precise criteria for adoptive cat parents currently vary, and are something that shelters are careful not to reveal.
"We don't want to give people a chance to rehearse their answers," said Michael M. Arms, the director of the North Shore Animal League in Port Washington, L.I.
Mimi Stone, the director of the shelter in Elmsford, agreed with that approach. "I'm not going to tell you our secrets," she said. "It doesn't work well for us if people know all the questions we tend to ask."
According to the Humane Society, there are no standard regulations for what shelters may require when considering an adoption, and no governing body to regulate animal adoption policies. "We offer adoption guidelines, but nobody is obliged to follow them," said Sally Fekety, a spokeswoman. "It's really up to the shelter's board of directors to decide what constitutes appropriate criteria. And that criteria may be a little subjective."
Dr. Sandra Bushmich, a veterinarian and an associate professor of pathobiology at the University of Connecticut, said pet adoption regulations are usually made out of concern for animal welfare. Most shelters forbid declawing, for example, calling it inhumane and saying it makes it difficult for a cat to protect itself outdoors. But sometimes, rules can be carried to extremes.
"There's no question that issues such as whether a cat should be spayed or neutered, or whether people understand the long-term commitment associated with a pet, are very real," Dr. Bushmich said. "But many other issues that shelters cover tend to be a matter of opinion."
For that reason, she said, adoptions should be made on a case-by-case basis, rather than by holding everyone to the same standards. "Otherwise," she said, "a shelter might overlook a very good home. You really don't want a cat languishing in a shelter or being euthanized if someone is out there willing to care for it."
Hedy Litke, director of adoptions for the 92d Street A.S.P.C.A. shelter, said that the shelter's guidelines are intended to prevent failed adoptions: of the 150 dogs and cats adopted on average each month, 25 percent wind up back at the shelter. She also noted that cats who remain in cages too long may become unadoptable. Pacing around a cage all day isn't good for a cat's mental state. These cats, she said -- which might not allow anyone to pick them up, or might hiss or stop eating -- are euthanized, as are cats with significant health problems. (Some shelters, like Elmsford's, are "no-kill" shelters.)
According to the Humane Society, which strongly advocates keeping cats inside, an indoor cat is likely to live 16 years, while the average outdoor cat survives only 3 to 4 years and is more likely to pick up diseases. But Dr. Bushmich said such risks are outweighed by other considerations. "I have two cats, and they would not be happy staying inside," she said. "It's not just length of life, but quality of life you should be concerned with."
The shelter in Elmsford rarely allows adoptions to families who plan to let the cat outside, even when accompanied by the owner. Ms. Stone, its director, said she makes exceptions. "I go by instinct," she said. (One tip: be sure to have a landlord's approval for a pet before heading off to the shelter.)
The North Shore Animal League turns down one of every three people seeking to adopt a pet from its shelter, Mr. Arms said.
"We do exercise a lot of quality control," he said. His criteria include that the cat is allowed outdoors only in rural or suburban areas, that it is not given to someone as a gift and that the owner is employed. "We feel it's better for a cat to have a long, safe life, rather than a short, happy one," he added.
To make sure that happens, the shelter makes an unannounced visit within 90 days of an adoption and can repossess the cat if an owner hasn't produced papers showing the animal has been neutered or vaccinated.
What recourse do you have if you feel you've been rejected unfairly? Ms. Fekety of the Humane Society recommends writing a letter to the shelter manager or board. "It may be that the board of directors needs to revisit a given policy," she said. Or a shelter employee may be applying the rules with a broad brush.
It is also wise, as Ms. Bright found, to shop around. She eventually adopted a kitten through a shelter in Rochester, where she had gone to visit her brother. There, she was told that full-time work was not an impediment to adopting a kitten. Go figure.
Alternatives to shelters include the classified sections of the newspaper (sometimes listed under "Free to a Good Home" or "Pets") and pet stores.
But even stores are getting picky. "We require people who want a cat to fill out an application," said Susie Park, owner of Animal House, a pet store on Ninth Avenue near 42d Street, which asks $50 for a cat (shelters charge $30 to $75), a fee that covers the cost of vaccines and spaying or neutering. "We then interview the person by phone."

GRAPHIC: Photo: For people wanting this cat, working too much, or not at all, is a negative. (Michael Shavel for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "The Right Answer: It Will Stay Indoors, With Claws"
Adopting a cat from an animal shelter these days requires more than choosing between the tabby and the calico. Expect plenty of questions -- and possibly a refusal.
 
Declawing. Almost all shelters will refuse a cat to someone who plans to declaw it.
 
Home Alone. Stricter rules apply for kittens; the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals requires you work no more than four hours a day outside the home. Other shelters recommend adopting two kittens to keep each other company.
 
Indoors or Out. Every shelter recommends not letting the cats outdoors, and many will refuse adoptions to those who say they plan to do so -- even if the cat would be chaperoned or on a leash.
 
Windows. Shelters in the city, including the A.S.P.C.A., require full screens on apartment windows (no matter what floor), because a cat can squeeze through a window guard.
 
Children. If there are children 6 or younger in the family, most shelters will refuse a kitten adoption. Some are more extreme -- when a caller told I Love Animals Inc. in Manhattan that she had a 6-year-old and an 11-year-old, the representative said, "Cats don't like kids," and hung up.
 
Pregnant. Some refuse adoptions to pregnant women because cats can transmit toxoplasmosis, a disease that can harm the fetus.
 
Employment. No job, no cat -- unless you can prove you can afford it. Students are almost always refused. Military personnel may need to show they have a place to leave the cat should they move.
 
Spaying and Neutering. Every shelter requires it. For kittens, some require leaving a deposit for spaying or neutering after eight weeks. Most will check up on the phone; at least one shelter will make an unannounced visit to your home.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Climbs Broadly, Aided By Signs of Weakness in Japan

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most leading currencies yesterday, bolstered by fresh signs of economic weakness in Japan and renewed calls for a stronger dollar from European officials.
The Bank of Japan reported its quarterly survey of business sentiment, known as the tankan, improved only slightly in November, leading traders to sell Japanese yen for dollars. The report suggested Japan's economy was still too weak to tolerate higher interest rates.
"The tankan report was not terrible, but the market had been short dollars against expectations of a slightly better report," said Ben Strauss, a currency trader at Bank Julius Baer & Company.
In late trading in New York, the dollar rose to 113.33 yen, from 112.47 yen on Tuesday, and the first close above 113 yen since Nov. 6. The dollar rose to 1.5268 German marks from 1.5244 marks, but fell to 5.1690 French francs from 5.1706 francs. Trading was light ahead of Thanksgiving, when financial markets in the United States are closed. Most markets overseas are open.
The dollar gained against European currencies after Prime Minister Alain Juppe of France told an audience in Paris that he thought the dollar was undervalued. Mr. Juppe also said he would ask other leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized nations to discuss the dollar's weakness.
The comments by the Prime Minister helped bolster the dollar against the mark and briefly against the French franc.
"Certainly it's his 'undervalued' statement in line with yesterday's French comment that's doing this," said Kevin Lawrie, global manager of foreign exchange at Mellon Bank.
The dollar had less success against the British pound, which climbed on renewed talk of higher interest rates in Britain.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, told a London news conference that he was prepared to raise interest rates if necessary to counter inflationary pressures as the British economy continued to expand.
"The comments gave sterling a little bit of firmness," Mr. Strauss of Bank Julius Baer said. "It had had a pretty good selloff the last couple of days and now it's bouncing."
In New York, the pound rose to $1.6781 from $1.6714.
