HEADLINE: CATCHING UP WITH: Bill Gates;
Filling Potholes In 'Road Ahead'

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
IN the techno-future foreseen by Bill Gates, people will have no need to carry money, identification or a watch. They will use a wallet PC, a hand-held computer that stores digital cash and information.
These quotidian encumbrances are already obsolete for Mr. Gates. When he wanted to know what time it was during breakfast the other day, he asked an aide, and the aide looked at his watch. After Mr. Gates finished his meal at Sarabeth's on the Upper East Side, the aide, a member of Microsoft's press office, pulled out a gold card and signed for the check. 
 For Mr. Gates, the future is already here, in the form of a Personal Nondigital Assistant.
The Microsoft founder and 41-year-old zillionaire had flown in from Lake Placid, N.Y., where he, his wife and their 7-month-old daughter had spent an unwired weekend ensconced in a resort hotel. Mr. Gates read The Economist front to back and worked on a devilishly difficult jigsaw puzzle. As his wife and only child returned home to a Seattle suburb, he chartered a plane to New York for business. But in some ways he was still in family mode.
He ordered a "Papa Bear," a large bowl of porridge, typical fare at Sarabeth's, a countrified place favored by mothers and toddlers. He seemed fascinated not so much with computer technology as diaper technology. "At home we have this thing, a special diaper pail, that if the diaper doesn't smell good you just put it in and twist it around and there's no odor," he said. "I think it's new only in the last year or two. I can't imagine what it was like before."
As he spoke, he folded his arms across his stomach, hands grasping elbows, and rocked back and forth on the banquette. It was not a grown-up's posture. Mr. Gates's several adolescent mannerisms -- he is fond of words like "cool" -- together with his tousled mop-top and pallid skin have fueled the myth that he is the original computer nerd.
In fact, since dropping out of Harvard to sell software to computer hobbyists, Mr. Gates has always been more cutthroat businessman than programming whiz. Microsoft built its near-monopolistic dominance of the software industry on his shrewd decision to license the computer operating system MS-DOS to I.B.M., rather than sell it outright; thus, it pockets a fee every time an I.B.M. PC or clone is sold.
Today the perception of Microsoft as the Evil Empire is greater than ever, measured in personal attacks on Mr. Gates from rival computer moguls, and on the Internet, the collective unconscious of computerdom. An Internet search of the name "Bill Gates" brings back numerous "proofs" that he is the Antichrist. One example (http://jr.ttisms.com/ pjf/666.html) uses numerology to show that the name Windows 95 adds up to 666. "Coincidence?" writes the anonymous author. "Or just the beginning of mankind's ultimate and total enslavement?"
Mr. Gates seems to pay no heed to such populist rumblings and dismisses the criticism of competitors as posturing. "We're about making great software, that's our deal," he said. "The current state of affairs, where we have a growing number of customers, and competitors don't like us, that's the ideal thing."
It had been 30 minutes since he ordered breakfast, and the food had not yet come. An embarrassed waitress appeared and said: "I'm sorry your order is taking so long. There's a computer problem."
If Mr. Gates felt a wave of cosmic irony breaking, he gave no hint. All he said was: "Sheesh. I wondered."
Eventually the food came, and Mr. Gates, wearing a plush green sweater, brown slacks and tasseled black loafers as smooth as baby skin, dug into his oatmeal.
He was in town to discuss the Penguin paperback edition of his 1995 best seller, "The Road Ahead." The new book is an upgrade, with 20 percent more material, a figure it is possible to give precisely because Microsoft tabulated the number of words in each chapter of the original edition against the number in each chapter of the new book.
The revision was needed because when Mr. Gates peered down the road ahead a year ago, the view looked far different. As he acknowledges, he was late to grasp the significance of the Internet's explosive growth, and the book has been rewritten to give it prominence.
In a now-famous speech on Pearl Harbor Day last December, Mr. Gates announced that every Microsoft division would be refocused to develop products for the Internet market and that henceforth, "we are hard-core about the Internet."
Since then, Microsoft has gone head-to-head with Netscape Communications in a war over competing software to browse the World Wide Web; entered a partnership with NBC on a cable news channel and Web news site, MSNBC, and redesigned the Microsoft Network, with 1.6 million subscribers, to be primarily an Internet access provider.
The bottom line: at a time when the stocks of many once-hot Internet companies have cooled, Microsoft shares have climbed 74 percent this year, and Mr. Gates, who owns 23.6 percent of the company, is worth a staggering $20 billion.
Still, the Internet's future may be dimmer than expected if the personal Web-browsing habits of America's No. 1 computer guy are an indication. On his own time, Mr. Gates is not all that hard-core about the Net. He has used it to buy books, and when his wife, Melinda French Gates, a former Microsoft executive (they married on New Year's Day 1994), was pregnant, the couple retrieved childbirth information from hospitals' Web sites. But mainly they consulted traditional paperbacks.
Their daughter, Jennifer Katharine, was born in April. "The first six months have been much more of a thrill than I expected," Mr. Gates said. "I thought, 'Well, when the kid starts talking, we'll do things together.' But even a kid who doesn't talk has little triumphs and a personality."
In the past, he has maintained that he did not believe in inherited wealth and intended to give away the vast bulk of his fortune in his lifetime. The reality of having an heir has not changed his view. "I'll make sure my kids have enough money to be good and safe," he said, "but I don't think it's helpful to have a ton of money."
He said he expected to leave his children less than $10 million -- adjusted for inflation.
Since 1992, Mr. Gates has put $200 million into a foundation, administered by his father, that gives mainly to education, population control and the United Way.
His main personal indulgence is a much-delayed 37,000-square-foot house that he and his wife are building on Lake Washington. He denied a rumor among Microsoft employees that Mrs. Gates dislikes the house, which has cost upward of $30 million, and will never move in.
The rumors can probably be traced to the shotgun marriage between the house's rustic stone-and-wood-beam architecture, designed when Mr. Gates was a bachelor, and the plush Euro-style typical of Mrs. Gates's chosen decorator, Thierry Despont, who usually seems more at home in the 18th century.
Curiosity about the house has run feverishly high from the first descriptions of its 20-car garage, trampoline room for Mr. Gates to exercise in and computer-controlled music system that pipes a visitor's favorite sounds into whatever room he or she enters. Watch Bill's House Grow, an unofficial Web site, posts updated photographs (www.morsepr.com/ MMdocs/Bill.html).
While Mr. Gates leaves most of the decisions about furniture to his wife, he is in charge of the guy-type stuff -- in particular, 30 or so wall screens throughout the house that will display a shifting series of digitized artworks and other images.
"One of the screens is the size of that wall there," Mr. Gates said, pointing at a 20-foot-long row of windows on Madison Avenue. "It's the most unique aspect of the house. We make it so easy to call up images, whether art or people or beaches or sunsets or Nobel Prize winners."
With all that, who needs family portraits?

HEADLINE: Growth Is Revised to a Slightly Slower 2%

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
The Government said today that the economy grew just slightly more slowly in the third quarter than initially estimated, and other new statistics suggested that the nation was continuing to enjoy modest growth and low inflation in the final three months of the year.
The Commerce Department said the economy grew 2 percent in the third quarter. Its original estimate last month had been 2.2 percent. Citing subsequent reports about the economy's performance at the end of the quarter -- particularly a larger-than-expected trade deficit in September -- many economists had expected the revised growth figure to be as low as 1.7 percent. 
 The Commerce Department also reported today that orders for durable goods rose one-tenth of 1 percent in October. Most analysts had been expecting a decline after September's robust increase in orders of 4.6 percent. The slight rise provided tentative evidence that the economy remained on solid footing early in the fourth quarter.
"Orders are still exhibiting enough forward momentum to keep the manufacturing sector gainfully employed at least into early 1997," said Kenneth Mayland, the chief economist at Keycorp in Cleveland.
Other indicators issued today showed no signs of any pressures that could push the economy either to stall or overheat.
The number of people filing first-time claims for unemployment last week held steady, compared with the previous week, at 342,000. The Conference Board's index of help-wanted advertising fell 2 points, to 82, suggesting a slight easing of demand for workers at a time when unemployment, at 5.2 percent, remains near a seven-year low.
A survey of purchasing managers in the Chicago area found a slight acceleration in business activity this month in that region, while a similar survey in the New York area found a somewhat stronger pickup.
"The data is consistent with a slowdown in the third quarter, but it doesn't look like there's any sign of cumulative weakness or a process that's headed toward a recession," said John E. Silvia, the chief economist at Zurich Kemper Investments in Chicago.
Since it became apparent late in the summer that the economy was slowing substantially from its 4.7 percent growth rate in the second quarter, the Federal Reserve and the financial markets have become considerably less worried about an outbreak of inflation, despite the continued low unemployment rate.
Analysts said the balance enjoyed by the economy should allow the Federal Reserve to keep short-term interest rates unchanged well into next year. The Fed, which next meets to consider monetary policy on Dec. 17, has held rates steady since January, betting successfully that a brief surge in growth last spring would give way to the current stable environment.
The Commerce Department's report on the gross domestic product contained further evidence that inflation remained contained. The two main price indexes used by the Government to adjust for inflation remained unchanged from last month's initial estimate and in both cases were below the second-quarter rate. The chain-weight price index was 1.9 percent in the third quarter, down from 2.2 percent in the second quarter. The implicit price deflator for the third quarter stood at 1.6 percent, down from 1.8 percent in the second quarter.
The downward revision in the growth estimate was largely a result of a decline from the previously projected level of exports and a drop of $6.8 billion from the previous estimate of business inventories, the department said.
The slight increase in durable goods orders was driven by a 17.3 percent surge in orders for electronics and other electrical equipment. That rise more than offset an expected drop of 7.9 percent in orders for transportation equipment, including aircraft. Aircraft orders, which tend to bounce sharply up and down on a month-to-month basis, had been particularly strong in September.
The Commerce Department also reported that after-tax corporate profits fell 2.6 percent in the third quarter, the weakest showing since a 5.8 percent drop in the first quarter of 1994. Profits had dropped two-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds End Short Session A Bit Higher

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended slightly higher in a shortened session yesterday, retreating from session highs on economic data that were somewhat stronger than expected.
The market retains a bullish tone, despite returning some early gains and even though the numbers released yesterday suggested a strong economy that could get stronger. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury rose 7/32 yesterday, to 101 1/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.42 percent, from 6.44 percent on Tuesday.
The market will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving, and trading ended at 2 P.M. yesterday. The market will again close early tomorrow since many market participants are not expected to return until next week.
Bonds rose in early trading yesterday, bolstered by a surge in the dollar against the Japanese yen. The yen weakened following the release of the Bank of Japan's survey of business sentiment, known as the tankan, which showed that the Japanese economy was recovering more slowly than expected and suggested that interest rates would not be rising in the near term.
The dollar's climb raised the bond market's expectations that foreign buyers would continue pouring money into the United States as a strong dollar makes investments here more attractive.
Indeed, Japan's eight biggest insurance companies have said that they plan to increase foreign bond purchases in the second half of their fiscal year, which ends March 31.
But bond prices were held down by several reports that pointed to a strengthening economy. The Chicago Purchasing Managers said that its index of business activity rose to 57.6 in November, from 56.9 in October, more than economists' expectations of a drop to 55.2. Readings of more than 50 suggest that manufacturing is expanding.
The University of Michigan's final index of consumer sentiment for November rose to 99.2, traders said, from the final October index reading of 96.5 and the highest reading in more than 10 years. The Michigan consumer survey is released only to subscribers.
And while the economy in the third quarter grew at a slower pace than an earlier reading had shown, gross domestic product data released yesterday were stronger than many Wall Street economists had predicted. The Commerce Department reported a revised 2 percent rise in G.D.P., compared with an earlier estimate of 2.2 percent.
The Commerce Department also reported that orders for durable goods rose one-tenth of 1 percent in October. Most analysts had been expecting a decline following a sharp rise in September.
"Today's economic numbers were stronger and more positive than expected," said Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, "and as the day progressed pushed Treasury prices to their lowest levels" of the session.
"The strong numbers showed the economy is still moving forward and with that the potential of a rise in inflation pressures," he said.
Even after the market ended virtually flat, Mr. Regan said that the overall sentiment was still bullish, "but you do have a cautionary feeling coming into the marketplace."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The E.P.A.'s tough standards: cost isn't a consideration.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
AFTER years of hinting, the Environmental Protection Agency now wants to tighten air quality standards for ozone and the tiny particles in dust and soot.
That's good, right? After all, the new rules are designed to meet the letter and spirit of the Clean Air Act, which requires the agency to "protect public health with an ample margin of safety." But they are raising eyebrows among economists inclined to look much more critically at the costs of regulation as well as the benefits. 
 Lumping together standards for the two pollutants, these economists say, uses the strong case for reducing particulates to mask the relatively weak case against ozone. More important, the tighter standard for ozone pushes regulation into little-explored territory where the costs of pollution control are large and obvious, while the likely benefits are ephemeral.
So how will the Government reconcile the stern dictates of the law with the cool realities of economics and politics? Good question. "Los Angeles never had a prayer of meeting the old ozone standard," Lester Lave, an economist at Carnegie-Mellon University, said, "let alone the new one."
The good news here is that the E.P.A. is updating particulate standards to mesh with scientific findings that very small particles (2.5 microns, or millionths of a meter, in diameter) are as damaging to health as larger ones. It is still not clear, however, that all new particles being regulated are equally dangerous. Exposure to nitrogen compounds (from car exhausts and power plants) may be less risky than contact with sulfur compounds (mostly from burning coal).
Even less clear is the logic in linking the regulation of soot and ozone. Killer smog, still a phenomenon in the third world, is typically loaded with both particulates and ozone. And reducing emissions of one often reduces emissions of the other. But those rationalizations mask big differences.
The epidemiological case against ozone is weak. For example, a study of the horrific air pollution in Mexico City by the widely respected Health Effects Institute found that particulates rather than ozone did most of the medical damage. And while researchers have been looking for the smoking gun on ozone for decades, Paul Portney, president of the economically aware environmental group Resources for the Future, says that "all they've been able to prove is that exposure causes short-term reversible effects," like bronchial irritation and watery eyes.
Above all, what the E.P.A. ruling will do is raise the bar for meeting air pollution standards to a qualitatively higher level. Under the old ozone standard of 120 parts per billion, some 70 urban areas fail to make the cut. But only Houston, New York, Philadelphia and a few cities in California were under pressure to make radical changes in order to meet the standard. And only Los Angeles was hopelessly out of compliance.
By ratcheting down to 80 parts per billion, Los Angeles will have plenty of company in the E.P.A.'s dog house. Mr. Lave expects that "much of the Eastern Seaboard" will fall into this category.
In a society that could cope rationally with these issues, Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, suggests, the appropriate response would be to change the law. Rather than an absolute Federal health standard, Congress may create a test in which the value of lives lengthened (along with other benefits) are weighed against the cost of compliance. Cities that want to pay for cleaner air -- resorts, say, or places catering to retirees -- ought to be allowed to find "local solutions for local problems," he argues. But no one is going to force Cleveland or Baltimore to abandon the internal combustion engine.
That is not how Washington works, of course. It has dealt with the Los Angeles compliance problem in the past, for example, through a process of endless delay. That has led to significant progress but has also allowed everyone involved to avoid confronting the serious trade-offs involved. The region has repeatedly been given more time to comply as long as it was making a good faith effort -- electric cars, reformulated charcoal lighting fluid and the like.
In the end, though, the only way around the impossible is to fudge the health standards. Today, noncompliance means the failure to keep the average ozone level below 120 parts per billion for more than one hour on more than one day a year. Raising the averaging period to a full day, along with allowing four or five noncompliance days a year, would effectively double the permissible level of ozone.
This approach is untidy and a bit cynical. But, then, democracy has always been untidy. And unless you can imagine members of Congress publicly debating whether asthmatics should be asked to stay indoors on heavy smog days, cynicism is probably the order of the day.

HEADLINE: Nasdaq Posts Another Rise; Dow Retreats

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq rose for the fourth consecutive session yesterday, lifted by a rally in computer issues.
But the Dow Jones industrial average fell 29.07 points, to 6,499.34, as investors took profits before the Thanksgiving holiday. It was the Dow's first two-day losing streak in more than a month. Even with the two-day drop of nearly 50 points, the Dow is up about 470 points, or 7.8 percent, in November. 
 The stock market is closed today for Thanksgiving and will reopen tomorrow for an abbreviated session, ending at 1 P.M.
Stocks started the session lower as the bond market slipped from an early rally that briefly pulled interest rates back down toward their lowest level since early March.
But bonds pulled back amid a flurry of economic data suggesting a faster pace of business activity.
The indications of rising consumer demand eroded some of the widespread confidence that the economy was slowing enough to keep the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates to keep inflation in check.
"There's an awful lot of anticipation factored into the slow-growth scenario and a non-Fed intervention environment," said Ned Riley, chief investment officer for the Bank of Boston. "Any announcement to the converse will have an adverse effect on the bond market."
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a 13-to-11 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 377.8 million shares , down sharply from Tuesday's heavy pace of 540.5 million.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.96 point, to 755.00, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.50, to 397.48.
But the Nasdaq composite index, which is dominated by technology and smaller companies, rose 6.12 points, to 1,287.32.
Intel rose 2 5/8, to 126 5/8, as the Nasdaq's most active issue, and Microsoft rose 1 3/4, to 155 1/2.
Other computing issues gained. International Business Machines edged up 1/8, to 158 1/8; Micron gained 1 1/8, to 33 1/4; Bay Network rose 1 1/2, to 26 5/8, and McAfee Associates surged 4, to 49. Texas Instruments rose 2 7/8, to 63 3/4, after Salomon Brothers raised its opinion on the stock, and America Online rose 2 1/4, to 34 7/8, after an upgrade from Cowen & Company.
Oil shares were among the Dow's weakest components amid worries that the potential return of Iraqi crude to the world supply would lower prices, which are currently at the highest level in years. Texaco fell 1 5/8, to 98 7/8; Chevron fell 1 1/2, to 66 5/8, and Exxon fell 1 1/8, to 93 3/4.
The Dow's biggest decliner was Disney, which gave back most of Tuesday's rally on a strong earnings report, falling 2 1/8, to 73 7/8.
Vacation Break jumped 6, to 16 3/4, after agreeing to merge with Berkley Group, a privately held developer and marketer of time-share resort properties in Florida and Virginia.
Armor All Products rose 1 25/64, to 18 57/64 a day after Clorox said it would buy the company for $408 million in cash, or $19.09 a share,
Shares of Conrail Inc. declined by 3/8, to 96 1/2, after The Wall Street Journal reported the purchase of the company. Whether by CSX or Norfolk Southern, the purchase is already facing stronger-than-expected opposition.

HEADLINE: Philip Birnbaum, 89, Builder Celebrated for His Efficiency

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Philip Birnbaum, the almost anonymous architectural hand behind many of the most imposing apartment towers in New York City, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.
Unlike his contemporary, Philip Johnson, Mr. Birnbaum enjoyed no public celebrity and little critical acclaim; "banal" was among the kinder words used to describe his work. But his output exceeded that of Mr. Johnson -- and just about any other architect in recent decades -- and his buildings are familiar to New Yorkers, even if they do not know who gets the credit. 
 What made him so popular among developers was the efficiency of his apartment layouts. There was virtually no wasted floor space in his units, meaning that builders could fit more apartments on a floor. Because he tried to eliminate interior hallways, occupants also got more usable room. He said he designed for the people who lived in his buildings, not the elite.
Among some 300 buildings designed by Mr. Birnbaum, alone or in association with others, were One Lincoln Plaza, also known as the Ascap Building, at Broadway and 63d Street (1971); the Galleria, 119 East 57th Street (1975); 1001 Fifth Avenue, near 82d Street (1979); the Hotel Parker Meridien, 118 West 57th Street (1981); and, cater-corner across Third Avenue, the Savoy, 200 East 61st Street (1986) and Trump Plaza, 167 East 61st Street (1984).
"Most people don't know Philip Birnbaum, yet he probably designed more buildings in New York than anyone else," Donald J. Trump said yesterday. "Not all were great but they all made money. And some were, in fact, very good."
"Whereas many people would design a building from the outside in, he would design a building from the inside out," Mr. Trump said, adding that Mr. Birnbaum was responsible for the apartment plans in Trump Tower.
Layouts were not his only trademark. Mr. Birnbaum also counted the rooftop swimming pool among his innovations. His daughter, Dara Birnbaum, a video artist in Manhattan who originally followed her father into architecture, said the idea was that "people need to have their own open space, even in a city of high-rises."
"He would say, 'Let's use the roofs for the common good,' " Ms. Birnbaum said. She traced this concern to a youth spent in railroad tenements so dark he would study outside by streetlight.
Mr. Birnbaum grew up in Washington Heights, attended Stuyvesant High School and earned his architectural degree at Columbia. He was accepted at Princeton but was cautioned in a letter from the university that, as a "Hebrew," he might not fit into the environment. Mr. Birnbaum carried that letter around for many years, his daughter said.
In the building boom following World War II, Mr. Birnbaum did a great deal of work in Forest Hills and Kew Gardens, Queens, much of it for the developer Alfred L. Kaskel. Over the years, his practice was known as Philip Birnbaum, the Office of Philip Birnbaum or Philip Birnbaum & Associates.
For Mr. Kaskel, Mr. Birnbaum designed the Doral Beach Hotel in Miami Beach and the Doral Country Club in Miami, but most of his major projects were in Manhattan. The 47-story Excelsior, at 303 East 57th Street, was for a time New York's tallest apartment building.
Other significant apartment towers included 45 East 89th Street, at Madison Avenue; Manhattan Place, 630 First Avenue, at 36th Street; the Bromley, 225 West 83d Street; Le Chambord, 350 East 72d Street; the Promenade, 530 East 76th Street and the Horizon, 415 East 37th Street.
Whatever the merits of his layouts, Mr. Birnbaum's facades typically had few distinguishing features, reflecting developers' quest for economy. Plain in material and monotonous in composition, the effect could be particularly deadening since the towers tended to be so large.
There were some notable departures, like the swooping, boomerang-shaped Trump Plaza, on the west side of Third Avenue. When Mr. Birnbaum was commissioned by another developer to build a tower on the east side of the avenue, he saw an opportunity to create a monumental gateway and designed a near twin. But Mr. Trump sued and won a settlement in which the design of the Savoy was modified. In recent years, his health failing, Mr. Birnbaum curtailed his practice, although he continued to work as a consultant.
Besides his daughter, he is survived by a son, Dr. Robert J. Birnbaum, of Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: Administration Issues Its Proposal For Tightening of Air Standards

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today proposed tighter air quality standards for the nation, saying that children, asthmatics, people who work outdoors and the frail elderly needed more protection from choking smog and soot and that the health and economic benefits would vastly outweigh the costs of new pollution controls.
The proposal, issued by the Environmental Protection Agency, had been widely anticipated and has already prompted vigorous debate. Industry groups criticized it today as unnecessary and very costly, while environmental and public health organizations were largely supportive but said it was too weak in some details. 
 The change sought by the environmental agency is certain to be among the most disputed in years. And in announcing it, Carol M. Browner, the E.P.A. Administrator, defended it as based squarely on health considerations and the best available science.
"The scientific evidence tells us that the current standards fail to provide adequate public health protection, especially for children," Ms. Browner said. "The question is not one of science. The question is one of judgment: Whom do we protect?"
The agency plans to decide next summer, after a period of public comment that began with its action today, whether to take its final step and adopt the new standards. Even that adoption would be subject to review, however, both in Congress and in the courts.
In effect, the environmental agency is seeking to change its definition of what counts as healthful air, as measured by the ozone and the tiny chemical particles that shroud many cities in haze. Those pollutants can exacerbate asthma, bronchitis and other lung ailments.
The new rules are intended in part to protect people who are exposed to lower levels of ozone than levels allowable under the current rules, and for more hours at a time. That change would better reflect the latest scientific understanding of the health risks posed by ozone, an irritant gas that is a main component of smog.
As for particulates -- complex mixtures of noxious chemicals suspended in the air -- the new rules would count particles far smaller than the size now being controlled. Again, the new focus is on controlling pollutants that present the worst health risks; smaller particles lodge deepest in the lungs.
One of the new standards calls for the air to contain no more than 80 parts of ozone per billion, measured over eight-hour periods. Cities would be permitted to exceed that limit several times over a three-year period without being found in violation, under a new enforcement formula intended to avoid haphazard instances of violations that occur in unusual circumstances, like weather conditions that occasionally trap smog in place.
The new standard for particulate matter is more complex, calling for particles less than 2.5 microns in diameter to be held below 50 micrograms per cubic meter as a daily average and 15 micrograms per cubic meter as an annual average. Here, too, the daily standard could be exceeded occasionally without violation.
As with other Federal clean-air mandates, the states would be responsible for writing plans to bring themselves into compliance, which they would achieve by imposing controls on various sources of pollution, largely factories and automobiles. Ultimately, then, the cost would be borne by industry.
Changing the definition of healthful air would throw hundreds of counties out of compliance with the Clean Air Act. And the E.P.A. estimated today that taking the additional steps needed to meet the goals would cost between $6.6 billion and $8.5 billion a year for at least a decade..
But the benefits, the agency estimated, would be even greater: between $51 billion and $112 billion a year, mostly in the form of reduced medical costs and lower absenteeism from school and work, but also because tens of thousands of premature deaths might be averted each year.
The agency said the new standard for fine particles would cut premature deaths linked to particulate air pollution by 50 percent, or approximately 20,000 deaths a year, and would reduce the number of asthma attacks aggravated by this kind of pollution by a quarter of a million episodes a year.
Chronic bronchitis would be reduced by 60,000 cases a year, the number of hospital admissions for breathing difficulties would drop by 9,000 a year, and haze and visibility problems in some areas, including national parks, would drop by more than three-fourths, the agency predicted.
The new ozone standard, meanwhile, would result in 1.5 million fewer cases of breathing problems in which lung function is reduced as much as 20 percent, the agency said. This in turn would mean fewer hospital admissions, visits to emergency rooms and missed days at school or work, and would cut down on the need for medication or other treatment for asthmatic children. The agency also estimated that the change would reduce by nearly $1 billion the losses of agricultural crops from damage caused by ozone.
Ms. Browner, the E.P.A. Administrator, estimated that 70 percent of the communities that would not now meet the new standards could do so in 10 years or so, using pollution control approaches either currently planned or already available. As an example, she cited new pollution control canisters that are planned for automobiles starting in 1998.
Under the Clean Air Act, air quality standards for ozone and particulate matter are supposed to be set solely on the basis of protecting health, without taking costs into account. How the standards can be attained, and at what expense, is considered later, when states draw up detailed plans to meet the goals.
But industry groups are already calling the new standards impossible to meet at any realistic price, and challenging the scientific basis for the rules.
"The E.P.A.'s proposal isn't based on sound scientific research," said Owen Drey, an environmental specialist at the National Association of Manufacturers, which is coordinating a broad assault by industry on the proposal. "The restrictions the new, more stringent standards will have on business expansion and start-up will have a chilling effect on economic growth in this country."
David Hawkins, an air pollution specialist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, called the proposal "an important step in improving public health protection."
Mr. Hawkins said the environmental group would ask the agency to alter some of the technical provisions, including those that allow repeated violations of some of the standards. "Seven strikes and you're out," he said, "seems like an excessive number of strikes."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "SORTING IT OUT: Understanding the Ozone and Particulate Pollution Standards"
 
OZONE -- A highly irritating, colorless gas that is the main component of smog. It is formed by reactions between nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons in the atmosphere. Near the ground, ozone is a serious pollutant, not to be confused with the stratospheric ozone layer that protects the earth from ultraviolet radiation.
 EXISTING STANDARDS -- Ozone should not be allowed to exceed 120 parts per billion in the air for one hour.
 PROPOSED STANDARDS -- Would limit this kind of pollution to 80 parts per billion over an eight-hour period.
 
PARTICULATE MATTER -- These complex mixtures of particles and vapors can be emitted directly into the air or are formed in the atmosphere when chemicals like hydrocarbons, sulfur oxides and nitrogen oxides combine.
 EXISTING STANDARDS -- Limited to 10 microns in diameter or less (a human hair is about 70 microns thick), to no more than 150 micrograms per cubic meter of air measured daily and an annual average of no more than 50 micrograms per cubic meter.
 PROPOSED STANDARDS -- Would limit smaller particles, of 2.5 microns or less, to concentrations of 50 micrograms per cubic meter daily and 15 micrograms per cubic meter annually.
 
HEALTH EFFECTS -- Ozone and fine particles can both damage lung tissues and aggravate existing respiratory diseases, such as asthma and bronchitis. Children, outdoor workers, and the frail elderly could be especially at risk from breathing polluted air.
 
WHERE IT COMES FROM -- Hydrocarbons like the volatile organic compounds that evaporate from petroleum products and nitrogen oxides that come from burning fossil fuels can form into both ozone and particulate matter. There are many other sources of particulate matter, and both types of pollution come generally from combustion of fuels by power plants, factories, and automobiles. (pg. B20)

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES;
A Meal With Family Alleviates the Burden For a Dying Man

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Sheila Dean will not say, not out loud, why Thanksgiving is so special this year. She will hint at the reason, whisper about it. For Anthony Dean, the man she lives with and plans to marry and whose name she has already taken, there will be no Thanksgiving next year, the doctors say.
Mr. Dean is dying of cancer. With luck, he will see Christmas, maybe his 57th birthday in January. Sitting in the half light of their downtown Brooklyn apartment, Sheila Dean silently mouthed the words, "I don't know if he is going to live." 
 Today is the last holiday he can count on, perhaps the last chance to gather his daughters and grandson around a table. His brother, Zachary, whom he has not seen in more than 30 years, promised to come from Kentucky.
But the Deans could not afford Thanksgiving dinner.
Together, they receive a little more than $1,000 a month in Social Security disability payments, but it is not enough. After rent for their apartment in the Raymond V. Ingersoll Houses and other bills, there is barely money for food. His health insurance is limited, and there is a $1,144.59 pharmacy bill they cannot pay.
Their apartment is cluttered with medicine bottles. Doctors' phone numbers are on stickers close to the phone. An unwinning lottery ticket lies on a night table. "We get the groceries, and when you get into the third or fourth week, things start running out," Ms. Dean said.
On Tuesday, with the help of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which begins its 85th annual appeal on Sunday, the Catholic Charities of Brooklyn and Queens gave Ms. Dean $20 for a turkey. Catholic Charities, one of seven agencies supported by the fund, also gave a basketful of trimmings and help with the medical bills.
This year, the average Thanksgiving feast costs $3.17 a person, according to the American Farm Bureau Federation, which surveys shoppers nationwide each year to track the cost of a meal that includes turkey, stuffing, cranberries, sweet potatoes, rolls, peas and pumpkin pie.
As meals go these days, $3.17 -- roughly $32 for a family of 10 -- does not sound like a lot. But it is beyond the means of thousands of New Yorkers. They are sick or homeless, elderly or orphaned, unemployed or just down on their luck. Like Mr. Dean, many are proud people, more accustomed to giving charity than seeking it.
"You can thank God that you have each other," Mr. Dean said the other day. "You shouldn't even ask for anything else. Sometimes, we have just one can of soup. We eat together and we have more fun with that one bowl than we'd have with a whole chicken. I'll say, 'Get out of my bowl, that's my noodle. Put my piece back.' We have so much fun."
Despite Mr. Dean's willingness to make the best of his lot, Ms. Dean, who is 42, knew the thought of not being able to provide the holiday dinner was bothering him. "He's from the old school," she said, calling him her soul mate. "He's a manly man. He has a sense of responsibility."
Her sense of urgency overtaking her pride, she called Cindy Blumenthal, a social worker at Brooklyn Hospital, who had offered help if they ever needed it. "I'm calling you on your word," Ms. Dean said. Ms. Blumenthal referred the Deans to Catholic Charities.
Today, in soup kitchens and homeless shelters, in community centers and private homes, thousands of needy New Yorkers will eat Thanksgiving dinners provided in an annual ritual of kindness that begins the most crucial weeks of the year for social service organizations relying on charitable donations. Statistics show that the holiday season is even more vital to charities than it is to retail businesses.
According to the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel, charities raise about 31 percent of their annual receipts between Oct. 1 and the year's end. In retail, 27 percent of the year's revenues come during that final quarter, according to the National Retail Federation.
Among those charities is The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which since 1912 has supported some of the city's largest social service agencies in offering a hand to New Yorkers who need one. The Times pays the fund's overhead, so all donations go to services.
Across New York, where despair is matched blow for blow by hope, the Deans are far from alone: At the Children's Aid Society's Dunlevy Milbank Community Center in Harlem, 700 people will eat more than 100 turkeys donated by many of the city's largest hotels and prepared under the supervision of Ron Roccasecca, the chef at the New York Sheraton Hotel and Towers.
About 500 meals are to be served at the El Greco Diner on Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. On Staten Island, five children at Geller House, a way station run by the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services for adolescents headed into foster care, will eat dinner together. Among them is a 15-year-old boy who thought he had been saved years ago when he was adopted by his foster mother in Queens, only to lose her to cancer and wind up back in the child welfare system, shuffling from home to home.
Some dinners were held early, like one last Thursday at the Waverly Day Care Center run by the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, where youngsters from Fort Greene and Clinton Hill were taught the holiday's lessons of charity and goodwill.
"The Pilgrims cook food for the Indians, then they have a big feast and they eat the food together and they share," explained Duvon Murph, 5. "The Indians help show the Pilgrims how to hunt and make clothes out of animal skin, and then they sell it on the ship and they sailed over the great blue sea."
More than 94 percent of households who give to human service charities reported doing so because they were asked, according to the Fund-Raising Counsel's Trust for Philanthropy. There is no solicitation for the Neediest Cases Fund, meaning it relies solely on readers of articles in the newspaper.
The articles, chronicling the city's needy and their benefactors, appear throughout the appeal, which ends Feb. 28.
Like Anthony Dean, many people who are assisted by the fund had always relied on their own resources. Mr. Dean worked all his life at Tocci Brothers, a garbage hauler in Brooklyn. He rode the trucks and worked in the plant, doing trash separation and recycling, consistently winning promotions. He was a supervisor of 25 workers when he was forced to quit after heart surgery a year ago.
He still wears his blue work shirt, his nickname "Shorty" embroidered on it in white script, and he misses working more than he can say. He likes to boast that there wasn't a machine he couldn't fix.
"I think everybody should have a job," he said. "And see what it is to lose it."
Sheila Dean once dreamed of breeding dogs and raising horses and of becoming a veterinarian. She studied at the Brooklyn campus of Long Island University and at Medgar Evers College, but congestive heart failure left her unable to work, unable to pursue her dream, she said.
Mr. Dean had hoped to return to work after his bypass operation. But last month, doctors at Brooklyn Hospital Center found a tumor between his ribs -- inoperable liver cancer, they said -- and gave him two or three months to live. Now, the pain in his side often makes him double over.
Sometimes, Ms. Dean tries to borrow money from friends, which makes Mr. Dean angry.
"That's why I want a part-time job," he shouted.
Mr. Dean is a short, slightly built man, bald with a wisp of a beard. His moods swing from anger and depression about his terminal illness to gratitude for his caretakers to worry and concern about "his baby," as he calls Ms. Dean. Often, it is not easy.
"You have to take the good with the bad, the sour with the sweet," Ms. Dean said.
"Hey," Mr. Dean interjected, "even if I take you to the movies and I can't buy you no popcorn, at least I still let you rub my head, don't I?"
They are planning to marry in January, sometime near Mr. Dean's birthday, Jan. 8.
"If God spares my life," he said.
At the Dean home tonight, the menu includes Ms. Dean's secret-recipe potato salad, yams and baked macaroni with extra cheese. Mr. Dean said he would bake corn bread, and he listed the desserts.
"Apple pie, ice cream, sodas, apple juice, you know, things kids like," he said. "And each other. If it's going to be my last Thanksgiving, I want it to be a nice one."

HEADLINE: A World Fed Up With Bribes;
Nations Begin Following U.S. Curbs on Corruption

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Almost 20 years after the United States became the only country to prohibit its corporations from bribing foreign officials to win contracts, the rest of the world may finally be ready to act against bribes and corruption in business deals.
In recent months, international development funds, economic alliances and the International Chamber of Commerce have all taken steps to curb corruption. 
 The World Bank has begun spot audits of its development loan programs, which last year disbursed $19 billion, and instituted procurement rules that empower it to investigate corruption complaints and to blacklist companies and governments guilty of large-scale graft.
The 28 democracies in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development have committed themselves to ending the practice of letting businesses deduct foreign bribes, often reported as commissions or fees, from income taxes.
And the International Monetary Fund has made "tackling corruption" an economic priority, authorizing its managing director, Michel Camdessus, to press for anti-corruption reforms in borrowing countries.
"The ministry of finance will no longer be able tell the I.M.F. this is none of your business," Mr. Camdessus said.
These actions, after decades of indifference to the issue by Japan, Europe and the international loan funds, are in part the result of pressure from the United States, whose corporations complain that restrictions in the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977 cost them billions of dollars in business every year.
American companies refuse to name contracts they have lost because they would not pay bribes, or the countries and governments involved, certain that doing so would bar them from any work there.
But many are sure they are losing business because of the ban. "We are highly vulnerable to bribery because of the size of the orders our members get" said Joel L. Johnson, vice president of the Aerospace Industries Association, a Washington-based organization representing manufacturers of civilian and military aircraft, radar and other airport equipment. "We've taken some considerable hits around the world."
International concern about corrupt practices is following a rising tide of scandal, and growing evidence in many countries of public disgust with corrupt officials and institutions. From South Korea to India, from Italy and France to Venezuela and Brazil, scandals have forced politicians from office and sent executives to jail.
"The tide is definitely turning," said Peter Eigen, the head of Transparency International, a group devoted to fighting business corruption, financed in part by American corporations. "We don't know whether corruption is getting worse, but we do know it is not being tolerated as it was."
Mr. Eigen, who left the World Bank to found his organization because of the corruption he saw in developing countries, called the bank's stand "revolutionary," saying, "In the past the bank shied away from the corruption issue because it looked like interference in a country's domestic affairs."
No one knows how much corruption there is in the business world, or to what extent it is increasing. Many experts say it is probably growing with the world economy and with the leap in foreign direct investment in emerging economies, to $167 billion last year from $44 billion in 1990.
Bribery and kickbacks have become common in former Communist countries as they embrace free enterprise. The spread of democracy can create new incentives for corruption as competing political parties seek campaign contributions. In the third world, some development projects may be more valuable for their graft opportunities than their direct benefits.
"My own commercial experience, spanning 30 years and 5 continents, convinces me it is a far more serious and damaging problem than it was even 10 years ago," the British businessman George Moody-Stuart wrote last year in his book "Grand Corruption in Third World Development."
At the same time, corporations have great incentive to go along with bribe solicitations: contracts worth tens or hundreds of millions of dollars for military supplies, aircraft, civil works and communications. In a 1995 report, Mickey Kanton, then the United States trade representative, said American companies lost $45 billion of overseas contracts the previous year because of the bribery ban.
That report did not disclose the names of corporations or countries, either. It is based on a study that used the resources of the Central Intelligence Agency and is classified.
The American law, however, resulted in part from a Senate investigation from 1975 to 1977 of the Lockheed Corporation, now Lockheed Martin, which was found to have paid $22 million in bribes to win aircraft orders. In 1995, the company pleaded guilty under the act to new charges, admitting that an executive paid an Egyptian official to assure the purchase of three C-130 cargo planes.
Other experts point to forces that are making the public less tolerant of corruption, ranging from its increased visibility to a better understanding of its cost.
The end of the cold war, for example, has freed democracies from having to tolerate graft-ridden regimes to keep them in the Western camp, argued Moses Naim, a former Venezuelan trade and industry minister who is now director of Latin American studies at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
The spread of free-market economics, he said, is making "government decisions more transparent, increasing the accountability of public officials and reducing the impunity that has often accompanied the corruption of those in high places."
The World Bank and International Monetary Fund have their own motivation for acting: the perception that much development money ends up in Swiss bank accounts can make governments reluctant to vote aid. But as both agencies this year, for the first time, declared corruption the enemy of development, they also had new evidence. A 1995 study by an I.M.F. economist, Paul Mauro, forcefully concluded that corruption reduces growth.
"In country after country, it is the people who are demanding action on this issue," the World Bank president, James D. Wolfensohn, said. "They know corruption diverts resources from the poor to the rich, increases the cost of running businesses, distorts public expenditures and deters foreign investors."
Corruption has become a government-toppling issue in many countries. In South Korea, where two former presidents, Chun Doo Hwan and Rho Tae Woo, were convicted this year for the coup with which they took power in 1979; they were also convicted of taking hundreds of millions in bribes from companies, including Samsung, Daewoo and Hyundai.
In Japan, payment scandals in the 1980's brought down both Prime Minister Noburu Takeshita and the chairman of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone. Then, in 1994, Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa resigned amid allegations of payments from a trucking company and N.T.T.
In Europe, corruption charges brought down Ireland's Prime Minister, Charles Haughey, in 1992 and Italy's Prime Minister, Silvio Berlusconi, in 1995. Italians now call Milan, their business capital, Tangentopoli: "kickback city."
Transparency International has created a Corruption Perception Index for 54 countries, based on a "poll of polls" of 10 surveys by organizations like DRI/McGraw Hill Global Risk Service and the Institute for Management Development, based in Lausanne, Switzerland, that ask executives how corrupt they perceived countries to be.
The 1996 index shows that New Zealand is perceived by the business community as being the least corrupt, scoring 9.43 on a scale of 10.00. Most corrupt is Nigeria, scoring only 0.69, followed by Pakistan, Kenya, Bangladesh and China.
The United States, where an Indonesian business family's influence in the White House became an issue during President Clinton's re-election campaign, is 15th on the index, with a score of 7.66, higher than Japan, France and Belgium, but lower than Israel, Britain, Germany and Singapore.
Many of the gains in attacking corruption, meanwhile, are due to the Clinton Administration finally making headway in its campaign to create a level playing field for American companies, which complain that the 1977 ban on bribery puts them at a disadvantage to foreign rivals who are free to buy contracts from corrupt ministers.
This year the United States became the 23d of the Organization of American States' 34 members to sign a convention that has been under negotiation since the Miami Summit of the Americas in May 1994, outlawing cross-border bribery and the "illicit enrichment" of officials in the hemisphere. It also helps in the investigation of bribery charges and speeds extradition procedures.
So far only Paraguay has ratified the convention as well as signed it. But only two countries need to ratify the agreement for it to become binding on all who have signed it.
Unlike the Bush Administration, which had shown little interest in the subject, the Clinton Administration set a high priority on securing international action against bribery and corruption as soon as it took office.
In May 1994, the United States prodded a reluctant Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development into setting up a working group to draft an anti-corruption proposal that would include criminalizing bribery and ending the tax deductibility of bribes.
After successfully tackling the deductibility issue, Mark Pieth, the working group's Swiss chairman, is now seeking an agreement to make the bribery of foreign officials a crime in time for next May's annual ministerial meeting. That meeting will also receive a report on compliance with this year's agreement to end the tax deductibility of bribes.
Some powerful private business groups are also throwing their weight behind the American campaign. Last March, the International Chamber of Commerce approved revised rules of conduct for its thousands of member companies and business associations that prohibit bribes and encourage them to press their governments to adopt the proposed O.E.C.D. anti-bribery convention.
But a new study of those negotiations by Mr. Naim of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, in collaboration with Patrick Glynn of the American Enterprise Institute and Stephen J. Kobrin of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, says many European countries remain only reluctant supporters of the American initiative. It concludes that "achieving the needed legal reforms in Europe -- and perhaps even more in Asia -- will mean a prolonged and hard fight."

HEADLINE: Trial Ends In Hung Jury In '81 Killing Of a Surgeon

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
A gunshot during a botched robbery ended the life of a young surgeon on a Manhattan street, and the city recoiled from the senseless waste. But public attention is fleeting, and interest in the shooting faded almost as quickly as the echoes of the shot that killed Dr. John Wood in 1981.
For years the case remained unsolved. But a detective, Gennaro Giorgio, kept pursuing it patiently. Finally, in 1994, he arrested a suspect. The man, an unemployed janitor named Patrick McDowell, was charged with the murder of Dr. Wood. The arrest, after the 13-year lapse, drew press interest across the country. 
 Mr. McDowell's trial ended yesterday. But the long and painful case is still not over. The jury was deadlocked and could not reach a verdict, and the District Attorney plans to try the case again.
In the last week, jurors in State Supreme Court in Manhattan were asked to peer back over 15 years to the crime. The difficulties were formidable. Witnesses have died or moved away. Evidence has been lost. Memories have shifted or faded. But the prosecution thought there was enough evidence to convict Mr. McDowell, a man who has spent 10 of the last 15 years in prison for killing a woman during a robbery.
But after two and a half days of deliberations, jurors could not reach a verdict on the charge of felony murder. The jury acquitted Mr. McDowell on the second charge against him, intentional murder. The difference in the charges lies in intent: felony murder involves killing another person in the course of a robbery or other felony, whether or not the killer intended to do so.
After jury members repeatedly said they could not reach a verdict, Justice Edwin Torres declared a mistrial. Besides saying that a retrial was planned, a spokeswoman for District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau declined to comment further on the case.
Mr. McDowell, who has spent two years and four months in jail awaiting trial, was returned to prison to await the retrial, expected early next year. His lawyer, Francis Karam, said he would request that his client be freed on bail.
"I am disappointed it was a hung jury," Mr. Karam said. "I did not think there was enough evidence to convict."
The prosecution's case was based on statements that Mr. McDowell made to the police in several interviews in 1982 and 1994, as well as the testimony of two people who said that the defendant confessed to them. There was no physical evidence linking Mr. McDowell to the shooting. Eyewitness testimony, while inconclusive, seemed to give support to the defense's contention that someone else committed the murder.
Detective Giorgio, a 36-year veteran of the police force, testified that Mr. McDowell told him that another man had committed the murder. But he said that Mr. McDowell admitted obtaining a gun for the man before the robbery in which the doctor was killed. The man who supplied the gun, Glenn Richardson, testified that Mr. McDowell admitted that he shot Dr. Wood.
The prosecution's third witness, Angela Spenser, testified that Mr. McDowell admitted to the killing during a chance meeting several years later.
However, the defense made much of the fact that Mr. Richardson, a convicted drug dealer, was testifying in exchange for a lesser Federal prison sentence. Mr. Karam, the defense lawyer, also pointed out that Ms. Spenser, an admitted crack addict, told the police of her conversation with Mr. McDowell after she was picked up in a drug sweep. Ms. Spenser was not charged with any crime.
The defense presented an alibi that Mr. McDowell was home with his girlfriend, who later became his wife, the night of the robbery. Carmella McDowell, who is now an executive secretary, testified that Mr. McDowell was with her when the shooting occurred.
Mr. Karam said his client has not been offered a plea bargain by the District Attorney's office since the jury's decision. He said his client maintained his innocence.
"From the first day he has told me he was innocent, and he has never said anything different," Mr. Karam said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Computer Stocks Rally, But Dow Declines 29.07
The Nasdaq market gained for the fourth consecutive session, lifted by a rally in computer issues that sent its index up 6.12 points, to 1,287.32.
The Dow Jones industrial average, in its first two-day losing streak in more than a month, slid 29.07 points, to 6,499.34, as Disney and oil shares fell with investors taking profits before the Thanksgiving holiday. [Page D7.]
 
The prices of Treasury securities rose in a shortened session, bolstered by a surge in the dollar against the Japanese yen. The 30-year bond gained 7/32, to 1011/32, pushing its yield down to 6.42 percent. [D13.]
 
Economic Growth Revised to 2%
The economy's growth was just slightly slower in the third quarter than initially estimated -- 2 percent versus 2.2 percent -- the Commerce Department said. Also, orders for durable goods rose one-tenth of 1 percent in October, suggesting that the nation is continuing to enjoy modest growth and low inflation. [D4.]
 
AT&T Upsets Japanese Competitors
AT&T upset Japanese competitors by offering to provide discount international calls to Japanese customers, using a technique known as call-back service to make calls technically originate in America, where rates are lower. Some countries prohibit the technique, and AT&T itself once condemned it as unfair. [D3.]
 
Cardinal Health to Buy Owen
Cardinal Health said it would buy Owen Healthcare for $27.25 a share, or $496 million, in stock. By combining Owen's pharmacy management services with its own drug distribution network, Cardinal intends to broaden the services it offers hospitals. [D2.]
 
In an Accord, Technology Before Art
Hollywood directors and cinematographers are conspicuously unhappy with this week's landmark agreement on digital television by the computer, broadcasting and consumer electronics industries. Despite aggressive lobbying by directors like Steven Spielberg, the film makers fear that their movie images will be cropped to fit TV screens. [D2.]
 
Environmental Rules Sought
The Clinton Administration proposed tighter air quality standards, saying that children, asthmatics, people who work outdoors and the frail elderly needed more protection from choking smog and soot. Industry groups criticized the proposals, which had been expected, as unnecessary and costly, while environmental groups were supportive. [A1.]
 
Economists find the E.P.A.'s new standards problematic in that they lump together the strong case for reducing particulates and the relatively weak case against tightening the air quality standards for ozone.
Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
 
L.A. Gear Announces Cutbacks
L.A. Gear said that it would cut 170 jobs, or 55 percent of its work force, and that its president, William L. Benford, would leave. It also plans other cost cuts and will take a charge of $28 million to $33 million. [D6.]
 
A Scurry to Save Canadian Airlines
Canadian Government, union and airline officials are scrambling to keep heavily indebted Canadian Airlines International, the country's No. 2 carrier, in the air. [D2.]
 
Negotiations on Indonesian Gold
Bre-X Minerals Ltd., which is allied with President Suharto's eldest son, is in talks ordered by the Indonesian Government to sell 75 percent of its $4.44 billion gold deposit on the island of Borneo to Barrick Gold of Toronto, which is linked indirectly to the President's eldest daughter. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Miami Looks to State for Fiscal Oversight

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Gov. Lawton Chiles is considering whether to establish state financial oversight of the City of Miami after being told by the Mayor that its fiscal problems were dire enough for such a step.
Reeling from a corruption scandal and a huge budget deficit attributed to mismanagement, Miami faces a state declaration of financial emergency that could result in Florida's first appointment of a state board to oversee a city's finances. 
 In a meeting with the Governor on Tuesday night, the Mayor, Joe Carollo, said the city had to deal with a larger budget deficit than the $68 million previously identified, although he gave no specific amount. Mr. Carollo said recurring deficits were now estimated at $50 million a year instead of $30 million.
The Mayor did not return calls to his office today. But state officials said they were reviewing the situation to determine whether they should invoke a state law that would give the state authority to impose a number of measures, including requiring the Governor's approval of the city budget, banning the city from issuing bonds and setting up a "financial emergencies" board to oversee city government.
Although the state has stepped in to help other fiscally troubled local governments in the past, Robert Bradley, Florida's Budget Director, said an oversight board had never been appointed but was contemplated for Miami because of the "size and complexity" of its problems.
A determination of a fiscal emergency could also be a step toward seeking Federal bankruptcy protection, but state and city officials said today that it was too early to tell whether such a move was feasible.
"Bankruptcy is an end of a process, Mr. Bradley said, "and we're right at the beginning."
Reaction to the news was swift and largely critical of the Mayor and the four other members of the City Commission, who are widely seen as trying to pass off responsibility for such decisions as raising fees for city services to help close the budget gap. The news also does not bode well for the re-election prospects next year for Mayor Carollo and two other commissioners. There is already a movement among angry residents to abolish the city and have its government taken over by Dade County.
One of the nation's bond rating services, Standard & Poor's, downgraded Miami's debt rating today for the second time since the fiscal crisis was first reported last September, this time giving it a noninvestment grade of single B. In a written statement, the service cited Miami's "limited progress to date in addressing its significant budgetary imbalance" and pointedly noted the recent postponement of a Commission vote on doubling garbage collection fees.
"You have a city in severe financial crisis, and the fact that they can't come together to implement a garbage fee is just unacceptable from a credit point of view," said Robin Prunty, a spokeswoman for Standard & Poor's in New York.
Dario Moreno, a political science professor at Florida International University said: "No one has the courage to do what is necessary, so the easy way out is to have someone impose it on them."
Yet in a letter to city officials last week, Governor Chiles warned that "solving your problem responsibly within the city government is a far better solution" than having the state take over.
A Miami Commissioner, Wilfredo Gort, agreed that the city had not done all it could and called Mayor Carollo's assessment "premature."
"I'm ready to bite the bullet," said Mr. Gort, one of two Commissioners who have said they would vote to increase fees. "We're elected to make decisions."
But a supporter of the Mayor, Commissioner Tomas Regalado, argued that other options, like layoffs and collecting garbage fees from those who do not pay them now, should be considered before "a step to burden poor people" like raising fees is taken.
The Miami Herald quoted Mayor Carollo today as saying that a state oversight board worked for New York City, which was at the brink of bankruptcy in the 1970's before the State Financial Control Board imposed fiscal austerity, "and look at New York -- it came back stronger than ever."
Miami's fiscal crisis came to light this past summer after the corruption scandal and subsequent resignations of several top city officials, including the city manager and the finance director. Dade County's tourism chief, who was brought in as an acting city manager to deal with the emergency, traced the budget deficit to loose financial controls and the comingling of funds. The official, Merrett R. Stierheim, presented a plan earlier this month on how the city could deal with the problem. In a report, Mr. Stierheim recommended such steps as raising fees, selling city properties and winning concessions from labor unions.
Mr. Stierheim, who has returned to his job promoting Miami and Dade County's 28 other cities as the president of the Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau, declined to comment today on the latest developments, saying his report spoke for itself.
Explaining his hopes for the city, Mayor Carollo told The Associated Press, "We need to rebuild Miami top to bottom and change the third world system that has been running this city for so long."

HEADLINE: By Plane, Car and Boat, a Holiday Is On

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Air fares, gasoline and hotel rooms are more expensive this year than last, and even turkeys will cost almost 8 percent more. But none of that will dampen the holiday spirit for millions of Americans this Thanksgiving, including a record 31.8 million who are expected to travel 100 miles or more from home over the four-day weekend.
That is not only 3 percent more travelers than last Thanksgiving, but it is the most in the 12 years that the American Automobile Association has been reporting such statistics. The Air Transport Association is also predicting a record 13.5 million passengers this week, up from 11.6 million last year. 
 On Sunday, the busiest single day of the year, the average flight is expected to be 80 percent filled. That compares with a 70.3 "load factor" through October of this year -- well on its way to eclipsing last year's 67.3 percent, the highest load factor in at least 50 years.
Passengers are advised to arrive at the airport at least two hours early for domestic flights, and three hours early for international flights.
An improving economy is helping spur the projected record travel, as are memories of last winter's blizzards and incesssant snowstorms over much of the country that made travel difficult, if not impossible. Now, travel industry officials say, people are determined to get away when they can.
James and Nancy Moeller of Phoenix flew to Portland last Monday, to board the Queen of the West for a seven-day cruise along rivers in Oregon, Washington and Idaho. It is the first inland river trip for Mr. Moeller, a Justice of the Arizona Supreme Court, and the first time in 35 years the Moellers will have been away on Thanksgiving. "But we won't be away from Thanksgiving dinner," Mrs. Moeller said, "because they're serving one on board."
Some 45 million turkeys will be consumed for Thanksgiving, said Stephanie Bergman of the National Turkey Federation -- even though the average price has increased to 84 cents a pound from 78 cents last year.
There are no comparable figures for pumpkin pies. But Marriott Management Services, which supplies corporate and college cafeterias with pies as well as other foods, discovered that in the past two years corporate employees and students were buying so many pumpkin and other holiday pies -- 105,000 last year -- that the company wound up with a surprise niche business.
For many employees, Thanksgiving is a four-day holiday, including the weekend, and that has greatly helped spur the record travel. According to the Bureau of National Affairs, a research and publishing company, 69 percent of employers are giving workers two days off for Thanksgiving, up 6 percent from last year. And with the trend in recent years to more and shorter vacations, four days are about all that many people need.
In recognition of that, and to fill planes at odd hours, a number of airlines offered special fares this year for Thanksgiving travelers who want to make a quick holiday trip. Delta Air Lines, for example, offered a variety of round trips from $96 (for example, between Memphis and Dallas/Fort Worth) to $196 (New York-Seattle), provided that return travel begins no later than tomorrow. American Airlines offered round trips from $88 (Chicago-Detroit) to $198 (Los Angeles-Miami), with return travel Thanksgiving Day or tomorrow. On average, though, the price of a domestic airline ticket has is almost 20 percent higher than it was last year.
Gasoline prices are 15.4 cents higher than they were a year ago, according to the automobile association, with self-serve regular unleaded at its highest price (averaging $1.28 a gallon) for a Thanksgiving holiday since 1990. And the nearly nine million travelers expected to stay in hotels this week (3 percent more than last year) will find room rates 6.6 percent higher, on average, at $71.48 a night.
Many Thanksgiving travelers are almost guaranteed to "waste time," at airports or on the open road. The automobile association has cited 10 of the worst major highway bottlenecks, places where motorists can expect big delays because of construction or obsolete roads.
These include Houston, where the single lane exiting U.S. 59 at the Interstate 610 Loop regularly causes stop-and-go conditions for up to six hours a day; I-5 in Los Angeles at the intersection with I-10, State Route 60 and State Route 101, where bottlenecks extend for miles, and the Gowanus Expressway in Brooklyn, where "significant delays" between the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel and the Belt Parkway occur for six or more hours on a typical day.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Holiday travelers were on the go yesterday at Union Station in Washington. The score: 31.8 million travelers, 45 million turkeys. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)
