HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
The National Pastime's True M.V.P.

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
A new baseball labor agreement was so elusive that it defied the intervention of President Clinton. Then Randy Levine came along.
In just one year on the job as the owners' chief negotiator, the Brooklyn-born grandson of two men who were union leaders succeeded where the President, Labor Secretary Robert Reich, John Calhoun Wells of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, the veteran mediator William J. Usery, Richard Ravitch, Bud Selig, John Harrington, Jerry McMorris and Charles O'Connor had failed. 
That is why Major League Baseball today is about to embark on an era of labor peace and, it expects, economic growth.
A few issues have to be cleared up before the union's executive board ratifies the new agreement next week. But it is highly unlikely that Levine would now encounter problems with Donald Fehr, the players' labor chief, after they made a breakthrough that, while not unprecedented, was unusual, and after the owners turned their repudiation of Levine into vindication.
"I don't look at it as I was repudiated or vindicated," Levine said yesterday before leaving with his wife, Mindy, for a holiday weekend in the country. "I look at it as the process was vindicated. Here is an agreement that will go on for the next five years that makes revolutionary changes."
The owners did not initially want to accept the changes, rejecting the agreement by an 18-12 vote. But three weeks later, at a meeting in Chicago on Tuesday, they embraced the agreement, 26-4, deciding that it was better to put their arms around something than to fill their heads and stomachs with more aches.
"I was very disappointed because I'm human," Levine said of the initial rejection. "Now I feel gratified to have been a part of solving this process and trying to restore baseball to where I think it belongs -- as the national pastime."
But why was Levine able to succeed where all of those others had failed? It was not a new experience for the 41-year-old lawyer, who likes to play golf, ride horses, stroll in the woods in Duchess County, where he and his wife spend weekends on their mini-farm. He also walks the streets of Manhattan when he takes his two Labradors out at 6 A.M. and midnight every day. After all, he came to his $600,000-a-year baseball job from his post as New York City's labor commissioner under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
"In my experience as a negotiator," Levine said, "most of my assignments have been in extraordinarily tough situations where people thought things couldn't change and where often other people hadn't been able to get the job done through no fault of their own. I guess it's just a certain style I have. I try to view collective bargaining as problem solving, not as winning or losing, not about hurting the next guy. It's about industries where people have to work together. I always try to keep my word; if you can't, you don't have credibility. I guess I'm also a bit of a masochist."
Ron Shapiro, a prominent player agent, offered another reason.
"When Randy Levine came on the scene, he brought a combination of credibility and sensitivity to his office that never had existed there before," Shapiro said, speaking from 20 years of baseball experience. "That broke the dam of mistrust between the union and the player relations committee."
Lauren Rich, one of the primary negotiators through the long-running dispute, was one of the union people who came to appreciate Levine's skills.
"In order to get something like this done, given what we've gone through," she said, "you need two people who always will be searching for solutions and who are willing to bang heads among their constituencies. Randy was always searching for ways to accommodate interests on both sides and was willing, when he thought he got to that point, to bang heads. None of their other chief negotiators brought those things to the table with such a passion."
One person who was not surprised by Levine's achievement was the man he worked for before he stepped into baseball's field of land mines.
"Part of the problem the city used to have in labor relations was the unions didn't trust the city," Giuliani said. "They felt the city was hiding money. The core of Randy's ability is a relationship of trust and confidence, trying to figure out what's the objective we want to reach and how to get there so everyone has confidence we're not trying to hide anything."
Giuliani cited two examples of Levine's work for the city: the workfare program in which people on welfare work for the city in return for their benefits and a severance and redeployment program in which the city bought out 23,000 municipal employees and transferred workers from one agency to another to fill resulting gaps.
But, the Mayor said, "What he had to accomplish in baseball was more difficult."
Levine, a graduate of Hofstra Law School, first became involved in baseball in 1990 as outside counsel to George Steinbrenner and the Yankees when he was a partner with Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn. In that role, Levine attended the owners' first meeting on revenue sharing in Kohler, Wis., in 1993.
A lawyer with the Justice Department in Washington from 1985 to 1988, he worked in Giuliani's mayoral campaigns in 1989 and 1993, then joined the administration as labor commissioner, a post he held for about two years. Then baseball beckoned. "I took this job because I love baseball," Levine said. "I thought I could contribute to solving this nightmare. I never saw an industry where there was more mistrust -- on both sides. I think Don was skeptical at first, but as we took baby steps, then giant steps that weekend in August, I think we came to have a mutual respect."
That weekend, Aug. 9-11, was the turning point in the negotiations.
"I think the key was late Friday night," Levine said. "I told the union I was authorized to make a last and final offer and go to court if necessary. We both knew once we did that, it would be hard to make a deal. We had real serious discussions about what the issues were. After that, we started to break through on the tax threshold, the number of years on the luxury tax revenue sharing. We started to build momentum."
Despite his efforts, Levine found himself on the short end of the owners' Nov. 6 vote and prepared to resign. He may still leave the job sooner rather than later, but he said he has made no decision.
"I'm going to take a nice long respite after the agreement is signed," he said. "I'll take some time off, go upstate, smell the flowers a little bit and see where we go from there. We'll weigh all the opportunities, whether in baseball or outside, and see what happens."
Whether sooner or later, Levine will very likely return to the Giuliani administration, perhaps as deputy mayor. Asked yesterday about that possibility, Giuliani said, "You can be certain, one way or another, we'll be working together again."

HEADLINE: Lithuania Will Share Jewish Books, but How?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We are grateful for your front-page article Nov. 24 on the priceless treasure of thousands of rare Jewish books in the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius that for decades had been hidden from the Nazis and later from the Soviets. 
 Lithuania greatly values its multicultural tradition and takes pride in the rich history of its Jewish community. We agree that these books should be made more accessible to scholars, and we regret that Lithuania is unable to provide proper facilities for this collection.
Unfortunately, as your article reports, the Lithuanian National Library is strapped for cash, with only a bare-bones budget for preserving and restoring rare books. Indeed, these valuable Yiddish and Hebrew-language volumes -- whose proper safeguarding would run into the hundreds of thousands of dollars -- are among many books (in various languages) faced with dire problems of preservation. This is part of the price Lithuania is paying during a difficult economic transition.
In 1997, the 200-year anniversary of the death of the Gaon of Vilnius, who wrote some of the books in the collection, will be commemorated by a conference in Vilnius. This meeting of scholars will be an excellent opportunity to discuss ways to cooperate in preserving this collection. One idea might be the construction of a separate library. We welcome all suggestions and support from Americans concerned with the fate of this great Lithuanian Jewish cultural heritage.
 
ALFONSAS EIDINTAS
Ambassador, Republic of Lithuania
Washington, Nov. 25, 1996

HEADLINE: How Not to Book Better Math and Science;
Children First

 BODY:
To the Editor:
When I heard the first news reports that our kids had done better than eighth graders in other countries (news article, Nov. 21), I thought America was doing better by its children -- until I read the fine print. We barely made it into the top half of nations in science, reaching 17 out of 41. 
 Perhaps it is time to admit there is a design flaw in the system itself. The best teacher gets no better treatment than the worst. Violence is a daily threat. Multiple choice, "dumbed down" textbooks, patronizing grade inflation and unearned self-esteem too often reign supreme. Bureaucracy is overwhelming and inefficient in district after district.
And no one gets fired. Not the uncaring teacher. Not the administrator who refuses to deal with discipline problems. And not the politician who sells his soul for re-election support from those who care more for power and patronage than for kids.
Some day educators will begin school by assessing the capacity of each individual child to learn. Some day parents will insist on results, not grades; on acquired ethics and morals, not unearned self-esteem. And some day business will have the integrity to announce that never again will it sponsor an advertisement that advocates, through its music or shows, violence against women, drug use or the killing of police officers.
That will be the day that America becomes the nation that puts its children first.
 
WILLIAM E. BROCK
Annapolis, Md., Nov. 25, 1996
 
The writer is a former Senator from Tennessee.

HEADLINE: Populism at the Pump

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Texas Meeting Seeks a Rebirth of Populism" (news article, Nov. 25): It's encouraging to see that there are people willing to meet and address the problem of corporate dominance of the American economy. 
 For years, I have avoided heavily advertised products. In Portland, unleaded gas prices vary, from $1.39 a gallon for Chevron, say, to $1.13 for smaller, unadvertised brands.
With a little effort, we can support products whose prices are not inflated by expensive TV ads, which add nothing to an item except a feeling of being in the in crowd. If we behave like sheep, we will give a lot of power to the wolves.
 
BOBBIE SAVITZ
Portland, Ore., Nov. 25, 1996

HEADLINE: The Looming Clean Air Battle

 BODY:
The Clean Air Act of 1970 -- strengthened by President Carter in 1977 and by President Bush in 1990 -- has greatly improved the quality of America's air. Responding to tough Federal mandates, science and industry have produced cleaner cars, fuels and power plants. The Federal Government now says it will try to draw the regulatory noose even tighter to help hundreds of thousands of people who suffer from respiratory diseases.
The proposed regulations, announced Wednesday, have already stirred the biggest political ruckus in Carol Browner's four-year tenure as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. They will surely be costly, to industry and consumers. But in public health terms, her decision is the right one. Her task now will be to allow cities, states and industry enough time to adjust to the new regulations in a measured, cost-effective way. 
 The new rules would triple the number of counties nationwide where state and local officials would have to impose stricter rules to clean up the air. At least 100 million people live in those areas. Business groups and many governors have been lobbying hard against the proposals and can be expected to do so in the months ahead when the rules will be open for public comment before they are finally written into law. Critics question the science on which the rules are based and argue that the billions they will have to spend on pollution control will not produce comparable health benefits.
The proposed rules address two problems. The first is the health damage caused by "particulate matter." Broadly speaking, current regulations are designed to trap airborne microscopic particles as small as 10 microns in diameter (a human hair is 70 microns). But many scientists have concluded that particles smaller than 10 microns are the deadliest because they can evade the body's natural defenses and lodge in the most fragile sections of the lungs. The new rules would, therefore, lower the size of the regulated particles to 2.5 microns or less.
Some studies have suggested that tighter standards could save over 20,000 lives per year and prevent widespread hospitalization for many more people who suffer from asthma, bronchitis and other respiratory ills.
The E.P.A., which by law is required to update regulations every five years but missed a 1992 deadline, has been under court order to issue new particulate standards. But Wednesday's proposals also included tighter standards for ground-level ozone, which helps create smog. Those regulations are also out of date. Since particulates and ozone share some of the same sources, including coal-fired power plants, many of the same pollution-control strategies, like cleaner fuels, for example, can be applied to both.
The E.P.A. has conducted four years' worth of scientific studies, many of which industry challenges. But an equally hot issue involves costs and benefits. Under the Clean Air Act, Ms. Browner's sole obligation is to set standards that protect public health with an "adequate margin of safety." She, nevertheless, conducted various economic analyses, as required by an executive order asking Federal rule-making agencies to make available their best estimates. Such estimates are necessarily inexact. But the E.P.A.'s analysis suggests that the benefits of small-particle reduction outweigh the costs by a substantial margin -- an estimated $51 billion to $112 billion annually in reduced medical costs, fewer sick days and other benefits, against $6.5 billion to $8.5 billion in costs.
Many areas will be able to meet the new standards without taking extraordinary new steps, largely because many of the pollution-control strategies inspired by the 1990 amendments have not fully taken hold. Compliance will, however, be especially hard for congested areas like New York and Los Angeles, which are still struggling to meet the old air-quality standards.
For that reason, the E.P.A. proposes a generous time frame for compliance. New York, for example, may not have to reach full compliance for 15 years. In the meantime, the agency says it will try to assist places like New York that suffer from "imported" pollution by requiring tighter controls on out-of-state sources, like power plants in the Midwest.
The comment period will allow time for what is certain to be vigorous debate. The White House and Congress -- which can review the proposals and send them back to the E.P.A. if it does not like them -- will be under great pressure from both sides. But it seems clear that the hazards associated with dirty air are greater than originally supposed. A sensible response is clearly required.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

COMPANY: ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) US ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (83%); US ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (83%);

HEADLINE: Questions About a Hospital Deal

 BODY:
A majority of the board of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation has sided with Mayor Rudolph Giuliani in approving a long-term lease of Coney Island Hospital to a commercial company. The Giuliani administration is confident that the deal will save millions for the city, while preserving care for the poor. But before state officials give their required approval, there are important unanswered questions that need to be addressed.
Mr. Giuliani has long pushed to privatize or lease city hospitals in an effort to cut health costs and overhaul care for the poor. Coney Island was one of the first hospitals to be put on the auction block. Nestled in a neighborhood of elderly and poor people, it has 460 beds and a number of outpatient services. But surveys indicate that about two-thirds of nearby residents seek health care elsewhere. 
 In what would amount to a virtual sale, city officials propose to turn the hospital over to Primary Health Systems, a two-year-old Pennsylvania-based company, under a 99-year lease that could be renewed at the option of the company for another 99 years. Because of city and state restrictions on out-of-state control of public hospitals, the company has created a subsidiary, P.H.S.-N.Y., to operate the hospital.
Legal challenges by three dissenting members of the hospitals board, community groups in Coney Island and the City Council question the city's ability to strike such a deal and threaten to prolong proceedings. Even without the lawsuits the deal faces a protracted approval process through several state regulatory agencies, including the State Health Department. These agencies can properly raise questions about whether P.H.S.-N.Y. can pay for promised improvements and what will happen to indigent patients who carry no private or public insurance.
The agreement obligates the group to pay about $50 million to settle the hospital's existing capital debt. Beyond that, the group has agreed to spend $25 million for capital construction, which will include upgrading the elevators, operating rooms and plumbing, and an estimated $5 million each year on maintenance and repairs.
The lease agreement also stipulates that spending for indigent care will be raised 15 percent above current levels as adjusted annually for inflation, and kept there. But the language is vague about what kind of care will be provided and to how many patients. Critics also question whether P.H.S. has adequately anticipated the impact of harsh Federal and state changes in the welfare system. Those changes could result in increased numbers of indigent patients who seek health care. The group also has to negotiate with the labor unions, to bring about a promised 25 percent reduction in staff.
City officials insist that P.H.S. is well capitalized, but the company is also trying to purchase other hospitals and still needs to raise money to finance this and other deals. The city boasts that the deal will save taxpayers $100 million initially and $30 million each year, while still maintaining adequate care for the poor. If the deal can really deliver all this -- lower costs for the city, a renovated hospital and more care for the poor -- it is too good to pass up. But it is imperative for state officials to examine the fine print and determine whether this deal can live up to its promise.

HEADLINE: Political Infighting Halts Indiana City's Salute to a Native Son

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: GARY, Ind., Nov. 28

 BODY:
It was supposed to have been the impetus to transform this gritty blue-collar city into the entertainment mecca of the Midwest. But political bickering and allegations of racism and conflict of interest have halted plans for the $2 billion entertainment complex.
Gary's most famous family is fed up, its lawyer said, and has withdrawn support for the complex because of the politics and fears of lawsuits. 
 Youngsters on the city's west side can direct visitors to the location of Michael Jackson's boyhood home, most likely including the address. "Everybody knows that around here," Malik Simmons, 11, said on his way home from school. "They even named the street after him."
The answer is partly correct. The Jackson family got its start in a modest single-story corner house on Jackson Street. But the street is named after the seventh President.
City leaders have proposed that the house be the centerpiece of a theme park near Interstates 65 and 94 that would include a Jackson family museum, an entertainment complex, hotels and stores. A Los Angeles lawyer who has been negotiating with officials for the Jackson family since last year, Brian Oxman, said the project had been stopped because of squabbling between Mayor Scott King and Mr. King's predecessor, Thomas V. Barnes.
Mr. Oxman said the family was concerned that the yearlong battle over control of the project had diminished confidence among potential investors. "It's not doable, given the current state of affairs," he said.
The dispute has highlighted the racial polarization between Mr. Barnes's old-line leadership and those who back Mr. King, the first white mayor in more than 20 years.
"It's become, unfortunately, a black and white issue," Mr. Oxman said. "Let's face it, the color of this project should be green, the color of money."
Mr. Oxman faults Mr. Barnes, the former Mayor, for the gridlock and for inserting race into the discussion. Mr. Barnes proposed the Jackson Theme Park in the second of his two terms. Late last year, his appointees to the Public Works Board voted to lease 200 acres that the city owns to a foundation formed by Mr. Barnes.
Shortly after he took office on Jan. 1, Mr. King said the lease was improper because Mr. Barnes was chairman of the foundation board, a post that he continues to occupy.
Mr. Barnes and the executive director of the foundation, Thomas Floyd, said Mr. King was seeking to freeze them out of the project to benefit the mostly white business sector. The two men said the complex should be managed by a mostly black steering group that would be more in tune with community needs.
"This is not just an important economic issue," Mr. Barnes said, "but equally important from a cultural and spiritual perspective. It's a way we can provide a cultural and moral underpinning to underprivileged African-Americans nationwide who have given up their hope of the American dream."
Mr. Floyd said Mr. King and others were convinced that "no black-led organization can pull off this type of development without a lot of direction from white people."
Mr. King denied that he was trying to squeeze anyone out of the project.
"My only position has been and continues to be that this was not a well-conceived nor well-executed idea," he said. "There has yet to be any type of site-suitability study completed, no preliminary planning -- just a lot of talk about money. All I want to do is what is right for the people of Gary, and, to that end, I've held open the door and tried to work with this group. Any talk that there is any type of racial agenda here is just a lot of hooey."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Beyond the Movie

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
And now maybe we should think a bit about Tibet -- the country, not the movie.
The Chinese Government tried to blackmail the Walt Disney people into scrapping an almost-finished movie about the Dalai Lama, occupied Tibet's spiritual and national leader, its one voice to the world. 
 Disney would have to kill the film or risk its dreams of expansion in China -- theme parks, and all that. Disney executives deserve credit for refusing to obey, and for being sensible enough to avoid the denunciation and boycotts that would have broken about them had they surrendered.
But all companies doing business in China or asking for more already know that they are subjecting themselves to Beijing's blackmail.
Sometimes that means accepting such items as governmental birth control -- the monitoring of menstrual cycles of women workers in plants built and directed by foreigners. And always it means shutting totally up about slave labor camps, torture or the occupation of Tibet.
For many years American Government and business have known that Beijing uses economic pressures against foreign enterprises to tighten its oppression of its subjects -- have known and submitted.
And for as many years, Washington and U.S. companies have refused to try to ease oppression, even by one thumb screw, by using America's far greater economic clout -- including the fact that Chinese sales to the U.S. dwarf America's sales to China by ever increasing billions.
So let's wipe the shocked look off our collective face because Mickey Mouse got his tail caught sniffing after Chinese cheese.
The Disney picture was never expected to be shown in China. But since obliteration of the reality of Tibet is a goal of the occupation, Beijing did not want the world even to think about Tibetan reality. Let's just do that.
The occupation of Tibet has now lasted a hideous half-century. The Chinese set about obliteration methodically, slicing off part of the country and incorporating it into China proper. They called what was left an "autonomous" region of China but allowed it no taste of autonomy.
Everywhere they sent Chinese in, moved Tibetans out. There were about six million Tibetans when China invaded and there are still about that many. But what with the partitioning, transfers and the colonizing Chinese, Beijing thinks it can get away with counting them less than two million. Still, in some districts that even Beijing deigns to call Tibetan, the Communists concede there are more Chinese than Tibetans.
Despite the deportations, murders, prison tortures and the relentless carnage of their monasteries and degradation of their religion, the unarmed Tibetans did not understand that they were supposed to be obliterated. They are not too naive to understand -- just too faithful to themselves and their country.
So in July 1994 Chinese leaders met in Beijing to update their strategy: even harsher steps against religion, punishment of Tibetan officials conceivably harboring dissident thoughts, and an all-out campaign against the political and religious influence of the Dalai Lama -- including a plan to "restructure" the Tibetan religion to eliminate his role.
More Chinese were dispatched to Tibet, more Tibetans deported and arrested. It has not worked. Tibetans remain a nation alive, worshiping and resisting, with a leader they have loved through the 40 years he has sought help for them abroad.
The Dalai Lama is a man of good heart. All over the world, men and women have listened to him and responded to him with their own good hearts. The nations have not, because they want to do more business with the occupiers.
In Hollywood, actors like Richard Gere and Harrison Ford and directors like Martin Scorcese have shown respect for him, and tenderness. To Tibetans they gave the gift of remembering their torments -- aloud. Their own American Government, meanwhile, has used its power not to help Tibetans but to betray them, lest an act of succor bring Chinese trade restrictions.
By "delinking" human rights and trade, Mr. Clinton broke his promises to Tibetans and to the Chinese victims of Beijing. That decision will be among the political monuments to his Presidencies. But how to depict it in marble I cannot imagine.

HEADLINE: Mother Held in Child Slaying Felt Severe Stress, Police Say

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

 BODY:
Drawing a picture of a deeply disturbed young woman, police officials said yesterday that a 17-year-old Brooklyn mother charged with fatally stabbing her 2-year-old daughter admitted that she committed the crime because she was depressed and irritable over the strains of motherhood.
The suspect, Yvonne Rogers, originally told detectives that a young drug dealer had killed her daughter Wednesday afternoon while attempting to collect a $20 drug debt from the child's uncle. But police said her story unraveled during an interrogation in the detective squad room of the 75th Precinct station house. 
 The baby, Michaelik Hall, was stabbed in the hallway of Ms. Roger's home at 214 Warwick Street in Cypress Hills, Brooklyn, and died in the emergency room of Jamaica Hospital.
Describing Ms. Roger's confession, a detective in the 75th Precinct said, "The stress was too much for her."
A senior Brooklyn police official, who like the detective spoke on condition of anonymity, said: "You have to crawl in the head of this disturbed person to understand this. You kill a child, stabbing her four times because you are stressed out?"
The official said detectives believed that Ms. Rogers stabbed the child once, then dressed her in pair of bluish-green pajamas and stabbed her three more times. He said she told them that she put the child in the hallway before stabbing her.
Ms. Rogers, who is unemployed and had no police record, has been charged with second-degree murder and criminal possession of a weapon. An official with the Administration for Children's Services said there was no record of any complaint to the agency of child abuse involving Ms. Rogers and her daughter.
Investigators said police officers with a search warrant found a knife under a bed in Ms. Rogers's apartment on Wednesday night and it appeared to be stained with blood. Laboratory technicians checked the knife for Ms. Rogers' fingerprints yesterday, and were investigating whether the blood matched the child's.
The investigators expressed surprise that Ms. Rogers did not seek help from her father before such a violent act. "This is just a kid who panicked," the senior police official said.

HEADLINE: Republicans Strike Deep In the Heart Of Texas

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 28

 BODY:
On election night earlier this month, Gov. George W. Bush declared victory in the Lone Star State. "I think the message to Texans is our state is Republican, and proudly so," Mr. Bush said at a victory rally. "It does look like an overwhelming night for Republicans statewide."
Mr. Bush was not up for re-election, but his party was, and the historic news in Texas was that Republicans had swept all 10 statewide races, and that for the first time since Reconstruction, the party was on the verge of gaining control of the State Senate. 
 While most populous states went for President Clinton, Bob Dole won Texas's 32 electoral votes handily, with 49 percent of the vote to Mr. Clinton's 44 percent, larger than President George Bush's victory here in 1992. In addition, Senator Phil Gramm easily defeated Victor Morales, the political novice who campaigned out of his pickup truck.
Even more important, the Republican Party racked up an impressive string of victories at nearly every level in this former Democratic stronghold, the home of Lyndon B. Johnson and Lloyd Bentsen.
"This is the first time in my memory when all 10 statewide races went Republican," said Bruce Buchanan, a professor of government at the University of Texas who teaches a course on Texas politics. "We're drifting Republican. It's part of the enduring political culture, which is anti-statist and pro-economic growth."
While a majority of elected officials here continue to be Democrats, over the past 20 years the Republican Party has made steady gains, and now party members hold most of the top-tier positions in the state, including the governorship, both United States Senate seats and majorities on the State Supreme Court and the Court of Criminal Appeals, which are elected judgeships.
The gains have been notable. In 1990, Texas Republicans held only 8 seats in the Congressional delegation, 8 in the State Senate and 57 in the State House. But after this month's election, the Republicans are assured of at least 13 of 30 seats in Congress, 15 of 31 in the State Senate and 68 of 150 in the State House, with several runoffs pending.
"Texas is becoming a Republican state," said Tom Pauken, chairman of the state Republican Party. "To be able to show progress in a year that things didn't go well for Republicans on a national level is pretty good."
Yet some Republicans here admit that the party's advances were not as far reaching as many had predicted. For instance, of 8 open Congressional seats, the Democrats won 4 and the Republicans 4.
While a realignment of party politics in Texas appears under way, officials of both parties agree that Texas has evolved into a competitive two-party state.
"It was like a Tet offensive," Royal Masset, political director of the state Republican Party, said of the recent election. "It's good in the sense that we didn't go back, but there was no tidal wave. This was not an anti-Democratic year. They held us back."
Indeed, Bill White, chairman of the state Democratic Party, said Republican gains this year were not as significant as they appeared, and that despite large advantages in fund raising, the Republicans had only inched forward against a revitalized state Democratic Party.
"Their growth has slowed in Congress and the State Legislature," Mr. White said. "And for the first time we've started taking seats from the Republicans. We stopped Republican gains, particularly at the local levels, and we have united the party and continue to be very strong in the largest eight counties in the state."
Mr. White said that while the Republican Party surged among white male voters and in rural areas, the Democrats were favored by minorities, particularly Hispanic voters, who turned out in record numbers this year.
More than 1.6 million Hispanic Texans, almost all of them Mexican-Americans, were registered to vote this year, and about 1.1 million cast a ballot, up from about 666,000 who voted in 1992, said Lydia Camarillo, executive director at the Southwest Voter Registration Education Project in San Antonio.
One surprise this year was the strength of incumbency. No incumbent of either party up for re-election in Congress was defeated, although two face runoffs. And in the State Legislature, incumbents lost in only 5 of about 58 contests.
"If there's any one message, it's that incumbency was very strong this year," said Mr. Masset of the Republican Party. "About 80 percent of our gains have been in election years. And so this was very similar to an off-year election."

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
A Putnam County project shows the revival of the New York market has extended far north.

BYLINE: By Rachelle Garbarine 

DATELINE: KENT, N.Y.

 BODY:
A TOWN HOUSE development of 116 residences is taking shape here, reflecting the recovery of the new-home market in semirural Putnam County.
The $13.5 million project, Sparrow Ridge, will have town houses spread over 27 acres off Hill and Dale Road in the eastern section of this township. Each town house building will have four to six residences with two bedrooms. 
 The start of a project 50 miles from New York City suggests that New York's housing market continues to improve, stoking builder interest in home construction in Putnam and Dutchess Counties.
"We see those counties as growth areas," said Lenard Thylan, president of Thylan Associates of Manhattan, which is developing Sparrow Ridge. It is the company's fifth project in the area; it has a total of 500 residences in its developments.
Demand is coming from people who work in Manhattan as well as from local residents, brokers in the area said. But many buyers may also be workers in the office buildings in White Plains and Somers in Westchester County.
The company also hopes to draw empty-nester couples. Such people may want to sell their current homes and buy in a development where someone else does the outdoor chores. Some of the homes will have master bedrooms on the first floor to appeal to such couples, many of whom no longer wish to negotiate stairs.
With a construction loan from the Poughkeepsie Savings Bank, the company will develop the project, designed by Zane Yost & Associates of Bridgeport, Conn., in phases over the next three years. Introductory prices for the 1,350-to-2,950-square-foot residences are $145,900 to $187,900.
The site was once part of a larger tract that had formerly been a golf and country club. Hill and Dale Associates of Mount Kisco, N.Y., bought it in the mid-1980's building surge with hopes of constructing 216 town houses on the 65-acre tract, divided by Hill and Dale Road. Just 100 homes west of the road were developed in a project known as the Fairways before the developer defaulted on its loan and the lender took back the site through foreclosure in 1990.
Before Thylan acquired the undeveloped 27 acres late in 1994, the seller, Congress Realty of Boston, had reached a settlement with existing owners that the old and new residences would be separate enclaves, each with its own homeowners' association.
But rather than develop the 116 residences according to the approved plan, the company enlarged the units by at least 200 square feet each, redesigned the exteriors with details that include porches and columns and added basements and one-car garages on most of the units "to broaden their appeal," Mr. Thylan said. Recreational amenities were also added.
Sparrow Ridge is welcomed by Kent because it provides an alternative type of housing that will help keep elderly and young residents in the community, Jeanne M. Ryan, secretary of the township's planning board, said. Ms. Ryan said more than 3,000 town houses were approved for construction in the 1980's in the eastern section of the township, most along Route 52. But, she said, most of the larger projects were stopped before they began because of the real estate recession.
There is interest among developers in reviving a few of those projects. But Ms. Ryan said large-scale development would become more difficult because of the tightening of regulations to protect watershed areas. Most of Kent lies within the region of the Croton Reservoir. Because Sparrow Ridge was begun in the 1980's as part of the Fairways project and will be served by a sewage treatment plant for the original 216-unit project it is not affected.
Single-family detached homes are the dominant style in Kent and in Putnam County. But Mr. Thylan said the project's site, just west of the intersection of Routes 84 and 684, with the Brewster Metro-North train station about 10 minutes away, would draw buyers.
The resale market for town houses and condominiums has rebounded as the lack of construction in the last few years pared the available inventory, Vincent J. Ficarra, president of the Putnam County Board of Realtors, said.
Of the first 28 residences at Sparrow Ridge, 11 are under way or completed. An outdoor pool has also been constructed, and other recreational amenities, including a clubhouse and a tennis court, are planned. The monthly maintenance fee is $180. Mr. Thylan said that since sales began six weeks ago, six homes have been sold or are under contract to be sold.

HEADLINE: Thanksgiving, for Odd Sort of Harvard Expatriate

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Americans in Europe like Americans in America took time out to celebrate Thanksgiving today.
But here, in an unassuming apartment in a concrete block on Karl-Marx-Allee in the former East Berlin, one American at least seemed to be giving thanks largely for the fact that America -- or at least American authorities -- never caught up with him. 
 The story of Victor Grossman, an American Army private who jumped into the Danube in 1952 and defected to the Eastern bloc, recounted over a lunch of liver and onion rather than turkey, is one of those tantalizing sub-texts that still come to light seven years after the Berlin wall fell.
It is a tale with a little Le Carre, a little John Reed, and, sometimes, as Mr. Grossman puts it: "a lot of nostalgia, and a twinge of homesickness, too."
Mr. Grossman, who was once Stephen Wechsler, born to a middle-class family in New York, decided to change his name after he fled the Army. His Soviet interrogators suggested Victor Grossman.
Throughout the decades of Europe's division, Mr. Grossman, now 68, lived in East Berlin, wanted by United States Army investigators on charges of perjury and desertion.
Only in 1994 did he reclaim his American passport and return for his Harvard Class of 1949 reunion.
Soon after he landed at Kennedy Airport, Mr. Grossman said, he was taken to the Army base at Fort Dix, where he finally received his discharge. According to Mr. Grossman, American officials told him that the case against him had been closed. They did not explain why.
The saga of his time beyond the Iron Curtain is the mirror-image of the way most Americans viewed the Communist East.
For Mr. Grossman, the risk of arrest or kidnapping by Americans was, he said in an interview today, far more of a threat than anything the Communist authorities or secret police could muster.
And seven years after the end of the cold war, he remains convinced that the system that crumbled with the Berlin wall in 1989 was by no means all wrong.
Mr. Grossman's trip behind the Iron Curtain had seemingly conventional beginnings. His father was an art dealer, his mother a social worker. He went to Harvard to major in economics and then, putting his left-wing convictions into practice, went to work in a factory in Buffalo, toting steel.
Throughout his youth, he said, he had been a member of Socialist or Communist organizations. When the draft came, he perjured himself by signing a declaration stating that he had not been and was not a member of any of those organizations.
Suddenly in 1952, the young soldier Stephen Wechsler, stationed in the American zone of occupation in Bavaria, was ordered to appear before a court-martial on perjury charges. He said he did not know how his deception had come to light. Perhaps someone informed on him. Perhaps it turned up in the routine check that followed his training as a radio operator. "I figured 10 years in Leavenworth breaking rocks, because this was a terrible time in the States," he said. So, rather than break rocks, he plunged into the Danube on a warm, August night and swam for freedom, as he saw it, in the Soviet occupation zone of Austria.
That's where the Le Carre part comes in.
By Mr. Grossman's account, his reception in Soviet-occupied Austria, shoeless and disheveled, was not hostile. But security officials there were, well, cautious about his protestations that he had arrived to join the revolution.
For two weeks he was held in a cell. There were moments of doubt.. "I did a lot of thinking in those two weeks," Mr. Grossman recalled, "and I wondered if some of the stories that we as leftists had dismissed as lies about labor camps in the Soviet Union were true."
The voyage continued -- a journey in a curtained vehicle across occupied eastern Europe, a safe-house in Potsdam, dispatch to the East German town of Bautzen to work in an auto factory with "30 or 40" other defecting foreigners, for whom he ended up organizing movies and bingo games, and his first enounter with the German woman who would become his wife and mother of his two sons.
After a four-year study course in journalism in Leipzig, Mr. Grossman made a name for himself in East Germany. Among other publications, he wrote a history of America and a book about American folk music. He broadcast, and wrote articles assailing the Vietnam War and the Reagan Administration. He undertook lecture tours. Mr. Grossman said he believed in socialism, but did not approve of the some of those who sought power, sometimes brutally, in its name.
A former United States State Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Mr. Grossman was not seen as a serious player in the propaganda wars between East and West. The defector, this official said, "did not figure very highly in our concerns" at the time. Nonetheless, Mr. Grossman continued to worry about his future: it was not until a year after the fall of the Berlin wall that he ventured into West Berlin.
He is convinced that his skepticism about the capitalist system that is now in place in the unified Germany was well-founded.
In East Germany, he said, "there was no unemployment, there was no homelessness."
Mr. Grossman, who has made two trips to the United States since the end of the cold war, is now writing an autobiography to be published by the University of Massachussetts Press next year.
He and his wife, Renate, live in a modest, three-room apartment on the eighth floor of the 1960's block on Karl-Marx-Allee. He spoke in a sitting-room lined with books in English and German, furnished without frills, where Mrs. Grossman served lunch on a coffee table as he talked. Mr. Grossman lives these days on a German state pension of around $1,150 a month.
Whatever else happens, he said:
"I always felt I was an American. I couldn't be anything but American."
Mr. Grossman said he has kept up with American movies in versions dubbed in German and German translations of authors like John Updike, Kurt Vonnegut and Saul Bellow.
"I've thought about Thanksgiving as I've thought about the 4th of July," he said. "I have always felt myself to be an American and I've kept very close watch on American developments."

HEADLINE: Study Faults Home Insurers For Big Losses From Disasters

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
In the last few years, the companies that sell homeowners' insurance have lost billions of dollars.
They attribute the losses to hurricanes and earthquakes. 
 But researchers at Conning & Company, a Hartford-based insurance investment and research concern, say it is the industry itself that is largely responsible for creating its own natural disaster.
The fundamental problem, according to a study released by Conning this week, is that the basic homeowners' policy has gone haywire. While competing among themselves for more and more business, the researchers say, insurance companies have been expanding benefits and taking on additional risk without correspondingly increasing prices.
The huge disasters that laid waste to parts of Florida, Southern California and a few other places, the researchers say, merely accentuated a problem that has been developing for years. Indeed, the companies have not just suffered recently; they have lost money on their policies in all but one of the last 16 years.
All of this has become an issue of public policy since Hurricane Andrew hit south Florida in 1992 and a large earthquake struck Los Angeles in 1994. Several smaller insurance companies went bankrupt and the survivors began cutting back on coverage.
For many homeowners, policies were unavailable, forcing them to turn to state-run pools that charged high rates for minimal coverage.
The Conning research suggests that with different pricing and benefits, the companies might well have been able to withstand the disasters without such drastic reductions and without sharply increasing premiums and deductibles. State Farm, the largest homeowners' company in the country, has doubled its premium for many policyholders in south Florida and Allstate, the second largest, is now requiring homeowners in Florida to take a deductible of $5,000, up from either $250 or $500.
Industry officials say their biggest mistake was in miscalculating the destructiveness of Hurricane Andrew and the Los Angeles earthquake. Andrew cost the industry $15.5 billion -- $10 billion for homeowners' policies alone -- and the earthquake cost $12.5 billion.
"Trying to show the worst possible scenario, the scariest thing we could come up with before Andrew was $7 billion in losses," Sean Mooney, an economist at the Insurance Information Institute, a trade organization in New York, said.
Some insurance executives agree that prices have been out of balance. But rather than introducing more flexibility and carrying out relatively small rate increases spread across the entire population, as the researchers advocate, the industry has set a target on Florida and other coastal areas to bear most of the pain. Their solution is to further increase deductibles and premiums in those areas.
They also contend that government should create cash pools to keep companies solvent when disasters threaten to wipe them out.
"What's needed is a way to smooth out the huge hits," Gary Grant, a vice president and actuary at State Farm, said.
Legislation that would have provided Federal backing for the industry failed in Congress this year. It was bitterly opposed by consumer groups. "These guys screwed up," said Mary Griffin, an insurance specialist at Consumers Union in Washington, "and they want the Government to come and save them from themselves."
But some people argue that the industry is simply crying crocodile tears. Insurance companies can afford to spend more on claims than they take in from policies in part because they invest the billions that they collect in premiums. That is where the big profits are, industry executives acknowledge. And when investment earnings are added to those from premiums, industry financial records show a profit in 5 of the last 16 years.
But the biggest reason that insurers offer homeowners' policies at low cost, executives say, is in hopes that the same buyers will also sign up for auto insurance, which has been consistently profitable.
Perhaps the largest single factor in creating the financial problems, said Claude Fongemie, a vice president in charge of insurance research at Conning, has been a shift in the late 1970's from selling policies that simply covered the market value of homes and their contents to ones that provide for the full cost of replacing the home and everything in it.
Because of escalating costs for building supplies, he said, replacement can far exceed a home's market value. In addition, with a replacement policy, the wear and tear on a 10-year-old couch is disregarded, and the insurance company simply pays for a new one.
Since the mid-1980's, Mr. Fongemie estimates, the cost of replacing a home and its contents rather than paying for them at market value has added as much as 60 percent to insurance company costs. By contrast, premium prices have gone down. Mr. Fongemie calculated that in 1984 the cost of $100,000 worth of coverage was $350. Eleven years later the cost was $210, a drop of 40 percent.
The way to get back to the at least modest profits the industry was earning in the 1960's and 1970's, Mr. Fongemie said, is to go back to writing coverage for homes and contents that pays what those things are worth when disaster strikes. Or raise prices across the board.
But neither consumer advocates nor the industry favor returning to the more limited coverage.
"Coverage at market value is often a crummy deal for people," Ms. Griffin of Consumers Union said. "The issue is: 'If my house burns down, will I be able to replace it with the insurance money?' And you won't if the coverage is market value."
Instead of reducing coverage Ms. Griffin says insurance companies should offer customers a choice of how much or how little coverage they want and charge accordingly.
"It's the insurance industry's responsibility to fairly and accurately set prices, based on risk," she said.
George E. Ruebenson, a vice president at Allstate, the second-largest seller of homeowners' insurance, said his company's profits had been better than those of the industry as a whole and that it did not foresee cutting back on policy benefits.
With almost every insurer offering full-replacement policies these days, Mr. Grant said, companies that chose to offer less "would find themselves at a pretty severe competitive disadvantage."

HEADLINE: Nigeria's Leader Presses Makeover of the Economy and His Image

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 28

 BODY:
In the face of widespread skepticism from Nigeria's domestic opposition, Nigeria's military leader, Gen. Sani Abacha, is pushing ahead with an effort to spur economic change and enhance his political image.
This week, the Nigerian Government announced formation of a 170-member committee set up to raise the living standards of Nigeria's 100 million people. The program, known as Vision 2010, was first announced at a conference in September in the capital, Abuja. 
 Opposition groups immediately criticized the makeup of the panel, which consists almost entirely of establishment figures. The chairman is Ernest Shonekan, head of the short-lived interim Government of 1993 that gave way to the current military rulers. Its members include prominent politicians, traditional rulers and business executives, all culled from among Nigeria's elite.
"We intend to capture the imagination of our people," General Abacha said this week.
Nigeria is among the world's top 10 oil-producing nations, pumping 2 million barrels a day, yet its roads and infrastructure are decaying. Poverty is widespread, with some public-sector employees earning as little as $450 a year. Infant mortality is estimated at 75 deaths per thousand births, nearly 10 times the rate in the United States.
While corruption has kept a rich elite comfortable, the middle classes and the poor have suffered a significant drop in living standards over the last decade. A recent study by Transparency International, a group devoted to fighting business corruption, rated Nigeria as the world's most corrupt country, followed by Pakistan, Kenya, Bangladesh and China.
Many ordinary Nigerians blame their country's economic troubles on years of rule by the military. Vision 2010, officials have said, is intended to convince Nigerians that General Abacha's Government is sensitive to the plight of common people.
But not every one is convinced. Some of the sharpest criticism has come from Nigeria's southern newspapers, many of which are critical of the current military Government, which for the last two years has imprisoned the presumed winner of the 1993 elections, Chief Mashood Abiola.
They have portrayed Vision 2010 as a carefully shaped campaign to burnish General Abacha's image, and say the date suggests the military intends to hold on to power at least until 2010.
"2010 Abacha's New Hand-Over Date?" read the front-page headline of the Tempo newspaper the week the program was begun. One opposition group, the Campaign for Democracy, asserted that Vision 2010 is intended to distract from Nigeria's real problems.
"While the trade-union movement, the intellectual and students' movements, the political and business communities in Nigeria today have been generally pummeled into frustration and general irrelevance, the regime is making claim to implement a vision for the next one and a half decades," said Sylvester Odion-Akhaine, one of the leaders of the Campaign for Democracy. "The Vision is for whom and with whom?"
In contrast to his predecessor, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, General Abacha is a retiring figure who is not often seen in public. A different tone was set in last month's Independence Day celebrations. Instead of the traditional military processions past the country's leader, hundreds of young children stood in rows, North Korean style, singing General Abacha's praises. The general stood facing a huge picture of his face in a stadium covered with slogans proclaiming themes of nationalism, patriotism and stability.

HEADLINE: Plan to Cut and Raise Taxes Is Contentious in Maryland

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md., Nov. 26

 BODY:
Gov. Parris N. Glendening needed to look no further than his own family for incentives to propose raising taxes on cigarettes in Maryland. Both of his parents were heavy smokers, and he said he constantly worries about the peer pressure to smoke facing his 16-year-old son.
"I'm passionate about this," Mr. Glendening said in an interview here, expressing his desire to discourage smoking by doubling, to 72 cents, the state's current tax of 36 cents on each pack of cigarettes. If the legislature passes the measure next year, as expected, Maryland's tax would be the highest by far among tobacco-growing states and the fourth highest over all, behind Washington (82 1/2 cents per pack), Massachusetts (76) and Michigan (75). 
 A first-term Democrat, Mr. Glendening proposed the increase as part of an overall economic development plan that includes reducing the state personal income tax for the first time in 30 years -- a 10 percent reduction over three years, starting in 1998, that will save taxpayers $485 million -- as a way to create jobs and attract new businesses into the state. The Governor estimates that the cigarette tax will help reduce smoking and, by generating $285 million over three years, will pay for almost 60 percent of the income tax cut.
But for all the health benefits that might flow from reducing cigarette consumption and economic benefits that might derive from lowering other taxes, the plan has not met with universal acceptance in the state. Critics contend that it comes at the wrong time and that Mr. Glendening is using it only to expand his political base for re-election in 1998 after a bruising campaign in 1994 when he won by fewer than 6,000 votes.
Since then, he has endured criticism on a variety of issues, including accusations that he and several aides profited from a pension plan they devised when he was the executive of Prince George's County in suburban Washington. He also irritated some people by changing his position on slot machines at horse tracks and by offering favorable terms from the state for construction of new football stadiums in Baltimore and Prince George's County.
By September, a group of top state Democrats had grown so alarmed with Mr. Glendening's leadership that they met to consider how they might challenge him in the 1998 primary. While no consensus emerged, Stewart Bainum Jr., a former state legislator and wealthy businessman from Montgomery County who played host to the meeting, said the group agreed to meet again.
Meanwhile, Mr. Bainum said, several prominent Democrats have indicated they might challenge Mr. Glendening, including Representative Benjamin L. Cardin of Baltimore and Casper R. Taylor, Jr., Speaker of the state House of Delegates. Ellen R. Sauerbrey, the Republican who lost in 1994 after campaigning on the promise of a 24 percent cut in personal income taxes, is expected to try again.
Mr. Glendening brushed off suggestions that he might face a challenge from his own party. And he defended his economic plan, which also includes new tax credits for small-business owners who create jobs and for any business owner who hires a disabled person and a faster review for environmental permits.
"The Maryland economy is doing very, very well," he said, citing record sales tax revenues and a high employment. The one major drag, he added, is its sluggish job creation. Ranking 46th among the states, Maryland has been adding jobs at no more than 2 percent a year.
But even if Mr. Glendening's tax package wins him wider support among voters, critics say this is not the time for a state like Maryland, which has struggled to emerge from the 1991 recession, to offer a large tax cut. They say that even though Maryland has saved money by changing its welfare system long before Congress acted, and by moving Medicaid recipients into managed care, the state must be prepared for more costs the new Congress might shift to the states and for the possibility of a national economic downturn.
"I don't know how the state can afford it," said Thomas V. Miller, president of the State Senate, a Democrat who represents a tobacco-growing region of southern Maryland. "We're in good financial shape right now; we've balanced our budget. But we're one of those Middle Atlantic States that has been very slow to come out the last recession. I doubt very seriously we can afford such a proposal now."
Brian Roherty, executive director of the National Association of State Budget Directors, said that despite legislation in 19 other states to cut personal income taxes in the 1997 fiscal year -- most of them smaller cuts than the Maryland proposal -- fewer states were likely to pass such initiatives over the next few years.
Cutbacks by the Federal Government could create "structural problems for the states" at a time few of them are interested in raising taxes, Mr. Roherty said. "Over the next five years, it's going to be very tough for them to find trade-offs," he added. "For most states, this is not the time to cut taxes to make a negative adjustment on the revenue side."
Still, Mr. Glendening is trying to sell his economic package as the way to improve Maryland's business climate, save families hundreds of dollars a year through a tax cut and, of course, cut down smoking. "The tobacco tax is the essential component of the plan," he said. "Even if it didn't help offset an income tax, I believe it's the right thing to do."

HEADLINE: Greater Than the Sum of Its Parts;
The Marriott Prospers as Three Separate Companies

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md.

 BODY:
If the experience of the Marriott hotel empire is any guide, the best way for a company to prosper may be to break itself apart.
Marriott has thrived ever since it split in two three years ago. But unlike most of the other Fortune 500 companies caught up in a recent tidal wave of corporate breakups and spinoffs, Marriott was not unloading a problem division or ridding itself of secondary activities that distracted it from its "core business." Instead, the hotel empire orchestrated the breakup as a way of bringing greater focus to its operations. 
 And so, while Westinghouse heaves a sigh of relief over shedding its industrial enterprises, and AT&T slices off a computer maker that bled it of billions of dollars, the new Marriott International property-management company and Host Marriott hotel chain, both independent entities of the now defunct Marriott Corporation, could not be chummier.
Despite a revolt by bondholders over the original breakup plan, the strategy has paid off, largely silencing its critics -- and perhaps exceeding its authors' wildest expectations.
Independence has bestowed a new nimbleness on the two Marriotts in pursuing their separate interests without diminishing their ability to pool resources in pursuing common goals. Indeed, these days questions about the companies -- which share a headquarters building, some staff members and the overarching guidance of the Marriott family -- center on whether their relationship is too cozy, and how they would behave if the interests of their shareholders did not coincide.
Having jettisoned most of its debt, which had been the old Marriott's stumbling block to expansion, Marriott International Inc. has roared ahead, buying 49 percent of the luxury Ritz-Carlton chain, franchising the Marriott name at home and abroad and signing many lucrative contracts to manage properties.
The Host Marriott Corporation, meanwhile, has sold off dozens of limited-service hotels and now owns 77 full-service hotels, most of them bought at bargain prices -- and most of them managed by Marriott International. Today, Host Marriott is one of the nation's biggest property owners, with assets of more than $4.4 billion.
"We think Host Marriott is the best vehicle available to investors looking to put their money into first-class and luxury hotels in major markets," said Mark Mutkoski, senior lodging analyst at BT Securities, "and that's the sector we think will remain insulated from significant new competition." He added that Host Marriott did "an incredible job buying high-quality assets at lower prices than its competition."
The breakup of Marriott worked so well that Host Marriott could not resist a repeat performance last year, spinning off the Host Marriott Services Corporation, which operates and supplies hundreds of food and gift shops at airports, travel plazas and stadiums.
Investors who have stayed the course have reaped a bonanza. Michael A. Stein, Marriott International's chief financial officer, estimates that stock in the old Marriott Corporation that sold for $8 to $9 in 1990 is now worth more than $70 in the form of shares in the three new companies. Similarly, the stock market capitalization of the three Marriotts now exceeds $10 billion -- with Marriott International accounting for more than $7 billion of the total -- compared with about $2 billion before the split-up.
"That performance is nothing short of extraordinary," said Bjorn Hanson, the chairman of hospitality services for Coopers & Lybrand. He added, though, that the success of the breakup resulted more from the recovery of real estate prices "than anything unique about the way it was restructured."
If anything, the prospects for the Marriotts are brightening. Joyce Minor, vice president for equity research at Lehman Brothers, recently raised her 1996 earnings estimate for Marriott International to $2.23 a share, from $1.87 in 1995. For Host Marriott, Ms. Minor predicted an increase in earnings before interest expense, taxes, depreciation and amortization -- an important measure for any company with a heavy debt load -- to $425 million from $311 million.
The biggest beneficiary of the stock surge has been the Marriott family, which controls the empire through its ownership of roughly one-fifth of the shares of the three companies, holdings worth about $2 billion and spread among more than two dozen descendants of the empire's founder, J. Willard Marriott. Power in the organizations is wielded by his two sons. J. Willard Jr., known as Bill, the first among equals, is the chairman of Marriott International and also serves on the boards of Host Marriott and Host Marriott Services; his younger brother, Richard, is the chairman of Host Marriott and also serves on the other two companies' boards.
The family connections and functional overlap assure a unity of purpose at Marriott that is largely absent in other corporate divorces.
Committees from Marriott International and Host Marriott discuss possible acquisitions at weekly meetings, and Marriott International manages most of the Host Marriott hotels.
The two companies have made joint investments in several big properties, including a 600-room Marriott hotel at the Mexico City airport and a 300-room Marriott hotel in downtown Mexico City. Also, Marriott International agreed to set up a $225 million line of credit to Host Marriott and to lend it $109 million for the purchase of the Philadelphia Marriott Hotel, which opened last year.
And after Marriott International bought the stake in the 31-hotel Ritz-Carlton chain last year (acquiring the rights to manage the properties and use the Ritz-Carlton name, but not any physical property), Host Marriott bought three Ritz-Carlton hotels.
In some ways, Marriott International and Host Marriott are more efficient as independent entities than they were when they were under the same management. Mr. Stein, the Marriott International financial officer, said the Marriott Corporation lacked the flexibility of its successor companies because its real estate side was often at cross-purposes with its hotel management side.
"The Marriott Corporation had always aspired to be the leader in managing and franchising, and its real estate ownership was incidental to that goal," he said. "When the real estate market collapsed, we ended up with great assets in a difficult market."
Moreover, he added, investors in real estate are not necessarily interested in investing in a management and franchising company, and vice versa. If the two sides are part of one company, he said, "it's a tougher sell when trying to raise capital."
For all their overlapping activities, officials of the two Marriott pillars have consistently stressed their independence. And analysts say the companies have been scrupulous in living up to their fiduciary responsibilities and in abiding by Federal conflict-of-interest statutes.
"They go right up to the limit, but they don't ever go over it," said one analyst, who insisted on anonymity. "The loans and terms of the deals between the two companies are very carefully constructed so no one can say they're unfair or unreasonable."
Nevertheless, analysts privately continue to raise "what if" questions. What if another management company appeared to be a better choice than Marriott International to run a future acquisition of Host Marriott? Which would Host Marriott choose? What if Host Marriott received an unusually generous offer for a hotel it would just as soon sell -- from a company that was likely to cancel or not renew Marriott International's management contract?
More broadly, what if other management companies approached Host Marriott with more favorable contract proposals than it received from its corporate partner? And what if Host Marriott decided to buy some of Marriott International's retirement communities, as it has indicated it might? Would it play hardball in negotiating for the lowest possible price?
"We have a strategic alliance with Marriott International, and from investors' point of view we've always represented ourselves as having that strategy," said Terrence C. Golden, the chief executive of Host Marriott. "Why would we go to another brand when there's a premium in occupancy and room rates being allied with Marriott International?"
Mr. Golden added that only two members of Host Marriott's seven-member board are in the Marriott family, that Host Marriott and Marriott International have "a separate set of shareholders almost entirely," and that the compensation of Host Marriott management is tied into the performance of the company.
"If it made more economic sense to go to another brand," he said, "we would be the first to do so."
 But that strategic alliance has, so far, benefited both companies. It seems especially to have energized Marriott International, which, unshackled from the old company's real estate concerns, has been expanding at a rapid pace.
Some rivals thought it was out of its league when it acquired 49 percent of the Ritz-Carlton hotels last year, because luxury properties require more personal attentiveness than even the Marriott full-service hotels and resorts.
But Marriott International formed a Ritz-Carlton company that operates separately from Marriott's other lodging brands, and its headquarters remain in Atlanta. Marriott has kept top Ritz-Carlton management in place, while combining the Marriott and Ritz-Carlton reservations systems, and leveraging on Ritz-Carlton's behalf Marriott's huge purchasing power (like buying $2.5 billion to $3 billion in food and related products a year for its own operations and those of its customers) and extensive food distribution system.
The result is that Ritz-Carlton's occupancy rate in the third quarter of this year is up 4.1 percent from the third quarter of 1995, to 76 percent, and revenue per available room (which the industry considers an important benchmark of performance) is up 15 percent, to $131, from $114 in the corresponding quarter of 1995.
Marriott International is also the largest operator of conference centers in the United States and is a major player in the time-share business, which sells part-time rights in vacation homes and apartments, and in retirement homes and resorts. With the number of Americans over the age of 75 projected to grow 29 percent in the 1990's, Marriott plans to add almost 100 more retirement properties over the next five years to its current stable of 68.
Overseas, Marriott International is adding hotels at a furious rate, with 24 opening this year and an additional 16 under development. Worldwide, Marriott manages more than 1,100 hotels, with a total of 221,500 rooms, and is well ahead of its goal of running 2,000 by the end of the century.
Marriott's founder started with an A & W root beer stand in Washington in 1927, and did not get into lodging until he built a motel in Arlington, Va., 30 years later. But that did not mean Mr. Marriott was uninterested in the trade, according to his son. "He just didn't like the debt that went with it," said Bill Jr., no fan of the stuff himself. "He lived through the Depression."

Canada Proposes Steps To Curb Tobacco Use
The Canadian Government began a broad anti-smoking offensive that would raise cigarette taxes sharply, ban most types of tobacco ads and restrict tobacco-company sponsorships of cultural and sports events. 
 Under legislation that goes to Parliament next week, outdoor advertising for tobacco would be banned, as would radio and television ads. Only ads in publications aimed at adults would be allowed. Separately, cigarette taxes in Canada's largest provinces are to be raised sharply. [Page A20.]
 
OPEC to Keep Quotas Steady
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to freeze oil production quotas at their current levels for a further six months, a decision it hopes will keep petroleum prices high despite Iraq's likely resumption of exports. [D11.]
 
Samsung Continues Fokker Efforts
Samsung of South Korea said that it would continue its efforts to buy Fokker despite a statement by receivers for the bankrupt Dutch airplane manufacturer that a takeover on the basis of its current plan was no longer possible. [D10.]
 
Lufthansa, Germany's national airline, said that its pretax profit fell slightly in the third quarter amid losses at its cargo unit and rising fuel prices. [D10.]
 
Stocks Rise in Germany and France
German stocks rose to a record close and French stocks also surged after comments by a policy maker at France's central bank pushed the dollar higher against the franc and the mark in European trading. But volume overseas was generally light as markets were closed in the United States because of the Thanksgiving holiday. [D12.]

Placer Dome Plans Acquisitions
Placer Dome of Canada proposed to buy Highlands Gold, a gold producer in Papua New Guinea, and the 24.6 percent it did not already own of Placer Pacific, which has interests in mines in Australia and Papua New Guinea. The transactions would have a total value of about $600 million. [D10.]
 
Philips Plans Cuts at 3 Plants
Philips Electronics said that it would revamp its television operations in Western Europe and reduce the labor force at three plants by half, eliminating 1,400 jobs. [D12.]
 
New Interest in Elf Aquitaine
Since France's largest oil company, Elf Aquitaine, was privatized, it has struggled to change the perceptions of many American investors that it is still dominated by the state and is unfamiliar with the ways of a competitive marketplace. But there are signs that Wall Street's mood is changing. In recent weeks, Elf's American depository receipts have surged to their highest point ever, breaking out of a five-year range. Market Place. [D12.]

French Truck Drivers Don't Budge
Striking French truck drivers refused to dismantle barricades blocking most main roads for an 11th day, rebuffing a Government-appointed mediator who had wrung concessions from their employers. [A4.]
 
Ski-Area Package Deal
In a new advertising campaign, American Skiing, which has expanded aggressively with the acquisition of a bigger rival, is attempting to promote as a group the seven New England ski resorts it now owns. Advertising. [D13.]
 
Nigerian Economic Panel Criticized
Despite skepticism from Nigeria's domestic opposition, Nigeria's military leader, Gen. Sani Abacha, is pushing ahead with an effort to spur economic change and enhance his political image. The Government announced the formation of a committee set up to find ways to raise living standards, but opposition groups criticized its composition. [A13.]

HEADLINE: Dismissal of Slovak Editor Called Setback for Press Freedom

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia, Nov. 28

 BODY:
When Tatiana Repkova was dismissed as editor in chief and publisher of an independent daily newspaper this month, many here viewed it as just another chapter in the continuing efforts of the Government of Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar to control the Slovak media.
Mr. Meciar's continuing contretemps with Slovak newspapers, his attempts to use the courts to stifle expression and his replacement of the heads of the State Television, Radio and News Agency with his own political allies have been so notable they have drawn criticism from Washington and West Europe. 
 But Ms. Repkova's dismissal as editor of Narodna Obroda, a newspaper owned by Slovakia's biggest private company and largest export earner, was different from the previous incidents.
Ms. Repkova was trying to create something never attempted before in Slovakia: a truly independent daily newspaper tied neither to the Government nor to the opposition.
Ms. Repkova, 38, took over the failing Narodna Obroda, a general interest newspaper, last December and won an agreement from the owner, the VSZ steel mill, not to interfere in editorial content.
She had previously proven her skills as the founder and editor of Trend, an economic weekly that in three years became a must-read for Slovakia's growing number of entrepreneurs and business executives.
The steel mill officials seemed to believe that Ms. Repkova could deliver on her pledge to convert Narodna Obroda into a daily business paper that would appeal to executives and turn a profit. They appeared to respect her credentials, which included four journalism fellowships in the West, including the United States.
Last month advertising revenues at the paper were almost double those of October last year.
But then politics got in the way. The directors and major shareholders of VSZ are close to the Government, and include the Minister for Transportation, Alexander Rezes.
Earlier this month, while Ms. Repkova was in the United States, the newspaper ran a report on the front page from the state-run Slovak Press Agency. The report was taken from the Russian newspaper Izvestia and said Mr. Meciar was ill with a brain tumor and would be going abroad for treatment. Speculation about Mr. Meciar's health has been rife since he disappeared from public view for nine weeks this spring.
Ms. Repkova said she agreed with the chairman of the steel mill, Igor Grega, that a follow-up story was needed to question the validity of the Russian sources. After that story appeared, Mr. Grega also demanded that an apology to Mr. Meciar be printed in the newspaper. The apology appeared without Ms. Repkova's knowledge.
When Ms. Repkova returned to the newspaper, she asked for reassurance that there would be no further editorial interference. Ten days later she was dismissed as editor and publisher, although no reason was given, she said. Ten of the paper's 40 journalists, including all of the six new editors, have quit in protest.
One editor who is leaving, Lubos Jurina, said he believed that Prime Minister Meciar was in contact with the steel mill board over the newspaper's policies. "The fact is one of the owners is a minister, so there must be contact," he said.
Ms. Repkova said that for the time being she had given up on the possibility of a independent newspaper in Slovakia.
"I've tried twice and to do it again would need an independent owner, a patient owner and a talented team of journalists," she said. "None of these are available at the moment."
