HEADLINE: Hundreds Block Spain's Embassy in Cuba to Protest 'Meddling'

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Nov. 28

 BODY:
A dispute between Cuba and Spain over Cuba's assertions that Madrid is meddling in its affairs grew more tense today as construction workers backed by the police blocked streets around Spain's Embassy here for a third day.
Only a few people on specific business were allowed through the cordon of hundreds of workers that ringed the colonial-style embassy. The police moved the crowd, which had been 500 yards from the embassy, to within 200 yards on Thursday so traffic could pass on nearby streets. 
 The confrontation followed Cuba's announcement that a new Spanish Ambassador was unwelcome because of Spain's criticism of Cuba's Government, and comes days before a Spanish resolution calling for political liberalization in Cuba is scheduled to go before the European Union.
Spain, which ruled the island until the turn of the century, was Cuba's closest friend in Europe under the former Socialist Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez.
But the rift between the two countries has been brewing since May when Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar, a conservative, took office in Madrid. Mr. Aznar's references to Fidel Castro as a "dictator" and demands for political reforms on the island have infuriated Cuban officials. He has also cut Spanish aid to the island nation.
The President of Cuba's Parliament, Ricardo Alarcon, denounced the Spanish Government on Thursday, while the Communist Party newspaper Granma, Cuba's only daily, suggested Spain was damaging its economic interests on the island.
Spain has the largest share of foreign investments in Cuba, followed by Canada.
The domestic Cuban press agency quoted Mr. Alarcon as saying that Mr. Aznar's Government contained people "with a racist and colonialist mentality."
"It is unacceptable that at these levels there are politicians who want to treat Cuba as a slave nation," he was quoted as saying in the eastern city of Santiago on Thursday.
Granma contended that Spanish officials had contacts with anti-Castro Cuban exiles in Miami, and suggested the Government was harming Spanish interests to favor the exiles.
Granma noted that Spain has tried to play a leading role in economic and cultural relations with Cuba, but that now, with United States backing, it was trying to "again convert Cuba into a U.S. neo-colony."
Late on Monday, the Cubans announced that the new Spanish Ambassador was unwelcome, citing statements by Mr. Aznar and the Spanish Foreign Minister, Abel Matutes, and by the diplomat himself.
Even when Spain was under the dictator Francisco Franco, "relations were never as strained as they are now under Aznar," said John Kirk, a political specialist amd Cuba specialist at Dalhousie University in Canada.
The clash with Spain holds risks for Cuba, which built widespread sympathy in Europe against the United States economic embargo of the island.
The confrontation has at least briefly overshadowed European opposition to the Helms-Burton Act, which seeks to punish many foreign companies dealing with the island.
The Cuban Foreign Ministry spokesman, Miguel Alfonso, tried to smooth over the dispute on Thursday, telling reporters that the two nations "are in the most total serenity" over their dispute.
Mr. Alfonso also said that the Government-organized workers ringing the Spanish Embassy were there to protect the mission, where asylum seekers tried to force their way in on Tuesday and Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Call for Weaker French Franc Helps Push the Dollar Higher

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the French franc and the German mark yesterday after another French official called for a weaker franc.
Jean-Pierre Gerard, a council member of the French central bank, was the latest official to suggest that the franc might be too strong. In an interview with the newspaper Le Monde on Thursday, he said devaluing the franc "may be necessary." 
 Mr. Gerard said the dollar was undervalued against the franc and that a correct rate for it would be 6 francs. The remarks helped push the dollar as high as 5.2320 francs. His remarks followed calls for a weaker franc earlier this week from another central bank council member and former president, Valery Giscard d'Estaing.
"The comments just reiterate that Europe is in need of a strong dollar to help its exports," said Paul Farrell, managing director of foreign exchange at Chase Manhattan Bank.
The dollar's strength against the franc also lifted the American currency against the mark and other European currencies.
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5387 marks from 1.5268 marks on Wednesday -- the highest level since Oct. 18 -- and to 5.2240 French francs from 5.1690 francs. Financial markets in the United States were closed on Thursday in observance of Thanksgiving, and trading yesterday was thin, exaggerating price movements, currency traders said.
Even with the recent calls from French officials, few analysts expect France to take any official action to weaken its currency. The governor of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet, said Mr. Gerard was speaking only for himself and that the Bank of France was "inflexibly committed" to franc stability. the Finance Minister, Jean Arthuis, also ruled out a devaluation.
With the French franc trading only 1 percent from its central parity rate of 3.3539 francs per mark in Europe's exchange rate mechanism, it is highly unlikely it will be devalued, traders said. Under rules for the grid, the franc can move 15 percent in either direction from its central rate.
"They're just trying to talk down the franc," not devalue it, Robert Katz, a currency trader at MTB Bank, said of French officials.
 Against the yen, the dollar continued to benefit from Wednesday's so- called Tankan report, which pointed to continued weakness in the Japanese economy and to continued low interest rates.
The dollar rose to 113.88 yen, from 113.33 yen on Wednesday.
"It will be a long time before they can do anything with interest rates," said Charles Spence, director of foreign exchange at Standard Chartered Bank.

HEADLINE: My Hospital, Dying a Slow Death

BYLINE: By Abraham Verghese; Abraham Verghese is the author of "My Own Country: A Doctor's Story of a Town and Its People in the Age of AIDS."

DATELINE: EL PASO

 BODY:
Every evening as I take the freeway home after a day of seeing patients and teaching medical students at El Paso's sole county hospital, I whiz by "Pill Hill," the area around Sierra Medical Center, where my colleagues in private practice work.
The locations of our hospitals epitomize our differences. My hospital, R. E. Thomason General, is down on the plain, just off the freeway, next to a cemetery, in the heart of a barrio of transmission shops, very-used-car lots, pawnshops and cheap motels. From the eighth floor of the hospital, a long tee shot would sail over the Rio Grande and into Juarez, Mexico. 
 Sierra, on the other hand, is north of the freeway, close to Scenic Drive, and has a magnificent view of the city below. Pill Hill is named for its concentration of doctors' offices, laboratories, radiology services and physical-therapy centers.
Until recently, the world of Pill Hill and the world of Thomason had not clashed. Both took care of two different populations. We tended the south-of-the freeway Medicaid and uninsured patients; it preferred the insured and private paying customers.
But that has changed. It is high noon in this frontier town, and our institutions are in a showdown. We are fighting over the Medicaid dollar. Managed care's success in pushing down medical costs has meant that for the first time the Medicaid patient pays as well as or even better than the patient who is insured through a health maintenance organization. For example, for a woman delivering a baby, Medicaid will pay an El Paso hospital approximately $1,800, which is close to what an H.M.O. will now pay for the same service.
Suddenly, Medicaid patients, who for decades were not so subtly turned away by other providers and sent to Thomason, are now desired by all.
It hardly seems like a fair fight. Sierra and the four other for-profit hospitals in town have all been taken over by either Columbia/HCA Healthcare or Tenet Healthcare, two national for-profit chains. These companies have deep pockets and no public accountability.
Thomason, on the other hand, is the only public hospital for a population of about 600,000. Like many other county hospitals across the country, it is overburdened with care of the poor. The 300 or so hospital beds at Thomason represent only 14 percent of the total hospital beds in the city. Yet by county mandate the hospital is required to provide medical care not only to Medicaid patients but to the 240,000 or so El Paso residents who have no medical insurance or Medicaid cards. These residents are medically indigent because they do not meet the income requirements to qualify for Medicaid or because they are illegal aliens or because there is simply not enough Medicaid financing for all who qualify.
Thomason manages to care for them, despite the unwieldy bureaucracy that oversees the hospital and in the face of the increasing resentment by homeowners over the rising property taxes that go to support it.
The price tag for indigent care is about $40 million annually. The property tax generates about $30 million. The difference is made up by Medicaid and Medicare patients, who constitute 40 percent of Thomason patients and who indirectly underwrite the care of the indigent by allowing the hospital to have certain services and specialists in place -- like neurosurgeons -- that would otherwise be unavailable.
It used to be that Thomason's childbirth unit, the hospital's only consistent moneymaker (most pregnant women are eligible for Medicaid), was so busy that the hallways routinely served as holding areas. But the number of deliveries is dwindling as pregnant women are courted away by the for-profit chains whose elaborate labor and delivery suites look like Scandinavian design showrooms.
If Thomason loses its Medicaid base but continues to serve the indigent, it cannot possibly survive. Predictably, the city commissioners have seriously discussed closing the hospital or selling it.
Of course, it is hard to begrudge Medicaid patients, once the pariah of the for-profits, their new-found popularity. But those without Medicaid will suffer. Their voices are not well heard, and those who speak for them are an old guard of community activists and do-gooders whose plaints sound numbingly familiar.
If Thomason is forced to close and if Medicaid dollars are cast across El Paso, the indigent will likely be passed down from one hospital to another.
There is a story by Thomas Carlyle about a poor Irish widow who goes with her three children from charitable institution to charitable institution. She appeals to them: "Behold I am sinking, bare of help, you must help me, I am your sister, bone of your bone, one God made us."
But those in the institutions reply, "Thou art no sister of ours." The woman ultimately collapses and dies of typhus, infecting 17 of her neighbors. At which point, the humane physician asks, "Would it not have been economy to help this poor widow? She took typhus fever and killed 17 of you."
The story is not about charity or lack of it; it is about vision. Let us remember that before the public hospitals were created, the care of the indigent depended on the largess of doctors and charitable institutions. In allowing county hospitals like mine to die a slow death, we could be returning to those days.

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (Kevin C. Pyle)

HEADLINE: Dow Up 22.36 in Light Day; Month Is Best in Five Years

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks rose in a shortened session yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average ended its best month in nearly five years.
Light trading and a gain in bond prices bolstered stocks. 
 The Dow rose 22.36 points, to 6,521.70, giving it a gain of 8.16 percent in November, the most since a 9.47 percent advance in December 1991.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.02 points, to 757.02, bringing its gain for the month to 7.33 percent, also the best since December 1991. The Nasdaq composite index rose 5.29 points, to 1,292.61, and advanced 5.82 percent for the month.
Some 150 million shares changed hands as trading ended at 1 P.M., three hours early. Advancers outnumbered decliners, 1,305 to 934. Trading was well below the New York Stock Exchange's three-month daily average of 421 million shares, and slightly above the 125 million registered on the day after Thanksgiving a year ago.
Retail shares gained, buoyed by the prospect of increasing consumer spending. Americans spent more ahead of the year's busiest shopping season, even though their paychecks barely budged last month, the Commerce Department said yesterday.
J. C. Penney rose 5/8, to 53 3/4; Sears Roebuck & Company gained 3/4, to 49 3/4, and Federated Department Stores Inc. rose 1/4, to 34 1/8. The toy maker Exx Inc. was among the biggest percentage gainers in United States markets as its class A shares soared 3 1/2, or 76 percent, to 8 1/8.
Consumer spending increased five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department said, as consumers paid more for services such as household insurance and recreation. Personal incomes rose less than one-tenth of 1 percent.
Though personal income was nearly flat in October, a strong job market, near-record levels of consumer confidence and a stock market rally "are going to bolster holiday sales, and, more importantly, sales going into 1997," said Dan Seto, an economist with Nikko Securities in New York. Unisys was the most actively traded stock in American markets. It rose 1, to 7 5/8, after Business Week reported it was a good buy and a possible buyout target in its Dec. 9 issue.
Among the day's gainers, Progress Software shares rose 3 7/8, to 20 1/8, after the CNBC television network reported that Microsoft might buy the company. Progress shares have lost 46 percent of their value this year.
Options to buy Progress at 20 in December tripled on the speculation. The option, known as a "call," rose 2 1/4, to 3, in trading of 923 contracts. On Wednesday, options to buy the stock at 17 1/2 in December doubled in trading of 212 contracts, five times the three-month daily average.
"With trading so light, wherever there is news the market tends to overreact," said James Miller, senior portfolio manager at Bartlett Capital Value Basic Fund, which oversees $2.4 billion. "We aren't seeing much today, but the bond market is helping."
Bonds gave the market a boost. Already at eight-month lows, yields slid further amid confidence that economic reports next week will bring more signs of slowing growth and tame inflation.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond's yield fell to 6.35 percent, from 6.42 percent on Thanksgiving eve.
Bank shares were helped by the falling yields. Banks are heavily leveraged, and moves in yields affect them more than other companies.
The Bank of Boston Corporation rose 1, to 70; the BankAmerica Corporation rose 3/4, to 102 3/4, and the Banc One Corporation rose 7/8, to 47 5/8.
Earlier yesterday, Japanese stocks retreated from early gains. The Nikkei index of 225 issues settled 15.18 points lower, at 21,020.36, a fall of 195.75 from last Friday's close.
In London, stocks ended higher, helped by continued strength in British Government bonds. The Financial Times Stock Exchange of 100 leading shares rose 7.8 points, or nearly two-tenths of 1 percent, to 4,058.0, up 39.3 points for the week.

HEADLINE: In a Quirky Market for Milk, Consumers and Farms Lose

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Consumers in much of the country are paying record prices for milk, cheese and many other dairy products. But that has not kept the milk prices paid to the nation's 150,000 dairy farmers from heading into a 25 percent free fall in recent weeks, even as retailers fatten their profit margins.
Such are the quirks in the patchwork of Government formulas and free market forces that these days drive milk prices. 
 The dairy markets have always been complex and, according to critics, prone to manipulation by the agribusinesses that stand between farmers and consumers. But life for farmers and consumers alike has now become more unpredictable, with Washington retreating from decades of policies designed to stabilize farm production and food prices.
"Farmers are about to get royally squeezed," said Robert Wellington, chief economist of Agrimark Inc., a large dairy cooperative based in Methuen, Mass. "The kind of price volatility we are seeing is the difference for many between profitability and losing the farm."
Such volatility is likely to become increasingly common in other farm sectors as well, according to many agricultural economists and farm state politicians.
"We sacrificed the ability of the government to moderate price swings on the altar of a free-market philosophy, and now we are seeing the consequences of that," said Representative David R. Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat, in a letter early this month supporting protesters seeking changes in milk pricing.
Urban consumers paid 12.1 percent more for dairy products last month than a year ago, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics -- more than triple the general inflation rate. That is also a sharp departure from the comforting experience of the previous five years, during which the 2.7 percent climb in 1992 was the biggest movement consumers saw in dairy prices.
It could have been worse this year, but milk shortages in the spring and summer rapidly drove wholesale dairy prices to such heights that many retailers did not dare pass the entire burden on to consumers. "There have been very few markets where we have been able to recover all our raw milk cost increases this year," said John Hitchell, manager of raw milk procurement for the Kroger Company, a Cincinnati-based supermarket and convenience store chain.
To rebuild their profits, Kroger and others now are holding on to higher prices as long as possible, even as costs fall. Consumers in some cities may already be seeing major price cuts in butter, the dairy product with the most volatile price. But which products will follow it down -- and when -- will vary widely from city to city, retailers say.
"There's quite a bit of variation in our prices depending on competition," Mr. Hitchell said.
The longer grocers hold on to high prices, of course, the more likely that consumers will cut back on dairy purchases, thereby putting added pressure on raw milk prices. That could end up accelerating the decline in the number of dairy farms, a relentless trend that started in the 1950's.
The pressures are most visible in Wisconsin, which calls itself American's Dairyland on its license plates but saw the bragging rights for highest milk production levels shift to California two years ago. The combination of smaller farms, aging farmers and rising real estate prices in many prime agricultural areas near cities makes it inevitable that the Upper Midwest and other older dairy regions like upstate New York will lose thousands of farms annually in the coming years.
But this year's roller coaster has shaken farmers well beyond the traditional dairy heartland.
"How can you plan for this volatility?" asked Walter Kessler, a dairy farmer in Galt, Calif., who is a board member of the California Dairy Campaign, one of many farm groups advocating changes in milk pricing.
The problems began with strong markets at home and abroad for American grain and a poor harvest last year of hay and other forage crops. Reserves were cut to the bone and feed prices skyrocketed this spring as poor planting conditions ignited fears that this year's crops would fall far short of demand.
"It was a classic Economics 101 situation," said Peter Vitaliano, chief economist of the National Milk Producers Federation, a Washington-based trade group.
Dairy farmers were forced to cut back on the quality and quantity of feed they gave their herds. The cows reacted to the cheaper diets by producing less milk on average. At the same time, herds shrank as farmers sold cows to raise cash.
Farmers were not the only ones scrambling to adjust to the soaring feed markets. Giant cheese producers like Kraft and Borden, ice cream companies and other major milk consumers bid aggressively for dwindling milk supplies to make sure they could keep supermarket shelves filled with their products.
Until the 1990's, they could count on the Government to buy buffer stocks of cheese, butter, powdered milk and other products in the spring when milk supply normally outstrips demand. Now, the only insurance is to build their own inventories.
Another contributor to the pressure for higher prices was continual if slow growth in the demand for dairy products, including milk itself. National dairy groups have invested heavily in recent years in advertising campaigns, notably the one featuring sports and entertainment celebrities like Kate Moss, Spike Lee and Cal Ripken Jr. sporting white mustaches of milk.
The winds began shifting in the summer as the outlook for current crops improved, sending feed costs down, while milk prices continued to rise. Dairy farming suddenly became very profitable and production began to expand by this fall.
That, in turn, led to a crash in cheddar cheese prices at the National Cheese Exchange in Green Bay, Wis., an obscure trading outpost where giants like Kraft and brokers sell surplus trainloads of cheddar to dairy cooperatives and other manufacturers on Friday mornings.
Anticipating more plentiful and cheaper milk, cheese makers decided to cut their inventories, and prices on the exchange began falling on Oct. 18.
That would hardly seem like a signal event to anyone outside the industry; the exchange handles less than 2 percent of the cheese market. But the Department of Agriculture uses its prices as a key component in a formula that is the benchmark for milk prices in most of the country. Nothing else, officials explain, provides as current and public a snapshot of the demand for cheese, which is the biggest manufacturing market for milk.
"It's like the jury system," said Richard Gould, the 74-year-old lawyer who serves as the exchange's part-time president and repeatedly reminds critics that the exchange never sought its pivotal pricing role. "It may have flaws, but no one seems to be able to come up with anything better."
Longstanding suspicions that the Green Bay market can be easily manipulated were fanned this spring by a University of Wisconsin study suggesting that Kraft Inc., the Philip Morris subsidiary that is the nation's largest cheese maker, had periodically sold cheese on the exchange for less than it could have received in the private spot market from 1988 to 1993. The study's authors theorized that because milk and other cheese prices were based on the trading at the exchange, Kraft knew any losses it incurred on the exchange would be recouped many times over by reducing the price it paid for milk and raw cheese in the open market.
Kraft, which controls 15 percent of the cheese market, scathingly attacked the university research. Among other things, the company said that those on the other side of the market were also huge enterprises that could hardly be expected to let any such attempts at manipulation succeed.
Kraft's view is endorsed by Mid-America Dairymen, a cooperative based in Springfield, Mo., with 18,000 dairy farmers and $3.7 billion in annual revenues. Mid-America has occasionally bragged to its members that it has driven the Green Bay market price upward by aggressive buying on their behalf. But its executives deny that such statements should be read as support for the charges that the market can be manipulated.
"The exchange reflects supply and demand," said Lonnie Spurgeon, chief operating officer of Mid-America.
Kraft and others say such views have been vindicated by Congressional hearings last May and an investigation by the Federal Trade Commission that concluded last summer that there were no antitrust grounds for proceeding against Kraft or anyone else in the industry. But that did not stop farmers from picketing and demanding changes in pricing formulas this fall as prices plummeted. Both Wisconsin and the Department of Agriculture are reviewing possible changes.
Many members of the dairy industry say the best hope for managing volatility lies with the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange's struggling initiative to create futures markets for milk, cheese and other dairy products. In theory, dairy futures trading would, at least, send public signals about where prices are headed and give both dairy farmers and customers better ways to limit their risks.
For now, though, eyes remain fixed on the National Cheese Exchange. The price for cheddar blocks stopped falling in mid-November, suggesting that farm milk prices could turn up as soon as January. But the only thing everyone is counting on is more volatility.
"People are still learning how to manage inventories when there are no Government buffer stocks available," said Paul Crist, vice president of dairy planning and analysis at Land O'Lakes, the big Minnesota-based dairy co-op.
